Everyone needs a copy of this book.  This book is a reference of how viruses take over your body and make you sick or kill you.The Spanish Flu in 1918 killed 100 million people worldwide.  This virus was virulent and caused bleeding very similar to Ebola.There are many herbal options to prevent and treat viral infections.  If you understand the process of how the virus invades and kills, you are prepared to take the appropriate herbs to survive.  It is simple.  There is no downside to taking herbs to treat viruses.  The herbs do more than kill viruses, there are many benefits to taking them.Do not wait until you have bad symptoms to take your herbs.  You can often knock out a virus in the first 24 hours if you are aggressive and take the right supplements.Viruses mutate.  You might already know that.  However, the author explains that some viruses mutate as they reproduce.  That means that you might have dozens of different strains of the virus inside you.  You can't wait for immunization to save you.  Even if you believe it would, they cannot possibly have an effective vaccine to save you when it is already mutating after it invades you.  There will be another strain coming shortly, which will probably be worse than the first round.My advice is to go through this book and pick the herbal remedies that address the most factors associated with viral replication.  Buy the supplements and have a big stock of them.I'm an herbalist and I'm recommending this book to everyone who will listen.  It offers insight into why viruses are so deadly and what to do about it.  It's a fascinating read.

This is the most thorough book on Hashimoto's I have found.  The book recommends you take strong probiotics.  If you take a regular probiotic, it only has a billion or so active units.  She says that you have hundreds of trillions of bacteria in your intestines and the small dosages are not enough to make a change.  She recommends using live foods like Kefir.  I started taking Coconut water Kefir and within days noticed a huge difference in how I felt.I am very grateful to this author for providing this information.  I drink Coconut water Kefir daily.  You can buy the cultures and make your own very inexpensively.  Each dosage of a tablespoon has about a trillion active units.  I drink 1/4 cup per day.  You can buy the Kefir culture powder, combine it with coconut water, leave on the counter for 3 days and you have your own inexpensive Kefir.  Each package of Kefir starter costs about a dollar.  Be sure to keep it cool, or the bacteria will die.You can also buy a starter bottle at your local health food store.  When the bottle starts to run out, make sure the white stuff on the bottom is not poured out.  Just add coconut water that has sugar in it, leave it out on the counter for 24 hours and put it back in the fridge.  You have just made your own Kefir, with trillions of active units.She says if there is one thing she wants you to remember from her book, it is that you need to take very high dose probiotics.  You will see your Hashimoto's and leaky gut calm down when you start to do that.

There have been relatively few printings of the Equinox until recent years. The original 1st Printing from a century ago, the Weiser 1972 2nd Printing, the 1978 3rd Printing, the 1992 4th Printing, the 1996 2-volume set (all Weiser), the Mandrake & Holmes hardback, the Mandrake and Holmes paperback. The most recent by-the-volume on-demand paperback and hardback editions have errors not found in the previously mentioned sets and are mentioned only because they are in-print and affordable, if not recommended.

This is the real deal, the mighty Zeppelin flying high over the BBC airwaves at the peak of their talents. True Zeppelin collectors have known about these recordings through off-the-air recorded fan tapes, and bootleg LPs and CDs for 40 years. This set is incomplete; Led Zeppelin – The Complete British Broadcasting Corporation Radio Sessions (Empress Valley EVSD-410/411/412/413) or Led Zeppelin – BBC Archives (Scorpio LZ-040171) are two bootleg sets (among others) that have all existing recordings, and the sound on them is for the most part excellent, if not *quite* as good as this, the legitimate release. But there are a lot more repeated numbers in those sets, this cherry-picks the best of the BBC archives. My only question is why did we have to wait over 35 years for a legitimate release of this material?

This is an astounding collection of materials concerning the original Bavarian Illuminati, its' complete initiatory rituals, its' knowledge lectures, more bona-fide, bedrock information on the *actual* rites and teachings of those Illuminated Seers than has ever before been published in English. Forget the 200+ years of disinformation and anti-Illuminati propaganda you have been fed, and learn the truth.This book could (and should) be compared with "The Masonic Magician: The Life and Death of Count Cagliostro and His Egyptian Rite", "Duncan's Ritual of Freemasonry," "Ordo ab Chao: The Original and Complete Rituals, 4th-33rd Degrees of the first Supreme Council, 33rd Degree at Charleston, South Carolina," "Secret Rituals of the OTO" (or "OTO Rituals and Sex Magick" if you can find it), "The Hermetic Brotherhood of Luxor: Initiatic and Historical Documents of an Order of Practical Occultism", and "The Complete Golden Dawn System of Magic" for a basic overview of the development of Secret Societies and their Initiatory Mysteries for the last 250 years (or so). The similarities between them all are quite as telling as their differences, and quite telling to the student of these Western Initiatory Schools. Highly recommended, especially in conjunction with the works previously mentioned (I have them all). It *is* very dry reading, not something that a casual reader will find engaging, but it is a wealth of material and information for those Initiates who seek the threads of "The Authentic Tradition" (as Jonathan Sellers and T. Allen Greenfield refer to them in their respective works) from the Knights Templar, the Rosicrucians, the Carbonari, and/or the Priesthood of Melchezidek.

This is a wonderful sounding overview of New Orleans Hot Jazz on Gold CDs. This goes from the earliest Jazz recordings in 1917, to 1945, by which time 20's Jazz Dixieland had begun a revival. If you are already a Dixieland affecianado, you probably already have much of this collection, but if you are just starting out, or purchasing this as a gift, it's a wonderful collection.

This is some Lower 9th Ward 1975 Funk as played by the Wild Magnolias Mardi Gras Indians, and it's some ballsy motherfunkin' R&B. Most people have never been privileged to hear the Funk layed down this thick. 40 years later, it's *still* Funky and it's New Orleans history in sound.

This is a Japanese made Laserdisc of the Walt Disney Movie "Song Of The South". Like many Laserdiscs of its time it has two sound channels that run different sound tracks, on this disc with the Japanese soundtrack in the right channel, the English soundtrack in the left channel. You may have to disconnect the right channel wire on the back of the player, if your Laserdisc player doesn't have a channel on/off button (later players don't) in order to hear the original soundtrack (in mono) unimpeded. All of the songs are Japanese subtitled. The Japanese subtitles are burned in the video data and not removable through a (cc) button on the Laserdisc Player's remote control. This is the only NTSC format release, the late 80's UK Videotape release is/was PAL format. All DVD releases currently sold are pirated copies of either this Laserdisc or the UK Videotape and are inferior.This Laserdisc WILL NOT work in DVD or Blu Ray Players. You must have a Laserdisc Player to play this disc. Be aware that Laserdiscs can be a perishable format, and some discs may experience degradation of data, or "laser rot." My copy is 25 years old and still works perfectly. This disc is expensive, expect to pay $50 minimum used in "good" condition, up to $200 for a mint/still sealed copy (this is a collectable item that is still in demand).
This is the rerelease of an LP compilation of VU material from 1970. There's nothing new here, but some completists will still want it.

The author sounds a bit ambitious, but this single volume covers more of the Occult Arts and Sacred Mysteries than just about anything else in the past 100 years. Be sure and certain to get a copy published by the Philosophical Research Society, those alone are reproductions of the original and include all of the black & white as well as color plates (which are often missing or shrunk to the point of obscurity in the unauthorized on-demand press editions, and even the authorized paperback). It is true they are more expensive, but a good investment for any Occultist or Rosicrucian's home library.

The first two and a half discs are material we've largely heard before, abiet remastered from the previously released "Deluxe Edition; Everything on disc one is duplicated from "The Deluxe Edition". The only track on the 2nd CD that *may* be different is the "I'll Be Your Mirror". On disc three there are five Nico/Cale/Reed tracks from "Chelsea Girls" and "The Marble Index" that are not found on "The Deluxe Edition". If you don't have these Nico CDs already, you really want to get them here. Disc four is the fabulous Scepter Studios disc, one copy of which was found in a used record bin by a collecter in NYC for a couple of bucks-- the only other known copy was found in VU Drummer Mo Tucker's private collection, and that's the copy that's used here, it's sound is quite superior to the other copy. The last two CDs chronicle the long bootlegged  Melody Laughter (Live At Valleydale Ballroom, Columbus, Ohio / 1966) and bring it up to a much more listenable experience.

Keyhole Records has let us down a bit with this release. This recording has been run at the wrong speed for 30 years, and it wasn't fixed *here* either.The Bataclan gig was legendary, bringing Lou, Nico and John Cale together for a mini-VU reunion. The material covered is from the two movie soundtracks Nico did with Cale and Reed, and the VU's 1st LP. I first started seeing LPs of this on import lists in the back of "Trouser Press" in 82-83. This *is* a field recording. If you are not familiar with previous Keynhole CDs, or other live Velvet Underground bootlegs be warned: Keyhole cannot make a silk purse out of a sow's ear, although they can do some amazing wizardry with noise reduction and sound form manipulation. I wish they'd fixed this recording's speed though.

Imagine Hell-Boy written by Meth-Shooting Biker Trash, filtered through the Past/Present/Future of Bill Burroughs "Place Of Lost Roads." "Checks", the Checkered Demon, wanders through a world of Space Pirates, Motorcycle Gangs, Butch Diesel Dykes, large-breasted barmaids. The Checkered Demon made his debut in "Zap Comix" in the early 70's and has continued on unabashed and unabated. This collects the first 20 years or so of The Checkered Demon. No taboo goes unbroken, this book is guaranteed to offend!

This appears to be a single chapter of the much larger book "Ophiolatreia: A History of Snake Worship" by Anonymous (Hargrave Jennings), a very interesting and informative 19th Century volume by one of the leading Rosicrucians of his time. Buy the whole book in a cheaper paperback, you'll be much more satisified.

Documentary? There was a documentary? I went straight to the special features to see the Miami Pop Festival show, the New York Pop Festival, bootlegged as "Rescued From Randall's Island" and footage from Jimi's "Isle of Ferhman" synched to the tunes. I have to give credit where it is due: these shows are good, or even great, and it's nice to see them compiled like this instead of pieced out a show at a time.

Jeez! I hardly know where to begin. I appreciate that this is the first Syd Barrett compilation that includes both his solo work and some of his work in the Pink Floyd, but some fresh material would have nice.It's not like there aren't unreleased tracks: This would have been the PERFECT place to put the demo tapes of "In The Beechwoods" and (maybe) "She's A Millionaire", the Jenner mixes of "Scream Thy Last Scream" and "Vegetable Man", the Pink Floyd BBC performances from 67-68 with Syd... but NOOOOO! We get Gilmore belatedly laying new bass tracks on a 40-year old track and remixing some other existing tracks. Not to say that some of these tracks couldn't have used some smoothing out prior to their original release, but the warts 'n all nature of "Opel" and the Peel BBC sessions are part of their charm...Supposedly, if you buy this CD, you can download an MP3 of Syd's "Ramadan" a 'lost track' from the "Madcap Laughs" sessions, but I see NO mention of this in the product description-- the *only* really 'previously unreleased' track associated with the whole CD; but previous descriptions of that track by the few who have heard it indicate that it's little more than an extended rhythm/drum composition, not a "song" with a tune or lyrics. However, that requires one to have a CD driver/player, more and more computers (like the one I'm writing this from) don't *have* a CD Drive.The cover is credited to Storm Studios, which I can only presume is Storm Thorgerson. It's pretty lame. I don't know who did the booklet paintings, but they aren't done by Syd, which makes one wonder what the Hell they're doing here. Syd was an artist who has many paintings that could have/should have been included here instead these incongruous illustrations that do nothing but take up a few pages of booklet.I really can't think of who this CD was made for-- Syd's dedicated fans already *have* all of this material, and a perfectly good solo compilation, "Wouldn't You Miss Me?" was already released a decade or so ago. This doesn't add much to Syd's corpus.

For Christmas, I got the blackstone pizza oven as a gift. I love it. My wife loves it. My kids really love it. We have really loved experimenting with different pizzas and flavors. The only downside to the pizza oven is it didn't come with this cover. Fortunately. the cover they made for it is really nice and under $50.The cover is a nice high quality stiff canvas. It easily slides over the oven. There are two elastic bands that go under the left and right side table. These help hold the cover on, even in a VERY windy environment. It also covers all of the oven area, but leave the bottom shelf exposed.Again, obviously I wish this was included in with the pizza oven. But even still I think that this is a must have accessory.

I have been purchasing these apple chips through amazon's subscribe and save for a few years. About every three or four months a box of granny smith and caramel  apple chips show up at the door. With the subscribe and save discount, we pay about $1 a bag.I really like the chips. It feels like you are eating a healthier snack then regular chips.... though OBVIOUSLY not as healthy as just eating an apple.What I find frustrating, is they assume that this bag has 2.5 servings. Typically I don't look at that while I eat a whole bag myself. I will say that often times my wife and I will mix a bag of granny smith with a bag of caramel apple. The sour and the sweet make a nice balance of flavors.Every now and then you will find an apple stem in the bag. That is the sign that they are using real apples.So while they aren't the absolute healthiest snacks availible, they are far better then most of the snacks down the chip isle.

A long time ago, in a house far far away..... before we had a cordless or even multiple phones in the house..... there was one phone.Typically it was in the center of the house or in the kitchen. And it had a 50ft cord so you could stretch it as far as possible and hopefully go into every room in the house. Ahhh, those were the days.Should you have a phone you want to mount on the wall, this 8 inch cable will let you do that without having much extra wire behind the phone.These type of phone cables are pretty basic, they either work or they don't. When I plugged it in, the phone immediately worked.I purchased this from amazon for under $5. It could be possible to find it in a local store for less. But I didn't feel like going to walmart or radio shack and dealing with it. Instead I clicked the "buy it now with 1 click" and it showed up 2 days later.

I had high hopes for this access point. Xclaim is a division of Ruckus, one of the best WiFi manufacturers that exists. Most people probably have never heard of Ruckus because they are focused on the enterprise.The plan for the xclaim division is to sell a consumer friendly version of their amazing hardware. To help reduce costs, some of the higher end features have been removed.Initially, the only way to configure xclaim hardware was to use an app that ran on either IOS and Android devices. After many complaints, they recently added the ability to configure it via a web browser. Although if you started setting it up on an android device you couldn't also use a web browser.... it was either one or the other.While I am very comfortable setting up wifi and networking devices, i found this product to still be half baked. Fortunately, future software and firmware updates will be able to resolve a lot of these issues. And Xclaim is being very proactive to do just that. While my initial rating is only three stars, I plan on revisiting this device when they have worked out some of the kinks. At that point I will update this review.

Let me say upfront that typically, Typically, I don't like these types of cases. They take a beautiful thin device like the iPhone and wrap it up with a much thicker box. My preference is a much thinner case. But while that works for me, that might not be best in all situations.For some people, there is a strong need for a case that not only covers the iPhone from small accidents, but also protects from far more severe damaage like dropping it, to even protection from the natural world. If your phone needs full protection, the Lifeproof case should be high on your consideration list.According to their website, the life proof case is designed to protect your device from water (surf, swim or soak), dirt (including dust, sand, grit and mud), snow (snow, ice and sleet) or even shock (built to exceed stringent Military Specifications for drop protection).Of course with this protection does come some concessions. First, while they claim that this case lets you have full use of the touch id, I found that the results were spotty, I would say that less then 50% of the time it worked.Second, the case is designed to use the actual screen of your phone. Let me say that again another way, this case does not protect your screen. So with all the other protection this case offers, Should your iPhone land screen first onto something.... you could have extreme scratches or a shattered display.Finally, the case isn't cheap. $90 MSRP. At that price you have to ask if you really need your device life proofed.Personally, I don't think that I am the target market for this case. But if you need to use this device in extreme enviornments, or are prone to accidental damage, this might be the best case for you
Never got to use them as they are sized WAY too big. If you order these, choose a size much smaller then the size show your kids wear.

Not sure if it was the ones we got or the entire brand, the back near the draw string riipped  after taking them off the first time. Didn't even get to used them as the ripped while trying them on. Sent them back.

These shoes are junk. We purchased them to wear at a waterpark. Shortly after getting there, we took the kids into the lazy river. Got out 20 minutes later only to realize the sole was coming out of the shoe. Apparently, the glue they used in them falls apart in the water. Total Fail. We had 2 pair of these shoes, and had identical experience with both.AVOID THEM!

I purchased this softball to use with my yongnou flash. I am very impressed with the results they get. I have a sony A7II camera and use the yongnou trigger. Between the flash, the trigger and this softbox, it only set me back $225. Quite a deal.This softbox perfectly defuses the triggered flash to get amazing results. It is very easy to set up and I have it mounted on a tripod stand. For the cost, I highly recommend it.

This flash is nearly identical to the Canon speed flash 580II..... except one BIG one.... the price. I have been using it for a while now and it is extremely reliable. But if it breaks, no problem, I'll buy a second. And should I need to do that it will still be over $350 less then just one canon flash.Honestly, my guess is someone for yongnou snuck into canon's  office, and stuck out with the blue prints for their flash, It looks nearly identical right down to the font they used on the front of it. It is like you are getting the Cannon flash for a tenth of the price. I purchased this with the remote trigger by yongnou (YONGNUO YN560-TX for Canon Flash Transmitter). They pared near instantly, and never have a problem communicating. It was under $50, which means you can get both a flash and remote trigger for less then the cost of just a set of triggers. With quality and reliability like this, Yongnou is posed to turn the photography world on its head.Don't think, just buy both of these. You will than me later.

Can I let you in on a little secret. I am a man, with kids, and tried this tan in a can. I typically wear shorts year round. In the summer, I get a pretty decent amount of color. But when it is cold out, and the color has faded away, sometimes my legs can look a little too pale.There is a little odor to it, and I would highly recommend that you wash you hands well after you are done. That said, it goes on pretty easily and just a small amount tends to do the trick. I would highly recommend starting with a light application the first time. Also make sure that you blend it our all over to give a uniform coat. The color lasts a few days. The trick is to do light applications to build up a little color.... rather then go from pale to copper all at once.My wife laughed at me when I told her about this. Well, since it has been really cold out lately and she noticed that I was a little darker, it wasn't like I could keep it a secret to her. So we had our little chuckle... well.... there was more laughing by her then me to be honest.I am still on the fence about this. I will say this is purely a vanity product. It isn't something you need. And more importantly, it may not be the right product for everyone. Should you want a little color without the ability to spend time in the sun, give this a try, it may help you get get through the last of the winter.

Even though I am an adult, I find that I do enjoy candy now and then. Having eaten my fair share of both juicy fruit gum and starburst over the years, I decided to give this gum a chance.It tastes just as you can imagine starburst to taste like. Though after chewing for a little while, it became a little too much for me and was spit into the trash. I think I lasted about 15 minutes. Truly, I think I am not the market that juicy fruit is going after.My kids on the other hand loved it. Not a piece offered to them was wasted. In fact they have regrettably asked me to get them more of it. One thing that is a bit nice is it is sugar free... though lets face it, even if it isn't sugar,  they have to be using something to sweeten it up.If you are debating trying this my advice is this: if offered gum would you rather have something like cinnamon or mint; or are you a hubba-bubba type person. If you said choice one, look elsewhere. But if you enjoy the fruity-fruit, hubby-bubba, silly gums, you will probably really enjoy this too.

This game is based on the 1996 Tim Burton movie of the same name. What I loved about that movie it unapologetically killed characters left and right. All the while the aliens had that same goofy look on their face. While it isn't going to win any movie awards, it is a funny movie to watch should you be in the right mood. Since then topps has also created trading cards based on the movie.The point of the game is to kill off all of the poor helpless citizen of earth.  You need at least three players for this game. Basically,  game is played by rolling the dice and hoping to destroy cities. There are three different symbols that can come up when you roll: ray guns, martian heads and nukes. After you pick a city card to attack, roll all of the dice. To conquer a city, you need to roll a certain number of ray guns. Should you get a martian head, you may choose to roll only those dice again. Roll enough nukes and your turn is over. Once enough ray guns are rolled, the city is conquered.There are other elements that make the game interesting. For example some city cards have special rules that come into play come into play once the city is defeated. Also, there are monument cards (like grand canyon) that are defeated by rolling enough martian heads instead of ray guns.So how do you win the game? Each city or monument card has a specific number of victory points. The harder to defeat that card, the more points. The person at the end of the game with the most points wins. The game takes about 20 minutes to play.My kids and I like to play this game. Since it is fairly quick paced, we can play a few times in an hour. Also, since most of what you are doing is rolling dice, it isn't too hard to coach my younger kids while playing. The premise is pretty straight forward and it is not only easy to understand but quick to learn. And even though it isn't too hard to learn, it is also enjoyable to play with just adults.

My wife is a huge fan of Melissa and Doug toys. While they do tend to be a little more expensive, they are always really well made and will last a lot longer then the cheap plastic toys that seem to be too common. We have purchased quite a few toys made by M& D and have never  been disappointed. So with that, I decided to give this set of headbands and barrettes to two of my daughters. While they are both pre-pre-teens, they have developed a keen sense of fashion.As the description mentioned, the set comes with 2 headbands, 6 barrettes, 10 decorative pieces, 1 sticker sheet, and 5 glitter sheets. The set is designed that kids can add their own bling to the headbands and barrettes. As a parent, one of my favorite parts is the mess free glitter. It is surprisingly, just that, mess free. And it was not only very easy for them to do themselves, it kept them busy for several hours. Further more, they willl use it for quite some time to come.If you have girls, and they are into hair, fashion etc, this would make a great gift for them. At under $13, it is slightly more expensive then just buying headbands and barrettes. But seriously, for what it is, and the quality and no-mess nature, the Melissa and Doug brand set a high standard for other brands to live up to. I am not only happy to endorse it, but I am thrilled to give it to my girls to play with.

This was my first time tasting pejoy biscuit sticks. They are a small snack to get your sugar fix without over doing it. While they are not my absolute favorite treat, they are pretty good. I would eat them again if other options weren't available. Probably the best part of these is they are under 300 calories. Taking this into account, my opinion of them does improve. Definitely check these out if you want to enjoy a tasty chocololate treat without feeling like you ate a mountain of sugar.

A keyboard, for the iPad?. On the one hand, I carry an iPad to liberate me from the complexity and bulk of a laptop. Yet on the other hand there are times that I really miss using a keyboard if I need to write a lot. If you find your self in this position, you may want to check out this keyboard case.As a little backstory, I have used a fair number of the different keyboards for the iPad. It always seems like you have to make sacrifices when using them. This case is no exception to that. But if you can live with some of those concessions, you may be looking at one of the better iPad keyboard cases.Lets get the cons out of the way. The first is it adds a bit more thickness and weight to the iPad. Not so much to be annoying, but definitely noticeable. Sadly it feels like it almost doubles the weight.Second, some of fit and finish feels a little cheap. Which is ironic, because other parts feel really well made. There is a high quality leathery feel cover but the keyboard side feels like it is more flimsy.Third, should you have large hands, you may struggle with the keyboard. It is quite a bit smaller then you standard computer keyboard. For many if not most people, this may not be a problem. But there are going to be other people who just have a hard time adjusting to the reduced size.Now that we have gotten those out of the way, there are many things that can be appreciated about this case.First it is fairly easy to get the iPad in and out of the case. I found that I take it with me when I travel, but keep it in my bag unless I need it. All other times I use a much slimmer case. For me, I only use the keyboard 25% of the time, so most of the time the added weight and thickness is a non-issue for me.Should the keyboard spacing not be an issue for you, this really is one of the nicest iPad keyboards I have used. It is very responsive and tactically, feels almost as nice as a regular keyboard. I have never found that battery life on it to be a problem. While welkin claims up to 160 hours of battery life, I typically get around 2/3rds that amount of time. Which is pretty good as the iPad only lasts 10 hours.So should you buy this? Well I think it boils down to this: Do you need to type a lot on your iPad? If yes, this is the one to put on your very short list. If you don't type a lot, then I wouldn't recommend it. As good as it is in this category, I could not help but feel that it wasn't the ideal way to use a tablet. For me, the truth is, if I have to type a lot, I prefer using a real keyboard connected to a computer. But since everyone is different, and there situation is unique, for others, this may be the ideal setup.

I gave this to my young nephew. Lately he has developed a real fascination with pirates. So I figured he would enjoy this set.The included pieces are nice. They aren't too small for his young hands. Basically, you have outfits that you can put on either pirate. There are pants, shirts, and headwear to create many dress variations. Also included are some traditional pirate accessories (monkey, parrot, map treasure chest, etc). This should give the basis for many pirate adventures.One of the pirates names is Capt Jack. Depending on your child, and how familiar they may be with the Johnny Depp version, this may be a little confusing. But this is more of a nit-picky type issue, and definitely not a con.The whole set comes in a nice transparent carrying bag. It should offer hours of creative fun play for little boys and girls.... and maybe even not so little.

At it's most basic form, this is just a towel. But with a little creative magic, one corner has been turned into a hat with cute eyes to make an owl. The sum of the parts turn a simple towel into something fun that young kids enjoy using.We gave this to our youngest child. Sometimes bath time can be a little tricky. First she doesn't want to get into the tub (or shower). Then, when she finally gets in she doesn't want to get out. I am not going to lie and say that this towel has solved all of our problems..... but it does make it a little easier. She does love to use it. And it has made getting her out of the tub easier.... well just a little easier.The towel is a good quality. It isn't the best, but it is really nice. stitching and the accents are also well done. My only complaint about it, is it is nearly $20, which isn't too crazy priced, but seems to be at the top of the price range for this type of towel.Should you have a little one, or need to buy a gift for one, this should definitely be considered.

We got this is anticipation of spring. We have a fair amount of small brush and shrubbery in front of our house and it is always a challenge to keep it all looking clean. Granted the electric trimmer does a lot of the major pruning, but sometimes you need to cut specific pieces. These will do the trick. As advertised, they will cut up to 3/4 of an inch. You may be able to cut slightly thicker, though you run the risk of damaging the pruners.We tested them on a few small bush limbs that were sticking out, and were impressed with how easily they clipped without having to overly expert effort. A simple squeeze was enough force to go through most of the small branches of the bushes. We are definitely looking forward to using them more in the spring as all of the shrubs begin to fill out.Like similar products there is a lock at the top. Once enabled, the blades are locked closed. To disable to lock squeeze the blades and flip the switch. Should you need pruners these are definitely some to consider.

As a parent of 4 kids we have been through our fair share of toys and clothes and baby supplies. Something that you always need is a place for the baby to sleep. While we did have a dedicated room for each of our newborns, we found that it wasn't always the ideal place for them to sleep. This bed can help over come that.One of the core features of this bed, is the "rock'n" feature. Basically you put a d-battery into it and when you turn it on it gently vibrates the bed. As most people know when you hold you baby and pat or rub him, he will tend to stay asleep. But as then as soon as you put  him down and walk away, like magic, you baby knows you left and will cray for you to return. The vibration helps to simulate to the baby that feeling that you are still there. While it doesn't work 100% of the time, more often then not it is great.We had 3 previous versions of this bed. It was interesting to see the slight evolution that it has taken over there years. Most of it is minor design tweaks. The fabric seems nicer. Also, the batter is now easier to get in.We found that this was used, more often then not, as where our kids slept the first few weeks and even months. Primarily because of the vibration feature, but also because it is much easier to get a newborn in and out of this bed vs a traditional large crib. And lets face it, it is so nice to move this where ever you need it to be and you can even move it while you baby is asleep.The bed is sets up and fold up very easily. It is very lightweight and doesn't take up much floor space so it can be moved where ever you need it to be. Fisher-Price also makes this same sleeper with a few other options. First there are a variety of design patterns. Some are more playful, have stronger color combinations or look more like animals. Also, you can get it with or without the "rock'n" feature.This bed may not be for every baby. Should you baby have special needs you may find better solutions. But at least for us, we used these for many years and have loved them!

I don’t think there is any such thing as too many charging cables so I was happy to try this USB Type C Cable from LaoHe.This is a standard length (about 3 feet) charging cable. I love the long handle on this Exfoliating Bath Brush from Earth Essence because I can reach my whole back when I’m showering!This bath brush is on an 13” long wooden handle with a cord for hanging. I don’t have a pastry bag so I just cut a corner off of a regular storage baggie & used that. It worked just fine. I tried squeezing the frosting through every tip in the box. I’m not very good at it but it was a lot of fun & I’ll continue to practice until I’m able to make decent decorations. I also practiced writing with the icing & that is NOT as easy as it looks. I need to watch The Cake Boss some more to watch how they decorate their awesome cakes.This set would make a nice gift for anyone that bakes or likes to create custom cakes at home.As a product review blogger, I often receive products in exchange for my honest review. The opinions expressed are 100% my own based on my personal use of the product.

I love kitchen gadgets but I’ve never owned an Apple Corer before I got this one from Orblue.During this time of the year, I do a LOT of baking & since it is also apple season I use a lot of apples. I used to just slice the apples around the core & then chop them up to use in my recipes. This cool little gadget makes that job so much easier.The Apple Corer is 8” long & made of stainless steel so I never have to worry about rusting. The handle is made of hard plastic that is easy & comfortable to grip. There is a hole in the end of the handle so that it an be hung for storage. The end of the corer has a sharp serrated edge to help get the coring process started. I just push the corer against the apple & twist a bit to get it started, then push the corer through the apple, twist & pull it back out. The core comes right out. Easy peasy!I’ve used this apple corer multiple times since I’ve had it & I don’t know why I have never had one of these before!As a product review blogger, I often receive products free or at a deep discount in exchange for my honest review. The opinions expressed are 100% my own based on my personal use of the product.

If you have kids who ride their bike to school or leave their bike outside overnight, this Bike Lock Cable with Resettable Combination from Sanren will help keep it safe.The cable on this bike lock is 4’ long so it is easy to secure a bike to a bike rack at school or around a porch railing or carport at home. The combination is easy to set & reset. The steel cable is plastic coated so it won’t scratch your bike. There is also a mounting bracket to attach to the seat post so the cable can be stored there when it’s not being used.This cable bike lock will be a deterrent to a thief. The School Resource Officer tells the students that any type of security will most likely cause a thief to leave your bike alone & move on to another unsecured bike that is easier to steal. So this is not a lot of money to spend for peace of mind.As a product review blogger, I often receive products in exchange for my honest review. The opinions expressed are 100% our personal use of the product.

This grip is for those of us who bought the XT-10 because it is so very nearly equal to the XT-1 in so many ways that we couldn't justify the extra $500, but still secretly wanted a nice, big, grippy camera.  With my big hands, I would have actually preferred a slightly larger camera.  But there's no way I'm spending $130 on the Fujifilm grip. I mean...come on.  It's not even a battery grip!  I love my Fujifilm, but that price is just...well I'm at a loss for words. Pure profit.I DID however, take a chance on buying this unreviewed but solid-looking third-party grip.That chance paid off.  Big time.This grip is incredible for the price.  It's solid metal, a cinch to install and uninstall, and is thoughtfully designed with functional and precise cutouts and tripod mount built right in.  The grip makes the XT-10 feel entirely different - like a "real camera".  Not to mention, it makes my clients happier to see a big camera too, pour souls.  This is solid, smooth, precise, cold, pure metal straight from the machine shop.If you want to add grip tape to this solid, smooth hunk of metal, it would be a cinch.  Me, I like the cool aluminum against my hands.  It's never been slippery for me anyway.  It's also a flexible accessory that allows the guard/tripod-mount on the left of the camera to be removed easily with an allen wrench. This shrinks the package a little gives  The entire grip can, in fact, be removed with an allen wrench in about 10 seconds, or in a similar amount of time with a penny if you forgot the wrench. It's little details like that that show a thoughtful design that are the hallmark of a good product.My only complaints are minor and inevitable with a product like this. The SD card is just ridiculously hard to get to on the XT-10 in the first place - one of the few negatives with the camera.  This grip makes it slightly harder - but I blame that on Fuji, really, for silly card slot placement. Second, it makes the screen harder to rotate out, though you figure it out soon enough. Not a big deal.In short, if you didn't buy the XT-10 because of size, this is not only an economical way to improve it's handling, but it's also going to improve the longevity and resale value of your body by giving it protection on most sides, and especially on the bottom, where most wear occurs.  I'm very pleased with this accessory and I highly recommend it to any XT-10 shooters with larger hands.

My first Fuji, this is a wonderful camera, capable of taking professional photographs. It has features making it a good fit for advanced shooters and beginners alike. Both will appreciate the beautiful, best-in-class design, the accurate and bright screen and viewfinder, the smartphone integration, and the on-lens aperture adjustments and dedicated setting dials. The camera is truly fun to use and changing settings is a better experience than in any other camera system I've used (along with most of the Fujifilm X-series).For anyone around, this camera is a complete steal compared to similar competitors at $799 for the body alone.For advanced shooters, it has 7 customizable buttons, very clean images at higher ISO (i.e it's good on low light), strong lens selection, and multiple focus peaking and other manual focus assists.But those newer to DSLR style shooting will appreciate the comparatively straightforward dial layout, compact size - and especially the dedicated switch which kicks your camera into automatic mode so you don't miss a good shot while you're still learning how to use the camera in manual or other advanced shooting modes. The latter shows Fuji's true intent for this camera as an accessible professional tool for all levels of shooter. The JPEG quality is generally accepted as the best in any brand, meaning new photographers can still get great images without shooting in the confusing, large file RAW format (though RAW is available for those who like to heavily edit their images).I love this camera and I've made better images on it than on any other crop sensor camera I've used. Even in low light, it suffers relatively little compared to full frame cameras. I personally prefer its images to the crop sensor Canon and Nikon DSLRs I've used. Actually, it's not a contest in most ways.The exception is for those who shoot sports or wildlife, who might find the XT-10's burst mode to be a little slow and cut out soon. It's comparable to a Canon Rebel series camera in burst capabilities. It also isn't weather sealed, which is too bad. And for those with big hands (like me), it might seem a little small - though it's not uncomfortable to use and a grip can be purchased.But for anyone who doesn't need super-speed burst mode or weather sealing, the $500 you save on the XT-10 vs it's bigger brother is much better put toward lenses. It has the exact same sensor, focus abilities and a similar screen and viewfinder. It will give you exactly the same images.BUT THERES A CATCH WITH THIS BUNDLE: It's still a better deal than buying the lenses separately. But it could be significantly cheaper were the redundant, lower quality 16-50mm lens omitted. It's entirely unnecessary with the fantastic included 18-55 lens, which is faster, better built, and produces better images. The only advantage of the 16-50mm is a lower weight. Those few ounces aren't worth the added cost.

Pros: > Subtle, luxurious smell. There is nothing flowery, fruity or overwhelming about this soap. Scent is difficult to describe in words, but those that come to mind are woodsy" and even a little "spicy" or "middle eastern". The best part is that it's subtle.  My wife is very sensitive to smells, to the point that I can't use any of the big-brand soaps if I shower before bed. This just leaves me smelling clean and slightly manly.> Cleans thoroughly.> Rinses cleanly and quickly - no "sticking" to skin or in crevices.> Larger bar than usual, but still fits in hand.Cons:> Does leave a very slight filmy feeling on the skin, but it's better than most soaps. Almost any natural soap will have this problem.> Price. Obviously.

Like most everyone, I have usually use the clorox or lysol brands of cleaning and disinfecting wipes. I've liked them a lot, overall.  But they smell strongly and don't work on skin, so I was interested in trying these softy wipes out.  I primarily use these in the kitchen and bathroom, as well as for hand cleaning.  Here's what I've found:PROS:1) These smell great, and the scent is far more subtle than other wipes.  It's a scent smell rather than a chemical smell, and it doesn't linger on the skin or on surfaces.2) You can use these on your skin.  In fact, that's one of the primary uses of this product.  It's convenient to keep these in the kitchen to use while handling raw meat (though I prefer to use medical gloves for an even better experience). I'm assuming they sanitize just fine. Obviously, not having a bacterial culture lab in our 1 bedroom apartment, I can't verify this. They clean skin better than sanitizer alone, at least.3) They sanitize without drying out skin like alcohol.  I would have loved these back when I was a paramedic and had super dry hands all day.4) The cloth material is strong.  It's stretchy and hard to rip too.5) They do a decent job of cleaning grease and messes up in addition to sanitizing.  For a quick clean, they do fine.CONS:1) They don't clean messes as well as other brands. They do okay, but stovetop grease and such will take more than just one of these wipes. Lysol brand wipes certainly clean grease/oil-type stains more effectively. I can't go strait to the polish stage of cleaning greasy counters after using these wipes unless I use several of them.2) They leave film on surfaces they clean. So do other brands, but these leave a slightly more noticeable patina. This is not a big deal, especially if you use a little window cleaner afterwards. This is only really noticeable if you want a shiny gloss clean and on dark or metal surfaces. On white porcelain in the bathroom it's not a problem.3) The cloth tends to stick together. The wipes are a little hard to unfold to their full size sometimes. Not a big deal.4) They cost more - but not much more.5) Occasionally, it can be hard to pull just one out of the container. I end up pulling 2-3 out instead.

I bought this pan because 1) I'm clumsy and have broken glass bakeware in the past, 2) It has a raised lid, giving a little more room and flexibility, 3) I've had good experiences with other Nordic Ware products.It has not disappointed.  I'll make Pros & Cons list to keep things simple.PROS:1)  The pan is super lightweight.  Really, really incredibly light. Being a huge ex-football player that doesn't matter much to me, but it's nice anyway.2) Food has cooked evenly and consistently, and without fuss. Dark aluminum pans can require some temperature adjusting.  This doesn't.3) Food doesn't stick. Well, not anymore than with glass bakeware. It's never been a problem for me.4) There's no nonstick coating to wear away.5) The lid of the pan is raised.  This is really convenient, as taller casseroles don't get compressed by the lid as sometimes happens with glass bakeware.  It's good for decorated cakes as well.  But for me, the biggest advantage is that I used these to hold and transport cookies to work, my wife's classes, etc. The raised lid is a surprising but major advantage of this pan.6) It doesn't stain.  I've cooked lasagna and other super-staining meals in this pan, and it's cleaned with no effort at all to the original silver color.7) The pan is a few centimeters taller than many of its competitors, adding even more height and the resulting flexibility.CONS:1) It scratches. But who cares? And at least it doesn't have a coating that scratches away, meaning performance stays the same.2) Using metal serving utensils can make a weird kind of scraping feeling that occasionally gives me the shutters. Like some people get with nails on a chalkboard. My wife thinks I'm crazy - it doesn't bother her. Probably barely worth mentioning but...well, there you go.Overall:  If I buy more bakeware in the future, I will buy this pan over and over again.

You need a clear case for the Moto X.  Obviously. Otherwise how would anyone see how awesome it looks!This case is super-clear and fits like a charm, snapping pleasantly into place. The hard shell is less slippery than many, and it's survived a few short drops onto pavement, protecting the phone without cracking. It's easy to remove and replace if needed.  It's inexpensive and, best of all, sleek, hardly adding any girth to the phone.My only complaint is that it doesn't protect from drops at all angles.  It will handle most drops okay, but the top and bottom corners along the top of the phone leave some minor exposure.  I get that less plastic means a sleeker case, but I would compromise for 100% protection.

There is no such thing as "the" perfect smartphone since each individual uses them differently and will have different requirements or preferences. So before I get to the details, I'll let you know my own. I've used iPhones for most of my life, but recently got bored with iOS and went on a long, expensive, chronically and unreasonably dissatisfied hunt for more interesting phones in the Android world. I value a well-balanced phone with:1) Clean, quick, uncluttered software with a pleasing user interface2) A camera that can stand-alone as my one-and-only camera (low grain, great exposure, decent color reproduction, decent HD video)3) Premium build quality that can please an Apple-seduced ex-iPhoner (feel-in-hand is especially important to me)4) A bright, colorful, and sharp screen5) Full day battery lifeI also care about durability, prompt software updating, and accessory availability. I use the Sony Xperia Z3 as my go-to phone, and have also recently owned the iPhone 5s, LG G2, Google Nexus 5, HTC One M8, and Sony Xperia Z2. My wife uses the Samsung S5.I bought the Motorola Moto X pure, unlocked version through the Motorola moto-builder site. As a disclaimer got a Bamboo back and Blue trim, so be warned that while I've felt the leather in stores I had a very slightly different experience. I've used the phone for two weeks.Okay, on to the review!1) Software: 100/100.I've never awarded a 100% to any phone for any feature. Until now. Motorola and Google absolutely nailed it. First, you'll get the phone at Android 4.4 KitKat, but 5.0 Lollipop is already out for the Moto X and the phone can (and should) be updated immediately. Stock Android Lollipop is gorgeous, colorful, and adds many small changes that, when they come together, makes the software almost perfect. Props to Motorola for keeping the phone stock.The few features that Motorola has added (all found in one app) are genuinely useful. The Moto X has excellent voice-activated commands with a customizable command phrase that actually works consistently. It also knows where you are and adapts accordingly; whether you're driving, sleeping, in a meeting, or having family time, you can customize how the phone notifies you and interacts with you given your current activity. You get nice and customizable lock-screen notifications as well. This is the smartest smartphone I've ever used, by far. Also, Google Now is omnipresent and is a decently useful (if creepily predictive) feature.If you care about software above all, look no further. The Moto X is the phone for you.2) Camera: 83/100.Like the rest of the phone's software, the camera app is smart, pretty, and quick. You can flick your wrist twice to open the app, an experience that is quick, pleasing, and works consistently if you can remember that it exists. Though not actually Google's camera app, the camera software resembles it in its minimalism and de-cluttered UI, which I really like. Also, shutter speed is one of the fastest I've seen, rivaling the iPhone.So it's not all bad. And while I'd read poor reviews about the camera, I was willing to give it a chance. And note that my standards are very high.Unfortunately, though, the images I got were just not consistently solid. In bright outdoor light you'll get nice, colorful, decently sharp images. In any other light, however, images are often blurred, sort of grainy, and discolored. The phone lacks Optical Image Stabilization, and it shows. Though the camera is 13 MP, the images were much less sharp than on the 4 MP HTC One or 8 MP iPhones. If you compose the photo, you'll get a decent image half the time. If you don't, it's more like 1 in 4. And try as you might, you'll have to fight hard to get a really, really good image that you'll want to print. The flash (which, by the way, is not a ring but is just two LEDs) is bright but doesn't solve the camera's low light issues, producing red-eye and off-tone colors. Video is better, but not amazing.I'm honestly sad about this, but it was a dealbreaker for me personally. If you're no shutterfly and just need the occasional quick snap of pets or kids, the camera will do the job. If you're at all picky about images though, you'll be chronically dissatisfied. Sad, but it's the one-and-only true weak point on the phone.3) Build Quality: 96/100.This is a gorgeous phone. And the range of customization options (Soft leather? Warm wood? Either, please.) is nothing short of brilliant and will turn more heads more than any iPhone. The curved back feels great in the hand. The Gorilla Glass is smoothly rounded around the edges. The metal rim is eye candy and feels awesome, if a tad slick. The aluminum speaker and camera trim is nice, whether stock or colorfully customized on Motorola's site. Look, it's just a stunner of a phone, at least on par with the HTC One and Sony Xperia line with much more personality.4) Screen: 90/100.OLED (Organic Light Emitting Diode) screens are interesting. Instead of a backlight, each pixel produces it's own light, giving the screen a unique, warm, saturated feel. Coming from the ultra-bright Sony Z3's LCD panel, the Moto X was quite a change. Colors are bolder and more saturated, and much warmer. Browns and colors look great. And since OLED screens produce black by simple turning the pixels off, blacks are inky-dark and contrasting colors just pop beautifully. It's a nice screen, and the resolution at 1080p is as sharp as I could ever care about.My only real complaint is that the screen is dim, at about half the brightness of its competitors in nits produced (whatever a "nit" is, don't ask me). You get used to it fast and it saves battery, but coming from the brightest phone on the market it was a little underwhelming. I could get used to the rich OLED colors very fast though, and the deep black will certainly be missed.5) Battery life: 85/100.It's fine, but nothing to write home about. Android Lollipop saves battery well, as does the dimmer screen and well-done notifications. I'm a heavy smartphone user (ahem...addict), so I never get more than one day with any phone. This phone will get you through a workday, but if you're like me then you'll need a quick charge in the evening to get you through bedtime.Note: Invest in a Qualcomm Quick-Charge 2.0 charger, supported by the Moto X. Just do it. It blew me away! You get 35% battery added in just 15 minutes. Plug it in during your after-work shower and you'll have juice to make it through Friday night, no problem.Summary:If you're somehow still reading this, here's the final verdict. If you don't care too much about camera performance, or prefer a stand-alone camera, just stop and buy this phone. It's fantastic in every single other way and costs less than rivals. Personally, I'd go through the Moto Maker website for free customization if you can stand to wait a week for delivery. If software and UI matter most to you, you'll be smitten by the scrappy Moto X. And if Motorola can come up with a better camera, I'll buy future versions of this phone in a heartbeat.

It's a nice screen, and the resolution at 1080p is as sharp as I could ever care about.My only real complaint is that the screen is dim, at about half the brightness of its competitors in nits produced (whatever a "nit" is, don't ask me). You get used to it fast and it saves battery, but coming from the brightest phone on the market it was a little underwhelming. I could get used to the rich OLED colors very fast though, and the deep black will certainly be missed.5) Battery life: 85/100.It's fine, but nothing to write home about. Android Lollipop saves battery well, as does the dimmer screen and well-done notifications. I'm a heavy smartphone user (ahem...addict), so I never get more than one day with any phone. This phone will get you through a workday, but if you're like me then you'll need a quick charge in the evening to get you through bedtime.Note: Invest in a Qualcomm Quick-Charge 2.0 charger, supported by the Moto X. Just do it. It blew me away! You get 35% battery added in just 15 minutes. Plug it in during your after-work shower and you'll have juice to make it through Friday night, no problem.Summary:If you're somehow still reading this, here's the final verdict. If you don't care too much about camera performance, or prefer a stand-alone camera, just stop and buy this phone. It's fantastic in every single other way and costs less than rivals. Personally, I'd go through the Moto Maker website for free customization if you can stand to wait a week for delivery. If software and UI matter most to you, you'll be smitten by the scrappy Moto X. And if Motorola can come up with a better camera, I'll buy future versions of this phone in a heartbeat.

There is no such thing as "the" perfect smartphone since each individual uses them differently and will have different requirements or preferences.  So before I get to the details, I'll let you know my own.  I've used iPhones for most of my life, but recently got bored with iOS and went on a long, expensive, chronically and unreasonably dissatisfied hunt for more interesting phones in the Android world.  I value a well-balanced phone with:1) Clean, quick, uncluttered software with a pleasing user interface2) A camera that can stand-alone as my one-and-only camera (low grain, great exposure, decent color reproduction, decent HD video)3) Premium build quality that can please an Apple-seduced ex-iPhoner (feel-in-hand is especially important to me)4) A bright, colorful, and sharp screen5) Full day battery lifeI also care about durability, prompt software updating, and accessory availability.  I use the Sony Xperia Z3 as my go-to phone, and have also recently owned the iPhone 5s, LG G2, Google Nexus 5, HTC One M8, and Sony Xperia Z2.  My wife uses the Samsung S5.I bought the Motorola Moto X pure, unlocked version through the Motorola moto-builder site.  As a disclaimer got a Bamboo back and Blue trim, so be warned that while I've felt the leather in stores I had a very slightly different experience.  I've used the phone for two weeks.Okay, on to the review!1) Software: 100/100.I've never awarded a 100% to any phone for any feature. Until now.  Motorola and Google absolutely nailed it. First, you'll get the phone at Android 4.4 KitKat, but 5.0 Lollipop is already out for the Moto X and the phone can (and should) be updated immediately.  Stock Android Lollipop is gorgeous, colorful, and adds many small changes that, when they come together, makes the software almost perfect. Props to Motorola for keeping the phone stock.The few features that Motorola has added (all found in one app) are genuinely useful.  The Moto X has excellent voice-activated commands with a customizable command phrase that actually works consistently.  It also knows where you are and adapts accordingly; whether you're driving, sleeping, in a meeting, or having family time, you can customize how the phone notifies you and interacts with you given your current activity. You get nice and customizable lock-screen notifications as well. This is the smartest smartphone I've ever used, by far. Also, Google Now is omnipresent and is a decently useful (if creepily predictive) feature.If you care about software above all, look no further. The Moto X is the phone for you.2) Camera: 83/100.Like the rest of the phone's software, the camera app is smart, pretty, and quick. You can flick your wrist twice to open the app, an experience that is quick, pleasing, and works consistently if you can remember that it exists.  Though not actually Google's camera app, the camera software resembles it in its minimalism and de-cluttered UI, which I really like.  Also, shutter speed is one of the fastest I've seen, rivaling the iPhone.So it's not all bad. And while I'd read poor reviews about the camera, I was willing to give it a chance.  And note that my standards are very high.Unfortunately, though, the images I got were just not consistently solid.  In bright outdoor light you'll get nice, colorful, decently sharp images.  In any other light, however, images are often blurred, sort of grainy, and discolored.  The phone lacks Optical Image Stabilization, and it shows.  Though the camera is 13 MP, the images were much less sharp than on the 4 MP HTC One or 8 MP iPhones.  If you compose the photo, you'll get a decent image half the time.  If you don't, it's more like 1 in 4.  And try as you might, you'll have to fight hard to get a really, really good image that you'll want to print.  The flash (which, by the way, is not a ring but is just two LEDs) is bright but doesn't solve the camera's low light issues, producing red-eye and off-tone colors. Video is better, but not amazing.I'm honestly sad about this, but it was a dealbreaker for me personally. If you're no shutterfly and just need the occasional quick snap of pets or kids, the camera will do the job.  If you're at all picky about images though, you'll be chronically dissatisfied.  Sad, but it's the one-and-only true weak point on the phone.3) Build Quality: 96/100.This is a gorgeous phone. And the range of customization options (Soft leather? Warm wood? Either, please.) is nothing short of brilliant and will turn more heads more than any iPhone. The curved back feels great in the hand.  The Gorilla Glass is smoothly rounded around the edges.  The metal rim is eye candy and feels awesome, if a tad slick.  The aluminum speaker and camera trim is nice, whether stock or colorfully customized on Motorola's site.  Look, it's just a stunner of a phone, at least on par with the HTC One and Sony Xperia line with much more personality.4) Screen: 90/100.OLED (Organic Light Emitting Diode) screens are interesting.  Instead of a backlight, each pixel produces it's own light, giving the screen a unique, warm, saturated feel. Coming from the ultra-bright Sony Z3's LCD panel, the Moto X was quite a change.  Colors are bolder and more saturated, and much warmer.  Browns and colors look great.  And since OLED screens produce black by simple turning the pixels off, blacks are inky-dark and contrasting colors just pop beautifully.  It's a nice screen, and the resolution at 1080p is as sharp as I could ever care about.My only real complaint is that the screen is dim, at about half the brightness of its competitors in nits produced (whatever a "nit" is, don't ask me).  You get used to it fast and it saves battery, but coming from the brightest phone on the market it was a little underwhelming.  I could get used to the rich OLED colors very fast though, and the deep black will certainly be missed.5) Battery life: 85/100.It's fine, but nothing to write home about.  Android Lollipop saves battery well, as does the dimmer screen and well-done notifications.  I'm a heavy smartphone user (ahem...addict), so I never get more than one day with any phone.  This phone will get you through a workday, but if you're like me then you'll need a quick charge in the evening to get you through bedtime.Note: Invest in a Qualcomm Quick-Charge 2.0 charger, supported by the Moto X.  Just do it. It blew me away!  You get 35% battery added in just 15 minutes.  Plug it in during your after-work shower and you'll have juice to make it through Friday night, no problem.Summary:If you're somehow still reading this, here's the final verdict. If you don't care too much about camera performance, or prefer a stand-alone camera, just stop and buy this phone.  It's fantastic in every single other way and costs less than rivals.  Personally, I'd go through the Moto Maker website for free customization if you can stand to wait a week for delivery.  If software and UI matter most to you, you'll be smitten by the scrappy Moto X.  And if Motorola can come up with a better camera, I'll buy future versions of this phone in a heartbeat.

What I like:-Blade extends only about 3/4", making it very safe-Feels good in your hand-Very, very sharp.  Slices up boxes and packaging like warm butter-Blade lasts forever.  I've used this almost daily for about six months, and its as sharp as ever-Hooked handle very well designed for pockets, keeping the cutter secure but accessible-Blunted blade tip means you're less likely to damage the contents of packages you're opening-No need to regularly change blades.  Not only is that more convenient, but blade changes are usually when people hurt themselves-Blade doesn't collect glue and sticky stuff as much as metalWhat I don't like:-Larger-than-average for a box-cutter.  I get the hooked handle, but it takes up a lot more space-Blunt tip makes it a bit more difficult to piece packagingOverall recommendation:-Buy, if find yourself cutting open boxes and packaging on a regular basis.  It's good to keep a box-cutter separate from your pocket knife or scissors to avoid glue and gunk on your good blade, and this is a very good one.

What I really love about this sound conditioner is that is it uses air movement to create noise rather than speakers.  This gives the product an unmatched natural sound.  Moreover, it is infinitely adjustable.  If you want a cozy, muted feeling, close the vents.  For a more natural, breezy feeling, open them up.  And find an infinity of noises in between.This product draws a very low amount of electricity (I keep it on 24/7 and noticed no real rises in my electricity bills) and is simple to operate.I only have a few real beefs with this product, which I really would never live without again:First, I am addicted.  I can't sleep without this baby, or something like it at the very least.  In hotels, I take the hair dryer out and turn it to low all night.  Maybe not safe, but hey, like I said, I'm an addict.  This really isn't the fault of the product.  In fact, it means it may be TOO good at what it does.The second is related to the first issue.  This product isn't really portable. You could take it with you, for sure, but its not designed for travel.  This is only a minor problem.The final problem is a bit more serious.  One night, I kicked a blanket off myself and it landed on the floor over my sound conditioner.  The result?  A dead, non-functioning product.  I have to think it over-heated without an adequate amount of air movement through the fan.  That's a bit scary, but then again, perhaps it was built to cut power rather than dangerously overheat (or maybe not, I don't know).  Either way, I had to buy a new product.  Keep this on a table to avoid the problem.UPDATE 03/01/13:Any company that cares enough to respond to customer concerns on Amazon is a good one in my book.  I already love this product, but if you look at the comments, you'll see that my few concerns were well addressed.  The blown-fuse that occurred due to my covering of the product with a blanket was confirmed to be a safety mechanism.  And it turns out the company makes a portable version for travel. What can I say?  I love this sound machine!  Changing to 5 stars.

I was prepared to fall in love with these shoes.  They are constructed to get anyone through the winters here in Chicago, being fully rubber and possessing excellent all-weather tread, yet being decently stylish.  That's a pretty rare combination.  Opening the box, and looking at the boot, they appeared perfect.But when I put them on, with some difficulty,  I was surprised to find that they fit uncomfortably tightly around the heel, side, and top.  The "stretchy" material you see on the side of the shoe is not very stretchy at all, and the shoe needs another half inch around the top to be snug but not constricting.Thinking they might stretch a bit, or conform to my foot, I wore them around the house for a few hours, but my feet genuinely hurt afterwards.  The length was perfect, even a bit long, so ordering a size up will not help.  I may try to find a wide version on another site; even though I don't usually wear a wide, it might help.  Amazon doesn't seem to carry them, but luckily they do have an excellent return service.Maybe my foot is a rare anomaly with these shoes - I hope so, even though I usually fit right in a 12D with no problems at all.  But I would recommend one of Bogs' boots with more history of high ratings.Too bad.  People seem to think the world of Bogs as a company, so I'll give the brand another try.  Three stars for quality construction and Amazon as a store.

I am one of those guys who drops his phone a LOT. I tried the thinner snap cases, but they didn't offer enough protection. This case is a good balance between sleekness and protection. It's my favorite vase around.I've been through probably seven different types of iPhone cases over the past four years. But I keep coming back to this one.This case is very, very thin for a full coverage case. You don't notice it after just a few minutes. I consider that a plus. It's the slimmest "full protection" case I've found. My only complaint is that they occasionally break when dropped, and I'm now on my third one. But as I said, I drop my iPhone way more than average.

For some time, I kept a different, far more expensive mini USB drive on my keychain. I loved the design, but went through 3 of them in a little over a year. They just couldn't stand up to the daily abuse a keychain handles.I've used one of these for a year now with no problems, even though I've dropped it in the snow and a few puddles.This durability, it's low price, and incredibly small size make it an ideal keychain drive.Four stars instead of five because it has no mechanism to make it easily removable. But I can handle that. By the way, I recommend a coated wire keychain over those terrible, common twisted metal versions. It will make your life just far easier. It complements this flash drive well.

You know, I wasn't really a believer in these things until I used them to prevent shock as a paramedic.  They work incredibly well if you wrap yourself in them very tightly.  I've seen them save lives, and I thought I'd stick a couple in my car for emergencies.I set up a little, limited scientific experiment to test their value.  Here it is:DO NOT TRY THIS YOURSELF!First, I took my temperature with a medical-grade thermometer.  98.6 deg F, right on the money.  I walked out on my back porch in Chicago on a 20 degree night, wearing jeans and a tee shirt.  I wrapped myself in one of these blankets, very tightly with my head covered, then sat in a lawn chair for the next two hours.  Don't worry, I wasn't too bored, I had an audiobook.  I walked inside and took my temperature again. 98.3 deg F.  Not too shabby, not at all.I repeated the experiment the next night, at 22 deg F, with almost identical results.  The next night, it was 26 degrees.  I sat out on my porch WITHOUT the blanket, as a control, as long as I could bear it, which was about an hour and a half.  My temperature without the blanket after 1.5 hours was 96.4 deg F.  A very big difference.As a medical profesional, I am very impressed with the lifesaving potential of this product.  I've worked with kids and the elderly who became hypothermic after being exposed for just a half hour in 50 degree weather.Now, I won't say I was wonderfully comfortable with just this product and a tee shirt.  It was not pleasant.  And my temperature did drop some.  If you were exposed with just this blanket, dressed as I was, for more than 5 or 6 hours, you'd probably have a problem.  Especially if the temperatures were below those at which I tested it. As your core temp drops, your body will focus heat in vital organs, away from the skin.  Therefore, there is less heat for this blanket to reflect back, and the rate of temperature decline will accelerate.But if you're stranded in a car with a coat, or inside a dugout shelter, this is pretty valuable.  In a survival situation, I highly recommend putting this INSIDE your warmer clothes against your skin.  It will exponentially increase the effectiveness of the product, in my experience.  In any case, make this an inner, not an outer layer, or your blankets and layering for sleep.I don't consider myself a "prepper" really, but I do keep emergency gear in my car in case I need to walk, and a little bug-out-bag at home just in case.  Why not?  It's not expensive, and a little entertaining if nothing else. Plus if things ever do go downhill quickly, you're a little better off having options.Anyhow, the problem with normal mylar survival blankets is they're quite bright if you're trying NOT to be found. They're either orange or mirror silver - made specifically to be visible.  That's why I chose these blankets.  If you don't want people to see you, olive green is pretty much the way to go. Moreover, this material Is VERY tough.  I'm a big, strong dude and I had trouble ripping it.  That's impressive.EDIT 7/26/13:After a helpful comment from another user, I did a little more research and found that these blankets work best with a little space between the skin and the blanket.  They are designed to produce a thin layer of warm air, shielding the body from conductive heat loss.  One site I read said that a quarter inch to a half inch of space is optimal.  If you can pull that off, definitely do so.  Overall, though, still make this an inner layer of heat loss protection.

I can definitely confirm that this Bible is very waterproof. It's taken some dunks, and you would never know.I wish the cover wasn't paperback. One would assume, after all, that this Bible is intended for wilderness activities. It's pretty much tailor-made for wilderness and camp ministry. But having spent some time doing that myself, I know that paperbacks become really bent-up in a backpack. Water won't destroy it, but other camping activities will. I do recommend this product for you wilderness theologians out there. But would make the following changes:-Hard, Waterproof Cover-Clasp to Hold the Bible Shut in a Backpack-Slightly Smaller SizeMake these changes, and this thing is perfect!And by the way, I just have to plug the ESV. It's a really great, balanced translation. It is as literal as possible while accounting for idiom when its really needed. You need to have a little training to use the ESV - a sense of context. If you're younger, not a leader, or not really theologically geared, the TNIV might be a better route. That's my plug!

I'm a paramedic, though I work in an entirely different field full time.  Still, I wanted to volunteer with the Red Cross for disaster relief, and I wanted something to identify myself as medical personnel that wasn't a lame tee shirt or star of life bumper sticker.  I keep this at the bottom of my car consul in case I get called out, and it sticks to my fleece jacket perfectly.  It's subtle but clear, I think, and pretty cool.

I've found that cheap pocketknives actually end up being slightly more useful that my nice ones, if only because I'm not afraid to really use them however I need to in order to get the job done. This one is cheap without being cheaply made. And is that not the essence of a good product?I grew up on a navy base in western Europe, and one of the lingering vestiges of that childhood is the Opinel folding knife. My father gave one to each of my brothers and I when were were lads, and I must have abused and carved a thousand trinkets and such in the Scottish woods with mine.As an adult, I now appreciate what high quality Opinel steel is for the price. It's stiffer than comparably priced knives, and holds an edge about as long as my Benchmade carry knives, longer than my CRKTs - for 10% of the price.The non-serrated, drop-point blade is a classic, proven shape that is useful for many tasks. And this smaller size is perfect - I prefer the size 6 above the several other options. The blade is stiff enough for light prying without breaking, and you don't need to be afraid to use the tool as you need to because of its price. I give it four stars instead of five because it requires a little more effort than is preferable to open with one hand, and the opening is stiff for some time when you first get it. I love the locking mechanism for this knife, though. So simple, so functional!Finally, this is a less "scary" looking knife - and has even been construed as "classy" in some men's magazines I've read. It is French, after all.  The walnut is even classier than the slightly cheaper, non-walnut size 6.

SHORT FORM OF THE REVIEW BELOW:-Small enough not to notice in your pocket, TSA compliance confirmed-Strong, convenient pliers, especially for the size-Pliers make this better than the comparably-sized Leatherman CS-Surprisingly use-able screwdriver-Scissors (no knife) that work pretty well, but broke after a few months.  Worth replacing.If you are the kind of person who likes to fix minor problems yourself, and you don't always have easy access to a tool box, you should purchase this tool.  There will certainly be times you will be thankful for it.I don't like bulky key chains.  That said, I've often wished I had a multitool with pliers, screwdriver, and cutting tool no matter where I went, as I spend a lot of time away from home.  The Style PS fit that bill while being very, very small, and also easy to detach from and re-attach to your keys.I cannot over-state the convenience of having pliers on me at all times.  I've fixed office chairs and desks, tightened loose screws, and opened oxygen bottles (as a paramedic) with them with no problem.  Will they replace your nice, big needle nose pliers? No.  But on a daily basis out of the home, they are strong and easy enough to use that they can do 75% of the same jobs with only slightly less ease.  The wire cutters are a decent addition as well. So if you spend long periods out of the house or travel a lot (yes, I've passed through TSA checkpoints with these), you seriously need this tool, for the pliers alone.I've successfully used the screwdriver for both phillips and flathead screws.  Again, not as good as a purpose made screwdriver, but for something that goes on your keychain, pretty darn good.  The file (on the screwdriver) is decent as well - it works for my man nails, at the very least.Finally, the scissors.  They are the reason I gave the product four instead of five stars.  The torsion bar broke on mine after about five months of moderate use, and I had to purchase a new item.  But during that time, they worked well.
