I would certainly prefer a knife (in fact I carry one separately), but with TSA's incredibly restrictive rules, I think using these little guys instead was a smart move.  I've used the tool in the airport a few times, and been very thankful for it.My final word?  This is a small, inexpensive, use-able keychain tool from a great company.  You won't notice it on your keychain, and there will be times you are very thankful to have it with you.

I'm not going to pay the Apple retail price for a new phone charger when this little guy is available.  But it charges at about half the speed of the real-deal charger.  That's a little frustrating at times.If you regularly get home from work and want to throw your phone on the charger for 20 minutes to have it powered up for a night on the town, look somewhere else.  If you just want something to recharge it overnight, go for this one!  It's obviously cheaply made, the connecter is clunky, and the cord is viciously short.But it will charge your phone for $5.

This is small enough to be a reasonable addition to a keychain, even by my minimalist standards.  Pliers are so incredibly useful to have at hand, and these are pretty capable for their small size. And it's stood up to a respectable amount of abuse for being such a little guy.Here are some things I've done with this bad boy when my toolbox was not at hand:-Put together an IKEA bed frame-Took the keyboard off my MacBook, then put it back on-Cut up IV tubing and trauma gauze (I'm a paramedic)-Re-wired a lamp-Trimmed my beard (yep...)-Pulled out deep splinters-Re-formed a bent-out-of-shape gym locker-Fixed drawer slides at work-And more!Was it sometimes hard to do these things with this little leatherman? Yes.Would it be possible to have done them without this tool? No.Get into a habit of keeping this on you, and you won't regret it.

Glasser does an amazing job here of presenting the unified, progressive story of Scripture.  The Church is addicted to verse-by-verse, "zoomed-in" interpretation of the Bible.  This work is a must-read if you are sometimes puzzled the seemingly eclectic way the Bible is put together.  If you wonder "where is God going with this?", you will find the answer here.Scripture has a message at all levels, but I will dare to say the most important message is found at the meta-level. This book is that message.  And we cannot let it become lost among the thousands of smaller passages and lessons that support it.Four stars only because Glasser doesn't do a wonderful job countering SOME of the inevitable assumptions of American, individualist evangelicalism.  But all works are limited by time and space, so I don't fault him for it too much.

This is a wonderful commentary, whether your a serious theologian or exegetical newbie.  As a missions guy, I fall somewhere in between, but I gave the gift to my (theologically untrained) mom for a Bible Study she's leading and she found it to be an amazing resource.  She told me that her class considered her an expert, even though she pretty much ripped off exactly what Dr. Walton wrote in the Genesis section.For those of you Scripture hounds who don't trust a commentary with pictures to be academically sound and challenging, I found that the pictures always aided immensely in the interpretive process.  For example, in the opening pages is a diagram that shows the ancient Hebrew concept of the world that completely changed the way I read scripture.  Since I had Dr. Walton in class for Old Testament I had heard this concept spoken of, but it wasn't until I saw the diagram that I really understood the way it affected their thinking and writing.I'll admit I'm biased because I just really like Dr. Walton.  I got to know he and his wife on a Holy Lands studies program in Israel, and he was an absolutely one of a kind, amazing man to take the trip with.  I can assure you, his knowledge of Genesis is surpassed by few scholars in this century in in the past.  Buy this commentary, and enjoy God's revelation even more!

I liked this knife.  It was classy enough not to scare the timid and very sharp.  The assisted opening was decent, but required a pretty solid press that actually hurt my thumb a bit.  But very fast.  And I'm used to $130 Benchmades, so for the price I'd give the mechanism 4 stars.Except that it broke not two weeks into my using it.  The a retaining support for the torsion bar appears to have ruptured, and now the knife won't close without seriously pressing on the blade.  Too bad - it was becoming my everyday carry knife pretty quickly.  I haven't made any return efforts so I can't comment on the process, so I'm going to be nice and give it three stars, assuming I got a lemon and that with a little effort I could get it replaced.PS I'm usually a generous reviewer, not one of those always dissatisfied types!

Working in some rougher neighborhoods, I leave this is my car's center console, just in case.  I'm a big, strong guy - no one messes with me - but I'd rather not get in a fistfight with a dog or druggie, and I personally don't want to carry a handgun, which are illegal in Chicago in any case.  I've had other sprays.  This is the easiest to aim and has the best "cone" of spray with decent, but not earth shattering distance.  It's pretty big, but not huge, which is both good and bad - easier to access and use, harder to conceal and less likely to find room in a purse or jacket pocket.  I test fired it and felt a lot safer than with other sprays.  In a nasty situation, you don't want to need to aim or think, just point in a general direction and squeeze.I also know that it burns like crazy.  How did I find out, you ask?The (accidental) test:I was pumping gas, leaning on the jeep, and my brother, a tall young man of 23, found this pepper gun in my console.  He didn't see "MACE" on the side and for unknown reasons thought it was a novelty lighter and decided to give it a go.  Unfortunately, it was pointing right at his face.  So the first thing I know, my brother jumps out of the car yelling and rolling on the ground.  I ran over and caught a small wiff, and it was like someone had squeezed a habanero pepper in my face.  I backed off, my face streaming with tears.  Eventually, I washed my brother's face with several bottles of water until he could function.  My brother says couldn't see for about 3 minutes, was basically incpacitated for 10, tearing up with a runny nose for 30 minutes, and seriously unhappy for the 2 hours until he could take a long shower.  And being in my car, even after seriously scrubbing the inside, was a bad experience for a couple of weeks.  Thanks bro.What we learned:1) This stuff seriously hurts.  Like, really bad, torture chamber hurts.  Which is good.2) Keep it in a safe place, away from kids or adults who make poor choices3) It takes a long time to clean off a surface4) Just toss the canister after use - it will leak slowly after it's been used once and you're face will always be a little on fire after you touch objects it's been around

Mott's book is highly Biblical (the references abound throughout the text) and incorporates a solid understanding of Hebrew culture.  I wholeheartedly agree with the majority of his conclusions, though not with the chapter permitting the Christian to use violence to protect the abused and downtrodden.  (But this isn't the place for my counter-arguments.)I don't personally agree with some of Mott's theological foundations, but I found that he did a very good job of making the book applicable to those of us of different theological persuasions.  If you have major questions about the Biblical foundations for "social justice" in the Church, look no further than this book.  It is a wonderful wake up for a Church that likes to excuse itself from having to take action because of an overly-internalized and individualistic faith.

I read Brand Jesus in a class a couple of years ago, and just recently returned to it as a source during my graduate studies.  We MUST think out how commercialization may have compromised the values of Christ, and understand how we might bring ourselves back.  Tyler Wigg Stevenson - who I met as a guest speaker at one point - is both critical and kind, and does not offer any easy answer. I admire these traits extremely in an author.If your interested in the overlap of American economics and the Church, definitely read this book!

These are a great option if you think they'll match your gym outfit, but the university blue of the earbuds and their cord is very gaudy unless you can fit into your overall look. I'd say that the sound quality after testing these was good, but like most in-ear headphones, it lacks some of the power of more involved, full-ear headphones.I received a free product for testing and review.

This was easy to install and gets a lot of compliments. The decal is a full square sheet, including the aluminum at the bottom where the paint drip effect reveals some of the Macbook. The aluminum of the decal is 'slightly' different from the authentic Apple aluminum, but you can't tell the difference from a distance. I get a lot of compliments on this decal. It's striking and looks very 'real' at first glance. It would be cool if the decal actually had texture/elevation to enhance the painted on look, but for $7 you can't be too picky. :)

I received a free sample of these for testing and review.Really pleased! I review a lot of Bluetooth headphones on Amazon, and it's rare that I actually use a pair more than once or twice after reviewing them. I made these my new main headphones. They have a very subtle appearance (not a big bulky look like many headphones) and the metallic color matches well with any outfit. The magnetic aspect works great. If I need to take them out of my ears, I can keep them around my neck without the risk of having them fall off. I've lost headphones that way before :(...The buttons give you all the same features that you find on a standard pair of Apple earbuds. The sound quality is good. I won't say it's exceptional. Like most in-ear headphones, there's a certain 'power' that you miss out on unless you get full size headphones.

I received a free sample for testing and review.I found these to be a very sturdy pair of cufflinks. They stayed on without issue for a full day. They're not the most unique looking cufflinks, and I recommend something more personable (like alumni cufflinks, or sports cufflinks) if you want an actual conversation starter.

I received a free sample of this product for review.While I love the features of this wallet, I have to admit that it appears the grain of the leather is decidedly feminine. Several friends have noticed and pointed it out. I don't recommend this for guys, unless you're comfortable giving gender roles the finger (and, hey, rock on).

I received a free product for testing and review.These are just OK. They do work, don't get me wrong, but it's a very particular aesthetic to have these on your wall, and you rely on the supplier for additional white markers whenever you need more ink. I think it makes more sense to just get a white board, but if you're chasing the chalkboard look without the chalkdust, you'll probably fall in love with this.

I received a free product for testing and review.I love the non-Bluetooth selfie sticks because I've always had pairing issues with the bluetooth ones. This has a nice white finish that I think is unique, since most selfie sticks are silver or black. The stick adjusts easily in any direction and isn't too hard to open for inserting the phone. I would like to see one that snaps open and closed, but haven't seen that yet. If you're in the market for a selfie stick, this is a good option!

I received a free product for testing and review.This is a quality bluetooth headset. It's amazing how far the price has dropped on bluetooth earbuds. They used to start at like $40/45. Anyway, I've never seen the 'stability clips' before, and I think they're a great touch. If you've ever tried jogging with headphones, you know the unappealing rhythm of the cord bounding around. This product helps to eliminate that issue by stabilize the cord with what is basically a small zipper (they call it a clip) that reduces the length of the free cable when wearing the produce. The audio quality and ease of connection are fine.Some criticisms: would have been better to have the buttons distributed over both earpieces instead of just one. Also, the size of the over-ear loops is a little large for my ears. It would be nice if they were somehow adjustable. It's not a stability thing, they just look a little big on me.

I received a free product for testing and review.I found no issues with this cable, and I like the matte black look of it, which is a better fit for the interior of my car than the classic Apple white. Charge time seems to be identify to official Apple cables.

I've written too many highly positive reviews of other Sedaris books to really hide my true colors. I love the man's written style and he's one of the few authors that can make me laugh out loud. Please, treat yourself to some of his essays. He'll brighten your day. -Ryan Mease

This title is remarkable for its clarity. It's effectively a comprehensive introduction to the emergence of cyberwar as a new frontier in global military conflict. Everything you need to become conversational on the topic is included: the China problem, Edward Snowden, the growth of cyberwar in Middle Easter Conflicts, the government topography related to cybersecurity, etc. I highly recommend this to any interested in the future of national security. The author's general tone is one of caution and worry, but there are no clear trouble makers in @War. The rise of cyberwar is a general issue and the NSA, etc. are not targeted as villains, but as invasive albeit necessary players in the future of cybersecurity. -Ryan Mease

Like many other books in this series, this is a fun and short introduction to two major figures in history, characterized by individual voice actors who read each figure’s quotations to help individuate personalities. There isn’t a lot of technical vocabulary (formal logic jaron) in the book, making it highly accessible to a general audience.

This book seems written for aerospace specialists. I work for Airbus, so I figured I would pick this up to learn more about the history of the plane, but found it really hard to follow. The authors are very passionate about throwing numbers into their book (you’ll find figures in every paragraph). Without context, these numbers often lack a “wow” effect that I think is intended. There is also an extensive use of aerospace engineering and materials/manufacturing terminology. The book present itself as a fun, picture-filled introduction to aviation for the general public, centered on one of aviation’s most impressive products. It would have been better to find vocabulary and terminology aids in the margin to ease the reader into the baffling word of aerospace jargon. -Ryan Mease

I received a free product for testing. I can confirm that it works, and that is has a similar appearance to the official Apple product. What more can I say? It's a charging cable. Given their pricing structure, I recommend the 4-pack! I don’t know about you, but I tend to lose the cables, or at least fail to have one on me when I really need the charge.

I really like the field of biomimicry, and it’s a blast to hear about all of the scientific and engineering creativity at play in the biomimicry industry. That said, the book is a little fast paced—the author tends to throw one invention after another at you, which starts to get overwhelming after a while. Focusing entire chapters on one or two related technologies would have allowed these technologies to have a more lasting impact on memory and perspective.Secondly, the author is very self-promoting, as other reviewers have already mentioned. It gets old after a while. We get it: you’re passionate about this and believe that you’re living the ideal life because you’re an outstanding engineer and entrepreneur. You think we should become just like you. Great. Thanks. The closing chapter also contains this casual rant about venture capitalists, which was actually really informative but also came out of left field for a book that was more about the science of biomimicry than the financing techniques of biotechnology.

This works as a fan, but I remain unconvinced that it is appreciably better than a traditional desktop fan. I have confirmed that I am using it correctly, but still feel to see noticeably different results. Others may have a better experience. In any case, it works well as a fan, so it was not a complete waste of the purchase money.

I was given a free product for testing, and I can confirm that it works! I don't have much to say about  the design of the product. These apple chargers are all very similar looking. I do not have a measuring stick, so I cannot formally confirm that it is one meter in length, but it looks like it is!

I love how much sass you can find in this coloring book. The author has a lot of strictly defined standards about the most appropriate approach to geography, and isn't afraid to provide these funny, victorian rules about 'how' to color the book.

I have used these throughout the week at multiple sites in both Germany and France without issue. I would say they are 100% compatible with both countries. It might be smart to be 2 packs (6 total). It's quite easy to remove the cord from the wall and realize that you left the adapter in the outlet.

These cases are very 'standard' in terms of features, but the iPad standard choice is a good one! You have the magnetic on/off, openings for all the buttons, and the built-in stand for the iPad. I would be exciting to see a case that had a stand for both configurations (horizontal and vertical) but this will do. :)
This is a men's shampoo and conditioner. It smells good and it works. What else do you want to know? :p

I bought this last minute for a trip to Europe. I purchased the 'teal' collection (which you will see has different bag options than the black collection). I like the duffel bag with rolling wheels; it makes an excellent carry-on for shorter trips. For a longer trip like the one that I'm currently on (I'm writing this in a Lufthansa lounge in Frankfurt, Hallo, Leute!), I recommend the carry-on + rolling duffel. I can imagine using the large case one day, but not when I'm on a multi-city trip. I hate checking bags.Three complaints: (1) the color of this 'teal' collection is decidedly ambiguous. Is it green? is it blue? depend on the lighting. (2) I love the look and design with the leather detail, etc., but as a guy I have to say that the shape of the duffel bag and the design of the handles make it look like a large women's purse. Not sure how I feel about this yet. (3) The wheels on the carry-on are a little stiff, but maybe they just need to be broken in.
This smells great and was easy to order from Amazon Same-Day in San Francisco. I don't really think anything more needs to be said. It's a men's body wash. Take it or leave it, bro. :p

I bought this for my partner and we share it with one another as a memento when one of us is traveling. We agree that it doesn't resemble a 'real' cat (it's face doesn't quite work and it's a little small—kitten size). It's definitely soft, and there don't appear to be a lot of alternatives on Amazon. It's too bad they didn't have a Scottish Fold option. :(

I received a free product for testing.This functions well and is significantly smaller than most selfie sticks. I also *like* that is *not* Bluetooth. I don't like having to pair and re-pair the selfie stick every time that I use it. B/c selfie sticks are not considered 'cool' but are also very useful, you really want the thing up and running before people have a chance to say 'no' to posing for a photo. I wish the top of this selfie stick weren't a bright green color, but beyond that it's a great product.

I purchased this but was disappointed so I returned the product. It adds quite a load to the iPad Air, making it almost as heavy as a Macbook Air. When I first picked up the iPad Air I was *delighted* by how light it was. When I put this keyboard on it—not so much. This keyboard/case also has no place to put a stylus, which is a feature available on many competitors. I chose to go with a different product. This isn't awful, but it's a bad compromise on weight and function.

These are definitely an improvement over the QY7, not that the QY7 was terrible. I was given a free same of this product for testing.The connection time is faster than the QY7. The appearance has improved. These are a nice, matte black color and the lights are more integrated within the earpiece. I would not hesitate to pay full price for these. They're a great product.

I was given a free product for testing.This is a great 'mini-kit' to have around the house, if you know for certain that you won't need pliers/etc. and just want the most basic tools in a convenient case with lots of options.

These are actually somewhat small for my front door, which has a metal lining underneath. The door comes so high that these just barely stop it an sometimes lose their grip in a strong wind. I recommend these for general use throughout the house, but not for the front door or any door that is not immediately on the ground.

This is a huge commitment of your time, so it better be worth it, no? I spent about three weeks reading this on and off, because the content is as gripping as history can be, but still rather dry. This is an excellent presentation of Europe's overall development in the late 20th century, including sections on Europe in the 21st century. As you might imagine, there is a strong focus on the Soviet Union and the collapse of communism. That said, we see plenty of information about the Western nations' reestablishment. This is about as good a book as one may find for a complete summary of modern Europe. It would be good to aid the book with basic review of information on Wikipedia, etc. -Ryan Mease

This is a very nice, well made, permanent filter. If you use it, you will save a ton of money over pre-filled K-Cups.I recommend using it with a disposable paper filter. Doing that will ensure that no fine coffee grounds end up in your coffee.One warning: stainless steel is an excellent conductor of heat. Because of that, if you remove this refillable K-Cup immediately after brewing a cup of coffee, it is going to be hot. Uncomfortably so. If you keep that in mind, and give it a minute to cool, you won't burn yourself.This thing should last indefinitely.

These are wonderful. Drop one into your reusable Keureg-type filter, add coffee, snap the top down, and brew. When the coffee is made, lift the paper filter out (over a wast basket!), drop it in the trash, and rinse the reusable filter.  They make clean-up a breeze, and provide a cup of coffee containing no fine coffee grounds.

Do I love these? You bet. I have two of them on my new sink.  One is for hand soap, the other for dish soap.They have a generous reservoir, so you won't need to fill this every few days. The finish matches most brushed stainless/nickel sinks/faucets. And best of all, it works well. It holds its prime, provides a good amount of soap if you depress it all the way, and less if you just push lightly on it.And...if you ever need to contact the company, the return emails are lightning fast. All companies should be this good.

This is a great Otterbox case.  While it might not be quite as durable as the Armor series (and not waterproof), it nevertheless is well made and sturdy. And unlike the one I previously owned for the Samsung Galaxy S5, this one heels solid.Lain on a hard surface with the screen up, there is a good deal of "traction" [provided by the case. This is a useful feature if you drive with the phone on the center console of your car. Lay it face down, however, and it will slide off the console like a ball bearing on an icy surface.I have dropped the phone numerous times. It is holding up well. I wouldn't hesitate to purchase another one.

Great way to save big bucks over the OEM model.These are high quality filters, remove chlorine taste from water, and work as well as the OEM. Unlike some generic brands I have tried, this one does NOT impart a plastic-like flavor to the water.Highly recommended.

I had high hopes for this sink. I needed one in this size, and the local big box stores had nothing in stock. My counter tops were being installed, the plumber was coming in as soon as they left, and Amazon had this one that could be delivered on a Sunday at no extra charge. The price didn't please me, but I assumed I was paying for quality.When I open the box, I was impressed. The sink was well packaged and protected, and had all the mounting hardware necessary. In terms of looks, it was GORGEOUS. It sparkled and shined like a polished jewel. And it was HEAVY. Heavy stainless is not cheap, so maybe the $345 price tag was worth it.The sink is a 4 hole model, so I installed the faucet in the middle, a hand soap dispenser to the left, a dish soap dispenser to the right, and a reverse osmosis tap on the far right. Sweet setup.Well, here is my experience. The sink has been installed for 12 days. Simply running water into this sink dulls that beautiful finish, and it requires a good scrubbing with a non-abrasive cleaner to bring back the shine. OK...I can live with that, but it runs counter to every other stainless sink I have ever owned (and I have owned quite a few).But here's the part that really sucks: it scratches like it is soft metal. By day 4 of use, there were very visible scratches on the bottom of this sink, and they absolutely RUIN its appearance. When one is remodeling a kitchen (new appliances, cabinets, counter tops, floor, and plumbing hardware), the expectation is that it will look new for more than 4 days. This sink reminds me of the saying, "You don't wear tennis shows with a tuxedo." It looks (already) like everything was replaced EXCEPT the sink.  I am hugely disappointed.Look at the 3 photos. The 2nd one shows the sink sponged down, rinsed, and wiped dry with a clean dish towel. The 3rd shows the sink after I just ran some water in it. No soap, just water. And we have a whole house water filter...this is good, clean, water. Both the 2nd and 3rd picture clearly show the scratches in the finish.American Standard used to produce a fine product. My experience with this one means I will never buy one of their products again.Save yourself the headache. Avoid this p.o.s. like the plague.Look at my other reviews. I rarely give anything a one or two star review. When I do, the product deserves it.

Charle Boer was one of my college professors, and a terrific teacher. I loved his translations when I was in college, and wanted copied for my children.Of all the translations of the Homeric Hymns I have read, his are, by far, the best.I was saddened to learn of his passing.

This is my second review of this brewer, reflecting my experience with the product and the company.The first brewer made terrific coffee, but when brewing the largest size cup (the travel mug), it did not automatically stop brewing. That had to be done manually. I wasn't sure if that was a malfunction or not, and I had difficulty contacting the company. Fortunately, Ekobrew monitors these reviews, and one of the owners left a comment , asking me to contact him directly. I did, and he was very responsive and most gracious.He told me that the machine was indeed defective. He immediately sent out a replacement. I have received it, and it works perfectly.I have tested it with Starbucks brand K-cups, an inexpensive K-Cup brand from Aldi, the reusable filter that comes with the machine, and the Ekobrew stainless steel reusable filter. It functions well with all of them.95% of the time, I brew coffee using the reusable filter. I drop in a paper filter, measure out some coffee, and in less than a minute, I have a cup of freshly brewed java. I have also not added anything to the waste stream. The spent coffee and paper filter go into the compost bin. No plastic to clog landfills.My wife also uses the Ekobrew to make tea, and it works perfectly for that as well.The machine is so simple to use, a caveman could do it. Really. Fill the reservoir with water, drop in a K-cup, hit the on button, and wait about 40 seconds. When the lights stop flashing, it is ready to brew. Choose your cup size: small, medium, or large, push the button, and your cup or mug is filled. When the machine beeps 3 times,  brewing is complete.If you walk away from the machine for a while, it shuts itself off.I absolutely love this brewer, and was treated very well when I had an issue with the first machine. I highly recommend this brewer and the company. Save yourself some money, and get this instead of a Keurig. You won't be disappointed.

This may be one of the best books I have read in the past ten years. It is certainly in my top ten, all time favorite books.The book has everything, and yet nothing, to so with training a young goshawk. What is it really about? Grief. Death. Discipline. Commitment.This is now one of my two "Elevator test" books. It joins "The Shipping News" as a book used in that capacity.Elevator test? That means if you read this book, and really liked it, I wouldn't mind being trapped in an elevator for a few hours with you. We would likely enjoy each others' company.

A decent quality, clear, plastic storage bin with a locking lid. Steririte is a well known brand, and these are of decent quality. Given the price, and the fact that they are delivered directly to your door, this is an unbeatable bargain.

As with every other season of Stargate SG-1, season 6 has a few lemons, and a whole lot of good episodes. The characters are well developed, there is plenty of action along with some great interpersonal relationship play, and well worth watching.

I am a Stargate SG-1 geek (unabashedly ans apologetically).  Season 4, like every other season, has a few losers and a lot of winners. If you enjoy decent science fiction where the characters are well developed, you won't be disappointed.

If you are a photographer, or an artist, you really should own this book. Diane Arbus had a unique way of seeing the world, and it is presented in this edition. She photographed circus people, entertainers, children, the people next door...all in stark, expressive black and white.She is a cultural icon. This book presents a good cross section of her work. She had a lot to say, and a lot to teach. Sadly, she ended her life around the time of the book's publication.

This is the grater our mothers and grandmothers had. This one sports an "Upgraded" handle, that is totally unnecessary. The original metal one worked just fine. There is nothing wrong with the handle on this one, other than the fact that it's an "improvement" that really doesn't improve anything.I use this for grating hard cheese, shredding mozzarella, and similar tasks It works very well.Construction is solid. With a little care, it should last forever.

I bought this as a spare vest, for when friends visit and want to use one of my kayaks. It will not see much use. It seems well made for the price. It has only been used a few times. While I would not buy this for heavy usage, it should work for weekend boaters or occasional use.

I am on my second Danby microwave oven. The first was defective (it kept tripping my 20 amp circuit breaker), so I returned it for an exchange. The second one is working with no issues.A few things: both microwaves were a bit noisy as the turntable rotated. I thought at first this might be a defect, but is doesn't seem that is the case.Second, (and this is nit-picking), if you open the door immediately after the timer shuts the oven off, you still get 5 beeps, telling you that the cooking is complete. I hate that kind of beeping, so I typically shut the oven off with one or 2 seconds left on the timer.The construction seems solid, the packaging is wonderful ( beautiful padding and double-boxing). For the price, I don't see how you could possibly go wrong.

I use this pan at least twice a week. It makes perfect baguettes.The pan is very lightweight, and the perforations allow for perfect browning/crisping of the crust.450 degrees is the maximum oven temperature recommended by the manufacturer. I bake typically at 425, so that is not an issue.One trick I have used for years, and it works beautifully with this pan, is to put a cake pan half filled with water on the floor of my gas oven. That increases the humidity of the heat, and paradoxically, makes foe a hard, crunchy crust and a chewy interior.Try this pan. Once you are used to using it, you will love it.

Inexpensive, good looking, and well made. The only thing lacking is hanging hardware. This is listed as a desk frame, but really, who uses a 16 X do on a desk?  So add two screw eyes and a piece of picture wire, and it's ready to hang.I use these frames (in black and in white) to display prints at art shows and galleries. They work well for that.

This is a wonderful lens. It is also weather resistant, which adds greatly to its usability.I own a few professional level Nikons ( D4, D800), and an array of lenses that sold to purchase a small house. That said, many of those lenses have plastic barrels (and in a few cases, mounts). This Fuji lens, on the other hand, just reeks of quality. The lens barrel is metal. The minimum focus distance is 3.6' at all focal lengths. That means it will function in closeup situations as a macro. The image stabilization system is better than Nikon's, providing (says Fuji) up to 4.5 f stops of shake-free images. I can say this: I have shot with this lens mounted on an X-T100 hand-held at 1/4 second and achieved images sharp enough to make 16 x 20 enlargements.Flare and chromatic aberration have not been a problem.I can recommend this lens without reservation.

These reading glasses are perfect: very heavy duty frames, high quality lenses, spring hinges, and molded-in nose pads.  When you first hold these in your hands and put them on, they scream "High Quality!"If your experience with reading glasses are the ones sold in drug or discount stores, be prepared to be blown away by the quality these offer. It's like going from a Yugo to a Mercedes. There is simply no comparison.

Good assortment of connectors and tools at a reasonable price. The teflon tape is a nice addition to the set, because it is an absolute necessity with air compressor connections.The set seems to be reasonably well made, and since it's not something I will use every day, I expect it to last a good long time.

This is a high quality, American-made, RUBBER airline hose. It is far superior to pvc hoses" it doesn't stiffen in the cold, and with reasonable care, it should last forever.  The fittings are heavy duty, and make attachment easy.  Really, how much can you say about a good hose?

This is a great anthology for the Bukowski fan, and a good introduction for the newbie. I bought this one for my wife, who had never read any of his works.There is something in this for everyone. Well, maybe not a Danielle Steele fan, but just about everyone else.

We bought this as a birthday present for a 35 year old Dr. Who fan. She LOVES it.  (We gave it to her filled with M&Ms.)This is a big, heavy mug that is rectangular in shape. It has a lid, so it might be useful in brewing tea. I'm not sure how easy it would be to actually drink out of this, though. The sides are straight, and this mug is so heavy, you might get your daily exercise just drinking from it.For the Dr. Who fan, this is a "must have" item.

This show is everything that a crime drama series should be: realistic, well acted, superb story, and first rate production values. Bosch is a great hero...complex, conflicted, and strong. If this were a novel, it would be a page turner.Congratulations are due Amazon for this remarkable production. This show ALONE is reason enough to join Amazon Prime.

I have been using this brand of yeast for years. I come back to it over and over again.It is a "Rapid-rise type yeast, which means there is no need to "proof" the yeast by dissolving it thoroughly in warm water before use. That said, old habits die hard, and I still do that.You get a LOT of yeast at a good price when you buy this package. Once opened, you can simply store the package with the top closed in the freezer. I used to to that, and the yeast was still perfectly fine after 2 years+. Or save a plastic vitamin type jar, pour the unused yeast in that, and store it in the freezer, (It lasts longer in the freezer than in the fridge, but you will still get at least a year when it is stored unfrozen.)My method is a little different. I store 1/4 of the package in a plastic jar, frozen. I break the remaining 12 oz into three packages of 1/4 lb each, vacuum seal them in my Food Saver, write the date on them, and store them in the freezer. They will last three years or so when stored this way.In any case, the next time you are in the grocery store, check price a 4 oz jar of Fleischmann's Dry Active yeast.  It will cost between $5 and $10. This stuff costs less, you USE less, and works better. You cannot beat the combination of price, quality, and value this offers.

This mattress pad provides excellent protection, and at a price that won't break the bank.It fits well and securely, and is unnoticeable under a fitted sheet.So far, it stands up well to machine washing.if you have a memory foam mattress,  one of these is a "Must have," as liquid will ruin that type of mattress.

An excellent sourdough starter.  I bought this one along with "Alaskan Sourdough Starter  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00M965V4I/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1#customerReviewsThey both work very well. Easy to get your starter going, and the strain is very flavorful.  Directions are clear and concise. All you need to use this is water, flour, and a non-metallic container. It really doesn't get much easier than that.

This e-book has some great recipes, as well as good information about sourdough in general. Well worth the price.The only thin I would change would be to add more information about the care and feeding of your sourdough starter. Sourdough started is a living, breathing, ever changing organism (or colony of organisms), and requires a bit of care to keep it healthy. Detailed information can be found elsewhere. It would just be nice to have it all in one place.
I needed this part to connect a large shower head to in-ceiling plumbing. It worked just fine, and cost 50% less than at my local plumbing supply company.  What's not to like?

I mixed this starter according to directions, and 5 days later I made my first loaf of sourdough bread. Good, but the tangy, sour flavor was more subtle than I hoped. Five days later, I made another loaf. OMG, this stuff is WONDERFUL!  Nice sour tang, the bread looks gorgeous, and the aroma that fills the house when this is baking is amazing.There seems to be a problem, though, with "Loaf shrinkage." Every time I walk into the kitchen, the loaf looks smaller. I'm not sure why that happens, but I have been noticing some bread crumbs on my wife's shirt.This culture will take on its own characteristics in your particular micro climate, and will likely change a bit each time you use it. All part of the adventure. And it is going to form a layer of water that floats on top of the starter. Don't pour off more than half of this: it is where much of the sour flavor comes from.  Just mix it in before you use the starter.Keep it fed (mine gets a feeding of 1/2 cup flour and 1/'2 cup water every 10 days, whether I use it or not. Over time, it will develop a "ripe" smell, but the taste it imparts to the bread will be wonderful. I keep mine covered with 2 layers of paper towels, held firmly in place by an elastic band. It allows the starter to breathe, but keeps bugs out. (Fruit flies live this stuff.) And mine stays at 74 degrees all the time.Buy this and give it a try. You won't be disappointed.

I have a confession to make,  so I will get it out of the way up front: I love OXO products. They offer terrific quality, durability, and desiga, and they do that at a great price.This brush is no different.  It is comfortable in the hand, does a superior job of cleaning the inside of glasses and jars,  and stands up your repeated use.The handle features a non-slip grip, which is great when wot king wit wet, soapy hands.I would buy another in a heartbeat,  but I suspect this one will last a long while.

These are decent quality brushes,  and hard to beat for the price.I use them to clean Grolch type bottles, and they do a good job of getting the inside of the bottles sparkling. (When bottling kombucha, there is no such thing as "close enough.")I would purchase them again without hesitation.  I am not certain how well they will hold up over repeated use, thus the 4 star review.  If they prove to be long-lived, I will edit this review and give them the 5th star.

These are decent quality funnels.  The black "grip strips" on the side are very useful in holding the funnel securely in the mouth of a bottle when pouring liquid.Be aware that these are not very big.  The largest is 4 1/2" across and 5 1/2" deep.  It holds 16 oz maximum.  The smaller one is 4" across, and 3 1/2" deep, and holds 5 1/2 oz.  The smaller funnel nests inside the larger one for storage, and both have a handy little handle (clearly seen in the photograph).The included strainer will fit either of the funnels.I make kombucha, and I need a funnel to fill grolsch-type bottles.http://www.amazon.com/CASE-OF-12-Bottles-CLEAR/dp/B0064ODUDK/ref=sr_1_2?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1418681111&sr=1-2&keywords=grolsch+bottlesThe larger funnel is just a tad too big to fit inside the mouth of those bottles. The smaller funnel fits perfectly.These are dishwasher safe, and like other OXO brand products, they are very well made.

I bought this diffuser to use under a glass tea kettle atop a gas range. A person reviewing the kettle said the handle of the kettle would melt without one of these.  Well, that wasn't quite true.  This diffuser does exactly what it is supposed to do.  It diffuses the heat.  It also happens to be larger in diameter than the glass kettle, so it directs a good deal of heat up the sides of the kettle and to the handle.  The only time I ever burned my hand on the handle of the kettle was when I used this diffuser with it.That said, this is actually a great, simple device.If you are cooking something on very low heat (like a pot of rice that is simmering to absorb water), this diffuser will keep the rice from burning or sticking to the bottom of the pot. Likewise, when cooking something like spaghetti sauce or chili. Unless stirred constantly, those foods can burn and stick to the bottom of the pot. Well, not if you use this device!  It spreads the heat around nicely.  It is the same thing with a frying pan.  Sometimes you want a larger heat source than your range can provide, or a gentler one. This is all you need to accomplish that.You can use this on an induction, gas, or electric cook top. Hand washing is recommended. It will discolor from the heat of a burner, but that won't affect its usefulness.So...I bought this based on a review for a totally different reason. It didn't work for that purpose. But I discovered a whole lot of things this diffuser makes cooking easier.  I bought it by mistake, and I am really glad I did.

This is a GREAT whistling kettle.  I like it so much, I bought a second one on the off chance I dropped one and broke it.Here are the highlights:  It holds 12 cups of water. The lid is removable.  The glass is heat resistant, laboratory quality boroscilicate.The handle is heat resistant. The whistle is gentle, not ear piercing. The glass is marked with the minimum amount of water for heating, as well as at the 6 cup level.  The handle stays cool on my gas stove.  You can see when the water begins to steam, form tiny bubbles, and boil. This is handy for brewing green tea, or when heating water for a manual drip or press type coffee maker, where you do not want boiling water, but you do want it very hot.It comes with a little wire "star" for use on a conventional electric range. It is unnecessary to use it on a gas range, but with an electric, put the wire "diffuser" on the burner coils, and then sit this pot on top of it.I use a gas range, so I sit the kettle right on the grate. I use the smallest burner, and I make certain that the flame is NOT licking up the sides of the kettle. If the flame is too high, it will do that, and chances are good that you will burn your hand when you grab the handle.  You might also MELT the handle...not a good thing. So keep the flame reasonable.One person mentioned the Norpro 144 Heat Diffuser as a solution to keeping the handle cool. Perhaps that is the case with an electric range, but on a gas cook top, it actually spreads the heat over too wide an area, wider than the diameter of the glass kettle. Because of that, heat will rise directly to the handle. I bought the Nopro based on that advice (it was in response to a question posted about this kettle), used it once, and burned my hand when I grabbed the handle of the kettle. So if you use a gas range, do not use the Norpro 144 Heat Diffuser.  It will just take longer for the water to boil, and you will need a pot holder to hold the kettle.Dislikes?  Only two, and the first one is nit-picking.  The top must be removed to pour the water.  Hinging it would be more convenient (but that might make cleaning it in the dishwasher harder).  Second: forget a 96 oz (12 cup) capacity.  This kettle holds just about 64 oz (1/2 gallon).Seriously, if you don't do anything like boiling the pot dry, or dousing it with cold water as soon as it comes off the stove, this tea kettle should last a long time.  Actually, the glass is thermal shock resistant, but why tempt fate?

Two adjustable back chaise loungers, with decent quality cushions, for just a bit more than the price of a single lounger.  How can you not like that?I am in central Florida, so these will be used all year.  So far, we love them. The backs are adjustable, they are comfortable, and they look like they will be durable.We never leave cushions on our outdoor furniture, because the bright sun here tends to destroy fabrics of all types. Taking the cushions inside has the advantage of not exposing them to the elements. I'm not sure how well these would hold up if they were outside 24/7/365, but the way we use them, I expect them to be going strong years from now.The chair frames are lightweight, so they will be brought inside in the event of a hurricane. That aside, they just stay outside by the pool.You really cannot beat the value you get with two of these loungers for $249.  And as a bonus, they will be delivered ay appointment at your convenience. The driver brought the package right to where we wanted it, and was here wight on time.  All in all, this was a very good purchasing experience.

Nice, heavyweight container with a full gallon capacity.  It is translucent, so you can see the level of the liquid.  The top is rigid plastic (mine is red, yours might come in a different color.  You can rotate it so the contents just pour, pour through a rudimentary strainer, or don't pour at all (good for preventing spills when carrying a full container).The handle is strong enough that nothing flexes when the container is full and lifted.It appears that this will last quite a while.

I bought these for brewing kombucha.  They are the perfect size, holding just over 5 quarts each.  The only problem with them is the spigots with which they are supplied. Those are cheap plastic with a finish to make then look like metal.I replaced the spigots with these:  2 of Stainless Works™ Stainless Steel Beverage Dispenser Replacement Spigot(Polished Finish)Those spigots are solid stainless steel, won't corrode, don't react with acid liquids, don't leak, and will last forever. Now, these dispensers function PERFECTLY.I have attached a photo showing the upgraded spigots I installed.  Because I am brewing kombucha, I am not using the supplied glass lids.  They are attractive, but I needed something that allows the free passage of oxygen and C02, while keeping contaminants out of the liquid.  That's why the paper towels are being used as lids.  If I were serving beverages with these, I would use the glass lids.These are a terrific buy. They are cost effective and attractive. Just do yourself a favor and upgrade the spigots.  You'll be glad you did.

These are fantastic. They don't leak, they easily replace the cheap plastic spigots that come standard on most beverage dispensers, and they should last forever.I bought a pair of glass beverage dispensers for making kombucha. (2 of Stylesetter Glass Beverage Dispenser- 169-Ounce) The only thing wrong with them was the plastic spigots that were supplied. They were junk.I bought a pair of these stainless spigots, installed them, and they work perfectly.I would buy these again in a heartbeat, but as I said, I expect I won't need to. These things look bulletproof.

I ordered this CD player along with player costing half as much from a different manufacturer. I had every intention of using this as my primary deck, and the less expensive one as a backup.  It didn't work out that way.Operation of the deck is pretty straightforward.  As other reviewers have noted, the drawer doesn't fully open, but that isn't really an issue when it comes to inserting a disc.  It is a major pain, however, when REMOVING a disc.  Unless the user exercises great care, discs will be scratched.  I managed to drop two discs on the floor when removing them from the deck.  Perhaps it's my big hands, but I believe this is more of a design flaw than Yamaha would lead us to believe.Second: if your listening style is anything like mine, you insert a disc, perhaps program a playing order (eliminating a few tracks, maybe changing the order in which they play, etc), get settled into your listening position, and then hit "Play" on the remote.  When you load a disc in this player, the disc loads, is read, and immediately begins playing.  Unless my deck is defective, this is really a dumb feature.Third: "Pure Direct."  One word: FUGGETABOUTIT.  Seriously.  I played Telarc DDD discs on this for evaluation purposes.  It was plugged into an Apt Holman preamp/Apt 1 power amp, and output to Klipsch LaScala speakers.  Cabling to the speakers is Vampire Wire (constructed of four 13AWG conductors. Each conductor is made from 277 strands of wire. Each of the four conductors is formed from three bundles of OFHC, and three bundles of silver plated OFHC. The four conductors are joined to make 2 conductors, which are rated at 10AWG. This cable is laid out in a Star Quad configuration, which is a superior method to attenuate EMI (electromagnetic interference).  I also used the same type of RCA cables to connect the Yamaha to the preamp.  Essentially, with this test setup, you will hear ANY flaw introduced by a component.  With or without the display on, the Yamaha is dead silent (a good thing). Switching between the "Pure Direct" mode (display off), and normal, display on mode, yields an almost unnoticeable difference: with the "Pure Direct" engaged, there was a barely perceptible increase in volume (measured at 0.8db). I could not discern any difference in the quality of the sound.Third: the deal breaker.  The remote for this unit is a joke.  My audio room is dimly lit.  It is sound and light isolated, and the floor, as well as excessively "Bright" wall areas, are carpeted.  The ceiling is acoustic tile.What does this have to do with the remote?  Simple.  It's impossible to see the markings on the thing.  I turned up the lighting, and it was still nearly impossible to read the markings.  I resorted to using the LED flashlight app on my phone in order to be able to see the markings on this remote.  Seriously, Yamaha, I expected more from your design group. A LOT more.Finally, the firmware in this unit is quirky.  Other reviewers have talked about the unit needing to go through the process of looking for a disc, reading the disc, or determining that no disc is present, before allowing the drawer to be opened.  One reviewer resorted to powering down the unit with the drawer partly open. This might not seem like a big deal, but when added to the other issues with this unit, the cumulative effect seriously detracts from the overall experience.  Think of it in this way (an example provided by my wife): "When a woman is badly dressed, you notice the dress.  When a woman is impeccably dressed, you notice the woman."  When that standard is applied to the Yamaha  CD-S300RK, I don't want to notice the CD deck.  It should be all but invisible.  I want to listen to the music being played on it.  The sonic qualities of this CD player are delightful.  The sound is rich, clear, and resonant.  Sadly, the way Yamaha engineers "dressed" it make it impossible to just sit back and enjoy the music.  I find myself noticing the shortcomings of the player, and that detracts from just being able to enjoy the music it produces.  For that reason, I am returning it.  Sorry, Yamaha.  It's like you hit a home run, and then didn't tag all the bases when running them, only to be called "Out" on a technicality.

This is a premium quality dog crate at a bargain basement price.  Well constructed, no assembly required (just unfold it), and more heavy duty than the description would lead you to believe.The door and latch function flawlessly.There is a divider panel included that allows you to make the interior of the crate smaller, which is useful for housebreaking.  (Dogs do not like to make a mess where they sleep, and the divider keeps the dog from having enough room to  use one end of the crate for eliminating waste and the other for sleeping.This is truly a great crate, and should last longer than your dog.

I'll admit it.  I was skeptical.  Yes, it carried the Denon name, but $249 for a feature-laden receiver?  They had to cut corners SOMEWHERE, right?  Nope, not really.First, a bit of a disclosure here.  I am what most would consider an audiophile.  My stereo system has consisted of Klipsch K-Horn speakers as my mains, A Belle Klipsch center channel speaker, and a pair of Klipsch Heresys as my rear (surround) speakers.  For electronics, I have used the flagship receiver models of Yamaha, Denon, and Onkyo.  I still own (and use) Apt Holman and Conrad Johnson separates with my pure audio setup. As for home theater, that's a separate listening space.  For that, I use a Sharp 60" LCD/LED display, original (unmodified) Klipsch La Scala main speakers, A Klipsch Cornwall center channel, and Klipsch Heresy ll rear speakers. I am running an NXG Nx-Bas-50 powered subwoofer for extra extra bass kick.(If you are unfamiliar with these Klipsch Legacy speakers, look them up here on Amazon. They are VERY efficient, providing live concert level (115db) at one meter with one watt of power.  Be prepared for a bit of sticker shock.)What am I using as my home theater receiver?  This Denon AVR-S500BT.  A $249 receiver.My system will show the weaknesses of any component with glaring clarity.  If a receiver is a bit harsh, it is magnified by the speakers.  Same thing for a CD or Blu ray components. I plugged in an inexpensive JVC cd player and popped in a reference digitally recorded performance of the 1812 Overture, and the output hurt my ears. Distortion from the JVC.OK, back to the Denon.  First off, this receiver has a Bluetooth feature that allows you to play the music collection you have stored on your iPhone or Android device, or in the cloud.  This is a very good thing.  If you want the same feature in a low priced Yamaha receiver, you need to purchase a Bluetooth adapter.Now, a word of caution is in order here.  You are going to have to crank the gain way up on the receiver to get acceptable volume levels when using a Bluetooth connection.  For me, that means about 80%.  With less efficient speakers, you may or may not get the volume level high enough to please you.  The first music l played through this receiver came from my phone. I have to say, I was disappointed with the volume level achieved.  Then I thought, "I'll bet a device wired directly into the receiver will give me better volume output."  After all, with 56 watts in, I should not have been able to stay in the room with those speakers.Now, here is the caution: do NOT switch from Bluetooth mode to CD or DVD mode without first lowering the volume!  I made that "One D ten T" error (1D1OT).  In the split second between the time I hit "Play" and when the sound started, I had an "Oh crap" moment.  Before I could react, the explosion of sound from my speakers caused a window to shatter and two fluorescent light tubes to explode. I know my wife was yelling at me, but I couldn't hear a thing.  I DO know I was grinning from ear to ear.The lesson here is that streaming music via Bluetooth will not give you nearly the volume levels that you get from a wired connection.  Not even close.  This was my first experience using my phone as wireless music source.  I won't forget it any time soon!The receiver provides 140 Watts/channel peak output.  That should be sufficient to power almost any home theater setups.  And please note that there are 5 discreet amps, with 70W continuous output per channel in this unit,  to power your main speakers, center channel, surrounds (rear speakers), and subwoofer.  This doesn't mean you cannot use a powered subwoofer with this system, because you can (and I do).There is an AV pass-through, so you can just watch your television without turning on the receiver.  And there are 5 HDMI inputs, allowing you to hook up more HDMI devices than you likely own (including game consoles).  There are also dual subwoofer inputs, allowing the use of two subs, and supporting LFE.  There is a single HDMI output for connecting one display.Do you have a 3D display?  This receiver fully supports 3D.  I am beginning to think that the list of what it cannot do is shorter than the list of things it can.  Worrying about obsolescence?  Don't.  Ultra HD 4K 60 Hz video pass-through, along with 4:4:4 Pure Color highest resolution sub-sampling, by way of the HDMI and gaming inputs.Initial setup is a breeze, but again, a caution.  To do the initial receiver evaluation, I hooked up my mains and center channel speaker only.  There is an onscreen setup assistant that makes setup a breeze.  Except when that 1D10T error recurs.  After telling the Denon I had 2 front speakers and a center channel speaker, and no rear channel and no subwoofer, I began listening to the output of this receiver in earnest.  I was pretty certain I was going to turn the receiver on, listen to a few audio tracks and part of a DVD, and then box the unit up and return it.  I mean, seriously, how good could a $249 receiver actually be?Well, VERY good.  I liked what I was listening to, and spent the remainder of the afternoon viewing the Blu Ray version of "Top Gun" and "Black Hawk Down."  Then I shut the system down.Two days later, I came back to the system, plugged in an NXG NX-BAS-500 subwoofer, and and the Klipsch Heresy ll rear speakers, completing the setup.  I fired up the system, and was totally underwhelmed.  I couldn't get any power to the subwoofer.  I spent an hour checking connections, reading the sub's manual, and talking to the vendor.  No joy.  I swapped out the subwoofer cable, eliminating that as a cause.  I was about to go out and buy a 3.5mm to RCA cord so I could plug my smartphone directly into the subwoofer to see if the sub was dead, when I decided just to sit back and think about the problem.  I put a CD in the player, sat on the sofa, and realized that there was no sound coming from my rear speakers either.  Hmmm.  Was the receiver faulty?It was not.  When I did the initial setup, I told the Denon I had 2 front speakers and a center channel.  No subwoofer.  No rear speakers.I went back into setup (there is a setup button on the remote), told he Denon I had a subwoofer and rear speakers, and everything worked just fine.  The receiver had shut off the amps that were not being used.  So be aware, if you set up the system as, say, a 2.1, you will need to go back into setup if you decide to add additional speakers or a subwoofer.  If you don't, the additional speakers won't work.You can also use an included microphone (it has a long cable) to set the sound levels of each speaker.  The best way to do this is to turn off all florescent lighting, air conditioners, and anything else that might be picked up by the mic.  Put the mic on a tripod at your normal listening position, and let the receiver do its thing while you wait quietly in another room.  Your speakers will be emitting sounds which the mic picks up and delivers to the receiver, which in turn sets appropriate volume levels for each speaker.  This is going to get you pretty close, but you will still need to tweak the levels to suit your tastes.Here's another great feature: if you use different settings for different sources, the receiver will remember those settings, so you don't have to make adjustments every time you change input sources.  This is a big time saver and convenience feature.Sonically, the receiver is very pleasant sounding, and easy to operate.  The tuner section is more sensitive than a Yahama RX-V475 I borrowed from a friend for comparison purposes.  This receiver will tune LOTS of stations (about 3 times as many as the Yamaha against which I measured it).As previously mentioned, the Klipsch speakers will quickly showcase any weak link in your system (including cable quality).  I can detect no IM distortion, no harshness, and indeed, no "color."  You hear what was recorded.  Visually, the images on the display  are true, with no added "noise."  I have not tried the AVR-S500BT with an Ultra Hi-Def monitor, but I have every reason to believe the results will be stunning.If you have speakers that are highly inefficient, this might not be the best receiver choice.  But barring that, you can spend double the money and not get much more power, or nearly as many features.  Denon has a real winner here.  I am not certain how long they will hold this price point.  Normally the name "Denon" is not used in the same sentence with the term "low cost."  In this case, you get all the quality, features 95% of buyers will never use, and an affordable package.  That, in my book, is not just a home run, it's a grand slam.Well done, Denon.  Well done indeed.

I purchased this blender from Woot, which I believe is an Amazon company.  It is, in a word, fantastic.I have used it to grind oats, millet, almonds, and brown rice into flour.  It handles the job effortlessly.I make a morning smoothie with almond milk, berries, banana, raw pumpkin and sunflower seeds (hulled), fresh ginger, and lots of ice.  Everything is completely smooth (not gritty or lumpy) in about 6 seconds.  And I have put water into the jar, added kale, cucumber, beet, chard, and carrots, and blended on high for about 10 seconds.  This makes an amazing "green" juice that contains all the fiber of the plants.I have also mixed fresh coconut and water, and had perfectly smooth coconut milk in 8 seconds flat.Every task I have thrown at this blender has been handled with ease.It is surprisingly quiet for having such a powerful motor.  The jar sits loosely atop the base.  That concerned me, so I called Omega, and talked with Robert in Customer Service.  He assured me this was normal.  Just place your hand lightly on top of the jar when blending (or chopping, grating, ice crushing, etc).Speaking of the jar, it has a unique internal shape that greatly facilitates proper blending, and eliminates the need for a push tool (as used by Vitamix).It has a variable speed control, as well as a "pulse" switch.  The pulse switch is useful when you are want to coarsely grate something.  I use this function for making gazpacho. Two quick 1/2 second pulses, and carrots, peppers, onions and celery are at the perfect consistency.The only warning I have is this: the blender will not likely fit beneath cabinets on your counter top.  It's pretty tall.Warranty wise, it's the best in the business: 10 years, parts and labor.  Having gone through Oster and Waring blenders at the rate of one/year for a number of years, I suspect this will be the last blender I ever buy.

This product smells wonderful.  That is all well and good, but I didn't bu it as an aromatherapy product, but to sooth my old, arthritic joints.  Used in that capacity, it failed miserably.I had my wife massage a good amount of this into my aching shoulder, and I rubbed it into my hands and ankles.  Nothing.  And when I say nothing, I mean precisely that.  Nothing: no heat, no cooling, no sensation whatsoever.Later in the day I showered, and applied some of her Tiger Balm Red to my hands and ankles.  Instant, soothing heat. (To  be fair, it Tiger Balm doesn't smell as good as the Badger, but it works as advertised.)  Then I had my wife massage some Biofreeze into my shoulder. Instant cooling, followed by deep heat that lasted about 4 hours.Badger may work for you, and it has certainly worked for others.  For me, however, it was a waste of money, packaged in a pretty tin..

My wife loves this stuff.  She deals with moderate to severe pain since losing a food deal of muscle, bone, and nerves from her lower leg following surgery to remove a tumor.  She says this is the only topical treatment that provides any measure of relief.Tiger Balm has been around since forever, and has stood the test of time.  This particular product is put up in tins, rather than in the tiny glass jars we have purchased in the past.  That is a very good thing, as the tins will not shatter when dropped on a hard floor.  And yes, we had that happen.This is the most cost effective way to purchase Tiger Balm we have found to date.  Until they begin to package this in 55 gal. drums, we will be buying these 3 packs again and again.

Now that I have been using this product for a few days, I have some observations.  First: this gel goes on cool, heats up within a few minutes, peaks in about 15 minutes, and continues to provide deep, intense warmth for 3-4 hours.  The gel is not greasy, doesn't stain clothing or upholstered furniture, and smells great.Compared to Tiger Balm Red, it provides more soothing warmth, has a nicer smell, and the effects last longer.  The difference between this and Badger Sore joint rub is literally the difference between fire and water, Biofreeze being the fire.  And compared to Icy Hot, the effects last longer, it smells better, and is more cost effective when purchased in the quart pump container.60+ years of use and abuse has taken its toll on my body.  College football left me with shoulder and knee issues, and now my ankles and hands are arthritic.  While Biofreeze doesn't "cure" anything, it takes the pain away, saving me from needing to resort to narcotic pain relievers.  It works, the effects last, and the cost per application is low.  Add it all up, and this is a winner.And don't waste your money spending $10-$20 for a 4 oz tube.  At $40, the quart is a deal.  Next time I need to purchase this, I will be looking for the gallon size.  Yes, it's that good.

Great bags.  Perfect seals.  Excellent price.The only thing I would change would be the numbers: if you are anything like me, you will use twice as many pints as quarts, and twice as many quarts as gallons.  So for me, 80 pint, 50 quart and 20 gallon bags would be a better assortment.  That said, I would buy this again in a heartbeat.The quality is the same (or better) than the FoodSaver brand, at a fraction of the price.  You will be happy with these bags.Update 12/17/14  I just ordered this deal again. Almost all of the original 150 bags have been used.  I have sealed everything from leftover turkey soup (frozen first in a small stainless bowl) to steaks, ribs, fish, pre-made meals, fresh berries, etc. etc.I have not had a single seal failure. These bags are every bit as good as the Foodsaver brand, and they won't bankrupt you.Don't be fooled by the low price. These are first rate bags at a bargain basement price.

...and that is a mixed blessing.  Character development is much better than season 1, and we can begin to tell the good guys from the bad guys.  This is the season that allows you to decide who you like and who you don't.  The episodes have some great plot lines (arguably better than anything SG1 and Atlantis offered), and Dr. Rush actually shows his wry sense of humor.All of this is a mixed blessing, because the franchise was cancelled at the end of this season.  It happened abruptly.  The last episode of the year set up year 3, but there was no year 3.  It was as though the ship exploded between seasons, taking the cast and crew with it.  While it is more likely the franchise wasn't picked up for a 3rd year, this was a lousy way to end the series.  The unrealized potential of SGU is truly a loss for Stargate fans.  Sadly, the series wasn't picked up by another network, as was SG1.A few of the episodes are haunting, and I find myself thinking about them days (and weeks) after viewing them.

This series is different than the two Stargate series that came before it.  The first season is very dark- dimly lit sets, an impending sense that the players are all doomed, and very slow character development.  It is seriously difficult to tell if most of the main characters are good people or carrying out some evil, hidden agenda.While the story line develops slowly, it does so surely, and some of the episodes are priceless.

Evangeline Andersons story entitled Mastering the Mistress had me jumping for joy as it's part of her awesome Kindred series! Following on from the book Enslaved we meet Solar a Havoc warrior who has been drugged and offered for sale as a sex slave! He is bought by the sheltered and completely out of her depth Kaylee but on the matriarchal planet Solar finds himself on men are considered savage brutes frequently abused and worthless . Kaylee is unsure just what to make of Solar but as treachery stretches out it's hand it's her slave who will save her. Can Kaylee let him go?This story was previously featured in the anthology Mastered 2 but if followers of the Kindred series missed it this is an excellent opportunity to catch up. Expect a strong alpha male showing the female of his dreams just how important to him she really is and prepare to need a cold shower as this talented author yet again turns up the heat. If this series is new to you and you enjoy hot sci fi then start at the beginning with Claimed and enjoy the journeyI was gifted a copy of this in exchange for an honest review

If like me you have read the prequel Accepting the Moon then you will be well acquainted with new werewolf and all round Alpha Mena. Mena had lived with her cheating , lying husband for twelve years when one night everything came to a head and she realised the relationship was well and truly dead in the water. Leaving Mark was a no brainer for Mena but unknown to her Mark was a werewolf and a very possessive one at that! A chance meeting with Jaxon a vampire sends her in a totally new direction as Mark and his Pack try to hunt her down leaving Mena no choice but to defend herself and then boy is the cat left well and truly amongst the pigeons ! Mena kills Mark which makes her the new Alpha and then of course there's Jaxons king to deal with but it would seem that Phoenix is about to make life even more complicated for the new Alpha!Mena is trying hard to sort out her feelings but one thing is sure not all her Pack are happy to see her! Ok select a new Beta , avoid being arrested for murder and somehow convince the Pack that an alliance with Phoenix and his vampires is a good thing. First problem is twenty seven step up to be her number two which is crazy! Second problem Menas inner wolf wants to climb the very human detective Alex like a tree! Oh and there's no love lost between vampires and wolves and someone is trying very hard to destroy both Mena and Phoenix. Can this woman catch a break? Apparently not as Menas inner wolf has ideas of her own and Mena feels herself slipping away whilst outside forces begin to attack her Pack!This is very unusual story and unlike any other I've read. The relationships are well and truly messed up with Mena insanely attracted to Phoenix but this seven hundred year old vampire is not sure he knows how to love. Her wolf keeps taking over and as she gets stronger it's clear she would kill Phoenix in order to be with Alex. An uneasy compromise is reached but I felt uncomfortable with the solution if honest and my heart ached for those involved. Alex might be innocent and unaware of what's under his nose but Phoenix stepped aside to protect the woman he is increasingly coming to care for. No he isn't perfect far from it and makes all kinds of mistakes but his arrogant armpit tendencies are forgivable as we watch him hurt and yet never give in. I struggle with Mena at times though. Yes it's all new to her but to this reader she switches from weak to loud and in charge and then petulant and I got whiplash from her constant dilly dallying. I like you , I don't like you, I'm going, I'm staying yes you get the idea that this female is not my favourite heroine. What I really liked though were the supporting characters as they really helped flesh this unusual story out and added so much to the plot. We've met wolves and vampire so why not add witches and lions to the mix? You will laugh at these characters and perhaps even roll your eyes but the last third of this book is anything but dull and the last page will leave you crying out for moreI was gifted a copy in exchange for an honest review

I just finished this and it's another super quick read that's humorous and very entertaining. If you enjoy characters with insane internal monologues than you will lap up the were ferret Melanie. Her character was introduced in the previous book Hunting a Mate when it became very apparent that her boyfriend Harvey was a total piece of work! Now she is single and has taken back control of her life but that no good and hugely overly self opinionated waste of space just refuses to take no for an answer ,Foster is a were bear with anger issues and to be honest has probably given up on ever finding that special female who should be his. That all changes when a small and curvy female arrives on the construction site he's working on. Now if only she hadn't driven off before he could show her just how good a bear is at devouring honey! Ok track her down is first on his list but finding out he has competition could very well push both man and bear too far!I love these quirky fun stories that seem to be set around a rather unique dating agency. It's hilarious as such diverse species get paired off and a bear and a ferret just add to the madness and mayhem. Very adult language and sexy shananigans abound in these stories but I thought this one a little too quick and have to warn that it's quite a violent instalment . This couple are such fun but it just seemed to end a little to quickly for this reader. If short sexy reads are your thing then this series might just be what you are looking for.I was gifted a copy in exchange for an honest reviewThree and a half from me

Finally we get inside the very private life of Roth the seriously formidable leader of Squad Nine and wow what a rush this story is ! Ms Hackett has come up with a fabulous addition to her Hell Squad series featuring those humans who have banded together in the Blue Mountain military installation . Constantly taking on the aliens who have invaded Earth these brave men and women still have time to play but for Roth there's only one woman who really appeals but is she really friend or foe?Avery was an agent for the Coalition and indeed was in the front line when initial contact with the Gizzida was made. She was found by Roth in an experimental tank but claims to have little to no memory of just how she came to be in the aliens laboratory. The gaps in Averys memory hold clues but accessing her memories is proving almost impossible. Step forward one very determined and obsessed Roth but it soon becomes apparent that safety within the complex might just have been compromised!This is by far my favourite book in this series. I do enjoy sci fi but it's usually the sort that features sexy aliens ( yes I'm a bit shallow!) and these books show just how loving and tough humans can be. Fast paced with great dialogue and white hot scenes that feel believable . The world is in chaos and it feels right to celebrate what life is left and these battle hardened troops sure know how to let their hair down! It's not all romance though as it's a very strong storyline that seems to be expanding with each book. It's almost as if the more the survivors learn about the enemy the more we as readers get drawn in. Gruesome creatures to make the reader squirm but as we learn in this story sometimes humans can be just as callous and maybe more so. I love the supporting characters and the dynamics really work very well. I suspect that technical genius Noah might feature next which would be awesome sauce! For now though I'm delighted to state that this fast, action packed story is very entertaining and I'm so pleased I found time to read itI was gifted a copy in exchange for an honest review

Ok this is very short so please buyer beware. That being stated it's a quick easy read that has its own unique world building. A young woman has a serious car crash and wakes up in hospital feeling and looking like herself but on the best day possible. When Eliza's released early she notices a turn on the road that wasn't there before but those who live there are definitely not the normal suburban types! Now luckily a sexy guy is around to answer her questions but as the story ends this reader is sadly left with far too many questions unanswered. Expect lust, instant attraction and sweaty sex.I was gifted a copy in exchange for an honest review

Well this book was a welcome return to the couple that started it all human Caitlin and vampire Kane. They were the first couple the author played around with but their turbulent journey was clearly far from over. As this book starts Caitlin is struggling with her work at the agency as few of her coworkers actually trust her anymore. Indeed most of this story does actually impinge on trust issues as the author well and truly hangs her characters out to dry! This couple have huge issues and although as a reader we are privy to their innermost feelings and inadequcies most of this story revolves around the suffering they put each other through.Now I'd hate anyone to imagine it's just about the tangled relationship and hasten to reassure that the author has one or two more tricks up her sleeve. First there are creatures from the fabled fourth dimension appearing in Blackthorn and then there's the tricky murder investigation that Caitlin is involved in. Kane seems determined to derail her but why? Clearly he is protecting Caleb but what does it all have to do with the much feared prophecy?
