I felt that the best character was the Duke's younger sister.A few things didn't quite ring true to the time period such as: the speedy divorce wherein the two parties involved never once met face-to-face and the third named party to adultery never gave testimony or appeared in court; the Duke printing his private business in the newspaper voluntarily; and the former duchess being turned out with no marriage settlements at all-not even her dowry returned to her-even in the case of divorce (although I suppose it is possible).There are sexual scenes, some violence and some mild language insulting to women. 3 1/2 stars.Heat factor hot.

This prequel to a new series is well written and well edited with realistic characters who are struggling with some issues in their relationship. Having started their relationship off with an unplanned pregnancy, they weren't on a firm base of a solid romance and security in their love for each other. The passion and closeness that Ian and Carrie once felt has been stifled over the years under the daily struggles of making a living, caring for their two children, paying the bills and all the every day things that take time away from togetherness.  With things reaching a breaking point, can they save their marriage?This story contains sexual scenes but no violence or profanity. 3 1/2 stars.Heat factor hot.

This book is the first in a series about a group of former military specialists who now work together as "good guy" mercenaries as the Titan Group. The story is well written and well edited into an exciting, chase filled, shoot-em-up plot, with a romance mixed in. The damsel in distress, psychologist Mia Kensington, turns out to be able to hold her own against drug cartel goons and former SEAL / Titan member, Colby Winters.There is a lot of coarse language and violence in the story, along with sexual scenes and some planned sexual violence. There are also some surprisingly deep family ties between the Titan members and some interesting aspects to both Colby and Mia's lives that give the story some depth and perspective. Overall I enjoyed the fast pacing of this story and will seek out other books in the series.Heat factor hot.

I enjoyed this book which was well written and well edited. The characters were complex and interesting and had good development and dialogue. The plot had some intriguing twists and turns along with a not-too-evil villain, so there isn't any violence or profanity, but the book still holds the reader's attention until the end.The main characters are the secretly radical Robert Blaisdell, Duke of Clermont and the supposedly quiet country miss, Wilhelmina Purseling, who has her own secrets and scandalous past. The Duke, his cousin and his bastard half brother, lefties all, earned themselves the name "the brothers sinister" while at Eaton together and those gents make a good supporting cast in this story ( and the heros in the others of this series).  There are sexual scenes in this book, but only very minor violence and no profanity. I enjoyed this book and look forward to others in the series. There is a prequel to this as well, involving the previous Duke of Clermont and the origin of Robert's half brother.Heat factor hot.

I really enjoyed this book. The writing was excellent and editing professional. The plot was character based, there were no truly evil villains, but the development of the multiple romances and their complications were what drove the storyline.  The author did a nice job of character development as well, making them believable and understandable people.I loved Miss Jane Fairfield with her horrible dresses and outrageous conversation! She was a very clever, warm hearted person dedicated to protecting her younger sister from charlatan medical practitioners. Oliver Marshall was an excellent hero as well. He was very quick to see beneath Jane's game, but it took him longer to see how she could be his match. I do love a man who can outwit the would be bad guys and admit that he was wrong to a woman!There are several sexual scenes and mild violence described in this story. I have been enjoying this series and plan to continue on.Heat factor hot.

I very much enjoyed these first two books in the Vinlanders' Saga, along with the bonus short story which the author cleverly incorporated as the prologue to Book 3, even though it originally appeared as a short story. The writing is excellent and although there are one or two typos, the editing is professional. The characters are interesting and the plot is well paced, there is a enough of the magical to make it a good fantasy, but nothing that throws the book into the realm of the unbelievable. (You know how that goes... and then a miracle happens, and they all live happily ever after....) No one character is perfect, they all are believable as people and come with good and bad traits. No character ever gains a huge amount of power or changes into a messiah-like figure either. Very nice.Celia Montrose is a 911 call center manager in Tucson who also has a great interest in Native American art, just as her mother did. She's managed to get the location of some petroglyphs through various sources and goes with a guide to photograph them, intending to keep the location secret so they won't be vandalized. When they get close, though, her guide refuses to go any further, insisting that he will wait for her but won't go where "the spirits walk". As she goes into the narrow ravine to photograph the fantastic petroglyphs, Cele feels that something is wrong, but before she can leave, the petroglyphs start moving, a rainbow appears, and she wakes up in a desert at night with stars that don't match any constellations she's ever seen before. Dressed only in shorts and a t-shirt for a day hike, with only one water bottle left, Cele almost dies of exposure before she's found by a group of soldiers who are, of all things, Vikings.Cele discovers that this world she has somehow been sent to is called Alfheim by the Vikings who were sent there almost a century ago by their gods Baldur and Freyr and they still hold to the ways they had when they came to this land from what they called Greenland in Midgard. Also living in this land are the Native American looking Tewas, whose art looks like that of the Anasazi, live in cliffside homes and who have been in this land longer than the Vikings, also brought over on a rainbow bridge during a time of great hardship by their gods. The third race of people in the land are the Elves, for whom the Vikings named the land Alfheim. There are many types of the fey, but they rarely interact with humans. The light elves are good and helpful and made a bargain with the gods not to interfere or directly harm the humans. The dark elves hate the humans and do not necessarily keep to this bargain.Book 1 deals primarily with Celia finding her place in this new world and society. All of the Vikings have developed a "talent" since coming to this world: finding water, seeing great distances, stoneworking, pathfinding, etc... As Celia develops a relationship with the man who found her, the Jarl's son, Lord Dahleven, she also develops a talent for finding things, a talent someone will want to use for ill.  Book 2  deals with the Jarl's second son, the second in hierarchy to the jarldom and the priesthood of Baldur, Lord Ragnor. There is, of course, much more to the story,  many adventures, lots of Viking and Anasazi lore, along with battles, romance and magic.Both stories were very enjoyable and I went on to read book 3. The author did a great job of world building and character development and I look forward to more stories set in this world. There are sexual scenes and violence, (and also for those with trigger issues, attempted / threatened sexual assault) but no profanity.Heat factor moderate.

A classic rock and roll single that you don't hear too often on the radio. I heard it the other day on a 're-run of the TV show "Supernatural" and couldn't get it out of my head. Now I don't have to hunt it down.
Another favorite track of mine from the Brits. Nice beat and clever lyrics, what more do you need? $.69 price? Done.
I've always liked this track and it gets the blood pumping for doing anything that requires energy, Happy I picked it up.
No doubt about it, Carlos Santana deserves every award he's received. This is a wonderful track, classic Santana with nice collaboration.

The first thing I have to say is that this book needs an editor. Although the dialogue is meant to sound like that of a 15 year old, it is strangely stilted by the odd absence of contractions in conversations. Also, the author has many misspellings and incorrect grammar usages within the story, along with the occasional incomplete sentence.The plot follows mainly Maddie, a 15 year old sophomore who is dating Ben, the 18 year-old senior that she was tutoring. They have a birth control failure and an unplanned pregnancy, but are supported by her mother (herself a single parent) in raising the baby. His parents throw him out for this decision and he moves into her mother's pool house, working and paying some rent while being there for Maddie and going to school. Maddie's cousin, Allison, who is the same age and is like a sister, is also pregnant and dating Ben's best friend Chance.The author gives a realistic account of some of the issues facing teens who are pregnant-social stigma and peer isolation, inability to stay in school due to physical complications, medical complications, increased risk of multiple births and increased risk of cesarean delivery. Although having been an OB-GYN and Labor and Delivery Nurse for many years (and the mother of 3), I felt she may have laid it on a bit thick with the physical misery. The author also throws in some serious emotional trauma during the pregnancy which further complicates things for Maddie, and for Allison as well. There are Christian themes throughout and no sexual scenes. Maddie remains sure that she will reach her goals of completing high school and going to college, despite raising children, so I appreciate that message.Overall, the book could use a good realism and editing overhaul, but I think the author has a well intentioned message. This is a clean read, no sex, profanity or violence.

This is the first offering that I've read by this author and it was well written and well edited but I found it unsatisfying. It is difficult to really establish characters in a short story and I just didn't get a good sense of the depths of the main characters previous relationship nor the reason for the heroine's continued deep resentments and cynicism. The author does find room for some steamy scenes, though.  Overall, this story just fell into the average category for me.Heat factor hot.

I'm a big fan of Kieran Kramer's historical romance novels, but this is the first contemporary romance of hers that I have read. I received a free copy of the ebook version as part of a contest by the publisher through Book Reviews and More by Kathy, with no obligation to review this book.I liked this well written, well edited story which had interesting main  and supporting characters, especially the H/h's siblings with varying degrees of Asberger's syndrome, which the author dealt with sympathetically and humorously. The hero and heroine were both complex and well rounded characters. I especially liked the way True found her own voice and confidence as the story went on. The plot was character driven, there were no mysteries, just the story of developing relationships, but there is more than one romance in the book.I enjoyed the story of two people who were friends as children but separated by her parents because the boy was from the wrong side of the trailer park. True Maybank was raised on a beautiful estate to be a Southern belle debutante and had her duty to her family name and history drilled into her as long as she could remember. She was expected to marry the son of the neighbor family and unite the two most important families in town. She dutifully dated Dubose Waring, the golden boy quarterback. Secretly, she cherished her childhood friend, Harrison Gamble, with whom she had spent so many happy hours until her parents forbade it when she was 12. On the night of Senior Prom, Dubose acted like a real jerk and left with another girl.  Harrison crashed the prom and True left with him and they spent the night together. The next morning, Harrison was ready to set off for Nashville to pursue his dreams and he asked True to come with him. When she chose to stay and follow her plans for college, it broke his heart (and hers), but she couldn't disappoint her family or leave her sister.Ten years later, True sees Harrison on the way out of the store where she has just picked up her wedding dress. He's a huge country music star and he's come home to see his brother and look for some musical inspiration. True's parents died and she never finished college. Harrison Gamble is now a household name and a multimillionaire. She has had to turn her beloved gracious family home into a U-pick farm in order to have a business and sell off all the antique furniture just to hold onto the property. She does all the work herself with help from teen labor and her teenage sister, whom she's raised since her parents died. She's finally supposed to marry the man her parents wanted her to marry, even though he dropped her when they died. Dubose's now an attorney and is promising her financial security after they're wed. Harrison is shocked to find out that the tables have been turned and just how far. He realizes that all his songs have been about True and he wants to win her over before she gets married to that stick in the mud Dubose.Can the singer charm the proper lady into becoming the girl she used to be in just a month? And what would it mean for his career if he settled down? Can he really make that kind of commitment, because True is a settle down, put down roots kind of girl? There are some sexual scenes and some mild profanity in this book.Heat factor moderate.

I enjoyed this book which was well written and well edited. The author does a nice job creating a feeling of being on a ranch in the west in this 1800's. The characters were interesting and likeable and they had complicated secrets in their pasts that were slowly revealed over the course of the story. A lot of time was devoted to character development and relationship growth between them. I really liked the way the author handled this, no instalust to be found. The plot was fairly character based, following their relationships, until the end when some intrigue and danger are added in to bring the story to an exciting finish. There is no sex in this story, only kissing, and no profanity, but there is some violence. I would like to read the sequel since I liked the brothers so much.Heat factor mild.

I enjoyed this story, the first I've read by this author. The story was well written and only had a few editing errors, mostly spelling issues and punctuation problems, but not enough to detract from the story. The plot was very good, the author kept the suspense going throughout the story and keeping interest right up to the end. The characters were complex and interesting and do a lot of development during the story.The author did a good job establishing a sense of place in describing the small town in Alaska and it's interesting inhabitants. These supporting characters lent an authenticity to the story and were welcome additions to the story. Rene was very brave to concoct a plan to leave her violently abusive and controlling husband and to try to get her young children to a safe place far away from him. Her sister, Maddy and her brother-in-law were very supportive in helping her with plans, new ID, lining up a job and transportation, etc...Maddy even posed as Rene on a plane with her children to be a decoy. As a volunteer at a battered women's shelter, Maddy had these resources available to help her sister. But when her enraged brother-in-law came after her looking for his missing wife, Maddy got a taste of what it was like to be abused. She had to hire a bodyguard, was forced to stay at home after being run off the road, and essentially became his victim as well.Meanwhile, Rene and her son and daughter were learning how to laugh, make friends,.relax and sleep peacefully. They were gaining confidence and learning how to love. Rene felt useful as a teacher and part of a community. She also felt empowered by learning to shoot a gun for self defense. They didn't know what lengths her husband would go to find her and what payback he planned when he did.This book contains a sexual scene, some profanity and violence.Heat factor moderate.

This was an interesting premise for a book and the first in a series. I enjoyed meeting the characters that form the core of the small group of friends who grew up together and around whom the series is based. The author lovingly describes the scenery of the ranch land of Montana and the life of a rancher/cowboy and one has to assume she has some knowledge of the subject matter. The plot is a bit quirky. Several of the friends are known for playing elaborate practice jokes on each other and it's Rob's turn to pay Ethan back for a really embarrassing one. Their other two best friends just keep tallies. I liked the main characters, they were real and likeable people. Even the bad tempered women mellowed out by the end of the book. I am looking forward to reading more books in this series.One night after his parents died and his fiancee left him when she discovered the extent of his debts, Ethan got a bit drunk at the local bar and began expounding on what kind of woman it would take to ever get him to propose to anyone again. Rob taped this drunken rant on his cell phone, edited it up nice and pretty and posted it on YouTube as a rancher looking for a bride. Because Ethan is a technophobe, he had no idea, but the other 3 musketeers were in on the joke. They got over 200 responses to the e-ad and the three friends picked out a wife and bought her a round trip ticket to Montana, not telling Ethan until they were at the airport. He's stunned by the beauty who gets off the plane, she's not a stuck up, high maintenance city girl, but a natural and nice person and he can't just put her back on the plane.Autumn is the second of 2 daughters of a highly successful single mom who has high expectations for her children to never be dependent on a man. But Autumn is struggling to make it as a writer for a magazine in NYC, and hasn't ever felt like she measured up to her mom's standards. As a last ditch effort to save her job, she answered the ad for a wife on YouTube hoping she could get a story out of it. She and her best friend exaggerated her skills when they made her video (although she really does secretly want to get out of the city, loves to cook and wants to have children) and she was shocked when she got chosen and that her editor accepted her story pitch. Autumn is bowled over by the ruggedly handsome cowboy who meets her at the airport, he's not the rube she expected.For two people starting a supposed relationship under false pretenses, there are some serious sparks flying when they first meet and start to get to know each other. Neither wants to tell the other that it's a joke, so they give it a month to get to know each other. Whose secrets will come out first? Whose past or present problems will be the straw that breaks the camel's back? Can something like this really work in this day and age?This book contains sexual scenes and some profanity.Heat factor hot.

I read this book a week ago and found that something bothered me but I couldn't put it into words, so I read it again. I am a big fan of Julia London's and I  really wanted to love this book, but there were some niggling things that maybe shouldn't have bothered me so much, but like something stuck in a tooth, they did. Details, details....I read a lot of historical romance and regency romance in particular and there were a few things that were missing that I just couldn't overlook. Where was Honor's maid? When she was sneaking out of the house and getting up to all kinds of mischief, there is never a mention of any maid. In fact, for the household of an earl, only one maid is ever mentioned and that is their mother's. Honor never rides out with a groom in the park, nor has a maid accompany her shopping. No young woman of a ton household would have been able to get away with this. It just isn't done. Also, her dresses are mentioned in great detail several times and she would require assistance to dress.The next thing that bothered me is that Honor calls, unaccompanied again, on a single gentleman's house in broad daylight on several occasions. She even remarks that his home is surrounded by old women of the ton who would love to gossip about it, but somehow, no one ever mentions any of her visits. None of the neighbors in Mayfair saw a crest marked coach drop off one of the most popular young women of the social set at his door? Really?The other problem I had was just that the book was pretty sexual from the get go. For being an innocent miss, George talks to Honor  in a very bawdy way, using words he would never use to any other innocent young woman. The liberties she allows him, I know are supposed to show their great attraction to each other, but instead I felt it showed George in a bad light for taking such liberties with her, and more than once. Don't get me wrong, I'm not a prude, but I think it was too much, too fast. And for being a bastard himself, one would think that the man who was rejected by his royal sire would practice some safe sex and not risk any more little unplanned babies. Just a thought.Now there were things that I did like about this book. I really liked the family relationship between the Cabot sisters and their individual personalities. I even liked their older half brother in his own bumbling, clumsy way. I liked how the truth about her mother's motives came creeping up on his fiance Monica and how it changed her perspectives. I loved how the whole family tried to protect the girls' mother in her confusion and descent into dementia. And I liked Honor as a person who did her very best to try and solve her family problems, even if it wasn't a very good plan. I didn't find her to be spoiled or selfish, just a little desperate. I liked George for being a man of principle and trying to stop Honor at first, and then for not wanting to take a wife if he couldn't support her, even if he was unnecessarily cruel in the means he chose to employ.The last chapter of the book shows us Grace in an uneasy situation, so I look forward to reading the next book also. I have great hopes for it, because, as I said, I am a fan of the author and rarely am disappointed with her work.Heat factor hot.

I enjoyed this story, the first time I've read anything by this author, and found it to be well written and well edited. The main characters were likeable and interesting and the plot complex enough to hold my interest through the entire book. The supporting characters were also endearing and infuriating by turns and rounded out the storyline well. The villain actually was a surprise to me, and that doesn't happen often in romance novels. My only complaint would be that sometimes the dialogue was very formal, as if it came straight out of a Jane Austen novel, and sometimes it would be more modern in tone, but that is a minor style notation that didn't detract from the story itself. I will be looking for other titles by this author. There was only mild sexual content, profanity and violence in this book.Heat factor moderate.

This was a great read and a new twist on a zombie theme! I'm not a decaying body parts/ brain eating zombie theme fan, but this one looked interesting and I am so glad that I picked it up. The story is well written and well edited with complex and interesting characters and a fast paced plot with enough intrigue to keep readers hooked to the last page. Jesse is an excellent heroine; sarcastic, scared, emotionally vulnerable, brave and loyal. She is a fully realized character, but one who can continue to grow as the series progresses. There are several other main support characters; Ally, Lane, Gloria, Garrison and Brinkley who are also well written, but not as fully fleshed out as Jesse, though they'll be around in the next book for more adventures, I'm sure.I loved this new take on the zombie theme. I'm sorry, please don't call them the "z" word, they're necronites, the 2% of the population that spontaneously regenerates itself after death,(unless beheaded, of course). It's this group of people, many of whom never realize their status, who in this version gave rise to the vampire legends and other spontaneous resurrection stories. When the government discovered their existence, they were put into the "protective custody" of the military, which meant all sorts of testing and experimentation to see if the perfect soldier could be created and what types of deaths needed how much regeneration time, etc.... When the public outcry over this treatment allowed them to be set free, many hid their status. Now some of them are employed, like our feisty heroine, Jesse, as death replacement agents. Some of the soldiers and others that the military experimented on became A.M.P.'s (please don't call them psychic) who can foretell someone's untimely death from non-disease causes by interpreting the magnetic resonance fields and disturbances in them -essentially visions. If the person has the money and desire, they can employ a necronite to be with them at the time of death and to die in their place. The necronite then regenerates for a few days and goes on with their life, as does the client. Unfortunately, the government has recently changed to a much more conservative party and all the churches in the country united under one gigantic doctrine, promising no more religious infighting. "The Church" is very powerful and it hates the necronites who may disprove their Savior's resurrection, and actively campaign to kill them. In the book, the author deals not only with Jess's experiences as a death replacement agent, but also with a bigger political power picture and some complex plots are set up to start emerging.I look forward to reading the next book in the series. The book ends with a wrap up of the action from the story, there are no cliffhangers, but the stage is set for the bad guys to step back into Jess' life and it's a good starting point for the next book. There are some mild sexual situations, some violence and some profanity in this book.Heat factor moderate.

I enjoyed this well written story with Cinderella elements mixed with some heavy Pride and Prejudice influences. Although the villains are original, the favored younger stepsister strongly resembles Lydia Bennett and the stepmother, Mrs Bennett. The reserved hero gives a slight nod to Mr Darcy and his younger companion, Mr Bingley. The disapproving close relation (Lady Catherine) role is the hero's sister, and the earnest, pompous, silly suitor-a faux Mr Collins is there as well. The heroine herself bears a good deal of character resemblance to Elizabeth Bennett. In the Cinderella theme, the hero's godmother becomes the heroine's fairy godmother as she and the heroine's grandmother are the best of friends. The three ladies have been corresponding since the death of the heroine's father and her aborted come-out season five years earlier and the older ladies are well aware that the stepmother dotes on her own daughter and doesn't particularly invest any thought in her stepdaughter.Although there are all these "borrowed" elements, the author still manages to make some interesting characters and an entertaining plot which was original enough to keep my interest. There are no sexual scenes, although some is alluded to, and there is mild violence.I rated this 3 1/2 stars, but rounded it up.Heat factor mild.

I enjoyed this novel, the first in a series, which was well written and well edited. The author does a good job of establishing a small coastal town that's growing due to it's proximity to NYC, and the feel of the characters who live in small towns and on the water. She also does a nice job incorporating food and a couple of chefs into the story.(I was so hungry while I was reading!) The main characters are interesting people, very different from each other in their personalities and backgrounds, but both wanting the same things in their lives.The supporting characters are also colorful and I have a feeling they will play parts in other books in the series. My only criticism would be that the romance seemed very fast and smooth, hardly any conflicts for the H/h once they got past initial hurdles. I'm not suggesting that an author torment her protagonists unduly, but a bit more tension does make for a more interesting plot. I'm looking forward to reading more books in this series. There are sexual scenes in this book and some very minor violence, but no profanity. 4 1/2 stars.Heat factor hot.

A well written and(mostly)well edited sweet Christmas themed contemporary romance. Though I'm baffled as to the "how or why" our heroine ended up engaged to her fiance in the first place, I'm happy to say she ended up with the right man for her HEA. A little bit of a farcical, whimsical tale to make you smile.Heat factor mild.

I haven't read anything else by this author, but this story was well written and well edited. I felt as if I had been dropped into the middle of a series, though, with this story. There were a lot of family members and neighbors introduced into the mix without having any real exploration of their relationships or characters and a lot of family history referred to and alluded to, as if there were other books exploring these themes. It made me feel as if the story could have been much more fleshed out, but wasn't. I would have liked to have learned a little more about the history of the H and h but it is never fully explained, just that they dated some. The details of the h's first marriage also are alluded to as being terrible, but very little information is given.There is considerable time spent on exploring the sexual attraction between the H and h and how this makes the H angry with himself, and some time spent describing sexual encounters that, while steamy, didn't really add all that much to the story line. IMHO, the author would have been better served to explore her characters and their relationships and family history a good deal more which would have made a more substantial book and much more entertaining story with well developed characters and an interesting plot, rather than trying to keep it bare bones and throw in a bunch of sex scenes.Heat factor hot.

This second book in this author's "sister" series deals with the older sister, Lindsey,  who was raised by her father, the General, to be the perfect daughter. She did not see the abuse her younger sister was subjected to and thought that she was just "wild".When she finally realized what was going on, she was instrumental in helping expose what her father had done to his younger daughter and convict him. In striving to achieve the perfection her father demanded of her for his approval and in her grief over her perceived failure to protect her sister, she set herself up as the perfect pawn for her husband to use for political gain.This book deals with very difficult issues of domestic violence and abuse and the terrible toll it takes, not only on the psychological health but the physical and financial health of the victims as well as the strain on all of their relationships. The story is not a comfortable, cozy read and it's not meant to be. Lindsey, however, manages to find a little wiggle room in her husband's iron control over her, and though it costs her greatly, she also manages to find a little bit of herself, and struggles, with lots of help, to finally be her own person and get free of the monsters who had taken everything from her. There is some sexual violence in this story along with other personal violence and profanity.

I enjoyed this story, but it had some gaping plot holes that I had a hard time overlooking. Stephano Jacob Coulson Notte was told about vampires and the whole nanos and society and turning options, etc when he turned 18 and basically found out that his entire family were vampires. He freaked out and started thinking of them as the monsters from the horror movies he loved to watch, refused to be turned and basically rejected his family. When he was fatally injured years later, his boss and close friend to him and his family turned him to save his life but like an ungrateful brat, he ran away and began using his middle names-Jake Coulson. He went into the bodyguard business in Canada. When his aunt Marguerite Argeneau, called and asked him to guard a friend for 2 weeks until her divorce was final, he couldn't say no.  He couldn't find a way to get out of it even when she told him he was going to have to pretend to be a cook/housekeeper and not mention the bodyguard business, because the young woman didn't believe that her ex was trying to kill her.When Nicole was told her family friend Marguerite had found her a cook/housekeeper, she was relieved. She was behind in her painting and really needed the help. She was shocked when Marguerite arrived with a handsome young man. When suspicious activity continued to take place, Jake was very worried and called in his human partner for  reinforcements. Of course, Nicole and Jake are very attracted to each other and Jake can't read her thoughts, one of the signs of a life mate. When an attempt to kill nearly does in Jake, the family arrives and the person behind the attempted murder had better watch out!My problems with the plot were with Jake's lack of research into the ex's whereabouts or money use, passport activity, etc. If he was such an experienced bodyguard, I would have expected him to do a little basic research. Nicole was certainly busy with her painting to give him enough time. Also his explanation to Nicole on being a life partner and going through the change was really sketchy at best. I did like that the family members were altogether, laughing and giving Jake/Stephano a lot of grief. It was good to see some zingers coming from Dante and Tomasso, they're usually such badasses and the muscle, not the comic uncles.There is sexual content in this book and violence.Heat factor moderate.

I laughed my head off at the antics of Tank the pug with the Napoleon complex and the visual of Grace trying to find him in the ocean... Still chuckling.: ) I liked this whole story, from Grace doing all kinds of odd jobs just to get by because she just couldn't face her parents, to the cute 5 year old Jedi knight and the angry wheelchair bound Anna. I sympathized with Josh not wanting to give up his father's dream, but being completely overwhelmed by his life.I enjoy the secondary characters that make Lucky Harbor a town in this series and that pop up in different books. The author has created a sense of place that makes the reader feel as if they are a part of it. I look forward to reading more.There is sexual content in this book, along with some violence in the form of accidents, etc..Heat factor hot.

This worked well for a few years, so for the price and getting 3 years worth of operation out of it it's not a bad deal. Mine was used inside to light a garage. The reason it did not get 5 stars is because the LED light actually gave out before I even had to change the batteries. Inside, with only once or twice a day use, 3 years is ok, just seems like the LED should outlive the batteries., especially when the LED is hard wired onto a board and can't be replaced.

Updated review: Had to drop this to 3 stars. Because this unit has only a 7 to 7.5 hour water supply, it has a nasty habit of running out of water before I have gotten 8 hours sleep. That alone is not a big issues. However the built in alarm that goes off to warn of the low water level is loud enough to wake me. So now I am left to try to figure out how to make sure the limited water supply does not run out before I get my sleep. Not fun.Original review: This would have received 5 stars except it is advertised as a 10 hour humidifier. In reality it runs 7.5 to 8 hours max at it's lowest setting. On the plus side it has an automatic shut off so running out of water doesn't cause any problems. Haven't had it long enough to talk about slime build up, I'll update on that in the months to come. It does look easy to clean, and does not have any parts like filters that need replacing, another big plus. It is small but I set it on my headboard on low and it makes a huge difference in sleep quality. I find it quiet. I'm a light sleeper and the motor is very quiet. The only real noise is a gurgling sound as it draws more water every 10 minutes or so, but that has not woken me up once, and again I am a very light sleeper. It does have a night light, but that can be shut off through the settings, without that on it is not even as bright as a cable box.The Good: Priced under $30, easy to maintain, will cover a bedroom, automatic shut off, no bright lights unless desired, 3 year warranty.The Bad: Made in China, does not last 10 hours even on low; more like 7.5 to 8 hours.

Maybe I'm doing something wrong. If so, I can't figure out what it is. With the multi colored pens, I expected to get corresponding colors on my IPad. No matter what software I tried they all just drew the colors i selected in the software, the color of the pens had no effect at all. Pretty disappointed. My wife likes them though, she uses them to turn pages.

It's perfect. Super good quality, Small enough to be very convenient, and large enough to pray 15 plants top to bottom. Love the spray nozzle that lets you spray under leaves just as easy as doing the tops. Very happy with this product.

WOW! I could've saved a bundle just using sand paper. Essentially all this is, is a sandpaper roller, hooked up to a grinder. It's does what it says though. It does have multiple speeds: Ouch, and OH MY GOD WHAT DID I DO!!?

Good quality blades, and a nice selection. Wish they had one for PVC included, but I think the wood blades will work fine. They work just fine in myPORTER CABLE PCC670B 20-volt MAX Lithium Bare Reciprocating Tigersaw, and since the selection of blades Porter cable offers was severely lacking, these were a life saver.

The fabric is a bit thin, other than that they are great. I've had them for about 3 months so far, and no holes, so they are better than most of the products out there, and at half the price. Overall a great value for the price. I wear a 34 waist and these fit fine in a medium.

Almost had to give this 3 stars, but fortunately I read the description carefully before buying. It does indeed say it has 2 programmable valves and one manual. I wanted 3 programmable, but they don't seem to make them. At least I knew what I was getting so...5 stars. Very easy to program, had the whole thing set up in less than 5 minutes, including the time it took me to toss the unread instructions to the side. It's been hooked up for 3 weeks now and is working without a hitch. I have it place in a covered bin buried in the yard so I does not have direct contact with rain, but is exposed to humidity, insects, and dust(sand). Seems to handle the weather fine. As with any electronics, I would not recommend placing this in a location fully exposed to the elements, you would probably shorten its life expectancy dramatically.It has 3 valves and all work fine with no noticeable drop in pressure from the 3 way split. Heavy duty plastic construction, and large LED display. No complaints at all to date. I will update the review as needed.

What a bargain! My grill heats up just fine, as long as you let it preheat for 20 minutes. If you do that you get a sear top and bottom. If not, you get lumps of gray cooked meat. It will comfortably hold 3 good sized burgers or 5 burger chain with clown mascot sized ones. I even made cheese burgers with it and the melted cheese stuck to the burger not the grill. How awesome was that?! Anyway, here's what I found:Good: A nice size for a 1 or 2 person meal. Non stick plates are very non stick, and seem good quality, especially for the price.(check the price on one ceramic pan and tell me I'm wrong). Super easy to clean, but based on experience with other "dishwasher safe" non stick surfaces I'm not trusting it to my dishwasher. Cooked a good sized burger to med rare in under 3 minutes after it's heated up.Bad: 20 minutes to heat up not 8 as instructions say. Don't trust the stupid lights. As other reviewers have hinted at they may work and may not, and if they do work, they may be reversed. My unit both lights come on when plugged in and the green light goes off when heated up. That's the opposite of the way it should be according to the instruction. Humorous, but not a huge issue. Tends to flatten burgers out. Since the lid is on a floating hinge it cooks more evenly, but that does allow the lid to put more pressure on burgers, so they do flatten out while cooking. Not an issue with steaks or sandwiches.Overall it was just what I expected, and I love it. At the price, under $50, it can't be beat.

My wife has Seborrheic Keratosis which are brown raised scales here and there. They tend to spread and grow if left uncheck...which is of course what she did. Anyway after searching online I found out what it was and saw that this type of peel works as a potential remedy. Bought the 30% and it seemed to be working, though a bit slowly. So upped it to the 50%. Worked much faster.Now here's the problem. Be careful. When it goes on it will itch. If you scratch, bad things happen. At least they did for my wife. (to be fair she has VERY sensitive skin.) We tested it as directed and there was no problem so I applied it to he problem areas, not paying too much attention to limiting it to the scales, so I did hit the surrounding skin. (Naturally this makes what happened next all my fault). After a week I noticed that everywhere she could have scratched, she had done so, and with quite a bit of zest( still not her fault...all mine). So now she had large brown areas all over the scratched areas. They looked like bruises. And on her back when she couldn't reach there were also brown areas but they were limited to brown dots where I had applied the product. It appears that the product has caused over pigmentation where applied. Especially where the 50% was used. Fortunately I did not do her face.Anyway, it did get rid of the Seborrheic Keratosis patches, and with the help of some whitening mask the spots are fading. Again, not all the products fault, my wife does have VERY sensitive skin. But do try this on a small area for a couple weeks first, you patience may well be rewarded.
Great lamp for the price. Casts a bright light over an entire desk area, no glare like the fluorescent kinds, and seems very well made. Love this lamp.

I bought 2 different sizes of the "Perfect Fit" imitations, one was totally the wrong size though it said it would be identical, the second hurt my back. It seemed like the insert was set at and angle and was putting was too much pressure on my back. Went back to the Dr Schools...and VOILA problems solved!. Now I can stand or walk for 4 to 6 hours without back pain. AWESOME PRODUCT

Took this to my Chiropractor to show him, because when I told him i got it for $32.95 delivered he had to see the quality. He said it was great. Comparable to ones he used to get for over 3 times the price. All I know is it feels just like the much larger unit he used on me in his office. I love this TENS unit. Don't use it to replace medical treatment by a professional, but it definitely seems to help between visits.

These pads are a bit bigger and thicker than the pads that came with my Santa Medical TENS, and the gel doesn't seem to last quite as long. However the price was great and the patches do work just as well as the originals. Get the Parker Labs Tensive Conductive Adhesive Gel, 50 g Tube to refresh the patches and combined they are a fantastic deal.

My battery for my S3 was losing it's charge. Got this to replace it. It comes with 2 batteries and 2 chargers. One charger plugs into your phone like normal, the other(I wasn't expecting this one) you put the 2nd battery in and it can charge while the first battery is in your phone. For the price the deal is unbeatable. Batteries seem to work just as well as OEM.

Follow the instructions, wrap it in a towel straight from the freezer and apply. Chills you like crazy. I used them for 4 weeks 3 times a day and they never had a problem. Ordered 2 and they are both still in the freezer waiting for my next injury. Highly recommend!

I used this product exactly as instructed. It specifically stated it was to be applied directly from the freezer to the skin. Bad mistake. After 2 days of use I had a 4 inch welt of dry painful skin in the area I was using this product. The compress was literally freezing my skin. It would stick to my leg similarly to when  a tongue sticks to a frozen pole. Not good. It worked fine when wrapped in a towel, however there are other products like the 9x12 Comfort Gel Pack by Accurate manufacturing, that work better when wrapped in a towel. They get colder so the towel doesn't block as much of the cooling effect.

My biggest issue ordering filters is the measurements. With this product from this vendor when they say exact measurements, they mean it. Love the product. The next concern i always have is will the filter overwork my AC by blocking too much air flow. I find the MERV 8 perfect, it filters all but the most microscopic particles, and the AC loves it. I live in Florida so if the filter block the air flow my electric cost can go from $200 to $300 in a blink. With this MERV 8 I had no problems at all.

When ordering food my only concerns are did I get the product I ordered, not an imitation, and is it fresh. The answers were yes on both counts for this product. Plenty of time left on the expiration dates(fresher than the walgreens I saw them at last time I bought). Great product.

I have been buying these for 2 years at Walmart, now that I am boycotting Walmart I will try to get them at Walgreens. 2 years ago I was suffering from back pain and tightness whenever I spent more than a half hour on my feet. I went to a foot specialist and she recommended custom orthotics, though she wanted me to go to a specialty shop. I went to the machine at Walmart and the testing sent me to the 440 Dr Scholls. I bought them and almost immediately after use my back pain improved. Now I can walk for several hours with no problems. They last about 6 to 12 months of continuous wear. When the pain starts coming back I know it's time for a new pair. I would recommend anyone with back pain use the machine in most Walmarts and Walgreens to diagnose your feet and buy the product indicated. It's only about $50 and could help solve your problem. It did for me.And now to bash some of the negative reviews:I get so sick of people who use product reviews to review suppliers. If you don't like the price or service of a supplier please review them. Product reviews are supposed to be about the product.And to the reviewer Matt who is negatively reviewing this product in order to promote your own product with a link to your own website. What does it say about your ethics that you have to stoop to a smear campaign to try to generate sales? You pretend to be dissatisfied with Dr Scholls yet you have reviewed 14 of their products pretending to have bought them all...you are dishonest and not that smart. Why not do things like the other competitor Perfect Fit and just price them much cheaper and make the same claims.So anyway sorry for the rant but I couldn't understand why these only had 3 stars until I read some of the 1 star reviews.

Updated review: Have owned a year and 2 months now and still very pleased with this product. My review and rating remain unchanged. A definite good buy.Initial review:If you're looking for a sprinkler to target specific areas, or aim at certain spots, to avoid wasting water this is perfect. I have 2 trees about 15 to 20 feet apart and this has a setting that shoots 2 streams of water in opposite directions, so I was able to sit it in the middle and adjust the flow rate till it landed right on the trees needing watering without wasting water on the surrounding area, which is mostly sand. Before, I had to set a sprinkler under each tree and let it dribble out, or water about a 500 sqft of sand to get both trees.The sprinkler has a bunch of other settings as well so it's perfect for landscaping arranged in tightly bunched areas, or in odd layouts.My only complaint would be the unit's ultra light weight. It is all plastic and weighs practically nothing, so your hose has to be straight and the the sprinkler flat on the ground or it might tip a bit. Still wasn't worth losing any stars over since there are few sprinklers out there that don't have to be placed with care, and for the price...well this one is great.I wouldn't recommend it for large areas there are other sprinklers much more suited for that, but this one says it's for small to medium areas and specialty applications, and that what it does.So 5 stars and a highly recommend.

Updated review. I have owned the sprinkler for a year and 2 months now and I am still just as pleased with the product as I was when first reviewed it. No changes to rating. Highly recommend.Initial review:Wow this is a GREAT sprinkler. I'm on a well and the water pressure fluctuates a lot. This sprinkle has great range allowing me to reach all 3 or my Orange trees at one time. What a time saver. Great construction, mostly metal. Definitely worth paying a few extra bucks for.I've tried 3 arm sprayers - the pressure had hardly enough energy to turn the arms;I've tried spike mounted pulsating sprinkler heads - they were ok, but this product pumps more water further, and is 10 times more durable;And I've tried the standard oscillating sprinkler - they start off ok, but my hard water starts clogging the holes till it's just a pathetic 2 holed dribble machine.This product seems built to last. Highly recommend especially if you're looking to cover a fairly large area. It has the typical pulsating sprayer settings so adjusting the direction of spray is a snap, and it's heavy so it doesn't move or tip over. Love it!

When I first got these 4 of them were not recognized by my PS3 which is the only BluRay player I have. After my initial dismay i went to a Best Buy and tried them in another player and they worked fine. Hmmmm what to do? So I went home and went through my PS3 setting and found out there was an update that had come out. After the update installed VOILA no more issues. Moral of the story - before you give bad reviews check your equipment and make sure you stuff isn't the problem. My experience cost me one BluRay disk since I left the test disk in the player at Best Buy.

I purchased this to cover a driveway gate about 280 ft from the window I had the base units sitting in. While the Defender unit started off fine, within a week I was not getting any detection from the sending unit. I had to move it to within 125 feet before it started working. At that distance it worked fine, so I gave it 3 stars because it worked, with a 2 star penalty for the shorter than advertised range.If you need a dependable longer range system i highly recommend the Skylink HA-434RTL Long Range Motion Alert Kit, which works great at the 280 foot range i needed. I have reviewed that product as well, and it is just as affordable.If you need a unit for mounting inside, or on your house, over a garage, or close to your house, this unit is fine.

Updated review. I have now owned this for a year and a half. Still works great, and have not had to replace any batteries. Totally pleased with the range, sensitivity, and the volume of the alarm. I have a 2400 sqft 2 story home and can hear the alarm in every room if I want to. Still would highly recommend this product.Initial review: A few months before I purchased this product I bought the Defender AL101 Wireless Driveway Alert System. This Skylink product is MUCH BETTER. I purchased both to cover a gate about 280 ft from the window I had the base units sitting in. While the Defender unit started off fine, within a week I was not getting any detection from the sending unit. I had to move it to within 125 feet before it started working. This skylink system, on the other hand, has been working fine at the 300 foot range.It has 2 settings, high and low. At the high settings, on very windy days (gusts up to 50 mph) it was picking up tree movement about 20 feet away and sending false alerts. A quick walk outside to the detector unit and I was able to easily set it to low detection. This totally eliminated the false alerts, no matter how strong the wind was, yet it still alerted each and every time a vehicle or animal ( we have a lot of wild rabbits coming and going) went through the gate.It is a motion detector, so if you have a lot of animal traffic they will be detected, so plan accordingly when you set it up. If you don't want animals setting it off,set it to low, mount it higher, and adjust the angle of detection, all of which are outlined in the brief but informative instructions.I give this product my highest positive recommendation.

This would be a great gift for a child(preferably girl). It looks delicate and cute but it is small. Most low rating reviewers must not have taken a ruler and looked at it before ordering. If they had they would have found the measurements are right, and if that is the case why give it a bad review for an accurate description just because you can't take the time to figure out what you're buying before you buy it? To me it's like ordering a pecan cluster then giving it a bad review because the piece of chocolate has nuts in it.Anyway based on the size I would limit this to kids, giving it to a spouse or girlfriend may lead to some awkward looks from the recipient while they try to determine how you decided to give this tiny pendant as a sign of your love.To clear up the size issue, the pendant, not including the clasp, is about the size of a pinky fingernail, and the stone is about the size of a small Hershey's chocolate chip cut into 3rds. It is small but it has a definitely cute appearance.I give it 4 stars because it is a fair price when you consider the chain is included, it is as described, and the stones appear real. One star off because it tries to pass itself off as a piece of jewelry for adults, and it's not.

Updated review: My only initial concern when I purchased the razor was that it would not work when it was plugged in, so when the battery goes bad the razor is trash. Well I am happy to report that so far the battery shows no signs of deterioration, and it's been a year and a half since purchase. I would still highly recommend this razor.Initial Review:I love the feel of the grip and the look of this razor. The cut...well it takes a bit of getting used to. The instruction says it takes 21 days for your skin to get used to the razor and your razor to get used to your skin. If it doesn't happen they say they will take it back, I've had mine a week so far and have begun shaving at night so the razor burns have 8 to 10 hours to calm down before I go out in public. Don't get me wrong, it's not too bad and my lower neck has always been prone to redness from shaving. But so far it feels like it will take the whole 21 days or darn close for me to adjust. So if you buy it be prepared for the break in period. UPDATE: The 21 day break in period is over and as advertised the razor is no longer rough on my skin. I do believe however that the break in period is less about skin getting used to the way the new razor cuts, and more about the razor blades becoming broken in and less abrasive. Either way the result is the same, the razor is working great!On the plus side: It feels like it cuts really nice and close, and you can feel the blades conforming to your face, so it is as advertised. It's very quiet. It also seems to be a lot more gentle on your face if you shave everyday. I'm a bit lazy so sometimes I'm cutting 2 to 3 days worth of hair and that probably won't work with this little piece of equipment.On the negative side: It seems like you have to rinse it to clean it and I am used to just being able to shake the razor clean daily and a thorough brush clean weekly. Not this one. The hair seems to want to cling to the inside. I don't know but running my hard Florida water over the blades a few times a week seems like a recipe for disaster, what with the blades being $30 to $40. Another thing I don't like it is won't run when plugged in. I didn't know they made them like that. My last shaver ran cordless and plugged in so when the batteries gave out, as they always do, I used it for a couple more years as a plugin. Won't be possible with this, when the battery dies, it's useless.Overall so far the razor seems to perform as it claims, gives a nice close cut, cuts the hair instead of ripping it out, and is nice and quiet. So I give it 4 stars. On star off for not being easy to clean, and the 21 day break in period.

This blanket is a great deal for the price. It has all the normal features of a heating pad plus the bonuses of being extra large (at 2 feet long and 1 feet wide it is almost twice the size of my past heating pads) and no auto shut off. The cord is good quality and about 10 feet long which is also nice. Has the usual settings of low, medium and high, and the cover is washable. I have absolutely no complaints and would definitely buy it again for family or friends.

Got this a few days ago when I ordered it from a black Friday deal(yeah so that offering was not a scam, some people did get one). It was a Christmas gift so I wasn't planning on opening it. After reading the 4 reviews for the product on 11/29 I decided I better open it and check it out...cause if it can go wrong, it will...that's my luck.Anyway, I opened the box with a fair amount of trepidation, and it was in there, so far so good. Next I unpacked it and plugged it in waiting for the blue screen of death, smoke, hard drive clicking, a total lack of activity, or anyone of the myriad of other signs indicating issues with the product.Well after holding my breath for a few seconds the machine started right up, went through its initial use procedure, got online through my network and is now being updated. PERFECT, works great! No ISSUES. Was just what I ordered and arrived as described. Now I can't guarantee it will still be working in a few months, but right now I am a very satisfied buyer.To address issues in other reviews:1) I bought it with windows 7, it came with windows 7, I didn't buy it for any windows 8 upgrade special so no points off there.2) Not repacked came new in a sealed box, no points off there. I must point out that one reviewer complained that no one checked his laptop to make sure it was configured correctly prior to shipping and another complained that his had been opened, so it comes down to how do you please everyone? Me, I want mine unopened please.3) A reviewer said his did not work, mine did so no points off there. Who knows maybe he forgot to hit the start button. This one doesn't automatically turn on when opened unless it's already been turned on...hey I've seen weirder things than that, like the guy who emailed brighthouse from his home computer to complain he couldn't get online from his home computer.Bottom line I have a working Dell I3 with 750GB hard drive, internet access, and it is a 15.6 in laptop running windows 7. I have what I ordered, it works fine, so 5 stars.

This is not why I gave it 3 stars- that's below- I probably should have done more research before ordering. I was in a bit of a rush though after seeing them use cardamom on Top Chef so I just ordered the best deal I could find. Turns out these Green Cardamom are used in drinks, like teas. If you want to use as a spice get the Black Cardamom which is much more pricey.Still, had I known what I was doing, I would still only give 3 stars. As described it does take over a month to get these, they are shipped from India they say, however even by boat a month seems long. If you think you'll get them sooner than what they say...don't count on it.The main reason for the 3 stars though, is because inside the green pods(hence the name) are supposed to be a clumop of little black seeds. Well over 60% of the pods I got had clumps of little tan seeds. Not sure if they weren't ripe or just weren't cardamom. I do know that there are a lot of fake products out there, and with such a high percentage of the wrong color seeds, it made me doubt the entire delivery.With that doubt I can't justify a better rating. My advice for prople looking for Green Cardamom: Do some research, know what you want, and test different suppliers by ordering small batches until you find one that gives you all green pods that are all filled with black seeds.
This funnel will pretty much put an end to your homebrewing woes.There's really nothing else I can say that hasn't been said. I used it for wine & mead, so I find the strainer very useful.

If you've read the other reviews on this figure you've probably figured out the amazon has combined the reviews from an older release with this one. I don't know if this would be such a big deal, but apparently that older release came with a cape and this one most certainly does not.It does, however, have a tiny peg in his back along the fin that can be removed, and it looks like something will clip inside there -- I suppose that might be for an optional cape.I'll start by saying this a figure for collectors, not kids. That isn't to say this figure isn't well made, it is, but it seems somewhat delicate - particularly in the hip and shoulder joints. A bit of rough play would trash this figire. The plastic is fairly light weight - if I had one complaint, that would be it.Another reviewers says he hoped the figure would be larger, but doesn't say how big the figure is. For the record he's about 6.5" inches, making Ultraman a bit taller than other Bandai Tamashii figures like Daft Punk.

Initially, I hadn't planned on buying this Kei Yuki figure -- but I was so impressed with the Play Arts Harlock figure I ultimately decided it made sense to complete the pair.There doesn't seem to be as many pictures or videos of this figure as there are for Harlock. This makes sense I suppose, after all -- Harlock is the star. Anyway, this was a small cause for concern as I like to research these pricier figures before taking a leap of faith.My biggest beef with this figure (at first) was the ridiculous busom. Most of the women (and men, honestly) are lacking any real curves in the original anime, but I reckon modern tastes demand a D-cup. All things considered, the updated body type is still represented fairly well -- and at least she isn't bursting out of her uniform. I guess that's the greater concern in this -- that the uniform is still true to it's original inspiration. To any other Harlock purists or female figure collectors -- we've seen worse examples of 'enhanced' female icons in animation and comics.Unlike Kei's counterpart Harlock, her paint job consists of more than just gold trim and highlights. A concerted effort was made to give her uniform a 'sheen' that would resemble a shiny leather or polymer fabric. There are numerous tints and tones and apparently, this is where many of the complaints come from. I have read about globs of paint and even partial fingerprints marring the paint job. My figure is free of any of these types of flaws, so clearly I am one of the lucky ones. If I had to describe the overall look of the paint job, I would say it almost looks like automotive paint. It's a very cool effect.The joints are pretty good and fairly tight. The left wrist doesn't want to budge and I don't want to force it. It's undoubtedly the thinnest joint on the figure.She comes with two guns, two identical guns. This is worth mentioning because you'll notice that both guns have a peg on one side, the same side. However, only one gun can be holstered -- and holstering that gun can be a bit of a challenge. On her right side there's a tiny strip of gold trim that can be removed -- it's so well-hidden I don't know if I ever would have found it on my own. This is such an amazing detail and it's almost shocking the sculptors went to such lengths to disguise the hole -- it makes you wonder then why they provided duplicate guns. I can understand the practicality of using the same mold, but why not clip the peg on the one gun before applying paint details, if for no reason but to bolster the illusion this is a quality, highly-detailed figure..? Particularly since this figure originally retailed for around $100? Again, not a big deal but a little strange.Finally, my one solid complaint - her elbow pads. This is easily the most oddball design decision regarding this figure. For whatever reason -- perhaps to make her elbows appear more rounded while bent -- the figure features these sort of free-floating elbow pads. It's almost guaranteed that one or both will be rattling around loose in your box when it arrives. The figure has u-shaped hinges on either elbow, and the pad has a horizontal shaft on the underside. It clips into place fairly easily, however it also comes off easily. Too easily. I debated leaving them unattached & storing them in the box, but ultimately decided to glue them on. I'm detracting one star for this -- it's really just such a bizarre design choice, and rather than appreciate it -- I'd sooner detract from the figure's value and permanently attach these pieces.In my review for the Harlock figure I explain how my expectations were lower than low, and how I was pleasantly surprised. Play Arts Kai can really drop the ball sometimes, but in the case of these Captain Harlock figures -- I have to say they really did a good job. I think the quality is exceptionally high on both figures, despite some peculiar if not nonsensical design choices. Kei Yuki is slightly less impressive than her male counterpart, but is still a fine representation of the character.I have no remorse from buying either figure.

I bought Guy and Thomas at the same time, although I used a marketplace seller for Guy. The box was apparently damaged, but since I was opening both figures I didn't care & the Monet I saved was nice.I was also on the fence about buying these. I suppose I had some lingering remorse about not buying the Medicom versions. Anyway, I read all the reviews about how people were saying they managed to break their figure minutes after first opening the package and was concerned. So, I checked out some up boxing videos to satisfy my curiosity.The first video was a sausage-fingered adult male manhandling these figures like they were made out of titanium. I figured if that doofus could be so harsh with these figures they can't possibly be *that* delicate.Now that I have both figures -- I can say that guy was LUCKY. These figures do not exactly instill a collector with much confidence. They don't feel cheap, but they don't exactly feel durable. They are fairly light in weight, and moving some of the joints feels risky. Pretty much any collector knows the feeling of trying to move a limb, it not budging, and then thinking 'better not chance it'.Durability issues aside, these do look cool. I think they're priced a little high, though.

Quintron isn't for everybody, but if you're familiar -- this track should suit you just fine.I started to notice a trend at his shows after Swamp Tech came out. "Swamp Buggy Badass" must have either gotten airplay on college radio, or maybe it was word of mouth -- but crowds at Q's shows started get larger and more boisterous, and all they wanted to hear was the driving beat of Swamp Buggy Badass. I think this annoyed Q."Haterz" feels like a spiritual successor to Swamp Buggy Badass in terms of it's primal, incessant beat. It's hard to not move your body when listening to it. Also, it's great to listen to in the car. Definitely a mood-lifter, this one.

Lately I've been tracking down Savages' earlier singles and ep's -- the clear vinyl, the white vinyl and so on. I bought this primarily because I expect it's availability to disappear. This is a great band still relatively early in their career -- I want to support them, so if I can binge purchase their records I will. As for this vinyl, the 'embossing' listed in the description refers to the album cover. It's a nice design choice, but I confess I didn't even notice at first. Aside from that it's just the two tracks, black vinyl. Am I disappointed by the plainness of this release? A little. But I can cope because both tracks are awesome. Supremely awesome.

I jumped the Cocteau Twins ship when they released Heaven Or Las Vegas, but have kept their older recordings alive in my heart these many years..And now there is this, which sounds very very Cocteau Twins, with an only slightly modern twist. It's very palatable, and  so if you're hoping this will hint more towards days long gone - you might be pleasantly surprised. Nothing stays the same after all, nothing lasts forever -- but this is a tiny gift of something long-faded from your memory.  You may find that nostalgia goes a long way.Anyway, I wanted to comment more on the vinyl release because the listed info is incorrect. It's two discs, Moon and Luna. Moon is on beautiful white vinyl and Luna is black. As you may have guesses, Luna is all the remixes you see on the mp3 version of the album.You also get CD versions of both discs, which is super nice. The packaging, in general, is very nice. This is a beautiful first release.

This patch had been sitting on my wish list for at least a year, priced at $20. When the price dropped at lunged at the opportunity.And maybe because I leapt without looking - I didn't pay any attention to the size of this patch. If you think this is going to be in scale to how the emblem was displayed on Zentraedai uniforms you are sorely mistaken. If it's two inches I'd be shocked - it's probably less, maybe 1.5"So if it clearly says that in the description then that's on me. It is well-enough made, nothing extraordinary, but it is mind-blowingly small.

I really feel that Dragon's Dogma never got the attention it deserved. I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game - and I fell in love with many of the stylistic choices that went into creating the in-game world.As far as art books for games go -- this one is pretty thorough. It's exactly what I want from an art book. It has great depth of detail. There's plenty of alternate looks, and the reader is walked through various character evolutions. Sure, I enjoy page after page of gorgeous screen-captures, but this book goes well beyond that & gives the reader some insight into the design team's aesthetic.My only complaint is that this wasn't offered in the US in a hardcover edition.

I'll start by saying that I've been aware of this figure for months, and despite it being Harlock, it wasn't *my* Harlock, hero of my childhood. I know this figure corresponds with the movie released in Japan last year - and I can say this is a very faithful reproduction of that look, but at first glance I dismissed this as some new emo-style Harlock. Whatever.When I found the figure on amazon - and saw that it was selling for less than half of what I was used to seeing online - I went for it. If nothing else, I reasoned, at least I can say - as a completionist-psycho-collector - that I *have* it. Like, 'yeah it sucks but I have it' or 'whatevs, I got it on sale, I have it' - my point in driving this point home is that my expectations were beyond low.So when it came I was surprised to see, for one, that the box was so big. I have other Kai figures and was expecting the typical 9" figure. Harlock is bigger, more like 10.25".The crown jewel in my Harlock collection is of course the Medicom RAH figure. This Kai figure is quite nearly the same height. So, if you missed the  Medicom figure - this May not be a bad substitute for you.The amount of detail is stellar. Play Arts Kai make really nice figures, but even so - I'm willing to say they upped the ante for Harlock. The sculpt is over the top. It's truly, truly superb. That said, there are a couple design choices - I won't call them flaws - that detract from this figure being genuinely, mind-blowingly awesome.The first is the plastic cape. I can imagine why they went with plastic - it's cheaper, I'm sure, and also by going with plastic the manufacturers are able to ensure the dramatic appearance of this figure. However, the plastic is heavy, it throws the balance of the figure off. It's also fairly inflexible, so it restricts the full movement of the arms. Obviously, it would have been nice if they'd gone with a cloth cape, so that you could take advantage of the ultra-posability of this figure. It would be nice, for example, if you could pose Harlock in his melancholy sitting pose on top of a pile of books, or what have you, mimicking his slouched-down in his seat position at the helm of the Arcadia.The other odd design choice was to not include Mr.Bird as a separate figure, but as an accessory permanently adhered to Harlock's alternate collar. Yes, that's right, you have to swap out collars to include Mr.Bird. You pop off Harlock's head and switch out the separate piece of plastic from his cowl. On one hand, this is an interesting solution to a minor problem -- even Medicom went the obvious route and their Mr.Bird's feet just clip on to wherever you can make him fit. You would think Play Arts Kai would have sooner considered just doing foot-pegs - which I admit readily invite the problem of breakage - but to go *this* route and have Mr.Bird permanently attached to a spare collar just seems bizarre. Granted, when in use both the collar and Mr.Bird are secure, so...there's that.Despite these complaints I'm pretty much in love with this figure - and I totally did not expect to be. Hence, I am not deducting any stars because of the few design choices I don't agree with. This figure is definitely bad-ass. I would think that most fans of Harlock would agree this is a respectful interpretation of our beloved space pirate, despite its flaws. You may or may not find some minor complaints with it - but overall this a great sculpt and a quality piece. Those qualities, in my opinion, are inarguable.

I first started seeing the cheesy commercials for this thing around Thanksgiving 2013. You know how crappy products start making tv appearances before xmas? I assumed this was another piece of plastic trash destined for landfill. Yet -- something tugged at my pile-infested heartstrings....could this be the product I've been secretly dreaming of??It's true that in the deepest, darkest, echoing caverns of my pessimistic heart a tiny voice does indeed cry out for a device that can clean fuzz-globs from my favorite socks and sweaters. Somewhere, a part of myself I lost touch with long ago -- yearns for crisp, clean clothes that look like new.Oh, I've tried the shavers. Those things are bloody torture. We should lock [insert bad person here] in cages with sweater shavers and an endless supply of fleece.Anyway, we're talking about the Gleener here so I'll get on with it. Is the price high? It seems high, doesn't it? The price kept me away from several months. But here's the thing to consider: Imagine the sweater or whatever article of clothing you have in mind for the Gleener. How much did that cost you? If you could have that article of clothing again -- free and clear of those nasty hair-globs clinging menacingly to it -- what would you pay for that??Because the Gleener does remove piles. Depending on the type of fabric it removes them pretty easily. It breezes across fleece. Wool is trickier, depending on the knit.I had three sweaters that I would no longer wear outside of the house because the piles were too bad. I also had two pairs of snowboarding socks that cost me like $25 each -- those were trashed! But the Gleener cleaned everything up, no problem. The sweater took ten minutes, I'd say, and I'm thorough.So yeah,  this is practically a miracle device. Gone are days of wasting tape trying to pull hairballs off my clothes.Lastly, and some may consider this a negative but it's worth pointing out -- this isn't really a *shaver* -- it doesn't have blades. The roughest 'blade' is like a mesh that grabs the piles -- like velcro almost. So if your issue is extra fuzz, like loose yarn or hairs -- I'm not sure the Gleener will help. I have a wool sweater from Ireland that practically looks like a Pekingese at this point -- the Gleener removed some fuzz, but not enough so that you could discern the individual strands of yarn.in closing -- it's pretty well built, sturdy construction and it does what it says.

I have a few medicom 1/6 figures: Rocketeer, Captain Harlock, original costume Wolverine -- I recently just picked up Manji from Blade of the Immortal. It was after buying Manji I thought it was odd that my modest collection was lacking my favorite super-hero of all-time, Spider-Man. So, I sought to rectify this.Of course, I've been aware of this as well as the previous medicom Spider-Man offerings. I was never too enthused about them. The comic-book version of Spider-Man always looked too cheezy for my tastes, and personally I never cared for the silver-webbing on the Spider-Man 2 costume. I suppose I could have gone for the black suit -- but I really wanted the traditional colors. I guess I'm a purist.Now that Hot Toys has entered the 1/6 ring -- I found I had quite a few options to choose from. I wasn't married to Medicom, I just wanted the best possible figure at the most reasonable price. So I did what any fan or collector on a budget would do -- I hit the web and watched a ton of unboxing & comparison videos.Even though I said I was a purist, I found that I was willing to consider the Amazing Spider-Man figure. The design is pretty cool and I thought the movie was a decent modern re-telling of the Spider-Man story. Also, a lot of the pictures look amazing.That said, the price for either the Medicom or the Hot Toys version was fairly steep. I found the cheapest price was for the Hot Toys version, which I was able to locate for $150 free shipping. Medicom was at least $180 and no free shipping. That was more than I wanted to spend.So I was leaning heavily towards Hot Toys but I have no personal knowledge of their quality. I know that some of their facial sculpts are stunning, but that's all I know. I've never held one in my hands. This is where youtube came in handy. Bless they guys who take the time to do reviews. They saved me from a $150 mistake.The main complaint with the Hot Toys Amazing Spider-Man figure has to do with an apparent design flaw. Supposedly, the shoulder joints break fairly easily. One guy says the instructions included with the figure say not to raise the figures arms beyond 80 degrees. Seriously?? Spider-Man not raise his arms above 80 degrees??  Of course this is information gleaned from the internet and thus is not completely and utterly reliable.
