I'm sure there are plenty of people who have the figure and love it and the shoulders are very much intact. I'm just saying for me, personally, it was a bit of a risk.Finally I watched a comparison video between both versions. The Hot Toys figure is smaller, and the body is more child-like. Granted, the actor has a very boyish frame. But compared to the size of other 1/6 scale figures -- the Hot Toys version looked impish. Also, the body of the figure did not look good. I'm an illustrator, so the proportions just looked off to me. This was the deal-breaker on purchasing the Hot Toys Amazing Spider-Man.And thus concluded my considering purchasing the Amazing Spider-Man figure in general. I just wasn't willing to shell out $200 on the medicom one.All of this brought me back to Medicom's Spider-Man 3 figure. I had 4 primary concerns:1) The suit2) The boots3) The head size/shape4) The utter lack of accessories.Regarding the suit -- I wasn't too sure how I felt about a non-removable rubber suit. I do like the way it bunches and gathers around bent limbs - I feel it adds a hint of realism. I suppose I was worried that the hexagonal-pattern to the movie version of the suit would be too pronounced -- and I'm relieved to say it's not. Medicom also did something really smart in extending the sleeve length so that you can extend the arm fully & never see the plastic body underneath.I know it makes sense that the figure be wearing boots rather than, say, socks or booties -- but from pictures it was hard to tell if they clashed with the overall look. They don't. The red of the boots, head and hands matches the suit perfectly.The head. Yeah. The head sculpt is my only real beef with this figure. The neck looks too long, making the head appear too small. I've been tempted to remove the head and alter the neck-length. This would satisfy me.But is it really *that* bad? No, it's not. There are plenty of poses that make the neck length appear less grotesque.Finally, this figure comes with a set of hands and a clear stand and that's it. The extra hands are okay. One is a webslinging pose and the other features spread-out fingers in an "action" pose. They should have includes fists, if not for fighting poses - then at least to attach string to use as webbing.On a final note -- this figure -- and I assume all of these vinyl-suit figures -- is a little hard to pose. The suit material feels like padded vinyl, like a car seat or something, only thinner. It fights back a little bit. So poses of Spider_man with his knees level with his face are not going to happen.I paid $82 free shipping for this figure, new. I feel it's worth that as a Medicom figure -- I'm glad I got it. It's not without it's flaws -- but it is a decently made, quality figure.

This was useful to me for awhile -- if for no other reason than I was tired of wasting tinfoil. Also, the concept of a windcover was appealing... There are a variety of windcovers out there -- they can get a little pricey too. It makes this item seem economical.However, I was still having issues with airflow and harsh smoke with this. I still had to pop the lid and push the coals around occasionally to keep the shisha from burning. This constant maintenance can really put a damper on your smoking experience.Eventually I bought the Kaloud Lotus and I love it. It's more money, a lot more money, but it solved all my issues with heat management. No, I don't work for them. I'm pretty new to hookah smoking, and undoubtedly there's a lot to be learned about the process. All I can really say is that the Kaloud Lotus (which I've also reviewed here on amazon) cut the learning curve. It's essentially Smoking For Dummies.If you are considering getting this for appearance purposes- or you've nearly burned your house down and want to lock up your coals - go for it. But if you're thinking it will help with your heat/airflow issues -- it's a pass.
I love this ring. It looks less cheesy to me than some of the other stainless skull rings available on amazon. The price is great and shipping was pretty darn quick.

Are you in the habit of spending $400 on boots? If so, this review may not pertain to you. I feel there's a certain disconnect between quality and expense these days, regardless of brand or designer, and if I'm going to spend $400 on boots then I expect to be buried in those *^^%%^#& boots.My quest began with a search for Engineer-style boots. I've had a pair of Frye riding boots for a good long while and their construction is top-notch -- and that's what brought me back to Frye.I researched the bejeebus out of this purchase. I price-checked. I read reviews. I compared this to it's Slouch and Short cousins. As far as pricing goes -- there's no break on price with this style, though the slouch and short seem to go on sale now and then. The latter two styles are also readily available on a certain online bidding site if you're okay with second-hand or cosmetically less-than-perfect boots.I ordered size 8.5 in Cognac Antique.If you order one of the more unusual colors - my first piece of advice would be to check and make sure you get the right color. Amazon sent my Cognac instead of Cognac Antique. When I first opened the box I was disappointed that the color did not match the amazon picture, but didn't check the sticker on the box for a day or two. Luckily, I emailed amazon and they made things right by me.Aside from that, I can confirm what most other women are saying. The toe box is pretty tight on these. I'm strictly an 8.5, with my right foot incrementally larger. The right toe box was super-tight. Even after several days of wearing them the toe box was still unpleasant and I had to resort to a shoe-stretcher to open it up. Now that they're thoroughly broken in I could wear these 24/7, and that is 98% of my four stars.The shaft of these boots is thinner leather than what I expected. The quality of the leather is nice, but if you're thinking this is thick, sturdy leather you are mistaken. Since this purchase I've checked out the Veronica Slouch in person, and in my opinion the leather is not as nice. Especially the chocolate and bronze colors. Not impressed with those at all. Maybe it's how they treat the leather to get those particular colors but they might as well be vinyl or pleather.The zipper is good quality. The snaps are nice too, but like other reviews say, they do come loose on occasion. It may not happen often, but it really just has to happen once to be annoying.The soles are good, you won't slip or skid on a smooth surface.All things considered, the boots look great. Stunning, actually. You will get noticed in these. But will your grandkids bury you in these boots after you've lived an adventurous, full life? Probably not. These boots will quit before you do.In short, these are not five-star quality boots. Or should I say, these are not five-star quality Frye boots. If you own an old pair of Frye's you'll know exactly what I mean. However, they are pretty -- and probably one of the more stylish versions of an engineer boot out there. If you're content getting a few good years out of a pair of boots you'll be cool with these.

I'll start this review by saying canvas slip-ons have been my look of choice since high school. Back then they were cheap -- the Payless flagship cheapskate shoe. My parents were too stingy to spring for Converse, and when I got my first job my money had other places to go besides overpriced gym shoes. Maybe other kids would have teased me for my inexpensive choice - but i'm an artist, and drew my designs all over the white canvas slip-ons. Bam, I was cooler than the cool kids.Maybe it's for this very reason canvas slip-ons have gotten so crazy expensive. $40? Seriously? And $40 is a conservative price on some styles. I'm not a tight-wad by any means but the cost-to-value ratio is way out of whack.In my adulthood my go-to brand for awhile was Rocket Dog. But -- their styles seem to have worn thin lately, and I've wanted something a bit more subdued.Anyway, my search turned to Amazon after exhaustive retail store searches. I was about to give in and get one of the cheaper pairs of Van's -- but saw Sanuk cross-referenced on my page. I looked and found that yes, some of the prices are high just like Van's -- but some colors are fairly inexpensive. Less expensive than Airwalks. Okay then. Ordered a pair of Donna's and a pair of Rio's -- the difference between the two is ...heck I can't tell.I followed the advice of other reviewers and went down a half-size. I am strictly an 8.5 without fail. But -- the 8 fit right out of the box, a little snug but not uncomfortable. And of course - after an hour the shoe fit like it was custom made for my foot.In short -- I LOVE these and couldn't be happier.Even so, I debated giving this shoe 4 and not 5 stars. My reason is that these shoes are light -- seriously light in weight. Practically non-existent. This isn't a problem necessarily -- but it does give me some concern when it comes to duration. The construction quality is tight; seams are even, there's no sloppy gluing to be seen -- but I seriously wonder how long these shoes will hold up. It could be they'll surprise me -- I don't know. But for what I paid I am very satisfied with the style, fit and construction of the shoe.How often have you bought something and just felt really, really good about it? This is one of those purchases for me.

Serious question that needs to be asked -- apparently there's another band called The Unicorns so confusion over the artis'ts name is one excuse.Flossie and the Unicorns are a puppet band from the puppet universe of Miss Pussycat. This isn't just weird music for the sake of being weird, it is the soundtrack for a puppet show. If you've seen the puppet shows you know that they are brilliantly creative and funny!So, as far as the negative reviews go -- they are listening to music completely out of context. Granted, they might not approve of miss Pussycat or her husband Mr. Quintron's music anyway -- it's not for everyone. It's not cookie cutter bs.

Not trying to be snide with the review title -- it's an honest question in regards to this receiver. You almost certainly will be befuddled at some point during installation, and rather than tossing the receiver back in its box and shipping it angrily back to amazon you'll need to hit the interwebs. We all live in the hope that someday someone will engineer electronics that will simply work the way we imagine they should, you plug everything in and bam! it all just works. That day is not here and this receiver is not that miracle machine.A lot of these negative reviews are older, or so it seems. My receiver was up-to-date out of the box.Because I was impatient, I did the quick audio set-up first. Listening to music afterwards I wasn't sure what to think, the sound was broad but flat in my opinion. After I did the full audio set up the sound improved drastically -- plus all the listening options, oh, it's hard to be unhappy here.I should mention this receiver is replacing a Yamaha661, which I loved dearly.The video is also improved over my Yamaha, and the issues with 3D that I'd been having are gone.One thing I will say about video upscaling -- the resolution of the device needs to be 480i. My largest hurdle in setting up the receiver was getting my wii to work; I had audio but no video. Some googling finally brought me to a forum that covered this exact issue; set the wii to output at 480i and that was the end of that issue. It looks good and clean now, even for the wii.I have an xbox360, ps3, wii, dvr and turntable hooked up to this receiver. The game systems look great, better than with my old Yamaha. As for the turntable, this receiver does not have a preamp. So, if your turntable doesn't have a built-in preamp you'll need a separate one. I use the ART DJ Pre II.Another thing to keep in mind is that with some of the inputs -- you need to tell the receiver what sort of signal it is looking for. I suppose that just means that they're unassigned within the receiver; I mean, you'd think if you plug an hdmi device into an hdmi input the receiver is just going to see it because, well, hdmi. That's not always the case here - you may have to go into the input settings and tell the receiver that yeah, look for hdmi. I was having this issue with AppleTV.My only roadblock right now is that the Network doesn't work with iTunes, it works with Media Player. I haven't yet figured out if there's a workaround for this because it's not a priority for me. I have a TB drive plugged in via usb and the receiver is able to pull my music off of there -- fairly quickly, too.All said and done this is a heckuva receiver for the lightening-deal price. I'm really happy I went for it.

I've been shopping for a vice I could enjoy in the privacy of my own home - something ritualistic and relaxing. My friend, a smoking caterpillar, suggested I get a narghile. "Hmmm," I thought. Interesting.After much googling and researching I thought an occasional bit of tobacco might be nice. My searches revealed a few obvious points, a few less obvious. Some cheaper hookahs rust. Others don't have a good seal.My research pointed me in the direction of Mya. Are there better, more expensive brands? I'm sure there are. My friend the caterpillar mentioned something about using a two liter bottle and half an orange if I felt like being cheap. That's okay, buddy, I can budget this.The base is heavy, clear glass - although it looks pale yellow/green in amazon's photo. It's a good size, molded - lest we take 'crystal' too literally, and thick. No complaints here.The metal stem is nice too, has a good heft to it & is well insulated. All seals are good and proper. Metal seems like quality, not coated. The silicon gasket seal for the base is thorough. It can slip up a little bit - though if moistened it fits into the base easily.The hose seems like good quality also. Lacquered woods tips at both ends. Looks very nice.The included bowl is a basic one. This set also includes a gasket or grommet as they are often called. Hard to believe a manufacturer would *not* include a grommet but apparently this happens. Rest assured here.Of course everything comes apart and cleans very easily.So, all said and done, this is a quality item and I'm content with what I paid for it. It's nice to have something at the end of the day to prepare for & enjoy.

These pants are so much fun. Made of t-shirt fabric, they are comfortable and cool to wear in the summer. Plus, they are totally unique. Why dress like everyone else when you can invent your own style...?

My iPad was given to me as a gift.  I hadn't asked for it and I didn't expect it -- so when I got it I was more than slightly baffled as to what I would do with it.I'm an artist by trade. I already have a few Wacom tablets.  So when it was suggested i give drawing on the iPad a try -- I scoffed.  The iPad doesn't have sensitivity like the Wacom tablets do, so I couldn't conceive that it would be good for anything beyond hangman or tic-tac-toe.  Of course I was wrong. Crazy wrong.The lack of sensitivity is an issue, but another stylus manufacturer has developed an algorithm that mimics sensitivity -- hopefully Apple will embrace this tech and implement it later on.In the meantime, i learned to love drawing on my iPad; i loved being able to do quick little doodles and email them off to friends or clients... and while it takes some getting used to, you are capable of some remarkable detail.Which is where using a stylus comes in.Since I was initially clueless as to what to do with my iPad -- it also hadn't occurred to me to use a stylus for drawing.  Here I was honing my finger-painting skills and then I watched as my friend casually whipped out her iPad and Pogo stylus and started doodling away.  My jaw nearly dropped; what a revelation!I ordered the exact same stylus she was using, the Pogo Sketch.  When it arrived and I started drawing with it I was less than pleased; the tip is sort of this prickled velcro-y like fabric that is stuffed with foam rubber.  It's pliant, and I didn't feel very in control with it -- by that I mean I couldn't be completely precise in where it would make contact with the screen.  I felt it was just too mushy.Then I ordered Boxwave's stylus.  This was a vast improvement.  The tip feels like a hollow rubber ball.  It's definitely much more precise, and in my opinion -- superior for drawing.  It's also a quality item, it's nicely made, the finish is nice, and it has a lanyard attached that plugs into the iPad's headphone jack.Drawing on iPad is not like drawing on paper.  There's a learning curve to it -- and different people will use different tools in their own way.  In other words, a perfect stylus probably does not exist yet....but for me -- this one is pretty close.

This book was included in the Collector's Edition of Gears of War 2.  As such, it is on par the the usual quality of these types of books.  It's fairly cheap.  The other reviewer says it should be longer and bigger -- and indeed it should be.  As it is -- it's merely a sampling of the time and depth and talent that went into creating the Gears universe.Regarding the standalone price of this item -- remember it is part of a larger package -- and you can still buy Gears 2 Collector's Edition used for less than what the current seller is asking.  On it's own this book is hardly worthwhile to most collectors.

Consider this a review of the special edition itself.  In no way is this a review of the actual game.  I'm going to assume that if you're considering the special edition you already are pretty well-informed about this game and what it entails.The Special Edition was a free, automatic upgrade from Gamestop if you reserved the game with them.  The Special Edition includes a cardboard sleeve proclaiming it to be the Special Edition, as well as a code for the Assassin Outfit and Soundtrack download.  The soundtrack is NOT on an enclosed disc.  What's worse is that ANY Red Dead code will work for the soundtrack -- whether it's the warhorse or golden guns code -- that same code will allow you to download the soundtrack.  So, honestly, the ONLY thing this edition has over a regular release is a paper cover.That's it.  You can decide for yourself if the vultures charging an additional $50 are justified, or merely bloodsucking opportunists.Some Collector's Editions I can understand the mark-up.  You snooze, you lose.  But this Special Edition is not remarkable in any single way.

I'll start by saying I didn't realise right away that it was vinyl.  It seemed like real leather.  This is a nice, simple strap that's soft to the touch and has some very light cushioning to it.  It's not padded, but it's soft against your back and shoulder.  The design is nice too.  I bought mine at a guitar shop so I got to compare the different colors in the flesh.  The 'red' design probably looked the best -- but my guitar is red, and I figured that would be too much.  This 'black' version has hints of brown and gold -- it looks classy and sort of retro.

Okay, you may not need this particular set -- but if you own suede or sheepskin boots -- you at least need to own the brush that comes in this set.  It is by far the most valuable tool out there when it comes to keeping your boots clean.This is the set I bought and used, so it's what I'm reviewing. I'm sure there are better kits available and possibly at a better value. I'm sure you are at least in part paying for the Ugg name.At first I wasn't too impressed with this set -- largely because it didn't magically do what I expected it do to.  Of course -- I've since come to learn that I didn't know how to use this set.  Perhaps that is the single criticism this set deserves -- it does not come with in-depth instructions -- just the instructions on the bottles of solution -- so not the best source of information.In January I bought a sand colored pair of Emu sheepskin boots.  One night when it was raining I stepped out of my car and into a puddle in the gutter.  One boot got soaked  but I figured it would dry okay.  I was wrong.  The rainwater must have been greasy because it left dark brown stains all along the sole of my boot.I tried everything to clean it and nothing worked.  If anything I succeeded only in spreading the grease stains around.  Soon, the one boot looked drastically different from the other and I couldn't imagine wearing them in public anymore.  That's when I ordered this cleaning kit -- but when I tried the cleaning solution -- it didn't seem to do anything.Just as I was about to throw the boots away I started scouring the web for solutions.  Eventually I found a site that detailed use of a nubuck brush -- like the one included in this set.The brush has bristles on one side, white chalk on the other.  Along the sides of the brush are rubber teeth -- like a comb.  Brushing the suede or sheepskin after it's been washed will restore the texture.  But by far -- the white chalk is the best possible solution for grease stains.  Rubbing the stains with the white chalk and then brushing it out works like a miracle.  It took several applications to some stains -- but this brush saved my boots.  I can't emphasize this enough -- my boots were so bad I was ready to throw them away -- but now they look new again.

I can't consider myself a huge fan of either Guitar Hero or Rock Band.  I bought the first Guitar Hero when it came out and enjoyed it immensely -- but immediately became dismayed by the onslaught of new game and controller releases.  Compatibility also became an issue after awhile.That said, I'll explain that I'm a game collector -- however -- I prefer to own the best of peripherals rather than a huge swatch of them.  I don't need 4 guitars and drums and all of that. One really nice guitar that is built well and will last is what would best suit my needs.  This Logitech seems to fit the bill nicely.When I originally did my research -- I was disappointed that this guitar wasn't full-size.  This almost kept me from buying it.  After some consideration I decided I didn't really need something that large taking up so much space.As for the guitar itself -- my only complaint is a cosmetic one.  The fret buttons are an eyesore.  When you think about the lengths that Logitech went to in order to make a nice "mini" guitar -- you can't help but think that it would have been nice if it looked a tad more realistic.  The brown plastic on the neck used for both the buttons and the slider bar cheapens the overall look.  This isn't a major complaint -- like I said it's purely cosmetic -- but it makes this guitar more toy-like, which is too bad.When it came to gameplay -- I scored significantly better with this controller.  There were songs on Guitar Hero Metallica I could never get through before -- but this controller feels a lot more comfortable to me.  The wood neck fits nicely in my palm -- making those fret buttons easy to get to.  And the strum bar is so silent that sometimes I thought I was missing notes!  Gone are the days of having to shake the controller to invoke Star Power, too.  I liked having all of the hardware right where I could get to it.All in all -- this is a great controller.  If pricepoint is your concern -- wait for a sale -- but this is definitely worth picking up.

I've never owned a pair of Uggs, so I can't make any comparisons.  I've enjoyed this style of boot -- regardless of brand -- but have been put off by the price.  $200 for such a simply made boot?  Come on.These Emu's came up on a one-day-only sale -- so I finally bit the bullet.  I read the glowing reviews here on amazon, bought a size down -- and have been enjoying them ever since.Here's the skinny:These boots are well made. The stitching is tight, the soles are nice.  The insides are warm without making your feet sweaty. The sheepskin is supple.  Everything about these boots is quality... I can see these lasting for quite some time -- and when it is time to get a new pair -- I won't hesitate to pay retail.  Buy with confidence.UPDATE (4/3/10)Weeks of constant wear was bound to result in disaster.One rainy evening I exited my car curbside, stepping into a gutter filled with rain.  One boot was saturated about an inch into the sheepskin.  I wasn't worried at the time -- I figured it would dry and be fine.  Oh, but I was wrong.  Apparently the gutter water was greasy, and the sand-colored sheepskin stained a dark brown.Attempts to clean the sheepskin only resulted in making it worse.  Wiping the stains with a damp sponge succeeded only in smearing the stains around.  Before too long -- one boot looked drastically different from the other. I purchased a sheepskin cleaning kit made by Ugg -- but it didn't help at all.Eventually, I was driven to more extreme measures -- I set my clothes washer to hand-wash, cold water, said a prayer and tossed the boots in(LET IT BE SAID I do not recommend anyone repeat this.  I have read that other people have done this with success, but you can totally avoid this!).  Suffice it to say I had reached the point where -- at best -- I had hoped to damage both boots at least similarly.  It was that, or throw them away. It was a last, desperate attempt to save the boots I loved. I'd already broken down and bought a cheaper suede pair of Emu's.With my sheepskin boots somewhat cleaner but dried out -- I began a web search to find out if there was any sort of additive that could restore softness to the sheepskin.  This is when I discovered an article that more or less explained that the most valuable sheepskin cleaning tool is a sheepskin/nubuck brush.  Luckily, I had one in the Ugg kit I'd bought.I include this update to tell all of you that the most valuable tool you can buy to preserve your boots is this brush.  My boots now look like new, despite all of my attempts to destroy them.  They are once again supple and smooth.The brush you need has bristles on one side, white chalk on the other.  Around the sides are soft teeth -- like a rubber comb.  Using these simple elements you keep your boots looking like new.  The white chalk will remove the nastiest of grease stains.I brushed the boots thoroughly while they were still slightly damp, raising the texture of the sheepskin suede, using the rubber comb first and then the fine brush.  I then used the chalk on the grease -- some stains I had to go over a few times -- but soon they all vanished.  It took about an hour or two of brushing -- but both boots are clean and free of stains -- and look new again.So please -- heed the advice of other posters -- particularly if you are getting these boots on sale -- spend the money you save on a cleaning kit.  Prep the boots with a stain repellent before you wear them, and use the nubuck brush to remove stains.  Do this -- and these boots will last and last....

My fiance and I have had in mind for awhile to buy a slow cooker.  We received a $100 gift certificate for a retailer - known more for their smarminess than their affordable pricing -- and thought this would be the perfect thing to spend it on.  This retailer in particular only had two models of slow cookers to choose from, this one and a 5 quart DeLonghi.  I like the DeLonghi brand well enough -- but we thought the cooker was kind of ugly looking.  So is the Cuisinart, truth be told.There were only a handful of features that helped guide our choice.  First was the extra quart-and-a-half capacity.  The programmable heating settings also seemed like they could be useful.  This slow cooker also comes with a cooking rack for when you're doing a roast. Ultimately what convinced us to go with this model was the fact that it's big enough TO do a roast -- you have room enough to do a whole chicken.When we got home we immediately checked amazon to see how badly we'd been ripped off.  Oddly enough -- it was the same price.  However -- the reviews shocked us.  How can a slow cooker get such horrible reviews when all it has to do is get hot and stay hot?  We freaked out a bit and almost ran back to return it.Like most people who bother to read reviews on amazon -- you're probably aware that typically some of the bad reviews are people just mouthing off, or rating the product based some other bad experience they've had, or they haven't read the user manual for their device and are in the process of breaking it themselves.  There might be a bad review or two like this here, for the Cuisinart.  But otherwise -- people are saying some frightening things -- namely, that the Cuisinart doesn't cook the food.As for this slow cooker being badly engineered or made cheaply -- I'm not sure where that comes from.  Look at it this way; this cooker holds a huge, thick, 6.5 quart ceramic bowl.  The bowl itself can not be confused for cheap.  The brushed stainless steel unit that it fits into likewise has to be huge.  So, you have this huge steel unit and it's only function is to get hot.  Do heating coils take up a lot of room?  No, they don't.  Are they heavy? No, they're not.  If if the opinion of cheap is coming from the fact that the base is big and feels hollow -- then in my opinion they are not being very fair.The only complaint I can make is that the programmable buttons are keypad type buttons.  I would have preferred actual push-in surface buttons, but when you think about it -- the keypad style is much easier to clean up AND prevents moisture from any spilled liquids from getting inside.Regarding the "permanent" fingerprints -- I'm not sure how that phenomenon can actually take place. I just wiped the unit down and it looks completely new again.  Just because it's brushed stainless steel doesn't mean it won't get fingerprints.Anyway, we decided to keep the cooker and we're glad we did.  I threw together some chicken soup last night and we each had a delicious bowl of it this morning.  Everything was cooked perfectly -- the carrots were soft and flavorful and the chicken melted away from the bone.  I have no complaints or regrets. I would have given it five stars if it were just a tad prettier..

A couple of years ago I fell for the alleged ease-of-use of a ION USB Turntable.  The price was reasonable, and honestly -- I just wanted to convert some of my old vinyl without much hassle.  I guess in that sense USB Turntables are okay.  But ya know -- a cheap turntable is made cheaply.  Even after I replaced the ION cartridge with one made by Shure -- the sound quality just didn't match what I was accustomed to from a "real" turntable.  YES, you can use software to clean up the sound a bit...but I can't help but think this dilutes the recording somewhat.My real dilemma came with having to transfer some recordings from tape.  The Ion turntable I have has a line in jack for just this purpose, but in the end the sound volume was too low, almost muffled.And so, enter the Behringer device.  This transfer device is a dream, it couldn't be easier to use.  Download Audactity and you are good to go.  I was making recordings within minutes.My recordings have a great volume level and are free of hum.  I couldn't be happier with this purchase. If Only I'd known about this years ago...

When a friend purchased the BSG pilot movie for me and insisted I watched it because it was "great" I procrastinated.  A child of the 70's I remember the original series, and thought it was basically Love Boat in space. The Ovions were cool, and the robot dog (Moffat?  Moppat?  Muppet?) was cool, but other than that I found it cheesy and for the most part uninteresting.So when I finally got around to watching that pilot movie for the new BSG -- I was blown away -- and within minutes.  It was clearly a quality product right out of the box, good writing, good acting -- great effects.  I went on to follow the series faithfully -- and the series as a whole was fantastic.  Sure, there were some pretty lame "filler" episodes, but all in all it was a monumental sci-fi series.Caprica did not inspire the same sort of enthusiasm.  To be honest, I thought it was fairly terrible, but I'm willing to withhold condemnation.  My issues so far revolve around the cast which seems spotty; Morales is a perfect choice for the serior Adama, and Stoltz, too, seems appropriately cast.  However, I honestly couldn't identify with anyone else.  In fact, I found the teenage characters brutally annoying.Without giving away spoilers -- the writing did not engage me until the second half of the movie.  Even then, I sort of felt like hanging on simply for the sake of being able to say I watched the whole thing.  There's also some sexual overtones sprinkled throughout which I'm sure were supposed to be provocative, but I felt were in poor taste. I'm not referring to the club scenes of writhing and dry humping either.  I'm referring more to scenes with the head-mistress.  It was sort of like 90210 in space, the very special "Just Say No" episode.  When writers throw crappy and obvious hints like that at their audience, it seems more that they're pandering to kids and shut-ins who's only experience with alternative relationships is what they watch on Jerry Springer.Anyway, for me, the writing seemed reminiscent of that lesbian tie-in that they did in BSG mid-season, Razor. Battlestar Galactica - Razor (Unrated Extended Edition)  That episode left me wondering why the lesbian relationship was integral?  To show Cain had softer, human side? Or to explain why she was so "tough".  From what I recall, that Commander was not a completely unlikeable character, sure -- she was tough as nails and very much by-the-books but those were/are respectable qualities.  However, she was an obstacle that needed to be eliminated, and in the process her sexual identity was dumped on the table, she was reduced to a "woman-spurned" and then axed. Let me quickly say that I "get" that the culture of BSG seemed to have a more open sexual identity, and that the show lacked the bias that real society actually has -- but for a show that has paralleled so many issues and handled them all with grace -- some things just seem thrown out there for the heck of it.  For ratings.  For titillation. For whatever reason, but this deliberate flirtation with open sexuality sometimes seems so cheaply done to me.  I say this not as a prude, but as someone who appreciates a connection between "sexy" and "smart".But that's just one aspect, other fans might recall that Razor was a bit of a mish-mash.  Caprica, too, is a little neither-here-nor-there as the writers struggle to make it more complicated than a future Frankenstein story.So, while I did not care for "Caprica" at all -- I'm willing to have some faith and stick around for a couple of episodes.  While I found this movie to be a poor teaser for the series -- it may take a few episodes to round out the plot and endear viewers to the characters.

I'll say first off I bought this at the discounted price, and that makes it a particularly sweet deal.The worst thing about this guitar is the fact it says Hannah Montana on it, and for those of you who are curious -- it's not a decal you can just peel off.  Luckily for me, I work in product development and have access to both acrylic and laser cutters.  So, I replaced the pick guard with one that covers the name of the shrill and annoying Disney Mutant Hell Spawn which is Hannah Montana.As I had this thing apart briefly, I can assure you that, despite some rumors on the web, the neck is not plastic -- it's wood, probably maple.  The body is wood also, but I can't say what type.  So -- this is a fairly solid constructed guitar. It's light enough for a kid, but it is not built like a toy.I can't vouch for the hardware, it seems pretty basic.  I had a musician friend tune it for me, and he had some difficulty tuning all the way up the neck.  He suggested taking it to a tech at a place like Guitar Center and paying for a thorough tune-up.  That would bring my expense pretty much up to full retail, however that may not be such a bad thing.Some better strings are also recommended.I plugged this into my amp at home and played around -- it has a pretty good sound, I'm definitely happy with it.  Strumming along, I had a vision of the future -- wherein my grown-up niece was onstage at the Grammy's -- thanking her aunt for buying her first guitar and changing her life forever.

I first saw this Dickie's bag during my daily commute -- a woman had the black-with-pink-stars bag slung over her shoulder and I thought it was the coolest looking bag I'd seen in awhile.  Luckily for me, the Dickie's label was prominently displayed on the front -- so I looked up the bag on amazon later the same day.When I received the bag I was pretty happy.  The material is stiff (although it does break in) and certainly seemed at least somewhat waterproof.  The construction seems rugged, the stitching is tight.  I had no reason to question whether or not I'd bought a quality product.  However -- my thoughts on that changed withing a few weeks.Here's the thing.  On one side of the bag -- where the strap meets the actual bag itself -- the strap is looped through an elongated "O" ring.  This is to accommodate the adjustable strap.  Because of this "O" ring, however, the strap bunches up and forces the O ring on to it's side. This may not seem like a big deal, but it throws the strap off and also looks pretty stupid. It's minor, and initially it didn't bother me too much -- but now that it's been about 6 months it irritate me to no end.  Also, the strap is permanently warped at this point -- it won't lay flat no matter what.So, this is an okay bag for the money -- the quality is good for the most part, the choice of designs is really nice.  But it has a significant design flaw that Dickie's needs to adjust.

I just got these to replace a pair of Creative bluetooth phones.  I thought I was happy with my Creative phones, even with the occasional bit of static and the limited battery life.. these things weren't major issues for me.  But I saw a deal on this headset and once I learned they are made by Harmon Kardon I figured I couldn't go wrong.These blow my Creative phones out of the water.  We're talking total annihilation here.First of all, these are designed to work wit iPods 4th generation AND ON.  So this includes the 2G Touch which is what I am using.The receiver is great, matches the Touch exactly.  It pairs in seconds, too.The headphones are comfortable -- soft, buttery leather.They also come with a bunch of swappable tips for the AC charger -- so you can charge these in Europe and Asia.  They also include a handsome carrying pouch.Very happy with this purchase.  Absolutely no regrets.

Ideally -- for music you want a pair of wired headphones.  They just sound better.  But if you want the convenience of wireless -- these bluetooth headphones aren't bad.I dispute the battery life claims on here -- mine last about 7 or 8 hours.  I make frequent flights from the midwest to California and I listen to these there and back without having to change batteries.I haven't had any issues with connectivity either.  I can listen to music from my computer in the next room without the connection dropping.  I get a second or two of static walking downtown but that's not unreasonable to me.I also think these are fairly comfortable.  They're also sturdy -- built well.The dongle is a tad irritating, though -- I do wish the cable were shorter.

Isn't it funny how some people and vendors think that ancient technology is still worth top dollar??I didn't by this switch from the seller currently under the item listing, but I did buy mine through amazon for a comparable sum.  It's ridiculous, but when you're in a jam I suppose you can't be too particular.My need for this item arose from my video game obsession.  I was not trying to use two computers and one monitor, but rather one computer and a Sega Dreamcast (with vga adapter) to my LCD tv.  Kvm switches would not work for me (I tried several) since there was no mouse or keyboard on the DC's end.So, this forced me to go retro.  This switcher box didn't work immediately for the Dreamcast -- I kept getting a display message saying the signal had to be 60Hz (which I thought was the default anyhow).  But eventually, and for no apparent reason (I was literally just checking all cable connections) it sprung to life and decided to work flawlessly.So, when all else fails -- you may want to take a trip back in time and try a good ol' A-B switcher box.  It gets four stars for being a bile-tinged shade of beige, otherwise I have no complaints other than what people charge for ancient garage-sale technology.

When you think about it -- Java Juice is one of those items that is so simple, so obvious -- you wonder why it wasn't invented sooner.  It's 100% arabica coffee extract and filtered water.  Unlike instant coffee (which tastes awful anyway) there's nothing to dissolve! Hot water, cold water -- it doesn't matter.  It's the ultimate on-the-go indulgence, decent tasting coffee when you want it.

Last week sometime I finally made up my mind to be more proactive in my battle against winter.. I've got the whole dressing-in-layers thing down pretty good, but I seriously needed a pair of winter boots.  I find the popularity and style of Uggs rather tempting, but not the pricetag.  I also thought that there's no way suede can hold up against snow and water for very long.  Who wants to spend $120 on boots that they only get a season or two out of?So, web searches eventually turned up Kamik.  "Snowden" wasn't my first choice, but other varieties were sold out.  Snowden was sold out in many colors, so I had to get them in light grey.I paid just over $50 and let me say -- they are absolutely worth it.  These are heavy duty, water and weatherproof boots.  I think they are tested to endure -40 degree weather.  The soles are thick and stiff and have deep treads.  Inside they are soft & warm.  The liner is removable for easy cleaning.  If I had seen these in a store I probably would have been willing to pay as much as $80, maybe more.  These boots are a quality item.I don't know if fashionistas would like them, however; they might be a bit too utilitarian.  Nonetheless they still look good, they are not cumbersome and they do not make your feet look big.  I've been walking around the house in them to break them in a little bit and they aren't the least bit clumsy.The only minor complaint I have is that they are made a half size too small.  I knew about this in advance, though.  They don't make half-sizes, so I went a size down instead of up and they fit perfectly.

I bought this movie because I watched Azur et Asmar and was blown away by it; while I suspected that Kirikou, an earlier film, would be more primitive I had not anticipated it would also be less interesting.This is a cute fairy tale, don't get me wrong. But it isn't nearly as complex or visually interesting as Azur & Asmar.One thing to consider, particularly if you are buying this for children -- is that this is not Disney.  This animated film depicts an african village as you might expect to see it; most of the women are only partially dressed. If you are comfortable with this aspect then Kirikou is a fine film for all ages.

I'm not sure why this film is so difficult to obtain in the US, english versions have been released in the UK and Ireland.  I sincerely hope that it's eventually released on Blu-ray -- as this movie is pure eye candy.  It is a joy and pleasure to watch.The story is simple enough; criticisms almost variably focus on the film's message of racial and cultural equality.  Yes, the film has a message but it's presented in a very tasteful way. The movie makes it's pount without rubbing your nose in the obvious.The characters in this film are also beautifully represented; they are robust personalities that you can relate to. I honestly can't say enough good things about this movie.The special edition of Azur & Asmar seen in this listing is Korean and it region 3.  The set itself is wonderful; the book is high quality and contains stills taken from the film.  There is also a bonus dvd which personally I've never watched.If you're looking for an affordable region free player I recommend the Philips 5690. I bought mine right here on amazon.  Google the model for further details.

I'd owned a few digital cameras before settling on this one, and I never regretted my purchase until now.  I say this because the camera is dead, and Olympus estimates the repair at $174.  That's just plain crazy.Turns out my problem is a fairly common one, so if you get this camera my advice would be to get the protection plan.  My camera lasted about two years.Contrary to the negative reviews on here, I think it got excellent battery life.  Try a Nikon CoolPix if you want to see crappy battery life.  Even with plain old AA's this camera would power up for a good while... but I would typically get those super-duper lithium batteries.  You pay more but they last far longer.As for the slow shutter speed, I agree it is a problem at time.  But I started using the sports setting for my action shots.  This helped.This is a good little camera, and it took great pictures. Just be aware of the fact that it's most likely mechanical failure will cost you the price of a new camera.  I'm not a fan of protection plans, but I would definitely suggest it here.

THE EARLY STRING QUARTETS by Beethoven, as recorded by Takacs Quartet on the Decca label, is a 2-disc set, with a small booklet with seven pages in English.  We learn that the members oare Edward Dusinberre, Karoly Schranz, Roger Tapping, and Andras Feyer.  The recordings were at St. Georges in Bristol.  Bristol is a town on the west coast of England, with an interesting history.  For example, town of Brycgstow (meaning the place at the bridge) was founded by 1000 and by  1020, was a trading center with a mint producing silver pennies. By 1067 Brycgstow was a well-fortified burh, capable of resisting an invasion sent from Ireland by Harold Godwinson's sons.Anyway, this is a review of the cuts on the second of the two discs.  Overall, it is the case that Takacs Quartet sometimes imposes a bouncing, oscillating quality to the music.  Perhaps, the goal is to prevent the music from being bogged down (though, this is not imply that, without the oscillating quality, the music would be bogged down).  Similarly, it is the case that Hilary Hahn's recording of the Bach Violin Sonatas possess a bouncy, springy quality, which makes these recordings especially engaging, and contrast them from the intolerably monotonous recordings by Elizabeth Wallfisch of the same Bach sonatas.  At any rate, the Takacs recording of these Beethoven pieces are exciting, and invite repeated listenings. The second disc has 12 cuts, which consists of Quartets Nos. 4, 5, and 6.Cut 1.  Begins with a theme having slightly ominous overtones.  Cut 1 is vigorous and occasionally bouncing and romping.  The piece is distinguished in that the flow of the piece is occasionally punctuated by a short disruptive motif that resembles a saw being used to cut through a thick wooden board.  (8 minutes, 10 second).Cut 2.  Begins with a dainty dance tune.  The piece is actually a fugue, where the tune is overlaid upon a motoristic chugging motif. (6 min, 18 sec).Cut 3.  This is played with a pronounced oscillation in volume.  At 1 min, 30 sec, the piece has a sudden change in character, perhaps sounding like a shepherd in an alpine valley calling to his flock, followed by a response of bleating.  (3 min, 30 sec)Cut 4.  The piece begins with a skittering motif that is repeated a few times, and this is followed by a lush flowing motif that is also repeated a few times.  At 1 min, 15 seconds, the skittering motif returns but this time it is more aggressive.  At 2 min, 50 sec, the listener is treated to the plucked cello.  This is one of the few cuts on this disc that has some repetitive qualities.  (4 min, 0 sec).Cut 5.  This piece is gentle throughout, and it is distinguished by a motif where one note is played like this, "Dum-ta-dum-ta, dum-ta-dum-ta," followed by a flourish reminiscent of a playground swing, whisking back and forth.  The playground motif is in three quarters time.  (6 min, 35 sec).Cut 6.  This is the boring cut of the disc, because the piece is dull.  At 2 min, 40 sec, Takacs Quartet engages in its distinctive exaggerated oscillations in volume.  This sounds like somebody playing with the volume knob (this is not a complaint, it is just an observation).  (5 min, 10 sec.)Cut 7. This begins with a tune having a descending motif, "Da-dahhhh, dee-dee-dee-dee-deeeee," that concludes with an upwards flourish.  At 2 min, 35 seconds, the pace doubles, and the repeated nature of what has transpired so far, is reiterated.  This piece would be good for contra dancing, because of the steady rhythm, because of the lack of jarring surprises, and because of the repetitiveness.  At 4 min, begins an extended motif sounding like a flock of birds.  The descending motif, "Da-dahhhh, dee-dee-dee-dee-dee-dee" is still hanging on, and at 6 minutes, this descending motif is repeated with enhanced vigor.  (9 min, 10 sec).Cut 8.  Skittering and jittery episodes separated by brief motifs that are gliding.  At 3 min, the vigor increases, and the various motifs are repeated, but at a higher point in the register or at a lower point in the register.  From my notes, it appears that I especially liked Cut 8.  I wrote these notes while commuting from a biotech company in South San Francisco, eastwards over the Bay Bridge, in the slow traffic.  (6 min, 25 sec)  In my notes, I wrote, "6 min, 25 sec of bliss.")Cut 9.  This cut is more like a contra dance, with more repetition, and a greater number of easily recognizable guideposts.  The violins and cello are treated as equals, and they take turns in leading the way, each singing the same quirky melody.  The melody goes like this, "Ta-dah, up, down, dup, down, uuuuuup, down."  I liked Cut 9, though the melody seems a bit silly.  6 min, 0 sec of silliness.Cut 10.  This is a slow piece.  At 5 min, 40 sec, what happens is a brief change in atmosphere, then after a half minute, the original atmosphere returns, and things just fade away.  (6 min, 40 sec).Cut 11.  This is a lively piece, and is distinguished by occasional prolonged violin trills on a high note.  After 90 seconds, comes a special effect, resembling one of the many, many special effects found in the Paganini Violin Concertos.  The special effect in the Beethoven Quartet, is like a slinky collapsing. (3 min, 0 sec).Cut 12.  Starts out very slowly, with an ascending theme, punctuated by ominous splashes. A ten second series of ominous splashes occurs at 2 min, 20 sec.  Then comes a very ominous ascending motif from a low-throated cello.  At 3 min, 30 seconds, a merry tune issues forth.  Despite being a merry tune, it is not repetitive, and certainly would not be suitable for contra dancing.  At 6 min, 20 sec, starts an ominous interlude.  (8 min, 0 seconds).

THE PURSUIT OF HAPPYNESS takes place in San Francisco, with about equal time given to a run down area in Chinatown and to upscale environment in the nearby financial district.  Please note that, aside from the main street in Chinatown, Grant Avenue, many of nearby side streets are somewhat run down.  The run down areas extend for only one or two blocks, to the east and to the west, of Grant Avenue.  The main characters include Will Smith, his young son, his wife, and a hiring manager at a financial firm, played by Brian Howe.Will Smith's job is to sell bone scanners.  During much of the movie, Will Smith is shown toting a box resembling a typical box that contains a Singer sewing machine.  The film shows Will Smith visiting various doctor's offices, attempting to gain a sale.  We learn that he needs to sell two bone scanner machines per month, in order to break even.  Will Smith's wife has a job too, but it is a humble laundry worker job.  In the opening moments of the movie, we see Will Smith in his neighborhood, accompanied by his son.  Graffiti decorates the outside walls of the businesses on the side streets in Chinatown, and we see an area with the F-word, and next to that is the word, HAPPYNESS. Will Smith asks the owner of the business, an elderly Chinese man, to remove the graffiti, because it is not appropriate.  But the man is not responsive to Will Smith's request.  In a couple of other scenes, we see Will Smith dropping his son off at a daycare center, which is run by an old Chinese woman.  Will Smith requests that the woman discontinue her behavior in exposing the children to television programs, and instead engage in, for example, reading stories or teaching games.  The old Chinese woman disagrees, and resists this suggestion.  These features of the plot line establish that Will Smith is a caring parent who has the goal of acting responsibly.ROADBLOCKS. Don't worry, I do not give away the ending.  In fact, I will only disclose the many roadblocks that occur in the course of Will Smith's occupation as a bone scanner salesman, and in his quest to gain entry to an internship to become a stockbroker.(1) On the visit to one medical doctor, the bone scanner does not work.(2) During his initial visit to the financial firm, when he wishes to apply for a job, Will Smith leaves his bone scanner in the care of a hippie girl who is playing guitar on the sidewalk.  But the hippie girl steals the bone scanner, and disappears in the subway, that is, in Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART).(3) A nutty man, with long scraggly hair, believes that the bone scanner is a time machine, and he steals one of the bone scanners.(4) Will Smith's wife has a humble job in a laundry, but the income enables the family to pay most of the bills.  The wife has no faith that Will Smith will every be able to support the family, and she threatens to move to New York, and that is just what she does.  As was the case in the another movie, Kramer v. Kramer, she abandons her young son.(5) Will Smith secures a job interview with the financial firm, but the day before, when he is painting his apartment, the police arrive.  The police take him to jail for the night.  His only clothes are a T shirt, old jacket, and blue jeans, and his face is splattered with paint.  The next morning, when he is released from jail, he arrives at his job interview, but does not have time to dress in his usual formal business attire.  Instead, he shows up for the interview in the T shirt, with face splattered with paint.  Will Smith manages to turn this very negative situation into a positive feature of his character, and he does this by an impromptu spiel.(6) During his internship with the financial firm, Will Smith is invited to a baseball game with a potential client.  The potential client is shown to live in an upper class home, and he offers Will Smith the opportunity to join him in a box seat to see the San Francisco Giants.  Thus, for this ten minute interlude in the movie, it looks as though Will Smith will make a sale.  But then, the potential client exclaims that there is no way that he will ever do business with Will Smith's company, and will not trust this company with his retirement plan.  The refusal is done in a good-natured way, and Will Smith handles the refusal with aplomb and is not fazed.CONCLUSION.  Basically, this is a film about showing tenacity during a prolonged job hunt, when everything goes wrong.  I only know of one other movie that travels along the same territory, namely, KRAMER v. KRAMER, where Dustin Hoffman loses his job and scrambles to find  a new one.  As is the case with THE PURSUIT OF HAPPYNESS, it is the case that the main character has a young son and is dumped by his wife.  In HAPPYNESS, the wife moves from California to New York, and in KRAMER v. KRAMER, the wife moves from the east coast to California.  During essentially all of story, Will Smith manages to stay cool, collected, and professional.  On only one occasion, occurring at about one hour and 17 minutes into the movie, it is the case that Will Smith loses his composure.  This movie will likely be an inspiration to any person who finds himself subjected to that feature of the game of life (not always a rational game), called the job interview

LONELY PLANET MAKE MY DAY SAN FRANCISCO is a guidebook with a cardboard cover that is 20 pages long. The subtitle, "make my day" is a reference to a famous line from the Dirty Harry movie, a film located in San Francisco.The cover is made of thick cardboard, and this is not quite a hardcover book. All of the pages, as well as a flimsy paper map in the back of the book, are secured to a white metal spiral binding. Each page is made of sturdy glossy paper, and most of the pages are sliced into three sections, where each of the three sections can be turned independently of each other. Thus, rather than state that the book has 20 pages, it might be more appropriate to describe the book as having 60 flaps.When the book is open, the flap on the left side has a large thumbnail photo of a particular feature while, on the right side, the corresponding flap has an informative paragraph and a tiny color map. This is a very clever and attractive feature of the book. The publisher's goal was to enable the travel to independently adjust the flaps, so that the top flap would show one attraction of interest, the middle flap another attraction, and the bottom flap yet another attraction. Thus, the goal was to enable the traveler to acquire idle amusement by creating "the perfect day," consisting of whatever is revealed by the top, middle, and bottom flap. Of course, just because it is possible to create your perfect day in this way, does NOT prevent you from spending the entire week visiting only features that in the top flaps.Each flap has different attractions, such as GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE, LOMBARD STREET, and CHINATOWN, as well as less iconic attractions, such as CABLE CAR MUSEUM, CITY LIGHTS BOOKSTORE, and DE YOUNG MUSEUM.I have visited San Francisco at least 200 times, in the past few decades, and am familiar with all of the attractions disclosed in this book, except for ALCATRAZ (nevah been there, and nevah will go there), SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS (I did see Pink Floyd perform in the Giants baseball park, though), BEAT MUSEUM, and KABUKI SPA. The written narratives are informative and not merely happy-sounding literary fluff. For example, regarding the MISSION DISCTRICT MURALS, we read that these are found on a street called, Balmy Alley, and that one mural depicts Archbishop Oscar Romero. Regarding CABLE CAR MUSEUM, we read that one can see three original cable cars from the 1870s, and that the cables were invented by Andrew Hallidie in 1873.CONCLUSION. This is a fine guidebook for travelers who do not have patience to thumb through a typical 200-page guidebook. Of course, every resident of the San Francisco Bay area will be able to name a great tourist destination that is NOT in this booklet. In my opinion, the omissions include FORT FUNSTON, where one can view at close range the hang gliders, and watch dare-devils step off into space from the side of a high cliff, and become carried aloft over the Pacific Ocean. Another omission is STOW LAKE, which is one of the tamer features of San Francisco, but which can always be relied upon for a predictable afternoon of relaxing boating among the turtles and stone bridges. But perhaps number one on my list of "San Francisco attractions," is the hike and view from the northern side of the Golden Gate Bridge to Fort Barry, which provides one of the most dramatic views of any city in all America. But technically, Fort Barry is not really in San Francisco. To me, the book is more like a novelty than a real source of information. However, to a person who has been to San Francisco only one time, or perhaps never, than the book is likely to be tantalizing.

ANCIENT PLACES by Jack Nisbet is a 240-page book, apparently about some of the geologic wonders in the Pacific Northwest, that is, in the states of Oregon and Washington.  These wonders include the Willamette Meteorite (page 39-66) and the Missoula Floods (pages 23-38 and 223-229).  It is difficult to understand what this book is about, unless one is already familiar with the subject matter.  For example, in the beginning of the chapter on the Missoula Floods, we read:"Farmed fields spot its interior, and tribal lore tells of epic horse races around its perfectly flat top.  It was a searing summer day when I visited the base of the mesa's north side with a group of Spokane tribal friends.  On the edge of a quiet neighborhood, we parked near a stand of cattails that marked a small spring" (page 23).Thus, it is the case that in the first few pages of this chapter (pages 23-38), it is impossible to figure out what is the subject matter.  The writing in this book is more like a diary, that is, where the author's intent in writing is only as a sort of self-therapy.  However, for a book intended for the public, the author should refrain from being so evasive in disclosing the intended topic.  Also in this chapter (page 32), we read, "YouTube videos monitoring the removal of modern concrete dams attest to the power of this process," but no citation is given.  The reader is not provided with the names or authors of any YouTube videos.  Moreover, please note that YouTube videos can be removed at any time, without notice.  Again, the book is more like a home-grown diary than a real book.I have done my homework on the Missoula Floods, and I recommend the following books:(1) D. Alt (2001) Glacial Lake Missoula and Its Humongous Floods (208 pages).(2) J. Soennichsen (2009) Bretz's Flood: The Remarkable Story of a Rebel Geologist and the World's Greatest Flood (304 pages).(3) J. Allen and M. Burns (2009) Cataclysms on the Columbia: the Great Missoula Floods (216 pages).(4) V. Baker (1981) Catastrophic Flooding: The Origin of the Channeled Scabland (360 pages).Also, I very much recommend the NOVA video, which is available in the DVD format, and also for free on YouTube.  This video is, "NOVA:Mystery of the Megaflood (2006) Produced by Ben Fox (56 minutes).CONCLUSION.  To conclude, in viewing the author's publications on Amazon.com website, it appears that the author is successful, and is liked by his readers, and that he has found his own literary niche.  Please also note, that, as a pastime, I have shown an ongoing and chronic interest in the subject-matter of Mr. Nisbet's books, that is, ecology and geology of the Pacific Northwest (as well as of California and Wisconsin).  However, I am not attracted to the aimless chit-chat writing style that is utilized by the author.  Well, as they say, "to each his own," and as they say, "different strokes for different folks."

LONELY PLANET DISCOVER FRANCE is a 415-page guidebook by Berry, Averbuck and Butler.  The book is printed on glossy paper.  Essentially every other page has a color photograph or a color map.  The rear cover has a paper fold-out map of Paris, printed on flimsy paper.  The map includes many colors: beige (city blocks), yellow (main streets), white (other streets), green (parks), and blue (rivers), with names of important locations printed in red, e.g., MUSEE DE LOUVRE, MUSEE D'ORSAY, and CATHEDRALE NOTRE DAME DE PARIS.Because most of the photographs are small, and because there is not much writing, as compared to guidebooks from FODOR'S or FROMMER'S, I would imagine that the budget for this book was relatively small and, moreover, I would guess that the authors were in the state of pain because the small budget prevented them from writing, at length, about all of the glorious things to see and do in France.CHAPTERS.  The book has seven chapters, where the edges of each chapter are color-coded with a different color:(1) Paris;(2) Normandy and Brittany Spears;(3) Champagne and Northern France;(4) Loire Valley and Central France;(5) Lyon and French Alps;'(6) Bridget Bordeaux and French Basque Country;(7) Provence and French Riviera.GRIPE WITH SMALL PHOTOGRAPHS.  The book is filled with many photographs, but unfortunately, most of the photographs are small, and also unfortunately, many of the photographs were trimmed to create a round-shaped photograph.  Although the designers of this book meant well, I find the circular photographs to be annoying.  The circular photos are annoying because they are not true to what was intended by the photographer, and also because they remove the context from the photograph.  The book, as a whole cannot be read for enjoyment --  the book can only be read for information.RESTAURANT REVIEWS.  This reproduces a couple of the restaurant reviews.  The writing is fine.  On page 158 we read about LE MILLENAIRE, which states, "San and claret hues and contemporary artworks create an air of intimate sophistications at this Michelin-starred haunt.  Chef Laurent Laplaige keeps flavors crisp and seasonal with specialties such as wild sea bass with celery, truffle risotto and Champaigne sauce."  I liked the fact that the writing identifies the chef.On page 237, we read about LE RESTAURANT DE FOURVIER, which states, "The views are so incredible that it'd be easy for this superbly located restaurant to be a tourist trap, so it's all the more impressive because it's not.  Instead, it concentrates on well-prepared local specialties, including a stellar salade lyonnaise (lettuce, bacon, poached egg and croutons)."  As you can see, the restaurant reviews are like thumbnail photographs in a high school yearbook.  They really do not provide enough information for you to make a decision.  The restaurant reviews merely serve the purpose of convincing the reader that the restaurant exists.PHOTOGRAPHS.  The most interesting of the photographs are as follows.Roman aqueduct near Nimes (page 21).Chateau de Chambord at the Loire River (page 35)Moulin Rouge, which has performances of dancing with costumes (page 94).Etretat cliff in Normandy, which has spectacular sea arches and white cliffs, where the cliffs have lengthy horizontal sedimentary lines (pages 108-109).Mont St. Michel (page 112) and also six tiny photographs on pages 130-131).Bayeux Tapestry (a very tiny picture on page 113, and a larger picture on page 122).  I have two books about Bayeux Tapestry.  In my opinion, if you did not already know about Bayeux Tapestry, this book would not be able to communicate to you the fact that it is a very spectacular thing.Notre Dame (page 160 (exterior); page 173 (interior).Vimy Ridge (page 176, World War I brick-lined trench where Canadians fought in April 1917).Chateau de Chenonceau (page 179.  This is one of the few full-page photographs in this book.  This is a castle built over Cher River, in the year 1515).Chateau de Charemeont (page 194, with huge cylindrical corner towers, built in 1465).Gorges l'Ardeche (page 223, a river located in a modest canyon, located near Lyon)Basilique Notre Dame de Fourviere (page 233, a beautiful church built in the late 1800s, with nearby Roman theater built in AD 120).Mer de Glace 9page 240.  This photograph is of a glacier near Mont Blanc.  Finally, in this book, we have a photo of a dramatic mountain)Aiguille du Midi (page 242.  More dramatic mountains, also at Mount Blanc, showing tourists meandering around on the snow, who apparently had arrived in a cable car tram.)Le Cap Horn (page 244.  A huge chalet in the Alps, with tourists meandering about)Pont du Gard 9pge 315.  A 3-tiered aquaduct built in 19BC by the Romans.  It is near Nimes.

WITNESS is a color movie, taking place in the present area, mostly at a rural community of Lancaster, Pennsylvania inhabited by the Amish. Parts of the movie take place in the grittier parts of Philadelphia. (Perhaps this is a tautology, since Philadelphia has been known, for many decades, as a gritty city.) The characters include Harrison Ford, who plays a young detective in the police force, Danny Glover who plays a corrupt policeman who partners with a couple of other on the police force to sell illegal drugs, Kelly McGillis, who is an Amish woman and who plays the love interest, and Lukas Haas who plays the son of single mother Kelly McGillis. Kelly McGillis has acted in about 27 movies, as of this writing, and Lukas Haas, who was about ten years old at the time of filming, has acted in about 54 movies, as of this writing.CLEVER PLOT DIRECTIONS. This is such a gripping movie, that I hate to give away too much. At any rate, I will disclose only one of the clever aspects of the plot. Early in the movie, Kelly McGillis and her son set forth from their Amish community to a train station in downtown Philadelphia. Their plan is to visit a relative in Baltimore. In the train station, the son witnesses a murder in the men's room. From the partly open door of the toilet stall, he sees Danny Glover and another man murder a man who is busy washing his face in the sink. The boy hides in the toilet stall. Within minutes, the murder victim is found, and Harrison Ford is brought to the scene of the crime, and he is the first to interview the boy. There are a few cute scenes, where the mother and son, both dressed in somber Amish garb, are noticed by typical city folk, and are apparently considered an amusing curiosity. At any rate, Harrison Ford brings the boy to the police station, where he is shown a lineup of about ten suspects, and where he is shown hundreds of photos in a book of suspects. The boy responds that none of these are the murderer. The boy ambles about the busy police office. Some employees are busy booking a petty criminal. Other employees are busy typing. Other employees are busy walking too and fro. The boy is fascinated, and he freely explores the busy office, until he comes to a small museum-type display of baseball statues, police paraphernalia, and newspaper clippings. One of the newspaper clippings shows Danny Glover, winning some sort of award. The photo in the clipping is in black and white, and the photo itself is somewhat fuzzy. But the boy recognizes him immediately, and reports this to Harrison Ford. In my opinion, this is one of the most clever moments every committed to film, and it represents one of the distinct turning points in the entire repertoire of American screenwriting.CULTURE CLASHES. As it turns out, Harrison Ford needs to live with the Amish for several weeks. (I am not giving away the reason!!!) Amusing culture clashes occur, where Harrison Ford is provided with an Amish man's outfit, which is all black, and comes with a round wide-brimmed hat. The result is almost comedic. Eventually, Harrison Ford becomes accepted into the community, because he proves himself to be a hard worker and, in particular, skilled in carpentry. He repairs a large wooden birdhouse, he uses a plane with great skill for smoothening wood, he uses a manual drill skillfully during the assembly of a large wooden barn, and he does not complain when he is required to wake up at 4:30 in the morning to milk the cows. The love interest develops very gradually, and the viewer will be impressed by Harrison Ford's behavior in refraining from being too forward with Kelly McGillis. He refrains from being too forward because, in his own words, he realizes that Kelly McGillis might be driven out of her community. In fact, her father expressly tells he that she risks being driven out. The father uses the technical term for this, which is being "shunned." Another quaint aspect of the Amish, as disclosed in the movie, is the fact that Harrison Ford has a wound in his abdomen, and one of the Amish elders realizes that the wound will likely be infected, and so he "treats" the wound with a mixture of milk and linseed oil. The dialogue, at least for the parts of the movie that are filmed on the rural farm, are peppered with German, though it is apparent that all of the Amish are bi-lingual. Another culture class is that between the Amish and the Mennonites, who lived in a nearby community. The issue is that the Mennonites allow themselves to use some modern devices and machinery, while the Amish are circumspect in avoiding these things. Yet another culture class, takes place when the Amish drive into town in their horse'n'buggy devices, and are met with derision by young hoodlums in the town. The hoodlums harass the Amish, complaining that the buggy is blocking traffic, and complaining that the Amish never serve in the military. Harrison Ford responds by calmly climbing out of the buggy, ambling up to one of the hoodlums, and driving his fist directly into the hoodlum's nose, resulting in the hoodlum becoming an unintentional blood donor.The film also discloses that the Amish are considered to be freaks by out-of-town visitors, who gawk at them and shove cameras into their faces, and this leads up to an amusing moment involving a gentle confrontation between Harrison Ford and an elderly tourist. Please picture Harrison Ford dressed in Amish garb, black pants that are four inches too short, a black jacket, and a round wide-brimmed black hat. The tourist is a wrinkled old lady dressed in a cheap Woolworth blouse. The blouse has a splashy red pattern in the poorest taste. The old lady tries to take Harrison Ford's picture. Harrison Ford warns her, "If you take my picture I'm gonna rip of your brassiere!"CHARMING DISCLOSURE OF THE HUMAN CONDITION. This film provides a slice of life disclosure of the human condition. Although the film concerns police corruption, and culture clashes of various kinds, I believe that there are some universal lessons to be learned from the story. Throughout the film, the continual cat-and-mouse activities involving the corrupt employees of the police force and Harrison Ford and his new-found Amish friends, provide more than enough thrilling suspense to those who respond favorably to suspenseful action movies. FIVE STARS.

CHANGELING is a drama set in Los Angeles and in the Riverside area.  In a nutshell, Angelina Jolie plays a young mother of a 9-year old son, where early in the movie the boy is kidnapped.  The Los Angeles Police Department  (LAPD) shows little interest in providing aid.  Early in the movie, a boy from Iowa is sent by train to Los Angeles, where he claims to be the son of Angelina Jolie.  Much of the storyline concerns Angelina Jolie's continued insistence that she is NOT the mother, and the continuing insistence by the boy and by LAPD that she IS the mother.  The plot goes like this:  "You're his mother"  "I'm not his mother"  "You're his mother"  "I'm not his mother"  "You're his mother"  "I'm not his mother."  This is a recurring theme.  Eventually, a minister, a police detective, and a prominent attorney, come to Angelina Jolie's assistance, and overcome the Nazi-style tactics taken by LAPD in attempting to brainwash Angelina Jolie's character.One of the many brilliant features of this movie, is the Angelina Jolie's acting, where she has mental breakdown upon learning that her son was kidnapped, and her mixed-emotion breakdown of pain/relief when she learns that her son (the false son) was found in Iowa and is being returned to her.  Another brilliant feature of the movie, is from child-actor Devon Gearhart, who plays a boy who escaped from the chicken coop, and who discloses information about the serial killer to the LAPD detective, and who has a mental breakdown in the LAPD interrogation room when he relates the facts to the detective.The plot concerns The Wineville Chicken Coop Murders, which was a series of abductions and murders of young boys that occurred in Los Angeles and Riverside County, California, between 1926 and 1928.  On the pleasant side, it can be said that this movie is a "period piece."  Every viewer will enjoy the outfits worn by female and male actors.  Also enjoyable, are the many automobiles from the era, as well as scenes in a telephone company with dozens of female telephone operators, plugging and unplugging wires, and using roller skates to facilitate mobility about the telephone operator's workroom.On the unpleasant side, it is the case that Angelina Jolie's character is mentally jerked around, and bullied by LAPD, from scene to scene to scene.  But fortunately, it is the case that Angelina Jolie's character is a courageous one, and she prevails despite all.  Also on the unpleasant side, are the brainwashing tactics taken by the Los Angeles Police Department, in aggressively persuading Angelina Jolie that she must accept the fact that she has been re-united with her true son, and in aggressively trying to persuade her that her role in life is to accept the boy as her son (even though she is not), where LAPD's Nazi-era tactics include incarcerating Angelina Jolie in a mental hospital where she is administered electric shock "therapy."CHANGELING was written by J. M. Straczynski, who is the author of many contemporary comic books.  Clint Eastwood is the director, and he displays the same genius and wisdom in portraying the human condition, as he did in GRAN TORINO, a film about Hmong immigrants in Detroit, Michigan.  The characters can be neatly divided into the good guys and the bad guys.  The good guys include Michael Kelly, who plays a police detective who believes Angelina Jolie that the boy from Iowa is not really her son.  Michael Kelly tracks down the serial killer.  Another good guy is Geoff Pierson, who plays an attorney who represents Angelina Jolie, pro bono, in her lawsuit against LAPD.  John Malkovich is another good guy, who is a reverend who crusades against LAPD, and who provides moral support and guidance to Angelina Jolie, and who drums up public support for her cause.The bad guys include Jeffrey Donovan, who plays Captain J. Jones.  Mr. Donovan uses an Irish accent.  Jeffrey Donovan is so utterly despicable and disgusting in this movie, that his character is so overwhelmingly appealing that it is a joy whenever he appears on the screen.  In another movie, TUSKEGEE AIRMAN, John Lithgow also plays a character who is so utterly despicable and disgusting, that the viewer shivers with pleasure whenever he appears on the screen.  All of the staff members in the mental hospital are also bad guys.  And last but not least, Jason Harner who plays the serial killer is another bad guy.  He plays a man who is totally nuts, in the same way that Gregory Peck's depiction of Ahab, in the movie MOBY DICK, is another character who is a genuine madman.Also notable are two characters who look ugly.  The front desk clerk in the mental hospital is ugly.  Also, the man who supervises the execution at San Quentin Prison is also ugly.  The ugly people provide a great contrast, to the overwhelmingly lovely clothing that is worn by the male and female actors in this movie.DISCLAIMER.  I made no attempt to explore or confirm the historical basis of any aspect of this film.  I have no interest in politics, and I have never had any interest in politics.  Generally, my only leisure interests are landscape photography, hiking, British history from the years 800 to 1650, classical music, be bop jazz, New Wave music from the early 1980s, and classic rock'n'roll and Motown.  That's it!!!

If Fire Cider is meant to be a beverage, then it is my opinion that it is meant to be sipped in small amounts.  The product is is called, "cider," indicating that it is supposed to be a beverage.  The stongest of the several flavors in this product is HORSERADISH.  The second most prominent flavor is GINGER.  The beverage also has a fragrance, and this is a VINEGAR fragrance.
