This is a great jump start for my diet.  I have battled my weight for the past 16 years and felt like I am losing the battle.  Starting this new express plan has finally got me motivated again to lose this weight.Its easy to follow, and its portable and clearly labeled which is for morning afternoon and evening.I haven't felt jittery like with many diet aids, and I''m down a pound.  I'm certain its only water weight so far, but its nice to see the scale going backwards!The drink powder is described as natural citrus, and it's very bland.  Think of water with a lemon slice.  Its not terrible, it's not sweet or sour, just bland.I'll keep updating this with my progress.  If I see results from this jump start I will look to buy the daily program.

This is a nicely made 4 piece towel set which includes one each: bath sheet, bath mat, hand towel and wash cloth.  The set I received is white and I am very happy about that.  We recently redid our bathroom and these match perfectly. Its a pure white which I like because it is easy to to keep them bright, clean and sanitary with Hot water and bleach.I'm thinking of replacing many of our old towels with Bluepoint brand.

This is a nicely made backpack/ daypack that works well for students or for hiking.  My son immediately starting investigating the many compartments and pockets.  The straps are adjustable, feel very comfortable and holds everything we need to carry.

This cord works just as expected.  I have purchased several Amazonbasics products and find they are made very well and hold up to normal wear and tear.  I would have no problem buying another Amazon branded product. They respect their brand name and don't put their name on junk.

Nicely constructed, with ample padding to protect your laptop. Love I can just leave the laptop in this case and use it while protecting it.Roomy enough to hold my phone & the chargers and headphones. Handy carry handle, and compact enough to slip into a briefcase or backpack. Highly recommended.

I generally like most Tresemme products and have used several over the years, including shampoos, conditioners, keratin treatments and hairspray.  This comes in an easy to squeeze tube and smells terrific.I have really long hair, so I typically need more product than what is noted on the package.  Used approximately 2 tablespoons to completely coat my hair.  I left this on for about 5 minutes while I showered, although the package states 1 minute for deep condition.It rinses cleanly away, and left my hair feeling silky.

I live at the beach and spend a lot of time outdoors.  I absolutely love Lifeproof cases and I've purchased several over the years for myself and for family members to protect their  Investment.  I can't comprehend why anyone would spend hundreds of dollars on a Smartphone and then put it in a cheap case.  I want my investment protected.Take the time to read the instructions and follow the instructions to the letter.  If the sound is muffled then you have too much air inside the case.  Open the port door and firmly press all the way down the screen protector; closing the port door before releasing pressure.

I love Barbie ! She always has the best everything!  Since I was a young girl Barbie has always known the current trend and pushed way past it.He we have her version of a camper and it Barbie Land its right on track.  Maybe one day we all can drive a pink camper with a hot tub and waterslide to the campground!

I use this on a 2002 Ford Ranger, after cleaning it thoroughly. This truck spends a lot of time near the ocean and usually has plenty of salt and sand debris.  Its pretty easy to use, just spray on and use some elbow grease.My only complaint is the spray bottle, I would prefer a continuous spray that was easier to aim and hit specific parts, but that's just my personal preference.

I use this on the bumper fender and side panels on a 2002 Ford Ranger.  This cleaned the Vinyl panels nicely.  Just spray on and use some elbow grease.  Removed a lot of old road dirt and grime.My only complaint is the spray bottle, I would prefer a continuous spray that was easier to aim and hit specific parts, but that's just my personal preference.

Alright, first let me give the caveat that I think Furbies are the stupidest toy ever.  The toy and its price seem ridiculous to me.  So why the four stars?  My youngest son loves this thing, as ridiculous as it seems.  He has had other Furbie Mini's I believe they are called and he has played the app on his iPad and he truly loves them.  Again, I'm at a complete loss as I find it kind of annoying.I do like the Star Wars tie in, although I think that might be a healthy part of its $70 MSRP.  But I do like my son and my childhood colliding like this.  I also like that they have revamped the application to include a Han Solo character Furby.  The app is not much of a game, there is a chance to kind of take care of your Furby...feeding him, bathing him etc.  Which is kind of cute but I don't know that it will hold interest for long.But like I said, my kid truly oves the little guy so it's a great toy.Pros+ My kid loves these things+ Star Wars tie in+ It was fun to explore the possibilitiesCons- Annoying- Expensive- Kind of ugly

This is a wonderful, light and crisp scent.  Immediately upon putting it on, it has a strangely candy shop sweetness to it.  I'm assuming it's the vanilla, but with a sense of sweet fruit.  But this seems to fade leaving a healthy lower scent of cedar and slight muskiness and some vanilla.  Again the scent remains pretty light.This crispness makes this a perfect work scent.  It is not over powering and moderately complex. But could also work well on the town afterward. The dispenser is nice in appearance and design and has one of the best pumping actions I've seen on a bottle recently.  It atomizes well.I have enjoyed the scent for the last couple of days, and rather unique to different scents I have tried recently, my partner noticed it right away.  Although it was early morning when the sweetness was at its strongest. Her word was delicious.

What a Great Book!! It is filled with little fascinating factoids that reward even a few minutes of reading.  Each history is actually rather short, just a third of a page or so, but packed with entertaining trivial facts.  This is a great way to improve your Trivial Pursuit or Jeopardy score, or improve your water cooler talking points. I have a number of boys in my life that inhale things like Guiness Book of World Records or Ripley's Believe It or Not books and this fits right in with those.The writing and page layout are very nice.  The book is a decent quality hard cover with dust jacket which looks great on a coffee table.  There is an illustrations for each entry.  All in all a nice book.I do not have volume 1 and it works, but I am putting that volume on my gift list for several people.  Highly recommend this "bathroom fact reader."

My step daughter is a huge fan of the Warrior series so I thought she would like this. Turns out she really loved it, calling it the best book she's ever read. And while there might be some hyperbole there, it completely engaged her for several days and got her reading, and that is worth five stars.The writing is very good as long as you can stand talking animal stories. I appreciated the action that kept pages turning. We read some out loud and I found it to be a decent book. Looking to read it myself once the kids are done with it.

This is a great premise, but  a somewhat lewd adult game.  We play a lot of board games with our kids ranged 8-14, and much of this game was racier than we would want for them, but they desperately wanted to play it once they heard how it plays.  So we made a pass through the cards and pulled out the inappropriate ones (about a third.)We found out a couple things, one, we are not that great at impressions and accents and secondly, our kids are much worse.  Which was very funny in itself.  The game consists of a judge who draws an accent card and then the other contestants pull quote cards from their hand to see who can make the funniest combination for the judge.  The judge then picks the best of the group.  We did start going to a panel for picking the best performance.All in all, it was a fun game.  Probably best played among college age players due to the risque quotes, but the concept is good for any age.

Easily the worst thing about this book was that I didn't read book one.  It is obvious that this plot is interwoven into book one considerably.  This book can and does stand on its own, but I really wish I had read the first book first.  I am definitely tracking down book one to fill the rest in.The best thing about this book is that it filled with suspense and dinosaurs...bunches of dinosaurs.  I am very impressed how well the author handles them.  This is what makes this a great book for my dinosaur mad sons.  What made it great for me was the way he handled the dinosaur knowledge of two time traveling experts that start 30 years apart but find themselves in the late cretaceous.  In fact, there is some much popular culture play in the book that you kind of have to be a parent to truly appreciate it all.  Not many kids know about Knight Rider or would understand that a kid from the 80's would be wowed by a VW Beetle from the 2000's.The book reads well, looks like it will be well illustrated and really engaged me.  I'm sure it will grasp the kids attention as well and I'm looking forward to talking to them about it.  Great Book.  Really looking forward to getting book 1.

I like this package, espcially that it comes with a couple of refills.  It made quick work of dust on the TV and book shelves without the need to any Pledge.  It is great for quick dust ups before guests, and at least in the short run it got the kids super excited to dust.  Although I am not counting on that lasting.The Swiffer really does seem to have a magnetic attraction to dust and I'm impressed how well it picks it up.  The sides are soft and size is nice to work in and out of niches.  On the bad said, we pulled the dusting head off to fluff it as instructed, then had a hard time figuring out how it went back on.  For a while we had it flying off the handle every time we tried to dust before getting it to stick.  Would be nice if there was a more obvious way to reinstall the dusting head.I don't know that this is a life changing product, but it is handy enough and warrants the price.

When I saw these offered, I immediately thought "camping in the Boundary Waters Canoe Area."  They seemed perfect for packing in a cooking oil, as well as an oil for rubbing out muscles that have paddled a little too long.What I got was a box of wonderfully individually packaged coconut oils.  The packages themselves are rather small, but enough to use to fry potatoes and vegetables for breakfast or to carmelize onions for burgers.  I wince a little when i think that they are very overpackaged, but for camping I forgive that.  I could see it taking a couple of these on some bigger meals, but the shelf stability and travel convenience is fantastic.Our camping season is pretty much done for this year, so to test the quality of the oil, we tore one open and popped popcorn in it.  The coconut adds a subtle sweetness to the popcorn and worked perfectly for popping.  Then we squeezed the left over for back massages. For back massages, it is great how to oil melts when it hits your hands and lubricates well for kneading muscles.  And afterward my girlfriend smelled delicious.  It feels oily for a while but soaks into the skin well and left her skin super soft.So it works perfectly for what it is.  We look forward to putting it into our food pack next summer as well a few winter massages.  It's pricey and it's over packaged, but it is perfect for travel and I have no doubts about the quality of the oil.

This appears to be a good cream. It applies very well. The scent is subtle, really smells like nothing, which is very nice. It absorbs well without a greasy feel. There does appear to be a little tingling after application. Skin feels soft and supple after application, but time will tell as I use it.I am very optimistic based on reviews and what others have said about eb5 products. The pricing seems decent and love that it is free of Parabans. There is a lot to like about this. Will update with long term results

Well the dogs seem to like this dog food well enough. We mixed it in with their normal food and they eat it preferentially. We have also been using it as treats and they eat it semi enthusiastically. There has been other foods that they have had better responses to, but for taste this seems a little above average for them.I like the grain free, which is a must for the dogs, but I'm not overly excited by the very long ingredient list, I see that most are supplements but some seem suspect like copper and zinc sulfates.The food is priced as a premium brand, and it probably is, but I trust our usual brands more. It does seem like a premium, but I think we're sticking to our usual. But I have to admit, the packaging is very nice and love that they give instructions for introducing new foods. That is thoughtful and promotes good dog care, kudos for that.

Well, I have to admit this was kind of an intimidating game.  The instruction books is big (although lots of pictures) and at times a little confusing.  We had to do a little interpreting and a little negotiating to make sense of some situations, but I think we have a good sense of how the game is played now.  Also I was a little concerned that having not watched the TV show, that we might be at a disadvantage.  This does not seem to be the case at all, although the glossy images from the show are probably a little lost on us.The game ended up being pretty intriguing.  I like the elements of distrust as you did not know the roles that others were playing and each person has a different incentive to hinder or abet terrorists. I was thinking that this would be basically a form of clue, but it is much more, and very playable.  Which is also kind of a surprise as I recall a slew of crappy movie and TV based games.The pieces are good quality.  The small plastic pieces are enough to keep younger kids kind of interested, but we found that our ten year old had problems tracking it.  It is definitely a more mature - 13 and up game.  The cards and board are decent and all in all, this is a very decent game.

I really like Fluxx.  It's not the greatest strategy game in the world, but it is one of the most refreshing.  It is amazing how the game can change on a dime, but there is some strategy but it is fragile and it becomes a game a tactics and reacting to what is on the table.  These seem to just throw another element into the game that might not be needed.  It just puts a little more strength on the side of chaos.  Personally, I think the game is well balanced now.One thing I really wished the makers would have done is to think about the packaging.  This box could have held a full deck, but instead it held a couple dice and a few cards.  With a little foresight, they could have made a protective case that could hold, the dice and an entire deck of Fluxx cards.  Perhaps with a clear case to show off themed sets.Otherwise the materials are ok.  A little pricey for what you get, and note this is not a stand alone game.  You will need a Fluxx game to use this with. It was fine to play with this addition, but I don't know that it made the game better. But if you have never played Fluxx, I recommend it.  Especially with children, as the chaos kind of levels the playing field.

This is a beautiful book that is wonderfully visual and digestible.  It is perfect for my step daughter and her friends, and eight to ten years old seems to be the bullseye audience.The graphic design of the book is super strong with very simple illustration composition and instructions.  The illustrations show very clearly what do do with the hair and the materials needed.  It is beautiful just flipping through the book with it's simplicity and stunning visuals.  Although I did laugh when I hit the page showing flowers inserted into a girls hair with a glue gun illustrated next to her.  It took a second to realize they were gluing the flowers to the bobby pins, not her scalp. Many of the design ideas are tiaras and such, outnumbering the actual hairstyles.You will need a few things to fully use this book.  Bobby pins, Fake Flowers (go to Michael's), Glue Gun, and very long hair.  The fact that it is heavy on glue gun usage means that young children should be supervised.  But all the ideas as easy to implement.  I anticipate this book will get a lot of use in the next year.  Perhaps peaking again when the sequel comes out.

In an age when we are all trying to find a way to make college more affordable I'm glad there is advanced placement in high school. I got both the US History and World History versions to help my son do his best on the test and hopefully save tuition on a couple of electives. Perhaps good or bad, I found that the Kaplan books were used in creating the curriculum for my sons classes.  Hopefully that doesn't give him to narrow a view of the material, but it is something of an endorsement for this test prep.My biggest fear is that my son will not understand the testing format which is what makes this book seem very worthwhile. The actual material in the book is not particularly robust, but there is an immense amount of information regarding testing tips and hints.  I feel like I can get more information for the actual content, but this is great for helping with the test itself.  He has months before he will be taking the test, but we have gone through the book to help reinforce main points as they come up in class and to keep him thinking about how to study.If these books help him test out of even a few classes, they will be worth their weight in gold.  Now to find the AP Biology one.

The actual material in the book is not particularly robust, but there is an immense amount of information regarding testing tips and hints.  I feel like I can get more information for the actual content, but this is great for helping with the test itself.  He has months before he will be taking the test, but we have gone through the book to help reinforce main points as they come up in class and to keep him thinking about how to study.If these books help him test out of even a few classes, they will be worth their weight in gold.  Now to find the AP Biology one.

I have never been much of a paper towel user, but my partner is.  And she is something of a paper towel snob.  She prefers the premium towels that are thick like fabric and are perforated every few inches so you can take just what you need.  I have to admit that whatever brand they are, they are nice paper towels.These paper towels don't quite live up to them.  These are decent paper towels. But they have a much more paper napkin feel than a cloth feel.  I would consider my partner's as ultra-premium and these to be plenty good.  I did use them to clean up after a breakfast and they held together well and absorbed spilled juice well.  Tree saving technology sounds good, but I can't help but think how many trees are saved over a year by using reusable cotton cloths.The big mystery on this is whether the pricing can match Costco/Sam's Club pricing.  Since this appears to be a new packaging option, there is no pricing available.  For the most part, you are getting a very decent paper towel in bulk packaging.  The differentiator here would be price per unit.  So if you need bulk paper towels, this is your product.  But check the pricing when it is available.

This is a very easily digested, visually stunning book.  I really like that not only does it tell the facts, but it also freely tells the areas of contention.  I feel better about a source that is willing to address what we do know and what we don't.  The best example of this is when the authors include quotes for and against supplements.I am not looking for a great change in my lifestyle, I was just looking for guidelines to help me get as much active life and I can out of my chance here. Much of this book's content is kind of clichéd but the presentation is not. For example, don't smoke.  But  the authors and designers go beyond with info graphics, illustrations and factoids that bring the information home and make it clear. It's kind of light reading with heavy duty information.  Love it.

OK, I know nothing about Adventure Time but my kids sure do.  And we are all familiar with Fluxx and I for one love the premise that the game changes on a dime, every third play.Per my 14 year old, this is a perfect union.  With each play, I get a long narrative about why something is so cool about this edition.  Granted, it all sounds like garble to me, I can definitely say that this edition is perfect for fans of Adventure Time.  Or at least I can convey their strong endorsement.If you don't know flux, it is a unique game where you play by adding rules and end goals to the game.  You can be close to victory and find that just before crossing the finish line, the goal has changed to something your are no where near to winning.  But on the other hand, you can be completely out of the game, then find that you have won.  This hampers long term strategy, but can enhance the short term tactics a lot.Personally, I really like the game.  Mostly because of it's uniqueness. The game is pretty easy, and I think the rules say that it is easiest to learn if you play with at least one person who has played it before.  This is very true.  You can pick it up easy, but it's a rough first game with a lot of close reading of cards and some debate about how cards should be played.  But you quickly pick up the gyste of the game.I've played the original and Bat Man version and I think I would trust any themed version of the game.  At least for the ones I've played, they use some rather insightful details of the theme to make an interestingly different and meaningful game.

This is a very likeable book. It fits well in to the easy reading books that scholastic puts out.  In fact, after 40 pages or so, I actually flipped to the publishing page to see if it was a scholastic.  The story is unique enough and the writing is good and propelled me through the book.The story has essences of many books but it reminded me of modern and lighter combination of Narnia and A Wrinkle in Time.  I suppose because of the combination of a magic portal and an attempt to rescue a lost father.  But the tenor of the book is far more light and whimsical.  This is not a piece a literature, but a fun little romp.My biggest concern is that the son I gave the book to has been having problems staying locked in on the book.  He typically inhales books so I look forward to see if this one eventually catches on with him.

I was worried about this game as it required our 8, 9, 10, and 14 year old blended children to negotiate every five minutes, but they did great. Although as the values of different gems is becoming understood, this is changing. They now know the value of the black gem and the relative scarcity of diamonds. Our first two games, the initial values were based on how pretty they are.And they are pretty. The gems are nicely created and make the game visually and tactilely exciting for kids. The cards and their artwork are high quality and the timer and privacy blinds are decent. All in all a game that should hold up well.Strangely for me. The strategy is in negotiating for the value of the gems. There are straight counters, bonuses for each set with one of each of five gems, a high pointer gem that makes other bonuses useless, and high bonuses for having the most of any gem type. So you can set a strategy for procurement to lead your negotiations. If negotiations fail. All the loot for that round is lost to everyone. Which has been enough motivation for flexibility amongst my kids and no fights have arisen so far.So it's a unique game for us. And I expect the negotiations to heat up as we realize the values of the gems more.

First, I wish I had gotten these as a Christmas gift for the boys.  The packaging is great and when they opened up the flap to expose the cars, their eyes lit up.  They have a lot of shock and awe when opened and keeps going while you are downloading the app in anticipation of playing these.My kids were a little skeptical at first because we have had a similar product with AI and iOS controls.  That one proved to be pretty flaky and left them pretty dissatisfied.  These had none of that.  The App ran even on iPhones and iPods that were at least a generation old.  The pairing was easy and worked well.  The controls seemed a little tight but the kids seemed to get the hang of them quickly.  All in all a very good experience.We had some issues with the AI in tight areas, but to be honest, everytime these have come out, there has been a waiting list and some squabbling to play with them.The game play is pretty good.  It's like a James Bond gadget car battle.  The battles have been full of laughing and good spirits.  There have been solid collisions which have so far proven the cars to be really sturdy.  The boys said and easy 5 out of 5 stars.

Most of us had never played Fluxx before so this is our only exposure to the game, but the game play is amazingly wild.  The changing rules make it possible to have victory snatched from you at the turn of a card, or suddenly find yourself holding the winning hand.  I have never played anything like it.We have played a number of games now and the kids truly love it.  I can see how there could be a whole fleet of games created around this concept.  For this one, there are some very Batman specific rules that fans of the franchise should like.  For example, there is an Archam Asylum rule card that contains the villains in play.  There is a rich collection of characters and equipment from the Batman world, which I am not a expert at, but I appreciate how they work the storyline into the game.  Much of it must have been specific rules which change the game at least a little from the original game.The art work is great, the cards and game are easy to read and understand, the quality is nice.  All in all this is a really great little game that can be learned and enjoyed in a single hand.  And due to the fluctuation in the rules, no game is the same and I have yet to discover a general strategy.  You just have to play the cards as they lie.Great Game

I really think that this product lives up to, you get what you pay for.  This is a reasonably priced pad, and it works reasonably well.  We have a number of more expensive pads and at least one cheaper, and this one does not match up to the more expensive pads for quality and comfort, but I would not consider it too cheap to be worthwhile.This is a very thin pad.  The ones we currently use are much thicker and have a much thicker waterproof layer.  This one has an internal waterproof layer pressed between "quilted" layers. (quilted by impressions, not stitches.)  The thinness does make it very portable and we will probably use this as our camping pad.The one concern I have with this is how well it holds up after washings.  Our others are very rugged and I just can't envision this one to holding up to a ton of washes.  I will update when we see how that plays out.  But for now, the pad is effective, has the benefit of being thin and packable and it is reasonably priced.  I can't say that I'm super excited about it, but I feel like it's a solid value for the money.

Four of us have read this book and we have all said the same thing.  This book is ridiculous. The premise alone, the only boy in the school that can morph from a boy to a boat is a pretty random way to set up a book for teen conformity angst.  And it gets even more whacked from there, while somehow staying in a real world setting of a high school and community.The maturity level is strangely eclectic as well.  The wackiness seems fit for 8-12, the high school setting and drama seems to be 14-17, and some of the jokes are clearly sent over their heads to parents.  There were a few things I felt were perhaps a little mature for young readers like nautical puns for swear words and (spoiler alert) a woman who is impregnated by a submarine.  But all in all, it is so ridiculous that it holds all readers.It is a quick read, very visual with very good, although almost computer generatedly clean graphics.  It lacks an artistic looseness, but is visually wonderful.  The dialogue is cleanly written and was easy for all readers from 8 to middle aged.  None of us really put it down after we picked it up.  Great, engaging book.  We use these for road trips and it did the trick of passing 30-45 minutes per reader.

I got Casey's book, the Devil's Teeth thinking I would learn about Great White Sharks and ended up learning so much more.  This book did the same thing.  It does a great job of going into the people involved with dolphins but even more importantly, it goes deeply into the ways that we are currently threatening dolphins, through both our love and disregard for them.I came away with an even greater sense of awe for the animals and a greater awareness of what they are facing.  I really recommend this to anyone who has interests in Dolphins, nature in general, or our environment.  Casey's personal experiences bring life to the issues and do a good job of stringing the facts into a nice narrative.  Five Stars

Well, I really like this craft set because the kids were engaged in making it. But it was not the most impressive set we have gotten. It seemed like mostly we were purchasing the idea and could have done the same thing with supplies we had around the house. The biggest value add was that they had patterns already set up.But I do have to like this set as our 8 and 9 year olds did spend a good chunk of time creating their pieces with us just needing to tie the knots to begin and end strings. Otherwise they were content for an hour or so, weaving their strings around their pins. I do have to admit that the resulting project is not my favorite work they've done, but for now these are proudly displayed on their cork boards.

I have often wondered about instant hummingbird food.  I have always boiled water and sucrose, replacing fairly regularly.  I am a little leery of adding unneeded preservatives into the mix.  This works as well as straight sugar, I decided to forego the boiling which made it very quick to prepare and we had it in the cabin feeder in no time.This is the end of the season so we have had a lot of activity of moving adults and lots of juveniles.  I can't say that there is any big difference in there reception for this over sugar water.  I do feel a little better about leaving this sealed over winter till their spring return.  But I'm not convinced that this is any improvement over straight sugar water.

OK, perhaps I requested this for slightly different purposes than most, but our dogs love the Wellness line of snacks.  In fact I have never seen them more focused on any other treat.  When we saw that Wellness also made moist cat food, we decided to use it to help get pills down.  The plan has worked perfectly.  They ravenously take the spoonful and pill down.I do have to say that Wellness is not cheap, but the quality seems to be there and the taste is obviously fantastic.  You can tell just by watching the dogs.  We actually have cats as well, but they are going to miss out on these because they work so well in getting pills into the finicky dogs.

So I tried to read this book and could not get through it due to time, so I gave it to two of my kids.  When asked they gave a rather lackluster, "It's Good." Which is kind of an endorsement, but far less warm than their usual reaction to books. And that was kind of the feel I was getting from it while reading it. It was interesting enough, but I don't know that I feel compelled to finish the story.  It was not bad, but it also wasn't great. I am glad that it kept the kids interested enough to finish the book.The kids were super excited to find a couple more books at the library, but apparently it was to glean codes to put into an online game. As of right now those books have remained unread after an initial flurry to find the codes. I'm not a huge fan of that kind of online tie in or marketing.

First, visually this is a beautiful book.  I love the layout design and the great images of mustangs that go along with some very good and eyeopening information about what mustangs are facing.  I don't think much of the country realizes the pressures that these wild horses are under. And I guess for that matter, I bet most people in the country don't realize that mustangs still exist, let alone be able to conjure an image of horses living on open range.  This book does a great job of informing the reader and building that image of horses living wild.The author gives a great background history of horses in North America, from fossil record to reintroduction after they were extirpated 8000 years ago.  The Paleontology is a little glossed over as is the release by the Spanish, but they are noted and the stage is set.  Where the book truly focuses and succeeds is in illuminating the current management crisis the horses are facing.  It informs the reader of the thousands of horses that are being held in government pastures, the traumas of roundups and hints at the true effectiveness of our current management policies.  She does a great job of painting that picture of wild horses and their natural habits, followed by the fear and breakdown of that pattern during and after the round up.  Also she points out the barely veiled industry of slaughtering the horses for dog food and other uses.The one thing that did kind of confuse me is that the Young People are prominent in the subtitle, but seem to be relegated to the last 30 odd pages.  It would have been nice to see the stories of the young horse lovers spread throughout the book to help connect with kids.  As it is, you have an excellent book about mustangs with an appendix of people helping out.I'm a little concerned about the somewhat graphic information about the roundups and slaughter. As a parent, I read the book first, and there is some mildly shocking information included.  To an extent, this is the information that needs to be disseminated to kids and adults to shock them into action, but you may want to read it first and judge how your little onces can handle it.  For me, there is some concern for a pretty informed 8 year old.  I don't think I would have any qualms for tweens and up.

I read the reviews, and one of the more helpful ones states that the shirts with holes in the sleeves run LARGE, the opposite of those without holes which run SMALL. It's too bad they're listed together, but I'm writing to confirm this is the case. I ordered this shirt in a size S. I normally wear an M/L, so I was a bit nervous about that S, but it fits perfectly. It might even be able to go a touch smaller, but I like the fit of the S. It's very flowy and doesn't show off a waist-line, and my husband doesn't much care for the shoulder exposure, but I think that dresses up an otherwise ordinary shirt. It's very comfortable and I like the Olive green color. Overall, very pleased!

First of all, after reading other reviews, I decided to go ahead and order this shirt in a 2XL (XXL). I normally wear a M/L, so this hurt my pride a bit, but I still gave it a shot. I probably could have gone a size down to XL because it is slightly baggy on me, but that suits me well, and it's super cute. I pair it with dress pants for a formal look and with jeans for cute and casual, and I absolutely love this shirt. My only complaint (besides the XXL) is that it's supposed to dry flat. I live in the South, so it is humid down here, but it's also autumn so it isn't that bad. Even so, I tried to dry it for two days, one day under a ceiling fan, before finally throwing it in my dryer on "air fluff" mode to get the last traces of damp out of it. It's not a huge deal, and I can live with it, but don't plan to wash it one day and wear it the next. Overall, very pleased.

Once you get the sizing right and the considering the price, this is a nice shirt. I haven't seen anything like it at this price-point, and I thought it was very flattering! The color is beautiful and so overall I am pleased with my purchase.  I even went on to order a second one; I do recommend this, with the following very important caveats:First, I followed the advice of other reviewers, and ordered a size XL for this shirt (I normally wear a M/L). The XL fit well, although a bit tighter than I expected considering I was nearly two sizes up. As other reviewers had said, this shirt runs SMALL! Order at least one size up, probably more like two. Secondly, the material feels cheap. Although it is a handwash-only shirt, I would not be surprised if it started to pill very quickly. But I paid very little for it, so that's probably the way it goes. I  have washed it twice without pilling, so I could be wrong, but I don't think so. I do have a fabric shaver, so hopefully I can still get a fair amount of life out of this really cute shirt.

I want to start by saying that I loved this book absolutely. I delved deep into the world, and even though Wulfric is not the sort of man I could ever love, Balogh made me believe in the true romance between Christine and the duke. My only complaint about this book was also something I enjoyed: it is so clearly inspired by "Pride and Prejudice" that sometimes I struggled a bit with certain expressions that were almost too reminiscent of the original, although Ms. Balogh preferred her characters to speak what Ms. Austen usually did with narration. However, while it was occasionally distracting to recognize certain lines or sentiment, it didn't stop me from diving in and loving it. In fact, I suspect over all the impression helped, as saw the characters mirrored so carefully.The vivacious heroine of the lower gentry who fines humor in everything and uses her fine eyes to express it, the proud and sullen and powerful hero who never smiles and yet still finds himself falling in love with the opposite spirits of a woman he cannot approve, the spirited male friend who appears to say one thing but is actually maliciously saying another, and of course the scandal which plagues the heroine only to be rescued by the hero, the only one she trusts enough to tell, the proposals, and I could keep going. It's a story I can't help but enjoy when the author is as good as Mary Balogh at descriptions and characterization, even though Christine occasionally behaves as Elizabeth never would, and I couldn't really picture Colin Firth as Wulfric and so instead ended up picturing sort of a young Peter Capaldi. Ha! I also had fun picking out the more minor characters: Basil and Hermione as Caroline Bingley and her sister and Wulfric's aunt and niece as Lady Catherine and her daughter, for example.I don't think you'd have to be able to quote P&P to love this book, however. The characters stand alone quite well, certainly many of the situations and the path of the plot is unique to "Slightly Dangerous," and while Wulfric is not a particularly likable guy throughout most of it, Balogh made me wish for the success of the romance anyway, which is quite a skill. Usually, if I don't like the hero, the book can't capture me, but I was just engrossed. I have also enjoyed reading later books and watching the duke and duchess interact after their marriage (although I don't think he would actually call her "my love," just my opinion). This is a well-written and wonderfully detailed story about two unlikely lovers who compliment each other well. Highly recommended.

Oh no, this book was such a disappointment. I am a huge fan of Mary Balogh, but I have read enough of her books by now to realize I won't like all of them. That's understandable. Especially when it comes to male characters, she writes about a great variety, and certainly each man won't appeal to every reader. But I just couldn't stand Sir Gerald.It was a let down, because I read The Ideal Wife and was looking forward to Sir Gerald's story, but I didn't even want to finish the book. And that does say something, because this is the first Mary Balogh book where this has been the case - even books I haven't particularly liked in the past have been suspenseful enough to lead me to want to read until the end. I found the writing to be lacking Balogh's usual elegance, and when it came to the story, I simply didn't care. I still don't completely understand why Prissy became a prostitute. It didn't sound to me like she was dying in a gutter and decided she had no choice, nor was there any blackmail, although I'll admit that by half-way through the book, I was skimming a lot of it out of boredom. I can understand a prostitute being passive, although it doesn't make a great romance. But beyond that, there was no reason for Prissy to love him, except that apparently the other men she "serviced" must not have been gentle with her (although except for one, that's never stated). Lord knows he clearly wasn't a very good lover, and he didn't care for her as a person in any way. But Prissy is clever, accomplished, pretty, and a lady, and there was simply nothing about Sir Gerald that would have drawn her interest. By the way, my dislike of him isn't because he's portrayed as having a learning disability, it's because he's an awful clod who never really does come to see Prissy as a person, as far as I could tell. Instead, he simply realizes that without the comforts she provides, he is unhappy. And then (spoiler alert!) he has the nerve to take her back to his home, where she will forever be recognized as his whore, when she's managed to create a comfortable and accepted life in a small town despite her occupation. How romantic. If you've never read a Mary Balogh book before, please skip over this one!!!! It is not a good first impression, but she has several books that are so much better. If you have, well, read at your own risk.

I borrowed the Kindle version of this book, and was very pleased. This is exactly what I was looking for to get my son interested in Japanese. He likes to learn things for himself, and so this book is perfect. It's very simple, it gives each line in English, romanji, and hiragana. I used to hate books that only shows the romanji, but since my son doesn't yet read hiragana, he needs something to help him make the connection, and he began making it right away. My only complaint is that the text is very small, even on a full-sized iPad. For young and old alike, the test really needs to be bigger.

I will start with the negatives. First, the Ferdinand in this book is in no way the Ferdinand of MORE THAN A MISTRESS. They're not the same guy. This was fine with me. I was a bit hesitant about reading his story given what a ignoramus he was in the first book, but don't go into it if you liked him in the first book. He's not the same guy.Secondly, this book is completely implausible. It requires you to suspend belief from beginning to end. Ferdinand and Viola living together? No, it wouldn't happen. Viola choosing to go back to work instead of accepting Ferdinand's help? I doubt it, although I guess she could be that stubborn. As for the Ton ACCEPTING Viola at the end because she's courageous???? Are you kidding me? I completely expected that Ferdinand would denounce town and decide to live out his life in the country with Viola where no one could recognize her, which was the only way I could see the story ending satisfactorily. The ending was lovely, but ridiculous. I can agree with some reviewers that this wasn't the best novel, but it didn't change how much I enjoyed it.Frankly, I don't read Mary Balogh (or any romance novelist) for the realism of it all. The number of scandals she writes about would have us believing that historically, every great lady was a mistress or prostitute and every great gentleman had run off with his fiancee's brother's wife first. A certain bit of reality must always be suspended unless the plot was only to be man and woman get married for political/familial/financial reasons and then manage to make it work. And I would read that book, because I don't require a ton of action to my stories as long as I can get into the characters and their lives. I was able to get into this one because I liked Ferdinand so much.I didn't find Viola that annoying, as some other reviewers did, and I absolutely adored Ferdinand. As people can probably tell from my other reviews, I really sort of detest the "alpha males" that often show up in romance novels. I prefer sweet, thoughtful men who truly adore their women, and Ferdinand was all that I ask for in a hero. I really enjoyed reading about his thoughts and he proceeded through the plot. His interactions with his brother, Tresham (who I couldn't stand), were some of my favorite of the book. This is just a sweet, fluffly, feel-good story. It doesn't require much thought or contain much action, but I came out of it feeling happy.
Very pretty and nice, and fits a 5x7 photo exactly.
This is a child-sized umbrella, so it was perfect for my son to take to school with him, and he loves it. It's very easy to use with no catches to pinch the fingers. Very happy with my purchase!

The frame had a couple of loose pieces, and also does not exactly fit a 5x7 photo. Also, if you hang it from the hangers provided, it hangs lop-sided. I had to cut all my photos down to fit into the frame. I debated just returning it, but I do like the colors, and loose pieces don't particularly matter once it's hanging. I went ahead and cut the pictures down by a couple of cm, used the curves of the flowers for the nails instead of the hangers provided, and it looks very nice on my wall. But I probably wouldn't buy it again, knowing what I know.

Pretty disappointed. We bought this to replace our old toaster oven, and have no returned it. It burned the toast even on the lowest setting. We double-checked directions, but could not get it to toast correctly. As an oven, it worked fine; the problem was only with toast. Judging by the reviews, I'd say we somehow got a dud, but we won't be repurchasing.

I really enjoyed this read for several reasons. I think the characters are delightfully imperfect, I love the writing style, which is descriptive and deep and flows well, and I remained wrapped up in the plot throughout the entire book. This is a somewhat dark romance novel, with intrigue and war as well as incredible sexual tension. The attraction between the main characters is almost a physical presence in the book, and the sex scenes are very steamy, but there is a lot of plot outside of the romance as well, as well as a couple of bends and twists in the plot. The heroine is both strong and insecure, determined and fearful, and she knows who she is. The male character wants to be more of a blackguard than he actually is, and the author does a good job of making his developing affection clear from the early stages so that it is quite believable by the time romance develops. The secondary characters were also interesting, and did not exist in the story simply to exist but rather played important roles throughout.The only reason I didn't give this book five stars is that I really struggled with some of the plot points, specifically the main hero's role in the heroine's life as savior/captor made me a uncomfortable. Even when they fall in love, he remains her blackmailer and jailer until nearly the end, as though she was Murasaki being raised for Genji's pleasure. I also didn't like the coercion that was involved when they finally had sex. The author does delve lightly into the psychological struggles of the couple, and she also tried to make up for that situation by making sure the heroine first acknowledges that she always wanted to make love to the hero, and finally breaks free at the end, and we learn that the hero loves, and even respects her for for it, but the manipulative nature of the couple's coming together made it difficult for me to see those scenes as romantic.However, even the scenes that I had some trouble with are well-written and interesting, and while I don't feel that this is the light and fluffy read that I usually seek out when craving a romance novel, I will undoubtedly pick it up again and reread it some time in the future. I absolutely recommend this book as an absorbing and interesting read.

This is our second Naturepedic twin mattress, and we've also purchased multiple crib mattresses. We always love them, and feel good about our kids burying their faces in this organic, harsh-chemical free mattress. I read through the reviews, but have to disagree that this mattress is too firm, at least, not for a child. I bought it for my preschooler, and little kids often use firmer mattresses. I've fallen asleep on it multiple times and think it's fine, and my kids sleep well on these. I love that one side is water-proof for now, and that we can flip it over for a softer side for when the kids are a bit older. I have no complaints at all.UPDATE: At age 6, my son did start to complain that his mattress was too hard. It was wonderful to be able to simply flip his mattress over from the water-proof side to the softer side and please him without having to buy a new mattress! I also have to add that Naturepedic stands behind their lifetime guarantee. After less than 6 months, a spring had somehow rotated itself sideways in our second of these mattresses and was poking to the side. We don't know why or how this happened, but we wrote to Naturepedic and sent them pictures, and they immediately sent us a new mattress. No charge, no hassle. Very, very pleased.

I actually want to give this book 2.5 stars, but rounded up since Amazon won't let me do that.Before I read this, I would have said I was a Lynsay Sands fan. I bought it when I saw the high reviews, because I very much enjoyed the Devil of the Highlands trilogy, as well as several of her regency-period novellas. I haven't read anything in her vampire series as I'm just not much of a fantasy person, but I have read enough to know that I enjoy her writing style. In the books I had read before, I sometimes thought scenes were a little silly but could skim through or overlook them for the sake of the rest of the story,. That wasn't possible with this book, since I was rolling my eyes almost all the way through. Nothing, from the premise to the dialogue to the characters' behaviors were in any way appropriate to the time-period or in the least bit believable. The romance between the main characters certainly wasn't. There was no heat, no attraction, just random moments when Radcliffe kissed Charlie out of the blue, to emphasize that he was only attracted to her and not to Beth, which any reader with half a brain understood from pretty early on. The scenes were steamy, but I didn't really have any emotional attachment to the characters as a couple.There were times when I felt like the romance actually distracted from the main plot, because while the romance was so weak, I actually really enjoyed reading about Charlie's experiences as a man, and her perceptions of the world around her and the on-goings of life as a man, as well as her attempts to help those around her. I found her very strong, practical, and charming, and decided to give the book an extra star because of her, but Radcliffe's only redeeming quality was the ability to put up with the misfits Charlie brought home. Once everyone knew that Charlie was a woman, I truly did lose interest, and finished just for the sake of it.I'll be donating this book to the library.

Our oldest child has outgrown the trailer, but he is extremely cautious, and has shown extreme reluctance to learn how to ride his two-wheeler (even with his training wheels). Family bike rides became impossible. Then, while in a bike shop, we discovered tandem bike attachments such as this one. We went online to read reviews and compare prices, and found the WeeRide Co-Pilot.It is a two-person assembly, and took my husband and I less than an hour to attach it to his bike. It wasn't difficult or complicated; but has a lot of parts, and someone needs to hold the adult bike up for straight attachment. I have read the negative reviews, but we didn't have any of the issues mentioned. We had no difficulty getting it attached tight enough (there is some give, which allows it to turn more smoothly).We have now used this attachment on three separate bike rides, and it's wonderful. Our son is excited, not fearful, when riding, he loves to help pedal. His Daddy tows him, and has had no trouble with balance. It performs well, and we're extremely pleased!Just a couple of notes for prospective buyers. First, this is a pretty hefty trailer. It is heavy-duty when lifting it, and takes some extra effort to tow up hills. Second, this bike is really for kids 6-7 years old +, not because of the balancing per se but because of the distance from the seat (in the lowest position) to the pedals. My son is 5, in the 90th percentile for height, and he has to stretch his tippy-toes to touch the pedals in the lowest positions.All-in-all, we're extremely pleased, and recommending the Co-Pilot to all our friends!
This is a large teapot in a rich blue color, and it is exactly what I wanted. Not sure what else to say - very pleased!

This was my first Meggan Connors book, and I really enjoyed it. I would give it 4.5 stars as well.Kenneth was a wonderful romance hero (sweet and gentle while strong and manly), and if you can forgive Isobel for not instantly realizing that he wasn't Malcolm, her estranged husband, she is very likable as well, if a bit odd for the time period. Their sexual tension is good, the romance is very sweet, and it is a steamy read. Although this is a romance novel, and thus by definition a relatively light read, I thought the suspense was good. I didn't even skip to the end, which I usually do with suspense novels, because the book was so detailed that I was sure I would miss too much by skimming through it.All of the characters, even secondary characters, are surprisingly multidimensional. I was particularly impressed by the depiction of Malcolm, who is definitely the villain of the story, and yet with softer contradictions that leave his character less certain, and his motivations remain unknown to the very end. While originally I wondered why the author intentionally neglected details about major events, I also think it added to the strength of the story. Those details would have been interesting and provided insights, and yet were ultimately unnecessary to the story, and far too many romance authors seem to throw in details for no other reason than to make the story longer. I respect the author for not feeling the need to expand on every little event in the characters' pasts. I do hope, however, that she has some plans for Ethan.The writing is detailed and absorbing. I think the author tried to maintain the historical atmosphere, and though it is not a time-period I know well, I bought it. I think Meggan Connors is an up-and-coming new romance novelist, and I shall watch with anticipation for her next work. If you are looking for a quick, sweet, and interesting romance, I recommend this one.

This is my first time reading anything by Erin Knightley, and I really enjoyed this book. The characters were fun, the sexual tension was good, and just as I was really getting into it - it was over.I do know that is the point of novellas, and usually I'm fine with it. But this time, I thought there was enough material that this could have been a full novel, and the ending was far too abrupt. Instead of feeling like I'd had a fun, fast read, I felt cheated out of a longer book. Still, I enjoyed it, and I'm going to go on to look for other intriguing books by this author.

We were looking for outdoor lights to make traversing our deck stairs easier at night, and we found them! We read the reviews and tried out each light before screwing it into the wood to make sure they all worked (they did). The motion-sensing-light-sensing feature is exactly what we needed, the light is bright enough to clearly see the stairs, and we have had these for a couple of months now, through rain, snow, and sun, and they continue to work perfectly! I have no complaints at all. Highly recommended.

After purchasing a very disappointing children's microphone, we decided to get this one because it is so inexpensive and had good reviews. I will say that the microphone portion broke within a week. However, Amazon returns worked flawlessly, and they sent us another one right away. We have now had the second one for four months with absolutely no problems or complaints. It is wonderful. The kids love it, it sounds terrific, and looks very professional. I hope we'll be able to get good use out of it!!!

We were looking for a tiny vacuum for our two small tanks - one is 3 gallons, the other is 5 gallons, and average-sized vacuums sucks half the water out so fast that there is no time to actually clean the tank. This is exactly what we were looking for. It works great, the suction is good, and it's small enough that we have time to clean the tank. We've been using it for several months now with no problems. Very pleased!

This dress was exactly what I was hoping for when I pulled it out of the box. Unfortunately, the skirt is a bit poofy, especially in the booty area. I already have a sizable behind, but this skirt made it look like I was wearing a bustle! I was really disappointed, because from the front, it was very flattering, comfortable, and fit well. But from the side, it was unacceptable. I had to return it. I would recommend this dress for someone who wants to emphasize their curves a bit more, but not for those of us who have a bit to hide.

What a huge disappointment. This is one of my favorite Elizabeth Rolls books (in novel format), so when I saw it had been turned into a manga, I was curious, since I sometimes enjoy manga and I already knew I liked the plot, so even though the price was more than $4 for  a digital book, I bought it.Less than 20 minutes after buying it, I deeply regretted spending the money. It is as though someone sat down and said, "Okay, let's make a comic about this book. Remove all of the character development, all the romance, and basically everything that made the story interesting. Now draw some pictures about what's left!" Thank goodness Amazon has an awesome return policy, even for Kindle books. If you like Kasumi Kuroda or Elizabeth Rolls, this still isn't the book for you. What a disappointment.

We bought two standard-sized organic cotton/PLA fiber pillows with the low-fill option that is available from Naturepedic. I wanted a natural, chemical-free, washable pillow for my children (ages 2 and 4), but I was afraid the standard-fill pillow would be too thick for their little necks.I am very pleased with my purchase. The outer shell of the pillows is a soft, satiny cotton, and they are soft but supportive pillows. According to the Naturepedic tag, these pillows can be machine washed and machine dried, which I have done once with good results.A couple of notes: when the pillows arrived, they had a sharp, woodsy smell that made my nose itch, but one trip through the washing machine (using unscented detergent) and the smell was completely gone. Once through the drier, the pillow had fluffed up a lot more than I wanted (hence the low-fill), but it returned to it's flatter shape after one night. It does look like it is a bit thick for my 2-year-old (although she uses it happily), but it is the perfect thickness for my preschooler.I highly recommend this pillow in general, and I recommend the low-fill version (currently available on the Naturepedic website, hopefully available on Amazon soon) if you are looking for a good organic pillow for young children, or if you don't want as firm a pillow. Very pleased.

Our kids (ages 2 and 4) got this for Christmas ($49.99 at Target, BTW) and we have had hours and hours of fun with it since. My 2-year-old is a bit young to understand the concept, although she loves the music, but my 4-year-old is exactly the right age to get a kick out of this toy. He LOVES switching out the instruments and the different songs, and has learned each instrument's name and sound and developed favorites.Much to our surprised, my husband and I have also really enjoyed this toy. It's really interesting to sit down with our son and create different sounds for the same song. I'm not sure this is a $100 toy, but it is absolutely a $50 toy and we have been extremely pleased. Highly recommended for 3-5 year-olds and those who are musically inclined!

We bought this toy for our 2 and 4-year-old for a 10-hour car trip, and it was a huge success. In fact, the kids loved it so much that I am now in the market for a second one, since sharing became an issue.Basically, you fill the pens with water (despite that there are 4 colors of pen, the pens do not write in color!) and then just color. Within about 5 minutes, the surface dries and you can color again. My son (age 4) in particular had a blast writing his name on one side, flipping it and writing his sister's name, and then flipping back again, and practicing his letters in his big writing that would take up multiple sheets of paper. My daughter loved to scribble and then watch her scribbles vanish. They didn't have any complaints that the pens didn't write in different colors, luckily.My only complaint is that the surface marks if you get anything besides water on it (little kids can have greasy fingers) and thus far, I haven't found a way to get the stains out with scrubbing (and I am afraid to use soap in case I stain the surface further). This is why I deducted multiple stars from the durability of this toy.Overall, I really recommend it. I still plan to buy another, even with the occasional grease stain, and the water-pens and fast-drying non-paper mat make this ideal for car trips. Just make sure your kids' fingers are clean, first.

Our kids (ages 2 and 4) got this for Christmas ($49.99 at Target, BTW) and we have had hours and hours of fun with it since. My 2-year-old is a bit young to understand the concept, although she loves the music, but my 4-year-old is exactly the right age to get a kick out of this toy. He LOVES switching out the instruments and the different songs, and has learned each instrument's name and sound and developed favorites.Much to our surprised, my husband and I have also really enjoyed this toy. It's really interesting to sit down with our son and create different sounds for the same song. I'm not sure this is a $100 toy, but it is absolutely a $50 toy and we have been extremely pleased. Highly recommended for 3-5 year-olds and those who are musically inclined!

I am a general fan of Leslie Kelly, in that I enjoy many of her works and dislike only a few. This particular book, along with its counterpart "She's Got the Look," are my two favorite Leslie Kelly books, hands down. I like the plot, I like the banter, the sex is steamy, and the character development is good. My only complaint is that the sexual attraction and tension is overdone, but that is a trait of Ms. Kelly's, and I've learned to look past it. Both Emma and Johnny are likable characters, and you can feel their affection for each other from the very beginning. If you like Leslie Kelly, this is a must-read!

We live in the south, and for the last couple of years in particular, that means fall/winter days in the 60s-70s and nights in the 30s-40s. We love to sit out on our porch, but once the sun sets, it can get pretty cold pretty fast. We bought this heater so that we wouldn't have to head inside as soon as it begins to cool down.The pros:This is a large enough heater that it sits far above everyone's heads on the patio table, which not only means we can feel the heat but also that there is no real risk of accidentally bumping it somehow.It feels very steady on our table.It is relatively easy to set up.The propane tank (which you can buy at any camping store - our Walmart also carries them) lasts for a decent number of uses.But there are some things that potential buyers should keep in mind.The cons:This is a very large heater! I put this as a pro, but it is also a con, as it takes up a considerable portion of our rather large patio table. I think it would take up an entire side table with no extra room. People should be aware of this before purchasing it.Perhaps I should have realized this before buying a table-top heater, but the heat stays ABOVE the table-top! This heater will not heat your legs and feet AT ALL. It probably would if you put it on a side table next to you, but then the risk of bumping it would increase considerably. If you are planning to use this with a patio table, you will still need blankets to keep your bottom-half comfortable.This heater is lovely for keeping us warm on a cool evening. It is perfect for 50-degree weather, instead of jackets and blankets. But unlike the full-sized standing propane heaters, this one isn't strong enough to make real winter weather tolerable for outdoor seating.Overall, I'm very pleased with my purchase and would recommend it.

We eat a LOT of Japanese foods in our house, both home-made and carry out, and we call those foods by their Japanese names, so my kids are familiar with sushi. I think this is a really cute board-book for a 2-3 year-old to help them recognize various types of sushi and get the pronunciation down. The drawings are also very nice. I am pleased with my purchase!

I really enjoyed reading this book, but I was pretty disappointed with the ending. It felt very rushed - there is so much lead-up to the characters, and then a little bit of an issue between them, and then suddenly everything's all better, the end. Rita is very likable, but it would have been nice to hear a bit more from her perspective about why she is attracted to Matthew (besides his green eyes) that lead her to never give her virginity to another man but to choose this man on their first date. Matthew could have been a wonderfully deep character, but all we find out about him happens before he is in a relationship with Rita. They never do work out why he throws her out of his house (the reader knows, but they never manage to communicate the miscommunication to each other), and why does the author spend so much time proposing that Matthew's family won't approve of Rita if, in the end, she is going to gloss over how happy they are about the match?This is a fun read, and I'll be looking up other books by Elizabeth Bevarly. The writing style is refreshing and light, and you find yourself caring about the characters. Which makes the quick and undeveloped ending even less satisfactory. I hope she does a better job on the next one.

I agree with many of the negative reviewers on here. Pendleton, while a nice shell to reflect Kit, is a one-dementional character, and you never do understand why he has fallen for Kit. Kit is entirely and completely unlikable - none of the "vulnerable" moments that Bevarly shows us in any way make up for her awful treatment of the men in her father's employ. Furthermore, although we are assured that her father and brothers care only for the money, that isn't what we see - Holt Sr. is very cold-blooded, but he also apparently spent her childhood chasing off gold-diggers who don't love his daughter but only her money, and for this she deeply resents him. Huh? Her brothers get the same blame, even though Holt Jr. is, by all appearances, a good brother who watches out for her, even if he, too, likes the money (find me a multi-millionaire who doesn't like being rich, please). So the characters never clicked for me, because I couldn't see them the way the author apparently intended, and Kit in particular is so unlikable that you do find yourself understanding why the only men who chase her want her money - lord knows no self-respecting non-gold-digger would love such a selfish, childish brat.Having said all of this, I really enjoyed Bevarly's style of writing. I found it light and witty, a fun read, and I rarely (if ever) rolled my eyes at the characters' interactions, an action that is almost unavoidable when reading romance novels. Analyzing the book, I find it didn't meet expectations, but while reading, I had fun. Pendleton, while he didn't have much personality, was a nice character to follow, and I liked him. I always kind of assume that the free book isn't the author's best (or worst) work, but just a taste. This author has room to grow, and I hope she does. I won't be rereading this book, but I might read another Elizabeth Bevarly book before making a final decision.

I wanted to love these because my favorite brand of pads, FuzziBunz, is no longer making overnight (super) pads. But I don't. They seem to slip more, bunch more, and although they are pleasantly thin, they absolutely hold a LOT less and lead to leaking - a problem I haven't had with other brands. These are are not even my second-favorite brand. I'll use them as backups or panty-liners, but I'm disappointed.

I have been buying Baby in a Bag for years, and I especially love the winter models, which are quilted for warmth. The zippers are high-quality, the blankets fit the sizes they are supposed to fit, and are wonderfully warm. They wash well and hold up over the years - I am now using the same sleep-sacks for my second child. Wonderful!

I have been buying Baby in a Bag for years, and I especially love the winter models, which are quilted for warmth. The zippers are high-quality, the blankets fit the sizes they are supposed to fit, and are wonderfully warm. They wash well and hold up over the years - I am now using the same sleep-sacks for my second child. Wonderful!

I live in Northern Kentucky, and our winters can get fairly cold (20s & 30s) and we also get snow regularly. My husband and I walk with our kids year-round, but bundling both toddlers into snow-suits, boots, heavy jackets, gloves, etc. every single night is exhausting, not to mention that I have to resize the straps on the stroller for their outer-wear.I read the descriptions of the JJ Cole Original Bundle Me and the Urban, and settled on the Urban because it is advertized as water-proof and we do get snow. Since I read that the purpose is to be able to avoid heavy coats, snow-pants, etc. in the stroller, I thought this blanket would be as warm as a winter coat. However, when the Bundle Me arrived, I was disappointed. Although the interior material does seem very soft and the exterior material feels like the stuff that is on the outside of a sleeping bag, the blanket itself is very thin. If it works to keep the wind out, that's something, but it is so thin that I worry it may not be able to hold any heat, and I am hesitant to even bother with it. I returned to Amazon to read some of the other reviews, and I see that several other people comment on the thinness and lightness of this particular Bundle Me. I wish I had noticed that before I ordered it.

I read the reviews and was fully prepared to have to return the umbrella, but actually, I was impressed. The umbrella arrived in one piece, and thus far, has held up for 3 good rains. My son, age 2.5, loves it. The bubble-shape keeps him dry, the clear version means he can see through it. Adorable.

I needed this to get a stump out of my garden. I had dug it out, but couldn't seem to break through the massive anchoring root. This saw caught repeatedly, got tangled, and I was about to give up when my husband pulled out the WD40. Um, problem solved! This saw did exactly what I wanted, stump removed, I'm happy!

What pieces of junk.I love my MacBook, but these adapters aren't worth $10, much less $80 apiece. In my first two years owning my MacBook, I went through 3 adapters. They all died through a disconnect at the joint where it enters the computer, and the third adapter actually began to smoke and crackle! Oh, and by the way, even though I went to the Apple Store each time, only the fourth adapter was free because it was "under warranty." When I asked them why I had had to pay for my second one and my third one, the genius I was working with at the time assured me that I shouldn't have had to, that someone had made a mistake, but was unable to give me a refund for the extra adapters I had had to buy since I didn't show up in their records (not sure why) and I had moved and was unable to find the receipts, so I couldn't prove that I had purchased the other cords there. Nice. Great customer service.The fourth adapter, which was free to me due to warranty and an educated genius, was this new design. I was thrilled, thinking the problems had been solved. Well, I'll give them this - the newer design did last longer. In fact, the new adapter design actually lasted a full 14 months - more than twice as long as the old adapters. But since I had already spent $160 on adapters that should have been covered by warranty, I'm not pleased by the longevity. Because 14 months is OVER the 12-month warranty that at least some of the geniuses were willing to honor. Yet another $80 that I might as well just flush down the toilet. Not only that, but when I took my laptop in again, the genius informed me that the charging port was corroded, as though I had "splashed water on it or something." I asked him if one of the previous adapters smoking and crackling in the port could have caused that damage - oh, huh, maybe.I absolutely won't be using the "genius bar" again, since I don't trust their geniuses, and I'm going to have to think long and hard about replacing my MacBook with another when the time comes. I may hate PCs, but these two are no longer my only options. What a disappointment.

I am very pleased with my purchase of the JJ Cole Toddler Bundle Me Lite. We bought it earlier this Fall, when the weather was starting to drop into the 50's in the evenings when we take our daily walk. We always put a jacket and hat on my 13-month-old daughter, but we were noticing that her legs (and particularly ankles) were very cold. Blankets fell off continuously, when they weren't caught under the wheels of our stroller.This product has solved our problem. I was not sure that the blanket would fit on our Graco travel system stroller, but it works well enough. There is nothing obvious to put the head elastic around, but I've made it work by wrapping it around the sun visor, which prevents the blanket from sliding down (I don't know if this is necessary - it may not be since the straps also fit through the provided slots). It is made from waterproof material (we found this out for ourselves when it began to rain on us suddenly!) with a very soft liner. It is wonderful for keeping the wind off of children, but I wouldn't use it below 50 degrees, as it doesn't have padding (lite). This is why I just now purchased the JJ Cole Urban Bundle Me, which I hope will be equally nice but heavier, and serve us over the winter.We did attempt to use it with our (currently rear-facing) carseat, however, without much success. Although it can be done, it was just a hassle to get the straps to line up, to get the fabric unbunched, etc. I cannot comment on whether it would work better with a forward-facing carseat, and I don't think it was worth the effort (especially since blankets are more likely to stay on a carseat than a stroller).The Toddler Bundle Me does zip up high enough on my (quite tall) 13-month-old daughter to cover her hands and arms completely, and I imagine it will last for at least one more winter before she will outgrow it. I have not yet washed it, so I don't know how it will hold up that way, but it doesn't often get dirty. The Gray Circle pattern is very pretty. Highly recommended.

I received this free to read and review.It took me a while to get into the story,The first two pages get off to a very exciting start and seems that it is going to be a political/murder mystery although set in non-earth location.The central character Jon although an accomplished high ranking politician does not come across as a particularly nice or even having a strong personality. In fact later in the book he seems quite out of his depth.Once the book gets into its stride and Jon gets his “personality” I can’t think of a better word to describe him being transferred across an enormous distance in space and into the body of a “ female aged 22”, hence the title of the book.It is interesting that the story is written by a man but for a large portion written from a female perspective, I have no idea how accurate this perspective is.All goes well until he cannot return to his own body, it is then a case of him trying to convince everyone that he is actually Jon.Much is dependent on different political and legal structures of the two planets and the negotiations between them, but this is essential to the story.In some places the stereotyping is a bit extreme, such as there has never been a female or small man as a “leader”.It is an interesting and thought provoking story, and at the end just when you think all is working out, at least for Jon there is a final twist to the tale.

I received a pre-release version to review.It was an interesting story but it just did not grab me.The main character “Meriel” is left as an orphan after the spaceship “Princess” is attacked by pirates. She then sets out to reunite the surviving children including her sister “Elizabeth” and find the location of “home”So far so good except everyone thinks she is delusional and do not believe her story as it is assumed that piracy is impossible in deep space due to the difficulty of finding where spaceships are.So the question for readers; is she imagining it all or did it really all happen and we do not find out which until near the end of the story.To add weight to the fact she is delusional is her determination to find the location of “home”.This is a good premise for a story but for me it just did not work I could not visualise or relate to any of the characters.

I received this book free to read and review.This is a comparatively short story and not the type I normally read but it is an engrossing story.A key is found which opens a box and Evelyn the central character reads the letters contained in it. From them it is gentle mystery with great character development.A short but good read.

I received this book free to read and review.Somehow I missed reading this one which would have cleared up some of the details in the next book. It does however stand well on its own the main disadvantage of reading out of sequence is that you know who survives to the next book. Having said that this one starts with one of the characters reappearing from the previous book that I was quite sure had been killed off.From this start the story switches to a whole new plot and away the story goes, in this there is a new rogue character that is intent on causing trouble to put it mildly at the very heart of the establishment.Nick Hartland in this story joins up with the British “security services” to catch and eliminate this new character. The plot is tightly written and at the end when all is resolved a new character is revealed which provides continuity into the next book.
