I also found out what happened to the character that I thought dead from the previous book and it was not at all what I expected.A good series which individually stand-alone but are much better when read in the correct order.

I received this ebook free to read and review.As this book covers a period of about 20 years it was always going to be difficult to cover it adequately in a single book and at times it seemed too slow paced and at times too much was condensed.The first half of the story built up the background to the characters including many that did not make it past the first half; I certainly was not sure about it at this stage. I thought the second half was much better as the story got into survival mode.As this is science fiction you have to suspend disbelief and accept a few facts such as a man who baring accidents will live for ever and a drug that gives super intelligence. Once you accept this the story is involving with well portrayed characters and locations. I did in truth prefer some of the animals to the people. Other than odd occasions this is not a violent book which is surprising as it deals with a cataclysmic disaster.With two separate groups who have survived using different methods it is perhaps inevitable that they will eventually meet, but not in this book.It certainly is an unusual tale of survival and rebuilding with a small number of people trying to return Earth to how it was before the disaster.Although I was not sure about this book initially; it grew on me and I will certainly read the rest of the series. At the back of the books the author states that it does not matter which order the books are read in however while that may be true of later books I think this one needs to be read first.

I received this book free to read and review.Although I liked the story it did not initially work for me and I could not work out why. I have read a number of books by this author and liked them, this is the fourth in the series.Characters have been reused from previous stories but this is a complete standalone story.  The characters and locations were well described I particularly liked George.Suddenly I realised why this did not work for me, the era and style seemed to be more suited to an earlier period. Take away cell phones and modern cars and it could easily have been set in an earlier period, then I thought “Dennis Wheatley” as it had a similar feel to some of his novels.So a good story but I don’t think it was one of the author’s best, it is probably me but although with earlier stories “I could believe it” even though I knew they were fiction this one I had trouble “believing” it.

I received this free to read and review as a pre-release issue.I have read the previous book in the series “Zara’s Flight” which I though was a very descriptive book. This one continues on the same theme and I thought that it showed a very imaginative glimpse into the future. It was not particularly way out which made it seem all the more plausible.It is worth reading for the descriptions alone which allowed me to visualise the imagined locations. However I felt that the plot was very straight forward with little in the way of twists and turns except at the very end which then sets the story up nicely for the next in the series.The first half is mainly descriptive and very good in the second have although the excellent descriptions continue however without revealing the plot it seems to be a reverse of the previous book.Still a series worth reading as a laid back type of science fiction rather than an all action battle one, this actually makes a refreshing change.

I received this book free to reviewShort stories are always difficult as they often get the balance wrong and spend too much time on character development and the story is lost or indeed the other way round. This is not a problem with this story as there is a good balance between the two.Essentially a story told from the victim’s point of view and her developing self-confidence until all is revealed.Lainey the main character works well and feels very realistic as do the other characters with just enough background to give them depth. Likewise the locations are vividly described. There are a number of twists and turns to the story and until near the end I was not sure who were all those involved in the robbery.I would however not have read the prologue if I had realised it would reveal something that happened later in the book I would have preferred it to creep up on me.

I received this at a discount to test and review.I like this a lot it is a stylish card holder which has 6 card slots that fan out when open to allow the cards to be taken out easily, it will take more than 6 cards as the slots are large. As it is a metal box (10.2 x 7.4 x 1.8 cm) it will protect the cards well, I travel light and have the habit of managing to bend cards when they are in normal leather card holders.The box is attractive with a lightly brushed finish and polished ends; it opens easily with a push button but also closes securely.It will provide better protection from the elements than a leather case and it is certainly weather resistant. I did a crude test by leaving it out in the rain for 10 minutes and no water came in so it could be IPX2.I could not test for RFID protection as my test equipment is loaned out at the moment but as it is a metal box I am pretty sure it will provide RFID protection.In all a well-made stylish case, I like it a lot.

I received this book free to read and review.This is certainly not one for the children as it contains adult themes such as rape, in fact the descriptions are all the more harrowing as they are described with an almost clinical detachment. The story itself is excellent the “Ivory Tower Cop” of the title is a university professor who although having a high level of academic knowledge has little or no real world experience.When I received this I had no idea it was based on a true story.The police have no clues as to the identity of the person committing the crimes so “Dr David Roth” the cop of the title joins the police as a cadet so he could be assigned to assist in the investigation. This is the only thing that does not ring true in the book as I don’t know why he could not just be brought on as a civilian I do not know.The story then gets into its swing and becomes a tightly written plot. Not only is it a detailed police investigation but also explores the relationship between Roth and the person he is assigned to. It further looks into the mind of the rapist. Unlike many detective stories in this one although we get to know much about the villain as the detail builds up throughout the book, he is not known to the police or any of the other characters in the book, so it is not a book that you can look for clues and try and work out who is the perpetrator.This is a stand-alone novel but I would like to see it become the start of a series, if it is I will certainly read the rest.

I received this ebook free to read and review.This was a very different story to the ones I normally read. From the beginning I thought this was going to be one of those stories that is great in character development and locations but does not do a lot.I was very wrong. Initially a travel reviewer wrote a very damaging review about a holiday destination, the sunset in the title, he is invited back to hopefully be persuaded to write a better story.  The two main characters Mathew Kane, the review writer and Kate Hampton, a psychiatrist, who is a regular guest there and wants to save the resort. Both of them leap off the pages as do the description of the locations. As well as the two main characters all of the others are well described and all are integral to the story. In fact this would be enough to be a satisfying read however about halfway through the story it takes a darker and certainly more adult turn.I can’t say much about the actual story without giving away the plot only that everything works out well in the end for most but not all of the characters.It is a book that would be worth reading just for the descriptions but the plot sets it apart from many.

I had previously read “A last act of charity” by this author and had wondered about “Stoner’s” background. This fairly short story fills in many of the gaps. The story is fast paced and the writing style is a bit choppy. However it is worth reading to fill in the gaps.I hope there is a similar short story featuring the “Hard Man”.

I received this free to test and review.I seem to be always getting garlic presses and we get visitors who would like them and I give them away. However I will be keeping this one.Garlic presses all do the same thing by pushing the garlic through a series of holes and this one is no exception, where it does stand out from the crowd however is in the cleaning. I have others where there is a separate gadget for pushing out any bits left in the holes, these work but I usually lose them. With this press you just flip the handle over and just squeeze to clean out the holes a great design feature.Apart from the fact it works well it is also very stylish, which is not something you can usually say about the normal drab cast ones. This one is very shinny and this is offset by two black plastic strips on each side which not only look nice but are kind to your hands is you have to squeeze hard.Very solidly made so should last well.

I received this book free to read and review.I have read the “Inspector Drake” series by this author and this is a comparable series but by far more exciting.  Still set in Wales but this time set in Cardiff it starts as most detective stories do with a murder when a body is found floating in the river Taff.There starts the mystery with inspector Marco and his sidekick Boyd investigating this murder it soon however becomes apparent that it is not just a murder that has to be investigated and the story expands to involve people trafficking in the Polish community.There is plenty of the characters background to get a real feel for them and the descriptions of the locations just leap off the page. I liked Marco’s family background and the emphasis on his Italian roots and the family way of doing things.The interplay between characters is good with Marco being worried that another inspector “Hobbs” is trying to take the case away from him.This could have been just a good solid detective novel but elevates itself above this by Marco’s involvement with one of the characters which at about half way into the book turns it into a faster read without losing the investigative aspect.A very good book and although part of a series it works well as a standalone, I will read the rest of the series.

It took me a little time to get into this book as it felt I was not starting at the beginning of the series but there is no information on whether this is the first or not.As I read on more and more of Cal’s (the main character) background was revealed which made the story more engaging. I wish the author had let on where Cal had got Molly (her car) from as it was a supercharged one when I had a WRX it was a turbo.This is what I describe as a gentle mystery with no graphic violence but a good solid plot which allowed me to try and find the clues as the story progressed, some I found, some I did not. Although Cal is portrayed as a hard person she did come over as having a human side to her character. I liked how all the characters were portrayed but would single out Mickey, Cal’s assistant and general IT expert.I found that a lot of the descriptive passages added to the atmosphere and made the story seem more real, one example is where a description of “crispy tacos” was given, a small example but it grounded the story.As the title implies there are loose ends at the end of the story which no doubt will be explained in the next of the series.  Although part of a series it does work well as a stand alone novel.I will read the next one.

I received this book free to read and review.This is a slightly more measured read than the previous book in the series however it is worth reading the initial one first so you get more of a feel for the background of some of the characters this is particularly important to understand the reason for Nick and Anna’s greater involvement in the story they are ex- police who have set themselves up as private detectives.John Kane the main character is still seeking revenge which is now directed at those he believes are responsible for Lynda’s suicide. Although this is a violent book it is more spread out than in the previous book with more time spent on planning and developing the actual story.However the end of the story is worthy of any Chicago gangster novel.Although John Kane is undoubtedly a villain by the end of the book I was feeling quite a bit of sympathy for him. Despite his actions there were characters in the book that actually I felt come over as more evil than he was.I liked the way all of the characters were portrayed in particular Harold who I thought was the most evil of the bunch.

I received this free to test and review.As I have a "Leatherman Wave" I thought I would do a comparison. This should not have been a fair comparison as the "Leatherman" costs at least five times as much. I cannot judge long term how this compares but will update this review in about 6 months time.On first impressions they are very similar the "Gelindo" looking to me the more stylish with red/black and steel compared to the Leatherman's all steel finish. Both have convenient pouches which will hang on a belt, the Leatherman's as the name implies is leather. When folded the Leatherman is slightly more compact which means the pouch is also smaller.On opening to reveal the pliers they are very similar with the Leatherman's being slightly more tapered and having a cut out at the bottom of the cutter for wire stripping. The Gelindo has the advantage that the pliers are spring loaded so that they open more easily than the Leatherman.The knife and saw are similar the saw of both performing about the same however the Leatherman's knife is marginally sharper. The other tools are very similar except that the Leatherman has more of a range of screwdrivers and very useful scissors.The Gelindo has a 2 1/2" ruler on the back of the fish scaler a tool which is not included in the Leatherman.Between the arms of the pliers on the Gelindo is a bottle gripper/opener which I found was also good for cracking walnuts.I would not like to say which is the best, they are both good quality but the Gelindo certainly wins on price.If I had to buy either, both of these were gifts one from the manufacturer and one a birthday present I think I would buy the Gelindo mainly on cost but also by the fact it will crack walnuts.

I received this book free to review.This I suppose comes into my gentle murder category in the sense there is little graphic violence.Set in the 1960s this captures the feel of the times and the old boy network that surrounded the government and secret services at the time and for all I know still does. The author has obviously done much research into the planes. Cars and trains of the period and I was very impress until one of the characters was said to have been driving an “MG sprite” (This would never have been said, there were MG Midgets and Austin Healey Sprites)  I know it is a silly thing but from that point on I was looking for mistakes I did not find any more but it did change my focus on the book.Anyway, the story proper starts with Alex Swann being engaged to find out if a Miss Townsley’s fiancé had been murdered. With this fairly slow start the story expands into one with much wider implications with government departments and the secret service from both the UK and the USA being involved.I liked how all the characters were portrayed and the locations were vividly described and made all the more real by the supporting background an example is the change of trains at Crewe.As the story expands the pace increases with a number of twists and turns drawing me into it and eventually the mysteries were solved.  Not the most satisfactory ending from the point of the characters but very plausible.It does seem to prove that while time moves on the actions of governments of whatever complexion never seem to change.A very engaging story if a bit slow to get going and well worth a read.

I received this free to review.This starts with what I thought was going to be an exciting page turner until the end of the first chapter when it turned into a “teen romance” type of story. At this point I almost gave up and left it for a few days. I returned and waded through this part and the story picked up. It was full of very descriptive passages of both the characters and the locations. Surprisingly one the main character in the story Ana was the one I had the most trouble visualising.There were odd lines like “………..but tonight my dying friend was the priority” I never found out who the dying friend was. Likewise near the end of the book there seems to be content missing between the end of chapter 26 and 27. Both of these may be because I have a review copy however I can only review what I have.The actual story involves humans, Fae, Siis and the odd witch. I particularly liked Maria the witch and Adam one of the Siis. The Fae are ever present as malevolent beings and well described but I would have liked to have been given a better look at their beginnings.  Although this is the first in the series which really starts with Ana coming into the scene most of the rest of the characters have been going for 1000s of years so fitting it into the present often left me wanting to know more about the past of these characters. Reference is made to a war going on but I am not sure at this stage if it is between the Fae and the Sii or if others are involved.This is a story that captured my imagination after a fast beginning and then slowing down as it is a series it leaves much untold for future instalments.

I received this book to read and review.This is a good one to read as an introduction to science fiction, nothing is too way out but still a good story. As this is Part one there is obviously much more to come. The only thing that let it down for me was the title as I kept wondering and waiting for Zara to get a flight. Eventually of course she did which is almost where the story ends and sets itself up for the next in the series.There were good and bad characters with no aliens at this stage most of the book concentrating on the rise and fall of two rival corporations and their leaders. The characters were all well described particularly Zara as she develops from what could best be described as a spoilt brat into a confident woman.I did like the story and will read the rest of the series.

I received this free to read and review.To say this book was hurried is a bit of an understatement, everything moves at a frantic pace. It has the basis of a good story but little time is devoted to either the character development or the plot. The book shows it is Episode 1 which means that it is only part of the story and quite a short book. I would have liked to see this expanded into a complete novel rather than being a part work. As it is I don’t know how many parts there are but I will not be reading the rest.

I received this free to test and review.At last a car charger with three outputs and I do not have to worry which one to plug into. All will deliver 2.4A but are equally suitable for 500mA devices. It is a well-made charger with a nice feel to it with a rubberised outer coating. I am not sure if I want a car charger to look stylish but this one manages it with a simple blue line at the top and a blue led indicating when there is power to the charger.Supplied with the charger is a coiled usb cable 7ft or 2.15 metres long when fully extended. The advantage of this is it allows back seat passengers to have a phone or tablet on charge while sitting normally. I also liked the way the cable had the manufacturer's name on one side and a lightning symbol on the other, it is not always easy to see what you are doing in a car when you are trying to plug in leads but with this one and the raised logo it is easy to feel which way the plug should go.These days I find I am using more and more usb devices in a car and this one allows me to run my Satnav, car camera and still allow me to charge a phone. I wonder how long it will be before 3 outputs are not enough.A nice and very useful charger.

I received these free to test and review.Although a good cable the advantage for me is I no longer have to worry which cable is which. I normally keep cables connected to an 8 way charger and have devices that need different current supplies. It would not be so bad if all the outputs were 2.4 A but I need to make sure to get a fast charge that I have the right output going to the right device. I also have devices that need mini usb connectors so I now keep these as black or white leads and I no longer pick up the wrong one.The actual cables are a bit unusual in that they have a braided outer rather than the usual smooth plastic ones. I also liked the Velcro type strip that enabled me to keep the cables coiled up, usually however much I try I end up with cables all tangled up and even if I try to roll them up they always manage to unwind themselves.The actual micro plug end is interesting as it is slightly longer than most which means if the socket is slightly obstructed by a case they still fit, until now I had to keep a specific cable for one of my phones. Both ends have the Velutz name on one side and a lightning flash on the other so I can easily see which way up the plug goes.I primarily use the leads for charging but being usb 2 I also tested that they would transfer data they did this at usb 2 speed with no problems.I have always thought that a cable is just a cable but these are well thought out and have lots of advantages over the standard black ones.

This is a good story that holds together well with all the right ingredients, two civilisations meeting each other a battle in space and political intrigue with an underground and revolution brewing. What more could I want. Well I just could not visualise any of the characters and just did not care what happened to them. I don’t really know why and others may love the story but it was just not for me.

I received this free to test and review, tested with a Canon EOS 70D.The first thing I noticed on opening the box is that this is a substantial and well thought out bit of kit. At 390g it is not a light weight. If you are used to a simple flash that just flashes when you press the shutter this will come as a revelation.BUT read the instructions or you will not get the best out of it and although the instructions are comprehensive they do need careful reading.The flash can be used in two modes on or off the camera as it will work as a wireless connected slave. Off the camera there is a supplied bracket that doubles as a table stand or tripod mount.It can be rotated horizontally through 180⁰ and vertically through 90⁰. 45⁰, 60⁰ & 75⁰ being marked, useful for bounce flash. It even comes with a soft pouch to store the flash in when not in use.Without reproducing the instruction book it is difficult to describe everything that it does, even the crisp display screen which can become crowded at times shows every conceivable operation. In practice it is likely that you will have a preference for a particular mode and this can be tailored by using the “customised function” however I found the most useful thing was that the flash remembered the last setting so once set up it was easy to shoot a sequence.I particularly liked the fact that it could be used as a slave flash and positioned easily exactly where I wanted it. If I have any criticism it was with the “catchlight” & “wide-angle diffuser”, this slides out of the body of the flash and the diffuser folds over the flash head, no problem, however the catchlight panel can slide back in and be difficult to get hold of to pull back out. This is such a minor niggle with an otherwise excellent and versatile flash.There were other things I liked such as being able to use it as a modelling light for one second. With such a powerful flash there is a possibility of overheating if you use stroboscopic flash more than 10 times in succession so if you do this leave it to cool down for 15 minutes before you try again so the flash head is not damaged, there is however an automatic cut out to prevent overheating.With a flash although having many features is nice there is nothing more important than even illumination. I took a couple of photographs of a grey screen and I could not see any variation in the coverage.A rechargeable battery/power unit is available however the 4 AA cells give at least 110 flashes and I find it just as easy to pop in some new batteries.In summary; a superb flash that will do everything you want.

I received this free to test and review.Although advertised as a device for detecting dog urine stains (I am trying to be careful with my words so Amazon publish this) and it does work well in this mode, some friends have a new puppy and were surprised what this torch showed when they thought that they had cleaned up.It not only shows up traces that animals have left behind it also showed up residual from a coffee stain that I thought I had cleaned up and could not see with the naked eye. It does give an ultraviolet light but also into the visible spectrum so you can see what you are pointing it at. The instructions say it works better in the dark and although this is no doubt true I found it was fine in normal lighting conditions.However I did not get it for that, now that I am semi-retired I have become a “jack of all trades” one of my contracts is to check documents, passports etc . There are loads of forged documents about and this torch makes it easy to identify where security markings are missing or changes have been made to documents.It is a well-made device looking like a small torch, it takes 3 AAA batteries that are inserted in a removable carrier which makes changing batteries easy although as it will not be used for a long continuous period I expect the batteries to last for ages.

I received this free to test and review.Although this is an Apple certified device it has many more applications. I often have a number of things running in the car and these days the current demands are getting greater all the time. As this charger has 3 high power outputs 2 x 2.1 A and 1 x 2.4 A it is more than adequate to power my satnav and dashboard camera leaving one output so I can charge something else if I need to. (I leave the 2.4A one free so it will cope with anything.It is solidly made and fits securely into the car socket due to the sprung buttons on each side. The usb sockets hold the leads in place well.As it can draw 6.6A on full load from the car battery make sure you use a properly installed fused socket rather than a temporary hook up.

I received this free to test and review.I do not intend to do any camping during the winter so I will not be able to test it as a camping lantern at the moment, however even without camping it is a very useful gadget. I have not seen another lantern like this before.Initially it is a compact disk that has a lens in the center which serves as a torch however twist slightly and it pops up to turn into a small lantern. It is equally easy to fold back. The trend these days is to make everything rechargeable; however this one needs you to put in your own batteries. Actually I prefer this as I see it being used more as an emergency light in the case of a power failure than camping.In the dark even with the dim setting it provides enough light to see in a reasonably large room, perhaps not to read but more than adequate in the case of a power failure. However on the "bright" setting I could read with it admittedly not from a great distance.It is claimed to be water resistant to IP44 which means that water falling as a spray at any angle up to 60° from the vertical shall have no harmful effect. Test duration: 5 minutes. Although I am not disputing this I am not sure I would like to expose it to that much water, but it should certainly be OK in normal rain.A useful light, which will be kept next to my electricity meter, waiting for the next power cut. I will take it camping with me next summer.

A well-structured book with an unusual premise, for some reason, which becomes apparent later in the book adults are being killed by animals and fighting amongst themselves. Against this background the characters in the book have to survive, there is plenty of graphic violence and it is essentially a simple story of survival but well written.Later on in the book it becomes more of a mission as the group realise the danger they are in. I thought all the characters were well portrayed and although there is a mild romantic involvement it does not bog down the story.This is part one of a series but it stands well by itself and I am not sure were subsequent books will go as there to me seems little to add.I will however read the next in the series.

I received this free to test and review.I have just got a new “smart” phone and find the onscreen keyboard is fiddly I have not got particularly large hands but I am always touching an adjacent key. This is only a real problem with passwords where I have been locked out of a site a couple of times due to hitting the wrong key.This stylus solves all the problems as it allows precision touching and although I will probably not use it for everything I have found it essential if it is a cluttered screen that has not been formatted for use on a small (4”) screen.The business end has a soft but seemingly substantial “point” which will not scratch or otherwise damage a touch screen. There is a useful pen if you pull off the end with the pocket clip. I do not know however what size refills it takes or if they are replaceable as I did not recognise the type.Unlike some styluses I have used in the past this one is well made and looks to all intents and purposes a well made stylish pen. Although smooth it does give the impression of cut pattern on the body.Very nice and useful.

The author kindly sent me all three of the series and I read them all before posting the reviews as often I find that often series turn out to be serials where they run into each other and you need to read all of them. In this case there is no such problem although the series contains references to the other books they read well as complete stand-alone books, after reading them all the more I thought that they did not need to be a series as there was little relationship between the individual books.The series are;-Worldship Praxis (The Worlds of Man)Shadow of Worlds (The Worlds of Man)Vanguard of Man: The Worlds of Man Book 3The first in the series "Worldship Praxis" is an exploration vessel which is sending colonists to distant worlds since Earth became uninhabitable and in the meantime having the odd battle with the Andiki an insect race. It is an interesting book that spends a lot of time in developing the characters and the enormous ship. I found the characters interesting including a "Pixie Sabre Tooth" and Nina the ship's Avatar. There are themes that have been used before such as nano technology but it all comes together as an easy read novel which is no bad thing.

I received this free to test and review.There are so many of these about that it is difficult for any to stand out from the rest, this one however manages to do it. Often I wonder how much charge is left of how much more charge it needs, with this one there is a digital display which shows the charge level as a real percentage. Very useful.Forget what the manual says as it is not very helpful, however it does not need much it the way of instructions. Plug a 5v (It will actually take a range of input voltages safely) charger you can either use a micro usb plug or use the included lead an adaptor which doubles as an output lead. It comes with 4 adaptors, mini usb, micro usb, apple and a small Nokia.There are two usb output sockets a 1A one and a 2A one, when you are discharging the battery to power a phone etc which output is being used is displayed.All this plus a useful torch is contained in a shiny piano black unit which also comes with a soft plush bag which is useful for carrying it about and preventing it from being damaged.

I received this free to test and review.This is going to be something you like or dislike depending on if you like the style or not, I did. I found it easy to pair with a number of phones including a Blackberry, Nokia and an iPhone. Read the instructions carefully as they are not too clear. I was pleasantly surprised with the sound quality both talk and listen. The display although small was very clear and displayed the caller’s number on incoming calls. I liked the fact that with nothing happening the face was completely black until a touch on either button brought up the time. With power off if you want to conserve power although it does have a standby time of up to 72 hours the watch keeps time so when you power it back up you do not have to reset the time.Charging was easy with a unique clip (a bit like a crocodile clip) which had two little prongs that clipped on the bracelet. As anormal charging lead will not fit remember to take it on holiday and don’t lose it.I have often worried about using an expensive phone in a busy city as it could so easily be snatched, with this you can keep the phone in your bag / pocket and answer or make calls from the watch without taking the phone out (outgoing calls are only to the last number dialled). One of the things I use in cities is the phones sat nav (Nokia Ovi maps) where it talks directions I found this very useful to have on my wrist rather than having to keep the phone out all the time.Music streaming worked but I think I preferred using an earphone off the phone.I am fortunate that I have a slim wrist as the bracelet does not expand very much and anyone with thick wrists may find it will not fit or be very uncomfortable.

I received this book free to read and review.Although the product details give away most of the plot it is quite straight forward Connor the main character wants to rather than search for UFOs actually encourage them to visit him.Most of the book is how he goes about trying to attract UFOs, the book is more of a descriptive work which develops slowly than an action story.  I often have problems with translated books but this works well. The author (in the publicity blurb) challenges us to decide which is real and which is fiction, some is decidedly fiction and whether the rest is I just don't care.Connor is a very interesting character who is determined to live his life how he wants and surprisingly his wife goes along with the unusual relationship without complaint. At the end of the book there is an epilogue which is set in the future and pulls everything together. I can't help feeling there should be another book or even a series between the end of the book and the epilogue.Still a very unusual story and well worth reading.

I received this book free to read and review.For a while I wondered if this was actually a science fiction/fantasy novel as it seemed that it could have been set in many early periods in Earth’s history except that it was played out between rival bands on floating rocks (aerocks). I thought that it worked well as a descriptive work of the location and all of the characters seemed realistic. The story slowly developed and although the mystery of who and where the knight of the title came from was a central thread it was more about the interaction between characters and the changing alliances. The science fiction elements which were developed towards the end of the story enhanced the story but were not overdone. I thoroughly enjoyed the story and although it wrapped up everything at the end there are plenty of loose ends to allow it to continue as a series and I hope it does.

I received this book free to read and review.Unfortunately the car was better than the story, I was intrigued when I saw the book as I used to own a GT6 like the one featured in the book, however I was disappointed in the book.None of the characters seemed to be realistic and the story although coming to a logical conclusion did meander getting there. Much was made in the publisher’s blurb of the detective wanting to seek proof that Elvis is still alive, although passing reference was made to this it was not developed in the story.  I assume it was intended to be an amusing story but perhaps I have no sense of humour. The descriptive passages were good but just not the book for me. There are more to come but I will not be reading them.

This is essentially a save the world there is a countdown to disaster type novel. The twist is that only the bad guys know the disaster is coming and try to conceal it from the rest of the world.There are a number of converging story lines which don’t seem to be leading in the same direction but eventually came together.An exciting tale with interesting characters and although I am not sure about some of the science it all sounded very plausible.Certainly a different take on a disaster novel, and did wonder until late in the story if everything was going to work out for the best.

I received this free to read and reviewA long short story if this makes any sense and one that is pitched firmly at the lower age groups. Told from the perspective of the alien and from that of the little girl whose family adopts the alien “Alfear”. Almost reading like a fairy story there is much that does not logically hold together like why should a family be able to suddenly adopt a boy found at a zoo. I actually liked the story from the alien’s perspective better, strangely it seemed more real. Slowly as the aliens powers became more apparent I thought it was going to have a twist and become more of a horror story but no it retained its gentle style to the end. One of the few friendly alien stories and a nice introduction to science fiction.There is more to come as Alfear has more adventures in the wide world and I can see this series creating a following however I am so far out of the target age group that I will not be one of them.

An all action thriller that proceeds at a fast pace. Everything is thrown at the reader and it requires you to suspend logic to for it to work. I have no idea why the “Robin Hood Hacker” Ronnie the central character as well as being a hacker has high tech (science fiction) weapons and devices, but otherwise the story would not work. All of the characters are very comic strip and larger than life as is the action.Thrown into the mix are “black death”, “Evil secret society (The Hidden Hand)” a few scientists, secret service agents and not to forget paintings from the great masters and even “Elvis”.There are twist and turns all through the book with a bit of romance thrown in.If you look as all the elements thrown in it just should not work but it does and does very well.Although this is the first of a series it works well as a stand-alone leaving just enough loose ends for the series to carry on.I will read the next in the series.

I received this free to test and review.This is a stylish and useful back up battery and at its price point very good value and powerful (2600mAh). It is however badly let down by its instructions which contains some gems such as “Charging, the mobile power hosts a slight fever which s a normal phenomenon” I assume this means it gets hot in use.. If you have never used one of these before it is difficult to know which is the input and which the output as it is not labelled on the battery (It is micro usb to charge and standard usb for output) there is no indication in the instructions how to tell if it is charged.(While charging a red led lights up, when fully charged it turns green and when used to power a phone etc it turns blue) Unfortunately there is no way of indicating the charge level other than fully charged.It is remarkably simple to use just charge it up and plug it into whatever you want to charge, I have a sat nav with a dud battery that is not replaceable and this powers it nicely and lasts all day.It has 4 interchangeable tips which allow you to use it with mini usb, micro usb, iPad and the small Nokia connector.Worth getting if you need a stylish and good value battery.

I have given it 2 stars as if you scroll through enough you can find some helpful pictures and instructions but I have never seen a book that has been formatted as badly. Strangely the look inside is OK.OK if free but please don't pay for it.In summary prise the case apart with a plastic tool and change the battery.

I received this torch free to test and review.I have a number of these types of torches but this sets itself apart from the others for a number of reasons one of the main ones being the battery. Usually these torches use 18650 rechargeable batteries which although very good are quite difficult to get in the UK. While this torch is no exception it also has an adaptor that fits instead of the rechargeable battery and takes 3 AAA type batteries, so much more convenient. The actual torch fits easily in the pocket being 135mm long or about 5 ¼ ". The other distinguishing feature is the "zoom" marked "dimmer" on the torch, instead of the normal intense but narrow beam this has a ring which when twisted changes the focus of the beam which can then become although still bright a wider angle which is very useful as often a spot beam does not light up everything you need it to.Simple to use with just a single on/off button at the end, no fancy SOS settings. It just does what it is supposed to do and does it very well. EDIT I have just found the flash setting click the on/off button twice for flash.There is a built in clip on the body of the torch so it can be clipped to a belt or pocket etc. It also comes with an adjustable head band with a couple of loops in various places to secure the torch, top of the head or either side. There is also a quick release clamp to fit cycle handlebars and finally a wrist strap.In summary a very versatile and useful torch.

I received this book free to read and review.Although quite a short book there is much in here to learn to avoid some of the embarrassing pit falls should you ever need or want to meet with the "toffs". It will probably do me some good as even my dogs have better pedigrees than I have.Written in a light hearted manner it is an enjoyable read even if you do not want to put any of the information into practice. I liked the example given of how an invitation should be printed with as much thought given to the quality of the printing as the actual message, I never thought of that. I would have liked to see a bit about hunting, shooting & fishing as I can imagine some hilarious gaffs that could be caused here.I read this on a Kindle Paperwhite and if there is a criticism some illustrations and quotes are not so easily readable in "pale grey".I think I am still spiritually a beige and plusfours man however I do now know how to dress if I ever get invited into the house rather than despatched to the hut with the rest of the pickers up.Well worth a read.

I received this book free to read and review.Although this states an adult book I would suggest it is pitched at the YA market and although I am far from that, but getting younger all the time, I thoroughly enjoyed it. Although dealing with time travel which can be confusing this book did not fall into the trap of using too many pseudoscientific descriptions some certainly but not too many. This was grounded by also trying to start the time craft with a truck battery.The romance stated in the description is a bit one sided but may develop in others in the series, when I started reading it I did not realise it was a series but it works well as a standalone novel with enough left over for the next one.I liked the characters, there were not too many of them, and they had a feel to them so that I could visualise them I actually liked the way Lola Garth (no relation to Garth of the comic strip) the lady from the department trying to close down the time travel operation was portrayed. Woodstock features quite a bit and it is a slight deviation from the main story line however it is described in such a way as the atmosphere of Woodstock comes  across. It is how friends of mine described it at the time. I would have liked to have gone there but my time machine (actually camper van) broke down about 100 miles away.In all a nice light read it does not stretch the reader but is very enjoyable.

I received this book free to read and review.I think this book is cleverer than I am. It starts with Richard Wallace an Attorney who is not making much money receives an offer he can't refuse however he has to go to New York, somewhere at this stage we don't know why he does not want to go there. The actual task is not specified at this stage but it is slowly revealed, well sort of. Once it gets to the end it is revealed that Richard Wallace knew about it all the time. Well I am pleased that someone did. I found he whole story difficult to follow as it was interspersed with dreams and flash backs, often I was reading and then the book had gone off on a different track altogether.I do like  a straightforward story and this is not one.

I received this book free to read and review.Some science fiction manages to have good descriptive passages of strange new worlds and others have good strong stories this manages both. On some levels it is a conventional detective novel but raised to a new level by the setting. It also deals with science, some very way out, in a way that makes it all seem very "normal" if multiple personalities, arms that convert into a multitude of weapons and implants that store all your memories and more can ever be normal.The two main detectives Lieutenant Hoskin and Sergeant Quinlin come across as real people going about their normal job with just enough background given to be able to visualise them. In fact all of the characters are well described, I particularly liked the enigmatic Sakura.In the end everything comes to a satisfactory conclusion and all the loose ends are brought together.There are enough of the characters in the book left for this to be the start of a series and hope it is.A great science fiction and I would like to read more from this author.

I received this book free to read and review.This is the second in the series but works well as a stand-alone I have not read the previous book.While most fiction relies on coincidences to move the story on this book carries this to an extreme and undermines the credibility of what could have been a good and exciting story.The story carries on at a pace with police detectives trying to catch a fugitive who is himself involved in a plot to assassinate the president of the USA.The detectives add little to the story other than to bring together the unlikely coincidences, as a book about an assassination attempt it would have worked well but for me it just seemed too implausible.

I received this book free to read and review.Set in the future where the State runs everything and provides everything. Against this background a man and his dog Anup try to live an independent life selling "Electronic devices that work and do not pack up the next day".The book is a very well described vision of the future and the decay of society. This works well into the first half of the book, after that it becomes a bit drawn out and the reason for the final collapse does not seem as well thought out as the rest of the book.Certainly a thought provoking book.

I have been using Serif software since they started and with most of the range I update every other version unless there is an upgrade that I particularly want. However I do not do much video editing and could not see much point in updating from a very early version. I however received a good offer from Serif which included the handbook, which is worth having.It is impossible for me to list all of the improvements from my early version but thought I would start the easy way and use a wizard (Quick Movie) to create a short movie and that is where I ran into trouble.I selected a theme downloaded 3 short clips with the intention of using them for an Amazon video review. So far so good, it created the movie with Title screen formatted all the frames in keeping with the theme and created a credits screen for the end.BUTI did not like the theme and could find no way of changing the theme without starting again (It is probably possible but I could find nothing in the help files or in the book. As there are loads of themes I would like the opportunity of trying an assortment to see which I liked best.I did find one I liked and then proceeded to try and customise it, I could enter additional title and other text boxes and change transitions of which there are many, I liked the 3D page roll. However I again ran into trouble here as I wanted 2 sequential text screens I could not find any way of preventing them merging when I ran the movie so the text was not readable.Once I had eventually produced the video it was extremely easy to save in almost any format and it does have formats specifically for "itunes"  and "youtube".IN SUMMARYA very comprehensive video editing package however I did not find it as intuitive as claimed. If I am prepared to put time into it I think it will do anything that anyone wants, it will even support "chroma key" and "AVCHD 1080", I am not sure what that is but needs a powerful  (Quad-core processor and 2GB ram as a minimum requirement).I am using Windows 8 with an i5 processor and 8GB RAM everything I have tried works very quickly.

I received this book free to read and review.Nothing annoys me more when I get to the end of a book and it turns out to be a serial there is no clue except when you get to the end there are the words "To be continued" in the Kindle version there is even a link to ask the author for more, I felt like logging on to so please no more.The publishers blurb and a lot of reviewers have called this thought provoking my only thought was what on earth it was about. The book starts with a young girl with paranormal abilities being tortured so that she becomes a number of entities, all rather nasty. After that I am afraid it lost me completely but I struggled on hoping that all would be revealed at the end.The only thing in its favour was the very descriptive passages but no substitute for a story.A book to avoid.

I have a new favorite book of the year: Sarah Bird’s Above the East China Sea. This is one of those deeply satisfying reads that works on many levels. It moves among several settings: the U.S. military base on Okinawa in the present day and Okinawa outside of the base; Okinawa during World War II when the Island served as a defensive barrier between Japan and U.S. warships; the Okinawan spirit world, led by spirits called kami.This book is the story of two young women and is narrated in their voices. The first, Luz James, is a military brat (a term she uses to describe herself), daughter of a single mother. Luz’s world has been torn apart by her older sister’s unexpected enlistment in the Air Force and her death in Afghanistan. She is responding to her sorrow with drug use and risk-taking, common pastimes among her two groups of friends: the “Quasi” crowd composed of other military brats (quasi because that’s the only sort of friendship one can establish with the constant moves of military life) and the Smokinawans, the local stoners.The second young woman is Tamiko Kokuba, an Okinawan originally a fanatical supporter of Japan (many Okinawans at the time considered it a compliment to be mistaken for Japanese), who works in the cave hospitals set up on the island for the Japanese forces, and who, pregnant at age fifteen after being raped by soldiers on both sides of the conflict, chooses to commit suicide. Okinawan custom requires recovery of the body and regular tending to the remaining bones in order to to have a life after death. Because she has committed suicide by throwing herself into the sea and her body was never recovered, Tamiko and her unknown child have been unable to move on. Their spirits await guidance by the kami, hoping the kami will provide them with a body whose spirit they can displace, which will allow them to move on to the afterlife. Tamiko spends the years as a waiting spirit by recounting her life story to her unborn child.Luz and Tamiko’s paths cross in both literal and spiritual senses as Luz contemplates suicide and Tamiko waits for a body to house her spirit. At several moments I was sure I’d guessed how these two different crises would be resolved, but Bird’s nuanced story-telling keeps adding complexity to the narrative, taking it to deeper, richer places than I’d imagined.I don’t want to say more than this because readers deserve the pleasure of following the several paths of this novel without having parts of the narrative revealed ahead of time. Whatever your preferred genre—history, historical fiction, contemporary fiction, mystery, fantasy—Above the East China Sea offers a satisfying read that will stay with you long after you close the book.

Jonathan Auxier’s The Night Gardener is an absolute delight—one of those “children’s books” that can just as readily pull adults into its magical world. I started it one night, read until I was exhausted, then picked it up again the next morning because I couldn’t wait to get back to that magical world.This tale was inspired, the author tell us, by Bradbury’s Something Wicked This Way Comes and the stories of Washington Irving, among other texts, but it is much more than a new twist on previously published works. One can see moments where these inspirations shine through clearly, but The Night Gardener remains its own creature throughout: moody, sometimes deeply unsettling, populated by a cast of characters one quickly grows fond of.The novel is set in the Victorian era, and the cast include young Molly and Kip, who may or may not be orphans, making their way to a mysterious manner house in hopes of gaining work as servants; the failing, fading family who make this mansion their home; a story-telling crone; and a self-satisfied rationalist doctor, alert for any opportunity to receive scientific fame.In addition to the human characters, we also have the Night Gardener of the title and the overgrown, menacing tree he tends and that grows not just outside, but throughout the home, shaping the lives of all who spend time there.This is one of those novels that meets expectations, but never disappoints by doing so. Our young heroes summon bravery in difficult straits. The threatened family’s love is dissipating, but emerges still at crucial moments. To paraphrase Oscar Wilde’s The Importance of Being Earnest, the good end happily and the bad end unhappily; that is what fiction means. Just as Harry Potter’s expected defeat of Voldemort does nothing to lesson the pleasure of reading J. K. Rowling’s series, the fact that our young heroes end (mostly) happily does nothing to dilute the pleasures of The Night Gardener. The fact that Auxier is a wonderful prose stylist doesn’t hurt, either.Whether you live in a home with children or without them, this is a wonderful book to keep on the shelves for those moments when one needs to sink into the company of literary “friends” and to allow the cares of day-to-day life to fade into the distance. After you’ve read this book once, you’ll look forward to returning to it again.

In Natalie S. Harnett’s The Hollow Ground, the characters attempt to make peace with themselves and each other while living—both literally and figuratively—over a great emptiness. The setting for this novel is a group of former coal-mining towns. The mines have closed, but the coal still in the ground has caught fire and has been burning for years. These underground fires can render playgrounds and basements literally too hot to walk across; they produce carbon monoxide, a constant threat for those living in these towns; and, as coal burns away, great holes develop underground, undermining the foundations of homes and sometimes collapsing, taking homes and lives with them. Whole cities are being destroyed in a major eminent domain project involving the digging of enormous trenches in hopes of ending the fires’ spread.This is where we meet our narrator, Brigid Howley. Brigid is in her early teens and her life has been completely destabilized. Her favorite aunt has died in a sink-hole collapse in the family’s backyard, the family’s home has been condemned, and they now live in a run-down local hotel on temporary assistance. All the adults in her life—mother, father, paternal grandmother—are at odds with one another, and when Brigid’s family move in with her grandmother, her life grows less stable, not more.Brigid’s father, Adrian, is a seldom-employed former miner, who lost the use of one arm in a mine collapse. Her mother, Dolores, was left at an orphanage after her father remarried—although the couple chose to raise her younger brother as their own. Brigid’s grandmother (whose mother also grew up in an orphanage) is the second wife of a man who lost his “true loves,” his first wife and children, in flash flooding caused by a mine collapse. Everyone, including the children has learned to keep their feelings and desires well hidden because, as Brigid tells us several times, the easiest way of losing something is to let others know you want it.Given this bleak setting and contentious cast, I admit to having a hard time really getting going with The Hollow Ground. The first third or so just seemed like an onslaught of unpleasant people being unpleasant with each other. But that changed as Brigid began to develop a friendship of her own and to create a (small) life for herself outside of her family. She still spends much of her time observing the adults around her, but she also becomes more of a girl: not completely jaded, experiencing a great many things for the first time.If you’re looking for mindless (or just comforting) entertainment, you’ll find this book deeply unsatisfactory. On the other hand, if you’re willing to fight your way through the unpleasantness, you’ll find yourself deeply engaged with Brigid, admiring her character, if not always enjoying her story.

Nathan Dueul's, Friday Was the Bomb, recounts his experiences living in the middle east, working as a freelance writer, and caring for his daughter, while his wife worked as a war correspondent for National Public Radio. This isn't a full-on memoire, rather it's a collection of some of his freelance essays (with revision) that originally appeared in a variety of publications, including Al Jazeera America, Los Angeles Review of Books, and The New Republic.I requested an electronic ARC of this book anticipating that it might give me an insider's view of the political clashes and civil wars currently fomenting in the middle east--but it's Dueul's wife who's the war correspondent, not Dueul. One learns little about the Middle East in these essays beyond the fact that an interesting range of ex-pats live there and that occasional violence breaks out with loss of life. In other words, this isn't really a book about the middle east.What it is is a book about balancing fatherhood and work, these tasks complicated by worries about a spouse with a very dangerous job. He is sincerely interested in events around him:I was excited and honored--overwhelmed, really--to be standing in the middle [of this region], hoping the darker forces of death and destruction would keep their distance and that my own enthusiasm to learn more--with Kelly's [his wife] ability to report well and stay alive, with the resilience of the Iraqi people, with America's ability to be honest about its power and priorities, with my ability to have faith in something it was difficult to have faith in--maybe things might actually get better.But what Dueul writes most about isn't the political aspirations of the Iraqi people or America's honesty. We get stories of taking children for a snow day in Lebanon, of an art opening made lively with ample beer, of getting the best shave and haircut of his life from a barber in Instanbul.Dueul isn't blind to the struggles being played out around him, but when he thinks of them, he's putting a good bit of his energy into watching his own responses to them, using the times in war zones to try to work out what sort of a man he is. Near the end of the book, transitioning to life back in the U.S. he notes that, "On the eve of our new life in America, I had a feeling that everything I'd struggled with the last five years--worrying, death, guilt--would dog me no matter what country we lived in."If you want to read a collection about the challenges of fatherhood and manhood--albeit in an extraordinary setting--you'll enjoy this book. But I was looking for insights into a political struggle often minimally covered by the U.S. media, and I left this book feeling none the wiser.

I’d been itching to read Norman Lock’s The Boy in His Winter: An American Novel since the moment I heard about its premise: Huck Finn and Jim sail down the Mississippi and along time, arriving in New Orleans as Hurricane Katrina hits. This synopsis (who knows where or how I absorbed it) isn’t really accurate. Yes, Huck and Jim are on a raft. Yes, the raft passes through the edge of Katrina. But The Boy in His Winter is much more complex in its aspirations.Rather than offering a quick one-line summary that includes only a small part of the book’s overall narrative, it might be more useful to look at the publisher releasing the book. In this case, the publisher is Bellevue Literary Press (BLP), which bills itself as “the first and only nonprofit press dedicated to literary fiction and nonfiction at the intersection of the arts and sciences.” BLP hopes to “promote science literacy in unaccustomed ways and offer new tools for thinking about our world.” This isn’t a Huck-meets-Katrina book; it’s a much more metaphysical work that questions the nature of time while traversing key moments in American history.I enjoyed this book at the beginning. Huck, now very old and near dying, is recounting his story to an anonymous amanuensis. He wanders a bit, he cogitates, he questions as much as tells: “Of course, I reckon time differently now than we did then, sweeping down the Mississippi toward Mexico as though in a dream.  Those days did seem like a dream, though not mine, or Jim’s, either, but one belonging to somebody whose hand I almost felt, prodding me onward in spite of my reluctance.” That’s rich language, the kind one wants to read aloud for the pleasure of feeling it roll about in one’s mouth.As the book progressed and the metaphysical pondering continued, I grew less charmed. The prose was still lovely, but as I read I felt as though I was waiting for someone or something to appear that, Godot-like, never showed its face. What I was longing for, I think, was the physical Huck, the boy of flesh and blood. Yes, Huck was a thinker, but he was also young, vital, alive, and to have this aspect of him jettisoned from the beginning left me frustrated.Many of Huck’s thoughts—on slavery and race, on friendship and its limits, on the human condition—are interesting. And the book offers some small moments of action: a Civil War battle, the brief glimpse of Katrina, the birth of jazz from southern blues music. Jim, who dies before Huck, reappears in different guises and the reader enjoys seeing him change as his spirit is transported to new eras. But too many of Huck’s thoughts are repetitious, and the blurred depiction of the external world leaves readers anchorless on this float down time and river.The Boy in His Winter does “promote science literacy in unaccustomed ways,” but the “tools for thinking about our world” are limited: Time is fluid; People do and don’t change. This isn’t so much science literacy as scientific generalization written over and over again.

If you're a fan of historical mysteries, you will be able to spend a few lovely hours with this book. The plot shows some understanding of Elizabethan England. The central characters quickly engage the reader.

This is a wonderful, wonderful read. The narrator is smart and self-possessed. In one sense this is a teen "problem novel," but it is much, much richer than that label suggests. I would urge anyone to read this, whether teen or adult. You will be moved and your world will be broadened.

I usually stick with a book to the (sometimes) bitter end, but I couldn't even make it through the first fifty pages (as Nancy Pearl recommends). The writing was florid and the plot improbable, particularly if one has any knowledge of the time period. If you like romantic fantasy, you may find this a grand read. If you like your historical fiction grounded in actual history, you'll want to skip this one.

Set in World War II France and Germany, All the Light We Cannot See is my favorite kind of novel: long, rich, populated by a range of imperfect characters, some who try to transcend that imperfection, others who cannot see it.The cast of characters includes Marie-Laure, blind since age six, with a quick mind and a great deal of self-confidence; her father, locksmith for the Museum of Natural History in Paris; Marie-Laure’s great-uncle, an agoraphobic haunted by ghosts since he returned from World War I; the great-uncle’s elderly housekeeper, who finds the courage to join the French resistance; Werner, a German orphan who is a prodigy in the creation and repair of radios; Werner’s sister Jutta, left behind when Werner is accepted into a science academy for Hitler Youth that offers more political indoctrination than science; and a whole host of others.Anthony Doerr brings this wide assembly of individuals to life, moving among them, slowly drawing them nearer one another, fleshing each of them out so that even those we might expect to be stereotypes are much more multifaceted.And among these multifaceted characters lies a multifaceted stone: a diamond with a legendary history. In less able hands, the diamond would have dominated this story, which would have degenerated into a variation on Raiders of the Lost Ark, but it’s the characters who are the heart of All the Light We Cannot See. There are a few we hate, but for the most part, we can’t help but see the better parts of them. The question is whether they will discover these better selves in time to make a difference of some sort in a world quite literally in flames.I’m hesitant to provide more summary. Reading this book, meeting the people in it, sharing their journeys, is an engrossing experience that shouldn’t be undercut by foreknowledge. All the Light We Cannot See contains a great deal of action, but that action is more than balanced by the development of characters we witness over the decade or so that this novel encompasses. This is novel of people more than it is a novel of events.I received and electronic ARC of this book to review and find myself longing for its release date so I can get a paper copy, one that will feel as solid in my hands as Doerr’s narrative. We’re less than halfway through the year, but it wouldn’t surprise me at all if in December I remember All the Light We Cannot See as my favorite read of the year.

Jurek Becker is probably best know for his two novels Jacob the Liar and The Boxer, but this is the first of his works I’ve read. It’s a slim volume, just under 150 pages, containing five short stories and one essay. Becker is a Holocaust survivor—one who was quite young during WWII. He was born in Lodz, Poland, and lived in the Lodz Ghetto for several years before being sent to the Ravensbruck concentration camp at the age of five. Later, he was sent to Sachsenhausen. His father, from whom he’d been separated, survived as well, and the two were united after the war. His mother died just as the camps were being liberated. He lived in East Germany for many years, a dissident author and playwright, but moved to West Berlin in 1977, retaining his East German citizenship.The editor (Becker’s wife) has placed the one essay at the end of the book as a way of demarcating the line between fiction and non-fiction, but, not surprisingly, this line is significantly blurred, and the book is better because of that, detailed in its brevity with stories in which scene and character are quickly established.If there is one theme that runs through the book, it’s the ways that we don’t understand the stories of our own lives as we live them. Four of the five stories are narrated in the first person: and each narrator’s grasp of his own situation is limited in some significant way. In the title story, an unnamed boy whose family is moved from one part of the Lodz Ghetto to another, recounts the adventures he and two friends devise. The narrator is aware that people are being summarily executed—an elderly shopkeeper friend of his was killed for the “crime” of having a plant in his apartment—but at the same time, cannot quite grasp the risks he faces, even in moments when he fears his own death is at hand.In “The Most Popular Family Story” an uncle relates a “prank” played on him while he was on business in London, one made possible by his lack of English and limited knowledge of local customs. In “The Suspect” a loyal East German deals with the fact that he’s under government surveillance with a series of rationalizations that make him unable to see the true nature of that government.This lack of full understanding is made clear in both the introduction and in the book’s final essay, “The Invisible City,” written to accompany an exhibit of photographs of the Lodz Ghetto. Becker, the author, knows the outline of his own childhood, but doesn’t remember it; he knows about the war years only through the handful of stories his father told him.I found this incomplete understanding moving. The opening story and the young narrator’s incomplete grasp of his own situation are heartbreaking because we, the readers, know so much more than does the story’s central character. What the boy sees as arbitrary rules and limitations, we see as the leading edge of a horror about to be fully enacted.The incomplete understanding also made me think of my own time and the things we choose not to understand because full understanding would overwhelm us. We “know” of injustices, famines, human rights violations, natural disasters, but for those not living through them understanding is not just impossible, it is also unwanted. As is the case with several of Becker’s narrators, it is, in fact, our lack of full understanding that allows us to survive.While this is a brief book—so brief as to be frustrating—it is absolutely worth reading, offering us mirrors on the past and, if we look closely, on our own present as well.

This series is off to a solid start. The central characters, Mina and Evaline, are well defined and easy to identify with. The steam punk elements are imaginative. My one complaint would be that this is clearly meant to be the start of a series, so there's no real resolution at the end. I would have liked a little something, even if the bigger, overarching mystery remained.

Steve Burrows’ A Siege of Bitterns introduces Inspector Domenic Jejeune, a detective recently assigned to the village of Saltmarsh who is deeply ambivalent about his work. Yes, he’s something of a prodigy when it comes to solving murders and missing persons cases, but he’s also a cipher of a man—one who would prefer the rather isolated life of a field ornithologist to his own.A Siege of Bitterns is the first in a promised series of “birder mysteries” featuring Jejeune, and I can’t wait for more.Well, I suppose I will have to wait for more, but I don’t want to. I’d much rather there were already a dozen volumes in the series that I could pore through, watching his character develop, seeing his changing relationships with colleagues, listening to his frustrated, conflicting internal dialogues.Whether or not bird-watching interests you (I grew up in a house of birders, but never became one myself), if you like high-quality police procedural mystery novels, you’ll be deeply satisfied with A Siege of Bitterns. Enjoy it now, then join me in waiting eagerly for the next volume.
This story is beautifully written, with some wonderful surprises. I have been longing for more of the author's work, and really appreciated this piece--though I am still hungry for more.

Upside Down in the Middle of Nowhere is one of those luminous YA reads that bookstores would do well to stock with adult fiction, as well as YA. It’s a “problem novel,” but the problem isn’t a distant boyfriend or a fight with a bestie; the problem is Hurricane Katrina.Armani Curtis’s family has yielded to her imploring and decided to remain in New Orleans, despite the pending storm, to celebrate her birthday. This is a bad decision. A very bad decision that puts everyone involved through all the worst that we’ve come to associate with Katrina: being stranded on the rooftop of their flooded house, losing (and not always finding once again) family members, traveling across and in badly polluted water, facing the misery and incipient violence in the King Dome, and trying to avoid child protective services, so the family won’t be broken up further.The pacing of this novel is just right. At first, we see the world simply, through Armani’s eyes. She chafes against some of the restrictions imposed by her parents, but respects the discipline and sense of personal history that they and her grandmother provide. The shift from normality to disaster begins gradually enough; we can see why the family might choose to remain. But when Katrina hits, things change quickly and dangerously.Yes, this is fiction, but it does a wonderful job of placing readers in the middle of a challenging, devastating disaster that may be beginning to slip out of current memory. This is a book we—adults and teenagers—need to help us grasp the magnitude of natural disaster. We also need it just so we can meet Armani and watch her, sometimes unwillingly, rise to the occasion.

The Resurrection of Mary Mabel McTavish is an odd sort of creature, rather like the result of some mad gene splicing experiment combining DNA from Nathaniel West, Carson, McCullers, and Horatio Alger. It is at once innocent and deeply cynical, a romance that litters the road to true love with all sorts of wreckage.Mary Mabel, stuck with a drunken, uncaring father, and living at the finishing school at which he serves as handyman, is both unhappy and genuine: dreaming of a different life, while seeing both the best and the worst in the world around her.The characters in this novel are types most readers will recognize, but they’re painted with enough detail that at their best moments they transcend stereotype. Besides Mabel’s father and the woman who runs the school (and later poses as a titled gentry) we have a half-crazed, going on fully crazed revivalist preacher; a sanctimonious con man; a newspaper man who will do anything for a story, and who hides a a streak of decency beneath his opportunism. There’s also the ghost of Mary Mabel’s mother.The story opens with a resurrection. Mary Mabel impulsively lays hands on and reanimates a boy struck by lightening during a revival held in a tent that was previously the site of an adultery-inspired double murder. And the story goes on from there: complex, ridiculous, mocking.At its best moments Mary Mabel is humorous and engaging, but at other times (those most West-like) it feels heavy-handed and deliberately provocative. The characters are never quite fleshed out enough to carry the weight of the narrative. Instead the author gets by keeping readers off balance and throwing one knuckle ball after another their way.This isn’t a book to read when you’re hungering for a narrative you can get lost in, but when you’d like some narrative pyrotechnics you may find it amusing.

Cara Hoffman’s Be Safe I Love You follows soldier Lauren Clay on her first few days home following a tour of duty in Iraq. There’s a strong arc to this story: unsatisfactory meetings with old friends and family leading to Lauren’s decision to take her younger brother on a survivalist journey through a remote area of Canada in midwinter.Suspenseful as that narrative is, the real heart of the book is the characters and their wrestling with questions of identity. What makes this book exceptional is what people think, not what they do. Lauren, not surprisingly, has the roughest time of it, unable to drop her vigilance and expectation of command (she was an NCO) as she returns to civilian life. For her, entering the military was an economic, not an ideological, decision and she questions what exactly it was she fought for. In her old church, she redefines the faith in which she was raised:The stained glass windows were dimly lit and she looked at them pane by pane; the long slow journey of Jesus, dragging his cross from window to window, until the Roman soldiers crucified him. It was a storyboard, she thought, like the kind you have to make and go over with your CO when you get back from a capture or kill. The stations of the cross were so everyone had their story straight, created agreement and uniformity in reporting the event. [...] Insurgent Jesus. [...] The stations of the cross made sense now, one more common war story hiding in plain sight.The characters around Lauren struggle with their own displacements. Her high school boyfriend has moved on to college and resents reminders of his working class origins. Her best friend’s early motherhood has limited her to minimum-wage jobs despite her outstanding high school record. There are “the Patricks” three brilliant, but failed men and a choir director who lost a promising career to alcoholism. All of these characters are drawn with a detail and honesty that makes them simultaneously sympathetic and irritating.If I were to call any book I’ve read this year a “must read,” it would be this one. The examination of the price paid by those who go to war on our behalf and of the compromises made necessary by poverty is rich—as is the prose in which it is presented.

The Train to Warsaw is an interesting work in both content and style. Jascha and Lilka, Jewish lovers who met in the Warsaw ghetto, escaped separately, and reunited in London years later are the passengers on this train. Jascha has become a famous writer and is invited to Poland to give a reading. He has no desire to return to the country that nearly killed him—and did kill so many. Lilka, with fond memories of prewar Warsaw, wants to return “home” and convinces him to accept the invitation. Of course, the home she remembers ceased to exist years ago.The plot of this novel is predictable: Jascha and Lilka remember the horrors of the past, and on their journey both reveal parts of their stories to they’ve hidden from one another for more than forty years. But the fact that the reader can predict the overall arc of the novel, doesn’t make it any less engaging.
