But you'll hear the boys laughing at each other and at their mom, and even you'll hear her laughing at them (demonstrating where they learned their distinct laughter cadence).  It's a chuckling hour well spent, one that I can happily recommend to others, with appropriate expectations...

Having listened to the audiobook version of Levitt and Dubner's "Freakonomics" and thoroughly enjoying it, I was curious to find out how the sequel would compare. In my estimation, "SuperFreakonomics" was even better, an utterly fascinating journey through the most random of topics that kept my rapt attention during many hours of boring driving.Levitt and Dubner stuck to their formula of poking holes in conventional wisdom from every conceivable angle, all ostensibly from the vantage point of economics, but in an accessible style that requires no economics background.  The basic premise of the book is that rewards drive human behavior, and the authors loosely use that idea to frame their analysis of various topics, including prostitution, terrorists, the bystander effect, child seats in cars, hospital safety, global warming, and a host of other seemingly unrelated issues.  I don't have a natural interest in any of this stuff, but herein lies the genius of Levitt and Dubner.  They make it all utterly captivating.  From chapter to chapter, I couldn't get enough of it.To be clear, I'm not planning to utterly reorganize my life around the conclusions of "SuperFreakonomics."  We'll still have our children in car seats when we're in the car, even if they are virtually useless.  But I love what the authors do throughout this book, asking great questions about any conceivable category of the human experience, making insightful observations, analyzing relevant data, and making compelling arguments for nontraditional solutions.  I like the way they think, I like the way they write, and I hope that they keep producing books like this.  If they do, I'll keep reading and pondering and chuckling and rethinking some of the ways I naturally think about a great many things.  It's challenging, fun, and fascinating to hear from these guys, an experience which I'm happy to recommend to anyone.

I recently taught a Christian apologetics course for a private Christian high school, and I took the risk of using this book as our primary textbook, even though I had never read it.  But I read enough positive reviews and was sufficiently impressed with Greg Boyd's other books which I'd previously read that I decided to go for it.  And I couldn't have been more pleased with the choice.  It turned out to be even more compelling and helpful than I had imagined.To be clear, Boyd comes from a particular Arminian/Wesleyan theological position (more formalized as open theism in his more recent publications) that drives staunch Reformed/Calvinists absolutely batty (as evidenced by the one-star reviews of this book).  Hyper-Calvinists take note, as you will surely hate this book as a heretical abomination.  But, for those of us who are trying to figure out how free will and real choice and meaningful human agency fit within the big picture of God's will and sovereignty and power, then this book can offer at least a set of cogent and consistent responses to the most pressing questions that both Christians and skeptics ask.  My own Wesleyan theological proclivities allow me to more readily embrace some of Boyd's thoughts in this book than my Reformed friends would, but I would suggest that a lack of complete or even significant resonance with Boyd's theology doesn't mean that this book wouldn't be valuable.  In fact, I think some Calvinists would do well to wrestle with some of Boyd's concise but profound ideas in this book.Theological tensions aside, as much as I personally appreciated and agreed with many of the fabulously clear summaries that Boyd offered to seemingly unanswerable questions, I thought that the main strength of the book was not so much the theology but the tone and attitude of the interactions between father and son.  What a charming and challenging premise, a skeptical and agnostic old man (Papa Ed) firing away at his pastor son with a series of the most vexing theological questions, batting these incomprehensibly huge topics back and forth over the course of 30+ letters.  I absolutely loved the father's brutal honesty, and in this context, wasn't bothered by his occasionally profane rants, as they reflected the authenticity of his positions and the earnestness with which he pondered these hard issues.  But I was absolutely captivated by the way that the young pastor (Sonny Greg) engaged with his dad, never angry, never frustrated, never pushy, never arrogant, never dismissive, never frantic.  Instead, Greg's posture was unflinchingly gracious, patient, humble, kind, loving, and winsome, all the while being perfectly direct and crystal clear that he was fully confident that his dad was on the pathway to faith in Christ.  Yet, that confidence was not based on the exhaustiveness of his own brilliant answers but more so dependent on the ongoing work of the Holy Spirit to continue to draw this grumpy old man into the loving arms of his heavenly Father.  Oh, what a beautiful picture of what it looks like to be part of God's work in pursuing those who don't yet know Him!!  And, to use admittedly flippant language for a gloriously complex journey, it worked.  By the end of their correspondence, Ed received the gift of salvation in Christ and became an adopted son of God (and, as we might expect, a dramatically changed man).I would recommend this book to absolutely anyone.  Skeptics, cynics, and indifferent Christians would do well to ponder the marvelous answers that Greg offers to seemingly impossible questions.  He handles these hot topics with not only theological rigor but also appropriate simplicity (such that high school students were certainly challenged but could absolutely follow the discussion).  For Christians who want to know how to talk about Jesus with people who have real issues with Christianity, this book is an excellent model for all of us to consider and follow.  Of course, the particulars of our own evangelism will likely not involve a series of letters exchanged with our fathers, but there remains much that we can learn from this book.  And even as I learned how to share about Christ more effectively, my own faith was strengthened and solidified.  This is one of the best books I've read in years, and I expect that I'll return to it again and again.

I recently taught a one-semester Christian apologetics course at a private Christian high school, and this 12-part DVD series was handed to me as our primary curriculum.  In short, with high expectations based on Ravi Zacharias' name and ministry affiliation, I was very underwhelmed.  Unfortunately, the quality of the 12 lectures was highly erratic, varying from solid to downright boring.  The production values were rather amateurish, with the twelve lectures recorded in a small, rather dismal room somewhere in a forgotten corner of the Oxford campus.  The cutaways to audience members were often awkward and unnecessary.  The graphic overlays of the Powerpoint presentations were archaic, screaming 1980s technology even though this thing was apparently produced in 2011.  There were even a few typos.But, most significantly, I just thought that much of the content was just plain stale.  A few of the presentations actually offered substantive, interesting, engaging, compelling content (Michael Ramsden and Amy Orr-Ewing immediately come to mind), but, in general, it just fell flat, for me personally and for the students in my class.  Even the stuff from the big names like Alister McGrath and Ravi Zacharias himself was ultimately blase.  To be clear, I greatly respect McGrath and Zacharias and have thoroughly enjoyed their stuff that I've previously encountered.  This just felt like a rather pedestrian and uninspired contribution from these great minds.In nearly twelve hours of apologetics content, some helpful ground is surely covered.  But this compilation is decidedly less effective than it could have been and just didn't seem to warrant its gargantuan investment of time and expense.  I wouldn't necessarily dissuade apologetics enthusiasts from using this material, but I am unable to recommend it as a means to draw out enthusiasm or provide deeply substantive and impacting content for the skeptic, cynic, or dispassionate believer.  For whatever it's worth, though a completely different medium, I found Greg Boyd's book "Letters from a Skeptic" to be the most interesting, compelling, and meaningful apologetics resource I've ever encountered, and I cannot recommend Boyd's contribution to the field highly enough.

It's hard for me to fully explain how much I dislike this book.  Having agonizingly worked through all 365 Bible stories with our 4-year-old daughter (who immediately became enamored with the daily number count), I felt such unfettered relief and joy at being able to permanently banish this mess into the rubbish heap.  It's all so badly done.To start, the quality of the cover and paper is poor, so our copy is beaten to smithereens having read through it only once.  The illustrations are few and far between, tiny, and bland (by modern children's literature standards).  The two questions at the end of each day's reading were usually so vague and abstract as to be virtually worthless.But all of these criticisms are insignificant in light of the big one, that this book was just not written with even the vaguest notion of how children learn and think.  Quality children's literature is a unique form of writing that understands the distinctions between simple and simplistic, between honest and inappropriate.  I can't explain this art form very well, and I absolutely couldn't do it myself.  But I know a story well-told for children.  And this just isn't it.  It may be targeted and marketed for children, but these stories were not written for children.One glaring example of this is the story of Jael and Sisera, but this specific case is indicative of the entirety of the book.  The actual sentence on page 80 is this: "Then Jael drove a tent peg into Sisera's head and killed him."  Yes, this is a book, as the back book jacket says, "written specifically for ages three to eight."  What three-year-old in the universe is able to process someone driving a tent peg into someone else's head and killing them when described so directly and dispassionately?  Of course, the argument in defense of this sentence is that the story is part of the Bible.  That's all well and good, and if anyone thinks that the entire Bible is appropriate for children to understand, then go ahead and just read the Bible to them.  I, on the other hand, think that God's revelation through Scripture, though all of it inspired and useful and necessary, is not entirely appropriate for any person of any age or any level of spiritual or physical maturity.  That's the potential power and beauty of children's Bibles, when thoughtfully and skillfully assembled, to help introduce children to the majesty and wonder of God's Word, through judicious, careful and creative excerpting and paraphrasing.I realize that this review may seem harsh, but I think that the Bible and our children deserve better than this book offers.  Obviously, many other reviewers disagree with me.  If you are looking for nothing more than 365 short, simplistic blurbs that summarize various stories from the Bible, this will do the trick.  But we are blessed to live in an age when there are countless better alternatives that help the Scriptures to come alive for children, visually and verbally, so I would highly recommend that interested folks look elsewhere.  "The Jesus Storybook Bible" is the best one we've discovered so far, which isn't merely a fragmented collection of random Bible stories but a cohesive and brilliantly written journey through the main theme of the Bible, explaining God and humanity and sin and grace and salvation in terms that children can understand and embrace enthusiastically.  In comparison, this book falls infinitely short.

Thousands of reviews have now been written about "Freakonomics," and many of my own thoughts resonate with both the acclaim and criticisms since its release almost ten years ago.  I agree that Levitt and Dubner turn a rather remarkable feat, taking the most random and seemingly irrelevant topics and regaling the reader with statistics and anecdotes to yield their counter-intuitive conclusion about the particular topic at hand.  From cheating teachers and sumo wrestlers to poor crack dealers and unethical realtors, the authors managed to keep me thoroughly intrigued, even if I didn't necessarily know where they were trying to go.  I'm not even remotely an economist, so it certainly wasn't clear to me how this book was necessarily a work of economics.  But as a non-economist, I am willing to embrace Levitt and Dubner's most generic of definitions, that economics is fundamentally a study of how incentives drive human behavior, a sufficiently sturdy point from which to launch into their fascinating analysis of whatever strikes their fancy.To be sure, some of their conclusions are quite provocative and controversial.  Of particular note is the suggestion that, rather than the host of alternative theories that have been offered over the past two decades, the steep drop in crime rates in 1990s America can be attributed to the legalization of abortion in the 1970s in the post-Roe v. Wade era.  I vaguely remembered hearing this theory before, but absorbing the idea as presented in such a direct and emotionless manner was shocking to this pro-life advocate.  However, the authors are not guilty of politicizing their analysis, making sure to avoid any pronouncements about the moral implications of this historical event.  They merely look at the numbers and draw some striking conclusions.  Their methodology is consistent and utterly fascinating, no matter how much I might disagree or even just want to disagree.Having recently worked my way through most of Malcolm Gladwell's books, I found myself comparing "Freakonomics" to his "The Tipping Point," "Blink," and "Outliers."  These authors seems to be attempting the same things, compiling extensive academic research (primarily economics for Levitt/Dubner, primarily psychology/sociology for Gladwell) to draw interesting, practical, and surprising conclusions about everyday life.  And I find that I love this developing genre of literature.  But I would add that I think Gladwell does it a bit better.  He's a superior storyteller and manages to make his presumed points of application more compelling to the reader.  Of course, he also appears to have a slightly more well-designed purpose than they do, so maybe it's a matter that my preferences align more closely with that purpose than the admittedly random and meandering approach of Levitt and Dubner.  In any case, if you like Gladwell's stuff, I suspect that you'd appreciate "Freakonomics," too, and may especially enjoy the points when their statistical analysis yields directly contradictory results (such as their public disputes about their respective opinions about crime rate drops).And as another particular note, I listened to the revised and expanded audiobook format of "Freakonomics," read by Stephen Dubner, one of the authors.  I thought he did a great job as an audiobook reader, not true of all authors, though I'm pretty sure he actually mispronounced a few words, .  And I appreciated some of the additional elements of the revised edition, including their very humble acknowledgement that they were at least partially hoodwinked by the featured participant in their analysis of the Ku Klux Klan.In conclusion, "Freakonomics" is a great, if imperfect, book, a captivating journey through a most random collection of topics.  The final chapter about names was an anomaly, decidedly less interesting than the rest.  And I'm not sure that the other chapters have necessarily informed my thinking in any substantive way.  But I spent many hours in the car listening to my very first entry into the world of popular economics, and it was hours well spent.  As they consistently turned conventional wisdom on its ugly head, I was surprised and even shocked, intrigued and even inspired, bothered but never bored.  And I look forward to seeing how else Levitt and Dubner can mess with my mind in their other books...

I was never a weekly listener, but I always enjoyed listening to CarTalk whenever I was in the car at the appropriate time, and I've even read their newspaper column over the years, even though I have absolutely no interest in cars or engines or anything remotely related to the topic of their show and column.  But Tom and Ray have such an endearing and captivating rapport with each other and their listeners that I never tired of hearing them talk about things that mean nothing to me.  That's a sure sign of true radio charismatic genius.In looking for some quality audiobookishness for a heavy dose of road tripping, I was delighted to stumble upon this collection of the best of CarTalk at the local library.  And I made quick work of these two discs over the course of a two-hour trip.  To be sure, I found myself chuckling along with these guys are various points, as I always do.  Their laughter is simply infectious, and as they enjoy their own silliness and the silliness of the callers, it's only natural to relish in the absurdity of it all.But therein lies my primary critique of this collection; it was a collection of the silliest and most absurd of their calls over the years, which are more fun in smaller and less frequent doses.  What I missed in the "Best of" discs were the more standard, simple questions that normal people have about their cars, and the ingenious and goofy way that Click and Clack are able to answer those questions.  The ebb and flow of a typical CarTalk show is part of the charm, from questions I might actually ask to puzzlers and bizarro situations that could never happen twice.  Unfortunately, this collection misses that rhythm, focusing only on the freakish calls.So, I enjoyed listening to the "Best of" collection of CarTalk, and I laughed with these guys as I always do.  But, frankly, I'm just as inclined to listen to a typical episode of the show as I am to this collection.  If you need a dose of CarTalk, this will do just fine, but you're just as fortunate to stumble upon a regular show on the radio.  It's a shame that they've retired from their show, but I'm glad that their legacy of lunacy lives on for all of us to enjoy.  Now don't write Amazon reviews like my brother!!

I've heard people reference Malcolm Gladwell's work approximately eighteen billion times over the past ten years, but other than a few articles he'd written for ESPN's Grantland, I've never actually read his stuff before listening to the abridged audiobook version, read by Gladwell himself.  And I would say that the book held up reasonably well to my rather high expectations.In general, Gladwell makes the seemingly obvious assertion that virtually every aspect of human life (infectious human behavior, booming businesses, pop culture fads, fashion trends, etc.) has the ability to explode on the scene out of nowhere, which he calls reaching the "tipping point." He attempts to offer a series of explanations for what factors cause a particular thing to tip.  Though some reviewers passionately dispute the scientific veracity of Gladwell's analysis, I'm not qualified or especially concerned about whether each and every one of his points is experimentally airtight.  I'm more interested in the experience of pondering his main conclusions and figuring out the widespread implications if he's right about any of it.My initial impression of the book is that Gladwell is a master storyteller.  I'm not a businessman or a marketer or a salesman, and I don't give two hoots about big business practices.  But like Jim Collins in several of his best-selling books, Gladwell is able to tell the success stories of companies like Hush Puppies, Airwalk, and Gore in such a compelling way as to intrigue an uninterested ignoramus like me.  Similarly, like Daniel Pink in several of his best-selling books, Gladwell is also able to analyze and describe sociological and psychological phenomena like crime rates, mass school shootings, "Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon," and many other seemingly random historical events and relational realities of modern American life in ways that make sense to non-academicians.  It is a true gift to be able to distill and organize literally dozens of anecdotal incidents and scientific studies into a book that not only makes sense but is actually quite compelling.  Gladwell has quite a gift in this regard.My primary critique of the book relates to its ultimate purpose or lack thereof.  Gladwell covers a lot of ground and introduces a lot of terms (connectors, mavens, immunity) and concepts (the law of the few, the stickiness factor, the power of context), but it's not always easy to connect the dots.  On some level, I wonder if Gladwell blazed such a broad trail that some readers may be unable to actually process and apply the concepts in any meaningful way.  Ultimately, I'm just not sure what I'm supposed to do with all of this fascinating information.  Of course, Gladwell doesn't seem to be terribly concerned about answering this question.  According to the afterword, he directly states that he's perfectly willing to allow folks to use his compiled information and insights for whatever purposes they might desire, to start their own "epidemics" of whatever nature.  I suppose that broad applicability is what makes the book so wildly popular because we all feel capable of dialing into these reasonable and logical ideas for our own desired outcomes.  But, at least on some level, my concluding thought was, "Huh, that was interesting, but what in the world can I do with it?"To be sure, I'm glad that I read the book.  It offered a lot of things to keep pondering, as I wonder if my personality might allow me to thrive in the role of a "maven" and considering if I could implement this concept of the tipping point to initiate some sort of epidemic around the things that matter most to me.  I have no clarity about what they could be, but I'm intrigued to keep thinking and processing.  I'm happy to recommend this books to any big idea thinkers, and I suspect that I'll be digging more into Gladwell's other books within the relatively near future.Audiobook note:  I didn't realize when I borrowed the audiobook from the library that this was an abridged version, and whenever I listen to abridged audiobooks, I'm always curious about what parts of the whole book I missed.  There was even some discussion in the afterword that specifically mentioned a case-study that I hadn't heard because it was obviously excluded from this version.  I have no idea if the book in its entirety would have been just more of the same or if it would have helped to provide some better connections between the points and helped to clarify the "so what" that I thought was not intuitively clear to me.  Who knows, I may decide at some point to read the whole book to try to fill in some of those gaps?I also found Gladwell's unique voice and cadence as the reader to be both soothing and at times disengaging (i.e. sleep-inducing).  But it always feels more authentic to listen to audiobooks when read by the author, not some random hired hand, so I'm glad that it was his voice reading to me.

I've read Klosterman's work for ESPN's Grantland and heard him speak a few months ago, so I was curious to stumble upon his "I Wear the Black Hat," intrigued to see what his book-length treatment on a topic as fascinating as villainy might be like.  And it was one of the weirdest books I've ever read.Klosterman offers an opening thesis, that villains are the people who know the most but care the least, and spends 200 pages telling stories and anecdotes of varying interest, both personal and very public, to presumably connect to that thesis in some way.  My primary critique of the book is that those connections were stretched, at best, and impossible to find, at worst.  I often found myself thinking or even muttering aloud, "What in the world is he trying to say?"  If ever there was a book that was nonlinear and nondidactic, this is it.  Though peppering very strong opinions throughout about fundamentally trivial things, Klosterman doesn't preach from a high horse of self-righteous superiority, as writers about ethics and evil are easily inclined to do.  But he also doesn't seem to have a point.  That left me rather baffled and even irritated at times.  To top it off, Klosterman is consistently and unnecessarily profane.  I find the use of profanity for shock effect, the only possible explanation for such a thoughtful and capable writer to use such language, to be lazy writing, much below Klosterman's considerable intellectual and linguistic abilities.On the other side of the coin, Klosterman's breadth of knowledge and insight is impressive.  He is conversant in a range of categories from pop culture, music (from The Eagles to N.W.A.), and sports (from Muhammad Ali to Kareem Abdul-Jabbar) to major and minor historical figures (from Adolf Hitler to Bill Clinton).  His perspective is interesting if not always coherent.  And I especially appreciated the chapters about the O.J. Simpson saga, long-forgotten for many of us, and about D.B. Cooper, a minor historical figure that was completely unfamiliar to me but whose story is utterly fascinating.  Though Klosterman fancies himself a funny writer, his humor most often elicited a wry smile, though a few chuckles did emerge.Ultimately, I don't know what to think about this book.  It was easy to read, and I genuinely didn't want to put it down.  But I'm also not sure what purpose it serves.  I think Klosterman hopes to speak on a deeper level than mere entertainment, but his lackadaisical style and directionless approach didn't help me understand villainy in any profoundly new way.  Even so, it was an interesting book to read, and I suspect when I'm looking for an engaging and readable book of contrarian randomness, I might just find my way to another one of Klosterman's books.  With appropriate expectations, he definitely offers something different and possibly important to the literary world.  I'm just still trying to figure out what it is...

In the midst of an unexpected job loss, I read through this book with a colleague who was in a similar situation.  And, in general, I found the content to be moderately helpful but not sufficiently thorough.  The first half of the book addresses the theological idea of calling and its implications related to vocation/jobs/career.  This was the more helpful part of the book, as I think that Creel addressed a number of important, if sometimes lofty and even idealistic, aspects of pursuing a calling from God as we consider what sort of work He intends for us to discover and employ.  Though there was nothing earth-shattering or especially profound, he covered some important ground, which fostered some great discussion and reflection.  I would happily encourage anyone who is interested in the notion that God might call us to particular work to read these chapters and discuss them further with thoughtful friends.The second half of the book is ultimately a "how to succeed in the workplace" guide.  This was the less helpful part of the book, as these chapters mostly felt like vastly underdeveloped descriptions of the vital workplace traits of endurance, character, integrity, frugality, mentoring, discipline, skill, humility, weighing your words, family, and boundaries and balance.  I certainly valued the topics, but these sorts of things cannot be adequately unpacked in the course of just a few pages.  Frankly, I feel as if I had read all of this content elsewhere, in much more compelling and engaging ways.My final critique of the book is my disappointment with the "Seasoned Advice" that followed each chapter.  These words of wisdom from various "experts" felt especially trite at times and often very disconnected from the chapter which preceded it and upon which it was supposed to expound or clarify.  It even seemed a few times as if the seasoned advisers were indirectly contradicting what the author had just written.  Frankly, I thought that these segments added very little to the book and could have been excluded to allow the author to cover his intended content more comprehensively.To be sure, much of my disappointment with the book may be the simple fact that I am a decade or more older than its primary audience.  Twenty-something college graduates may find this book much more helpful than I did, and I certainly think it has much to offer any reader pondering these issues of calling and vocation.  But I would have preferred if the author had tried to cover fewer topics and instead pressed into some of the nuance and finer details of the most important ideas which he had to offer.  This book certainly isn't a total loss, but I'll keep looking for something to more thoroughly address some of the big picture questions that are relevant to my own situation as I look towards the next chapter of ministry to which God is calling me.

I read the entire Sherlock Holmes canon when I was a teenager and absolutely loved it, but after a 15+ year hiatus, I decided to return to Holmes during a recent beach vacation, diving into the iconic "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes."  What a great decision!!I was amazed that several of the stories, characters, and specific case details were very familiar to me.  Of particular note, I remembered "The Red-Headed League" and "The Adventure of the Speckled Band" as if I had read them last week.  Some of the other stories were seemingly completely new to me.  In either case, the experience of reading these short stories was so much fun.  To be sure, there is a delightful simplicity to these stories which did not yield the same intellectual wonderment that I experienced as a kid.  But the narrative creativity, snappy dialogue, and vivid imagery made each story its own small-scale page-turner.In some cases, I had a good suspicion of the resolution of the case.  In others, I had no idea what was to come.  But all the way through, Doyle's writing style is engaging and accessible, even with all of its 19th-century British vocabulary and the various London geographic markers which mean absolutely nothing to me.  It's a credit to his genius that Doyle created these characters that are truly ageless, in the sense that these stories can be read and appreciated in any age (at least from the 19th-century through the 21st-century) and by any age (at least from a teenager through my present age of 36).I've hardly read any fiction over the past many years, but my brief foray back into the world of Sherlock Holmes has motivated me to read through the rest of the Holmesian tales, novels and short stories.  I might even check out some of the recent television representations of the Holmes character to see how well this amazing mind and personality translate to the screen.  In any case, I'm grateful for rediscovering this gem of literary history.

As an American evangelical Christian, I have been raised to view missions work as glorious, glamorous, and almost always successful, based on the missions stories that we (rightly) celebrate and share in our church communities.  Endo's "Silence" offers an uncomfortably different view on one of the possible outcomes of global missions work, in which the missionary arrives with grandiose ideas about what (or who) he is bringing to a needy people but who is ultimately rejected, tormented, and converted to some fundamentally new forms of spiritual understanding.Of course, the response to Endo's work is understandably widely varied and even controversial.  Some might interpret the journey and ultimate destination of Endo's Father Rodrigues as a tragic trajectory toward generic syncretism.  Others might interpret his departure from his initial assumptions about Christ and faith as a triumphal arrival at tolerant pluralistic spirituality.  I would argue for some sort of middle ground, that there is a tragic aspect to the disillusionment and reorientation that Rodrigues experiences but also a necessary and helpful distancing from some of the ethnocentrism and smug cultural superiority that can easily accompany the best of missionary intentions.To be sure, what makes this uncomfortable journey through "Silence" worthwhile is not just the end result but the entire emotional experience of walking this journey with Father Rodrigues.  From his optimistic beginning to his downtrodden end, the story is gripping and fascinating.  The characters are well-developed, the imagery is evocative, and the themes are necessarily complex and nuanced.Though I think that Endo was overly critical of the purpose and vision for Christian missions work, I consider this book to be well worth reading.  Anyone with a heart to share Christ with others would do well to consider many of the presumptuous and unintentionally arrogant assumptions that can easily accompany the very best of intentions.  Though I am deeply and firmly committed to the need of all people for Jesus, there is much nuance required when we consider introducing Jesus from one culture to another.  "Silence" is an agonizingly helpful tool to consider the complexity of that task and some of the inherent challenges when cultures and religions collide and cross-pollinate.  My appreciation for that complexity was expanded by reading this book, a journey I'd highly recommend to others.

I have appreciated Richard Foster's books in the past.  "Celebration of Discipline" is a genuine classic, and "Streams of Living Water" is one of the most fascinating and illuminating books on church history that I've had the privilege to read.  So, I began listening to the abridged audiobook version of his "Longing for God" with relatively high expectations, only some of which were met.The primary strength of "Longing for God" is its broad approach to combing through church history to uncover or at least rediscover literally dozens of saints throughout the ages who have approached their pursuit of God with different perspectives and orientations.  In fact, this non-sectarian, theologically-gracious approach to not just discussing those who fall within one particular stream of theological thought is what made "Streams of Living Water" such a fabulous book.  And in "Longing for God," Foster against manages to find so many nuggets of wisdom and Scriptural insight from church fathers, both famous and obscure.  As someone who appreciates the value of church history, I find these sorts of journeys to be utterly fascinating and extremely helpful.  We are so often smitten with the largest craze or hottest fad in the church, but there is truly nothing new under the sun, and Foster helps us to engage with the work of the Holy Spirit throughout the ages.However, in contrast to the six clearly defined and easily understood paths that Foster describes in "Streams of Living Water," I never got a clear sense of what differentiated the "seven paths of Christian devotion" into which Foster organized the vignettes within "Longing for God."  Quite simply, the seven paths all rather mushed together in my mind as I was listening to the book, and I couldn't recite even one of them without looking at the back of the book.  The implication of this muddled approach is that I ended up experiencing the book much like a series of encyclopedia entries.  Yes, Foster included some fascinating historical insights, but they didn't personally connect with my heart or mind in any substantive way.  I can't help but wonder if some of this effect might result from listening to an abridged audiobook version, but nonetheless, this was my experience.In short, "Longing for God" includes some great information, but it's a far cry from much of his other more inspirational and captivating work.  Rather than recommending folks to investigate this one, I'd instead point any prospective reader to his "Streams of Living Water," to which I hope to eventually return to dig from its deep well of insight and perspective.

I'm a pastor, not a businessman, so I read business/leadership books like those by Daniel Park from a different vantage point than many.  I don't pretend to have any experience in the marketplace and certainly have no business acumen.  But I have benefited greatly from reading books by folks like Jim Collins, Patrick Lencioni, and, more recently, Daniel Pink, who offer big-picture ideas that have applications across all of the human experience, not limited specifically to the business community.I read Pink's "Drive" a few years ago, and it provided such clarity and challenged several of my assumptions about what motivates human action, which has plenty of applications not just within church ministry but also in education, parenting, and many other arenas of leadership.  Though I haven't embraced every idea from "Drive" as some sort of pure truth, it has substantially influenced my thinking for the past several years.I began reading Pink's "To Sell is Human" with comparable expectations, which were augmented when I recently heard him speak at a technology conference for educators where I was again favorably impressed by his approach.  And, to be sure, "To Sell is Human" offers a very compelling case that we are all in sales, in one way or another, as long as we are willing to broaden the definition of sales as Pink does to mean "moving others" to a particular action.  From that perspective, my job as a pastor is some level of salesmanship.Unfortunately, "To Sell is Human" disappoints on the level of focus and clarity.  In fact, one of the chapters in the book was about clarity, but I think that Pink failed to follow his own advice in this regard.  In contrast to "Drive," which offered one big idea with three primary bullet points, "To Sell is Human" offers a collection of big ideas, each with their own bullet points and sub-ideas.  At the end of the book, I was a bit lost amidst all of the chatter.There is no question that Pink is an outstanding writer.  His prose is engaging, his stories are relevant, and his ideas are insightful and challenging.  But I think he failed somewhat in this book to take the reader on a clear and direct journey from beginning to end.  Instead, I think he did more meandering than what I would prefer.  Having finished the book just a few weeks ago, I can't say that I remember any particular point or idea with any level of specificity.  It is for this reason that I am unable to more highly rate what was otherwise a pleasant and accessible book to read.I continue to like Pink's style and content, and I suspect that I'll read more of his books in the future.  But at least for general readers like me, I hope to rediscover the simplicity and focus that so captivated me in "Drive," rather than the vast and semi-directionless musings that I encountered in "To Sell is Human."

While teaching through the "I Am" statements of Jesus from the gospel of John, I was thrilled to stumble upon Warren Wiersbe's "Jesus in the Present Tense," which promised to cover the very same ground I hoped to use in our teaching series.  Having heard Wiersbe's name for years, I was glad to finally read one of his books, and I expected that it would be most helpful.Unfortunately, I was largely disappointed by "Jesus in the Presence Tense."  It's not that I disagreed with much, or even anything, that Wiersbe wrote in the book.  To be sure, his writing is nothing if not biblical, with Scripture references generously peppering every paragraph.  And Wiersbe is clearly a preacher and Jesus-follower with much wisdom and insight to share.My disappointment is that the book seemed like little more than a randomly collected string of theologically true statements.  It didn't grab my heart.  It didn't challenge my mind.  It didn't motivate my actions.  It didn't offer anything substantially new or profound or unique.  It didn't take me anywhere.  And that's exactly why I am so captivated by great writing, because the best of books mess me up and inspire me and encourage me and embolden me to feel differently or think differently or do things differently.  This book had no such effect.The final evidence of the meandering and purposeless nature of this book was the final chapter, which hardly even mentioned the "I Am" statements of Christ.  It's as if Wiersbe had a bunch of stuff that he wanted to say, but not being able to force those thoughts into one of the preceding chapters, he just dumped them into a random, final chapter.  Quite simply, I expect more purpose and intentionality from such an esteemed author.In summary, for readers who are satisfied with a bunch of true statements, feel free to check out this book.  Wiersbe is no fool and no heretic, and he has many good points to make.  But having finished the book merely a few weeks ago, I truly can't remember a single thing that I read.  That's the sign of a book that lacks teeth, as far as I'm concerned.  I've not given up hope that some other entry in Wiersbe's voluminous catalog of books might be helpful to me, but this one certainly failed to satisfy, and I'm not able to recommend it.

I always appreciate N.T. Wright's writing, and this little 84-page booklet is no exception.  It's basically a compilation of nine messages that Wright preached in 2005 through Holy Week (with two on Maundy Thursday and two on Easter Sunday, hence a total of nine).  Rather than teaching through the most traditional Holy Week accounts in the gospels, Wright wades through several of Jesus' parables after the triumphal entry in Matthew 21, before redirecting three of the final lessons from various passages in the gospel of John.Frankly, it's an unexpected and somewhat circuitous journey through some atypical Easter passages, but Wright does a good job of drawing meaningful and fascinating connections to the events of Holy Week.  I wouldn't say that the book offered me any transformational or utterly captivating ideas, but it was a refreshing approach to consider the events of Holy Week from a new vantage point.  This certainly doesn't represent Wright's most earth-shattering work, but it serves a purpose of giving the reader something fresh to ponder in the midst of one of Christianity's most familiar (and, therefore, most susceptible to staleness) seasons.  I hope to revisit this little book over upcoming Easters and may even integrate some of Wright's teaching into my own preaching in the future.

I literally haven't read an autobiography in 15+ years, but for whatever reason, I decided to try Phil Vischer's "Me, Myself, and Bob" while on a beach vacation.  And I was positively astounded by how much I both enjoyed and appreciated the entire experience.  For the uninitiated, Vischer is the primary inspiration, brains, and brawn behind the inexplicable force of nature within 1990s evangelical Christianity that was (and still is, to a degree) VeggieTales.  I've only seen a handful of VeggieTales episodes in my life, but I have liked them and have thoroughly enjoyed the "Jonah" full-length movie several times. And my daughter absolutely adores the VeggieTales series, so I figured it might be fun to read about the history of VeggieTales' origins.What I discovered in Vischer's book was so much more than a history lesson, but was instead a fascinating and honest description, from the initial idea all the way through to the ultimate bankruptcy and apparent dissolution, of the VeggieTales company that Vischer had founded.  What a gripping and entertaining account it turned out to be!  As many of us know from those silly talking vegetables, Vischer is an extremely engaging storyteller, a gift not limited to singing asparagi.  And in the midst of an interesting tale, Vischer unpacked significant ethical and spiritual dilemmas in the context of an explosively growing company that got a little too big for its britches.  It was all packed with ample servings of humility, humor, candor, confession, intrigue, and inspiration.Of particular note was Vischer's obvious decision to not name names, except for the folks that he was praising and thanking.  There were several individuals whose actions really wounded Vischer personally and professionally, but he made the honorable decision to refer to them with only vague descriptors (the brilliant CEO, the marketing guru, etc.).  Clearly the heart of the story did not depend on us readers knowing the names of these individuals who were not well portrayed through Vischer's account, and I'm grateful and appreciative of his decision to allow them to remain anonymous, contrary to how most such "tell-all" books tend to operate.Finally, it is worth noting that there is great spiritual depth to Vischer's journey.  He experienced amazing highs as his company and his "Big Idea" gained phenomenal fame and tremendous financial rewards, followed by the crushing disappointment as the VeggieTales empire crumbled around his feet.  Thankfully, he chose to use the entire journey as an opportunity to learn about himself and to learn about God.  And we have the pleasure to go along that journey with him through this book, to learn with him and from him.  But, if VeggieTales has taught us anything, it's taught us that learning and fun need not be separated.  So, as deeply impacting as this book was for me, it was also simply a joy to read.  I'm happy to recommend it to anyone who isn't too proud to be willing to learn a few important lessons from a tomato...

I consider Gary Thomas' "Sacred Marriage" to be the finest, by far, of the several dozen marriage books that I've read, as I greatly appreciate that he offers a somewhat radical and deeply profound concept of marriage as a spiritual discipline through which God primarily desires to make us holy.  I am happy to recommend that book to anyone and everyone who is married, was married, will be married, might be getting married, or knows people who are married.  It's that good.And it is because of how deeply I appreciate "Sacred Marriage" that I withheld a five-star review from Thomas' follow-up, "The Joy of a Sacred Marriage."  This slimmed down, excerpted, soundbite-based edition of "Sacred Marriage" was specifically created and published to be a wedding gift, presumably the sort of thing that married couples could read together on their honeymoon or over the first several weeks or months of marriage.  And there's a lot of good stuff packed in there.  But, much to my disappointment, for the sake of creating a little "gift book" (and probably with the unspoken motivation of offering a marriage book short enough that more men might actually read it, a necessity that ought to shame my gender), the profundity of the original "Sacred Marriage" is sliced and diced and fragmented into almost unrecognizable form.  Yes, the main thesis of "Sacred Marriage" still permeates this gift book, and it surely includes some great stuff, but it's simply not as great as in its original form.So, if this excerpted, piecemealed booklet is the only way that a couple might engage with the main ideas of "Sacred Marriage," then go for it.  It would still be tremendously challenging and helpful.  But I'd much more emphatically recommend that folks just read "Sacred Marriage" instead, to dig into the significance of what Thomas has to offer.  Sure, beef jerky is still tasty, but wouldn't you rather enjoy a nice cut of filet mignon?

My wife read Shaunti Feldhahn's "For Women Only" several years ago and found it to be an utterly fascinating discussion of several of the main ways that men are fundamentally different from women, several of which surprised my wife greatly.  What followed was much discussion, as we analyzed the categories in which I mirrored Feldhahn's conclusions and the categories in which I defied the norms.  And I found those discussions to be sufficiently engaging that I decided to listen to the audiobook version of "For Women Only" a few years down the road, to hear the material for myself.Obviously, the book has struck a chord with readers in all directions, positive and negative.  Some describe how this book has finally helped them to understand men.  Others decry that it is filled with stereotypes and over-generalizations and doesn't do justice to the complexity and diversity of men.  And having now seen what the fuss is all about, I fully understand both perspectives.Yes, the book is full of stereotypes and over-generalizations, and I see them most obviously when Feldhahn is painting a picture of men that doesn't even remotely resemble me.  But stereotypes and generalizations exist because they are generally true, and I'm sufficiently self-aware to realize that I don't define the entirety of manhood.  If we're not able to speak in generalities about how most people in a particular group tend to often, usually act and think, then we can say nothing at all.What Feldhahn has offered is a thoroughly researched summary of some of the primary ways that men tend to think about several important categories like work, sex, play, and other such things.  Her research probably wouldn't qualify her for publication in a peer-reviewed journal, but she spoke with hundreds of men, which seems to qualify her to draw some conclusions.  Our job as readers is to sort through the generalizations to find the points of resonate and dissonance with the reality of our own experiences.To be sure, I didn't think the book was perfect.  Frankly, Feldhahn's reading voice was a bit too sing-songy for my taste in the audiobook format.  And I did think that she spoke unnecessarily dogmatically at times, when a little less absolutism and certainty might have served her well.  But I think she has done us all a great favor in starting a conversation that many of us were long overdue to have.  The divide between genders is unnecessarily wide, and Feldhahn has offered a useful tool to begin to establish a clearer understanding of how we men function, why we do what we say, and how our women might love us well.  For that, I'm certainly grateful, and I'm happy to recommend the book to those who are able to take some of the dogmatism with a grain of salt while welcoming the considerable insight that Feldhahn's research has to offer us.

I've used the StrengthsFinder assessment at a previous job and have always found it to be a helpful tool to understand my own strengths and those of my colleagues.  And I have always marveled at how well the assessment painted an accurate picture of me.  So, I was pleased when my new employer decided that our entire staff would utilize this "Strengths Based Leadership" book as a means for learning about our unique leadership strengths and how we might more effectively leverage them together as a cohesive unit.Though I had done it before, I took the assessment again, and four of the five strength themes were identical to the last time I had done it, further validating those original results.  It was great to reflect on those strength themes again, to consider how I've developed and leveraged them over the years and how I've sometimes allowed them to languish and atrophy at other times.  Like any personality test or assessment, StrengthsFinder ideas can be abused to box people into particular designations.  But, rightly used, it's a wonderful tool to discover who I am and who others are and how we might work together most effectively.  We had a fascinating discussion among our staff, as we calculated which strength themes were most common and which were not reflected at all amongst our team and what that might mean for the productivity of our team.The one primary idea which seemed to be new in this 2.0 version of the assessment was the delineation of four domains of leadership strength, four general categories into which each of the 34 strength themes were divided.  Each of those domains was further explained through the example of a highly successful leader whose StrengthThemes were strongly represented within each of the four domains.  I found this structure to be really helpful to provide some clarity and simplification, in contrast to simply stumbling around as I had before, trying to understand and thoughtfully organize the original and sometimes overwhelming list of 34 themes.  And this structure of four domains provide significant clarity to our staff conversation, as we considered the domains that were most prevalent and most absent from our team.The bulk of the book is actually a description of each of the 34 strength themes, and though this was organized around the premise of leading from those strengths, much of this material could be found in many of the other StrengthsFinder resources.  Ultimately, "Strengths Based Leadership" did not provide a significant quantity of new material beyond that which is available elsewhere.  But there was certainly some value in the new stuff presented here.  For those with an interest in applying the StrengthsFinder ideas within the specific context of leadership, the book is certainly helpful, if not earth-shattering.  But of particular value is the StrengthsFinder assessment itself.  For those who haven't taken it, I highly encourage it, through this particular book or another.  I'm glad to have the StrengthsFinder concept in my leadership vocabulary and plan to use it in whatever contexts I'm privileged to lead for the foreseeable future.

For reasons I can't even fully articulate or understand, I really can't tell you how much I want to dislike Donald Miller.  Maybe it's the sort of people who originally flocked to his books that put me off to his writing, good folks but just not my type.  Maybe it's the way that those people acted as if Miller had received a new burst of inspired Scripture to offer this generation.  Maybe it's the fact that "Blue Like Jazz" sounds like a ridiculously nonsensical title for a book.  For whatever reason, I want to dislike him.But, over the years, every time I've read his stuff or heard him speak, I'm forced to reckon with the fact that I really actually like Donald Miller.  I think I would like to be his friend.  Of course, I don't know if he would be my friend, since I don't smoke cigars or drink beer at apparently every possible opportunity like he and his friends do.  But I think he would be a great guy to know.  I think he would have a lot of stuff to say to me that would make me both irritated and intrigued, and ultimately, I think he would say stuff to me that I need to hear that nobody else would have the courage to say or even know how to say.And that's the beauty of Miller's "Blue Like Jazz," which I finally read over ten years after its publication.  Miller's writing style is simple and easy and comfortable.  He comes off as a rather normal guy, as opposed to the sort of superhuman demigods who seem to most often write Christian books.  But as normal as he is, he clearly loves Jesus and wants others to know that same love.  And as he tells the story of his life, interspersed by a fascinating set of supporting characters, I couldn't help but be inspired and challenged by much of what he wrote.To be clear, I'm not entirely on board with all of Miller's theological assumptions.  And I can't say that I align with many of his lifestyle decisions.  But I deeply appreciate his spirit and tone and writing style, through which God has clearly spoken to millions of people over the years.  So, less begrudgingly than before, I suspect that I'll continue to stumble upon Miller's other books, hoping that he'll continue to say what nobody else has the courage to say, and trust that God might want to use Miller's unique gifts to say some meaningful things to me.  (Ugh, I can't believe I've become a Donald Miller fan...)[As a quick point of clarification, I actually listened to the abridged audiobook version of "Blue Like Jazz," which was read by Miller himself.  And as a gifted storyteller, it's no surprise that he turned out to be a fabulous audiobook reader.  Though I wouldn't say this with many other authors, I may continue to try to engage with Miller's work through audiobooks, as his style and delivery seems uniquely well-aligned to that format.]

Having read and deeply appreciated Dallas Willard's "The Divine Conspiracy" over 12 years ago, I decided to dive into his "Knowing Christ Today" shortly after his death, hoping that I might be similarly intrigued and captivated by the depth and profundity of his writing.  And, to be sure, "Knowing Christ Today" is a deeply challenging and intellectually stimulating book to read.  To his credit, Willard acknowledges in the beginning that it will be difficult and slow to comprehend what he is trying to say in this book, and he certainly delivered on that promise.  And though there are some rewards for wading through this beast, it wasn't nearly what I had hoped it would be.In short, the purpose of the book is to demonstrate and ultimately prove (herein lying Willard's mistake, I think) that those who seek to know about Christ and know Christ can do so with confidence and certainty that their assessment of reality truly and accurately reflects the nature of true reality.  Of course, this sentence alone belies the tricky nature of the entire discussion, as we need to clearly define such complex terms as "know," "reality," and "truth."  In fact, Willard spends considerable time defining what it means to "know" something, as opposed to simply "believe" something or "profess" something or "commit" to something.  And in the midst of this discussion, I found his distinctions among these terms to be much less clear-cut than he fancied them to be.  And I especially found his conclusions to be lacking regarding the tragic flaw in "merely" believing or professing or committing to certain ideas, rather than truly, absolutely knowing these ultimate things, the only landing place which seemed to carry any value in Willard's mind.  Basically, I felt like the entire premise of the argument undervalued the biblical call for the followers of Jesus to certainly know but also to believe, profess, and commit.But I soldiered on, hoping that Willard would convince me that certain knowledge of all of the central ideas of the Christian faith was not only absolutely essential but utterly accessible for us.  And I was not convinced.  In fact, my primary and prevailing critique of the book is that the arguments posited by Willard were not nearly as air-tight as he supposed that they were.  Time and again, he would refer to a point that he had just made, suggesting that the point had been "proven" or "clearly established" or other such definitive terms.  And I found myself disagreeing that he had proven anything.  And, just to be clear, I can't be a more favorable audience for where he wanted to go.  I'm a lifelong Christian and long-time pastor, and I agree with all of the primary spiritual points that he was making.  I just didn't agree that he had successfully "proven" the points or that I now felt like I was able to claim absolute and certain knowledge of those ideas.In that light, I feel like the book was largely a failure for this reader.  Of particular curiosity, I found Chapter Seven, "Knowledge of Christ and Christian Pluralism," to be the absolute highlight of the book and, frankly, felt as if it were written by a different author.  The entire tone of the chapter, one of winsome humility, was in stark contrast to the rather unbending and even arrogant posture that emerged throughout the rest of the book.  Unfortunately, the dominant tone of the book returned for the concluding chapter, during which Willard essentially lambasted my pastoral ministry as a weak, deceitful facade because of my disinterest in speaking as if I have exclusive access to a full and certain knowledge of all of the central questions of life.  Because I am satisfied to simply profess things that I firmly believe to be true without claiming to know these things with absolute certainty, then I am merely an imposter and a disgrace of a pastor, in Willard's view.Ultimately, this book offered some challenging thoughts for me to consider.  But I found the overall tone of the book and the author's definition and conclusions about the nature of spiritual knowledge to be disappointing, unconvincing, and uncompelling.  I hope to continue to dig into some of Willard's other work, much of which I have appreciated, but "Knowing Christ Today" is not one that I'll widely recommend.

In his "Pure Pleasure," Gary Thomas has the courage to buck the conventional wisdom of so many churches and Christians by stating that pleasure is a good thing, a God thing, when rightly understood.  And in so doing, he provides an invaluable guide for any of us who might struggle under the oppressive sense that we should at least be wary and hesitant to pursue anything which we fully enjoy and probably ought to flatly turn away from any such pleasures.  Thomas suggests another way, a better way.Thankfully, this book is so much more than a Christian defense of the "if it feels good, do it" philosophy that governs much of contemporary American life.  Instead, Thomas delves deeply into the profound spiritual implications of how God created humanity to experience pleasure as part of His grand plan.  Thomas spends much time addressing the ways that pleasure can inappropriately become an idol that we pursue without restraint.  He doesn't avoid the necessary conversation about how this obsession with pleasure can lead to sin.  But he refuses to make the easy conclusion that the possibility of sin should warrant our avoidance of pleasure altogether.Instead, Thomas paints a compelling and exciting picture of human life as it was designed by God for us to experience, filled with the many pleasures that were specifically created for us to enjoy.  He paints that picture with a broad stroke, refusing to pigeon-hole a specific definition of what those pleasures should be.  He certainly describes those created pleasures in his own life through engaging stories, but he does the hard intellectual work of distinguishing his main conclusions from his own experiences, giving the reader the necessary freedom to fill in the blanks for their lives, for their unique pleasures.  And as Thomas always does, the book is filled with relevant verses of Scripture and fascinating quotes from Christian thinkers throughout the ages.There is no question that some will read this book as a license to sin.  But that is no fault of Thomas, as he goes to great lengths to provide caution and nuance and disclaimers to avoid that pitfall.  I am convinced that the thoughtful reader can embrace the main thesis and the particular implications of that thesis as an opportunity to pursue the life that God intends for us to live.  Even over the weeks since I began reading the book, there have been numerous occasions when I've experienced pleasure and specifically used the ideas from this book to reflect on the value (and, to be sure, the danger) of that pleasure.  I can say without hesitation that I have a newly inspired and informed commitment to receiving God's gift of pure pleasure in my life, and I strongly recommend this book as an opportunity for others to journey down that exciting, freeing, delight-filled pathway.

In his "The Way of the Lord," N.T. Wright writes with his characteristic style that is paradoxically not only intellectually profound but also fully accessible to the reader.  He uses the general idea of pilgrimage to the Holy Land as the context for taking the readers through a series of journeys, more theological and philosophical than physical.  In fact, I found this to be the greatest disappointment of the book.  Though Wright frames the book around the idea of a pilgrimage to the Holy Land, he very intentionally writes with readers in mind who are not actually traveling there.  And, in so doing, I found that it became unhelpfully vague and esoteric.  I bought this book in preparation for a trip to Israel, and I thought that Wright would help to provide some significant spiritual substance to the trip.  Though this substance was not entirely absent, his attempt to make the book inclusive to non-travelers made it less specific and applicable than I would have preferred.Having acknowledged my disappointment in the broad approach, the greatest asset of the book is Wright's ability to make a compelling case for the deep and profound spiritual significance of pilgrimage, of visiting holy places and sacred spaces.  Of course, the point is not that God's presence is affixed within or confined to particular earthly locations but that we have unique opportunities to learn about God and His work, to pray in new and powerful ways, and to ultimately grow in our relationship with God as an act of discipleship if we rightly understand what pilgrimage can and should be.  For this broad and important idea that framed the entirety of our trip, I am deeply grateful.  I read the entire book on the flight from Newark to Tel Aviv, and it was a great way to clarify what we were doing and seeing in our visit to the Holy Land.Ultimately, I would say that this book was less powerful and meaningful to me than the other works of Wright that I've previously read, given its unfortunately broad and sometimes generic approach.  But for those who might wonder whether traveling to Israel has any real value for the Christian or for those who have decided to make the trip but want to orient their intentions and goals rightly, I am happy to recommend this book as a helpful contribution to that conversation.

The "Holy Land Travel Diary" was one of several books we snagged before a recent trip to Israel, and it turned out to be a useful guide that, frankly, I wish we had utilized more extensively, as it's so tiny that we basically forgot that we had it for the first several days.  It includes a five-page summary of the history of Israel in the front and four pages of general travel information in the back.  The rest of the book consists of about 25 two-page entries related to various towns or sites around the Holy Land, including Capernaum, Nazareth, Megiddo, Caesarea, Jericho, Bethlehem, the Mount of Olives, the Wailing Wall, the Garden of Gethsemane, the Garden Tomb, and many others.  Each of those entries includes a few sentences of introductory information, the actual text of an entire passage of Scripture, several references to other Bible verses where the location is mentioned in Scripture, some blank lines for note-taking, and a color picture of that site.To be clear, this book is largely informational.  If you're looking for a devotional guide, Wallace's "Pilgrim's Progress" functions in that capacity.  But in terms of a simple, informative guide to some of the key sites in Israel, the "Holy Land Travel Diary" is a nice tool.  I have no idea why a Table of Contents is not included.  And I would have preferred a bit more content, rather than the blanks spaces, as I'm not sure why anyone would scribble a few notes in a hard-bound book like this.  And, of course, there are many sites and locations that could have been additionally included, as this book is far from comprehensive.  But it's small, thin, and light, which serves a weary Holy Land pilgrim well.  If we ever head back to Israel, I'm sure we'll toss this little book in our bag and try to use it for all it's worth.

Before heading on our first trip to Israel, I picked up a few books that I hoped would add some spiritual depth and Scriptural connections for the various sites that we would see, particularly because we were not going with a tour group with a guide who could make those connections for us.  When "Pilgrim's Progress" arrived in the mail, I was surprised by how small it was and was initially disappointed that it wasn't more substantive.  But, in the end, I came to appreciate what this book was and how it helped to serve us on the trip.Ultimately, "Pilgrim's Progress" is a collection of about 40 two-page devotionals on a host of different sites from all of Israel.  Each entry includes a recommendation to read an accompanying passage from the Bible, two pages worth of devotional thoughts from the authors, and a concluding prayer.  There is an understandable concentration of entries in Jerusalem (i.e. Mount of Olives, Via Dolorosa, Garden Tomb, Western Wall, etc.), but a number of other important locations (i.e. Masada, Caesarea, Megiddo, Capernaum, etc.) are also included.Because the devotionals were relatively short, I wouldn't say that they were especially profound.  But they certainly helped to ground us in understanding the spiritual relevance of whatever it was that we were observing.  And it was helpful to have a particular passage of Scripture pre-selected for us to read and consider.  Reading those Bible verses was sometimes the most helpful part of the book.  I found most of the prayers to be rather trite and even theologically thin, so we would often just pray on our own in a more personal way.  A final asset of this book is its compact size, which originally disappointed me.  Frankly, we didn't need to be hefting around a twenty-pound book in our bag as we trekked all over Israel, a fact that became increasingly evident as the trip and physical exertion continued throughout the trip.In summary, this book probably isn't going to radically transform anybody's life.  But it's a helpful supplement to the amazing sites that are all over the Holy Land, and if we ever return to Israel, I'm sure we'll tuck this little guide in our bag again.

Just what we need, right?  Another book about how we should read the Bible.  Please feel free to yawn with me.  Evangelicals certainly do love the Bible, yet it's so hard to understand and interpret, so it seems as if there are a few books released every year to help us figure out how to read the Bible "correctly."  What could Scott McKnight offer that hasn't already been said a million times before?Well, thankfully, McKnight's "The Blue Parakeet" offers much that I think many of us in the evangelical community need to hear.  First and foremost, he lays out a framework for understanding the Bible as story, rather than law book, a collection of blessings and promises, a puzzle to be solved, or any number of other ways that we can view the Bible.  Though I'm not sure that the descriptor of story captures the essence of the Bible entirely (I think that the Bible is too complex and God-sized to be so constrained to any one category or description), I appreciate McKnight's case that engaging with the Bible primarily as a story may be the best and most robust approach.Next, I commend McKnight for acknowledging, in clear and unapologetic terms, that each and every one of us picks and chooses what parts of the Bible we think are applicable for today and what parts were only relevant in another cultural or historical context.  Of course, some will dispute this notion on the grounds of respecting the entirety of Scripture, but McKnight calls their bluff, specifically and insightfully.  And he then proceeds to spend the rest of the book offering us a template for how we should do our picking and choosing in line with God's design and intentions, rather than operating under the common but false premise that we would simply never do such a thing.Finally, I appreciate McKnight's courage to dive into the murky waters of sorting out an appropriate understanding of women in church leadership.  He tackles this issue because it's one in which we need to answer the very real and very hard question of which Scriptures about women in leadership are applicable to us and which Scriptures about women in leadership were culturally and historically specific.  Or, more appropriately, McKnight walks us through the imprecise and uncomfortable process of engaging with the whole Bible as the story of God and how we might use that biblical lens to draw appropriate conclusions about how we might view gender and leadership in our day, in our culture, in our world, in our time.  I'm not ready to concede that I agree with all of McKnight's conclusions on this topic (or any other, for that matter), but his willingness to be specific and clear and definitive was most helpful and quite refreshing.To be sure, I didn't think the book was all that it might have been.  I thought a few of McKnight's points were slightly under-developed or strangely unclear.  And I felt like his tone was unnecessarily harsh as he described people who disagree with his methodology or conclusions.  But I'm very happy that I finally read this book, and I've already given copies to a few folks in my church who I hope will be challenged, as I was, to reconsider how we approach the great blessing of the Word of God and what we're supposed to do with it.  McKnight's contribution to the conversation is helpful, encouraging, and inspiring.  I'm grateful to add this book to my library and expect to return to it often.

In preparation for an upcoming trip to Israel, I snagged Donald Zeigler's "Israel," a primer in a series called Modern World Nations intended for middle school students.  And though the book was understandably simplistic and dry, this was to be expected for a textbook for teens.  Nonetheless, it was still quite helpful to me, an admitted ignoramus about Middle Eastern politics and history who needed some help understanding some basic facts before I find myself walking around that part of the world.Of particular value in this book was its rather comprehensive approach.  Though only scratching the surface, the author managed to cover a lot of ground, discussing the history and present status of religion, governance, geography, and economics in the fascinating nation of modern Israel.  And to his credit, I thought he did a remarkable job of remaining impartial and even-handed in his descriptions of the obvious tensions that exist between various religious and cultural communities that co-exist very contentiously in the Holy Land.  Of course, another reviewer thought otherwise, and any readers who have a firm commitment that one of the warring parties is the rightful owner of the land of Israel and should have priority and authority over the other will surely be disappointed that the author does not align with their allegiance.  But I commend Zeigler for dispassionately analyzing the reality of Middle East tensions without bowing to the twin dangers of either ignoring the situation altogether or making the book a stump-speech for one particular side.  I found his approach to be tempered and responsible.Of course, there is much more that could have been included.  I would have loved some more serious and thorough engagement with the religious undertones of the historical and present-day tensions.  I think some more maps would have been helpful.  And some further discussion of the more significant historical and sacred sites throughout Israel would have been interesting.  But I need to remember that I'm looking at the book as a prospective tourist, so my interests certainly vary from a middle school student.  Ultimately, I think that this book is a helpful guide for understanding what and who the nation of Israel is in the early part of the 21st-century, and I'm happy to recommend it to other folks like myself who are starting at ground zero and want to build a basic foundation of understanding.

Since I became a father a few years ago, I've read a handful of books for dads, including Dave Meurer's "Stark Raving Dad!"  Like others who write in this genre, Meurer attempts to offer a humorous take on the many serious and meaningful aspects of fatherhood.  And though Meurer thankfully avoids the crass and juvenile humor that seems to be prevalent among other comparable books, I did not find "Stark Raving Dad!" to be very funny, insightful, or helpful.  Most of the attempted jokes just fell flat to me.  The advice seemed overly simplistic.  And the stories were not especially endearing or compelling.To be sure, I cracked a few smiles, and a few of Meurer's reflections were warmly charming.  I have no doubt that Meurer is a good Christian man and a great father, and this book was certainly written with the best of intentions.  But I didn't find it to be sufficiently engaging in any way that would allow me to wholeheartedly endorse or recommend it.  The funniest and most inspiring books on fatherhood that I've read are Paul Reiser's "Babyhood" and "Familyhood," and I'd encourage readers to check out Reiser, who remains my favorite entry into the "sentimental fatherly humorist" category.

As a new pastor in campus ministry, Michael Gleason's "When God Walked on Campus" was given to me as a sweet gift from a dear friend, and I was excited to read this "brief history of evangelical awakenings at American colleges and universities," to help me to acclimate to the new mission field to which I've been called.  On one level, the book accomplishes its perceived purposes.  After briefly setting the stage, Gleason walks through four distinct, historical eras in American history when God breathed a fresh movement of His Spirit on numerous college campuses all across the country.  And each historical snapshot is followed by the written text of a contemporary preacher from that era who was somehow involved in the work of God during those respective revivals.  Gleason concludes the book with a synopsis of the governing principles that seemed to consistently run through all of four major campus awakenings.To be sure, Gleason's research seems rather comprehensive, as he lists example after example, all with appropriate citations, of the particular revivals that broke out during each era of spiritual awakening.  But this is where the book fell far short of my hopeful expectations.  Rather than telling stories and offering engaging anecdotes and corresponding reflections, the main text of the book really did feel like little more than an elaborate list of events.  "This happened here.  Then this happened there.  Then this happened here again."  Though I have every reason to expect that the content is accurate, and the sheer volume of examples is impressive and inspiring, the book failed to really grab my heart in any substantive way.  The amazing work of God throughout history which Gleason was considering in this book seemed ripe for leveraging the power of story, but instead fell rather flat as little more than a fancy list.  And, as a final kicker, the sermons that he included at the end of each chapter were not especially compelling to me.  They were certainly biblically faithful and theologically solid, but they didn't really seem to connect in obvious ways with the unique nature of campus revivals.  Ultimately, they almost felt like filler to me, rather than meaningful additions to the narrative.I suppose this review may seem unfairly harsh.  Ultimately, I'm glad that I read this book, as I now have a clearer and more specific sense of the work that God has done at American colleges over the past several centuries, as I pray towards that same work to happen on our campus and through our ministry.
