But the lack of accessibility and engagement makes it difficult for me to recommend this book to others.  For those who want some historical perspective, "When God Walked on Campus" offers that.  And the final chapter, in which Gleason summarizes the points of continuity throughout history and offers us principles and patterns of campus revival that we might pursue today, is certainly informative.  But for those, like me, who want to hear powerful and riveting stories of what God has done when He walked on campus, this simply isn't it.

I've known about this book for many years, but after transitioning into a new pastoral role in campus ministry and asking some seasoned campus ministers what books I should read, several of them suggested Robert Coleman's "The Master Plan of Evangelism."  So, I dug into this abridged second edition, and I'm certainly glad that I did.The strengths of the book are many.  It is very well-organized and easy to follow.  Coleman basically just looks at the evangelistic strategy of Jesus, breaks it down into eight steps (Selection, Association, Consecration, Impartation, Demonstration, Delegation, Supervision, and Reproduction), and explains how we should follow that example.  The ideas are clear and accessible.  The justification is thoroughly biblical.  And the implications are powerful.  If Jesus decided that investing wholeheartedly in a gang of twelve unpolished newbies was an adequate approach to spreading the gospel and the result was the historical growth of the church over the entire earth throughout the following centuries, then Coleman makes a compelling case that we don't need to invent a fancier model for our ministry to thrive.  I applaud the simplicity and power of this message and look forward to using this framework to shape my leadership for the coming years and decades.My disappointments with the book were few and secondary.  Yes, some of the language and general tone of the book is clearly from another era.  The KJV quotations are clunky.  The writing style is somewhat dry.  But the power and simplicity of Coleman's book remain strong.  I'm glad to have finally read this classic and will happily recommend it to others who are looking for a structure to shape and drive their evangelistic endeavors.  And I hope to continually fine-tune my ability to more closely align my ministry with the world-changing model that Jesus showed us.

I've served for a number of years at a church where words like "choice" and "options" are sacrosanct.  The default setting is to assume that more options on the menu will serve more people, thereby furthering God's mission in our community.  And certainly the heart of this philosophy of ministry is pure and gospel-centered.  But I have found that this style of church life leads to fragmentation, disorientation, confusion, waste, and frustration for so many people.  And the ordinary people on the ground, charged with executing the ever-expanding ideas of the visionary leaders, are caught in a pattern of never-ending assignments to support the huge machinery of unfocused ministry.  Having been one of those people and married to another one, it is utterly exhausting, unsustainable, and ultimately counterproductive.So, I am excited for any model of church ministry that points in the direction of focus, consolidation, stream-lining, and clarity.  These ideals just seem like good stewardship to me and offer a church an opportunity to be more effective for the Kingdom of God.  This is where I had hoped that Browning's "Deliberate Simplicity" might deliver.  And on one level, "Deliberate Simplicity" does describe a very different approach to ministry than what I've personally experienced and observed in so many other overly busy churches.  Browning does describe a laser focus that emphasizes high amounts of energy in only a few directions, rather than a shrapnel-like smattering of energy in a hundred different directions.  And this involves the hard leadership work of saying "no" to some very good things so that a church might correspondingly say "yes" to very few but even better things.  This overall approach seems much more manageable and sustainable to me, something that I deeply desire in my ongoing ministry in the church.But Browning started to lose me when he elaborated on his ideas of velocity and scalability.  Frankly, at the end of the day, the model that he described seems to offer just another methodology to ensure exhaustion.  Rather than bouncing back and forth from one ministry endeavor to another, Browning seems to assume a willingness to keep grinding out reproductions of the original model, over and over again with increasing speed and franticness.  As I look at his description, I again say, "No, thanks."  I got tired just reading about it.I won't pretend to fully understand my own theoretical solution to these complex issues.  I do generally prefer Browning's fundamental simplicity over the ever-expanding smorgasbord that is most familiar to me.  But having watched numerous people faithfully and passionately engage in ministry only to feel like they've been run over by a truck, I'm not satisfied if Browning merely offers an alternative method to grind people into the ground.  I am convinced that there must be ways to do church ministry that aren't primarily defined by exhaustion, and "Deliberate Simplicity" did not offer the alternative that I had hoped to find.

I grew up in a household and a church deeply informed by the parenting principles of Dr. James Dobson.  I watched some of his teachings for young people during my teen years.  And I even attended the Focus on the Family Institute, a one-semester study program for college students and recent graduates, at his FOTF headquarters in Colorado Springs.Though I have grown to disagree with some of his teachings and especially his increasing focus on politics instead of the parenting and family issues that gave him his prominent and influential platform, I still think highly of Dr. Dobson.  But "Love for a Lifetime" is actually the first of his books that I've ever read.  And, in short, I would summarize that it fell rather squarely within the expectations that I had for it.  The entire book is informed by Dr. Dobson's biblical worldview, and his commitment to his understanding of biblical instruction and godly wisdom shapes each chapter, paragraph, and sentence.  I applaud his consistency and passion, and there is much that married couples in 21st-century America, both young and old, would do well to consider and apply.Having said that, I will admit that this book is showing its age, and that's not necessarily a good thing.  Frankly speaking, Dr. Dobson is an icon of a bygone era, and much of what he thinks and writes will surely seem foreign and even offensive to many readers, including many evangelical Christians.  He has very traditional views of gender roles and rather rigid understandings of gender characteristics.  I think that much of it is generally true and reflects a historical interpretation of Scripture.  But I would suggest that one of Dr. Dobson's points of disconnect with the younger generation of listeners is his inability or refusal to speak about gender issues winsomely and gracefully and humbly.  A generation (or four) ago, this book would have been pure gold.  Right now, I'm sure it will still hit home for some folks, but I'm just as sure that some folks will want to spit and curse.Dr. Dobson apologists will love this book.  Dr. Dobson haters will loathe this book.  I would simply encourage readers to understand what they are getting and adjust expectations accordingly.  There is some great stuff in "Love for a Lifetime," and if you're looking for a relatively short, readable book containing some basic truths about Christian marriage from a very traditional perspective, this will do the trick.  But if you really want to dig in, I'd recommend Gary Thomas' "Sacred Marriage" instead, the most insightful and challenging of the many marriage books that I've read and my first recommendation for newlyweds and long-time married folks with a willingness to ponder the depths of God's intention for marriage.

This collection of three discs contains live recordings of the very best barbershop quartets from 1990-1996.  And if you enjoy barbershop quartet singing, then these tracks will surely be a delight for you.  Most of the songs are classic barbershop arrangements, delivered with vocal excellence, blend, charisma, panache and a bit of humor.  There were a few quartets that get a bit pitchy, which is the great limitation of live recordings.  And there were a few other quartets who were apparently especially enamored with themselves and decided to turn every single note of their songs into an extended fermata, which may be charming to some folks but seemed a bit pompous and unnecessary to me.  But with those few exceptions, this collection contains three discs of barbershop virtuosity.  I have loved listening to it over the years and recommend it to anyone with an appreciation or even just a curiosity about barbershop singing.

I'm not a church planter and have no intention of becoming one, but a friend of mine recommended Ben Arment's "Church in the Making," so I decided to give it a read.  And even though I've never planted a church, I've had a front-row seat to watch several failed and struggling plants in our local church community, so I've gathered a few scattered and rather disconnected opinions about that unique corner of churchdom.  Right away, I was thrilled to read Arment's analysis of church planting that put words to my observations and offered the sort of straight-shooting honesty that seems to be sorely missing from so many plants.  He suggests that some church plants should be allowed to die much sooner than they do.  He states that many (or most) church plants are launched far too quickly.  And he even goes so far (as his primary thesis) as to declare that the best church plants are the ones that result from someone being asked to do it within a community where existing relationships have already prepared the ground to bear much fruit (as opposed to random parachute plants by strangers from afar with no understanding of their community context, no relationships to leverage, and no patience to wait for the right time to launch).  And Arment's experience as not only a former church planter himself but also an observer and consultant for numerous plants offers him some personal credibility to make such vital but unexpected assertions.  His honesty and vulnerability about his own struggles and failures as a planter make his ideas ring especially true.I agree with another reviewer that the end of the book moved further into prescriptive details that could be found in any number of standard church leadership books, as he seemed to lose some of the originality that made the opening chapters so compelling to me.  And maybe this is nothing beyond my own natural cynicism, but I couldn't help but periodically wonder if Arment's youth and relative inexperience (as far as I could tell, he planted one slightly successful church before transitioning into other ministry endeavors) offers him sufficient experience to write with such certainty about the complex and diverse world of church planting.  But none of that changes the fact that Arment has some important stuff to say to any would-be, has-been, or current church planter, to help make more sense of the remarkable failure rate for church planting in 21st-century American evangelicalism.  He and I agree that it doesn't need to be so, and several of his reenvisioned notions of what drives church planting might help to improve those sobering statistics.  Whenever I encounter someone considering the brave leap into the risky world of church planting, this is the first book that I'll recommend as a great place to consider some healthy perspectives to offer the best chance for getting a new church off the ground and into the Kingdom mix.

I was intrigued by the premise of this book, an analysis of the remarkable success stories of five preacher celebrities of the American contemporary evangelical church world of various theological inclinations: Joel Osteen, T.D. Jakes, Brian McLaren, Paula White, and Rick Warren.  And the authors quickly acknowledge that they will be focusing on the marketplace factors that have allowed each of these five preachers to grow large churches and amass international followings and much acclaim (and corresponding disdain).  This marketplace focus derives from the authors' academic fields of sociology and history.  They specifically state that the book does not cover theological terrain and does not critique the spiritual nature of the five subjects because the authors are not theologians.  And from that perspective, what follows is a simple discussion of each of these Holy Mavericks and the various innovations and unorthodox approaches to ministry that has allowed them to thrive.  The authors are careful not to be critical but simply state the facts of what these five pastors have been doing and how those methodologies have led to such outwardly success.  The discussion all falls within the framework of this analytical model (p. 160):  "The theory of religious economy views churches as firms, pastors are marketers and producers, and church members as consumers whose tastes and preferences shape the goods and services ministers and firms offer."And that direct quote very succinctly explains the limitations inherent in this approach to analyzing pastoral ministry.  The authors (and their academic predecessors who birthed the theory of religious economy) certainly did not create the notion that there is value in considering logistical and sociological reasons why people are drawn to certain religious approaches, methodologies, and techniques while they are repelled by others.  This idea goes back at least as far as Charles Finney and his honest and practical reflections on the best way to organize his 19th-century revivals.  But there is a point at which this sort of analysis is inadequate or even completely contrary to the gospel.  The church is first and foremost the body of Christ, not a firm.  Pastors are first and foremost shepherds, not marketers and producers.  And church members are first and foremost part of the body of Christ, not consumers.  Just because a spiritual leader makes methodological innovations that draw more people to follow and participate in their church, that does not mean that the innovations are aligned with the Gospel.  In fact, certain innovations of these five prominent church leaders are worthy of careful reflection, criticism and possibly even downright dismissal, but this book never enters that territory.To be clear, I am fine with the decision of the authors to stay within their fields of expertise and training.  I am quite certain that this book has the potential to offer interesting insight into the sociology of religion that academics may more fully appreciate than I did.  And I certainly learned some interesting information about the backgrounds, stories, and leadership innovations of the five featured preachers, some of which may someday inform my own pastoral ministry (both in terms of what I want to mimic and what I want to avoid).  But for those outside the relevant academic circles, I would only recommend reading this book in tandem with Skye Jethani's "The Divine Commodity," which offers a helpful corrective to some of the basic assumptions of the theory of religious economy that run directly in contrast to the gospel of Jesus Christ, which should be the nexus of the innovative leadership of all servant leaders of Christ but far too often holds only a peripheral place.

I consider C.S. Lewis to be the finest author of the 20th century, and I think that several of his books are genuine, timeless classics.  So, I'm always interested in reading anything that I can find that he's written.  And there is a thriving publishing industry of collections of snippets from Lewis, some of which are fabulous and others which are mostly forgettable.  "C.S. Lewis on Love" falls primarily in the latter, though it is not entirely without commendation.This book is a compilation of a few dozen blurbs from Lewis about love, related to various sub-themes (marriage, sex, friendship, forgiveness, etc.)  But some problems with this format tamper my enthusiasm for this project.  First, Lewis writes with such depth and complexity that he is not easily excerpted.  And as the editor acknowledges in the preface, love is not a topic on which Lewis necessarily wrote with great focus and frequency, at least not in excerpt-able form.  To be sure, love is integrated within most of his writing, but in a way that requires greater space and depth than what can be pulled out in a paragraph or two.  Lewis offered reflections about love in a much more organic way than what can be readily sliced and diced into a "greatest quotes" collection.The two major places where he wrote about love are the books "The Four Loves" and "Mere Christianity," and not surprisingly, those sources offer the vast majority of quotes in this book.  And the quotes that emerge from those two books are wonderful, several of which I cite with regularity in my preaching and even general conversation.  But, as is always the case with excerpts, the power of those quotes is somewhat mitigated by their removal from context.  Frankly, I'd encourage anyone to read the original books.  "Mere Christianity" is one of the finest books that I've ever read, and "The Four Loves," though decidedly less remarkable, offers many helpful contributions to my understanding of love. Beyond the excerpts from those two books, many of the other snippets are really quite forgettable, further validating that love simply was not a theme about which Lewis spent much focused and isolated attention.Having offered my critique, there is no doubt that Lewis' unique and brilliant way of articulating godly and helpful insight about so many topics is not lost in this book.  Lewis has some great stuff to say about love.  So, if you need a quick entry point into Lewis, this isn't a terrible place to start.  And if you want a coffee table book or a book to place in a waiting room or a bathroom for short bursts of reading, this offers some fabulous soundbites of Lewis' profundity.  But if you really want to dig into C.S. Lewis, you really ought to start with "Mere Christianity," then move on to "The Screwtape Letters," "The Great Divorce," and any of his other classic works.  Time spent with the words of C.S. Lewis is always time well spent.

I am a huge fan of Bill Cosby.  I grew up with "The Cosby Show" and still consider it one of television's best sitcoms.  I later discovered his stand-up comedy work, have gone to several of his shows, and was very favorably impressed.  But I'd never read any of his books before my wife gave me a copy of his "Fatherhood."  And I was genuinely excited to enter this new medium to experience the unique combination of warmth and humor that Cosby provides in his inimitable way.  Ultimately, the book was fine but largely unremarkable.In trying to figure out why I didn't enjoy this book more, I've decided that the problem is the transmission of Cosby's style of humor into the written word.  It seems to me that Cosby's genius is his facial expressions and vocal patterns.  Though he's certainly an intelligent man, I wouldn't describe him as a wordsmith.  So, many of his jokes in this book just didn't work in this medium.  Of course, some of the material came straight from his stand-up routines or from The Cosby Show, and as I could imagine Cosby delivering the lines, they elicited some chuckles.  But, in general, his written humor felt a bit flat to me.And the introduction and afterword by a professional psychiatrist, I suppose intended to provide some more intellectual heft to a book that was mostly silly and hyperbolic, was odd and disconnected from Cosby's stuff.  The good doctor's advice was dry and pedantic and just plain boring.  Given Cosby's commitment to education and families, I imagine that he envisioned this additional content to be a way to help inject a slice of serious parenting advice into the minds of readers who will readily read a book by a comedian but might not otherwise read a book about fatherhood.  I appreciate the sentiment but thought it was poorly executed.To be sure, Bill Cosby is Bill Cosby, so there is some funny stuff in this book.  And it was even funny to read anecdotes or punchlines that I've already heard from his stand-up or television work.  But in the category of funny books about family written by comedians, I'd much more readily recommend Paul Reiser's "Couplehood," "Babyhood," and "Familyhood," as Reiser's humor translates much more effectively to the written word.  I still appreciate Cosby and might even give another one of his books a try, but "Fatherhood" didn't do much for me.

C.S. Lewis is one of my favorite authors, and I consider his "Mere Christianity" and "The Screwtape Letters" to be two of the finest books written in the 20th century.  But I must admit that some of his stuff is rather grueling to read.  "The Abolition of Man" was one of the more laborious that I've read, and though not to that same extent, I would categorize "The Four Loves" similarly.To be sure, "The Four Loves" offers some fascinating insight into the four different types of love that Lewis describes: affection (family love), friendship, eros (romantic love), and charity.  His analysis of these different loves helps to explain how and why we can profoundly love different people in substantially distinct ways.  I especially appreciated some of his critique of how modern assumptions about romantic love have created vastly dysfunctional and destructive patterns of relationships.  I was able to borrow a few quotes from the "Friendship" chapter for a sermon that I recently preached about relationships.  And Lewis is always Lewis, finding clever ways to explain very profound ideas and putting words to things that we've all felt in the past but have previously been unable to articulate.However, "The Four Loves" was definitely more laborious for me to read than most of Lewis' other work that I've read.  Several of his main themes (the distinctions between "need-love" and "gift-love," for instance) were so abstract that I really struggled to follow his reasoning.  And even when I was able to decipher what he was saying, I struggled to understand how his ideas even mattered.  Lewis' gift as an author is taking high-minded, intellectual stuff and bringing it down to earth, to make it accessible to normal folks like me.  I just never felt like "The Four Loves" ever really landed, but instead stayed in the philosophical stratosphere.  It's a fine and decent book which offers some interesting food for thought about the nature of love.  And there are definitely some sound bites that provide great quotes to share in various contexts.  But I'd easily recommend a dozen other book by Lewis before I'd point someone in this direction.

I heard Randy Frazee speak at a conference years ago about much of the content contained in his book, "Making Room for Life," and have always remembered and even taught and preached about some of his ideas over the years.  Having been rather captivated by what I remembered, I finally read the book to reiterate and clarify some of his ideas, and it was definitely time well spent.Frazee begins the book by describing the lifestyle that a significant number of middle-class, suburban Americans experience throughout their lifetimes.  This crowded loneliness, in which we scurry about from day to day, frantically trying to keep our heads above water, as we pass hundreds of strangers while meaningfully interacting with no one, including our family members.  Many of us have at least some familiarity with the mess that he describes, and it's distasteful at best and utterly disheartening at worst.  For the rest of the book, Frazee proposes a completely radical solution to the problem.Frazee's radical solution requires a complete shift in priorities, focus, and thinking.  He advocates the Hebrew Day planner, an ancient daily schedule that allows for work from 6:00am to 6:00pm, relational time from 6:00pm to 10:00pm, and sleep from 10:00pm to 6:00am on six days a week and a true, fully practiced weekly Sabbath rest.  He advocates finding employment that allows the work day to end no later than 6:00pm, every day.  He advocates living close to work, to minimize wasted time in commutes.  He advocates minimizing organized children's activities, to curb more commuting and allow for more natural kids' play.  He advocates a consolidation of relationships around proximity, where the neighborhood becomes the nexus for adult friendships, kid friendships, church friendships (i.e. small groups), evangelism, service, and virtually everything else.  He advocates simple living in smaller houses with less stuff, supported by smaller incomes (preferably one).In short, Frazee advocates the abandonment of the mutilated version of the American Dream to which many of us are still clinging, even though we know full well that it is disfigured and dying.  We are a people driving ourselves into the ground, trying to be filled with activity and flurry and accumulation and leisure, while all the while knowing that much of what we pursue is gross.  Frazee offers an alternative.Critics suggest that Frazee's model for life is idealistic, unrealistic, and archaic.  If we hope to cling onto any significant portion of the trappings of 21st-century American suburban madness, then this claim is probably true.  But Frazee isn't suggesting that we tweak the system to try to make things a little bit better.  Instead, he offers a comprehensive paradigm shift, an opportunity to start over and get it right.I credit Frazee with shooting straight with us, with calling out the ridiculousness of our lives, made all the more absurd because we know we hate so much of it.  Yet, what he advocates is so radical, so outside the box, that I'm not sure what to do with it.  Frankly, I'm not sure that I want to go as far as he has gone, not sure that I want to give up all that he suggests.  I am challenged by his book, and I am motivated to change.  But I'm not sure that I'm willing to go where he calls me to go.One of my biggest points of dissonance with the book is its remarkable specificity.  If you want to design your life in imitation of an ideal, Frazee basically offers the complete template.  But I'm left pondering if some of the big ideas of this new way of life are attainable with some shifts and adjustments.  For instance, Frazee is dogmatic about the precise time-frames (6am to 6pm for work, 6pm to 10pm for relationships, 10pm to 6am for sleep).  Is there any reason why I couldn't shift the whole thing two hours later, since I'm pretty sure that all alarm clocks in Satan's domain are set for 6:00am?  Of course, I can try it and see how it goes, but I just wish that the general tone of Frazee's book was a bit more descriptive and a little less prescriptive.To be sure, "Making Room for Life" is provocative in all of the best ways.  This is a book that I know will surely impact my thinking for years to come, and I do hope to read it with others to foster some really good conversation.  I share Frazee's frustration of so many ills of modern American life, and I appreciate his general diagnosis of the problem.  The extent to which I resonate with all of his solutions remains to be seen, but I admire his commitment to doing something, to changing something, to taking some steps to do life differently.  I doubt that I'll ever commit full-scale to his plan, but there is much wisdom to be gleaned from a different way to think, work, love, and live.  I'm grateful to Frazee for this contribution and happy to recommend this book to anyone willing to consider if there might be a different way, a better way, to make room for more of the life that God intends for us to live.

As a pastor, I read a fair number of books, many on Christian living and church leadership.  I like some, I loathe a few, and I find many to be fine but unremarkable.  Without a doubt, Mark Buchanan's "The Rest of God" falls in the former category.  In fact, I've been telling friends that this is one of the best books that I've read in years, and further reflection affirms that assessment.  I've been wanting to read this book, and I'm so glad that I finally did.The strengths of "The Rest of God" are both in its content and its style.  Buchanan's writing is both intellectually stimulating but also fully accessible.  It is an engaging book to read, but not at all laborious to finish.  It is thoroughly biblical but completely practical.  It is very specific without being legalistic and overly regimented.  It is completely convicting while also offering hope and encouragement.I won't attempt to summarize the substance of the book in this review, as that would only short-change Buchanan's commendable book.  I will simply acknowledge that "The Rest of God" has changed my thinking and affected my life.  When I finish most books, at best I'm usually able to say that it was interesting or challenging, but I'm rarely changed in significant ways.  When I finished "The Rest of God," I immediately changed my weekly rhythms of rest.  Thanks to Buchanan's challenge, I am thoroughly convinced that I have never really experienced Sabbath rest as God intends, and I want to live differently.  Even for the most skeptical of readers, I happily recommend "The Rest of God," without hesitation, as a remarkable journey into the life that God desires for all of us to experience.  I know that I have been changed, and I suspect that this book will shape my life for many years to come.

Other than the snippets from his long-running TV show, I'd never seen Jerry Seinfeld's stand-up comedy, which means that I'd never seen his act for more than 30- or 45-second sound bites.  But having enjoyed the shows and those snippets, I was excited to see this collection of old jokes when it was released years ago, as he was supposedly retiring all of his old material.  And this became an instant favorite in our house.The opening sequence, a fake funeral where his old jokes are buried in a casket surrounded by a bunch of famous comedians, was cheesy and unnecessary.  But once Seinfeld got on stage, he's laugh-out-loud funny from start to finish.  One sure sign of good comedy is its ability to elicit laughter even when the audience knows the punch lines before they are spoken.  Having watched this show many times, I remember most of the jokes in advance.  Yet, I laugh constantly.  His writing is brilliant.  His delivery is perfect.  It never stoops to low-brow, sophomoric junk.  It's classic stuff.Whenever we are inspired to rewatch this disc, it never disappoints.  I'm not exactly a connoisseur of stand-up comedy, but this is possibly the best stand-up show I've ever seen, and I'm happy to recommend it to anyone.

In preparation for preaching a sermon about Sabbath rest, I stumbled upon Dan Allender's book "Sabbath" and plowed through it in a few days.  Having previously read a marriage book by Allender and not being overly impressed, I was hoping that a vastly different topic would bring out his strengths as an author.  Though the book certainly wasn't a total loss, I was generally disappointed.The greatest strength of "Sabbath" was Allender's repainting the Sabbath canvas in terms of what we should pursue, rather than merely the avoidance of work.  He went to great lengths to articulate his vision for Sabbath that primarily centers around joy and delight as the ultimate goals.  He offered a number of specific examples, especially from his own life, that helped to make those potentially abstract ideas a bit more concrete, and I was quite compelled and inspired by much of what he shared to pursue comparable ideals for my own Sabbath rhythms.But as much as I grabbed hold of the notion that Sabbath rest should be about joy and delight, I struggled throughout the book to track with Allender's style.  His writing is so poetic, so abstract, and so meandering that I often found myself thoroughly perplexed about where he was going.  His language is so creative that it often just doesn't make sense.  I've heard from folks who I know who thought this book was utterly fabulous, so I suppose that my disconnect was probably more about stylistic preference than about the actual content of the book.  I didn't disagree with him or think he was out-of-line.  I just struggled far too often to track with his points.As someone with a lousy personal Sabbath history, I was glad to read this book to get me inspired to think differently, or even to just think at all, about what God might intend for Sabbath.  And I really did appreciate the inspiration to pursue joy and delight in my future Sabbath commitments.  But as other reviewers have suggested, I'd recommend Mark Buchanan's "The Rest of God" as a more comprehensive, more accessible, more tangible, clearer guide to challenge and motivate us to wholeheartedly receive God's gift of Sabbath.

I heard Bill Hybels speak about his "Holy Discontent" idea at the Leadership Summit several years ago, shortly before this book was published, so I was introduced to the idea at that time.  And several others at our church have read the book and listened to his talk, so the phrase "holy discontent" has been part of our shared vocabulary for awhile.  But I finally actually read the book and learned more about what I've been contemplating and discussing all this time.As I had hoped, Hybels offers an inspirational charge in "Holy Discontent."  He suggests that each of us has a gnawing, perturbing, irritating frustration with something that we observe in the world around us, and when that frustration aligns with the concerns of the heart of God, we have available to us the most holy form of motivation to get out there and do something to right that wrong.  It's a simple but very compelling concept, especially when illustrated with a dozen or more stories of the work that God's people have done and are doing all over the world when their energies have been catalyzed by the fire of the Holy Spirit to do His work.And having read many of Hybels' books before, this one followed suit as extremely readable and totally accessible, not some sort of high-minded, theologically-dense tome.  I read this over the course of a few days and could probably have read it in one sitting if so inclined.  And, as such, this brings me to my primary critique of the book.  It felt a bit thin to me, rather lacking in substance in some places where I wanted to hear more.  What do I do if I sometimes feel like I have a dozen holy discontents?  Is it possible for some people to have one life-long holy discontent while others experience a series of shifting holy discontents throughout their lives?  These sorts of questions were barely addressed, but I would have appreciated more reflection along those lines.Frankly, Hybels covered this material extremely well in his Summit talk.  If you've heard him talk about it, the book doesn't add a lot of additional material.  But if you're unfamiliar with the concept, unable to access any of his talks on the topic, or simply prefer to read rather than listen/watch, I'm happy to recommend "Holy Discontent" as a solid, helpful, and challenging book.  The world would be better off, the church would be more effective, and God would be more glorified if we were all willing to listen to the stirring within our hearts and minds and responded accordingly to pursue the holy discontent that God has placed within each one of us.Update:  I recently "reread" the book via the audiobook version, and my impressions were similar to the first time.  "Holy Discontent" is a book filled with an interesting and helpful idea, though it's less thorough than I would have preferred.  If you've never encountered Hybels' thesis before, it's well worth your time to investigate this small book.  But once you've heard the basic explanation, other resources are definitely necessary to fully unpack what it means to pursue the passion borne out of frustration that God has given to many of us.

Last year, I stumbled upon Paul Reiser's "Couplehood" and "Babyhood" and absolutely devoured them.  They were very easy to read and simply hysterical, with many parts that I simply had to read out-loud to my wife after chuckling so much that she needed to know what was so funny.  So, when I saw that Reiser recently released "Familyhood," I couldn't wait to read it.  I was thrilled when my wife purchased it for my birthday, and I read it in bed over the course of just a few nights.Like Reiser's previous books, this one is extremely easy to read.  His writing style is accessible, pleasant, and informal, and it feels as much like a conversation as an actual book.  But it seemed to me as if the overall tone of this book is different from its two predecessors.  The first two seemed to be primarily comedic, with a few drops of poignancy and seriousness interspersed throughout the jokes.  But "Familyhood" was much more serious in overall tone, with a few drops of comedy interspersed throughout the poignant anecdotes.  And the funny stuff in this one elicited more wry smiles than outright belly laughs.But let me be clear in stating that this is not a bad thing.  Amazingly (and contrary to his renowned career in comedy), Reiser handles the serious stuff with aplomb.  Maybe this change in tone reflects his maturation through life or the difficulties in raising a son with significant physical disabilities.  In any case, the shift was not uncomfortable or inappropriate.  Though it didn't quite fit my expectations, based on the first two books, "Familyhood" is still a book worth reading for anyone interested in hearing one man's honest reflections on the joys and sorrows, the victories and trials, that family life brings to all of us.  Frankly, whenever Reiser produces "Emptynesthood" or "Retirementhood" or "Oldhood," I'll anxiously await the opportunity to read it.  This funnyman familyman has quickly become one of my favorite authors.

My aunt passed along her copy of "F in Exams" and recommended that I read it, and I'm glad that I did.  It's really simple book, easily read in 15-20 minutes.  And the silly and/or ridiculous answers offered by students to these exam questions were truly priceless.  Mostly, I read the book with a wry smile on my face, and I actually laughed out-loud several times.  As a former student who frequently tried to have some fun when I was thoroughly stumped by a test question, I genuinely appreciated the futile attempts throughout this book.  No, this is not a great work of literature.  And, yes, it's hard to imagine that some of these answers were actually written on actual tests by actual students.  But it's a lot of fun, a quick read, and a great way to pass some time and enjoy a few chuckles.

4.5/5Honestly I felt this book was even better than #1.  Sebastian was so much easier to accept and had a greater depth than I was expecting.  I sympathized with him and also loved Kaderin as she wasn’t like other heroines.  She took hard to get to a whole new level and not because she was playing games.  The internal battle she fought with herself and the difficult choice she had to make at the end made her character such a vibrant and fun one to read.So the break down is thus, Kaderin can’t feel anymore, a gift from a god of some sort after the death of her sisters because normally Valkyrie dye from sorrow but she was so strong she wasn’t but she was effecting the other Valkyrie with her sorrow.  So one day she wakes up and all emotion is gone and that includes the even sexual ones.  She walks around this way for as long as anyone can remember earning her the name Kaderin the Cold Hearted.  She mercilessly hunts and kills Vampires and one such vampire lives in an abandoned castle and she is asked to dispatch him. She arrives, he gives her his neck willingly only she hesitates. . .the first time since becoming emotionless.  Things explode from there as the pull between them becomes evident.  Sebastian realizes right away what she is to him and Kaderin FEELS and it scares the crap out of her not to mention she hates vampires.Thus begins the chase, only this time it is a vampire hunting Kaderin and not for her death.  This allowed for some fun interactions and some great comedic moments.  I love Ms. Cole’s writing and this story is no different.  I was swept away on a fun adventure  and the movement of the story is brought about by the use of a race between immortals like the Amazing Race only immortal style.I always am checking on books in the series to see when some go on sale and trying to grab them even if out of order because I know I will be reading this entire series.And I dare to say that I am enjoying this series more than JR Wards Black Dagger Brotherhood.

4.5/5I was captivated and really intrigued once I started reading this book and was really eager to find where things would go.  I found the character likable and related to them as living breathing people who do interesting and sometimes silly things.  The story while emotionally compelling was lighthearted and even at times funny.  I found myself smiling many times at some of the situations Mili finds her in, or things that Samir did.  This really had the trappings of a rom com movie in my head.  I kept playing scenes from Bend it Like Beckham too (the only movie I can think of with Indian themes similar to this that had the music and dancing that I could thus picture so vividly).One funny quote from Mili that I loved was:“No, it’s raining, but only on my face.”Overall this was a fun read that took me just a few days to get through.  While I did enjoy it overall there were a few issues I had with it that kept me from feeling like it was a home run.The book was a little drawn out for me.  It was great that the relationship between Mili and Samir was given the time and attention it needed to build and establish an actual connection rather than the insta loves we love to hate and hate to love and bitch and moan about.  That said I still felt like it dragged a bit and needed either more momentum or something left out.This next part is less with the story and more the set up of the book.  It switched between Mili and her life and Samir and his life without anything to signal it.  One paragraph I am reading about Mili, the next one Samir and several times in the beginning I would have to stop and reread it several times before realizing what happened.  I am use to some sort of break to signify a change, such as *** between the paragraphs that gives the reader a heads up and says “Hey! Something changes here.”  This is just a pet peeve of mine though so don’t take too much from it and just use it as a forewarning so you can expect it.She has sex for the first time up against a tree and then several more times that night.  This is her first time and while the author describes her crying out in pain when her hymen is torn it just felt a little unbelievable.  Especially considering how rough the guy takes her:“He slammed into her, mindless frantic thrusts until he exploded, and exploded and exploded without end.”Uhh.. . great for a story but not if you want to be true to life because any guy doing that to a virgin the first time will most likely have a woman in serious pain. (Yes I realize some people have had glorious first times, kudos to you.  You probably orgasm on command too).There is also a part in the story where Mili tells Samir that his story isn’t a decent story because the main character shouldn’t loose something he loves but instead the story should almost take it away and also only take away something he thinks he might love.  It is very similar to how this story felt and I am not sure if that was a good thing.  Great emotional depth can come from a character loosing something he loves and  yes it doesn’t always need to happen but this story while very well written and enjoyable almost seemed superficial, like it had yet to really scratch the surface of what it could have.  This resulted in me satisfied but also vaguely left wanting.Overall a very enjoyable, lighthearted read and I had fun with Mili and Samir.

4.5/5So I am in my local walmart (hahah, local, it is 1 hour away from me but it is the nearest one to me) and it was one of “those” days there which meant waiting in line an hour to check out (I kid you not).  So the husband and I took turns going off to do something other than stare at the persons back that was in front of us.  I of course found my way to the books, saw The Martian and just had been hearing some friends online talking about the awesomeness that was the book.  So I grabbed it and went back to the waiting line of forever and started reading it.Firstly, I wasn’t expecting it to be so freaking witty!  Here we have a book that the majority of the story is a guy alone and with such little interaction with another person you wouldn’t think you would be able to laugh and smile as much as I did while reading it.  The character was amazing.  He was sarcastic and upbeat and cracked jokes in the face of such adversity it was beyond amazing.  Mark Watney was instantly a guy you wanted to be friends with in real life.  He was a well developed and interesting character and I was eager to see how he would manage the next situation he found himself in.So for the record: I LOVED THIS BOOK. READ IT.  it was amazing, a page turner, one I talked with my husband about and while my husband isn’t a reader he was interested in this book so hung on my every words as I gave him the break down.  Needless to say he will happily see the movie when we can rent it.So that all said, I had one issue with this book.  It is kind of spoiler like but not really but kind of.  It is based off information we are given early on (in the sample even) and while it doesn’t make me take away from the rating it gnaws upon my brain and is driving me crazy.  So if you want to know what I had issue with check out my original review on my blog and I will say this much: antibiotics.Of note, the last quarter of the book started to drag for me, it might have been all the science being repeated, and Watney repeating some of the things he said earlier so I started skimming.  I didn’t need to be reminded of those things told before and by this point I didn’t care much about all the science, I just wanted to know what happened to Watney! I still loved it.Loved the book, save my one issue with that early part and I guess the last quarter.  This book was very technical and scientific but it was explained in a great way by the ever charismatic Watney so that it doesn’t matter if you have a science mind or not you would enjoy the read. I am blown away that this is Andy Weir’s first book, he hit it out of the park.  If you have been considering reading this one I say go for, grab it!!

4.5/5I really enjoyed the first book int he Searching For series, Searching for Someday, and  had a good time reading this one as well.  It is a contemporary romance with humor and a hint, like just a hint, so much a hint I don't know why I even mention it, of magic.  Watching Kennedy and Nate get to know each other was enjoyable and kept me interest through out the read.The plot is predictable, the story not so knew but still the read was fun and endearing.  Ken sees a challenge in helping Nate find his forever wife.  There is the reference to how he is her Eliza from my fair lady in how she wishes to help transform his exterior so people will stop and give his interior a chance. I think for me this was a little bit of a sticking point for me, the whole emphasis on personal appearance and changing his.  Granted her work wasn't just in appearance but making him think before he speaks so he doesn't insult women anymore with his very straight to the point attitude.This book while emphasizing outward appearance also dives into body issues, eating disorders and bullying to help bring balance.  We get to see a depth to each character that is more than just scratching the surface but still would have enjoyed a bit more.I am actually quite enchanted with this series and want to read the next two in the series, especially because the side characters they bring in our intriguing and captivating enough that you want to learn more about them.  I honestly kind of feel that Jennifer Probst with this series especially is one I would read when I want a Penny Reid or Daisy Prescott'esque read.

2.5/5This book was free and looked cute so I grabbed it up to hold for a day when it fit my mood.  A couple months later I finally opened it up and what I got was a bit surprising.  Basically I was disappointed.  Xavier is an a$$.  I have read many books with guys who are asses, it is fine when they have redeeming qualities but I really could find none in Xavier.  Further more his character did not seem well established.  One minute he is one way and the next another resulting in mental whiplash.  It almost seemed like his character had not been fully fleshed out.  There were times when I was liking him but again the mental whiplash would occur when his a$$hole tendency reared it's ugly head in a way so unneeded and unattractive that I found no inherent desire for this character in anyway.Then there is Lola, a strong independent young woman who seems to have a back bone and no fear but at the same time is annoyingly naive.  Why, WHY would you go work for him?  I felt like I was getting to know her character well enough by the time she made this decision that she would have told him to eff off and turned the offer down but instead becomes this big pile of stupid and does it anyways.I have read many books where the female lead is attracted to the male a$$hat and is conflicted by their desire and their dislike of the guy but 1) usually the guy has one redeeming quality that you latch onto because it results in endearing him to you, the reader, and the female lead 2)They at least seem to have a bit of a back bone and must be somewhat seduced or placed into needing to do something they don't want to because of extraneous circumstances.Overall just a let down and not a series I feel compelled to continue reading.

4.5/5I decided to grab this book because I had heard from several people they were enjoying it and had even heard mentioned that it was giving a Love Hacked vibe and we all know how much I love Penny Reid.The first few chapters in were a bit Rocky for me.  The Characters of Kate and Ian were first introduced but the introduction wasn't grabbing me.  I hung on and I am glad I did because the story and the characters felt like they solidified and was better at grabbing me after the initial few chapters.The story was fun and light hearted and warmed the heart.  You cheer for the characters and feel invested in them.There were some cons I had and I have a feeling this is in part to my going in being told about the Love Hacked vibe and because of that I want to say don't go in thinking you are getting a book exactly like Love Hacked, it isn't and personally to me they don't compare even with the premise and qwerky parts.Cons:Weak side characters.  The story really only built up Kate and Ian.  Towards the end you got more of other characters but you didn't feel invested in them, I didn't feel like I wanted to know more about them.  I like having strong side characters that make the story feel bigger rather than a small tiny bubble and for most of the story you lived in a tiny bubble with the characters.  This is fine for certain stories (such as this authors first book I read, On the Island, because well they lived on a freaking island by themselves ;) ) but I think this book could have benefited more from better side characters.Furthermore there were no surprises in the book, and it felt rather predictable.  I like a little mystery to the story, things that I wouldn't expect even if small are nice.Again for me the weak start.  I already elaborated on that though.There was good to this story of course I wouldn't be rating it as I have.  I did feel like it was teaching me a little bit about things in life(hacking and how it affects my day to day life) and the characters both served a greater purpose.  What I mean is the characters had depth and wanted to do more for others which helped make them likable, fun and enjoyable to read. You really rooted for them.The story is full and complete leaving me satisfied at the end and once I got past the rocky for me beginning I was captivated and engaged and wanted to read on.An enjoyable read for when you are looking for something fun, modern, filled with qwerkiness and humor.

3.5/5I had been hearing from some that this series was a good one and when I saw that the box set was free I decided to grab it.  I quickly ate it up and enjoyed it enough to know I will be getting book #4 sometime in the future.The stories where simple yet captivating and provided that alpha male read I was craving.  The gals are a bit of the damsels in distress but it worked out okay for the type of read I was expecting.The stories didn't feel like anything greatly unique but were different enough that they kept my interest and I enjoyed my read.I wasn't sure how I was going to feel going in, but I was pleasantly surprised.  The Russian aspect was worked in nicely as to these stories taking place in the US, Texas to be more specific. The women for each book were unique and strong in their own way.  The men are very similar but yet has his own story that brings out their unique moments.  I am really intrigued to find out more about Nikolai as his story and Vivian's screams of past and turmoil.Underlying themes in the books are drugs, theft, corruption, mobs, gangs, all things I don't read a lot of but the stories were done well enough that they didn't bother me and I kept wanting to read more.Overall I am glad I read them and will at some point check out the other books in the series. So why 3.5?  The stories were predictable, they didn't feel like something completely fresh and new.  They lacked a depth I would have liked especially in the men (though I am thinking book #4 might actually give me that depth).  Very much a simple Alpha male with eyes only for her read.

I absolutely loved Sweet Filthy Boy which was the first book in the series and couldn’t help but be excited to read Finn and Harlow’s story.  I will admit the beginning while captivating and engaging felt a little bland for me.  It was a good story, kept my interest but it was sitting for a while feeling like just another story of boy and girl fight attraction with some kinky rope play.  HOWEVER, the last 25% really turned my view around.  I became emotionally invested in the character’s relationship at this point because this book pulled out the feels. Not only that but I felt like it was here there was some uniqueness to the story helping it be set apart by the way Finn reacted to events that took place and his choice in response.  I don’t want to give anything away but at this point my heart broke and I thought “a**hole!” and yeah I couldn’t wait to see what Harlow did next, or him.  I didn’t expect some things to end up how they did and I enjoyed that so definitely the last quarter changed my mind on this read. I am very eager to read about other characters now.

A fun, endearing, bittersweet, romantic comedy that had me glued to my kindle staying up until midnight trying to cram as much time in as possible.  I loved Honey, name and all and Hal was one I had to warm up to but he had me in the end.  This story was so very sweet and had a full house of great supporting side characters to help propel the story, engage me and make me laugh.  I could see this book playing out perfectly on the screen and Honey was the reason for it.  Sometimes naive and very stubborn she had a way about her you couldn't help but admire.  Of course the constant knock downs by Hal made it hard for me to accept the attraction she felt for a little bit but she had the proper internal push and pull going on that allowed me to accept and understand.  The side stories of the home, Millie and Lucille's life and Nell and Simon brought not only great variety, but depth and intrigue.  Even in moments that should be slow there was enough going on not to drag it down.  Sadly the end as great as it was did not have an epilogue and I fear I have become quite addicted to those and getting a short quick glance into the lives of the characters I have grown to love down the road.  A fun read.

This story was captivating enough that I read it within 24 hours and enjoyed my time spent reading it.  However, I am not sure I have the drive at this exact time to read book #2 in the series yet because I don’t feel personally invested in the characters in such a way that I MUST KNOW what happens next.  Heath Lawson was a desirable enough male lead that I respected him and rooted for him.  The way he helped Allie in the beginning, in a very unexpected way for me, was what endeared me to him from the start not just the fact that he is some attractive fighter.  His quick turn around from manwhore to one woman man was a little cliched for me without a bit more interaction/time and perhaps back story or desire in their history.Allie frustrated me a bit.  I liked her strong character, you could tell she was a fighter even being so young, she just turned 18,  and in unimaginable circumstances.  Still I wish I felt from her conviction about her break up with Ryker more.  I felt if that had been stronger from the start, especially her anger I would have enjoyed the evolving relationship between her and Heath much more. I realize that might have been done to give reason for more of her back and forth, fighting the attraction, etc.  Still a little more developing of her feelings in this area was needed in my opinion.For the most part the characters felt more 1 dimensional than I would have liked for a story that had the possibility of having some characters with great depth and intrigue.  More on Allie and school and her drive with that would have made her pop more.  Or more of her interactions outside of the apartment with Heath would have allowed me to see more sides to her. The story was also lacking in depth and felt rather basic at times but still had the intrigue I needed to remain involved.Ryker is an interesting character who becomes such right at the end when we are given a back history of his side of things.

This was a very sweet story that centers on Corey Callahan and her first year of college a year after an accident that leave her paralyzed from the waist down.  From the start I loved Corey because of her strength and resolve to continue on with her life though it meant morning the loss of a life she thought she would have.  Adam Hartley is a charismatic and good heart guy who is a bit lost at times.  I wanted to give him a good shake down but the maturity Corey displayed helped soften the frustration for me.  We get a taste of college life experienced by someone who can't live it as the average college student would.  I wanted to know what happened next, I loved the blossoming relationship between Hartley and Callahan.  That said there was a depth in each character that I felt was missing as well as in the story.  They were not as three dimensional as i would have liked to help bump this story to the next level. I think it felt like such a snap shot into them and I wanted a bigger picture.  Still a great sweet read that I enjoyed

It is thick and durable and seems made to last.  Came with a lid like scoop inside.  Does not take up too much space but difficult to carry as it slides out of hands easily so fill it where you intend to keep it.
Stops that itch that can be a real. . .witchand makes both Mom and child happy.Clear and thick and goes on real quickand makes the whining child take her nappy.

Doesn't print that many pages, the XL lasts much longer and normally I would have bought that but on a budget for the month went with the less costly.  If you can afford the 200XL I would recommend that over this one just for capacity.  Otherwise ink is nice and prints well.

I heard from several ladies I am in a group with how they loved this book and so I decided it would be good to grab and try out.  I was happy I did.  This book has a different premise than I am use to reading, though the idea is the same as many romance books.Dominique is that brooding dark alpha like male only with a soft and sweet side.  Similar to other books? Sure but the difference here is this man is a creator of the most sinfully delicious chocolates.  He goes for the exotic, new, never thought possible flavor combinations that makes him the bad boy of the chocolate world.  So let me get this straight, we have a handsome, damaged, boy at heart, all man, alpha hero who also makes chocolate.  Yup you are right it is the ultimate fantasy.Then there is Jaime.  When introduced to her we find a frail delicate woman who savors life. . . and chocolate.  She catches Dominique’s eye in his store without even knowing it and he is captivated by this woman who does nothing but enjoy each bite of his chocolate, of him.  What is nice about Jaime? She is definitely anything but frail and delicate.  She is fierce and she is a fighter. She had a set back in life, a moment in time that has made her afraid when she otherwise wouldn’t be but that hasn’t broken her spirit.When the two finally meet it is a tantalizing chemistry and kept me reading more and more.  I loved the interaction between the two, the growth and the exploration of self.  They both are very aware of themselves, but unaware of each other’s thoughts and that is were the tension lies.Bits of french are scattered throughout providing an education in another language for those of us not familiar with it.  A bit predictable in story line but definitely fun and had me grinning with the funny moments and the very sweet ones indeed.

I love Kristen Ashley books.  She is my escape into a different world.  I often binge on her books when I just need some fun and then go off to read other books for a while before returning.  She has built an alpha man set of books that feel the need of many readers to excess.  She does it well and consistently.That said, this book, Sweet Dreams,  frustrated me.  For many this is an all time favorite book. Had I read this one first I might have enjoyed it more and rated it higher than I did.  But I didn’t, I read and loved The Gamble first and the result is I had a bit of a bad taste in my mouth as I read this one.  This one by the way like most KA books gives you your monies worth with over 200K in words.My problem lies in the similarities between the stories.  Now I realize for most of Kristen Ashley’s books she has a character formula she sticks to (especially for the men) and it works for her and us readers.  Though admittedly it has started to not work as well on me of late.  Anyways, she has the formula she plops it into the setting and the story and off she goes.  We read, we enjoy having gotten our fill of a read we need.Sidenote:  Some people watch t.v., what they watch varies based on taste but many people have their guilty pleasure shows.  You know, those reality t.v. ones that are all the same but different settings but still the same contrived story with built in drama and what not.  Well when I read I have my guilty pleasure books too that for some people make no sense and for others they completely get me.  In large part Kristen Ashley books are my guilty pleasure reads.  They are predictable yes but still they are fun, allow me to escape, minimal angst, I know what will happen and I tune in every time.This story had so many similarities to The Gamble it was pretty upsetting for me.  I will list some but hide them because there are spoilers so look if you don’t want to know:(spoilers removed, original list can be found on original review)I get it that too and extent books will have similarities and it is even something I often enjoy with Kristen Ashley books, like I just know there will be an amazing cast of side characters that will love the female.  There will be little antics and the female will often be quickly loved by all.  I enjoy that and expect it.  However, what I don’t like is when many of the story elements feel the same.  This perturbed me to say the least.  I still read it and enjoyed it.  I still want to read more Kristen Ashley books and would most likely right now dive into another because I am just in the mood.  That all said I was just a bit disappointed in this one.Another things I was disappointed in, I often feel like the men, who are JERKS often are way too jerky.  Their behavior would not fly in every day life.  I mean hell I try and transpose myself into the situation and I know it would not go down as it did.  I am stubborn like most of these women but so many cave so quickly to these men and change their ways but the guys never seem to change theirs.  They apologize but often it is “this is me, do it my why and take me as I am.  No go learn to be a biker babe who can handle me”  Yeah no.  I think this is why I loved the Rock Chick Series more so.  While those alpha men were very much the same, there was a connection between the men and women and i felt like often where the men came from in their actions where less stalker/asshole.Okay, I will stop there because I said what I needed to say in regards to this book. Again, love me some Kristen Ashley (not every book will be a winner for me and not every book of hers has been) and will be reading more of her. Just let down by the overt use of story details (minor alterations of course) from the book right before this one in the series.

A story with lots of bite, yup I just went there.  Okay so I had been hearing about this series for a while and it is one of those long ones, like 14 or 15 books in it so far.  I found the first three books on sale so grabbed the first (this is technically book 1 I think, with a novella happening before this).  This is the book that made me realized that the reason I love paranormal is because before I start I go in suspending reality and can accept the unacceptable.  Such as a large growling man that kidnaps a woman (albeit a vampire woman) and forces her to take off her clothes and join him in the shower.  Normally all that would have me running away going “no, no way not going to listen to a romance that starts this way” but I could hold off judgment long enough and soon accept it and found as the story progress I really enjoyed it and got into it. I am eager to find out where this whole series goes but I really liked the start.The female lead starts off weak, but grows into this amazing strong woman who does the unimaginable.  She is feisty and has bite herself.  Lachlain is . . he is just his own person.  Once you get past the beginning which I was able accept his behavior because he is part animal and was locked up and tortured for over 150 years straight.  When you get out of a situation like that while part animal you are going to be a little crazy like and rough around the edges.Definitely a series I will dive into more by an author of another favorite series of mine, The Arcana Chronicles.

I had been eyeing this book for a while, seeing lots of great praise for it and finely treated myself to it because I love Samantha Young.  I found myself quickly immersing myself into the story and wanting to find out what happened next.  Granted I couldn’t help but feel that the story just didn’t stand out enough on it’s own to be remarkable to me.  It had great characters, and had I read it a year ago my rating would most definitely be higher.  However, I just felt like it had already been done.  Now yes, lots of books have similar plots/characters and they are amazing books, but there is usually something in the story that makes it stand out, makes it unique.  I just did not feel that was the case with this book even though I enjoyed my read.Here is what I am talking about:HOT Male lead that has money, runs a major business and is closed off, overbearing, and doesn’t want anything serious.Male lead is damaged from something in his childhoodAttractive female that hasn’t had sex in forever, intelligent but so overly attracted to the male lead she can’t help herself.female lead has a connection to something in the male leads tragedy.They must heal each other.Now, it did have a nice suspense/mystery aspect to it that was introduced towards the end that I liked because it rejuvenated my interested in the story and kept it fresh so my interest was held.I liked the book, I liked the characters, especially Caine’s next door neighbor.  It was just missing something to set it apart for me and make it more.

I am not sure how I feel about this book, and that is rather frustrating. The book was, as always with Jessica Park, a well written story with great side characters and development of emotion. My problem is not with it being a genre bending paranormal because I love paranormal and I read across genres all the time. So the best I can do is explain each thing that comes to mind when I think back on this book and hope it gets across what I need it to.First and for most I need to state that I am giving this book a 4 because while she very clearly states it is a stand alone I am beside myself with hope that she really means: it can be read as a stand alone but there will be more to come to help explain that which was left unsaid. If not, then my rating is really a 3.5 and not a 4 and I will explain why.From the start of reading this story I was grasping to understand the “feel” I was getting from the world being created for me. I knew I was going to be reading a paranormal but unsure what type exactly. We are first introduced to a situation that seems very normal, very contemporary with a side of girl your momma is f'ed up. This continues on until a main side character is introduced to us for the first time, Costa. At this point things go insane and my brain kept going whaaaa?! How the. . but what. . okayyy.Things get all paranormal and I start going along for the ride but the entire time I am riddled with questions and this is why I need there to be more because if this is the ONLY book on this story then way way way too much is left vague and unanswered. If this is truly the only book to be written on Death Trippers then I am left with tons of I don’t knows. Perhaps that is Jessica Parks intent, to write a story filled with mystery, intrigue and frustration because I know I am seriously frustrated. I need to know about the Dad, I need to know about the “under” I have questions of things that just don’t make sense and at least when I normally read paranormal the author tries to give some answers. Here with this book we are left with the characters saying they don’t know the answers either so you don’t get to know basically and it frustrates me too much to be able to enjoy the book fully.For a list of my questions see original reviewThen there is Costa himself. He is a freaking *bleep bleep*. There I said it. I know I was suppose to find redemption in him in the end and have sympathy for him and what was thrust upon him but seriously after what he did to Stella, nope. Again the explanation for him being the way he is doesn’t work so well for me because Sam had it thrust upon him in an even worse way in my opinion and the guy handled it.Not going to lie, this book was a bit twisted with the number of ways death is done. I found myself squirming at times especially with how death and sex played side by side sometimes. Again, I just didn’t know how to feel about this book, it pushed so many boundaries.The story was a good one and I really liked Stella & Sam but I am left wanting and needing more resolution. If there is no other book for the rest of the series, then the explanation that there is no explanation (for at least SOME of the unanswered questions) isn’t good enough in my opinion and feels like an easy way out of having to figure out some tough questions. When it comes to paranormal for me, the ones I truly love have perfected the building of the world and with Clear I am left without any understanding of the world I am living in as I read it.
They are dice, so they role with the punches.  It would be sad if there were only one, as it would then die.  Good weight, rolls well and plenty to spare when one goes wayward.

Do you enjoy a good physiological who dun it?  Need that fix of the dark and suspenseful?  Don’t mind some seriously messed up people?  This book is for you.  I started it is and found that after 20% I couldn’t put it down, I wanted to know what was happening.This book tells the story of a woman gone missing from the POV of three women who as time goes on it becomes quite clear are more than they seem.I found myself disappointed in the characters multiple time through out the story but the author was crafty enough to take the disappointment and disgust and mellow it out and make you want to read more, learn more about them.  I found myself thinking constantly after 50% “What is wrong with these people!??!”Rachel is the first woman we are introduced to and we see through her POV that she has crafted lives and personalities for the man and woman she sees each morning on the train to London.  She names them and stories for them, a rather innocuous thing that many of us make a game out of when we are people watching.  This takes a horrible turn into the sad and pathetic realm when a devastating revelation comes about that has Rachel wanting to immerse herself more into their lives.I did not see the ending coming early on, I was just as perplexed as several characters in the book. As the story unfolds and the clues get placed before you and the reality becomes clear you soon learn that some people are just messed the eff up in the head.A must read if you like a good psychological thriller and this one focuses the story around the women involved.  In fact I was reading this when I watched Gone Girl for the first time (never read the book) and it gave me that same people are messed up and omg feel.

Cyborgs, Androids, Plague, a Lunar race that has “magic”.  Sci-fi meets Grimm’s fairy tales. . .hell yeah!  I loved it.  I was captivated from the start.  Loved the marriage of a fairytale we know and love with a futuristic world.  Cinder is not a damsel in distress but a strong fighter of a girl who has been through a lot in her young life.  With no true fairy godmother though she has to find her own pumpkin to transform into a carriage.The story was compelling and grabbed my attention from the start when we meet Cinder, a mechanic.  Her world is a less than glamorous one but she fights and works to do what is right despite the prejudice against her.The world building was done well, allowing me to become completely immersed in New Beijing and Cinder’s life. I could see this story playing out as a movie easily the visuals were so clear. Everything came alive and my emotions for her were real.  I was hopeful, scared, sad and disappointed along with her as the story unfolded.I did find myself glossing over parts towards the end, feeling some descriptions just weren’t needed to progress through the story.  I don’t mind detail, they add to the image in my mind, but sometimes I just didn’t feel it was warranted for me to enjoy and again, skimmed.I am eager and interested in finding where this goes and will pick up the next book soon.

I know this is a well loved book and has won Pulizter Prize but I was left with a feeling of wanting and basically a bit let down.  I expected to read a book with a main focus on Callie and being born a hermaphrodite with supporting histories spanning the 8 decades the synopsis speaks of.  However, what I got was something that felt much more like two separate books.The first 50% of the book is background story of Callie/Cal’s heritage.  Who he came from, where he came from why he came to be before he ever came to be.  Some of the details seemed unimportant to that aspect unless in fact the main point of the story was the history of this family.  So I diligently read the first 50% with Cal interjecting from time to time and narrating in an omnipresent way that rather baffled me.  Still I wonder how he supposedly knew all he did.  For me it would have been much better narrated by an unknown all seeing person that would allow me to explain away how I was be informed about stuff that Cal would have never known.After 50% we start getting into more of Cal’s childhood, his life and being him.  But unlike the first part of the book where he seems to know everything, talking about himself instead seems rather difficult.  It is as if he is not comfortable describing his life and giving much details and this felt rather frustrating.  Even if it is a device or perhaps a way to emphasize how he feels about himself it was rather annoying after the time I spent getting to know his family when what i wanted was the exploration and insite into Cal.It was not until 80% when I finally got what I was looking for when I started this journey of a novel.  For me this is what I thought the focus would be and it is where I finally became engrossed again in the story.  Truth is between 60 & 80% of the book I contemplated putting it down and walking away I was so frustrated.  I am glad I stuck it out but still it was not enough of an ending to make up for the blah of the middle.  For me it felt like two separate books and I would have happily read the book on the family history as a separate story all together and then one on Cal/Callie if only the depth of exploration in to Cal’s life was further explored.A very informative read that I found enlightening in many ways and am glad I read but not sure I will ever explore it again.

This was a fun historical romance that had me smiling and interested the whole time.  With a heroine like Genevieve who is smart, intelligent and very clever I never felt like I wanted to hit her over the head.  She called things as she saw them and often saw straight through the actions of another, namely the Duke.  Though blind to some things she quickly figures them out and corrects any errors she made.  I really enjoyed reading a heroine that wasn’t easily duped or played dumb.The Duke is a quintessential alpha male intent on receiving his revenge.  When his plan is foiled, so to speak, he starts at another objective to “help” Genevieve.  Through the days of the house party we watch the romance blossom.  Barbs and innuendo are thrown back and forth which I delighted in.There is not much else that occurs during the course of the story besides the interactions between the Duke and Genevieve which made the story feel light.  Not much depth to the story either but still plenty of wittiness and “cleverness” to delight me and make me want to know what will happen next.I really enjoyed this one and am happy I read it as it seemed to help pull me out of a funk I had the week prior.
Plush and nice, my daughter loved.  He gets walked around with and has lasted thus far.

Worked well for my daughter's ear when it started hurting.
