Unfortunately I am unable to review the program itself as I wasn't able to get the downloaded software running.I downloaded the application, it started, then kept telling me I needed an update to run it. Every time I'd update, it would tell me again to update.I tried calling the manufacturer but they were only open pretty much business hours, times that I was at work or traveling, not weekends or late evenings. People use software like this in their spare time, which is to say often not during business hours. I wish I had known prior to purchasing and wasting over an hour of my time that 1. the product doesn't work properly and 2. the company does not provide adequate support hours.

I have a cabinet full of low-fat, plant-based, whole foods cookbooks and I know this one will be the most used of all of them.I cannot state emphatically enough how amazing it is that this book brings to the reader traditional comfort food in an EASY and healthy package. You will find many of your old favorites reborn into healthy dishes. I am amazed at how Ms. Campbell was able to accomplish this with such simplicity of both ingredients and preparation.This book is beautifully presented. It is professionally designed and laid out with professional color photographs for nearly every dish. I'm not sure what it is that makes it easier to select a recipe if there's a great picture, but the author and publisher were smart enough to realize this and I appreciate that. Everything looks delicious, and the recipes are all so simple and reasonable to make, but at the same time come out so good. Healthy has never been so easy or so tasty.The book begins with a short introduction that manages to stuff a lot of good information into a small space without rehashing everything else done by all of the other cookbooks for this audience. It gives sound advice for those transitioning to a plant-based diet.The book is then divided into Breads & Muffins, Breakfast Dishes, Appetizers & Salads, Soups, Sandwiches, Entrees,Side Dishes, and Desserts. Appendices include metric conversions and an index.New family favorites from this book include Fiesta Corn Bread, Apple Turnovers, Lemon Tahini Quinoa Salad, Sesame Noodle Salad, Tomato Tortilla Soup, Thai Wraps, Asparagus Crepes, Seasoned Mushroom Soup, Macaroni Squash, Moroccan Eggplant. The Coconut Mango Pudding is to die for!No added oil in the recipes. A very small number of recipes include a very light handed use of nuts/seeds. This book does have a number of recipes with wheat ingredients, so if you are gluten free and not an old hand at substituting ingredients you may have to pass on some of the better recipes.The author uses sucanat as a sweetener, but you can obviously substitute another sweetener of your choice. There is an occasional use of tofu or non-dairy milk. Recipes use reasonable convenience foods, like whole wheat tortillas or canned tomatoes. If you are a purist, you can use fresh ingredients instead.

I grow scarlet runners every year. They are a beautiful, easy to grow low maintenance vine, the hummingbirds love them, and the beans are absolutely delicious.These are the best scarlet runner seeds I've used yet. They are very big and I experienced 100% germination from them. I soaked them the day before I planted, but you don't have to do that to have success. My plants are really healthy and grew faster than I expected. They will trellis on anything nearby and are vigorous but don't get out of control.The beans can be eaten with the whole pods (like a string bean) when young or as shelled beans when they mature a bit more. Personally, I don't like them as a whole pod because they are a little fuzzy and the texture just doesn't appeal to me. The beans can get pretty big, but are best when not fully mature as they are more tender. The mature beans can get close to an inch per bean, but I like to eat them when they are between 1/2 and 3/1 inches per bean. The beans are a really pretty pink mottled with a brownish purple when raw, and cook to a browner color. Picking the pods enhances new pod growth. They will rebloom and produce beans all summer if you keep picking the beans.Definitely pretty enough to be part of an ornamental garden, with the added benefit of being a great food producer. You'll be sorry if you hide these on a back fence or behind other plants in your garden--give them a featured spot.I've placed a picture of the raw beans in a bowl the photos for this product so you can see how pretty they are.

I use these as part of my supplementation to keep my CFS/ME at bay (see my review of a CFS book here for more details: http://www.amazon.com/Chronic-Fatigue-Syndrome-Treatment-ebook/product-reviews/B009B9X36Y/ref=cm_cr_dp_synop?ie=UTF8&showViewpoints=0&sortBy=bySubmissionDateDescending#R13OCLNDXU6UT).They work well and I am happy with the quality.These come in blister sheets (10 tabs per sheet) packaged in a square paperboard box, and NOT in a bottle as shown. The pills are very small and easy to swallow, which is an issue for me as I have swallowing problems from the CFS/ME.You have to take these about half an hour before eating or drinking, so make sure that fits into your lifestyle.

These are great for my fruit and vegetable bins. I don't have to put everything in the reusable freshness bags, so it's easier to see what's in the bin.You do need to leave some spaces in the bin so air can circulate--these won't work well in a stuffed bin.

These bags do what they say they do. They definitely keep things like my delicate greens for about twice as long as they would last in a regular plastic bag. They work about as well as other brands I've tried.My biggest complaint is the color of these bags. The other brands I've used were colored either green or pink, so it's easy to tell that they are not the disposable grocery store bags. These bags are clear like the grocery store bags, so it's harder to tell that they are not disposable. That's not a problem for me since I think about those things and know what's in the reusable bags, but for family members and guests it's not obvious that these are reusable and they have been inadvertently thrown out.UPDATE 13 August 2013These bags don't hold up over time. I've had to throw over half of them out by now because they rip. Other brands I have purchased never ripped. Because of the lack of durability. I cannot recommend this product.

This is a great redesign of the Apple ear buds. They fit nicely even in smaller ears, and are designed to take different ear sizes into consideration. They fit snugly but comfortably.I use hearing protection often, and these buds actually work well under protective ear muffs. They stay in my ears under hearing protection (unlike the previous types) and allow me to listen to music or audiobooks when I'm working.The audio quality is a definite step up from the older design. The sound is so much more of what you should expect for a digital sound device. Everything is clearer.The controls are good and easy to use.

This is a light but reasonably durable collar. The breakaway release works, but isn't so sensitive that it comes off all the time. Does well on my three indoor/outdoor cats. I took off the bells because I thought they would catch on shrubbery and make the collars more likely to come off.Easy to adjust, and the color looks surprisingly good on a variety of cat coat colors.

I'm Hungarian and paprika is a national pastime in Hungary. While this isn't a Hungarian paprika, it is an excellent addition to any spice cabinet. The taste is bold, rich, and smokey (obviously), but with very little bitterness compared to most other paprikas. The smokiness overpowers the sweet, so it's not as sweet as an unsmoked sweet paprika. This isn't a spicy paprika. It has excellent dark red color and great aroma. It blends well into liquids.It can be used alone as a more subtle seasoning, or if you want to really up the effect, mix it with just a little liquid smoke and/or toasted sesame oil to enhance the smokiness and add more complexity of flavor.The canister is a bit difficult to open. You'll need to use a knife to pry it off, and if goes back on tightly so you will have to do that every time, not just on the first opening. I'd be happy to see a packaging redesign for an easier to open canister. The canister itself is attractive enough to display with other containers on an open shelf--it doesn't look like a typical cheap mass market spice jar.

I am very happy with this bin. It's a decent size, so I don't have to empty it several times a day, but not so big that it's visually overpowering on my counter.The ceramic crock is a nice quality and doesn't look like a cheap plastic garbage container sitting on my counter. It's heavy enough that it doesn't get knocked over or pushed around, but the plastic liner is light and makes it easy to take the compost out. It's also easy to clean.No odor problems so far, but I typically take the scraps out after I cook and rarely leave it more than a few hours if I don't.

This is a good book. I'm not all raw but eat mostly raw foods. I eat mostly salads, so I am always looking for variety. This book gives a nice variety of salads that are easy to prepare using normal ingredients. Lots of variety of both taste and ingredients. I have tried several recipes in the book and have enjoyed them all so far. They aren't just your typical lettuce and dressing, and very little use of nuts and seeds.The book is divided into two sections: dressings and salads, with an appendix on raw basics and an alphabetic recipe list. Dressings include Cayenne Tahini, Easy Garlic Avocado, Tomato Extravaganza, Cinnamon Thyme, and Latin American Fiesta Vinaigrette. Salads include Jicama Soul Slaw, Carrot and Orange (a family favorite in my house), Asian Sesame Cucumbers, Garlic Grapefruit, Tomato Corn Salsa.I like that the raw basics are put in an appendix and not the focus of the book. The basics are basic recipes, not basic how-tos. Too many cookbooks these days include the how-to basics in all of them in detail, so I end up with a shelf full of basics books with some recipes almost as an afterthought. I don't need to read 20 books on how to julienne carrots. The focus in this book is on the recipes.My biggest complaint about the book is that it includes the use of oils. Oils are a fractionated food, not a whole food, and therefore, in my opinion, not a suitable part of a whole foods diet. Easy enough to substitute out.Based on how happy I am with the food that I make from this book I plan to order a couple of others of hers.

First, this isn't a diet book. If you are looking for recipes or a specific menu plan, this book does not contain any.It's mostly a reflective piece on the journey Patenaude has gone through to become increasingly dietarily rigid to a point where he no longer has any "rules," with some dietary suggestions that you can choose from. Patenaude talks about the physical and emotional problems of a purely raw diet, and how he worked through those issues to find a solution that works for him. He's not suggesting his specific solution to his readers, but informing them of what problems exist with a raw diet balanced with what problems exist with the standard American diet (SAD), and how we can each find our own sweet spot somewhere in the reasonable middle ground.I eat a diet with a lot of raw foods and have been all raw. My doctor supports both approaches. As a scientist myself, while I have found and reaped the benefits of such a way of eating, I have been horrified by the pseudoscience claimed by many raw foodists about the benefits of eating raw. Patenaude covers all of those myths and discusses why they are incorrect, which I very much appreciated. I think a diet high in raw foods is healthy for a number of reasons, but I would like to see valid science used to support such a way of eating, not wives tales that make the general public unnecessarily skeptical of the raw or high raw lifestyle and that make us look like a bunch of uneducated kooks.I also appreciated Patenaude's discussion of raw lifestyles as well as the variety of lower fat vegan diets (McDougall, Esselstyn, Fuhrman) as well as the comparison.If you've read Esselstyn, you know he believes that "moderation kills." McDougall has a similar philosophy. That is, most people in developed nations aren't able to eat a healthy diet with occasional splurges--we are too gluttonous and can't just have one cupcake once in a while. This is true for some people. This is also true for people who have already developed serious diseases of excess, such as heart disease, diabetes, or serious chronic inflammatory diseases. This is also more true for the older population who are suffering from the results of a lifetime of excess. But it is not necessarily true for those who have not yet eaten themselves to the edge of the grave or for those who are younger and have not yet reaped the punishments of decades of such self abuse. This book is for the healthier and/or younger folk who have not yet found a happy, healthy middle ground. This book is NOT for those with heart disease, diabetes, etc. If you are in that category, you would be better served by the suggestions of McDougall or Esselstyn and probably do need a strict and more restrictive way of eating.I also agree with Patenaude's discussion of the amount of fat we should have in our diets. He basically does not take the once size fits all approach of 80-10-10 or Esselstyn or McDougall. The 10% fat approach is appropriate for some, but not all. I maintain a total cholesterol in the 130s with 12-17%. That works for me, and is where I feel best. My mother is older and needs a lot less fat in her diet, more in the 5-10% range. An endurance athlete may need more like 20%. Patenaude has a sensible discussion of this, and also a discussion of what happens on a diet too high in fat, particularly a raw diet too high in fat. I found this a useful section.Patenaude's book is also only for those who have overcome their food addictions and don't suffer from binging issues. He has some suggestions for those who do have cravings and who binge, so those may be valuable to you, but be aware you may just be one of those people who can't have one french fry and walk away. That's something you will have to evaluate for yourself. If Patenaude's book is anything, it's an homage to the discovery of moderation through a lifetime of deprivation. Which is good for those able to be moderate. Unfortunately, that's just not all of us.If I had to select an overarching theme for the book, it's self tolerance and self forgiveness of not achieving dietary perfection, and finding that sweet spot for you where you are free to eat whatever you want at times (within reason) and yet remain healthy.I find most of the dietary suggestions firmly grounded in science, with the exception of the suggestion for a calcium supplements. (The science I have read does not support the use supplemental calcium). The book provides a very practical approach to diet, with a dual focus on health and reducing/eliminating "rules" that restrict your life through your diet. While the emotional and psychological approach in the book is relatively unique, the actual dietary suggestions didn't seem too different to me than what Joel Fuhrman suggests or what you might deduce about diet from reading the China Study.This book is useful for anyone who has or is exploring a raw or cooked plant-based diet. I am not sure it is relevant to those just starting out on a healthy path or those on SAD who don't understand the subcultures of the plant-based world. But for those of us who do, I think it's a healthy, important discussion of topics relevant to our lifestyles, whether we agree with all points or not.

This is a good mask. Light but sturdy and does not bother their eyes.My only complaint is the sizing. If you have a horse with a big head or from a larger boned breed, order sizing as is. If you have a finer boned breed, order a size down. I have finer boned horses and the masks are all too large.

I ordered the mini size for my very mini donkey. The ears are way too large and the throatlatch is too small. If you have a mini donkey, order a size up from mini and expect the ears to flop over.That said, he no longer has horrible scabs in his ears from the flies. This mask does a good job of protecting him, I just wish it fit better.
Good value for basic paper. Does not curl in my laser printer like many other lower-cost papers, no jamming. Arrived in good condition in a sturdy case box. I will order again.

I owe a debt of gratitude to the author. This book gave me the tools I needed to solve the puzzle that is (was!) my CFS/ME.The book discusses all available treatments, including diet, supplements, medications, and lifestyle. All of the material is supported by the best available data and the book is full of relevant citations.Anyone who has this condition knows it's a huge mystery. What causes it, how to live with it, and how to treat it. The author realizes that the condition isn't the same for each individual, and therefore, neither is the treatment. So she presents an incredibly comprehensive look at pretty much every legitimate treatment out there. That's the good news. The bad news is that each of us with this life-stealing syndrome will need to do the work to figure out which treatment protocol, or which combination of protocols, will work for her or him.Prior to this book, I discovered that a mostly raw, low-fat whole foods vegan diet free of gluten helped somewhat, but didn't completely eliminate my CFS. I am one of those who has a high oxidative burden and therefore needs a high level of antioxidants in my diet.I did numerous painstaking elimination diets with the hope that I could rid myself of a trigger food or two (or even ten) and be cured. What I was missing in my personal CFS puzzle was the supplements. As the author states, some people need a diet like mine, and others need a lot of meat. We are all so different.But after adding a selection of supplements suggested in the book I experienced my first REAL 100% remission and became my old self that I missed so much. I worked hard, gardened and did hours and hours of yardwork a day, and felt GREAT. I had a relapse the last couple of days because I tried to add some wheat to see if I could do this on supplements alone, but it is clearing from my system and I will now do some more tweaking of my diet to see if there is still work to be done in that area.I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this book to anyone who has CFS/ME or even fibro or who cares about someone who has it. But you will have to do some of your own detective work to figure out which protocol or combinations you need. Be methodical, and be persistent, and stay strong. If there's an answer for you, there's a good chance it's somewhere in this book. You must be willing to be your own advocate and detective, but don't give up! If I can beat this, you can too!Even though the answer is different for all of us, I will post my own plan that put me in remission in case someone finds it helpful:PUZZLE PIECE 1: DIETI am one of those who has a high oxidative burden and therefore need a high level of antioxidants in my diet. I also have a few trigger foods, particularly wheat. I can tolerate a small amount of a trigger on occasion, but more than just a taste will set me back.I eat a whole foods, low-fat, vegan, gluten-free diet. Dairy, meat, and wheat fatigue me physically, and wheat also adds brain fog. I don't eat fractionated foods. That means no added oil, even olive oil. Oil is a fraction of its source. So are things like refined grains, table sugar, etc. Basically, if I can't easily separate something from its whole source in my own kitchen (example: squeezing lime juice from a lime), then I don't eat it.I eat a small amount of fatty whole food with each meal to help ensure uptake of fat-soluble vitamins (like pumpkin seeds, flax seeds, and avocado), but I keep my overall percentage of fat from calories below 15% per day. I eat as much of my food raw as possible, about 75%, but do eat some cooked food with dinner most days, as cooking makes available some nutrients that aren't as available in the raw food (for example: lycopene in tomatoes or beta carotene in carrots or sweet potatoes). I have a whole foods, gluten free starch with most meals (quinoa, sweet potato, red potato, banana/plantain, etc) for slow release but sustained energy. Processed starches, such as white sugar or rice flour or most processed foods have just the opposite effect and cause problems with insulin and sugar spikes--a big no-no.The dietary changes also eliminated my muscle soreness and headaches (migraine quality). Completely.I also have white tea every morning as it has virtually no caffeine and a very high antioxidant level. I avoid stimulants of all kinds, particularly caffeine and chocolate.As an aside, my diet has improved other aspects of my health, including reducing my cholesterol from well over 200 to 134, reducing my BP, and reducing the inflammation in my body to the point where things I considered part of aging (like gum disease) just went away.PUZZLE PIECE 2: HORMONESI have had thyroid disease for decades, so I need supplementation. I am also peri-menopausal and on recent testing have found I have virtually no progesterone in m body. So I need to supplement progesterone. Inadequate supplementation of either thyroid hormone or progesterone result in a small increase of fatigue and a giant increase in my brain fog. My mental clarity is entirely dependent on both of these hormones. I recommend all women, regardless of age, with severe brain fog should be tested for their hormonal status, both thyroid and sex hormones. I support my family through a very cognitive job, so I need to keep the brain fog at bay to keep my home and feed my family.PUZZLE PIECE 3: SLEEP/RESTProgesterone supplementation significantly helped my sleep, especially since it eliminated night sweats. Also, I make sure I get a sufficient amount of sleep to the extent that I try most days to sleep until I wake naturally, not until an alarm goes off. Oddly, this is one of the harder things to adhere to given the way we live in our society. On the days when I do need to wake using an alarm, I use one that monitors my sleep cycles so that I wake during light sleep, not deep sleep. This is REALLY important for me otherwise my sleep is not restful. I use an app on my phone for this called Sleep Cycle-- it does not require any additional hardware.I'm not a napper, but there are days when I know I need to just stop and rest for a little while, so I try to pay attention to that as I've learned that a short rest can prevent a complete relapse.PUZZLE PIECE 4: EXERCISEI LOVE to exercise and be physical. This was a huge element of life I lost to CFS. Staying active when I'm in remission is important, and light activity when I'm in a relapse is also important, although due to my love of physical activity I have a hard time with the concept of "light" activity and on days when I could drag myself outside I always did too much when I was in a relapse.PUZZLE PIECE 5: SUPPLEMENTSThis was my final puzzle piece. The doctor who diagnosed me with CFS/ME told me she thought mine was due to a mitochondrial disorder. Basically, this means that my body was getting energy from my diet, but not really burning it in my cells (which happens in the mitochondria). Kind of like a car having a tank full of gas, but not getting enough gas to the engine to burn so that it will run properly.I took this to heart as I believed her to be correct due to my specific symptoms, and when I read this book I focused on the protocols that treated mitochondrial dysfunction. So my supplement regime includes: ribose, NADH, acetyl-carnitine, co-Q10, magnesium, B-12, selenium, and lysine.Prior to adding the supplements, I had partial remission and occasional glimpses of full remission. A hour or afternoon or once in a long while a good day. But never consistent remission to the point where I was my old energizer bunny self. The supplements, when combined with all of the other lifestyle changes, was the final key for me. And I don't think I would have found that piece without this book.PUZZLE PIECE 6: DRUGSThat same doctor prescribed ritalin for me to help with the fatigue. It was useful for days when I absolutely HAD to be functional and was in a bad relapse, but the doctor recommended it daily and used like that over time the ritalin ended up draining me more. It made me be active on all days when I just didn't have the energy (which was just about every day), and that's not a good thing as it ended up draining me more. I now avoid the ritalin for all but an emergency situation.A doctor prior to that tried to put me on anti-depressants. I don't know why most doctors can't understand that while CFS/ME has symptoms in common with depression, and there are a select number of patients who have both CFS/ME and depression, for most of us it is NOT depression and anti-depressants don't work. In fact, for me it made things worse as I was still fatigued and the meds made me feel even less normal.So that's my new life. Most people around me think it's a crazy, restrictive lifestyle, but for me it's freedom. It's freedom from the insanely debilitating fatigue and brain fog that left me alive but not really living. It's the freedom to now have CONTROL over how I feel and how much I can do. And it's the freedom of being myself again. It's a choice I gladly make every day.Again, I thank Erica Verrillo for contributing to my solution and for writing such a comprehensive and excellent book. I couldn't have done it without her.

I live out in the boonies and have a sensitive septic system. I've tried supposedly flushable wipes, but my septic system does not like them.These do the job to help keep me clean and don't clog my pipes and challenge my plumbing. I also like the small size--I'm not a baby with a dirty diaper and I don't need a giant wipe.

I have chronic fatigue syndrome. I do a lot of things to fight it, nutrition, sleep/rest, moderate exercise, and supplements.Nutrition/sleep are the most beneficial, but after that, this supplement contributes most to helping me fight the fatigue. It's the only supplement that gives me a definite, distinct, and nearly immediate benefit in terms of combating fatigue.My doctor tells me my fatigue is the result of a mitochondrial disorder, so it makes sense that this will work because it gives my mitochondria one of the building blocks it needs to help produce ATP, which fuels my body.If you are dealing with fatigue, I'd recommend trying this. I mix mine in with a smoothie in the morning, and just mix a little in a glass of water if I need a boost in the afternoon. Since ribose is a type of sugar, it's sweet tasting, but not the same neutral sweet as white table sugar. If you are sensitive to taste, you may need to mix this in with a smoothie, juice, coffee, tea, or your oatmeal. If not, just mix a little with in a glass of water and shoot it down.I purchased the Now Foods brand once and it had such a horrible chemical smell that even from a couple of feet away I felt like I was being exposed to a harsh, nasty chemical. No way I could get near it, let alone eat it. I've never had any problems with any Source Naturals supplement, and recommend this specific brand and product.

I used these while on  a commercial growing project, and now use them at home to start seeds. Nothing works better.I like the larger ones because my plantlets can grow a little larger before I transplant them. Easy to seed as well. The divot in the top allows for better seed placement and fewer wayward seeds, especially with smaller one.These pots also make it possible to start indoors plants that normally are hard to transplant since they significantly reduce transplant shock.These are great for most seeds, but a little small for larger seeds, such as pumpkin, squash, or beans.

These have turned an unpleasant stuffing of pills down my dog's throat into something he enjoys. My dog needs to be medicated with two pills twice a day. Not very fun with the old-fashioned stuff-it-down-his-throat method, but with the pill pockets he gets treat time twice a day instead.In fact, I use it as a training opportunity. Since he knows this is part of his schedule and anticipates it, it's easy to add some training to pill time, which means I get free training twice a day. I ask him to sit, down, do a trick, whatever, and he does it happily and it reinforces things for him.For the pills he is using, I am able to break off 1/3 of a pill pocket, flatten it out, put both pills on the flat piece, then fold it over and roll it into a ball. Saves a lot of money and works just as well as using a whole pocket.

I purchased this for use as part of a treadmill desk. It seemed like a perfect solution.In terms of size and speed, it's fine, but the motor can't seem to even handle moderate walking. It groans and slows with each step (I'm about 150 lbs, and it did the same thing with a 110lb family member). Additionally, the belt slips to one side regardless of how I adjust the tension.Golf Outlets was gracious about an exchange, but the same things happened with the second treadmill, therefore I am concluding that it's an engineering.manufacturing problem and not an isolated defect.I do not recommend this product.

Smelled so strongly of acetone or a similar chemical that I was afraid to use any of it. Reported this to the manufacturer and the FDA. So far, no response from the manufacturer.I can not recommend this product.

These are adorable cookie cutters and a big hit with everyone in my house. A family member even made a gingerbread dojo using these. Came out great.A very nice change from bunnies and trees (not that there's anything wrong with bunnies and trees).

I bought my daughter a blow dryer caddy for Christmas that hands on a towel bar. I wanted to put a bar on the side of my bathroom vanity but it's a small area and I couldn't fit a drill in there to use a screw-in type towel bar.I bought this not expecting it to hold up and figuring I'd have to find some other way to secure it. Well, the darn thing is still up there months later, taking the abuse of the daily slinging of blow dryers, curling irons, flat irons, and other hair appliances. I'm very impressed with how it's holding up.It's also very attractive and does not detract from the rest of the bathroom.Recommended.

I eat a lot of apples, so I use this once, twice, sometimes three times a day. It has held up well so far for several months of this daily use.Slices them well and easily and cleans up well. The padded handles make it comfortable to press down.Another reviewer complained that some of the core gets into the slices. I've noticed that can happen if the apple doesn't sit square on the counter, with the top level. Some apples just grow in a way that makes them a little tilted. So for those apples I simply slice the bottom just enough so that the apple sits on the counter properly and the core is perpendicular to the counter. Press down, and the core stays in the center.

I am not sure if it's my frame or the canopy, but it sags and collects water in heavy rain. This did not happen with my OEM canopy. I have tried making several adjustments, but it still collects water and one or two sides will come off the frame from the weight of the water from a heavy rain.My initial review was 5 stars, but I reduced it to 3 because of the water collection problem. If I find a resolution, I will post that and adjust my rating accordingly.UPDATEThis canopy was useless after less than 3 months. I wouldn't stay up because it didn't fit properly and the color faded from the sun and seemed to degrade the fabric.Not recommended.
Fabulous germination rate--almost 100%. I tasted a tiny leaf and it's great. Little plantlets are growing right now. They are hearty and beautiful. Expecting great things upon maturity.
Fabulous germination rate--almost 100%. Little plantlets are growing right now. They are hearty and beautiful. I tasted a tiny leaf and it's great. Expecting great things upon maturity.

You get TWO pieces of hardware in each box, enough for one saw horse. If you need one sawhorse, order one of these. If you need two saw horses, order two of these.These sawhorse brackets make it quick and easy to make your horses.Cut your top piece to the width of your table. You can use a 2x4 or a 2x6. Drill a hole in each end of the top piece to attach it to the hardware.For the legs, cut (4) 2x4s. There's a paper jig in case you want to cut them on a beveled angle for a more stable horse.Slip the legs into the hardware, then tighten down the wing nut on the bolt. A few cuts, two holes, and some twisting. Pretty easy.The only criticism I have of this is the actual hardware they give you to tighten down the apparatus. If you use the wing nut, you will never get a stable saw horse. Even if you have hands of steel and are able to get it wrench tight by turning the wing nut, it will open on its own eventually and your horse can wobble or just fall apart.I solved this by exchanging the wing nut for a locking washer and nut and used a deep socket ratchet to tighten it. (You could use a wrench, but there's not a lot of room to turn it because of the positioning of the legs, and you'll need a deep socket because of the length of the bolt). I understand the manufacturer wanted something easy to use and open, but since it doesn't provide the most stable end product, they should at least include something like the option I used for mine, so I took off a star in my review for that.

I've got am expensive water system that kills microbes in my well water, but it always tasted swampy. The Brita makes the water very palatable and easy to drink and saves money on bottled water as well as landfill space from all of the bottles.The slim pitcher doesn't take up much room in the fridge and works fine for the three adults in my household.

I have been doing project management for years and can't imagine functioning without these file folders.The old manila folders we are used to seeing are great for filing. These are not for filing, but for USE of your files. When I have manila folders on my desk, I can't see what's inside and I'm always fishing around to see what's on the tab and whether that's the folder I want. These don't need to be labeled because you can see the top page (you can just leave your papers in there or make a project cover sheet, which will show through the clear plastic.)They are sturdy, retain the pages so much better than paper folders, and withstand anything that spills or drops on them. No more crinkled folders and pages, no more coffee cup rings.Very protective for files that need to go with you to a job site or construction site. Overpriced at most stored, but less than half the cost on Amazon.Highly recommended.

This is a very cute sponge holder. The suction cups work well and I don't have much trouble keeping it on the sink (my sink is stainless). The only caveat I have is that if you have water high in minerals that tends to leave deposits, they will show quickly on the bronze finish.

Very happy with this powder. I sue it when I want to add richness to soups, stocks, stews, whatever. A little bit adds a subtle amount of umami and richness (not necessarily identifiable by most as mushroom flavor), and if you use more the mushroom flavor is more pronounced. It doesn't take much to really enhance whatever you put it in.

This is a really cute hose hanger. I have several of them, both for the house and barn. They are sturdy and hold up well to daily use and give a little flair to what would otherwise be a bland functional item.Recommended.

For some reason stores no longer seem to stock veggie brushes, and those that do only offer cheap, ugly plastic ones. This is a nice brush, and I like that it has both a soft side for more tender fruits and veggies and a harder side for food like beets or potatoes.I store mine bristles down to help drain water. If you store this bristles up, it doesn't dry as fast and the wood will discolor from the water damage.Recommended.

I have some old Hungarian family recipes that call for sour salt and couldn't find this stuff anyplace. So I checked Amazon and was so happy to have found this. This tastes great in my stuffed cabbage and other dishes and the bulk packaging means I won't have to reorder any time soon.

I was really surprised to find out how well this bar works. I was a bit skeptical, but am very pleased. This is the only antihistamine that gives me relief without any drowsiness or other side effects. I take half a tablet usually, and that's plenty for me. This is a good buy for a hard to find battery. These batteries works just fine and I appreciate being able to find them online.

When I think of menstrual cramps, I think of pain, agony and feeling like I'm being tortured from the inside. I have tried heating pads, medicines and the like. Nothing has helped. Not until I tried one of these MenstruHeat pads. Oh sweet relief!The pads come in individual packs, so you don't have to worry about whether you are getting enough use out of it. No need to worry about having an outlet nearby simply because these pads heat up via an air activated heating patch. MenstruHeat uses a gradual warming technique that heats up within 5-10 minutes of use, so that your body can get accustomed to the heat for most effective relief.These pads can be taken with you anywhere and they last up to 12 hours. I just lay on the couch or in bed with mine and let the MenstruHeat pad work it's magic. When I say "oh sweet relief" I truly mean it. Heating pads just cannot do what these pads do. These pads were designed to get into the areas that heating pads cannot.I have been convinced that MenstruHeat was designed with women in mind and worth the price. My kids, husband and I are into remote control like toys. They are tons of fun and can keep you entertained for hours on end. The RC Tire Twister resulted in many hours of giggles, ooo's and aaah's. So this product is more suitable for the young ones over the older ones. It came packaged very well and it was pretty easy to put together and set up. We love that you get a 2 in 1 product here. You can easily take the car out and let it go on an adventure. I recommend use this toy on hard floors over carpets. With carpet, pieces can get stuck in the wheel and that's not always a good thing. It can damage the toy or result in one big mess to clean up. We love Little Tikes toys and feel it is a trusted brand for our kids (and us adults too who are still kids at heart)!

When they say Clinical Strength, they truly mean it. I love the scent too. Very subtle yet feminine. *I received a free sample of Secret Clinical Strength deodorant as a member of One2One Network.

I have loved Elizabeth Strout's writing ever since I read--and reread--"Olive Kitteridge," so I leapt at the chance to review her new book, "My Name is Lucy Barton."  This latest of her books is shorter than the previous two, and I think it is more personal as well, though I have no way of knowing how much of the action, if any, comes from real life.As the book opens, Lucy Barton, a successful writer, is in the hospital with a mysterious complication of surgery that is never fully explained.  She remains in the hospital for nine weeks, largely isolated from the outside world--her husband hates hospitals and rarely visits, and her two daughters are too young to come on their own.  Suddenly, Lucy's mother, whom she has not seen in several years, shows up and stays with her in the hospital for five days.  During this time, the action alternates between the present and Lucy's past, her childhood and young adulthood, and the reader gradually comes to an understanding of both Lucy and her mother.  The two reminisce about various events and persons from the past, and in particular, they discuss the marriages of various friends and relatives.  As the book develops, the reader sees that all this talk of other people's marriages is a way for both Lucy and her mother to avoid the elephant in the room, their own marriages and relationships.Lucy's mother's visit is not all sunshine and roses.  In chapters alternating between past and present, we see the truly terrifying past that Lucy has overcome, and her mother's limited awareness of the damage she has done to her daughters and son.  Lucy's brother and sister are mentioned in small but important glimpses into the past, and the reader sees the childhood of poverty and abuse that is her heritage.  Despite all this, however, Lucy loves her mother and desperately wants her approval.  She slowly comes to a realization of who she is--the time in the hospital could be compared to an extended retreat, without the religious element--and we see the results of her epiphany in the last part of the book.I loved the way this book was written.  There is very little action; most of what happens is conversation and memory and conversation about memory.  The point of the book is the development of a self, an identity, an awareness of who you really are--thus the title:  "My Name is Lucy Barton."  The book reads very quickly--it has fewer than 200 pages--but it will stay with you long after you have read it.  I recommend this book for anyone who enjoys contemporary literary women's fiction.

I am always reluctant to spend money on good freezer bags, and I alway pay the price in other ways.  I do a lot of quantity cooking and then freeze individual portions in plastic bags for later use.  These bags are superb for that purpose.  Though they are a little more expensive than regular bags (with a twist tie for closing them) or zip lock (the original kind with the seal you have to work at to make it seal properly), they are definitely worth the extra money.  The slider is sturdier than most I have seen, and the bag itself holds a great deal.  I tend to reuse bags if they are not dirty, and these hold up well.  Highly recommended!

Battleship is one of those classic games that seems to have been around forever.  I remember my brother (now in his 60s) playing it as a kid.  I was intrigued by this new version, and as my nephew is a great Star Wars fan, I decided to field test it on him and his friends, who are all 11 or 12 years old.  They all know and like the original game.The directions to the game are easy to understand.  The point of the game is to destroy the other player's fleet of ships.  There is no difference between the Star Wars version and the original version except that some of the pieces are characters or ships from Star Wars.  You could enjoy this game even if you had no previous knowledge of Star Wars, but it would appeal to you more if you were a SW fan.I always wonder about the educational value of games, but this one, according to my nephew, has no educational value.  There is some strategy involved, so maybe you could say that it sharpens a player's thinking skills.  It is scaled quite small, and I am not sure it is worth the price.  Still, if you like Star Wars, you would definitely have fun with this version of Battleship.

This chocolate is exceptionally smooth and delicious.  The chunks of nuts and fruit are large, and the bar separates easily into individual rectangles for easy serving. I think the candy is a little pricey, but it is definitely of high quality.  The packaging is amazing--the box it comes in is obviously made to order for the chocolate bars, which means that your candy is protected in shipment.  Highly recommended if you don't mind the price.

This is a charming little ABC book for preschoolers.  It is subtitled "A Natural Alphabet," and I found that it was true to that in many ways.  First, the animals and other items named in the book are somewhat unexpected.  For example, E is for egret, and Y is for yellow-bellied sapsucker.  I can imagine kids having fun with the language of the book.  Second, the illustrations are lovely.  They have the look and feel of woodcuts, though actually they are paper art.  Finally, the colors are subtle and beautiful.  There are grays, yellows, blues, browns, pinks--but nothing bright or garish.  (If you want bright colors and cute animals doing human things like washing dishes or cooking, this is not the book for you.)  This book would be a lovely and inexpensive shower gift.  Highly recommended.

I ordered this shaver for my husband, who is used to the Norelco brand but wanted to see what else was out there.  First of all, the user manual for this shaver is almost overwhelming, but don't be intimidated.  You don't have to use every aspect of the shaver, such as the self-cleaning/auto clean aspect.  For my husband, manual cleaning is fine.  Just figure out how to turn the thing on and you are good to go.This shaver gives a very close shave, somewhat closer than the Norelco, which was not bad either.  However, it is just a little noisier (but not all that noisy), and to get that close shave, you have to hold the shaver at an angle.  If you are used to the Noreco, which angles the shaving apparatus for you, this may be a little awkward at first, but you will appreciate the closer shave.All in all, this is a great shaver.  It is a little pricy, but it does a very good job and does not irritate your skin.

I was a little skeptical when I ordered this Black and Decker iron to review.  B&D makes products at all price points, and most of my experience has been with their less expensive brands.  However, I took a chance with this iron and I am so glad I did.  This is by far the best iron I have ever had.  The directions are intuitive and easy to follow.  The iron is clearly marked with five different heat settings and three steam settings.  It is easy to fill and seems to be extremely well-made.Of course, none of this makes any difference if it doesn't iron well.  I am thrilled to say that I have never had better performance out of an iron.  It easily gets the wrinkles out of both sides of trouser legs or knit tops.  I would recommend this iron to anyone who is looking for great performance at a fairly reasonable price.The only caveat I have about this iron is that it is quite heavy.  Three years ago I injured my wrist and had to get a lighter-weight iron.  Today I can manage the weight of this iron pretty easily, but I still notice the weight.  If you have arthritis or other issues with strength in your hands, this may not be the iron for you.  Otherwise, buy it with confidence.  You won't be disappointed.

I purchased this robe as a gift for my niece.  She loved it, and she used it the very day we gave it to her.  It is warm and very comfortable.  it has an inside tie that helps keep it closed in addition to the belt.  It runs somewhat large, in my opinion.  We bought the size S/M, and I think that if you are really small, say size 6 or less, you may swim in this robe.  My niece is about a size 10, and it seemed a bit large even on her.  Other than that, this robe is great.

I love this enormous Boss Office chair.  It arrived earlier than I expected, by freight truck, not UPS or FedEx.  The driver brought it into my foyer, and my husband and I opened it immediately.  It was packed perfectly, with no loose ends.The chair came in five parts, not counting the screws. At  first we were delighted to see that there were only five parts, as we thought that meant that assembling it would be a piece of cake.  However, we were quickly disabused of this idea.The assembly instructions are located on one sheet of paper, and except for two sentences, they are all pictorial.  After we finally got the chair together, the instructions made sense, but trying to figure out exactly how to make everything fit was problematic.  There is an 800 number on the assembly sheet to call for help, but after several minutes on hold, I gave up.  Fortunately, my brother is skilled at figuring out how to put things together, and he came over that evening.I highly recommend that when you assemble this chair, you enlist the help of at least one and preferably two other persons--you need the third at the end, which I will explain below.  Brother Tom, the expert, said that while it would be possible for one person to assemble it, it is far easier with two.  He figured out how the parts went together and from that point on, we easily matched the screws with their appropriate holes.  The company provides an Allen wrench for your convenience, but you will also need your own Phillips-head screwdriver.  After the chair itself is assembled, you have to drop it onto the base, which is where you need the third person, two to hold the chair and one to guide it onto the base.The chair itself is beautifully made of high quality leather.  It is extremely comfortable with superb lumbar support.  It is meant to accommodate persons weighing up to 350 pounds; thus its heaviness.  The wheels are already attached to the base and roll smoothly over even our deep carpet.  I have been using it a few hours a day since we assembled it, and I love it.  If you are sitting in the chair, it is easy to adjust the height downward; to go up, I had to get out of the chair.  This is almost certainly my own issue, something I have not quite figured out about how to go up while sitting in the chair, but it is not a problem for me because I am the only one who uses this chair, and I do not change the height.I am delighted with this chair, and I highly recommend it.  Save yourself time and frustration; enlist a helper to assemble the chair.  From that point on, I bet you will be delighted, too.

These are excellent towels.  They are large and absorbent, and they look nice hanging from the oven door.  Be sure to wash them before using them, or you will not see their absorbent quality very well.  My only issue with them is that they do not dry quite as quickly as my old towels, probably because they are better quality.  Highly recommended.

My husband and I enjoyed all six flavors of coffee in the Java Factory Variety Pack.  By far our favorite was Choconut, a blend of chocolate and coconut, but we also liked all the other varieties.  The only other flavored coffee was a French vanilla; the others were normal coffee flavor of varying strengths. All were smooth, with no bitter taste or post-coffee stomach upset.  We have used about half the box, and all have worked perfectly in our basic Keurig (NOT the Keruig 2.0).  My only issue is that the flavors are not evenly alloted; there are more of the "regular" coffee and fewer of the flavored coffees.  In fact, our favorite, Choconut, had the fewest of all.  But that was a minor problem.  We are still enjoying the coffee and recommend it without reservation.

I was attracted to this product by the Delta brand and reputation and the water temperature sensor.  The shower head itself is very lightweight and easy to handle in the shower.  I love the temperature sensor and so does my husband.Installation was easy except for one thing.  The instructions (which are very easy to follow) indicate that a washer was needed.  At first we could not find the washer, so we tried to install without it and the shower head leaked badly.  So we searched the packaging for the washer.  Be advised that the washer is located in the wrap-around packaging at either end of the "cord" part of the faucet.  It occurred to me that this might be the case; we checked, and there it was. I had discarded this material at first, so be aware that the washer is kind of hidden in the packaging.  Other than this, installation was no problem at all.One reason I decided to get this shower head is that my husband's shower stall is extremely small, and the old shower head "cord" stuck out and took up room he didn't have when he showered.  This cord seemed more flexible, and it is, slightly.  But it still is an issue in a tiny shower stall.  This is definitely not the fault of Delta or the product itself, but it is something to keep in mind if you have a very small shower stall.In my opinion, the price is a bit high, probably because of the sensor technology.  However, the product is excellent, and I recommend it.

I was attracted by the colorful complexity of this toy when I volunteered to review it for Amazon.  A good friend has a six-year-old grandson, so I asked her to "field test" this product.  While it is rated for ages six and above, there is no way a six year old could put this toy together.  To be fair, this fact is clearly stated upfront, but at the same time, a toy that requires this much adult intervention is challenging at best and frustrating at worst.The many (100) tiny plastic pieces are brightly colored; they are individually numbered to correspond with the pictures and diagrams in the instruction booklet.  Assembly took two hours, partly because the pieces were extremely hard to snap together.I can see that this toy has the potential to be a great deal of fun for a young child.  However, for this to occur, all the parts would have to remain secure and the marbles wold have to move through the chute effectively.  This did not happen.  The gear handle that operates the toy fell off repeatedly, and the marbles had trouble moving through the spiral tube.A child of 12 or older might be able to assemble this toy, but would he or she have the patience to do it?  I tend to think not.  It would be nice if this toy were capable of being redesigned or repurposed for more creative play, but it is not.  Once assembled, it does not have enough flexibility to hold the interest of a child.I cannot in good conscience recommend this toy.  If I had purchased it, I think I would have returned it.  Caveat emptor!

"All Dogs Go to Kevin," a clear reference to "All Dogs Go to Heaven," is a delightful book that will be loved and appreciated by anyone who loves dogs and has ever had a dog share his or her life.  Jessica Vogelsang, the author, details her own coming of age and her relationships with the three dogs she has owned:  Taffy, Emmett, and Kekoa.  She begins the journey in middle school and takes us on an emotional journey through high school, college, veterinary school, and marriage.The book is engaging and very easy to read; even kids in upper elementary grades would be able to manage it.  However, the part I found most compelling was the role that dogs play in the lives of, as the author puts it in her dedication, "the misfits, the miscreants, the misunderstood, the freaks and geeks and socially inept, and the dogs who love them."  It is clear from the outset that the author sees herself as one of these "misfits" who found salvation in the love of a dog.  She write with grace and compassion of her relationship with both animals and people, and she clearly does not write off anyone, no matter what issues they may have.Some reviewers have compared the book favorably to James Herriot's "All Creatures Great and Small."  I do not share this view.  I found Herriot's books far more charming and compelling and have read each one several times.  This book is just not in that category.  However, that is not meant to dismiss the many virtues of this book.  Almost any lover of dogs would enjoy and identify with the characters in the book, especially the author.  I recommend it highly, and if you are not expecting Herriot, you will enjoy this book exactly for what it is.

I love cookbooks and have far too many, even after having donated several dozen to our local library booksale.  My favorite kind of cookbook is one that you can read like a real book; one that has comments about each recipe and personal stories to accompany them.  "Goldie's Kitchen Cookbook" is exactly the sort of cookbook I love.  Written (or collected) by a writer of mysteries whose work I have never read, this cook book connects each recipe with one of the author's works.  Each has an introduction detailing the connection with the book, the personal experience of the author with the recipe, and any caveats about challenges you may encounter as you prepare the recipe.The recipes themselves are not the "simple and easy" kind, but they are not overly complicated, either.  The author often urges the cook to use the best and freshest ingredients available, which is a great suggestion no matter what you are preparing.  Some recipes are ultra simple, such as Green Beans Amandine, which is exactly what you would expect, a simple preparation with salt, pepper, and butter to add flavor.  Others are longer and more complex, such as Shuttlecock Shrimp Curry, but none are truly complicated.  I look forward to reading and re-reading this book and to trying out a great many of the recipes.  Anyone who loves both cooking and commentary would love and appreciate this book.  Highly recommended.

As a retired English teacher, I am always looking for interesting and amusing ways to teach language concepts.  The title of this book, "My Teacher Is an Idiom," suggests that it will introduce young children to the concept of idioms, and indeed it does.  It describes what an idiom is, gives many examples, and even investigates the idea that different languages have different idiomatic expressions.Where it falls down, however, is in the "interesting and amusing" category.  Perhaps second graders will be captivated by the borderline cruel Patrick and his hapless victim Richard, but that may be too much to hope for.  The third main character, Sophie, a transfer student from France, is better, but only somewhat.  The two boys run afoul of school rules and are required to do a presentation about good manners.  If this does not sound particularly interesting or amusing to you, that is because it is not.  I have a feeling kids will be bored with this book and set it aside about a third of the way through.That said, it is easy to read, written on a very basic reading level.  I cannot in good faith recommend it, but if you decide to get it, it will teach your child about idioms.  There are, however, far better ways to accomplish this.I

"The Year She Left Us" by Kathryn Ma is the story of a multi-generational Chinese American family told from multiple points of view.  At the center of the story is the youngest member, Ari (short for Ariadne), a very young adult who is trying to come to terms with having been abandoned as an infant on the steps of a Chinese department store and adopted by a single parent, Charlie (short for Charlotte), a Chinese American public defender with more than a touch of social worker in her.  The other major narrative voices are those of Charlie's sister, Les (short for Lesley), a lawyer/judge, and their mother (and Ari's grandmother), Gran.  Each of these women is complex and interesting, each strong in her own ways.As the book opens, Ari has graduated from high school and is on her way to her grandmother's alma mater, Bryn Mawr.  She decides to visit China with her closest friend, A.J., who is also a Chinese adoptee, to see the orphanage she was adopted from and to determine whether her birth parents ever regretted their decision to give her up and tried to retrieve her.  The reader realizes that this is futile, but it is important to Ari, who is suffering from many of the issues that beset adopted children, especially those of abandonment and the fantasy of "what might have been."  In China, Ari suffers what can only be called a breakdown and does something irrevocable to herself, a highly symbolic act that I will not reveal.Meanwhile, at home in San Francisco, Charlie is living in major denial that anything is wrong with Ari.  She wants her to come home in time to get ready for college; she has no clue as to Ari's true state of mind.  Charlie has a secret of her own, one that is not revealed until midway through the book, but it has a major impact on all the characters.  Les's importance as a character increases as the book proceeds; despite being sisters, Les and Charlie  are very different personalities with diametrically opposed approaches to life.  Gran has the strongest personality of all.  She and her sister left China after World War II, leaving their entire family behind to deal with the horrors of the Communist regime.  Gran has more secrets than anyone else, and some are revealed only in the final chapters of the book when she herself returns to China for a visit.Most reviewers would classify this book as a coming of age story, and indeed it is, but it is also a family saga, a cautionary tale about the corrosive power of the past and its secrets, and the dangers of not dealing with reality.  Frustrating as all of these characters are, they are also endearing; the reader cannot help but feel affection and sympathy for each one of them.  The writing is superb; if I have any issues, it would be with the pacing of the book about a third of the way through, when it seems just a bit sluggish.  The second half, however, is riveting; it was hard to put the book down.I know personally some young adult adoptees, and the issues Ari is dealing with seem authentic and well defined.  I hope to share this book with my young adoptee friends, as well as with their parents and others who are trying to help them deal with their issues of abandonment and identity. I give this book my highest recommendation.

This is a very heavy and sturdy pie plate.  I not only made a chicken pot pie very successfully, I also used this pie plate as a weight for a crust I wanted to pre-bake briefly.  It worked perfectly.  The only problem is that you cannot see how brown the crust is (the way you can in a Pyrex or other glass pan).  Despite this,  I like the pan; the crust browns evenly, and if you have a recipe you trust and accurate oven temperature, you should be fine.

"We Are the Goldens" is very fast paced and easy to read.  Written in the form of a long message from the younger sister, Nell, to her adored older sister, Layla, the book covers nearly one school year, a year in which Layla begins to lead a secret life and involves Nell in keeping this secret from their divorced parents.  The specific nature of the secret is not revealed until about midway through the book, but the perceptive reader will have guessed it long before that point.  Much of the conflict in the book centers around Nell's discomfort with Layla's refusal to share what is going on with their parents, and the fact that she has to bear the burden of Layla's deception alone.As their name suggests, the lives led by Nell and Layla are privileged:  They are from upper middle class families, go to private schools, and are endowed by nature with physical beauty, athletic, artisitic and literary ability, and keen intelligence.  However, the "gold" of their lives is not all it seems.  There is a cancer beneath the surface that goes unnoticed amid all the distracting glitter.  One authentic bright spot, however, is Nell's relationship with long time "friend who happens to be a boy" (as opposed to boyfriend), Felix, who is (as much as he can be at his age) the moral center of the book.  Nell is also testing the waters of her own first sexual relationship, with less than stellar (though not disastrous) results.  And for those who like a bit of the supernatural in their YA novels, Nell also gets advice from the "ghosts" of two brothers, friends from the neighborhood who died in separate incidents the previous year. These brothers visit her at various crisis points throughout the novel, offering perceptive advice and perspective.  The parents in this family are essentially good people, upper middle class, divorced, each loving in their own ways--but they are largely excluded from the emotional lives of their daughters.I would classify this book (just in time for summer) as a beach read for young teens.  There are some good points made about the corrosive power of secrecy and the burden it places on those who share our secrets.  In addition, the book has a strong message about  appropriate sexuality and the ways young teens explore their sexuality.  (However, there is very little explicit sex in the book; most of this exploration is by way of recollection and consequences.)  Though I liked this book, I do not think it is great literature.  It is enjoyable, however, and I do recommend it.

My husband uses this product, and it works superbly.  He says that the taste is good; he does add about half a teaspoon of sugar.  Be sure to let the tea steep the recommended length of time.  Highly recommended.

This DVD was a gift for my nephew, Evan, and he reports that there is nothing about it that he did not like.  He was already a big fan of "Gravity Falls" and was thrilled to get the DVD, which has all sorts of extras on how the television show was made.  There is also a little booklet accompanying the DVD that was an unexpected extra.  The picture clarity is superb, and it is very easy to navigate from scene to scene if you want to skip around as you are viewing.  Highly recommended for all fans of "Gravity Falls."

"Close Your Eyes, Hold Hands" is a book you will not soon forget.  Set in the present (or possibly near future) in Vermont, it concerns a meltdown at a nuclear plant (think Japan's Fukushima Dai-ichi in 2011) that has a predictably searing effect on the main character, 16-year-old Emily Shepard, whose parents are implicated in the accident and are both killed.  As the book opens, Emily is homeless, living in an igloo she has constructed of trash bags and wet leaves with a nine-year-old companion, Cameron.  How she got here is the subject of the book, and it is a coming of age tale for the ages.I will not spoil the book by revealing too much, but you should know that Emily goes through the tortures of the damned in so many ways:  physically, psychologically, spiritually.  Imagine months of life on the streets of Burlington for a homeless teenage girl, and you will not be far off the mark.  Emily is a marvel, however.  She is by turns and all at once insightful, childlike, hopeful, cynical, intelligent, honest, deceitful, passionate, caring, lost, and found.  She quotes Emily Dickinson at length and often, and shows uncanny insight.  The author, Chris Bohjalian, has a pitch-perfect ear for the bright but disillusioned teenage girl voice, and this is evident from page one.  (To be fair, he credits his young adult daughter for her help in achieving this.  Still, it is amazing.)If this book interests you, I recommend that you listen to the NPR interview with the author conducted by Diane Rehm in July of 2014.  (You can find it on the Diane Rehm website and listen to the entire thing or read a transcript.  I recommend listening.)  In that interview, I was surprised to learn that the author did not envision this as a YA novel.  Although much of the subject matter is very adult, this is not unusual for today's YA literary scene, and I thought from the first that this book would be the next new thing in YA literature.  That said, I can see it as an adult novel as well, one that adults and teens might profitably discuss together.Hats off to Chris Bohjalian for creating Emily and letting her tell her story.  This is a novel you won't want to miss.  Highly recommended for everyone from mature teens to adults.

If you are looking for a great gift for someone who loves dogs, you could not do better than Ace Collins's "Man's Best Hero."  Collins is obviously a dog-lover himself, and this affection shows in every page.  Whether he is recounting the exploits of dogs on the battlefield or showing how the relationship with a dog can transform a hardened criminal, Collins makes each dog a unique "personality."  The book is short and very easy to read, and since there is no continuing story line, it lends itself to short reads when you have only a few minutes.  While I am at the cat stage of my life now, I have owned dogs in the past, and I can testify to the love and loyalty they offer and inspire.  Anyone who loves dogs will be delighted by this book.  Highly recommended.

I got this shaver for my husband to try.  He has been a committed Norelco man for as long as we have been married (38 years), and I was wondering if he could be charmed by another brand.  In addition, I liked the idea of a charging station that could be used as we travel, since in foreign countries you cannot always count on being able to use your own electric gadgets without an adapter.  I am pleased to say that he is very enthusiastic about the shaver.  It has the same basic design as the Norelco (three floating heads) and gives a very close and smooth shave.  It is easy to clean and the charging station is easy to set up, though directions could be a little more clear in this respect.  Once you figure it out, however, it is a piece of cake.One thing I cannot evaluate yet is how long the heads will keep giving this close shave, and this is important as replacement heads are not cheap.  This is one downfall of the Norelco brand--sometimes it is just easier to buy a new shaver than to buy replacement heads because of the price.  I am hoping that the Remington will last a long time and continue giving a great shave.My husband did not test the shaver in the shower, but other reviewers did, and you can read their remarks.  Highly recommended.

The Fisher Price Dora and Friends Cafe is a charming toy, and it is appropriate for toddlers as well as preschoolers, as long as you keep a watchful eye for small parts.  The cafe is easily put together except for the staircase, which took several tries before it was secure. It is nice that batteries are included, and  the toy has a lot of potential for imaginative play.  There are two caveats, however:  the toy includes only one figure, Dora; it would be nice if there were at least a couple more figures included.  The preschooler I tested this toy on used his imagination and cut out the figures on the packaging to use as extras.  In addition, I am not sure the price is appropriate.  While there is a sound/spoken word aspect to this toy, the rest of it is basically plastic.  At this price, I would expect at least two additional figures to play with, so I am not sure I can completely recommend the toy.  Still, both Brandon (5.5 years old) and little brother Joey (2 years old) found ways to enjoy this toy, so I do like it.  Recommended with reservations.

I ordered this book because my husband is a railroad enthusiast, and I knew that he would be able to help me review it honestly.  In addition, the is a DK book, and for those unfamiliar with DK travel books, they are a delight.  Although other books may provide more text, DK books offer a wealth of photos, maps, and drawings.This book, "The Iron Road" by Christian Wolmar, has exceptional drawings, photos, maps, and graphics, but in addition, it provides a superb and detailed text.  The book is divided into five sections, each dealing with an aspect of railroads around the world in chronological order.  Many books have examined the engineering of railroads, but this one also deals with the human aspect of railroad construction, especially the intrigue and greed that form the backdrop of many railroads.  Most readers, unless they are well acquainted with railroad history, are unaware of the human cost of rail expansion, not only in the United States but around the world.  Wolmar recounts this human cost with compassion and insight, never over-dramatizing it, but making sure the reader does not dismiss it.In Australia, for example, rather than standardize the track width, 22 track widths were used, a case study in how not to create a railroad network.  Why did this happen?  Every rail baron wanted to be first to get his piece of the railroad action.  This greed precluded cooperation and set Australia's rail system back decades.The transformative effect of railroads on society cannot be overestimated.  In addition to travel, industry,  and commerce, the impact of railroads on war, especially the American Civil War and in Europe, World War II, is covered in detail.  The role of rail transport in the mass deportation of entire populations to prison and extermination camps in Germany, France, Poland, and China is recounted.  Railroads in Asia and Russia are significant, too.  This book reads more like an adventure story than a history; indeed, if history were taught this way in schools, many more of us would know it and learn from it.I recommend this highly readable book to anyone who is looking for a good general history of railroads around the world.  An expert will likely know most of what is in this book, but the general reader will not.  This is a perfect book for the general reader.

I am stunned that this is Celeste Ng's first novel.  I was instantly drawn into this book, with its beautifully drawn characters and superb writing.  On its surface, the story is a mystery:  What led to the death of Lydia Lee, a sixteen-year-old honor student with (supposedly) everything to live for?  In reality, the mystery goes far deeper, into the lives of each member of the family.  By the end of the book, the reader is fully in sympathy with each character.The novel, which takes place in the late 70s,  begins with Lydia's death.  Was it murder?  Was it suicide?  Or was it something else?  The reader spends most of the novel thinking one thing, only to be surprised at the end with the truth.  The author delves into the lives of each family member:  James, the father, who never felt really at home in any situation; Marilyn, the mother, whose dreams were shelved by the demands of marriage, family, and the times; Nathan, the older brother, whose brilliance is overlooked; Lydia, the golden child burdened with all the frustrated aspirations of her parents; and Hannah, the overlooked afterthought of a child, a silent but keen observer of everyone in her family.  (I was torn between imagining the author as Lydia or as Hannah; I suspect she is an amalgam of both.)Many chapters in this novel focus on just one character, telling the story from his or her point of view.  The reader is led to an understanding of just how profoundly even the best intentions can go terribly awry.  Once again, we see people living out their own frustrated dreams through their children, who may or may not be on board.  The term "helicopter parent" comes to mind, though this idea was not in vogue until the 90s.  In addition, issues of race in America  and women's roles are explored through the parents, James and Marilyn, who came of age in the 60s and early 70s at the height of the sexual and civil rights revolutions.  Even gay identity comes into play, and remember that this novel is set in 1977, not 2014.I am compelled to praise the writing of this book.  Both psychologically astute and poetic, it draws the reader into the story and evokes sympathy and awe.  We see the devastating grief that overtakes each member of the family as he or she tries to see why Lydia died and what he or she may have done to prevent it.  I also loved the way the author treated memory, that old deceiver, who smoothes out that which we cannot bear to recall.I do not think this book is marketed as a YA novel, but it is certainly a book that parents and teenagers may profitably read and discuss together.  The issues  are fresh and relevant, and I can imagine that meaningful discussions and insights may result.  Highly recommended for all readers 14 and above.

Katherine Howe's "Conversion" is an exploration of two parallel stories: the Salem, Massachusetts witch trials of the late 17th century, and the appearance of a mysterious "illness," or symptoms that come suddenly upon the (mostly) senior girls attending an exclusive Catholic prep school, loosely based on the Le Roy Mystery Illness of 2012 in New York.Most of us know, or think we know, the story of the Salem trails, in which adolescent and pre-adolescent girls claimed to be possessed by Satan as the result of having been cursed by one or another of the women in the town.  Sixteen women were convicted of witchcraft and put to death, and only fifteen years later did one of the accusers, Ann Putnam, confess that the girls had been either faking or deluded.  Her confession is included in the book, but it does not totally resolve the mystery of what went on in Salem.Fast forward to 2012.  We find ourselves in Danvers, Massachusetts, at St. Joan's Prep School, where girls are under extreme academic, social, and emotional pressure.  Suddenly, three of them begin to exhibit unusual symptoms for which no physical explanation can be found.  Enter a round of media attention, self-proclaimed experts, conspiracy theories, and panic.  As more and more girls exhibit stranger and stranger symptoms, few adults are able to remain rational.  Bizarre theories are floated to explain the symptoms, and none proves definitive.The book is structured so that most of the chapters are set in the present and told from the point of view of one of the most rational of the girls, Colleen Rowley, although even she falls victim to whatever is happening eventually.  Every two or three chapters, we go back to Salem, where Ann Putnam, now in her late 20s or early 30s, is confessing what really happened back then to her minister, the Reverend Green.  In both instances, the symptoms make the girls celebrities of sorts in their communities, and it is strongly suggested that the desire to be noticed, to be paid attention to, is a major part of whatever is happening--not consciously, in every case, but on some level.  Malevolence is not ruled out as well, especially in Salem, and especially with one of the girls.A major theme of this book is that everyone involved, both in Salem and at St. Joan's, hijacked the crisis and made it fit their own agenda.  The author does this very skillfully in both instances, though I think young readers will naturally find it easier to relate to the modern story and see more clearly how adults manipulate events for their own reasons, consciously or not.  Especially odious in this regard are an obnoxious parent and a self-aggrandizing celebrity with a new theory as to the cause of the illness.I liked this book very much.  The parallels between the two events are skillfully drawn, and the characters are mostly relatable and attractive.  Readers who think they know about the Salem witch trials because they are familiar with Arthur Miller's "The Crucible" will be in for a surprise--I liked this part of the book especially, as it reinforced the theme that no matter what historical event a person writes about, he or she will do so with a particular point of view, and will therefore select some events and omit others to reinforce that point of view.I am eager to hear what younger readers have to say about this book, and I will be lending it to my nieces to get their opinions.  This would make an interesting summer reading assignment for high school students, especially those in honors or AP tracks who may be facing the same pressures as the girls at St. Joan's.  Highly recommended.

Count me among those who were immediately involved in E. Lockhart's "We Were Liars."  Readers both young and old will be captivated by the characters and the superb writing, which combines everyday life with a hint of magical realism.As other reviewers have noted, the plot revolves around the Sinclair family.  When you imagine this family, think of a cross between the Kennedy clan and a Ralph Lauren print ad in an upscale magazine.  This is an old money family, with more than its share of secrets, prejudices, rituals, and customs.
