The patriarch of the family owns an island off the coast of Massachusetts, to which his three daughters and their families come each summer for a golden idyll in a magical place.  At least, this is the way it is supposed to be, but that is a lie, and it is just the beginning of lies.Now think of King Lear, and you will have an idea of the sort of father this patriarch is.  The daughters are not exact parallels to Lear's daughters, but there are enough resemblances to keep the reader interested.  The focus of the book is on the next generation, the children of the three daughters (and their friend, a contrast both in culture and social status).I hope no one reviewing this book has revealed the plot in too much detail.  You will have to trust me when I say you will not see the final plot twist coming, though when you re-read the book (as you will feel compelled to do), you will see all manner of foreshadowing and hints.  This book is an examination of the lies we tell ourselves and each other to live harmoniously on the surface of our world, and the price those lies exact.  I am recommending this book to all my reader friends, and I will be sharing it with my nieces, who I am confident will love it.A final note on style:  You will occasionally encounter a disconcerting narration that seems at first literal, but is in fact magical realism.  For example, when Cady Sinclair Eastman, the 15-year-old narrator of the book, is recounting her parents' divorce, she describes her father packing his things into his Mercedes.  Then you read this:  "Then he pulled out a handgun and shot me in the chest.  I was standing on the lawn and I fell.  The bullet hole opened wide and my heart rolled out of my rib cage and down into a flower bed.  Blood gushed rhythmically from my open wound,then from my eyes,my ears,my mouth.It tasted like salt and failure.  The bright red shame of being unloved soaked the grass in front of our house, the bricks of the path, the steps to the porch.  My heart spasmed among the peonies like a trout.Mummy snapped.  She said to get hold of myself."My first thought upon reading this was that Cady's father had lost control and actually shot her.  The mother's comment makes clear, however, that this passage is a poetic description of how devastated Cady was at her parents' separation.  This sort of thing happens throughout the book, and I came to enjoy the poetic imagery.  Just don't take these passages literally.I hope you enjoy this book as much as I did.  Highly recommended.

I have long been a fan of Cutter products, as we live next to the Cuyahoga Valley National Park and enjoy its facilities frequently.  Cutter products have always been effective, so I was eager to try this new spray as it was described as "dry."  I was very pleased to see that it dried almost on contact, and it had absolutely no offensive odor.  In addition to mosquitos, ticks are becoming more of a problem in our area, so an effective repellent is a must.  I recommend this product to anyone looking for effective, comfortable, and odor-free insect repellent.  I wish I could spray it on my brother's dog, as she is a tick-magnet and my brother is always finding them on her.  But I am not sure it is approved for animals, so I cannot recommend this.

I regret that I am unable to recommend these dry-erase markers.  The colors are very nice, but two of the six tips were damaged before we used the markers even once.  The tips are very fine, so fine that it is hard to make a continuous line on a dry erase board without going over your work.  If you want an ultra fine tip, you may enjoy these markers, but in general, I would recommend the usual felt pens made for dry erase boards.

In a recent purge of our bookshelves, my husband, a retired math teacher, donated his copy of this book to our local library.  Of course, six months later he wanted it back, and we were fortunate to find this copy on Amazon.  It has no bells and whistles, no colorful pictures or cutesy approaches, just clear, direct explanations of all aspects of analytic geometry.  He is tutoring students in high school geometry, and although much of the material in this text is beyond the scope of most high school curricula, he is finding it helpful to review some of the principles in this book.  This text is a classic, and it is particularly good in its approach to matrices and trigonometric functions.  It emphasizes the use of matrices in solving equations.  Though this text was written nearly sixty years ago, it is still relevant.  The examples for each concept are clear and the practice problems are excellent, and answers are given for the odd numbered problems.  The section on solid analytic geometry is extensive.  I highly recommend this text to anyone desiring a thorough understanding of analytic geometry.

I like canned tuna a great deal and always buy solid white, usually packed in water.  I decided to get this tuna and I was so happy with it that I ordered four more cans.  The tuna is packed in oil, and it looks great in the can--perfectly solid with no little flakes.  I decided to try it on greens with just a little fresh lemon and a few extra veggies, and a tiny bit of Hellman's mayo.  It was excellent.  I was going to make a regular tuna salad with onion and celery, salt, pepper, and mayo, but I decided I like the tuna flavor "straight."  I am delighted with this tuna and recommend it to anyone.  I will be buying this from now on, even though it is a bit more expensive than supermarket brands.  The quality is well worth the cost.

This is an excellent gift for any parent (or other interested adult) who wants to encourage in kids an interest in science in an engaging and fun way.  The "experiments" are not difficult, and they do not require too much parental involvement, though you may want to get in on the fun.  They do not require any special equipment that you would not be likely to have around the house, though you will need a number of common household items.  I actually think this is a plus, as you can do the experiments again and again if your child shows interest.  Many kids younger than eight would be interested in these activities, though they may need help reading the instructions.  We are having a hard winter here in northern Ohio, and I think many parents would love this science kit to help keep their children entertained and learning in a fun way on the many "snow/calamity days" we have been having.  Directions for the experiments are clear.  I do recommend this product.

I was looking for a coffee maker that would allow me to use my own coffee rather than the very expensive single-serve cups.  The Hamilton Beach fits the bill really well, and you will be satisfied as long as you do not expect it to do things it was not designed to do.  For example, it will not keep your coffee warm, as there is no warming plate.  I like the size of the coffee maker and the stainless  steel finish, and I find that it is easy to keep clean.  There is a little splashing as the coffee is being dripped into the cup, but it is easy to clean afterward.  On the recommendation of other reviewers, I purchased the replacement filters for Aeropress, and I find that they catch most (but not all) of the coffee grounds.  There is a backup filter, so it catches any grounds that escape before they get into your coffee cup.  I am very pleased with this product and would recommend it to anyone who does not want the more expensive single serve system.

I ordered these filters on the recommendation of another Amazon reviewer when I bought a single serve coffeemaker that allows you to use your own coffee without a special cup.  I like the filters, and I find that they eliminate most of the stray coffee grounds.  I find that some coffee grounds do escape the filter, though there is a secondary filter that catches them.  In the meantime, these little filters make it easier to clean the primary filter.  Therefore, I do recommend them and will buy more when I run out of these.

"No Book but the World" is a a very thoughtful, philosophical novel that is on its surface a family saga/crime story, but is in reality a meditation on the limits of human freedom and the existence of free will.  The main characters, all adults, are brother and sister Ava and Fred, and their childhood friends Kitty and Dennis (who by the time of the novel is married to Ava).  The principal narrator is Ava, who has always felt a combination of responsibility and resentment for Fred, who is impaired in some way that is never fully defined.  Ava and Fred's parents were followers of the philosophy of Jean Jacques Rousseau, especially with respect to his views on education.  They founded a free school based on Rousseau's principles, and Ava and Fred were brought up there in relative isolation from the real world.  This is important because of the interplay of imagination, freedom, and reality that is a constant motif in the book.  Kitty and Dennis are brought up much more conventionally, but they remain close friends.As the book opens, Ava is trying to find out what is going on with her brother, who has been accused of a murder.  There are long sequences of memory and description, and if the reader is looking for a fast-paced, plot-driven narrative, he or she will be very frustrated.  There is little dialogue, and what dialogue exists is only a springboard to more memories and philosophical musings.  The book is divided into five sections, with Fred, Kitty, and Dennis each narrating one, and Ava bookending them with the first and last.  The reader learns about the unusual relationship between the parents and the children, and all the linkages between the past and present.  The events of the present, with all their legal ramifications, are also explored.The theme of this book is most aptly summed up in the frontpiece, a quotation from "Promenade" by Maria Irene Fornes:  "I know everything.  Half of it I really know.  The rest I make up.  The rest I make up."  This quotation gets to the heart of the book:  What do we really know?  How accurate are our memories?  How do we frame the story of our life so that it makes sense?  How much of what we think we know is really wishful thinking or imagination?  All of these questions are explored in great detail through the narrative.This book is not for everyone.  It is extraordinarily well-written, but the long ruminative passages will be off-putting to some.  However, if you know what to expect and you are interested in a reflection on memory, imagination, and freedom set within an unusual family, you will find this book ultimately rewarding.

I gave the Alpha Explorer to my cousin to evaluate with her five-year-old son Brandon.  Brandon was ecstatic when he saw the toy, saying, "I always wanted a space ship, and no one ever got me one!"  He loved playing with it from the start, and he told his mom he wanted an entire galaxy in his living room.  So Laura blew up balloons of different sizes and hung them around the living room, creating our solar system for Brandon and his space ship.  Brandon was in heaven.This toy is durable, and it makes several sounds, both words and "spacey" noises, and this brings me to my one issue.  When the toy was delivered, it was making a beeping noise (which I am sure was delightful to the UPS driver).  We opened the box immediately and fiddled with the batteries, but we could not make the noise stop until we changed the batteries.  We read in the instructions that this sort of event is an indication that the batteries are nearly spent.  The new batteries worked fine, except that now the toy is very sensitive, and even a slight jostle will set it off, making some sort of noise.  This is startling and disconcerting unless you are expecting it, and I advise that when you are not actually using the toy, you store it where it cannot be moved.Still, that is my only caution.  Your preschooler will get hours of imaginative play out of this toy, so I do recommend it.

"Doing Harm" is Kelly Parsons first novel, and it is the best novel I have read since "Defending Jacob."Steve Mitchell is a chief resident in surgery and is the supervisor of a group of medical students at Boston University Hospital, a teaching hospital associated with BU.  Steve, who is in charge of making these students into doctors, is married to Sally, a stay-at-home mom who used to be a high-ranking assistant to the head of Human Resources at the hospital, where the two met.Sally and Steve go to Dr. Collier's annual cocktail party.  Collier is Steve's boss and chairman of Steve's department. Sally wants Steve to become a member of the faculty of the medical school, which would be an enormous advancement for him.  She hints at this to Dr. Collier, with whom Steve is scheduled to meet in the next week.  At the meeting, it seems that Steve will get his promotion, but then things become a little crazy at the hospital.Two of Steve's new students are Luis, a very serious and conscientious student, and Gigi (which stands for Golden Girl), a very bright student who is perhaps a little too smart for her own good.  After Steve is promised the promotion, very bad things begin to happen.  Medicine is not given in the proper dosage, patients go into comas, and some do not ever come out.  All of these events are blamed on Steve and his students, and soon, even Steve's favorite mentor will not allow Steve near him in the operating room.Does Steve get to the bottom of these mysterious events?  Is he destroyed mentally and professionally in the process?  Read this superb novel and find out.This is a very well written novel.  The characters were very realistic, and it is easy to see that the author has first-hand experience in a hospital.  If I could, I would give this novel ten stars.

In the interest of full disclosure, I must admit that when I ordered this SteelSeries 9H Gaming Headset, I thought it would be appropriate for my husband to use.  He enjoys flying on the Microsoft FlightSimulator, and I thought he would use and enjoy this headset.  However, we soon discovered that the headset is meant for other sorts of games.  As neither he nor I is a gamer, I asked my nephew to field test this headset, and he and his son (who is nine) have been using it for about two weeks.  Here is his evaluation:The first impression of the SteelSeries 9H Gaming Headset is the feeling of quality you get when you take it out of the box.  The headset itself is sturdily made, and the included cables have a woven sheath around them that seems far better constructed than plain vinyl cords.  The included 2-meter extension cable is also a welcome addition to help prevent the headset from being ripped off when the player accidentally gets up without taking it off (as I often do when I am engrossed in my game!).But quality reaches an entirely new level when you put this headset on.  The over-the-ear design provides comfort and excellent isolation from ambient noise, and at the same time it delivers unbelievably crisp audio, from the lowest growl of monsters to the highest note of your favorite diva belting out the latest top-40 hit.  Another excellent feature is the included connectors which allow the headset to be used on virtually any device, from PCs, to Macs, to laptops and mobile devices.  For those who do not own high-end sound/graphics cards, the SteelSeries 9H Gaming Headset includes a USB sound card to provide the ultimate in sound experience--including Dolby support!  You can also customize the settings (equalizers, mic noise reduction, and compression, among others) for your headset using the available software.  The on-cable controls for mic-mute and volume are also handy.Overall, the SteelSeries 9H Gaming Headset is an excellent piece of sound technology.  With all of the connection options, software features, customization possibilities, and Dolby support, it will easily meet all of your gaming communication needs.  From directing your squad to flanking enemy monsters or starships, this headset will give you the edge you need to dominate!It sounds to me as if this is an excellent headset for the money.  I highly recommend it for avid gamers.

This set of pearl earrings and single pearl necklace is very lovely.  The pearls themselves are medium size--neither tiny nor large and imposing.  They are cultured pearls, but I do not have the impression that they are ultra-expensive--that is, they lack the luster of very expensive pearls.  The backing on the earrings and the chain on the necklace is gold, fairly thin, so that does not look expensive, either.  The chain is just under 18 inches long.  This set would make a very nice gift for a teenage girl getting her first "real" pearls--not cheap and fake, but not so expensive that it would be a disaster if she lost them.

I purchased these pillows for my sister, who had been waking up throughout the night and every morning with terrible neck pain.  Thinking that a change of pillow might be helpful, she began searching for a down pillow, but found that they were very pricey.  I found these pillows on Amazon and we decided that for the excellent price, they were worth a try.  I am happy to say that my sister is very pleased with these pillows, and her neck pain has completely disappeared.  Of course, this may be a coincidence, but she is happy to be pain free in any event.  These pillows are not down filled, but they are very comfortable.  They are neither too soft nor too hard.  Like Goldilocks, they are just right!The pillows arrived quickly and were well packaged.  I would recommend these pillows as a good and reasonably priced alternative to down.

I gave this game to my teenage nephew, who played it with several family members and friends.  They found the instructions not really hard, but very long and involved, and it took awhile for them to figure out how to play the game.  They tried to follow the rules, but ended up playing the game according to their own "house rules."The game comes with a timer, which makes a very loud noise.  They eventually stopped using the timer because the noise was so annoying.  One player even thought that the timer might have been broken.  The timer went off completely on its own, making that obnoxious noise.  Another player, an adult woman, did not enjoy the game at all, but the teens enjoyed the aspect of the game that required you to draw or to describe a product or the logo or symbol for a product.  The game seems to be a combination of Pictionary and Charades and Trivial Pursuit.  The kids thought this was a good, creative game, with a combination of old and new products.  This aspect of the game made it good for mixed age groups.  As other reviewers have said, this game is best played in teams.  I have the feeling that this experiment may have gone better if at least one player had really understood how to play the game so that so much time would not have been consumed in trying to understand the rules.The teens are willing to give this game another try.  I am going to edit this review after they do to see if they enjoyed the game more.  I have a feeling they will, especially as they become more familiar with it.

I have been a huge fan of Lonely Planet guidebooks ever since I first ordered one on Rome with kids as the target audience.  I like the adult Lonely Planet guides, too, but when it comes to children, no one does it better than Lonely Planet.  So when I had the chance to review this book, I jumped at it, and I was not disappointed."Lonely Planet Not for Parents  Real Wonders of the World" has as its subtitle "Amazing Stuff to Know about the Coolest Places on Earth," and that just about sums up this book.  The book is divided into eight major sections, each having seven to nine topics.  Some of the major sections are Stupendous Structures; High Tech; Cultural Wonders; Hidden Places; Thrills, Spills, and Games; and Fright Night.  Each sub-topic is composed of two pages loaded with a collage of photos and graphics, and while there is some text, it is not overwhelming.  The topics are wide-ranging, from Barrow, Alaska, to Pompeii, to the catacombs, to outer space.  While the guide is aimed at children (about age 8 and up, I would say), I am convinced that most adults would learn a thing or two from this book.The book is oversize, so it is not a conventional travel book.  Rather, it is a great "Let's find something interesting to read" book, one that I can see kids returning to again and again.  It is well made with heavy paper and a sturdy hard cover, so it should last through several children.  I give this book my highest recommendation.

I selected this game for my young cousin Brandon, who is just a few weeks shy of five.  I am happy to report that he loves this game and has played it 6 times in less than 24 hours!  The object of the game is for the dog, Shelby, to steal as many bones as possible.  The bones are made of rubber, not plastic, and the dog dishes are sturdy cardboard (which may or may not hold up, given that many pre-schoolers are hard on games and toys.  However, the game is designed to teach counting and simple math skills, and it does this quite well.  Since the dog steals bones from other dishes, the children learn to do simple addition and subtraction.  At the end, children count the number of bones Shelby has stolen, practicing their counting skills in a fun way.  I recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a fairly sturdy educational game that a pre-schooler will love.  A testimony from Brandon's mom, Laura:  "I love this game!"

I have purchased three of these toaster ovens in the last six months.  My own, which was purchased in early summer, is so good that I recently bought two more as gifts.  I like the upscale look of the oven, but even more, I like the way it works.  The controls are easy to understand and change.  The toasting function, which is the one we use most, is effective for both bread and bagels or muffins.  The first toasting cycle takes a bit longer, as the oven is starting cold, but after that, the bread toasts fairly quickly, and you can adjust the degree of "toastiness" that you prefer.  I really like my oven, and I think it is well worth the cost.

I ordered this guidebook, Lonely Planet Hawaii, because my husband and I took an all-too-short trip to Hawaii earlier this year, and we are both eager to go back and experience our 50th state in a little more depth than we did the first time around.  I was hoping that this guidebook would help, and I was not disappointed.Hawaii is a beautiful and complex state, and this guide covers just about every aspect of it:  people, culture, history, natural resources, ecology, and cuisine, to name just a few.  The book helps the reader plan a trip based on his or her individual interests, whether they are artistic, historical, or nature-oriented.  There are the usual "Where to Stay" and "Where to Eat" features, as well as some "Don't Miss This" features as well.  If you are traveling with children, this book includes several child-friendly attractions to help you plan a trip that the entire family can enjoy.  The book includes an up-to-date driving map that includes each island, helping in the planning of an itinerary.  It should be noted that the maps are not street maps; rather, they give an overview of each island.  If you want a street map, you will need to go elsewhere.  (I suggest the Auto Club, which has superb maps that alone are worth the price of membership if you travel a great deal.)In our previous travels, we have relied on Eyewitness Travel Guides, and if I were forced to select only one guide, I would prefer Eyewitness.  I do not know if they have one on Hawaii, but I suspect they do.  The advantage of the Eyewitness guides is the superb photography that accompanies many of the cultural and geographic entries.  Eyewitness claims to be "The Guides That Show You What Others Only Tell You," and we have found this to be true.However, this is not to denigrate the Lonely Planet Guide.  It too has photographs, though far fewer than an Eyewitness Guide.  It includes a wealth of information about Hawaii, so much so that I am convinced that even a native Hawaiian would learn a great deal about his state by surveying this guide.  A tourist will find it extremely helpful and informative.  Highly recommended.

I ordered this toy for my cousin's toddler, who is just a bit over 16 months old.  Joey adored the toy from the very beginning.  He quickly caught on, with the help of older brother Brandon (who is nearly five), how to keep the puppy reading and singing by turning the pages of the book.  In fact, it was Brandon who figured out the toy and taught Joey how to use it completely, a testament to the user-friendliness and age-appropriateness of this toy.  I thought the price might be a little high, but I must say it had provided hours of fun and laughter, as well as a good learning experience for Joey.  I would guess that this would make a good "from the grandparents" toy, simply because of the price.  I definitely recommend it--and the batteries are included, something I wish would become industry standard.Update:  After speaking with people who are more accustomed to purchasing toys than I am, I am going to change my opinion of the price.  One person I spoke with said, "Thirty five bucks?  For a puppy that sings and reads and moves?  That is really reasonable."  So I think I may be living in the previous century when it comes to price.  This is a delightful toy, and I think any toddler would love it.

I purchased this sink to use in our newly renovated bathroom and I am very happy with it.  It looks great in our gray toned and white bath, and the hardware is very modern.One thing that is a little tricky is controlling the amount of water--it is very easy to get an excessive flow of water, and you have to adjust the control.  I am used to this now, but I would recommend it for a bath that is going to be used by adults--I think kids might waste a lot of water by not controlling the flow very well.As this is our first vessel sink, I also wondered about water splashing onto the counter, but this has not been a problem at all unless you turn the flow to super high.  I also thought it might be difficult to keep spotless, but I find that it dries really well.  If I am not going to use the sink for awhile, I do wipe it out after use, and I find that this is very effective, too.I am very happy with this purchase.  It was well packaged and arrived intact, as have most items we purchased from Amazon.  Highly recommended.

Like the many other "Teach Yourself Visually" books, "MacBook Pro" is an excellent book for anyone who has or is planning to get an Apple laptop but may want some help finding out about and navigating all that it has to offer."MacBook Pro" is set up logically, and the reader can easily find the area he or she wants to learn about and simply go through the step-by-step instructions.  The photos are excellent, and they are photos, not diagrams or sketches.  The index is easy to use as well, and you will definitely learn a great deal about your new Mac by using this handbook.Highly recommended, especially for the technologically challenged.
This wallplate was purchased to a bathroom with updated brushed nickel finishes.  It is very nice, with a substantial look that I appreciate.  We are very pleased with this purchase.

This wallplate is in a hard-to-find configuration, so we were delighted to find the finish we wanted.  We are updating a bath with oiled bronze finishes.  This wallplate looks black when you see it in the package, but on the wall you see the oiled bronze accents, and it looks great.  It is a bit expensive, but I am very pleased.

These pulls were purchased for a bathroom vanity that we wished to update with new paint and hardware.  I am delighted with these pulls; they are lightweight, yet they look beautiful and substantial on the cabinet.  Highly recommended.

I did not read these books myself; they were a birthday gift for my 15-year-old niece.  She was absolutely delighted, so on that basis, I recommend them.  I was also impressed that the language is appropriate and that sexual content is virtually nonexistent, based on the observations of other reviewers.

This hose performed far better than the ones you see advertised that can fit into your pocket before and after you use them.  They are a waste of money, for the most part.  This one, on the other hand, really does not kink, and it is a real hose, with good water capacity.  Highly recommended.

I write here as one who has never read a book by Allison Leotta, but "Speak of the Devil" has made me want to read everything she has written.  The main character in "Speak of the Devil" is Anna Curtis, a sex crimes prosecutor in Washington DC, who has just become engaged to Jack Bailey, chief of the DC homicide unit.  Jack has a six-year-old daughter, Olivia, and his late wife, Nina Flores, had been killed four years earlier by one of the street gangs of Washington DC.  Most investigators believe that that the crime was committed by MS-13, a notoriously violent and ruthless DC gang.  The leader of this gang is Diablo, accurately named "the Devil."  Diablo's skin is completely covered in tattooed hieroglyphs.  His nose is two sunken holes; he has long black hair and two fleshy horns protruding from his forehead.  Indeed, he is aptly named.Diablo and his gang appear throughout the book as Anna Curtis and Jack Flores attempt to solve various gruesome crimes occurring in the DC area.  There are many twists and turns, and a huge red herring that comes as a total surprise to the reader in the last third of the book.  I really enjoyed this book and recommend it to anyone who likes true-life crime fiction.  The author's experience as a sex-crimes prosecutor for 12 years in Washington DC is evident on every page, and she is a superb writer.  If I could give the book more than five stars, I would.  Highly recommended.

"The Radical Practice of Loving Everyone" is a charming and light-hearted book about Mollie, a golden retriever, and her human companion, who learns all sorts of life lessons from her.  The author is on a journey toward enlightenment, and it is clear that he uses all sorts of events in his life to reflect on ultimate questions of truth and meaning.  Some of his reflections are excellent, such as taking the roads less traveled and being open to new experiences and eager to learn from them.  Some may strike the reader as ridiculous, such as taking hours to remove earthworms from a path so that no one steps on them as an expression that all life is sacred.The book is a very easy read, and it would make an excellent gift for a young person, especially one who loves dogs.  As an exploration into Buddhism, however, it is very lightweight.  A serious student might be charmed, but he or she would get little in depth from this book.  Still, that does not mean it is worthless or should be avoided.  Most people are not serious students of Buddhism; they are simply trying to make sense of life as they find it.  This book gives the reader fresh perspective, and if some of the lessons are a bit obvious, well, so what?  Readers will enjoy the dog/human connection.  And one could do worse than to learn from a dog, especially one as lovable as Mollie.

This is one of the best books in the "Dummies" series.  Unlike many of them, it is beautifully illustrated and colorful.  It gives wonderful descriptions of Apps the are appropriate for young children.  I was hoping to find apps that were suited to older tweens and teens, but this book is really for young children and early elementary age kids.  However, if this is the age group you are searching for. I recommend this book highly.

I should never have selected this novel.  Young adults in an isolated cabin during a blizzard attacked by nameless monsters--is this not the most ridiculous plot you ever heard?  And yet you have to endure this exercise in horror for 300-plus pages.  You will not like any of the characters, and you will not understand the monsters because they are never fully explained or developed.  Are they even real, or is this a psychological mystery?I suppose if you like "Return of the Living Dead" and TV shows like this, you may like this book.  It is fast-paced, and it is not at all hard to read, except that it is so ridiculous you can hardly stand it.  I would not have finished it if I did not have to review it for Vine.  Save your money and get "Turn of the Screw" out of the library for a real literary horror story.

I have to admit that I did not like this product at all.  I followed the directions exactly, and found that I was rinsing the conditioner out of my hair for at least seven minutes.  This to me is far too long.  Despite this, it never seemed to come completely out.  My hair took a long time to dry and was still a little greasy.  Thinking I had made a mistake, I tried it three more times, to no better luck.My hair is chin-length, so maybe if you have long hair this conditioner may work for you.  But I cannot honestly recommend it.  It is called Milk conditioner, and it does have the consistency of skim milk.  The ingredients include shea butter, soy milk, and honey, so these would be enough to make it hard to rinse out.Truthfully, it did not even make my hair soft.  It was hard to style and frustrating.  I am sorry to say I just cannot recommend it.

This is another excellent novel from L. J. Sellers.  He has once again shown how great a writer can be.Detective Jackson's ex-wife has disappeared; he learns of this while on vacation in Hawaii with his girlfriend.  His daughter Katie calls to tell him she needs him to cut his vacation short in order to help locate the ex-wife.Back in Eugene, Oregon, Jackson is sure that his ex has been kidnapped, and he fears for her life (for his daughter's sake, not so much for his own).  A ransom note is received, but a rescue attempt ends in total failure.  Sure that his ex wife is dead, he nevertheless continues the search because of his daughter.The ending is a complete surprise and will make many readers say "What???"  If you like detective fiction, you will love this novel.  I certainly did--four stars.

This is the third novel in the Vanessa Michael Munroe series.  I have read only "The Innocent," which I loved.  I felt that the main character, Michael as she is called, was a superwoman in "The Innocent," but in "The Doll" she is somewhat lacking.  Her physical and mental strength is much less in this latest novel.The villain in "The Doll" is "The Dollmaker" along with his goons, who kidnap girls who are either movie stars or just extraordinarily beautiful.  These girls are procured at the behest of "The Dollmaker's" wealthy clients (think Donald Trump), who pay him to get a young woman to their exact specifications.Michael is also kidnapped, but for a different reason.  She is to escort "Neeva", a rock star wanted by one of the Dollmaker's customers, to his location so she can be made into his sex slave.  Michael is coerced into doing this because the Dollmaker has threatened her loved ones with death.  Neeva does not go without a fight.Meanwhile, Michael's love interest, Bradford, is trying to rescue her brother, who has also been kidnapped in the attempt to coerce Michael.  Bradford succeeds, but at great cost.This book has many twists and turns, and it keeps the reader interested.  However, it is a hard book to read because it is so dark.  It portrays the worst side of human nature and the only redemption is survival.  (Not that everyone survives.)I did like this book, but not as much as "The Innocent."  Michael's personality was toned down so much that she seemed almost like a different person.  The ending is also weird.  Sometimes, even in a thriller, I want the good guys in a book to conquer the bad guys and live happily ever after.  This is not that book.

This is an excellent geometry text for honors and advanced  placement students.  It is extremely challenging and provides in-depth learning for students who enjoy the challenge of math or who have access to a teacher or tutor on a regular basis.  It is far too difficult, however, for the typical high school geometry student.  It is very proof-oriented, and the difficulty may discourage the student who may like math but does not want a career that is dependent on it.  For the budding engineer or scientist, this book is  a great choice, but it is not for everyone.That said, I want to point out one aspect of the book that is great.  Each chapter has three levels of practice problems, labeled A, B, and C.  The A problem set is for everyone, and B and C levels are for those who want a greater challenge.  I wanted this book to use for a geometry course for home schooled students, who meet with me only once a week.  This is not nearly often enough, given the difficulty of this book.  However, in a school, where students and teacher meet five days a week, the levels of problems provide the teacher with great flexibility.  I could see the book being used at several levels.In short, this is a great book, but it is not the best choice for me.  However, if may be a good choice for you.  I suggest that you buy a used copy so that you can judge for yourself before you  invest in the entire course.

I selected this faucet for our newly remodeled kitchen with the help of a plumber, who had some excellent advice for people who like this type of faucet.  His advice was to always select a faucet with a magnetized head.  If you do not, your faucet will look great for about two months, but then gravity will exert its force, leaving the head of the faucet hanging limply from the base.  A magnet solves this problem, and the head retracts easily into the faucet base.I also selected this faucet because I did not want more than one hole in our granite countertop.  With our previous sinks, we had three holes:  for the faucet, for the water control, and for the soap dispenser.  I fought to keep these areas clean and free of hard water stains.  With this faucet, you have one hole.  The water control is attached to the faucet and works well.  For soap, we have an attractive free-standing dispenser.  This is a matter of taste, of course, but if you like clean lines, this may be the faucet for you.  I could not be more pleased.

I purchased this support for my husband when he was having some back problems.  He had worn similar supports in the past, all far more expensive.  Based on other reviews, I decided to try this one, and he is very happy with it.  It provides excellent support and he was able to resume almost all his normal activities.  The only thing I would caution purchasers about is size.  My husband is not a large man, and we thought the medium would be an appropriate size.  In reality, the large would have been better--the support is very tight.  Of course, it has to be somewhat tight in order to give support, but there is almost no "give" in the brace.  So select the size you want accordingly.

While I am not a scientific expert on shampoos, I am something of an amateur expert.  I can honestly say without exaggeration that I have used a few hundred different shampoos in my lifetime.  In my teens and early twenties, before marriage, I would shampoo at least twice a day:  once before school or work, and again before a date or evening event.  On the advice of my hairdresser, I never used the same shampoo twice in a row.  People who saw my bathroom said it was better stocked than a drugstore!Now I shampoo only once a day, and I found that I love TRESemme shampoo.  I can use it two or three times in a row, and I find that I keep going back to it.  It makes my hair silky, shiny, and smooth every time I use it.  No more shampooing twice a day!  I will definitely buy this product again.Try it.  I would not mislead you.  And the icing on the cake is that it is made in the USA, a definite plus!

"Chocolate for Two" is the fourth book in the Waverly Bryson series by Maria Mumane.  I have read only this one, so take that into consideration when assessing my review.As tis book opens, our heroine, Waverly, Is recovering from having been almost literally left at the altar by a cad who appeared on her doorstep two weeks before the wedding and proclaimed he did not love her.  A popular young woman with many love interests,  Waverly is a well regarded talk show host who also owns her own very successful business, Waverly's Honey Shop.  Despite all this, her self esteem is shaky until she meets Jake McIntyre, a wealthy scion of an upper class family.Naturally, they fall in love.  We seem to be headed for a story book ending, but wait--we need some drama.  Enter Jake's parents, specifically his mother, who is controlling and insufferable, in the nicest possible way (ahem).  She hopes to take control of the wedding and make it a huge expensive affair in Florida.  Waverly and Jake, meanwhile, want a small intimate wedding in New York.  Jake is besotted with Waverly and pretty much defers to her on every issue, but at the same time he does not help much in dealing with his overbearing mother.The novel is a fun beach read, good for a rainy day on the porch.  There is humor and emotion, as well as many sidebars with Waverly's career and business.  Eventually, Waverly finds a retailer who somehow makes her see everything, both professional and personal, in perspective, and the ending is light and satisfying.  You probably will not remember this book too long after you read it, but you will be entertained as you read, especially if you are a fan.

I purchased this sink for our new kitchen based on the recommendation of our designer, who has one in her own home.  It is a beautiful sink, and I am sure I will love it.  However, there are two things you need to know.First, the sink is fragile.  This may sound bizarre as it is a granite sink, but the first sink I ordered was canceled by the manufacturer as it was too damaged to be delivered, and the second, which was delivered on time and apparently intact based on the outer packaging, in fact had two cracks, and the installer (quite rightly) refused to install it.  He got an identical sink from his supplier and installed that one instead.Second, be aware that the color may be misleading.  I ordered the sink in "Truffle," as the color on the Amazon website looked like a cafe au lait brown.  So I was shocked when we opened the box and saw that the sink was more gray than brown.  If gray is what you want, you will be delighted, but we wanted brown, and we opted for "Cafe Brown," a darker, richer, deeper  brown.Finally, do not be put off by these cautions--but take them into consideration when you are ordering.  We are returning the second sink, and Amazon has been great about assisting us in that.  The sink itself is wonderful--but you may want to get it directly from a supplier or local store so you can assess the appropriateness of the color for yourself.

Set in the fictional town of Red Paint Bay, a typical small town where everyone knows everyone else and nothing is kept secret for long, this book deals with a long-buried secret that is about to re-emerge and haunt many, especially one family.This family is headed by Simon Howe, who was born and raised in Red Paint and is now the editor of the town paper.  He is married to Amy, a psychotherapist,  who runs the family with an iron hand.  Their son, Davey, is a more or less typical teen, but he gets into trouble and is grounded regularly for some pretty bizarre behavior, such as throwing knives at his best friend.  Simon and his staff are always trying to think of events to fill their small-town paper.  It has been said that when the gods wish to punish us, they answer our prayers, and this is true in spades with Simon.  His 25th high school reunion is approaching, and in this town, that qualifies as front page news.  It is here that the excitement and horror begin.Simon has been getting a number of unsigned postcards, the content of which ranges from mundane (Will you meet me for dinner?) to threatening.  He decides to meet  with the postcard-sender, and though he is instructed to come alone, Amy insists on coming with him.  Davey is left alone with strict orders to stay in the house.  (Never a good idea in a mystery book.)  The mysterious writer is a no-show, and when Simon and Amy return home, they find that Davey has disappeared.  The police are called, and Davey is found safe in a treehouse.  But how did he get there?  There is, of course, a connection with the mysterious postcard-writer.The story gets better with every page--I challenge you not to finish this book.  Many interesting and typical small town characters have their roles to play, and the mystery deepens with each chapter.  If you enjoy mysteries with a small town flavor and fast pace, you will like this book.  Highly recommended.

I gave the Colorama game to my cousin for her four-year-old, and I am happy to say that he loves this game and asks repeatedly to play it.  Essentially, this game is designed to teach a young child shapes and colors, and it has several levels of play, from very basic to a bit more complex.  You can play by concentrating on shapes only, on colors only, or on a combination of the two.  The game is fun for kids, and if Brandon is any example, they will like it even if they already have a good grasp of shapes and colors.  Brandon has a younger brother, Joey, who  at 10 months is too young for the game,  but I can see this as a game the two could play together in about a year, with Brandon "teaching" Joey all the ins and outs of shapes and colors.  This game is a good use of time and money,  and I recommend it to anyone looking for a fun way to reinforce the basics of shapes and colors.

Susan Tepper's stories are quirky and magnificent. Tepper has that rare ability to take the mundane and make it thrilling. The prose is masterful and rivals that of any of the canonicalized short story writers.It's worth mentioning that I'm good friends with Susan Tepper, which might make this review seem biased. However, as her friend, I also judge her work harshly. Much more harshly than I would judge the work of say Stephen King or E.L. James. Honestly, I wish I could find flaw in this book to help her become a better writer. Alas, I cannot.

Imagine the funniest book ever written. Now multiply that by ten, strap a bomb to it, stick it in your pants, and jump off a mountain. That's how funny this book is. Jon Konrath is a comedic genius. He'll turn your sense of humor inside out and punch it in the face. Anyone capable of reading a story like "My Friend, the Jihadist" without laughing 79 times is a soulless Android who was probably programmed by a jihadist. Konrath, I applaud you. Get yourself a fistful of pizza now.

I was fortunate enough to get a signed copy of this book from directly from Bud Smith, and it's a possession I shall cherish until the day when all our books are burned by some evil dictatorship. Until then, let's talk about how amazing this book is.F250 is one heck of a fun ride. It makes me want to quit my job and start a band, and then quit the band and find a job because life's too crazy and unstable.This book had me laughing from the beginning, just imagining this narrator driving around his POS F250 and running into things. But it's not all fun and games. Smith's prose is mature and often hits on deeply emotional and philosophical points (without trying to be too bloody serious, of course).I'm a huge fan of Bud Smith's work, and I would rank this near the top of what he's done. I don't know if I like it quite as much as Tollbooth, but it's a fantastic novel and worth reading by anyone who likes music, trucks, beer, or words. Do yourself a favor and buy a copy.

I've been waiting almost two decades for this, and I couldn't be happier with the final product. When Failure toured in 2014, I considered myself pretty darn lucky to see them. I never really expected new music though. But the boys came through, and they did it in big fashion.This album could very much be viewed as an immediate follow-up to Fantastic Planet. The production is a bit more polished, but much of the songwriting comes off in a similar vein. But it's certainly not a copycat album or even some attempt to recapture old magic. No, the magic here comes naturally. It's an album that is epic in scope and unravels beautifully throughout.Throughout the album, the band shows maturity while occasionally giving a nod to their old (or should I say young) selves. The Segues are beautiful and show the band could easily become a post-rock powerhouse if they wanted. But there's plenty of that old space rock here too, such as "Hot Traveler."Surprisingly, I've heard some negative criticism about "Mulholland Dr," which is one of my favorite tracks on the album. It's a bit classic rock, but it also reminds me of "The Nurse Who Loved Me" and a few other songs from Fantastic Planet. It's a magnificent piece of songwriting that fits well on this album.I'm certainly not ready to proclaim this better than Fantastic Planet, but it definitely is a worthy successor. I think it's much better than any of us could have really expected after this long. 2015 has already been a great year for the comeback album, and Failure has made it even more of a success!

As a relatively new fan of Refused, I think I can bring an unbiased approach to this review. It seems that every die hard Refused fan either says this is awesome just because it is new music from Refused or that it's terrible just because it's new music from Refused. Same reason, different perspective, right?When Refused last put out music, I was in high school and listening mostly to classic rock. It wasn't until almost a decade later that I discovered The Shape of Punk to Come, an album that instantly had an impact on my musical tastes.While I didn't necessarily crave new music from Refused, I was certainly excited when the announcement of a new album was made. I was lucky enough to snag one of the limited edition vinyl copies from the Refused preorder (before they announced about a dozen variants of the vinyl). Based on the strength of lead single "Elektra," I had high hopes for the album (even if it did sound a little like Dave Grohl trying to make a hardcore punk album).The album doesn't disappoint, but it certainly isn't perfect. There are some really rough moments (like the "murder, murder, murder, murder, kill, kill, kill" nonsense in Franafrique). The music is powerful, but it occasionally feels like the band is trying too hard to make another Shape of Punk to Come. It's a worthy follow up, but it will never have the same impact. However, it will continue to bring new fans to quality punk and hardcore music.

Let me start by saying that I didn't discover MewithoutYou until a year after "Brother, Sister" was released. So I'm not a diehard fan who can say I've been there since the beginning. I do enjoy the band's entire discography, but I tend to listen to "Brother, Sister" and "Ten Stories" the most.Now let's talk about "Pale Horses." Honestly, I was a bit skeptical about this album when I first heard the single "Red Cow." I thought the song was just okay and didn't think this album was going to stand much of a chance compared to the band's previous work. I even put off ordering it until I heard the stream. I didn't even get halfway through the album before I found myself ordering one of the last few copies of the deluxe edition vinyl."Pale Horses" is a masterpiece and possibly my favorite MewithoutYou album as a whole. While there aren't necessarily any songs that can necessarily live up to "In a Sweater Poorly Knit" or "January 1979," this is a beautiful and powerful album from start to finish. The band is in top form here, delivering an epic album that's overflowing with emotion.My favorite songs so far are "Watermelon Ascot," "Mexican War Streets," and "Rainbow Signs," but every song is great and has a place on this album. I even find myself enjoying "Red Cow" a lot more in the context of the album than I did before the release."Pale Horses" should delight MewithoutYou fans regardless of when you started listening to the band. This is a work that's representative of everything they've done. If you like any of MewithoutYou's previous records, you will probably enjoy this.

As a longtime fan of Muse, I’ve been disappointed by the band’s recent output. It’s not that the past couple albums are bad per se, but they haven’t resonated as much with me as Absolution, Origin of Symmetry, or Showbiz. I’ve come to terms with the fact that they will never release another Origin of Symmetry, which is fine by me. After all, we already have that album and don’t really need another version.This was one of my most anticipated albums of the year. Early reports about “Drones” indicated it was going to be “back to basics.” I really enjoyed the singles (other than the silly drill sergeant bit from “Psycho”). Listening to this album, it’s obviously a long way from Origin of Symmetry or Absolution, but those albums were far from basic.On the surface, there’s plenty about this album that’s laughable. From the awful cover art to the ridiculous Drill Sergeant track to the autotune to the cheesey drone theme that’s overplayed throughout the album. It’s clearly a concept album, and I’m not sure the concept is compelling enough in this presentation. The lyrics are far from subtle, and the “message” feels a bit like juvenile politics. But somehow, this album works.Musically, there’s no doubt this is the best the band has done since Absolution (or at least since Black Holes). There are big riffs and bold sounds, and it’s obvious that Muse was pulling from some of that old magic when writing and recording these songs. Some fans might be a bit turned off by the seemingly excessive falsetto on the album, but it actually plays well with the music.I didn’t really expect to love this album, but it’s grown on me rather quickly. I’d put it just above Black Holes and Revelations. It’s not a perfect album by any means, but it’s the best Muse has done in quite some time. I suspect that fans will be torn on this record. If you’ve been disappointed by the last couple, there’s at least a decent chance you’ll like this one. If you love everything Muse has done, you'll definitely love this album. But if all you want is another Origin of Symmetry, then why not just listen to the copy you already have and be content?

As a huge fan of The xx (including their underrated sophomore album "Coexist"), it's taken me awhile to warm up to Jamie xx. I wasn't a big fan of the remix collaboration he did with Gil Scott-Heron, and some of his other post-xx work hasn't really stuck with me. However, "In Colour" has me sold on Jamie xx as a solo artist.This is a strong album with a little bit for every music fan. There's dance, rave, EDM, minimalist, electronic, pop, rap, jazz, and every other sub-genre in between. On this album, Jamie xx proves himself a master of blending genres without overdoing anything. He even gives some nods to The xx on a few tracks, which will surely excite fans of the band.The album flows well together, whether the songs are big and bold or intimate and chill. It's the type of album that comes full circle and works great on repeat. It's probably an album best listened to on headphones, and you'd probably enjoy it more with the lights off. But you could also play it at a party and keep people on the dance floor.The highlights of the album include "Gosh," "Loud Places," "SeeSaw," and "I Know There's Gonna Be (Good Times)." But there really aren't any duds on here. At times it may feel like Jamie xx is playing it too safe, but that's only to the untrained ear that isn't looking for the subtlety in this music. These songs are rich and have plenty to offer on repeat listens. There's plenty here that's catchy, and the album as a whole moves the soul.Jamie xx has proven himself as a solo artist, not just a producer or remix artist. This is a colossal achievement for his proper debut, and I look forward to more Jamie xx in the future.

I have been a big fan of Daniel Johns and Silverchair since Frogstomp came out 20 years ago. It's been fun watching Daniel Johns grow from an angst-filled teenager into the mature and brilliant musician he is today. Although I was disappointed by the news a couple years ago that Silverchair was calling it quits, this album more than fills that void.Let's make something very clear: "Talk" is not a Silverchair album. Not every Silverchair fan will enjoy this album. "Talk" is not a guitar album, and it doesn't have the anger of Johns's early work. It's a beautiful blend of electronic, rock, pop, and dance, with a bunch of other stuff mixed in as well.Although the album seems vastly different from Johns's other work, it shouldn't come as a surprise to anyone who has followed his career. Just look at the progression from Frogstomp and Freakshow to Neon Ballroom and Diorama. Johns has gradually been getting more ambitious and more orchestral with his music, and "Talk" sees that vision become something new in a way that grows on his previous songwriting experience.Nothing on here really sounds like a Silverchair song, but Daniel Johns's vocals occasionally recall those earlier days. On "New York," for example, it almost feels like Silverchair doing an electro-pop song. There are other moments where Daniel Johns sounds a lot like the Daniel Johns we are all familiar with, but not in a way that makes us pine for something this record isn't. No, this album stands on its own as something special.Some of the best songs on "Talk" also appeared on Johns's "Aeriel Love EP" from earlier this year. "Preach," which might just be one of the best songs Johns has ever created, is one of the songs that spills over. But it feels much more at place here than at the beginning of the "Aeriel Love EP." While the EP was good, "Talk" is a more complete vision of what felt like experimentation and finding a new voice. Johns doesn't feel like he's searching for anything on this album. It's clear throughout "Talk" that he knows exactly what he's doing--and he does it quite well.This is a phenomenal album that will surely grow on anyone who gives it a chance. Whether you're a fan of rock, electronic, dance, or pop, this is a true gem of a record worthy of repeat listens.

Merle Drown's "Lighting the World" is a fast-paced coming-of-age story with a powerful voice that will be enjoyed by adults and young adults alike.Drown creates a rich backdrop of character and setting that flows brilliantly from beginning to end. It's a difficult story at times, with main character Wade encountering many hard situations as a teenage boy. This is a chilling read that rewards all the way to the shocking end.Drown doesn't hold back when telling this story, allowing the characters to fully develop in a way that makes the reader feel. This is much more than a book about a teenager looking to find himself. This is a story that everyone can relate to. Drown truly lights the world with this bold novel.

I purchased these Pioneer bookshelf speakers to accompany my Pro-Ject Debut Carbon. For the money, I don't think you can get a better set of speakers. The sound quality, range, and volume are all excellent. This is a 5-star product all around.After trying several other models of similar size and price, I've come to the conclusion that these Pioneer speakers deliver big for the buck. They easily fill my large basement room to provide a quality listening experience whether I'm sitting close or relaxing on the other side of the room.These speakers have a wide range and sound great right out of the box. I've had them for about a year now and have listened to hundreds of hours of music. Records that only sounded okay with my previous set of speakers now have a fuller sound thanks to these. Naturally, not everything sounds great on these speakers. A really bad recording can actually sound a bit worse on here. But who wants to listen to bad recordings anyway?Besides the great sound, another huge advantage of these speakers is their size. They are fairly compact and fit nicely on my Expedit shelves. For the size and money, you won't get a better listening experience.I won't lie and say these are the best speakers I've ever heard. My friend's set of $1000 Klipsch floorstanding speakers sound significantly better. But it's ridiculous to compare systems in such a different price category.If you're looking for great speakers on a budget, you can end your search right now. I highly recommend these speakers.

If you're easily offended, turn back now. If you like your fiction to have some grit and plenty of vulgarities, then Brian Alan Ellis's "mustache" collection is just the thing you've been searching for your whole life. This little book is filled with hilarious, absurd, dark, and offensive stories. It's hard to believe that Ellis could squeeze so much into so few pages.I'd list the best stories, but that would just be a list of all the stories in here. Do yourself (and Brian Alan Ellis) a favor and buy this book. Sure, you'll be a worse person with a horrible outlook on life, but the few hours of entertainment the book provides will more than make up for that.

Throughout this short story collection, Lou Gaglia weaves together the absurd and serious, somehow making everything believable. These are stories that are easy to get lost in, and you'll find an exciting new adventure in each tale. There's never a dull moment in this book. I highly recommend Gaglia's work to any fan of short stories. .Gaglia has a knack for taking mundane, everyday tasks—like pumping gas, selling pools, and getting your car repaired—and turning them into the funniest and most damn profound stories you've ever read. Don't let the title fool you. Gaglia's stories are full of good advice. Just don't take any of them too seriously or you may find your life in shambles.I received an advanced reader copy of Poor Advice and Other Stories directly from the author. Having been a fan of Lou Gaglia's work for several years, I was honored when he asked me to reader an advanced copy. After reading the collection, I was truly blown away by Gaglia's talents.

For the price, you'd be hard-pressed to find a better oil drain pan that isn't an open design.This 10 quart oil drain pan will easily hold all the oil from two cars, which is perfect because it allows me to do both cars at once before transporting the oil for recycling.When transporting, you have to be very careful. This isn't exactly the most sturdy design, but it seals well enough as long as it isn't flying around your trunk. I haven't had any issues with oil spilling out, but based on the material, I could see that as an issue.The major design flaw is the size of the mouth for catching the oil. The diameter of the mouth isn't wide enough to catch the stream of oil that shoots out at an angle (which is the bulk of the oil) AND the oil that drips straight down at the same time. Some spilling is inevitable, so you need to be sure to have plenty of cardboard or newspaper down on the garage floor. You have to constantly reposition the pan in order to minimize spills.Honestly, I wish I had thrown out a few more bucks and bought a better pan. But this gets the job done, so I'm not going to complain too much.

This is a free app, so it's hard to complain too much. I downloaded it for my Kindle Fire HD. It loads quickly and has all the features you need for Spotify on a tablet. Unfortunately, there are a few playback issues. Three main examples:1. Songs often skip or have annoying pops.2. When using the shuffle feature for an artist, the app seems to play the same few songs over and over (and mostly from the artist's most recent albums).3. The app often stops playing music when using another program on the Kindle. For example, if I am browsing the internet, the app sometimes quits halfway through a song and has to be restarted.Overall, this app has some challenges to overcome, but it gets the job done most of the time. After all, if I'm listening from my Kindle Fire, I'm not exactly in search of a premier audio listening experience.

So we all know that this is a classic 90s alternative album. But how does it translate on the new remastered vinyl? The answer: outstanding. Sixteen Stone has never sounded this good before. The remastered vinyl is crisp and perfectly balanced. The records are free of noise, and the music isn't simply remastered by "turning up the volume." This is an example of remastering done the right way. The sound is much richer and clearer than the original CD release, but it still has that edgy grunge vibe to it.If you are thinking about getting this album on vinyl, this is a must buy. The packaging is fantastic: gatefold jacket, sturdy sleeves, and plenty of artwork. Oh, and don't forget the 2 X LP on thick clear wax. And the price is ridiculously cheap considering what you get.Put this on your record player and relive the 90s in a way you never heard them before.

"Why Make Sense?" is Hot Chip's 6th album and the band's best since "One Life Stand." Okay, so there was only one album in between "One Life Stand" and "Why Make Sense?", but it feels like it's been a long time. "One Life Stand" was an instant classic and the album that really made me fall in love with this band. Unfortunately, "In Our Heads" didn't quite live up to the band's previous efforts. But "Why Make Sense?" stands strong in the band's catalog.This album is filled with all the things that make Hot Chip great. Jammed with groovy beats accompanied by R&B, Hip-Hop, Electronic, and Dance influences, this is an album that will make you get up and move. The production is smooth and doesn't get in the way of the band's diverse sound.Album highlights include "Huarache Lights," "Dark Night," and "Easy To Get," but the entire album is consistently strong. That isn't to say that the album is consistent in sound. While the songs do flow together, this is an album that blends genres and pushes boundaries. Whether you're listening to the more subdued tracks like "White Wine and Fried Checking" or the dancey "Need You Now," this album delivers again and again.With "Why Make Sense?", Hot Chip is back. So get those dance shoes out of the closet and dust them off. Let Alexis Taylor's soulful vocals and the band's groovy beats take control of your body.

Soil starts off as a very promising Southern noir novel with all the makings of a classic. Jay Mize is a fantastic character, and the premise seems like a brilliant balance of the absurd and the terrifying.Kornegay does an excellent job building into the tale, creating a rich setting that shows as much care as farmer Mize gives to his soil. The way Kornegay subtly works environmental issues into the plot is skillful without being overdone or preachy. Truthfully, Kornegay doesn't seem to infuse any of his own opinion on the subject, leaving it all as part of the nature of the world. The author shows a deep knowledge (or at least adequate research) of farming, composting, and growing.The book really hits strides as the paranoid Mize begins his work at hiding the body he discovers on his property. The plot here shows the struggle that all humans face with guilt and the need to provide and live a decent life, which is certainly enough of a theme to carry what's otherwise a rather flimsy plot.Unfortunately, the book takes some turns for the worse before we get too far in. "Deputy" Danny Shoals is a dreadful cliche of a playboy that gets way too much attention (especially in the second half of the book). Every aspect of this character is pulled straight from the proverbial book of typical country cop with a powerful uncle. In general, Kornegay treats every character as either a male or female stereotype, and it's especially disappointing the way the author characterizes Sandy Mize. Still, the novel isn't ruined by these shortcomings.The worst thing about this book by far is the ending. It's an overly contrived, cliche, predictable bit of nonsense that undercuts almost the entire reader journey in an attempt to drive home a ridiculous metaphor that wasn't really there. I won't spoil it for you, but you can surely guess what happens.Overall, this novel shows a lot of promise for Kornegay as a writer. Although it's far from perfect (and probably 100 pages or so too long), I look forward to reading more of this author's work.

It’s been 18 years since we’ve had new music from Faith No More. Finally, Mike Patton and the boys are back (and it’s the first time the band has kept the same lineup on two consecutive albums since The Real Thing and Angel Dust). From the very first moments of Sol Invictus, we know it was worth the wait.The album immediately explodes to life with a jazzy track that has Mike Patton channeling his inner folk hero. We know right away that this is still Faith No More, but it’s not a band just trying to recapture what they were. Over the course of the 10 tracks on the album, the band creates a confident and compelling record that demonstrates a group of musicians coming together for the purpose of music rather than reunion.The two lead singles, “Superhero” and “Motherfu**er” are two of the strongest tracks here, both showing that Faith No More is still capable of creating that innovative and driving music that pushes the boundaries of what songwriting can do. FNM was not about to settle on this album, and they prove that on every track.“From the Dead” is the perfect closer to this album, perhaps a symbolic nod to Faith No More’s comeback after all these years. Other songs, like “Separation Anxiety,” also allude to their time apart, but not in a way that makes this some cheesy concept album. No, Sol Invictus remains a strong and diverse rock album that expresses everything great about this band.Yes, it’s been 18 years in the making, but this is no nostalgic trip. This is a triumph in every sense of the word. The band has grown and matured but still manages to deliver a unique sound that plenty can try to imitate but no one can match. This is an album that will thrill old fans and create new fans.Faith No More is alive and unconquered. Please don’t make us wait 18 more years!Sidenote: I’m a little bummed that I have to wait until July or August for the vinyl release, but other than that, this is pretty much a perfect return for one of the most innovative bands in rock history.

1000 Palms starts strong with "Grand Inquisitor," a spacey-surf rock song that instantly makes it feel like Surfer Blood is on the verge of something new with this album. However, it quickly retreats from there, failing to explore any new territory. This is a safe album, lacking the urgency and uniqueness of Astro Coast and the catchy power of Pythons. It's pleasant enough, but it doesn't show any growth in a band that's already released two solid albums. Instead, it's a wishy-washy in-between ground. Nothing here is bad, but it's not a very memorable album either. If you're a Surfer Blood fan, it's worth a listen. If you haven't heard Surfer Blood before, I wouldn't recommend starting with this album.

Imagine if two massively talented and creative bands joined forces on one album. That's exactly what you get with Pfarmers debut Gunnera. This collaboration between members of The National and Menomena works well on so many levels. It feels a bit more like a Menomena album than a National album (which is expected whenever you get a singer from one band but not the other). However, the National's influence definitely shines through at times on the instrumentation.This is a strong album, although it does take a bit to get going. Opening track "Benthos" is an ambient horn piece that feels a bit like a throwaway track until it blends perfectly into "You Shall Know the Spirit" and you realize they were just getting you in the mood. "Benthos" probably could've been a bit shorter without losing much effect, but it doesn't take away from the experience of the rest of the album.As good as this album is, it probably doesn't stack up next to anything that either band has released before. It's important to look at this collaboration as a separate project. If you go into it expecting the next Friend and Foe or Boxer, you'll be wholly disappointed. If you go into it looking to hear fantastic music from brilliant musicians, you'll be rewarded greatly.If you're a fan of The National, Menomena, or just great music in general, you need to grab a copy of this now.

What a year for David Duchovny. A novel, an album, and the return of The X-Files! Holy cow, could one man be more talented?Okay, so we all know that David Duchovny is the most talented man alive (and he's pretty darn handsome, too). So what about this album? Is it any good?Of course it is! Duchovny's deep and melodic voice conjures all the greatest American singers of all time (most notably, Tom Petty). Musically and thematically, this album just feels like classic Americana. It's everything you'd expect from such a talented human being. And the fact that almost every song references water shows Duchovny's brilliant mind at work. This might just be the greatest American concept album of all time.Seriously, this album rocks. "Unsaid Undone" contains one of the best searing guitar solos in American alt-rock history. Make all the jokes you want about an actor trying to sing and play music, but Duchovny is the real deal.Too bad The X-Files reboot isn't coming out until January 2016. Otherwise, Duchovny might be winning a Grammy and an Emmy in the same year! Oh, and maybe a National Book Award, too!

Sprinter is a diverse album that’s rich, dark, and a tad bit catchy. The instrumentation is fantastic and diverse, with influences of folk, electronic, rock, shoegaze, and more.Torres, aka Mackenzie Scott, has a bold and beautiful voice with a raw power that works well on both loud rock songs and soft/folksy ballads. Her voice is a bit reminiscent of other great female vocalists like Sharon Van Etten and Fiona Apple, but she definitely stands alone with her own unique sound.The highlights here are “Strange Hellos,” “Sprinter,” and “New Skin.” All of the songs are strong (except for maybe "Son, You Are No Island" which tends to drag a bit). In general, Torres is at her best when she's rocking. This definitely ranks as one of the best female rock/singer-songwriter albums of the year.

Imagine Shakespeare without his pen. Or Picasso without his paintbrush. Or even Hubble without his telescope.Now, imagine Mumford & Sons sans banjos.Okay, now that's being a bit dramatic, but we've come to identify with this band based on their unique use of instruments and their passion, both of which are almost completely absent from this album.Now, this isn't a bad album by any means. Anyone giving it a 1-star review is likely acting based on some knee-jerk reaction. "OMG, they changed their sound. Sellouts! I hate them!"No, that's not what happened here. You can't fault the band for pursuing a new sound. What band has remained the same throughout their entire career? Mumford & Sons needed to try something new. The problem here is that their "new" is the same old thing that tons of bands have been doing for years. This is a generic pop/rock album. It's like they've taken a Coldplay formula but stripped out everything that's unique.There are enjoyable songs on here. Actually, there's not really a bad track. But nothing stands out as memorable either. It's just another album that will be filed away as utterly forgettable. Had this been Mumford & Sons first album, no one would have even cared about it.This album deserves three stars because it is about as mediocre and middle-of-the-road as music can be. Mumford & Sons have set the new standard for generic.

The Waterfall didn’t really grab me on first listen, much like every My Morning Jacket album since Z. Honestly, after the first time through The Waterfall, I was ready to give up and declare it the worst MMJ album yet. As a huge fan since I first heard At Dawn almost 15 years ago, the vibe on The Waterfall felt too far removed from what MMJ can do.Fortunately, I decided to come back to this album rather than writing it off, and I’m definitely glad I did. This is an ambitious and bold album that shows a band still progressing and trying new things after two decades. Sure, MMJ could release more alt country stuff that everyone would love, but this is a band that wants to grow. And they’re definitely growing here on The Waterfall.There seem to be many reviewers and fans out there who still want to refer to MMJ as an alt country band, but let’s be honest: they haven’t alt country since Z. They aren’t going back (although there are always reminders embedded in the music), and The Waterfall is another step forward, not a step in the wrong direction.At times, the album feels too ambitious (but not in the same way as songs like “Highly Superstitious”). For example, the chorus of opening track "Believe" feels a bit cheesy coming from Jim James. But, on the whole, this album works quite well. The guitar work is incredible throughout, especially on songs like “Tropics.” “In Its Infancy (The Waterfall)” is one of the catchiest and most epic MMJ songs to date. And the singing continues to show off James’s impressive range and influence.It’s not my favorite MMJ album at this moment in time. Not by a longshot. But it’s a grower, and it is slowly moving up the ranks.The Waterfall as a whole might not immediately grab all MMJ fans (although quite a few people seem to be saying it's their favorite MMJ release already). Like I said, it took a few listens for me to really appreciate it. But once it finally clicked, I realized this was a fantastic piece of art from a band that delivers again and again.

In 2015, one might ask whether a new Everclear album is really necessary. The honest truth is probably not. However, for those willing to give this a listen, it's a high quality rock album with plenty of punch. The guitars are heavy, the vocals are spot-on, and the lyrics are (thankfully) not as cheesy as the title. It's actually the band's most consistent record in a long time.If you are an Everclear fan, you will like this album. If you are an alternative rock or modern rock fan, you will like this album. If you are nostalgic for Everclear, you will like this album. Heck, even if you like to make fun of 90s alternative bands that are still making music, you will probably like this.Even if it's been a while since you listened to Everclear, give this a spin. You'll be glad you did.

Without even listening to a single track on The Magic Whip, it's obvious this is the best thing Blur has released in over a decade. All kidding aside, it's great to finally have some new Blur. This album does not disappoint. While it doesn't sound like the most Blur-ish thing the band has ever done, it isn't a radical departure either. Sure, there's a bit more Damon Albarn than usual (some of his more current projects do crossover a bit here), but when all is said and done, this is a Blur album at heart. Musically and lyrically, you can feel the Blur come to life throughout the pleasurable listening experience that is The Magic Whip.There's plenty to enjoy here, although the album does feel maybe a bit too mellow at times. Still, the strong guitar tones keep this from falling into a funk. The album really feels like a logical progression from 13. which is certainly not a bad thing at all.
