I'll start by saying that I loved Big Little Lies, written by the same author.  Funny, sad, well-plotted.  Kept me entertained, and guessing to the end.  Because I liked that book so much, I read this one right after.  This one is not nearly the same quality.To begin, there just wasn't enough story to fill a full-length novel.  A short story, maybe, but not much else.  And there wasn't much of a real plot.  What a reader learns in the first few dozen pages comprises nearly the total substance of the story.  The rest of the book is mostly just a character study.  Because BLL had such unexpected plot twists, I kept expecting that something unexpected would happen in this one.  Nope.  Not really.  Just more of the same, chapter after chapter.  Moriarty attempts to create some uncertainty about the main male character, but that turned out to be smoke and mirrors.  None of that uncertainty panned out into anything.So skip this book, and go straight to BLL.  If you read that, you're in for a treat.

I love Sofft shoes and boots.  I own many pairs.  But this pair is getting sent right back.  Why?  First, the boots (Ebano Brown) are WAY lighter in color than the one shown in the photo.  They are actually tan, not brown.  Second, while they don't fit badly, they don't fit nearly as nicely and comfortably as the other Sofft footwear I own.  Those feel like butter.  These?  Not so much.

This is a pretty mug.  That is why I am giving it two stars instead of one.  But it has a huge and fundamental flaw.  The silicone lid doesn't seal around the lip of the cup very well, so liquid dribbles out all around its circumference.  Every single time I've used it.

This book works on some levels.  As a little slice of life story about a young, poor writer/poet attempting to find her way in the New York literary world, it was interesting.  As a glimpse into an old-school literary agency, it was also interesting.  But there are other aspects that are complete turnoffs regarding both the story and Rakoff herself.First, most obviously, she betrays Salinger.  A strong word, perhaps, but I think it is warranted.  Salinger was an extremely, drastically, notoriously private person.  Rakoff was employed by his literary agency, which worked very hard to protect his privacy.  Confidentiality certainly would have been expected.  For Rakoff, who worked within that realm of confidentiality, to now write a little tell-all book about her interactions with Salinger while she was working at the agency is truly unethical.  That is nearly akin to a paralegal writing a book about her interactions with a client of her law firm.  Rakoff really should be ashamed of herself.Second, Rakoff doesn't write about Salinger from some historic sense of adding to our understanding of the great writer.  No, she does so simply to inflate herself, to put herself in juxtaposition to Salinger in order to generate a little fame by glomming on to his.  How saleable would her book have been without his name attached?  Yeah, you get the picture.Third, her relationship with Don is nearly repulsive, and completely incomprehensible.  A reader never has any sense whatsoever of what she is doing with him.  Near the beginning, she mentions that they are attracted to each other.  So?  Any given person will meet many people to whom he/she is attracted.  That doesn't mean the person should jump into a long-term relationship based solely on that attraction.  And if there was more than physical attraction between Don and Rakoff, we never get the faintest hint of what it might have been.  The scenes between them cause a reader to cringe.Fourth, Rakoff, even as she gets older, apparently was and is very immature.  She dumps her college boyfriend, whom she claims to love, and shacks up with Don, while still claiming to be in love with the (ex) boyfriend.  She later marries a third guy and has two kids with him, and then she dumps him to reunite with the college boyfriend.  This last occurred when she was about 40 years old.  I feel sorry for the kids.

First, I liked this book.  I'd never head of the Dyatlov deaths, and found the story and mystery to be interesting.  If you know little to nothing about the circumstances surrounding the deaths, then you likely will find the book worth at least a good skim.With regard to the conclusion that the author draws regarding what drove the experienced hikers out of their tent with no shoes and inadequate clothing into sub-zero degree weather, it is certainly plausible and rather fascinating.  A worthy possibility.  As a caveat, however, the conclusion is not definitive.  It is one logical option.  So if you are looking for proof positive, you won't get it.  But, again, an interesting hypothesis.The information about the deaths themselves is interesting, and perhaps worth 4 stars.  What detracted significantly from the book, however, were the every-other-chapters about the author himself and his investigation.  I am becoming more and more perplexed as to why non-fiction authors these days inject themselves into the stories they tell, as if they are at least equally as important as the main point of the book.  With very few exceptions, they aren't.  I found myself skimming past, or even skipping, the sections about the author Eichar.  Even the parts that were germane to the story, such as the interviews of the 10th member of the hiking party, who dropped out before the fateful night, didn't need to be partially about Eichar.  Simply convey the information that the 10th hiker provided, without making a big deal about journeying to meet the hiker, talking with the hiker, etc.  (It is as if Jill Lepore, who recently wrote the excellent Book of Ages, spent lots of page time talking about going to libraries to research Jane Franklin, who she met in the libraries, what her own experiences were.  What on earth would that have to do with telling Jane Franklin's story?)  Ahem.  Anyway.  Don't know if the reason for the author's focus on himself was due to ego, or simply a need to stretch the story into book-length, or both.  But if you can overlook this flaw, I would recommend that you give the book a try.

I'm not sure why this book was written.  Please, don't waste your time on its 500+ pages, as I unfortunately did.  Those are hours that I will never get back.  There are many things wrong with the book, but I will attempt to describe only some of them.  (Rack up the Not Helpful votes, but here goes.)First, the book doesn't add anything of interest to the vampire genre.  It is a highly derivative work.  And the few "new" details are unimaginative and add no further dimension.  And, really, the vampires in this book are some of the most uninteresting vampires about which I've ever read.Second, the book is poorly paced.  Very little actually happens, though scads of inert information are continually given.Third, for the most part, the climactic scenes towards the end occur off stage.  Seriously.  The scenes towards which the entire book is leading?  Off-stage.  For instance, during one crucial confrontation, someone is actually sitting on the roof, away from the action, imaging what might be going on downstairs where the confrontation is occurring. ???Fourth, the book needs some drastic editing.  It is far longer than it needs to be to tell the given story.  For instance, the entire first section of the book describes the childhood relationship between two of the characters, before the story itself actually starts.  There is no reason for this section.  It easily could have been summarized briefly in the body of the story.  And, oddly, though those are two of the main characters, there are quite a few other main characters for whom little or no back story is given.  So why give it for just those two?  Very odd.Fifth, due to the previous reasons, among others, the story is dull and tedious, a real slog to read through to the end.Sixth, the ending is silly.  The final last little twist on the last page is one of the most hackneyed, unimaginative, overused twists I've read in a very long time.Seventh, why?  That, really, is my main reaction to the story.  Why did the writer think that this was a good idea?  Why did she spend months, if not years, of her life writing it?  Why did a publisher spend the money to publish and distribute it?  And why has it gotten some good reviews?  Why?  Truly inexplicable.

I was expecting to like this book.  I had read good reviews in several respectable publications, and was especially interested in the assertion, by two different reviewers, that Jamison shows similarities in potential and intelligence to the great essayist Susan Sontag.  And, since essay writing seems to have been nearly forgotten as a popular literary form, it was very nice to see attention being given to the book.  Unfortunately, The Empathy Exams didn't come close to deserving the hype.To get to the heart of the problem, none of the essays seems in the least insightful.  Each essay takes as its topic one aspect of empathy. And, though Jamison relays some information, usually through the telling of a true story, she never pushes beyond the facts to explore the meaning, import, impact, or implications of empathy.  There is essentially no analysis, no exploration of greater significance, no rumination upon empathy as a fundamental quality of many human beings (or what that fundamental quality reveals about greater human nature).  Or, conversely, what a lack of empathy might mean.  The essays never expand beyond the specific stories.  Sadly, I learned nothing beyond the facts (which weren't very interesting).Another disappointment.  The writing was quite dull.  Good writing, non-fiction or otherwise, should be engaging.  It should draw a reader in, seize the intellect and/or imagination, and convey something new to the reader in a way that energizes him/her.  Perhaps Jamison just isn't a very good writer, or perhaps she mistakenly believes that "intellectual" writing must be arid and unenjoyable.  Too bad, either way.  I had to force myself to finish each essay.  And by the end of the volume, I was sadly forced to admit that they weren't worth the time spent.

There certainly are some things to like about this book.  I am not sorry I read it.  A few of the discussions, sparked by books Rose read, are particularly interesting.  For instance, she discusses the belief that female writers aren't taken as seriously as male writers.  Surprisingly for me, I realized I hadn't really thought about that before, since I personally had never made any perceptual distinction between the two sexes as legitimate writers.  But once Rose started exploring the issue, it suddenly became obvious.  Thank you to Rose for that!  As another example, she discusses how books are weeded, that is, how books are permanently removed from library shelves to create shelf space for new acquisitions.  I suppose I must have known this happens, but how, why, the criteria used, etc, were all unknown to me.  More good information!  And her description of the book Gil Blas is a nicely dynamic piece of writing.One of my criticisms of the book is the subtitle: "Adventures in Extreme Reading."  I understand that in today's publishing world a book must capture a reader's attention, sometimes with such a gimmick.  But I find it off-putting.  Reading one shelf of books is hardly, by any stretch of the imagination, extreme.  An interesting little project, perhaps, but nothing more drastic than that.  As a result, the subtitle promises far more depth and drama than the book actually delivers.Another criticism.  I suppose the trend started with Julie Powell's Julia Project (cooking all recipes in Mastering the Art of French Cooking in one year).  Since then, similar types of projects have sprouted like weeds for the purpose of then publishing a book about the project.  Do this for a year, do that for six months, try something different for 4 weeks.  Get some publicity, sign a publishing contract, and, voila, instant fame and success.  Very gimmicky.  This book falls somewhat within that category.  And the problem with such projects, why they seem a little unsavory, is that they often use serious work created by another person/people to cobble together a quick little project for the aforementioned publicity and publishing.  It is as if those project formulators can't create anything original and unique themselves, so they glom onto someone else's abilities and exploit them for personal gain.  I'm not saying that Rose is exactly like that.  She is very successful in her own right.  But this book has the strong whiff of that trend.Overall, the book is somewhat interesting.  It doesn't really comprise a coherent whole, but if the chapters are read as separate essays rather than as related chapters in a single book, the volume makes a little more sense.

This is one of the best books I've read in a long time.  I'd never before read a book by someone who experienced the Cultural Revolution, and, while I knew generalities about it, was stunned by the stark and concise descriptions written by Anchee.  If you've ever wondered what the CR was like for the average Chinese person, this book will tell you, no holds barred.  You will feel yourself, alongside her, kneeling in the mud on horribly hot and humid days, planting rice plants amidst swamps with snakes and vermin slithering all around, all the while knowing that there is little chance that the plants will survive.  Excruciating lessons in futility.Some reviewers have complained about the graphic depiction of sex in the book.  First, it isn't very graphic, nor do those scenes dominate the book in any way.  While I find no use for gratuitous sex scenes, the ones in this book are far from it.  This is a coming of age story as much as it is a story about the CR.  During the CR, people were taught that love was a fake, bourgeois construct, and that sex outside of marriage was punishable by death in many cases.  Discussing the topic was utterly taboo.  What this book explores is how adolescents and young adults, with absolutely no framework into which to place their burgeoning desires, stumble and fumble in confusion while trying to figure it all out.  The sex scenes are placed within that context.  Not gratuitous at all.

I enjoyed this book.  Robbins picked a great style of memoir.  Rather than creating a narrative describing the beginning of his life to present, he chooses episodes- little vignettes and/or observations- that elucidate what was happening at a given point in his life.  These episodes tend to be amusing and unusual, while also managing to convey a greater impression of the man.The book moves along fairly chronologically, with digressions that don't perceptually interfere with that forward motion.  A reader receives a very good sense of how Robbins was living in any particular time frame.  Up until the publication of his second novel in the 1970's, that is.  From there, the memoir falls apart a little.  The chronology becomes somewhat unclear.  He chooses fewer and fewer episodes for a given amount of time.  And how he was living in the later decades, what his general circumstances were, are no longer really described.  Up until the 1970's, the progression of his life was clear.  After that, no so much.  But, still, I enjoyed the read.If you are a Robbins fan, the book is definitely worth the read.  He writes in his seamless, breezy style.  And it is fun to learn about his life, especially his childhood.  If you are neutral about Robbins, or don't really know of him, the book can still be fun, especially, again, the portions about his childhood.  Gives a good description of growing up poor in the South during the Depression (which is not nearly as depressing as it sounds).

To begin, I must equate this book with the movie Seabiscuit.  Why, you might ask?  Because, while this is a non-fiction book/story, it isn't a straight, evenly presented, all facets explored kind of non-fiction.  Rather, it is non-fiction that has been shaped and perhaps somewhat manipulated into a rousing, emotion-evoking story.  Like Seabiscuit.  That being said, for what this book is, it is a good and fun read.I had never given a second (or even a first) thought to ultra-marathoning.  Ever.  Until I happened to pick up Eat & Run by Scott Jurek at the library recently, and liked it considerably.  That book led to this book.  And here we are.  The lesson being, you don't have to be a running aficianado to enjoy either book.  This book, like Jurek's, is a story of human endurance, of human possibility, of the amazing feats people can accomplish when true strength of mind overcomes any physical obstacle.  Rousing and emotion-evoking, yes, but elucidating fundamental truth.  Enjoy!

I'll preface my review by saying that I had never heard of Scott Jurek before picking up this book.  I don't follow running at all, and so came to his story with nary a preconceived notion.  But the inner jacket description sounded interesting, I like to read about unfamiliar things, so I gave it a shot.  Glad that I did.Other than one quibble, which I'll mention below, I very much enjoyed this book.  It was an easy and engaging read.  Scott (and his co-writer) write in a lucid manner.  Scott's own voice rang through loud and clear.  (That is unfortunately unusual in books these days.)  His experiences are truly impressive and fascinating.  Even as someone who has never followed the sport (though I used to run a little for exercise), I found real inspiration from Scott's accomplishments and attitude (both as a runner and as a person).A crucial aspect of the book: you don't have to care one whit about veganism to enjoy the book!!  I, myself, found that part very interesting, but it in no way overshadows the rest of Scott's story.  The vegan aspect is presented with a very light hand.  So don't let it deter you from reading the book!!The quibble.  Scott mentions here and there throughout the book that he has read philosophy since a teenager.  He says that this learning has impacted him greatly.  But other than a brief description of how the ideas behind bushido influenced him, he doesn't explain at all which philosophies impacted him and, more importantly, how they impacted him.  I very much would have liked more discussion about that.  I don't know if the reading didn't have as much of an impact as he says, or if he simply didn't know how to articulate the impact, or if the publisher discouraged too much of a philosophical discussion in order to appeal to a lower common denominator.  (I would guess the last, but don't know.)I usually don't address points made in other reviews in my own reviews, but will make an exception in this case.  I have no problem with negative reviews that are rational, based on a book.  But some of the negative reviews for this book display real anger and vitriol.  Very strange.  There seems to be some sort of hidden subtext and motivation behind them.  First, some people complain that this book is too much about Scott, that it is self-centered.  ????  It is a memoir about his life.  Of course it is about him.  One person claims that he abandoned his wife and treats his friends badly.  ????  His wife fell in love with someone else and filed for divorce.  And how did he treat his friends badly?  No hint of that in the book.  Another reviewer claims that he was an obnoxious competitor.  ????  Not only is there no hint of that in the book, but from what I've read elsewhere, the running community at large believes him to be one of the least egotistical champions out there.  A few people, with real annoyance, claim that veganism is pure drivel, that there is no proof whatsoever that eating vegan is any better than chowing down on cheeseburgers and steak.  Hmmm.  First, if, over 25 years of competing, Scott has found that eating vegan makes him much more fit and healthy, and gives him far greater stamina, then I believe him.  What possible reason could he have for lying?  (The great vegan industrial complex is paying him millions?)  Second, I would bet every last penny I have that not one of the angry detractors has ever eaten a healthful vegan diet (whole grains, legumes, fruits, veggies) for any amount of time whatsoever.  Because, if he had, he would have felt immensely better after about the first week.  (I've tried all eating styles, and feel soooooo much better eating a healthful vegan diet.)Anyway, if you wish to read an interesting book about the amazing (non)limits that humans can achieve, and enjoy a lucid, clear narrative voice, give this book a try.  It is highly enjoyable.

Apparently I'm not as enamored of this book as most people seem to be.  It isn't bad, hence the 3 stars.  But it isn't particularly good.  I've made about 15 of the recipes, and they were all fine, but none of them were delicious.  None were the type that I would want to serve to anyone outside my family.  And, really, I serve them to my family only when I need something both very quick and healthful.  I have so many other vegan recipes that are truly delicious.  This book has retreated to fallback position.I still make recipes from the book, for this one reason.  I like having something healthful in the fridge, so that if I want lunch or a snack, there is something already prepared, thereby preventing unhealthful grazing.  I would recommend this book if you are looking to fill that niche.  And most of the recipes use ingredients that are already in a decently stocked kitchen, so you won't have to run to the store for something unusual.One aspect of the book that is a tad bit off-putting.  Nixon changes, sometimes significantly, traditional recipes from many cultures, making them both vegan and easy to prepare from standard U.S. ingredients.  That's fine.  But she still calls her recipes by the traditional recipe names.  It seems a bit presumptuous, in a steam-rolling western kind of way, to usurp something from another culture, change it significantly, but still call it by its traditional name.  (Certainly use traditional recipes for inspiration, but call them something different.)  I'll likely get lots of Not Helpful votes for daring to say that.  But, really, think about it.  Isn't that kind of rude?

I would give this book 3.5 stars, if I could.  Since I can't, the question becomes, 3 or 4 stars?  Since I would recommend it, I'll round up to 4.The characterization is very good, far better than in most novels these days.  Not once did it seem as if each character weren't real.  They all spoke loudly and clearly in their own distinct voices.  It was this aspect of the book, the people, that was the most enjoyable part of the read.  Together they created a unique story world.  If you want to immerse yourself in the Southern domain of the 1930's (or at least the author's vision of it), this book will take you right there.The plot is a little weak.  I knew from nearly the very beginning who the killer likely was, and I was correct.  And the plot is a bit sparse and linear.  But, still, given the rich texture of characterization and character interaction, the plot sparsity is nicely filled in.  Again, I would recommend this book.  And unfortunately, these days, there are very few new novels that I would recommend.

This book didn't sit well with me, for a variety of reasons, some of which I'll try to explain.  To begin, the book's structure is off-putting.  It is broken into small sections, most only a few pages long, with each being written from the viewpoint of one of the authors.  I understand that all three wanted to tell their stories, each from his/her own point of view, but the constant jerking between them was disruptive.  What made this structure even worse, all three speak in essentially the same literary voice.  Meaning, it is nearly impossible to tell one person's section from another simply by reading them.  (I had to keep referring to the listed name at the start of each section to keep them straight.)  Without being able to hear each person as an individual, it is somewhat difficult to immerse oneself in the story.  I wish they had found a more engaging and elegant way to convey their stories.Another problem.  This has been mentioned by quite a few other people.  I have a difficult time believing that the hikers had no clue where they were. Why?  I've traveled extensively both in the U.S. and in foreign countries on multiple continents, and not once did I not know where I was.  Especially if there was a border anywhere nearby.  That just doesn't happen with experienced travelers.  And, given the extremely fraught nature of the greater Middle East area, it would be even more imperative for any experienced traveler with any common sense to be extremely situationally aware.  Especially since it was the IRANIAN border.  But these three claim that they thought they were 100 miles from the border.  Not one mile, where some confusion might be expected, but 100 miles.  That is a huge distance, especially in the mountains.My next paragraphs will probably cause the Not Helpful votes to rack up like a pinball machine score, but I've got to be honest and tell you what I think.  First, I was put off by the fact that the hikers refuse (to this day) to admit that they did anything wrong, or in any way contributed whatsoever to their imprisonment.  I am not saying at all that what happened to them was justified.  But look at the situation.  Three Americans hiking within a few feet of the Iranian border?  What did they think was going to happen?  What do you think the U.S. would do if three North Korean hikers were found in the mountains at the Canadian/U.S. border without required papers?  They certainly would be detained and questioned, as they should be.  (Not imprisoned for years, but you get the point.)  It is as if the authors feel that they should be able to do anything they want, without realistic consequences because, hey, don't you know who we are?Another negative.  The hikers, in the years before their imprisonment, as well as during their imprisonment, made a big deal out of being so sympathetic to and understanding of the Middle East Arab and Persian plights, and so critical of the U.S.  Gosh, Mr. Iranian interrogator, we disagree with the U.S. and empathize with you greatly.  If you could just understand how much we sympathize, you would know that we're really on your side.  (This wasn't a strategy.  They actually believed this.)  The sheer hypocrisy of this attitude is almost overwhelming, and yet the crazy thing is that none of the three hikers has the faintest recognition of his/her hypocrisy.  They are sitting in a prison in which the Iranians are brutally torturing and killing their own political dissenters, and yet the hikers sincerely explain to their captors how much they sympathize with Iran, and disagree with the U.S.  And they are stunned that their captors don't say, oh, you sympathize with us?  Gosh, we'll release you because we're such great and tolerant people.  How can the hikers possibly be that blind?  Inexplicable.  This is Sarah, speaking to Ahmadinejad himself, after her release: "The three of us are very critical of our government's foreign policy.  We are all against the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.  I even helped organize a protest against bombing Iran when I was in my twenties.  Will you tell this to the [Iranian] judiciary?"  And yet, oddly, Sarah doesn't beg Ahmadinejad to be allowed to leave the U.S. and live in wonderful Iran.  Hmmm.Another problem.  The hikers continually insist throughout the book that Sarah spends her captivity in solitary confinement.  This annoys me.  I've spent many years volunteering time with organizations that attempt to help brutalized political prisoners in many countries.  And, let me tell you, Sarah is not in solitary confinement.  Simply being by herself in a cell doesn't qualify.  She is regularly, almost daily, taken to visit the other two hikers.  They spend large amounts of time together.  She also has regular interactions with non-hostile guards and some fellow prisoners.  This doesn't constitute solitary confinement.  The continual misuse of this term is a huge slap in the face to all of the political prisoners who truly live in solitary.And, I don't know how else to say it, the hikers' continual whining was embarrassing.  Being imprisoned is horrible.  No doubt about it.  But they, like many Americans (myself included), have led such easy and entitled lives, in which I'm sure they were continually told how important and unique they are, that they seem to have no mental capacity to deal with, or even comprehend, adversity.  Bad things just can't or shouldn't happen to them.  We hiked at the Iranian border.  We were imprisoned as a result (which was an entirely foreseeable consequence), but how can this possibly be happening to us?  Don't you know how unique and intelligent and empathetic we are?  Don't you know how cool we are to have lived in foreign countries and thought so very much about the plight of you poor Iranian government, so abused by the dastardly Americans?  Don't you know... don't you know... don't you know how very special we are?  Because we're us.  Us.  Isn't our value self-evident?Next, the hikers aren't abused in any way.  Other than a few scuffles, nothing physically bad happens to them.  They are given plenty of food and water, books, even a refrigerator, TV, VCR, and delicious birthday cake.  During this time, on more than one occasion, they hear the horrible screams of Iranian prisoners being brutally tortured.  So the hikers' complaining about relative trivialities casts them in a very unsympathetic light.One positive use for this book: it is an excellent, if inadvertent, psychological study of truly entrenched and unthinking white American entitlement.  First example.  After being released, Sarah thinks, "I'm not sure that I've ever felt anything akin to nationalism in my life- my core identity has largely been shaped in response to (and rebellion against) what I dislike about my culture...greed, selfish individualism, a sense of superiority and entitlement over others."  Unbelievable.  Why?  Because the three hikers continually display and embody every single one of these attributes, apart from greed.  They are the living essence of them.  They feel so incredibly entitled and selfishly individual, that they have no ability to self-reflect and recognize that truth.  (And, might it be pointed out, that American taxpayers contribute more humanitarian aid to people around the world than just about all other countries combined.  Very selfish and greedy.)Second example.  The hikers have a firmly entrenched image of who they are.  And not even a deep, internal image, but an image that they believe they project to the exterior world.  A superficial, look at my fabulous empathy image.  And it is amazing how they can twist their perception of events to fit this image.  This is Josh, witnessing a minor and equal scuffle between Shane and a guard: "I can't be mad at Shane for fighting with [the guard].  Even Gandhi wrote that he would choose violent resistance over cowardice.  That was what Shane did.  Perhaps fighting, yet refusing to gang up on [the guard], was Gandhian."  Wow.  So Shane gets into a little scuffle with a guard, but it can't just be that.  No.  These hikers have such an inflated view of themselves, of their grand importance, that in having a scuffle Shane isn't Shane having a scuffle.  No, Shane is like... Gandhi.  I say it again.  Wow.Again, rack up the Not Helpfuls, write nasty comments, but here goes.  Get over it, you three hikers.  Get over it.  Something bad happened to you.  Something that was somewhat foreseeable, given the circumstances and your actions.  You are partially to blame.  While imprisoned, you were treated well, allowed to see each other, fed, watered, showered, tolerated even when you screamed at guards, slapped them, and demanded things.  You are extremely lucky that you are Americans, that you are from a great and tolerant country, because if you had been Iranian, you would have been tortured, raped, and killed by your own government.  Put that in perspective, why don't you?

As I write this, this product costs $7.95 per pound.**  I have heard it said by some people that reviews should be about the product alone, rather than also about the price.  Hmmm.  Perhaps for wealthy people that is true.  But in my life I've never met anyone for whom price isn't an issue.  Price, for any regular person, is always an issue when deciding to purchase something.  At least as important as the particular item itself.  That being said, while the flour itself is fine, the price is exorbitant.I purchase Bob's Red Mill garbanzo bean flour at my local (rather expensive) store for $3.84 for 2 pounds (twice the quantity offered here).  This product costs $15.90 on Amazon for the exact same quantity.So, flame me if you like.  Rack up the Not Helpful votes.  But if you, like me, don't have endless money to waste, consider purchasing this item elsewhere, if you can.  If this is your only option, however, then I'm truly sorry for your added expense.**If the price lowers considerably, then please disregard this review.  Thanks!!**

The characterization in this novel is lovely.  It kept me going long after most books would have, given the lack of plot and suspense.  I very much wish that Baker had married this characterization to a more compelling story.I am not all about crazy suspense or action.  I believe that any suspense or action must be equally balanced by true depth of character.  Most novels, unfortunately, are action/plot heavy and characterization light.  This book is unusual in that it reverses that balance.A bus accident occurs right at the beginning of the story.  Very soon thereafter, we know who caused the accident.  The rest of the book is simply character interaction and development, loosely hanging on the fact of that accident.  The vast majority of characters don't know who caused the accident, but, and this is significant, the reader does.  Wondering if the characters are going to discover the truth doesn't really create any suspense.  That is the mistake that Baker makes.  If the reader knows, even if the characters don't, suspense is minimal.So, not much happens plot-wise for most of the book.  Then all of a sudden, at the very end, there is a very quick rush of a denouement, in which truths are revealed and death occurs.  The plot goes from zero to sixty in about 10 pages.  Very abruptly.  Unsatisfying.Baker clearly can write.  Again, the characterizations are lovely.  So I can't wait until she can join characterization with plot.  Now THAT is a book I would like to read!!!!

There is a lot to like about this book.  The characters are interesting and well-drawn (which is fairly unusual in popular thrillers these days).  The story is interesting for the first two-thirds or so of the book.  It kept me engaged and interested.  I was really liking the novel, and would have recommended it without qualification, until I started reading the final third or so.In the final third the story devolves into a cookie cutter, hackneyed plot, the kind that has been used too many times in mediocre thrillers.  I won't say what happened, but it was trite, implausible, and kind of silly.  Given the first two-thirds of the story, I know that Elo is capable of far better.  I wish she had devised a more interesting and elegant climax and conclusion.

This is McHugh's first novel.  She does have talent.  She writes scenes in a way that made me truly believe the people and the action.  In that regard it was an effortless read.  I enjoyed the setting, the characters, and the story.My quibble with the book is this.  McHugh has yet to develop a feel for dramatic pacing.  The book moved along at one speed at all times.  That is, the pacing was very even.  What should have been the more tense, dramatic, and/or climactic scenes didn't feel any different from any other scene.  Even the denouement, when the bad guy gets his due, didn't feel much different from a baby shower that was depicted.  For this reason, at the end, nothing of particular consequence seems to have happened.  There is no sense of reader catharsis whatsoever.Now that I think about it, I'll add one more (slight) negative.  The story was structured as two parallel stories, one following Lila as a young woman and the other following Lila's daughter Lucy as a young woman.  Parallel structure is fine, in story, theme, etc.  But in this book the parallels became too obvious and heavy-handed.  In fact, in Lucy's story, a potential love interest, Daniel, appears, but serves no real purpose other than as a parallel to Lucy's father Carl.  If Daniel didn't exist, the story wouldn't really have progressed any differently.  And that is just one example.I enjoyed the book to some degree, but I can't quite say that I would recommend it to others. There are other novels of mystery and/or suspense that are far more well-paced and suspenseful.  But I will read McHugh's next book, to see if she has matured as a writer.

Wow!  I give very few books, of any kind, 5 stars, because for me a book must be essentially flawless to rate that high.  Ancient Grains deserves those full 5 stars, and more.I cook mostly vegetarian, with a little vegan thrown in.  Though this book has a few non-vegetarian recipes, the vast majority are vegetarian, and some are vegan.  This is one of my very favorite, go-to cookbooks.  Whether for a quick meal on a weeknight, or a more impressive weekend meal for guests, this book is fantastic.And lest you think I'm rating the book based on the photos or the sound of the recipes, I've cooked at least 15 of the recipes, and have adored them all.  There is one recipe, in particular, a warm oat berry salad with blue cheese, green olives, and walnuts, to which I am absolutely addicted.  I've made it at least a dozen times, and plan to make it many more.  And the creamy farro porridge with honey roasted grapes?  Ahhhhhhhh.........As for the skill level required by the recipes, I would say that the vast majority of them are quite easy for anyone with a rudimentary cooking skill set.  And the ingredient lists aren't long at all, for the most part.  This is one of those recipe books that proves that a few good, fresh, tasty ingredients can be combined into a fantastic meal.I seldom gush, but this book is fantastic.

I love some of Jillian's other videos, especially 30 Day Shred and Banish Fat Boost Metabolism.  I would recommend them highly.  But in Yoga Meltdown Jillian misses the mark.  After using quite a few of her other videos, I've gotten to know her on-screen persona fairly well.  Compared to those other videos, it seems as if Jillian didn't particularly like making Yoga Meltdown.  She is frown-y, slightly grouchy, and has no enthusiasm for the yoga workout.  I'm guessing that since yoga is currently popular, her team told her that she needed to make a yoga video, so she did.  But her heart clearly wasn't in it.  So it is difficult, while doing the video, to have any enthusiasm for the workout when the instructor doesn't.As for the yoga itself, well, it isn't.  Yoga, that is.  I wasn't expecting strictly traditional yoga.  This is Jillian, after all.  But this workout can be called yoga only with the very most tenuous of connections.  And it is one more example of an ancient and lovely practice being co-opted without any respect or understanding for its true nature.  My recommendation would be to give this video a pass, but to try the two excellent videos that I mentioned in the first sentence.

I must say, I like this book. It has a few flaws, which I will mention near the bottom, but overall I found the volume to be quite useful. To begin, the text itself is completely understandable to a modern Westerner. It is clear, concise, and conveys complicated ideas in a comprehensible manner. This quality may be due in part to the particular translation, but it is also largely due to the clear writing of Hakuin himself. Why do I mention this at the beginning? I've read other older/traditional Asian Buddhist texts, and many of them are highly abstruse, even for an educated Westerner. They often seem as if the reader must have a large well of cultural and experiential background knowledge in order for the texts to even begin to make sense. With this book, however, any intelligent person can pick it up and immediately gain useful knowledge.I've been studying Buddhism for a couple of years, and have found myself a bit confused by the many different strains of Buddhism. This book is the first I've read that clearly explains the difference between Zen Buddhism and Pure Land Buddhism. (Very roughly, Pure Land Buddhism relies solely on meditation to achieve enlightenment, while Zen views kensho- a sudden, clear insight- as the first true and necessary step to gaining enlightenment. After kensho has been experienced, the hard work of both meditation and study has just begun. Pondering koans is one essential method that leads to kensho.)And this book not only explains Zen, but it does so in a truly traditional Japanese way, in the words of a Japanese master. I like many books about Buddhism written by modern Western writers and/or for a Western audience, but they sometimes can seem too superficial. That is, they don't really delve down deep into simple but fundamental truth. And too many of them also go to great pains to be so very secular, eschewing any hint that Buddhism has a religious-like aspect, and instead treat Buddhism almost like a self-help regimen. This book is a refreshing and needed change from that type of book.I wasn't expecting this, but Hakuin has a sense of humor that shines through very clearly. One example: "You could take a conventional explanation like this, knead it up with some good rice, and stick it out under the trees for a thousand days, without getting even a crow to fly by for a second look."I mentioned above that the book has a few flaws. Flaws might not be the correct word. Perhaps negativities might be better. Hakuin spends a considerable amount of page space excoriating both Pure Land Buddhism and false Zen masters. Some explanation of why he doesn't like them is reasonable, but he goes on at great length. Hakuin was also a main proponent of screaming at students, beating them with sticks, and starving them. This seems extremely un-Buddhist-like to me. In addition, hell is mentioned frequently. And not a theoretical hell, but a fiery, horrible hell. Again, doesn't seen like Buddhism. (But I am a newbie, so what do I know?)Overall, I would recommend this book highly. The text itself is very useful. And it is preceded by both an excellent Translator's Introduction and a Foreward.

I must say, I like this book.  It has a few flaws, which I will mention near the bottom, but overall I found the volume to be quite useful.  To begin, the text itself is completely understandable to a modern Westerner.  It is clear, concise, and conveys complicated ideas in a comprehensible manner.  This quality may be due in part to the particular translation, but it is also largely due to the clear writing of Hakuin himself.  Why do I mention this at the beginning? After kensho has been experienced, the hard work of both meditation and study has just begun.  Pondering koans is one essential method that leads to kensho.)And this book not only explains Zen, but it does so in a truly traditional Japanese way, in the words of a Japanese master.  I like many books about Buddhism written by modern Western writers and/or for a Western audience, but they sometimes can seem too superficial.  That is, they don't really delve down deep into simple but fundamental truth.  And too many of them also go to great pains to be so very secular, eschewing any hint that Buddhism has a religious-like aspect, and instead treat Buddhism almost like a self-help regimen.  This book is a refreshing and needed change from that type of book.I wasn't expecting this, but Hakuin has a sense of humor that shines through very clearly.  One example:  "You could take a conventional explanation like this, knead it up with some good rice, and stick it out under the trees for a thousand days, without getting even a crow to fly by for a second look."I mentioned above that the book has a few flaws.  Flaws might not be the correct word.  Perhaps negativities might be better.  Hakuin spends a considerable amount of page space excoriating both Pure Land Buddhism and false Zen masters.  Some explanation of why he doesn't like them is reasonable, but he goes on at great length.  Hakuin was also a main proponent of screaming at students, beating them with sticks, and starving them.  This seems extremely un-Buddhist-like to me.  In addition, hell is mentioned frequently.  And not a theoretical hell, but a fiery, horrible hell.  Again, doesn't seen like Buddhism.  (But I am a newbie, so what do I know?)Overall, I would recommend this book highly.  The text itself is very useful.  And it is preceded by both an excellent Translator's Introduction and a Foreward.

Our closet is too small to hold several laundry bins, so we have to set them out in the bedroom itself.  To keep them from being visually obvious, I wanted nice-looking, neutral colored hampers that also 1) can hold a decent amount, 2) are easily carry-able down 2 flights of stairs, and 3) are a reasonable price.These hampers fit all of those criteria, except...  The interiors are a bright medium blue.  Since the bins are only about 23" high, when you stand in the room you look down into them, so the interior blue is just as obvious, if not more so, than the tan/cream exterior.  Too bad.  If the interiors had been the same color as the exterior, these hampers would have been 5 star perfect.  Apart from the blue, however, I am quite pleased with the hampers and would recommend them.The exterior is made of a nice light tan canvas-like material.  Just what I was looking for.  They are a useful, largish size, larger than 23" by 14" by 14" sounds.  I'd say they each hold about a load and a half of laundry, so they don't fill too quickly.  Perfect.  The handles make the hamper easy to lift and carry.  I've never had any problem carrying a full hamper up or down 2 flight of stairs.  The price is very reasonable, especially for the quality.  These aren't shoddy boxes.  Instead, they are actually well-designed.  The blue material on the interior is an easily cleanable smooth synthetic.  A square insert, made of the same blue material, fits down into the bottom of the hamper to keep it open.  But if you remove that insert, the hamper easily folds flat for streamlined storage.Overall, the hampers are better than I would have hoped for, especially for the price.

I first read this book as a youngster back in the 1980's, and it was already nearly a quarter of a century old then.  In my twelve-year-old perception, I thought it was a good book, and have remembered it fondly every since, though the details became vaguer and vaguer with time.  Then, for some reason, the other week I thought of this book (and of Stewart's books in general) and decided to read it again.  To my surprise, it actually has stood the test of time.  And my much older self liked it nearly as much as my younger self.This is not a literary book.  It is not weighty stuff.  But it is a fun, light, classic mystery, the kind that one might read on a beach (although it is better than the average modern beach read these days).  It moves along at a fairly brisk pace.  It has a bit of exotic mystery.  The characters, while not particularly well-developed, are all distinct and clear.  It does suffer a tad from implausibility, in that, for the sake of moving the plot along, an intelligent character makes a couple of silly choices, which (wouldn't you know it) put her in danger.  But overall, a nice, breezy read.Given that the book is now 50 years old, a good question would be, how dated does it seem?  It doesn't seem dated at all, except for two minor exceptions.  If I hadn't known better, I might have assumed it was written recently.  The two exceptions?  First, the main characters view the Corfu "peasants" in a rather patronizing way.  Second, one kiss between two of the characters apparently causes the female to fall so deeply in love that she will do anything for the guy.  Other than those two minor aspects, the rest of the book seems entirely modern.  If you want a fun, light read, you might want to give this book a try.

I've been using various Moosewood cookbooks for a couple of decades, and this is by far my favorite among them.  (Remember the older Moosewood books that were filled with recipes for lentil loaf, cashew cheese, etc? :-) )  This is the kind of recipe book that you can pick up after getting home from work, and find something that sounds delicious, but that is also quick and easy to make.  The specific recipes that I've tried so far have all turned out very nicely.  And you don't have to be any sort of expert cook to prepare the recipes.  A basic knowledge of cooking will allow you to successfully complete most of them, and a decent knowledge of cooking will allow you to complete all of them.  This book is quickly becoming a kitchen staple for me.I will emphasize the word "staple."  This book contains many staple-type recipes.  Fine by me.  That sort of cookbook certainly has its place in my repertoire.  If, however, you are looking for more uniquely inventive (though not complicated) vegetarian recipes, try New Vegetarian Kitchen by Nicola Graimes.  Truly spectacular.It is SO nice that vegetarian and vegan recipes are now becoming so much more fresh and appealing.  I look at such cookbooks from the '70's, '80's, and even '90's, and so many of the recipes seem to be like hairshirt punishments, giving that sense that a person is being so conscientiously sacrificial to pursue a vegetarian/vegan eating style.  But v/v has come a long way, emerging into truly tasty goodness.  This cookbook is a terrific example of that emergence.  Eat well, and enjoy!

I paid $7.97 for each panel.  At that price, I give these curtains 4 stars.  The Mandarin color is true to the product photo.  The "silk" material is nice.  Overall, these curtains add a nice color accent in my room, which is exactly what I wanted.  I am pleased with them.Apart from the low price, these curtains do have some flaws of which you might want to be aware.  When viewed up close, it becomes clear that they are rather shoddily made.  Just below the hanging rings, there is a horizontal seam that runs the width of the panel.  The seam is very crooked/wavy.  And the horizontal seam at the bottom of the curtain is also crooked/wavy.  These flaws aren't particularly noticeable from any distance.The material in very thin.  For my purposes, that isn't a problem.  However, if you are expecting the curtains to act as visual barriers between inside and outside of a dwelling, they won't.  If the room is lit at night, everything in that room will be clearly visible from the exterior of the dwelling.  And during the day, the curtains let in a considerable amount of light.**I wouldn't pay much more than I did for these curtains.  They aren't worth a higher price.  However, if you simply want a nice accent of color in a room, the curtains aren't a bad deal overall.  I've seen curtains of a similar quality at much higher prices, so I consider these to be a fairly good find.

I've tried other Stash teas that I've liked considerably, including Breakfast in Paris and Pomegranate Raspberry Green Tea.  But this Coconut Mango Oolong really misses the mark.  First, there isn't a hint of wuyi oolong flavor.  Nada.  Tastes like a tea-less herbal "tea."  That, in and of itself, wouldn't be a problem if the tea were good.  But it tastes very strongly and harshly of coconut.  I love coconut.  It's one of my favorite flavors.  But this coconut isn't good.  It tastes artificial (even though I believe it isn't).  There is a faint mango flavor, but it doesn't balance the strong coconut flavor.  Not good.  Wouldn't recommend it.  If you're looking for a tea that tastes of tea but has a pleasant additional essence, try Breakfast in Paris.  Tasty.

This is a lovely little book.  In it Pennington explains the contemplative life to the layman- its patterns and attributes, the more profound meaning of various monastic rules apart from their mere observance, and the methods by which a layman can incorporate contemplative/monastic aspects into his/her regular daily life.  This isn't a particularly deep discussion, but it does provide useful information presented in a simply elegant and easily read style.  This book can be read quite quickly, and yet a reader walks away with far more information and understanding than the shortish length might suggest.This book isn't just for Christians.  I'm a practicing Buddhist who loves reading about all religions.  There is a great deal in common between Buddhists and contemplative/mystic Christians.  This book, elucidating the Christian monastic rule, enhances the understanding of Buddhist meditation.  Highly recommend it to Buddhists and Christians alike.

Vitamin C serum is a crucial step in my daily skincare routine...it has been for the last year, and I'm always searching for the perfect, well-made serum to use that actually fits my budget. The serum will actually help to draw the moisturizer into your skin...just be sure to let your products dry between every step to avoid any flakiness, especially if you'll be applying makeup after you apply the serum.This serum feels really smooth and silky on my skin, which really just seems to love and soak it up. I don't have any age spots yet, but I would prefer to prevent them while helping my skin to look young and healthy, and this serum is an affordable way to help with that.I received this vitamin C serum for the purpose of my review, but my opinions are 100% my own, and based on MY personal use. I was not told what to say, only asked to give an honest review based on my own experience with the product.

This scale is simple, yet incredibly elegant! I've had few expensive scales that save different users' info, track weight loss or gain, and break down things like % body fat for the user, and they're great...but not really for me! What I really wanted was a scale that everyone in the house could use without having to 'learn how', and that's exactly what I got!Once I got things switched from kg to lb (you do this by crouching, so make sure you're not too close to a wall..haha I learned the hard way), it was really quick and easy to use. You don't have to tap it, step on and off, or do anything at all to turn it on, you just step on, and it reads super-fast, which is perfect for the youngest, most impatient members of my family who don't like to stand still. The lowest weight that it measures is about 10kg, which is around 22 lbs, so it works for all of us, from age 3-30.The initial charge that it came with didn't last long, but it only took a few hours to charge with the included USB cable...the BEST part about this, besides the obvious fact that I don't ever have to replace batteries in my scale again, is that there's a storage compartment on the bottom of the scale for the cord, so I'm not going to lose it, or get stuck searching for a cord. That's a huge deal for me, because it seems like that everything comes with a cord, and I have a hard time remembering which cord goes with what.I really like the sleek, shiny design of this scale, and how well it fits into my bathroom's decor without sticking out like a sore thumb. It also doesn't look like a big, shiny toy, so I don't find the kids in the bathroom playing with it too much, either. This is a great, simple scale for the price that has some amazing features, like the usb charging function, that I haven't seen in a scale before.I purchased this scale at a discount for the purpose of my review, but my opinions are 100% my own, and based on MY personal use. I was not told what to say, only asked to give an honest review based on my own experience with the product.

I'm always skeptical when buying new seat covers for my car...Especially when they clam to be 'universal fit'...but these are really versatile to fit many different seat styles, including mine, which is most important to me!When I opened the package, I was immediately overwhelmed with all of the different pieces. It was tough to figure out what was supposed to go where, so I took it all out to my car, checked out the instructions, and got to work. I started with the back seat. I figured that would be the toughest to install and fit properly, and I wasn't incorrect. The instructions say to pull up or completely remove the seat bottom to ensure a perfect fit...I almost gave up then and there, because I don't believe that I could put the seat back on properly if I removed it. It's just not an option in my older car. But the edges of my seat pulled up just well enough for me to get a good fit and hook the elastic strips together. I had to cut holes for the seat belt buckles, which was a little frustrating, but it makes sense, because of all of the different types of seats.I didn't have to do any unzipping or anything to put the backrest portion of the back seat cover on, thanks to the fact that I have a pretty standard seat for a car, so I just pulled it down like I do to access the trunk and worked the straps into the crack until I could get them to click together, tightened them, then tightened all of the little elastic straps. Both the cover for the seat bottom and back actually fit well, and give the back seat of my car a whole new look.The front seat covers were a bit easier than the back, with no cutting necessary (I just pulled the headrest covers off, rather than cutting them, and they came away easily). Once I pulled the flap through the back like the instructions said, they looked nice and tight-fitting, like they were made specifically for my car. The steering wheel cover wasn't too tough to convince onto the wheel, and the seat belt covers are padded nicely, with strong velcro. Overall, I'm really pleased with this set. The colors are really vibrant, and my old car feels just a bit nicer! I will be purchasing a set for my boyfriend's truck for his birthday. I can't wait to see how they fit!I purchased this set of seat covers and accessories at a discount for the purpose of my review, but my opinions are 100% my own, and based on MY personal use. I was not told what to say, only asked to give an honest review based on my own experience with the product.

I am in LOVE! FINALLY, after 30 years, my search for the perfect eyeliner is over! I have tried liquid eyeliner (runny, tough to apply, comes right off), I've tried pencil eyeliner (so many different brands/styles over the years..a few were great, but ridiculously expensive), crayon-style (again, great, but expensive)...This was my very first gel eyeliner. Seriously. I'm in love!The first time I tried to apply it, I had a rough time due to my inexperience. I ended up with a few clumps, but it was still easier than any liquid I've ever used. (I need to buy a good brush...for the time being, I'm using the brush to my liquid eyeliner from the dollar store, but it works well). I was impressed with how well it actually stayed on..usually the outside corners of my eyes tend to leak just enough that i end up with little black teardrops in the outer corners of my eyes, but this process took a LOT longer with this gel eyeliner.Yesterday, I wore this eyeliner to a funeral...the ultimate waterproof test. After hours of crying and dabbing at my eyes, I was AMAZED at how little of the liner came off onto my tissue! This stuff honestly held up througout the entire day, with very very little coming off. This is such a beautiful solution for small-print! I got this as a gift for my mother, who is legally blind but can see directly in front of her. I've been seeing 'greens' around for a really long time, but I'm one of those people who is skeptical to try something like this, no matter how many people tell me that they like it. I have a really strong sense of smell and taste, so sometimes the nutrient-packed superfoods just aren't for me. This is NOT one of those things. This is for me! I have to admit, I wasn't so sure that I could handle the strong 'green' taste at first...I tried it in my iced cappuccino, and I hated it. Never do that to coffee. Well...try it, but don't try a whole scoop at first, and make sure you take your sweet time mixing it up really really well. Day two I tried it in this little Dole fruit and yogurt smoothie thing, and I was absolutely hooked. I love the smoothies, but I have trouble justifying the amount of sugar that's in them...Drinking my greens in the morning gives me a great reason to drink my favorite yummy smoothies, and the sweet taste of the greens is actually really, really good! I've been using a scoop a day, in the morning, for about a week and a half now. I notice a difference on days when I don't get my greens. I'm a bit run-down, more on-edge, and more likely to really want that afternoon nap.I'm very prone to depression, but refuse to take medication, so I love it when I find an all-natural supplement that gives me the mood boost that I need. I've heard that greens are really amazing for the immune system too, and I have to admit that I had a sore throat this week, but it lasted for one day. That's it. I was pretty impressed! This is absolutely the perfect thing for this busy mom/ college student. This review of the performance is taken from Disc 1 of BBC Legends (ICA Classics ICAB 5113), a set of 20 discs of BBC classic performances that contains numerous superb performances of classical works.I first began a 40-year passion for Mahler symphonies when reviewer David Hall of the now-defunct Stereo Review recommended Solti’s highly-charged account of Symphony 8.  I have sought out recordings of this work ever since, each time hoping to find the Holy Grail performance.  When I recently learned of Horenstein’s legacy for this symphony, I was disappointed to find it only available at highway-robbery prices.  I wondered, could it really be worth it?  And the quick answer to that question is YES!I am in general agreement with the bulk of positive comments regarding this performance.  Despite less than superb sound and a wish for a slightly quicker tempo, both in the 1st Movement, and some ensemble imprecision at times throughout, this account approaches very close to the Holy Grail.  It is an emotion-provoking performance of the highest order.  The climaxes are simply awe-inspiring.  I am writing this review during the fourth time I have listened to it in 24 hours.  Nuff said?  I am also hearing orchestral and choral details that I have previously missed in other recordings.  What it must have been like to have heard this performance live.  I can only drool in envy.  If ever a group of musicians performed with more profound inspiration, I’ve never heard it.Needless to say at this point, I cannot recommend this recording more highly.  I am still looking for the Holy Grail, but Horenstein will more than suffice until I find it - if that is even possible!

This set of Beethoven’s Nine Symphonies performed by George Szell and the Cleveland Orchestra and recorded between 1962 and 1967 has enjoyed classic status for decades.  And well it should!  There isn’t a less-than-excellent performance among these five Sony discs, and most are stellar.  The symphonies are not presented in order of composition but rather economically so they would fit on the fewest discs.  This is somewhat of a pain if you seek to follow the master as his symphony writing matured over the years.  Still, the set is such a bargain that you find it difficult to complain.  The sound may not be exemplary but given the age of the recordings, it requires absolutely no statements of caution or apology – and you bass-lovers will never feel short-changed.As for the music, it is simply sublime.  Szell certainly had the pulse of Beethoven, and I found myself so engrossed in the music that I would have to repeat movements so that I could pound out the review.  It is difficult to pick out favorites, but I found Szell’s Pastoral (coupled with Symphony 1 on the first disc) to be particularly exquisite.  This was my first LP of a Beethoven symphony as a prepubescent and has always been one of my favorites.  In Szell’s hands, it just flows beautifully, with the sonorities bringing more than the occasional tear to my eyes.  Szell allows us to seemingly peer into the heart of Beethoven.  The brass of the 3rd Movement were wonderfully raspy.  The ensuing storm felt like one! The final movement had no shortage of drama and ended with soft intensity.  After over six decades of listening to Beethoven, I am still in awe of the vast range of mood and intensity that he conveyed in his music.  And Szell is second to none in his ability to draw that same range from an orchestra.  This ability is well-demonstrated in the Eroica on Disc 2.  The energy is almost palpable, especially in the fast movements.  Symphony 7 (Disc 3 with Symphony 4) is as fine a performance as I have ever heard and, again, the intensity is arresting.  Ditto for Symphony 5 (Disc 4 with Symphony 2), but Kleiber still reigns supreme.  Symphony 9 for me was the least successful in the set.  The Ode to Joy dragged a bit too much for my tastes.The playing of the Cleveland Orchestra is perfect.  Such precision would be the envy of any orchestra.  So, you have the finest symphonies ever composed (and Overtures), intensely interpreted, spectacularly performed, and at a price not to be beaten.  Needless to say, Very Highly Recommended!

Jesus Arambarri is a Basque composer who lived from 1902 to 1960.  Maurice Ravel came from the same area.  One of Arambarri’s teachers was Paul Dukas.  I was unfamiliar with this fantastic talent before hearing music from this album on Pandora.  I was so impressed that I immediately ordered the album.  This Naxos album, recorded in 2000, contains Arambarri’s Witches on New Year’s Eve, four Impromptus for orchestra, eight Basque Melodies for soprano and orchestra, In Memoriam (an elegy for orchestra, Offering, South Wind, and three Fantasia Espanola.  Performing are the Bilbao Symphony Orchestra under Juan Jose Mena and soprano Itxaro Mentxaka.Witches on New Year’s Eve is a rousing work of three short movements that is sure to get your blood moving in the morning (or any other time of the day, for that matter).  The writing is full of equal parts of energy and interest.  The Impromptu include motifs reminiscent of Witches.  The first is another rousing piece, the second soulful, the third even more so, and the final one takes a more agitated character.  As a group, the Impromptus are delightfully interesting but not enough so to get many replays on my audio system.I must confess not to be an enthusiast of many song cycles.  Vocally, I’m basically a choral guy, but this cycle is gorgeous.  I may actually play it again!  The songs are sure to please lovers of solo voice.  The Soprano sings beautifully with more than a bit of mezzo in her.  The orchestral writing is remarkably interesting and definitely not written as a mere accompaniment.The elegy, In Memoriam, is as expected a wonderful lament that that becomes reanimated at the 4:00 mark and vacillates between grief and glory for the remainder of the piece before ending on a sublime note.  It is just beautiful.  Offering is difficult to describe other than melancholic.  South Wind begins like a lazy, gentle breeze that gains some momentum and intensity as the work progresses.  The final rhythms mark it as a Spanish South Wind.  The album concludes with the three Fantasias espanola.  The first two are easy on the ear and rather dreamy at times. The Fantasia Espanola No. 3 is the longest piece of the entire disc at 7:05.  It erupts ebulliently with sharp idiomatic rhythms and percussion and only loses the dramatic momentum for moments.  Its longer second section is, by contrast, dreamy with flutes playing scale-like passages.  Solo violin introduces an extended melodic theme followed by an up tempo momentum-build to an agitated recapitulation that swells to a grand tutti section that features a galloping prelude to the big finale.  That was just plain fun!The recorded sound is exemplary.  My single criticism of the album is the TINY print that even my reading glasses couldn’t decipher.  But for the music I can only applaud.  My favorites were Witches on New Year’s Eve and the Fantasia espanola No. 3.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Ernst Toch was a fascinating and gifted Austrian composer and pianist who could tout formal training in the disciplines of philosophy, medicine, and music.  Though a highly regarded pianist in Europe, his principal concentration was composing, and he won six music prizes before World War I.  Fleeing Hitler’s Germany, Toch eventually immigrated to the United States where he taught music and philosophy at the University of Southern California and lectured at Harvard.  While on the left coast he wrote some film music but had limited success.  His most memorable achievement in Hollywood was that his music was used for the Frankfort chase scene in the 1937 film, Heide.  In contrast to his disappointing ride in Hollywood, his composition students during that period included Andre Previn and Alex North.  Toch eventually returned to Europe where he taught piano and composition at Mannheim University where Richard Adler was his most notable student.  I have previously reviewed some of Toch’s earlier but distinguished and enjoyable orchestral works performed by the Louisville Orchestra  in these pages.Surprisingly, Toch’s distinguished symphonic work did not commence until 1950, and he composed a total of seven in those last14 years of his life, receiving the Pulitzer Prize for his Third Symphony.  In this CPO set, all seven are performed by the Berlin Radio Symphony Orchestra with Alun Francis conducting.  Spoiler Alert:  These are skillfully crafted and very accessible modern compositions that deserve far greater recognition and performance than they have generally received.Disc 1 includes Symphonies 1 and 4.  Symphony 1 is rhythmically interesting and very well-orchestrated, but it failed to emotionally involve me.  Best was the 4th Movement, which opens with a series of bold assertions by brass and tympani.  The resulting tension is interspersed with pockets of quiet relief.  Symphony 4 is a 3-movement work with spoken lines separating the movements.  The 3rd Movement is the most intense and involving.Disc 2 contains Symphonies 2 and 3.  Symphony 2 is comprised of four movements and is a far more involving work than Symphony 1 or 4.  The outer movements are characterized by a menacing intensity.  Though clearly a modern symphony, Toch’s Second is much more accessible than those on Disc 1. The 2nd Movement could easily have been marked Dolce and its successor Adagio is immediately involving.  The final movement’s coda is spectacularly bleak with an emphatic use of tympani to underscore the despair in the concluding measures.  Wow!  Symphony 3 won Toch a Pulitzer Prize, but I would have voted for the Second.  The Third is full of interesting ideas, but they just were not enough to engage me until the 4th Movement.  It is agitated and the most emotionally involving movement of the symphony.  Let me tell you, Toch was no slouch when it came to writing climaxes!Disc 3 is comprised of Toch’s final three symphonies, which were composed during an 18 month period when Toch was dying of gastric carcinoma.  Jephta, Rhapsodic Poem is Toch’s 2-movement Fifth Symphony.  A musician expresses feeling most completely by music, and Jephta speaks volumes about the myriad of emotions an individual is likely to experience upon realizing or learning that they have a fatal disease.  I don’t know if it is the musician or psychiatrist within me that hears sadness, anger, denial, despair, mourning, and that child within crying in this music.  At this point in his life Toch, by all accounts, had an urgency to complete his musical mission on earth in the time he had remaining, but his Fifth can certainly be deemed his emotional reaction to discerning or learning of his fate.Symphony 6 begins peacefully, as though Toch had cleared his emotional throat in the Fifth and was back to simply being a composer again.  The 2nd Movement has a charming quality to it, though not without moments of intensity.  The final movement rather explodes onto the scene but quickly gains a melodically melancholic quality that finds quite beautiful resolution towards the movement’s conclusion.  Symphony 7 is typical Toch as represented by his ability to weave multiple ideas and emotions into a single movement.  The 2nd Movement has extended passages of pure joy.  I was unsure what direction the 3rd and final movement would go as I listened.  There is lightness with increasingly frequent hints of profound intent.  The conclusion measures are emphatic but left me with a feeling of being unfinished.  Perhaps it was the perfect epitaph.The Berlin Radio Symphony Orchestra plays with precision and the recording captures orchestral sonorities perfectly.  I was particularly impressed with how well-defined the tympani sound.  Toch used percussion brilliantly to underscore the music’s more serious moods.  Alun Francis clearly understands Toch and pulls out all the stops.  Toch was a superb orchestrator and his music seldom fails to maintain the listener’s interest.  My personal favorites were Symphonies 2 and 5, but all except perhaps the First are worthy of repeated listening.  Toch may rate only 4 Stars as a composer, but this complete set is definitely 5-Star!

It’s difficult not to enjoy beautiful choral music.  I find it less difficult not to enjoy solo vocal music.  And so, for me, this disc of choral music by two of the Twentieth Century’s greatest composers – Aaron Copland and Virgil Thomson – represented somewhat of a mixed bag.  The choral music herein is often stunningly beautiful, but I must admit that sections of the works of solo mezzo Luretta Bybee, though she possesses a beautiful voice, were endured rather than enjoyed.  I am certain that those of you who are solo voice aficionados should enjoy the album more.  Gloriae Dei Cantores under Elizabeth C. Patterson performs all of the choral works.The disc begins with Copland’s In The Beginning, followed by his Old American Songs and, finally Four Motets.  In The Beginning is a modern sounding work that failed to win me over.  Old American Songs are a set of five rollicking choral pieces with piano accompaniment that are easy on the ear and sung superbly.  Most are immediately recognizable (Simple Gifts, for example) and completely enjoyable.  The Motets are superb modern choral music.  Help Us, O Lord, unlike In The Beginning, is a moving piece of quiet beauty.  O, Thou Jehovah, Abideth Forever is an interesting piece that reiterates a jumping rhythmic and melodic motif.  Have Mercy On Us, O Lord, like the first motet, has quiet beauty but with greater rhythmic interest.  Sing Ye Praises to Our King, like the others, is modern without the loss of melody of near-conventional harmony.Virgil Thomson has long been a favorite of mine because of his ability to recall hymnal harmonies of yesteryear in his choral compositions.  His Hymns from the Old South is simply gorgeous in every respect and equally moving.  The set of four hymns are some of the most beautiful choral pieces I have ever heard.  I’m sorry I never had the opportunity to sing them back in the choral days of my youth.  It is impossible to pick a favorite among them.  Unlike the case with Copland’s In The Beginning, Gloriae Dei Cantores could not have been recorded with more distinction here.  This is a choral set you MUST hear.  With Mass, for 2-part chorus and percussion, we transition to modern tonal composition, albeit Thomson style.  Dissonances never get in the way of music.  The percussion is minimal, a single snare, for example.  But it works.  De Profundis is a weighty piece, modern enough.  When I Survey the Bright Celestial Sphere is accompanied by six brass instruments.  Although modern, most neophytes shouldn’t find it difficult.The recording is well done but I always wished for a more expansive sound to match the depth of feeling expressed by the chorus in the Copland pieces.  The piano in Songs of the Old Soust is much better recorded with perfect balance with the chorus.  Gloriae Dei Cantores performs with distinction throughout, and I give the album a Very High Recommendation.

Mahler’s Symphony No. 1 “Titan”  has been one of my favorites since I first heard the Leindsdorf recording back in the 70’s or 80’s.  I am unaccustomed to the Blumine movement and the few times I have listened to accounts that contain it, I have not felt it added much to the 4-movement version, but that may just be a matter of what I am used to hearing.  In this 2004 performance by the Hungarian National Philharmonic Orchestra with Zoltan Kocsis at the helm, I was struck both by interpretation and playing.  This is an exciting, high energy performance.  It was recorded live, and it sounds as though many of the audience had the sniffles that night.  The sound from 2004 is a bit close but top notch, nonetheless.  The brass are just splendid. This account will join my top-shelf recordings of the symphony.  I have found myself listening to it again and again, and let me warn you:  it is capable of evoking emotional expression.  The more I hear it, the more I am impressed.  I must admit that occasionally I felt the pacing could have breathed more, and the ensemble work in tutti sections in Movement 5 is not always absolutely precise, but the interpretation and playing is otherwise superb.  I very highly recommend it to Titan-lovers!  This is one you MUST hear!

I have listened to quite a few Alpine Symphonies over the decades, and it remains my favorite Strauss work.  So, when a new performance comes along, I am eager to hear it.  Most are also-rans to Karajan and Kempe, but this one with Daniel Harding at the helm and the Saito Kinen Orchestra is definitely top shelf.  The Decca disc has only the symphony, and at 51:59, it isn’t a bargain.  Don’t let the total time dissuade you from hearing it, for this is a deep and revealing account with just the right portion of gravitas scattered among its soaring melodic lines.That this performance is not just another flash in the pan is evident from the first few measures of Nacht.  Harding has the pulse of this music like no one else I have heard recently.  I think his interpretation approaches that of the giants.  This music represents Strauss’ love of nature.  He was raised at the foot of mountains and hiked in them often.  This was his religion.  This is what grounded him.  This was his soul.  Throughout the work, we hear a succession of superbly interpreted ideas of profound depth.  Wait.  Was I referring to Strauss or Harding?  The answer is both.  As a musician for six decades, there is an indescribable spark of creative genius that is rarely sensed.  There are more conductors who conduct notes on the score than who make music.  Harding is solidly in the latter camp when it comes to Strauss.  If his Auf dem Gipfel doesn't moisten your eyes, I'll be surprised.  At my age, I can't ignore the end of life any longer.
