When it does come (which I hope will be years from now, by the way!), Hardin's Auf dem Gipfel would make a very pleasingl send-off.The recording abounds in perfect phrasing, superb orchestral textures, and profoundly moving ideas.  Orchestral climaxes are gripping and moving.  Softer passages are handled delicately.  Ensemble work is precise.  Sonics are extraordinary.  Soundstage is wide with excellent center fill.  Sonorities couldn’t be more refined.This is a sublime recording.  If you love this powerful, emotional journey through the foothills of the Alps as I do, then Harding’s account must sit alongside Karajan and Kempe on your top shelf, not to displace them but rather to assure us that the finest interpretations have not already passed into history.  I think we have seen only the beginning for this very talented conductor.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

I feel a certain kinship by proxy with Leopold Stokowski.  I studied piano with Joseph Battista at Indiana University in the mid-1960s.  Battista studied with and was subsequently chosen by the Julliard legend Olga Samaroff to become her teaching assistant in the 1940’s.  Samaroff discovered and married Stokowski, and she has been credited with propelling his career to international fame.  Stokowski would frequently drop in to his wife’s piano classes held for her students.  Stokowski was a colorful figure in the mid-century musical landscape, including an extramarital affair that led to his divorce.  His conducting style and interpretive creativity were equally dramatic, although without moralistic challenges.Only after his death did Stokowski’s love of creating arrangements of classics become widely known.  He composed arrangements of some 200 classical works, four of which are presented on the present BBC Philharmonic label with Matthias Bamert conducting the orchestra.  We hear Stokowski’s arrangements of four works by Mussorgsky:  Pictures at an Exhibition, Boris Godunov: Symphonic Synthesis, A Night on the Bare Mountain, and Entr’acte to Khovanshchina.The first characteristic of this disc to note is the truly exceptional sonics.  I have rarely listened to a recording of such exquisite sound.  A rather sinister A Night on the Bare Mountain is superb from every perspective.  Stokowski clearly had a magical ability to orchestrate.  Throughout this disc his orchestral arrangements pull the listener in and their interesting nature proves thoroughly spellbinding.The same goes for the six sections of the Symphonic Synthesis on Boris Godunov, which begins with begins with such a sweet, melancholic nature.  The 2nd section will be familiar to most and is quite stirring.  You can imagine its initial relentless foreboding music used in a movie on SciFi channel until its melancholic dignity prevails.  The 3rd section begins quietly.  The 4th section is a lively Cossack dance.  The final two sections return to desperation and melancholy, and the final section depicts the Death of Boris.  Frankly, the Symphonic Synthesis is so persuasive, I am going to buy a CD of Mussorgsky’s opera.Khovanshchina is another supremely melancholic arrangement of an unfinished opera that speaks despair and anguish.  It is incredibly beautiful, and I will return to it often.  As a psychiatrist, I have listened to a countless number of tragic stories for which this music would be so appropriate.Familiar to most listeners is Pictures at an Exhibition.  Stokowski’s arrangement is particularly solemn in the Promenade and amazingly beautiful.  Gnomus is quite sinister with a creeping-like quality.  This is NOT party music by any means.  The return of the Promenade is less solemn this time around.  The Old Castle is very close to Mussorgsky’s but slower, lighter and more delicate.  Still the hint of melancholy almost yielding to sinister remains.  Bydlo is a larger, more refined, and more serene until the mid-piece crescendo that ultimately dies away.  The third Promenade is scarcely there compared to its two predecessors but with a sinister undercurrent.  Ballet of the Chickens is another section with strong resemblance to the original.  Samuel Goldenberg and Schmuyle are likewise similar.  Catacombs is drawn out in a quietly dramatic fashion.  This technique is frequently seen in Stokowski’s arrangements.  Con mortuis in lingua mortua is more like a sunset than the original.  The Hut on Fowl’s Legs is more interestingly orchestrated than the original with frequent use of sliding trombone lines, but it retains very similar rhythmic structure.  The Great of Kiev is a mixed bag and perhaps the least successful of the set.  It seems as though Stokowski tried to inject too many tempo changes and add too much drama.  It just seems disjointed.  The coda is a bit overblown.As you might have surmised, Pictures is of variable success but not so the remainder of the disc.  The music is beautifully played and recorded exceptionally well.  Stokowski’s ideas work best in Night on Bare Mountain and the pair of operas.  This is a splendid disc that I recommend very highly.

These performances of the Beethoven symphonies with John Elliot Gardiner leading his Orchestre Revolutionnaire et Romantique were originally produced by DG in 1994.  We have here the Archive Production reissue, and it is superb.  The ORR is a 79-member period instrument orchestra of the so-called Historically Informed Performance tradition.  But don’t let that designation scare you away.  You won’t hear any screechy violins that might diminish your enjoyment but their often this sound. Rather, you are in for a real treat.  These are highly (but not overly) charged accounts of the symphonies that are splendidly recorded, and in no way sound 20 years old.  If you, like me, believe that recessed timpani can degrade otherwise wonderful recordings, you will love these accounts, for period drums frankly kick ass.  I have been ambivalent when it comes to Gardiner’s choral work, because too often “charged” becomes “punchy.”  Not so, here.  There is just plenty of good, old-fashioned energy.  No, make that ENERGY!Period instruments provide that “fresh” feel to Symphonies 1 & 2.  LVB was always at the edge in his symphonies, but the lush sound of modern strings dampen one’s ability to imagine being in the original venue and being struck by this brash, new symphony composer.  The Minuetto of Symphony 1 is just glorious.  The profound opening to the 2nd Symphony has plenty of weight, but Gardiner doesn’t belabor its gravity, and there is wonderful flow to the movement.  Unlike many period performances, Gardiner’s tempos don’t seem particularly hurried to my ears.The Eroica is early mature Beethoven from start to finish, but Gardiner gives the listener more to appreciate in way of more pronounced dynamics and a slightly faster flow with more lightness in the softer passages.  The Scherzo is appropriately intense, and climactic passages are everything you could hope for from period instruments, that is unless you are an enthusiast of overbearing gravitas.  Likewise, the Finale is full of intensity and, when appropriate, majesty.  Gardiner allows me to hear the parts better without sacrificing the sense of intensity.  I certainly enjoyed his approach and will return to this Eroica often.  In Gardiner’s hands, Symphony 4 sounds like a more mature work than its predecessor, and it most clearly demonstrates Gardiner’s ability to peel away the cobwebs of tradition while preserving the music’s dignity.  I think his account has quickly become my favorite performance of the 4th.  You have to hear it!Gardiner’s account of the 5th Symphony is excellent.  It has elements of Kleiber’s electricity along with some very sweet passage work at times (remember, Beethoven was not completely hell-bent on scaring the bejesus out of us in this work).  The brass are especially impressive.  The 2nd Movement has just the right ebb and flow.  Tempos seem spot-on to me across the board. There is grandeur everywhere.  The final coda in the 2nd Movement is simply beautiful, but the grand rush to the concluding bars lacks a bit of weight.  It is during this symphony that I really missed the power and forces that the modern orchestra can give interpreters such as Carlos Kleiber.  When the 3rd Movement yields to the 4th, there is electric intensity under Gardiner’s baton.  This is one of my (and probably everyone else’s, as well) favorite symphonic movements, and the orchestra does not disappoint.  Not as white-hot as Kleiber, I’ll grant you, but it is a piece of very fine orchestral work.  Brass and timpani are both thrilling and don’t be surprised if it evokes some teary eyes.  (I must confess, however, that mine will moisten with lesser accounts.)  The final accelerando again made me wish for greater forces.An LP of Symphony 6 was my first Beethoven symphony as pubescent kid.  I still love it!  Gardiner’s interpretation is Pastoral without ever sacrificing intensity.  The 2nd Movement, however, was clearly played by period strings which seemed thinner than I would have expected after listening to the previous five symphonies.  The horns of the 3rd Movement are glorious, and the lower strings are equally impressive.  The real test of period orchestral forces is, of course, the storm scene of the 4th Movement.  The ORR passed with conditional honors, a very honorable effort, to be sure.  After the storm clouds subside, we are back to some very fine music making with only a trace of lightness in terms of weight.  When the theme appears in the prominent horns (or should) in the 5th Movement, I had to strain to hear them.  What a curious engineering snafu.Symphony 7 with Gardiner and the ORR is a veil-lifting experience.  Although I love what a modern orchestra can do with this symphony, I experienced the sensation that was hearing more of what was in Beethoven’s creative mind at the moment of composition when listening to the current forces.  The Allegretto moves along with melancholic intensity at an unhurried pace.  It was simply beautiful, and the period instrument climaxes were excellent.  Symphony 8 comes through with surprising success.Symphony 9 is more of a mixed bag.  From the onset, the thin period violins once again made me wish for instrumental modernity.  Violin issues aside, this performance demonstrates the same intensity, slightly faster but unhurried tempos of its predecessors. The 2nd Movement (the old theme for NBC’s Huntley and Brinkley Report before John Williams got in there, for those of you old enough to remember the news show) is beautifully played but there was frequently a wish for modern instruments and their added richness and weight, especially in tutti passages.  The same issue is seen in Symphonies 3-8.  Movement 3 offers a needed respite from the agitation of the 2nd Movement, and it should be highlighted in Gardiner’s resume.  It is that lovely.  The final movement is hugely successful.  The soloists are uniformly stellar, but the relatively small size of the chorus is a negative factor.I must apologize for the length of this review, but there was just so much that needed comment.  Needless to say, I very much enjoyed Gardiner’s cycle.  The recorded sound is pristine and somewhat close.  For who enjoy period performances, this period Beethoven cycle is second to none.  For me, I prefer the modern orchestra for its richness and weight, but these performances are very impressive.  I found Symphonies 4 and 8 to be the best of the cycle.  They seem to defy the limitations of period instruments better than the others.  Honorable mention goes to the 3rd, 5th and 7th.  In each of the symphonies, however, Gardiner opens the drapes and gives superbly interpreted performances.  I will return to 3, 4, 5, 7, and 8 often.  Very Highly Recommended.

I didn’t listen to much contemporary music when I was young, preferring instead the safe confines of music from the Baroque, Classical, and Romantic periods.  As I got older (and older, and older), I began exploring the non-standards, finding initially that such music swept cobwebs away and kept mental rust from forming.  It took a series of decades for me to fully appreciate post-impressionist music, music that I now so enjoy exploring.  In the present London album from 1994, we get two American originals:  Edgard Varese and Charles Ives – composers once deemed heretical by the classical music faithful.  Performing is the Cleveland Orchestra under the direction of Christoph von Dohanyi.Varese was born in France but migrated to the U.S. in the early 1920’s.  Here he produced most of his compositions.  The present album begins with Varese’s gigantic Ameriques, his second major work.  This work is scored for a massive orchestra including13 percussion instruments including a fire siren, cyclone whistle, and crow call! (Large sized orchestras are not unusual for Varese.  He called for 120 musicians for his work, Arcana.  Ameriques calls for 27 winds and29 brass.)  Varese spent his compositional life looking for new orchestral sonorities, and more than a few will delight you in Ameriques.  The work is a sprawling piece that visits a multitude of musical ideas at a fast, highly charged pace.  The work is not initially high on the accessibility scale, and the plethora of percussion instruments and the endless series of climaxes help sustain one’s interest along the way.  Nothing in Ameriques stays the same for long.  Tempos and musical thoughts are varied and constantly evolving.  Ameriques is like a swirling musical kaleidoscope.  You will be hard-pressed to identify conventional melodies. Varese keeps the interest high, but for me, the real listening pleasure only began to open up to me in the second and third sessions.  So, don’t be discouraged if the piece at first seems bewildering.  The final measures are a spectacular sonic experience – snares, siren and all.After Ameriques, Ives’ Symphony 4 seems almost conventional by contrast.  Although Ives composed the symphony between 1909 and 1916, the full, revised work’s premiere wasn’t until 1965 with the American Sympony Orchestra conducted by Leopold Stokowski – ever the champion of new American music – and two assistant conductors (in the 4th Movement) including Jose Sebebrier!  Symphony 4 is divided into four movements:  a prelude, a comedic second movement, a majestic fugue third movement, and a spiritually inspired finale.  As common in Ives’ works, glimpses of traditional hymns make frequent appearances.  The fugue-like 3rd Movement is one of Ives most luscious pieces of writing.  It has always fascinated me that a composer who could at times write music that sounded cataclysmic could produce such inspirational music of the highest order.  The 4th Movement begins quietly and never completely gives away that placidity.  Ives believed it was his musical zenith and had “… something to do with the reality of existence and its religious experience.”  The Unanswered Question, an essay on the meaning of existence, is the final work on the disc.  And the Answer is never found.This is a splendid disc of once-new American classics.  Sonics are first rate.  Dohnanyi is one of our greatest conductors.  The disc is one of my favorites and I highly recommend it!

John McCabe is an English composer and pianist.  As a pianist, he gained a certain degree of fame by recording the complete Haydn sonatas.  As a composer, he claims no particular style.  In the Hyperion disc under review, we hear his Fourth Symphony entitled Of Time and the River and his Flute Concerto.  Performing is Vernon Handley and the BBC Symphony Orchestra.Of Time and the River is structured as a two movement work with each movement further subdivided.  In the end, you get two movements, five tempi, and a total of 12 sections.  The listening experience is a constantly shifting musical work.  Elements prominent in this Fourth Symphony are repetition, an assortment of sonorities, traces of minimalism, and even traces of tonality.  Each section of the work seems to generate a rhythmic and melodic motive related to the 1st section of the movement and develop it.  This sometimes becomes a bit tedious.  The penultimate section is a robust recapitulation of the 1st section of the 1st movement, while the 47-second final section offers the symphony a few last dying breaths.  There is considerable beauty in this symphony, but we may be too close in time to the composition to deliver valid verdicts.  Only time will tell if McCabe’s work survives, but given the sometimes tedious nature of the work, I don’t think you can predict its chances as certain.The Flute Concerto is of a similar ilk to the symphony, including repetition, an assortment of sonorities, some traces of minimalism, and perhaps a greater number of hints of tonality.  I found the Concerto less interesting, no doubt because as a pianist, listening to 25 minutes of flute is just excessive.  The Concerto is organized as a single, 12-section movement of contrasting tempi and dynamics.  The final section is reminiscent of the symphony in that it, too, dies off softly.The BBC Symphony performs this often-tedious work with skill and energy.  The recorded sound is superb, and I found no issues in soundstage, center fill, or orchestral balances.  I can recommend the performances very highly, but the compositions themselves do not inspire nor lend themselves to eager repeated listening sessions.

As atonal music, neither Andrzei Panufnik’s Sinfonia Votiva (Symphony No. 8) nor Roger Sessions’ Concerto for Orchestra are easy listening for most music-lovers.  In the Hyperion disc under review, we hear both works performed by Seija Ozawa and the Boston Symphony Orchestra.  For me, this is music I simply listen to and absorb. I do NOT try to understand or analyze it at first (and it’s not like I am going to perform some Vulcan Mind Melt on atonal music later, either!). Both works share some characteristics besides atonality.  Both begin rather sparsely with increasing vitality and complexity ensuing.Panufnik is a very structured composer who practically calculates his music with engineering precision.  Naturally, few compositions are designed to be haphazard, but modern atonal music IS distributed along a continuum between sounding, for lack of a better word, haphazard and structured.  Panufnik stands are the latter end.  In Sinfonia Votiva, every note’s harmonic and temporal position sounds very determined.  It is much the same with Sessions’ Concerto for Orchestra.  The Sinfonia Votiva’s 1st movement begins with a series of slow melodic intervals played by flute that are answered by the xylophone.  From here the complexity and number of instruments involved gradually increases including the addition of percussion, and the intervals now becoming atonal lines and dissonant chords.  The tempo, too, increases gradually.  The effect of all of these gradual increases is quite interesting and actually rather attractive.  The 2nd movement begins much more aggressively with trumpets sounding quickly repetitive chords under the violins attempt at a reaching melodic line.  The music intensifies with significant use of cymbals and brass.  There is an attempted reversion to calmer waters, but the repetitive, agitated rhythm pulls the music back into the fray. A veritable feast-frenzy of instrumental agitation concludes the work as a note on the tubular bell gradually vanishes.Sessions’ Concerto for Orchestra has greater complexity, density, and more rapid increases in that complexity than its predecessor.  Also, Sessions’ atonality is less stark that Panufnik’s.  The work is structured in three linked movements and was completed in 1981.  Sessions work is more difficult to describe than Panufnik, but equally if not more enjoyable.  As it is denser, the Concerto for Orchestra bears greater resemblance to more conventional tonal music than does Panufnik.  The work opens with an announcement of its vitality but soon the tempo, complexity, and dynamics begin to vary.  The music is never anywhere for long.  Definitely no time for boredom!  Sessions’ writing is exquisitely interesting and for that reason equally appealing.  He produces very attractive sonorities.  Even more to the listeners liking is his unique ability to move the music through one beautiful passage after another.  This is music that is far easier to hear than to describe.I find atonal music difficult to describe, so I just listen and try to be simply open to what comes my way.  What I can say is that the experience is very enjoyable with both works.  Difficult music, yes, but absolutely worth the effort.  The performances have the benefit of exemplary sound.  The orchestra plays with incredible precision and feeling.  These may be strange sounds to some listeners steeped in tonal music, but they should be explored and never be prematurely dismissed as too difficult.  For me, this is top shelf atonal music of the highest kind, and the album gets my ABSOLUTE HIGHEST RECOMMENDATION!!!!!

Symphony No. 2 is Johannes Brahms's most lyrical symphony, and it has received a host of superb recordings.  The present 1981 DG disc presents the account by Carlo Maria Giulini and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra.Giulini immediately conveys that his will be an intense, emotional interpretation but not at the expenses of the lyrical element.  The 1st movement is typical of Giulini's approach.  Forte tutti's are forceful but the softer passages are sublime.  The 2nd movement is beautifully played and sweet as can be.  Yet, Giulini always supports the interpretation with an intense undercurrent of emotion.  The sublime is never far from the tension, and the final two minutes reveal the inner substance to be the juxtaposition of lyricism and strength.  The 3rd movement is a walk, simple and innocent, then a serious, intense dance, but one of joy.  The 4th movement begins softly with the glorious explosion of full orchestra confirming the intensity that joy can contain.  I have heard some beautiful accounts of this symphony, such as the surprisingly robust recording of Celibidache, but I can't think of one that tops this in any meaningful way.  The final minute of the movement is the greatest I have ever heard.  It is truly astonishing!When you listen to Giulini's masterful account of this wonderful symphony, you get the feeling that this must be what the master intended.  It feel that right.  I would not complain if this was the only account I could ever listen to again.  The sound is fully supportive of the majesty of the reading.  Despite the 1981 recording date, this early digital recording bears few if any of the faults so common in recordings from that period.  The brass may be the slightest bit grainy, but there is no early digital over-brightness.  Soundstage and center fill are superb.  This one is capable of evoking tears and that's what makes it magical.  It easily gets my ABSOLUTE HIGHEST RECOMMENDATION!!!!!

Virgil Thomson was multitalented and could have been a writer or musician.  So, he chose both, and composed while also working as a music critic.  Growing up, he was a friend of the granddaughter of Joseph Smith.  This proved fortuitous, because when his family couldn’t afford to send him to college, Thomson received help from the Mormon church.  After graduation, he moved to Europe and studied with famed French composition teacher Nadia Boulanger whose other noted American students included Aaron Copland, Roy Harris, Elliott Carter, and Walter Piston (pretty much a Who’s Who of 20th century American music).  While in Europe, Thomson formed friendships with James Joyce, Gertrude Stein, Ernest Hemingway, Aaron Copland, Ezra Pound, Igor Stravinsky, Pablo Picasso,  and Orson Welles.  When Thomson returned home to America in 1940, he landed the position of music critic with the NY Herald Tribune alongside Aaron Copland.  Although Thomson may be as well or better known as a film composer, he wrote three symphonies which we hear on the present Naxos disc.  The works are played by the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra under the baton of James Sedares.Symphony 2 opens with a lively, simple tune in a movement marked as Allegro militaire, but the music sounds more peasant-like than military.  Thomson had a true gift for the simple melody.  The structure of the 1st movement is anything but long-lined, and it sounds more like a musical stream of consciousness than coherent composition.  The 3rd movement is much the same.  Interesting to hear and pretty but not enough to repeat the experience very often.The Symphony 3 is quite different, opening with soft timpani, gong and cymbals.  The 1st movement is a serious piece but only a little more complex than its predecessor.  The 2nd movement is delightful, tuneful, and happy, even in the minor mode passages.  The 3rd movement Adagio is slow ala Thomson, i.e. NOT grave by any means.  The theme is actually lovely.  The 4th movement begins with a very Classical Period sound.  This may be the movement with the greatest intensity but I hesitate to call it intense.  The piece ends softly.Pilgrims and Pioneers is a lovely work that was originally the score for a film about immigration to American that was shown in the United States Pavillion at the 1964 World’s Fair in Seattle.  It is a dissonant series of vignettes and hardly a coherent work.Symphony on a Hymn Tune is a work inspired by the hymns How Firm a Foundation and Yes, Jesus Loves You.  I think this is the finest work on the disc.  Although written in 1926 while Thomson was living in Paris, it is a mature-sounding work.  It structured as four movements but really represents a near-endless set of variations on the two familiar hymns.  The other works on this disc are certainly skillfully composed, but the Symphony on a Hymn Tune is by far the most enjoyable.  This Is one that I will put on my Fiio X-5.This is an interesting disc comprised of Virgil Thomson’s more serious orchestral works (in contrast to his film scores).  The Symphony on a Hymn Tune is the highlight of the album.  The playing is superb.  Soundstage is quite good.  For the Symphony alone, this disc is VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

American modern music composer Christopher Rouse was Born in Baltimore, MD in 1949.  His music education began with an undergraduate degree from Oberlin and graduate degrees from Cornell where he studied with Karel Husa.  He also studied privately with George Crumb. After holding faculty positions at the University of Michigan and Eastman School of Music, Rouse moved to the Juilliard School of Music in 1997 where he teaches composition. His most successful student is Michael Torke. Stylistically, Rouse is considered a neoromantic composer who often blends tonal and atonal music in his compositions.  In the 2004 Ondine disc under review, Leif Segerstam and the Helsinki Philharmonic Orchestra perform Rouse's Der Gerettete Alberich, Rapture, and Violin Concerto.The album begins with Der Gerettete Alberich, a percussion concerto inspired by Wagner's dwarf character Albrecht in Gotterdammerung who survives with the Rhinemaidens.  The piece opens with a musical flashback to the opera before moving forward a century.  Der Gerettete Alberich imagines various moods of Albrecht following his survival.  The music is predominantly atonal, so don't look for a recognizable melody.  The three-movement work is interesting with some wonderful tutti climaxes and dazzling percussion solos. The slow 2nd movement begins with high-pitched violins and occasional notes from the steel drum.  This section of the work actually presents a brief but beautiful and mournful melodic line.  The 3rd movement could wake up the dead with its STRONG Big Band influence (there is a drum set!) .  The drum solos are energized.  You can't help but enjoy the 3rd movement!Rapture opens slow and tonal.  There is something very beautiful about the work as it builds into a brass chorale in the first few minutes.  The piece progressively builds further with tension, intensity, and complexity of texture increasing.  The ascent isn't smooth and there are repeated flashbacks to earlier in the flight.  Rouse is rightfully acclaimed for his orchestration and especially for his exquisite writing for percussion, and the timpanist in particular gets a workout.  Oh yes, there was plenty of lactic acid accumulating in this piece.  I don't see how any listener couldn't have fun listening to this work.  It is just over the top!I generally shy away from two genres of music, solo voice or instrument (other than piano) and violin concertos.  But this violin concerto (and Brahms, Beethoven, Mendelssohn, Tchaikovsky, and Bruch) are exceptions to the rule.  Moreover, I had anticipated that a modern one would be even more difficult to endure.  Not so!  This one is endlessly fascinating.  Of course I miss the conventional melodic lines, but the fascinating writing for the violin kept me in the spell.  This is a two-movement work.  The Barcarola begins slowly with solo violin.  A second joins in, then viola.  Their trio is soft and mesmerizing, but the orchestra explodes with profundity.  Calm is reestablished and the violin carries the melodic line over a glimmering accompaniment.  At about 4:30 a tutti climax seems to signal a premature close, but the music resumes with a faster tempo to another pause. Now, the pace quickens again with a constantly moving melodic line.  Another section appears with similar organization, and the solo, duo, trio reemerges.  The orchestra awakens with a set of intervals with timpani to close another section.  Finally, solo violin reappears over soft timpani, a wonderful effect that concludes the movement.  The 2nd movement Toccata opens quietly but excitedly.  The agitation sometimes leans toward frenetic.  Occasional brass chords are sounded incessantly with increasing rhythmic complexity.  No one sleeps while listening to the Toccata!  Soloist Cho-Liang Lin performs admirably with little rest.  Rouse gives us a rest with a slow melancholic interlude at about 6:30 before the music again picks up tempo at about 9:30 when the music becomes rather furious.  Solo violin plays agitatedly to the close when an brief orchestra flourish concludes the work.This is a fascinating album of Rouse.  For me it is the Big Band 3rd movement of Der Gerettete Alberich and Rapture that steal the show, but the Violin Concerto was quite an interesting work.  The sound is exemplary, with excellent soundstage and center fill.  Another highly successful Christopher Rouse disc that deserves a VERY HIGH RECOMMENDATION!!!

I am going to take a long paragraph to familiarize you with the personal experiences of Otto Klemperer that helped shape the conductor responsible for the set of recordings under review.  If you would like to move directly to the review, you may skip to the next paragraph now.  Ever notice that in all of the photographs of Otto Klemperer, his face was suggestive of a stern or depressed individual?  Actually, both are true and more.  He suffered humiliating attacks on his character and dismissal from his post at the Kroll Opera in 1933 Berlin by the recently elected Nazis, because he had the audacity as a Jew to conduct a production of Wagner's Tannhauser.  Actually, Klemperer had converted to Catholicism shortly before then to marry his wife but for the Nazis, once a Jew, always a Jew.  After the Nazis issued an arrest warrant, he reluctantly fled his homeland to America, leaving his family until he could send for them.  Once in the U.S., he was appointed conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic.  He subsequently sought posts at Philadelphia and New York, but he was passed over in both cases.  Klemperer's facies was the consequence of the excision of a brain tumor the size of a small orange in 1939 which left him with considerable facial paralysis.  Throughout his life he suffered from bipolar disorder (manic depression) and was hospitalized once in New York.  During the 1941 ordeal, he was arrested as a deranged individual and was briefly jailed.  To literally add personal insult to injury, the New York Herald Tribune ran a pathetic, humiliating photograph of him behind bars prior to his commitment to a mental hospital.  Later, he was severely burned in a fire from smoking in bed, a matter made only worse by Klemperer's tragic attempt to douse the flames with a flammable liquid.  In 1951, he suffered a severe fall on a conducting trip to Montreal.  Afterwards, he had to conduct from a seated position.  When the U.S. refused to renew his passport in 1952 because of his leftist views, Klemperer returned to Europe.  Having suffered a relentless series of physical and emotional infirmities during his life, it is no surprise that Otto Klemperer may have become a stern individual or a stern conductor, but his facies and other physical disabilities obscured a musician of the highest order, a fact to which these recordings attest.I note the above because there is a remarkable contrast between the Klemperer of record and the Klemperer ON record. In the set of four EMI/Warner discs under review, the legendary conductor reveals his insights into some of the major works of Johannes Brahms:  the four symphonies, Haydn Variations, Alto Rhapsody, and Ein Deutches Requiem.  Performing is the Philharmonia Orchestra.  The recordings date from 1954 to 1961.  The Haydn Variations are in mono.  They were all produced by the famed Walter Legge, whose recordings opened the world's eyes to Klemperer's genius.The set begins with the Brahms Haydn Variations on Disc 1.  I don't really know how to explain Klemperer's performance here except to postulate 1) that he may have been suffering a mood episode of his Bipolar Disorder that interfered with his usual intense expressiveness, 2) that the relatively degraded quality of the mono master tapes prevents us from hearing correct orchestral balance and sonorities, a possibility that would prevent other aspects of his expressiveness to show through, or 3) some combination of both.  The detail is all there but the typical Klemperer expressiveness is diminished beginning with the tempo itself often sounds a little rushed.  Adequate evaluation of the performance is almost impossible because of the negative bias that is created by mono recordings, and to make matters worse, because it appears that the master tapes suffered some degradation as evidenced by the thin sound of the recording.  None of this is to say that the performance is bad.  It is not.  But it is also not up to the interpretive level of the symphonies and requiem.Symphony 1 is partnered with the Variations on Disc 1.  It is a splendid reading of the Brahms First.  The 1st movement flows a bit faster than some, but the expressiveness of the interpretation is certain.  This is a performance that is weighted towards the lyrical elements rather than the aggressive ones.  The 2nd movement reveals less of the mushy, romantic side of Brahms (as if Brahms even had any histrionic aspect to his musical self) and, instead highlights clarity.  Brahms and Klemperer both studied relentlessly the music of Bach and Beethoven to learn classical forms and probably had an ear for clarity that is reflected in the works of Brahms and Klemperer's interpretation of those works.  It is interesting to consider the possibility that Klemperer's interpretations are truer to the composer's intent than other conductors.  In fact it makes sense that Brahms' wrote his thick textures with the assumption that interpreters would be especially careful not to thicken them further by mush.  The 3rd and especially the 4th movements benefit from Klemperer's ear for clarity of texture.  Don't read into this that Klemperer's clean interpretation lack the monumental element.  Just listen.  As critic Joseph Horowitz once stated, "Klemperer's most characteristic performances, rigorously projecting outward design, amassed a magisterial poise and weight."  The conductor has an uncanny ability to preserve the lyrical and the monumental element simultaneously.  There are only rare interpretations of Brahms First that can equal the satisfaction that Klemperer gives the listener.  Of course the clarity that Klemperer achieves would not be possible without the precision that the Philharmonia gave to their conductor.  Just listen to the final minute of the 4th movement to hear it all come together in one long, glorious, heaven-sent moment.Disc 2 begins with Symphony 2, one of Brahms most lyrical, and here will not unpredictably find Klemperer giving what some might call a lean interpretation, especially when compared the excesses that other conductors bring to their performances.  There is no lack of weight, however, to the 1st movement.  Rather, we hear sweet majesty.  If any criticism can be levied it is that at times, the tempo feels like it should be broadened.  The 2nd movement Adagio is less Adagio than one would expect but at no expense to the drama.  The 3rd movement is perfect in tempo, innocence, and weight.  It conveys an innocent happiness that feels right.  In those minor mode passages, the mood dampens only briefly.  The loud tutti passages have adequate weight without ever being overblown.  In the 4th movement, Brahms dropped any nave elements in preference to mature joy which normally contain traces of the profound.  Klemperer is magical here, producing a mood that we psychiatrists would term euthymic.  Brahms concludes his symphony with joyful but profound majesty, and Klemperer gets it perfectly!In contrast to the frequent lightness of his Second, Brahms' Symphony 3 explores the deep parts of the soul.  The 1st movement is a hodgepodge of faces within that most mysterious part of who we are.  There is the anguished opening theme, light figurative passages, and the serious, pensive corner of the soul or unconscious mind.  In the 2nd movement, Brahms conveys an almost prayerful state, full of calm and rightness with the world.  It is one of Brahms most beautiful movements.  The brief excursions towards melancholy never are allowed to dominate the landscape for long.  The longing of the 3rd movement never quite gets to anguish.  Instead, you can feel the mood vacillate between joyful and melancholic memories.  A similar feeling permeates the 4th movement, only the intensity awakens in full dress uniform.  If the 3rd movement represented longing, then the 4th demonstrates "I can't live without you."  Anguish played by the violins blooms and then visits beauty and back to anguish and back and forth.  As tension quietly grows, so does the progressive resolution to the deep peace of acceptance.Disc 3 contains the Academic and Tragic Overtures as well as the Alto Rhapsody.  The Academic Festival Overture has always been one of my very favorites but here is played at a tempo that robs it of some of its youthfulness.  At the same time, I heard detail and instrumental lines that I didn't know were hidden within the score.  That aspect was fascinating.  As the overture progressed, the tempo quickened and intensity increased.  Now things sounded as they should.  When the coda that always makes me think of ivy-covered wall, Klemperer moves to a slower majestic pace with all of the weight the music deserves. (But I think the music would have appreciated a majestic that was a few beats per minute faster!)  The Tragic Overture is less to my liking in both composition and performance tempo.  I don't consider it on the level of beauty the other Brahms works and Klemperer's pace does nothing to further its case.  With regard to the Alto Rhapsody, I generally stay away from the solo voice, and will defer comments on the performance to those reviewers who appreciate such works more than I do.  I will say that the men's choral element is very persuasive and the orchestra is no less so.Brahms' Symphony 4 1st movement under Klemperer's baton just flows.  It is lyrical without sacrificing its power.  What is missing is that element of excitement.  The finest, most exciting Fourth is unquestionably Carlos Kleiber with the Vienna Philharmonic.  You can find my review of this magnificent account under that listing. Klemperer, to my ears, cannot compare to Kleiber in this symphony.  The 2nd movement is almost redemptive.  Klemperer and the Philharmonia shine in all respects.  The intensity is ever-present and the movement is a moving account.  The 3rd movement is almost successful but the tempo holds it back as does a slight pause that I am unaccustomed to hearing (and don't like).  But otherwise, the tutti sections are near-perfect in performance.  Somehow, the intensity of the 3rd movement fades in the 4th which never seems to get off the ground.Disc 4 is Klemperer's account of Ein Deutches Requiem.  It is classic, and I have reviewed this seminal performance elsewhere on Amazon:  http://www.amazon.com/Brahms-Deutsches-Requiem-Elisabeth-Schwarzkopf/dp/B0032HKEPO/ref=sr_1_5?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1409522063&sr=1-5&keywords=brahms+requiem+klempererThis set of symphonies and other orchestral/choral works by Johannes Brahms performed by Otto Klemperer and the Philharmonia Orchestra is a mixed bag.  Symphony 1 and Ein Deutsches Requiem are complete successes, and the latter is the definitive performance of the work.  Portions of the remaining works approach such lofty heights, but none are performances that are particularly top shelf.  Still, as a collection and in respect for the performances of Symphony 1 (of which there are equally compelling accounts such as Celibidache - no kidding!) and the Requiem which is definitive, the set deserves a High Recommendation!!  You can purchase the Requiem separately and thereby obtain the essential work from this collection while saving money.

These are an attractive variation on the original Sperry Topsider deck shoe.  I have two pairs of these fine shoes and find them quite comfortable.  The sole is a bit thick, and I like that because it makes the shoe more comfortable.  They seem true to size.  I will probably be buying these shoes for the rest of my life.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

This is a fine basic dictionary that satisfied my basic needs.  The print is large enough to be readable with my reading glasses on (yes, my eyes are that bad).  I read some reviewers' criticisms about the inadequacies of this dictionary, and I have no reason to believe they are incorrect.  For the majority of individuals, like myself, this dictionary will serve your needs quite nicely.  You know, even basic dictionaries such as this one are quite humbling.  I have a number of advanced degrees, have lived almost 67 years, and am still humbled to this day by what I DON'T know.  Perhaps that is the ultimate purpose of dictionaries.  At any rate, I like this one very much.  Highly Recommended!!

I purchased this charger to charge my Fiio X5 high-resolution audio player.  It worked, and it is inexpensive..  Just be certain of the amps needed for your device.  Don't you just love simple solutions that are so inexpensive?

We bought two of these cord caddies to wind our anchor rope at the bow and stern of our 20' pontoon boat.  We use 1/2" double braided nylon line for 100' of anchor rope.  The gizmo works well for something that sells for less than 10 bucks but there are a couple of imperfections that should be noted.  First, the rope should be under a minimal amount of tension in order for the rope to wind around the spool properly.  Second, someone must feed the line back and forth across the width of the spool to fill it evenly.  Third, the rope can easily go between the spool and the vertical piece that attaches to the handle.  Fourth, the unit is quite flimsy.  BUT you get what you pay for.  The metal units are $150 and up.  So, I would definitely recommend the K-100 because it is better than nothing, and it is so inexpensive.  Just be aware of its shortcomings.

This is one of those discs that just delights with its wonderfully-lively music and superb sonics.  We have Roger Norrington and his London Classical Players of yesteryear giving performances of seven popular Overtures by Gioachino Rossini on this 1991 EMI disc.  I'm not sure how authentic the orchestra instruments are to Rossini's day, but each overture is fresh and lively.  I especially like tracks 1 through 7 (grin).  The disc is really that much fun, and I don't think there is a weak performance on the entire disc. The William Tell Overture could have been a bit more propulsive, but that is the only criticism I think fair.The London Classical Players were comfortable with the music covering three centuries and always played with precision and polish be the fare Handel, Bach, Beethoven, or Rossini.  The sound is glorious with just the right bit of reverberation.  Soundstage and center fill were both excellent as were orchestral sonorities.  This one is top shelf and gets a HIGHLY RECOMMENDED review from me!!

John Pickard is a was born in 1963. He studied composition with Louis Andriessen at the Royal Conservatory in The Hague, Netherlands and in 1989 obtained his PhD in composition from the University of Wales. He currently teaches composition at the University of Bristol.  Pickard's compositions are known for their powerful, large-scale musical architecture.  He has written four symphonies of which No. 4 is presented on this BIS Super-Audio disc along with Eden, a work for brass band.  Performing is the Eikang-Bjorsvik Musikklag led by Andreas Hanson.  Both works are scored for a standard British band.The album begins with Eden, a 15-minute, three section work inspired by the final lines in Milton's "Paradise Lost."  The 1st section, entitled Tsunami, depicts Adam, Eve, and the serpent by euphonium, cornet, and trombone.  It opens with sustained chords but then proceeds with introducing the principal characters.  The theme is reminiscent of the opening theme to the movie Superman.  See if you aren't reminded of the same.  The remaining music represents a duet between Adam and Eve.  The music livens up, but I must confess that the music isn't the most beautiful I have heard.  The 2nd section is somewhat fast and furious.  The 3rd section is slow and quite beautiful.  Despite a meager beginning, the 3rd section of the work was immensely enjoyable.The Gaia Symphony opens pensively with brass chords over maracas before the pace quickens.  The 1st movement, Tsunami, has strong jazz and minimalistic undercurrents.  The orchestration is very fine but less so than Rouse works, some of whose works I reviewed earlier.  Still, this is excellent albeit not the greatest modern music.  I found the tutti passages far more enjoyable than the small ensemble work.  Between each movement are 2-4 minute Windows.  The one that follows the 1st movement (Water - Fire) is primarily percussive.  The 2nd movement, Wildfire, is one of near-perpetual motion.  There are few melodic elements of any consequence, and the movement is largely one of brief motifs that are often repetitive.  In Window 2 (Fire-Air), the Fire is EXTREMELY LOUD - loud enough to crack speaker cones, so test it out on low volume first.  I'm sorry but this is sound effect - NOT music!  The 3rd movement, Aurora is a calm meandering piece.  Window 3 (Air - Earth) begins with a continuation of what sounds like the 3rd movement.  The 4th movement, Men of Stone, has a slow tempo and also meanders to successive crescendos.  After 4 minutes, the pace quickens as does the inherent interest to some degree.  The symphony has a nice, conventionally tonal finish.I don't want to be too hasty and simply dismiss Pickard as an also-ran, but the works on this album do not inspire confidence in him as a great composer.  I would like to hear some other of his symphonic works before abandoning him.  The music is modern, moderately interesting, but otherwise inconsequential.  The sound is faultless and the performance is superb.  TENTATIVELY RECOMMENDED.

Christopher Rouse was born in Baltimore and teaches at Juilliard in NYC.  His most prominent student is Michael Torke.  Rouse has composed more than 50 works, and he is regarded as one of the most audience-pleasing composers of the 20th (and now, 21st) century.  He was trained at Oberlin and Cornell and studied with Karel Husa and George Crumb.  I just reviewed a stellar album of his music performed by Marin Alsop and the Colorado Symphony Orchestra that  is probably the single most exciting disc of late 20th century music I have listened to.  In this Koch album, Alsop conducts the Concordia Orchestra in performances of Ku-Ka-Ilimoku, Concerto Per Corde, Rotae Passionis, and Ogoun Badagris.The album begins with Ku-Ka-Ilimoku, a work for percussion ensemble that depicts the Hawaiian mythological god of war.  For percussion-lovers like me, the work is incredibly interesting with multiple repeated rhythms using multiple percussion instruments.  The booklet accompanying the disc says that the piece is best viewed as a savage, propulsive war dance.  Actually, I didn’t find it as savage or war dance-like as I did propulsive, but it is a perpetual motion piece that is extremely energized and fun to listen to.Concerto Per Corde is based on Rouse’s String Quartet No. 2 but is not a simple transcription of the earlier work, as the composer apparently did considerable rewriting.  The work is based upon a permutation of Bach’s name in the German letters for musical pitches.  The 1st movement is a sad-sounding piece, very mournful and anguished.  It is quite beautiful (why is it that melancholic pieces are so often so?).  The 2nd movement is rather savage (there’s that Rouse adjective, again) with only brief passages of calm.  I really enjoy Rouse and his creative genius for creating engaging rhythms.  The 3rd and final movement returns to the slow tempo that characterized the 1st movement, but it is more modern-sounding and strident at times.  I think the term “bleak” best characterizes it.  The booklet call it “cold desolation.”Rotae Passionis is a difficult piece to love, although anything with bass drum, snare, or timpani will always provide some pleasure for me.  Think of drums and a few other instruments and that’s it for instrumentation.  The work is in three sections depicting various aspects of the Crucifixion of Christ.  There is little in it that most would call music in the conventional sense.  I didn’t particularly enjoy it and won’t probably play it again.Ogoun Badagris is inspired by Haitian drumming patterns and bears some relevance to Voodo.  Ogoun Badagris is one of the most frightful Voodo deities.  With that as an introduction, it should come as no surprise that the brief percussion work is dance-like, repetitive, extremely rhythmic, strongly percussive (Duh!), and often angry-sounding.  Interesting piece.Passion Wheels, as the album is entitled, is a fascinating compilation of works by Christopher Rouse that rely strongly on a multitude of percussion instruments.  My favorites are the first two works, Ku-Ka-Ilimoku and Concerto Per Corde.  I will record those two for my Fiio X-5.  Marin Alsop must be a magician to conduct these challenging works, and the Concordia Orchestra needs no better proof of its virtuosity than this disc. The sound presents the sonorities of the instruments very well.  On a high-end audio system with subs, the effect is often hair-raising.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED, especially for Ku-Ka-Ilimoku and Concerto Per Corde!!!

Baltimore-born Christopher Rouse was trained at Oberlin and Cornell.  He studied with Karel Husa and George Crumb and held faculty positions at U. of Michigan and Eastman School of Music before moving to Juilliard in 1997.  Juilliard's gain.  Everyone else's loss.  His most prominent composition student is Michael Torke. Stylistically, Rouse is considered a neoromantic composer, but some are more musically obtuse.  In the present RCA album, Marin Alsop leads the Colorado Symphony Orchestra in Rouse's Trombone Concerto, Gorgon, and Iscariot.  The works were recorded in 1995 using 20-bit technology and the sound is astonishing!The album begins with the Trombone Concerto.  Right from the start, I must tell you that I thought this was one I was going to have to listen to for purposes of the review, but surprise, surprise:  I actually enjoyed it immensely.  This is wonderful music, one of the most fantastic modern works I have heard.  The 1st movement begins rather darkly and sparsely.  My first impression was "Oh, God, is this even music?"  The trombone makes slow, low-pitched,  almost groaning sounds similar to... well, you can just guess.  But then it became increasingly musical in a more conventional sense, and I realized that I was actually beginning to enjoy it.  A lot. It... became... beautiful!  The 2nd movement is stunning, sort of perpetual motion.  It is often loud.  The rhythms are fascinating.  The trombonist must have required resuscitation by the end of the movement!  Really, really enjoyable.  I'll be listening again and again to this.  I couldn't help but think of Close Encounters of the 3rd Kind.  Remember, the trombone note coming from the saucer after it landed on Devil's Mountain?  Well, multiply that times a hundred, and add percussion, additional brass, and strings.  All I can say is WOW!  What impactful music.  You have to hear it to believe it.  Amazing!  The 3rd movement returns to a slow tempo with woodwinds playing soulfully.  But the music crescendos and gathers increasing intensity before coming to a quiet and sublime section that is exceptionally peaceful.  Soft timpani lead into a gentle conclusion.Gorgon is a three-movement piece that begins in raucous fashion with wonderful timpani passages.  I love that instrument, and in the 1st movement it plays an important role.  Rouse described Gorgon as "... a work of exorcistic rage, an attempt in music to heal by facing that which seems unfaceable."  I think exorcistic rage is an apt phrase for this music.  Chords are repeated 10 or 15 times in rapid succession.  It's riotous and stunning - almost shocking.  The 3rd movement, Medussa, is so in-your-face that it is difficult to describe.  The booklet says that Gorgon is an attempt to take Rouse's attraction towards fast, loud and wild music to its terrifying ultimate.  That about says it all.  I will play this often.Iscariot is the antithesis of Gorgon, with its slow, mournful yet sublime nature.  It is a pleasure, and a needed one after listening to Gorgon's terror.  But don't think that Rouse has robbed you of terror completely.  There are many such moments, but their intensity, though impressive, don't equal those of Gorgon.  I found Iscariot less compelling than Gorgon but stillRouse's music is astonishing for its relentlessly energized drive and dynamics.  No dozing off here.  I found myself eagerly anticipating the next new flurry of rhythms and percussion effects.  The sound is splendid with a full soundstage and center fill.  The Colorado Symphony should be recognized as on the brink of world class.  They play this difficult music with aplomb.  Marin Alsop, whose other recordings have not impressed me that much, needs not to prove herself further.  She is a major talent.  This is one of the most exciting and thoroughly enjoyable albums of modern music I have ever listened to.  ABSOLUTElY HIGHEST RECOMMENDATION!!!!!!!!!!

This is a spectacular Albany album of serious wind music performed by the University of Miami Wind Ensemble.  Ensemble?  Well, it is a 57-member “ensemble” led by conductor Gary M. Green – and the band is superb on all counts as is the recorded sound!The disc begins with Symphony from Ivy Green by Mark Camphouse.  The work is a song cycle of sorts with lyrics consisting of the writings of Helen Keller, who was born at Ivy Green.  This is beautiful musical depiction of Keller’s thoughts, ideas, struggles, and joy.  Singing is the composer’s spouse, Elizabeth Curtis, who sang in the work’s premier in 1998.  Curtis’ diction is superb and moving.  The wind music is impressive and blends with its vocal partner seamlessly.  The work is divided into six movements with descriptive titles such as “Silence Sits Immense Upon My Sould.”  Everything about this work is meaningful, sobering, moving, and while not always typical of modern music, beautiful.  I don’t usually enjoy the solo voice, but this is a notable exception.  You must hear it!Next up is Equus by Eric Whitacre.  The work was commissioned by the wind ensemble that performs the music on this disc and must be considered definitive.  Clearly inspired by minimalism, Whitacre calls it Dynamic Minimalism, and dynamic it is.  This is not obtuse modern music in any sense, but rather is one of the finest pieces of minimalistic structure I have hear since the wonderful film music for Hamburger Hill by Philip Glass.  Whitacre intended the piece to depict perpetual motion, and he was superbly successful.  Its rhythms never dull, and the music is quite compelling.  You are going to really enjoy this one!The final work is a four-movement Concerto for Marimba and Wind Ensemble by Ney Rosauro that is ever more interesting as the work progresses.  Its original form was as concerto for marimba and string orchestra, then reiterated as a piano piece, and finally a concerto with percussion ensemble.  Dr. Thomas McCutchen later arranged it for wind ensemble.  Brazilian rhythms are enticing and percussion is clearly a major force in the music.  I would not have imagined that  the marimba would be a natural solo instrument in a concerto, but it works.This album is a pure joy from start to finish.  The U. Miami Wind Ensemble perform exquisitely with polish and precision.  Personally, I love hearing college ensembles like I love watching college basketball.  Both play their hearts out, although only the basketball players are reaching for the big bucks.  Gary Green must take great pride in the quality of his instrumentalists.  The sound is as splendid as the music.  Soundstage is great, center fill perfect, bass definition superb, and the sonorities astonishing.  Have I made my point?  ABSOLUTELY VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED !!!!!!

This is an important docudrama that depicts the struggles of Linda Pino, MD with the managed care system.  In medical school, managed care was not the terrible influence it is now.  I didn't know Dr. Linda Pino, but her husband was my resident during my rotation on OB/Gyn at the University of Louisville.  The problems seen in the movie are real and even greater today.  I wish EVERYONE could see this movie.  As a physician in private practice, managed care makes taking care of my patients more than a little difficult.  Moreover, most all of my patients have seen increases in deductibles, copays, and premiums while at the same time experiencing greater difficulty in obtaining the medical care that they deserve, require, and believe they had paid for.  This movie easily deserves MY ABSOLUTE HIGHEST RECOMMENDATION!!!!
This is a lightweight pizza pan that is quite sturdy and the pizza doesn't stick (we use Bobolini whole wheat crust) even without spraying oil on the pan.  What more can you ask for?

The Pilot G2 Gel roller ball pen is a fantastic pen AND it's retractable, as well.  I use both fine and bold varieties and have been very pleased.  One negative is that the ink will smear.  I use is mostly for our checkbooks to circle checks uncashed and to check those that have been.  If I moisten my finger to flip pages, the dried ink will smear, so watch out for that.  Otherwise, I have no complaints.  The ink if bright as it can be.  It also feels good to write with.  Solid construction for a pen like this.  I don't think you will be disappointed.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!

Samuel Barber is among the finest composers that America has ever produced, much less than one of the greatest of the 20th century.  He knew that his destiny was musical composition from early childhood and told his mother so in a letter at 9 years of age.  By14, he was enrolled in the newly-formed Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia.  His dream came true – for Barber and for us, as well.  Barber wrote standard symphonies and concertos, but he is probably best known for his shorter works.  We get a bit of both in this Argo album with Symphon1, Adagio for Strings. Overture to The School for Scandal, First and Second Essays for Orchestra, and Music for a Scene from Shelley.  Performing is David Zinman and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra.  The recording was made in 1991.  Since this album competes with Schippers’ account with the NYPO and Columbia Symphony Orchestra, I will point out contrasts between the two sets of accounts as I review the present disc.The album begins with Barber’s timeless Adagio for Strings, adapted for string orchestra from an early string quartet movement.  It receives a moving account by Zinman and Baltimore, but it is more relaxed than Schippers/NYPO performances.  The music has been said to be authentic.  William Schuman stated that there is no apparent compositional technique.  It is just effortless and natural.  Few listeners have not been moved by its timeless beauty.  Its seemingly longing mood accounts for it having been called America’s national funeral music.  Both this and Schippers/NYPO accounts are equally valid interpretation, and both receive superb performances.The Overture to The School for Scandal was written for the play by Sheridan, but musically is really a literal depiction of little of the play’s content.  But as a musical work, it stands well on its own.  The first theme is an ebullient one of some intensity.  The second theme introduced by oboe is one of the loveliest composed during the 20th century.  Both this and Schippers/NYPO accounts are equally valid interpretation, and both receive superb performances, although the profound bass of this account could make this one a more attractive choice.The First Essay for Orchestra is an elegiac work with contrasting section of light playfulness.  Barber composed it as an attempt to duplicate the contrasts and cogency of his Symphony 1 on a smaller scale.  When it begins, it is reminiscent of his Adagio, being equally dark but less profound and with a theme that competes poorly with that of the Adagio.  It lacks the smooth melodic nature of the Adagio.  Still, it is a beautiful work and profound in its own right.  This work is not included on Schippers/NYPO.Music for a Scene from Shelley was composed in response to some lines from Shelley’s Prometheus Unbound.  The piece opens mysteriously, not really progressing anywhere in particular but doing so with some beauty and with gradually-increasing intensity.  Finally, a tutti explosion offers a stirring, almost anguished, longing theme that is embraced by a singly trumpet, then strings.  A dialogue between instrumental sections leads to another intermediate climax, pause, greater and percussive climax of death blows.  An eerie calm is restored reminiscent of the original opening sequence and the work quiets to a close.The Second Essay for Orchestra begins with a pastoral mood that evolves texturally and dynamically to some climactic passages.  These increase in intensity to percussive climaxes with prominent timpani.  Next a jumpy sequence of extended motifs appears that gives occasional way to minor climaxes.  We never hear a real melodic line, but the music has much interest and some of the intermediate climaxes are profound and stirring.(Most of the following comments on Barber’s Symphony 1 are taken from my review of Slatkin’s superb account.)  Barber’s First Symphony is a remarkably accessible work written in 1936 when Barber was 26.  In Program Notes, Barber describes the symphony in this way:  “The form of my Symphony in One Movement is a synthetic treatment of the four-movement classical symphony. It is based on three themes of the initial Allegro non troppo, which retain throughout the work their fundamental character. The Allegro ma non troppo opens with the usual exposition of a main theme, a more lyrical second theme, and a closing theme. After a brief development of the three themes, instead of the customary recapitulation, the first theme in diminution forms the basis of a scherzo section (vivace). The second theme (oboe over muted strings) then appears in augmentation, in an extended Andante tranquillo. An intense crescendo introduces the finale, which is a short passacaglia based on the first theme… over which, together with figures from other themes, the closing theme is woven, thus serving as a recapitulation for the entire symphony.” (Heyman 1994, 140)  Barber had an ear for the long line and it shows in this intensely dramatic symphony.This disc gives us superb readings of Barber works.  The bass is strong but slightly less well-defined than in competing accounts such as Slatkin/St. Louis SO and Schippers/NYPO.  Generally speaking and although Schippers is a considerably older recording, he brings greater excitement to these works than Zinman and Schippers sound is a bit brighter.  Likewise, Slatkin’s account of Symphony 1 is infused with more excitement.  Each of the recordings, however have something going for them that makes each compelling.  For Zinman like the other two, the disc is VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

Samuel Barber is regarded by the public at large as one of America's greatest 20th century composers because of one single composition - the timeless Adagio for Strings.  Yet for music lovers, we know that his talent doesn't end there.  The present album is a reminder of his ability to write enduring works longer that 8 or 9 minutes.  Barber knew, even as a child, that his destiny was musical composition, and at 9 years of age, he wrote a letter to his mother and told her so!  He was one of the first students to enroll in Philadelphia's newly-formed Curtis Institute of Music.  This RCA disc features two of his large-scale works, Symphony No. 1 and his Piano Concert, as well as Souvenirs for four hands.  Performing is Leonard Slatkin and the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra with John Browning, pianist.  The recording was made in 1990.Barber's First Symphony is a remarkably accessible work written in 1936 when Barber was 26.  In Program Notes, Barber describes the symphony in this way:  "The form of my Symphony in One Movement is a synthetic treatment of the four-movement classical symphony. It is based on three themes of the initial Allegro non troppo, which retain throughout the work their fundamental character. The Allegro ma non troppo opens with the usual exposition of a main theme, a more lyrical second theme, and a closing theme. After a brief development of the three themes, instead of the customary recapitulation, the first theme in diminution forms the basis of a scherzo section (vivace). The second theme (oboe over muted strings) then appears in augmentation, in an extended Andante tranquillo. An intense crescendo introduces the finale, which is a short passacaglia based on the first theme... over which, together with figures from other themes, the closing theme is woven, thus serving as a recapitulation for the entire symphony." (Heyman 1994, 140)  Couldn't have said it better myself, but what Barber leaves out is how truly beautiful the work is.  Barber had an ear for the long line and it shows in this intensely dramatic symphony.Barber wrote the Piano Concerto FOR John Browning.  Before he began writing it, Browning spent three or four days with the composer who asked him to play everything he knew so that Barber could tailor the work to Browning's personality.  As a pianist myself, I have always found it difficult to love 20th century piano concertos.  Unlike with 20th century orchestral works, I am just not moved by them.  John Browning plays spectacularly as usual.  I first heard Browning 50 years ago when he was about 30 and remember my impression that he was a pianist with unbelievable technique.  (I also heard Leon Fleisher that same season and thought he played with far more emotion than Browning.)  The Piano Concerto is a virtuosic tour de force with much that is interesting but little that moves me.For Souvenirs, conductor Slatkin serves as the other two hands.  This is a six-movement nostalgic work that includes Waltz, Schottische, Pas de deux, Two-Step, Hesitation-Tango, and Galop.  Browning studied with Rosina Lhévinne at Juilliard.  Slatkin studied violin, viola, and piano.  Although not perfectly together at times, Browning and partner are technically well-matched for Souvenirs.  The piece is fun to hear.This is a an interesting album.  For me the major work is the Symphony 1 and it is played par excellance.  The Piano Concerto played by its dedicatee is self-recommending and competes with the performance with Browning/Szell.  The sound is superb in every respect.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

This is a very good music encyclopedia for the targeted audience.  So there are really two questions: 1) why is this book only very good, and 2) who is the targeted audience?I initially bought this book because I was trying out several encyclopedic volumes for my classical music reviews here on Amazon.  I wanted a book or books that would be a quick reference for factual bibliographic information regarding composers and some additional information regarding their compositions.  With regard to composers, the book contains much bibliographic detail on all of the major composers.  What is missing is info on the others.  For example, there are no listings for Henze or Rubbra, both significant 20th century composers.  The major composers prior to the 20th century have been filtered by time so that it is relatively easy to say who the major ones are.  In a hundred years, there will probably be a half dozen "major" composers of the second half of the 20th century, but today we can only say who the contenders are.  For me, it isn't worth looking up many composers of the last 50 years, because they often aren't listed.  The problem is even worse for  works of music.  Only often recorded works are certain to be included.  Again, for the majority of works from the last 50 years, they are unlikely to be included.The audience best served by The NPR Listener's Encyclopedia are all listeners relatively new to classical music.  More experienced listeners and those, like me, with formal training in music, will be less likely to benefit from the book for the reasons noted n the preceding paragraph.  Those listeners who are not new to classical music but are still listening primarily to the major 16th to mid-20th century compositions should also find the book beneficial.I think that the term "Listener's Companion" might have been a more accurate title for the book.  It is not encyclopedic.  If you are looking for succinct presentations of most all composers, this is the wrong book for you.  This is no fault of the author or editors.  No single book can give you what it seems to promise.  I am partial to the Oxford Dictionary of Music and the Harvard Dictionary of Music and use them primarily.  So, for its intended audience that I have described, I think this is an excellent reference.

Samuel Barber is among the finest composers that America has ever produced, much less than one of the greatest of the 20th century.  Even as a child, he knew that his destiny was musical composition.  At 9 years of age, he wrote a letter to his mother and told her just that!  By 14, he was enrolled in the newly-formed Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia.  His dream came true - for Barber and for us, as well.  In this incredible Sony album, we have Thomas Schippers leading either the New York Philharmonic or Columbia Symphony in performances of Barber's Medea's Dance of Vengeance, Adagio for Strings, Second Essay for Orchestra, Overture to The School for Scandal, Andromache's Farewell, Intermezzo from Vanessa; Menotti's Overture to Amelia al ballo; Berg's Interlude from Wozzeck (Act III); and d'Indy's Introduction to Fervaal.  The works by Barber are performed by the NYPO, while the remaining works are performed by the Columbia SO.  All were recorded in the early 1960's and subsequently remastered.To begin the Barber fest, we hear Media's Dance of Vengeance, a suite taken from the ballet music.  The music depicts the themes of jealousy and revenge and begins quietly with strings, woodwinds, and percussion.  But the quiet beauty of longing is only temporary, and in time it transitions to a broader, more sweeping, almost sultry treatment of the theme.  The music next becomes agitated with even larger orchestral ideas including the use of piano.  The catchy rhythms keep the music lively as it expands to near riotous tutti's.  Finally, the piece concludes with anguished passages before the agitation makes one last heroic statement.Little needs to be said of the Adagio for Strings, Barber's adaptation of an early string quartet movement for string orchestra.  Here, it receives one of the most emotional and endearing performances that I have ever heard.  The music has been said to be authentic.  William Schuman stated that there is no apparent compositional technique.  It is just effortless and natural.  Few listeners have not been moved by its timeless beauty.  Its seemingly longing mood accounts for it having been called America's national funeral music.The Second Essay for Orchestra is not my favorite Barber piece, but it receives a superb performance by Schippers/NYPO.  Ever since I heard the Overture for the School for Scandal, I have been taken by its propulsive rhythms and melodic motifs, and what an exciting performance it receives.  When the pensive theme finally arrives, it induces a deep calm to all who hear it.  It is certainly one of the finest themes of the 20th century.  The recapitulation of the original agitated introduction is simply glorious, especially the restatement of the timeless theme.I was unfamiliar with Andromache's Farewell, but while interesting, it isn't one of Barber's best works IMHO.  It is a work for soprano and orchestra with the text from The Trojan Women by Euripi¬des.  In contrast, the Intermezzo from Vanessa (Act III) is a lovely piece with the oboe taking a prominent role.  The final three works, played by the Columbia Symphony Orchestra, begin with Menotti's Overture to Amelia al ballo, a lively and beautiful work full of energy and good humor.  The conclusion is pure joy.  Next is Berg's Interlude from Wozzeck (Act III).  This is a mournful work that turns to anguish.  The conclusion with brass fades to darkness.  The final work is d'Indy's Introduction to Fervaal.  It, also, is rather melancholic but the melancholy of love, not sadness.  Its theme is rich and beautiful.Throughout this album, I was struck by how splendid was the sound.  These are 50 year old recordings.  Columbia took care of their master tapes.  There are absolutely no criticisms possible with the sound, including soundstage and center fill.  Okay, maybe the soundstage is a tad shallow, but everything else is superb.  The orchestras under Thomas Schippers also deserve much praise.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!!

Christopher Rouse is a modern, living American composer with a very impressive Curriculum Vita and about 50 compositions to his credit.  Born in Baltimore, MD, his music education includes a bachelor degree from Oberlin and graduate degrees from Cornell where he studied with Karel Husa.  He also studied privately with George Crumb.  He has held faculty positions at U. of Michigan, Eastman, and since 1997 at Juilliard.  His most prominent composition student is Michael Torke.  Stylistically, Rouse is considered a neoromantic composer.  With regard to the present album, David Zinman leads the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra in Rubbra's Symphony No. 1 and Phantasmata.Symphony 1 begins eerily with high violins that are subsequently joined by a tutti explosion.  The 1st and only movement is largely comprised of this rather dark and frequently ominous music which at times increases in interest, texture, and dynamic volume.  Still, it reminds you of the score to a fright film.  To be fair, however, the music is of MUCH higher quality than most of those films.  There is plenty of percussion bombast to work out your audio systems and prized subwoofers.  At times, the music becomes conventionally and beautifully tonal.  Rouse is a bit of a chameleon.  I like that, but I sometimes wondered if we were stretching the definition of music as we know it.  I have maintained for years that modern music, if nothing else, cleans the cobwebs out of our brains and prevents us from becoming stale in our listening habits.  Symphony 1 does that job and does it well.  It IS music, after all.  It just isn't music we are accustomed to hearing.  For me, it is worth repeated listening sessions.Phantasmata has three movements with uncommon titles, like The Evestrum of Juan de la Cruz in the Sagrada Familia at 3 AM, The Infernal Machine, and Bump.  Seriously!  I'll just stick to the music here.  The 1st movement is eerie.  Like Symphony 1, Rouse inserts wild dynamically contrasting passages, although the movement is never bombastic.  The 2nd movement is agitated with lots of ascending and descending glissandos, percussion effects, and a fascinating array of orchestral sonorities, pulsations and rhythms.  It's actually fun to listen to.  Promise.  The 3rd movement, Bump, Rouse takes us on a Boston Pops tour from Hell, with gouhls and the like dancing around bumping into things and people.  Another treat!I would love to see the neuronal firing patterns in Zinman's brain as he conducts these works by Rouse.  The Baltimore Symphony should never have to prove themselves again.  I'm certain they had quite the workout.  Much of this is music is fun to listen to.  I am not going to try to tell you that I understand it well enough to give you an erudite analysis, but I think you will find it extremely enjoyable.  (Plus, I like timpani, and there is plenty of it!)  The sound is spectacular.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

Randall Thompson was one of the leaders of 20th century American music who taught at UC Berkeley, was the Director of Curtis Institute, and faculty member at Princeton and Harvard. Besides his three symphonies, he also composed considerable choral music including Choose Something Like a Star from Americana. This is a stunningly mesmerizing work, and If you haven't heard it, I heartedly recommend you do so.  I recently reviewed Thompson's Symphonies 2 and 3.  The present disc features his Symphony 1 but also includes Morton Gould's Fall River Legend on the Koch label.  The works are performed by James Sedares conducting the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra and were recorded in 1992.Morton Gould was another 20th century American composer whose compositions were usually related to American themes.  Fall River Legend depicts the Lizzie Borden affair.  Borden was tried for the hatchet murder of her father and stepmother in 1892.  Gould wrote music for a ballet at the request of famed choreographer Agnes de Mille.  This is pleasant, interesting music from a relatively unimportant American composer.  Much of it is exciting, and Gould was quite an orchestrator.  However, I think the story more than the music itself has guaranteed its place in the orchestral literature.Thompson's Symphony No. 1 is the main feature of this album.  The 1st movement demonstrates syncopation and other jazz influences.  The music is not particularly memorable.  The 2nd movement isn't either.  The 3rd and final movement moves from pastoral and a bit lively to excellent intensity and energy.
