The performance is far better than the music.If you want to hear superb music of Randall Thompson, listen to his Symphonies 2 and 3.  The current fare on this disc is pleasant and interesting and little more in my opinion.  Sound, however, is superb.  Recommended for completists.

Edmund Rubbra, considered one of the leading composers of the 20th century, wrote a total of 11 symphonies. He studied composition with Gustav Holst at the Royal College of Music and later wrote a biography of his mentor.  I recently reviewed performances of his Symphonies 6 and 8 with Norman Del Mar and the Philharmonia Orchestra.  The present Lyrita disc includes Rubbra’s Symphonies 3 and 4 with the same forces.  In addition to the symphonies, we also hear A Tribute and Overture Resurgam fitted between the two larger works.Symphony 3’s 1st movement opens in major key but soon dark clouds begin appearing on the horizon as the intensity picks up.  While less dark than Symphonies 6 and 8, the ominous character of the Third is ever-present.  Rubbra’s superb orchestration skills are immediately apparent, and Del Mar and the Philharmonia are up to the task of expressing them.  Rubbra’s orchestration and thematic structure are reminiscent of Sibelius at his early best.  The tempo slows to a lovely finale.  The 2nd movement begins quaintly with music that continues its resemblance to Sibelius with equal accessibility.  Rubbra’s music isn’t quite the match to the Scandinavian, but then that would be a tall order for any subsequent composer to fill.  The 2nd movement, however, is no thematic equal to the 1st, but its intensity is typical Rubbra.  The movement returns to major in the prominent brass conclusion.  The 3rd movement is music of quiet melancholy and occasional anguish but of considerable beauty throughout.  The movement again ends with a lovely major mode conclusion.  Del Mar is in tune with the darkness, and it is difficult to imagine any other conductor drawing more from the score.  The 4th and final movement continues the melancholic mood so common in Rubbra, but it lightens slightly about 2 minutes into the movement.  The mood progresses further away from despair.  Structurally, the 4th movement is constructed as a theme with 7 superbly written variations that demonstrate contrasts in mode, style and tempo and concluding with a fugue.  These aren’t up to the quality of Elgar’s Enigma set, but they are impressive nonetheless.  The final variation is the longest and grandest, with brass ablaze and timpani underscoring the thematic majesty at the conclusion in a Bach-like harmonic resolution to a Picardy third.A Tribute resulted from a commission from the BBC for a short work to celebrate Ralph Vaughn-Williams 70th birthday.  It is slowly paced, rather pastoral, somewhat melancholic work that while attractive really doesn’t sound very much like Vaughn-Williams or celebration.  Overture Resurgam was also a commissioned work but by the Plymouth Symphony to commemorate the Nazi bombing of the city.  It is appropriately dark in mood during much of its 7+ minutes.  (I’m beginning to think that no composer does dark as well or as often as Rubbra!)  It is a pleasant, far more dramatic piece than A Tribute and seems to depict considerable light at the end of the tunnel.Rubbra himself conducted one of the early performances of Symphony 4 dressed in military uniform, but Sir Adrian Boult premiered the work.  It begins with a serene, conventionally structured dialogue between violins and woodwinds/brass repeating a simple rhythmic motif.  This interplay evolves to a somewhat mournful and intense, pulsatile prelude to a moving intermediate climax.  Eventually, the music becomes increasingly intense with an exquisite brass dialogue passage.  Once again, Rubbra’s orchestration impresses, and the movement ends like someone in a death struggle taking some final breaths.  The 2nd movement is rather easy-going but of less interest than the 1st movement.  The 3rd movement is a serious affair lead by the low strings.  The characteristic Rubbra intensity is ever-evident.  This is easy music to love.  The 4th movement picks up the pace, and Del Mar and the Philharmonia play their hearts out.  I hope, by now, you don’t expect happy music.  Good!  The music becomes majestic and ends gloriously.This is a superb disc in every respect.  Interpretations, performance and sound are all exemplary.  Unless you have a naively happy character, there is so much to love about the music of Edmund Rubbra.  I don’t believe that Del Mar and company recorded more the the Symphonie Nos. 3, 4, 6, and 8, but I sure wish he had.  I’ll have to buy the Chandos complete set of symphonies to hear the others, but for these Lyrita recordings, I’ll be surprised if Hickox betters these performances.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

I was first introduced to Gibran's masterpiece when I was a young intelligence analyst serving in Vietnam in 1968.  You may think what an odd place to meet The Prophet, but actually a combat zone may have been the perfect locale.  Vietnam was an area where man's inhumanity to man begged for something that was beautifully expressed and was profoundly true, something that was man's greatest achievement in an area of his worst.  This is just one example of the power of The Prophet.The Prophet is a relatively short book that can be read in an afternoon, but its impact will endure for a lifetime.  I have given copies to friends on the occasion of their weddings, and read it to every woman I ever loved.  I have also recommended it to countless patients in my psychiatry practice.  One would have to be dead inside not to be moved by the poetic beauty of Gibran's carefully chosen words on life, love, marriage, joy and sorrow, children and the like.  It was truly inspired by God himself, so profound are its truths.This edition is equally perfect.  It is hardcover and contains Gibran's own unique drawings.  The paper is heavy and softly feathered, giving it an expensive appearance appropriate to the value of the writing within. It really does make a simple but valuable gift for occasions such as weddings or for others you love.If you have never read The Prophet, then you must buy some copies, read one and keep it, and give the others away to people you care about.  After all these years, I cannot count the number of times that I have quoted it.  It is my favorite book of all times and easily garners MY ABSOLUTE HIGHEST RECOMMENDATION!!!!!

Edmund Rubbra (1901-1986) was an English composer who studied composition with Gustav Holst (he later wrote a biography of the composer) at the Royal College of Music and who was regarded as one of the leading composers of his day.  He composed a total of 11 symphonies of which Nos. 6 and 8 are presented here along with his Soliloquy for Cello and Orchestra to top off this generous Lyrita disc.  Norman del Mar and the Philharmonia Orchestra perform the symphonies, while the Soliloquy is played by Vernon Handley and the London Symphony Orchestra.  The recordings were made in the late 1970’s (Soliloquy) and early 1980’s (symphonies) but neither was recorded digitally.  They were all digitally remastered with great success.Symphony 6 is a darkly beautiful work that I found rather melancholic.  Unlike so much modern music, it takes little effort to enjoy this work that is dominated by strings.  While you won’t get up from your listening chair humming the melodies, they are nonetheless beautifully woven themes that carry drama, emotion and intensity.  This is particularly true of the 4th movement which I found emotionally stirring.  Rubbra was a superb orchestrator, a fact illustrated by this movement especially, with its sonorous finale of strings and brass.  And the timpani, while never overplayed, is an important and well-defined pulse of the coda.Symphony 8’s mood resembles that of the Sixth.  If you are familiar with my classical reviews, you already know how I look for the timpani’s definition in works.  Well, I was not disappointed here.  The 1st movement is large in scope and intensity with prominent timpani.  Del Mar is one of those conductors who you don’t hear a lot, but he is always exciting.  He seems well able to elucidate the ideas within the murky texture of this symphony for the listener.  I honestly can’t find anything I don’t enjoy about Rubbra.  He never allows the music to loiter.  There is always a new idea or an old one redefined.  The 2nd movement is more lively but not much happier.  The 3rd and final movement is a tragic sounding Poco Lento with a sorrowful mood of considerable intensity.  Now, this is a movement that dwells in the doldrums of despair.  At around 5 minutes, the intensity increases with a strong pulsatile rhythm that gives way to anguish.  Wow, can this composer ever search the darker places of the soul.  Then, almost surprisingly, the music lifts out of the swamp and ends softly in major.  At times, the music will make you reach for the Prozac.  But despite the predominant mood, I found the movement growing on me with repeated listenings.The Soliloquy begins immediately with the cello presenting a dark theme.  No surprise, right?  I must confess that I found the Soliloquy less compelling than the symphonies.  It was recorded earlier than the symphonies, is played by Handley/LSO, and has a sonically constricted ambience.For the Symphonies 6 and 8, I can report that the sound is excellent but not superb.  Soundstage and center fill are superb, however.  At times the strings sounded a bit grainy, but otherwise is not issue.  What is an issue is how great the music is.  I think you will want to explore Rubbra’s other symphonies.  I certainly will.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

We bought two of these for our 20' pontoon boat, and I hope they will gather dust for the rest of our lives.  But we may sometime use the eagle end of them to grab a loop to help us get in to our very narrow slip at the marina.  They are well-constructed, relatively lightweight and sturdy.  They fit easily under the lift-up seat cushion on the boat.  What else can you ask for in a product you hope you will never use?  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!.

When I opened this pack of penlights, one didn't work.  Frankly, these are so inexpensive, so what?  They provide adequate light for checking pupils and mouth, although not as bright as that from my Welsh Allyn diagnostic set.  The quality is otherwise excellent.  The best part of disposables is that they are... well, disposable.  Penlights tend to have a shorter half-life than Xanax, so their low cost is a major advantage.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!

Eugene List was a pupil of Olga Samaroff at Juilliard who also taught Roslyn Tureck.  He had an illustrious concert career but his recordings are hard to find, now.  This Vanguard disc presents him in performances of the piano music of Louis Moreau Gottschalk.  The first disc is devoted to two-hand piano music, while the second features one-piano four-hands and two-piano works.Disc 1 begins with one of Gottschalk’s most well-known works, The Banjo.  While I have heard faster accounts, I have heard none with such rounded tone. Nor has the piano been recorded so well.  If you have never heard The Banjo, you are in for a real treat.  This is the finest performance of the virtuoso piece ever!  I will mention a few other pieces of note beginning with Souvenir de Porto Rico which receives a caring performance and perfect idiomatic playing.  This is a rather sultry piece, and List gives it plenty of sway.  You won’t fail to be impressed.  Bamboula is another of popular pieces.  It is the forerunner to the cakewalk.  The reading is luscious.  The Last Hope is a mournful piece of great beauty.  Tournament is a gallop that is just plain fun to hear.Disc 2 is comprised mostly of arrangements by List and Cary Lewis.  They are, of course, performed with distinction, but I have little interest in arrangements as they are not the intent of the composer.  Only Tremolo is the original Gottschalk version and it receives a superb performance by List and assistant.  This is a very lively work with a wonderful theme.  The four hands almost play as one.This is a superb album of Gottschalk piano music.  The second disc is equally enjoyable but largely consisting of arrangements.  The piano sound is excellent but sounded like a different instrument on Disc 2.  Curious.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for Disc 1!!!

People who buy compilations such as this one aren't necessarily looking for definitive accounts of the works but rather a mix of styles that share the quality of being enjoyable to listen to.  We classical musicians are looking for an easy way to hear superbly performed musical candy.  So, it is a real plus for the first group when almost all of the selections are excellently performed as these are.  For those in the second group, a plus with caveats  The second plus is that Reference Recordings records these wonderful performances.  Both groups win on this plus.Chabrier's Espana  Rhapsody receives a stellar, exciting performance.  Finlandia is beautifully recorded but lacks the intensity and punch it deserves.  Still the work never fails to bring tears to my eyes and does here, as well.  Escales has never been one of my favorites and still isn't, although it is a sweet piece.  Alfven's Midsummer Vigil is a lively piece but this attribute is lacking the nth degree in this performance.  Borodin's Steppes of Central Asia receives an average performance, again lacking any magical quality.  Smetana's Moldau is held back by tempo.  Tchaikovsky's Capriccio Italien is the longest work on the disc and too often seems it.Oue could sometimes seem uninspired, and he does here.  Tempi are a bit on the slow side, which robs the works of their edge.  The orchestra performs beautifully, and the sound is simply stellar.  For what the intent of this album is, it's a success.  But I don't think that most musicians or experienced listeners will be too interested in repeated listening.  Highly Recommended for those looking for a fine compilation of classical candy.

This is the perfect line (double braided nylon) and size (3/8 inch) to use for a 20' pontoon boat.  Easy to tie-off to a cleat, and the loop made attaching to the boat's cleat simple.  Fifteen feet is really longer than we need but we will simply cot off the excess.  We just bought three more this morning.

This is great line to use for an anchor.  Used it for the first time yesterday on a 20' SunTracker with an 18 lb river anchor at Laurel River Lake in Kentucky.  The rope was smooth enough that I could control the line as the anchor sank and grasp the line when pulling the anchor back up.  I wouldn't use any other line for anchoring.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

I don't understand why medical professionals would use tongue depressors that weren't in sterile packaging these days.  Paying a few cents more to insure a clean tongue depressors is more than worth my AND my patients' satisfaction that I am not introducing a contaminated product into their mouth.  Yes, yes, I know how unlikely an infection would result, but why not just be safe?These tongue depressors are smooth and elicit no complaints - other than the knowledge that most patients wonder why their doctors aren't more careful not to make them gag!  LOL.  I have always educated my patients that I make them gag on purpose to check on cranial nerve function.  Great, inexpensive tool for physicians.  I hear you can also mix epoxy with them.

These 1/4" labels are the perfect way to organize CD's.  My system for classical music is as follows (for those of you interested in such things).  My top picks for a work are designated with two red dots on the right spine of the case.  Other superb recordings of that work get one red dot.  All of my superb or better recordings are in my top three drawers.  Everything else is in the drawers below.  Contemporary recordings that I want to listen to again get a green dot on the left portion of the spine.  Demonstration quality recordings get a yellow dot on the left, as well.  This makes it easy to refind the great albums.  Of course, there are in alphabetical order by genre and composer.  With about  500-600 albums, using these dots fixes the problem of not recalling which albums I rated as definitive recordings.The dots are easily removed from the paper, and they stick on the CD jewel case very well.  I only wish they were fluorescent.  They can be removed with little more effort than using your fingernail.  We use the larger ones at my private practice office for patient folders.  Avery has a good thing going with such a simple but effective means of identifying what you want to find at a later date.

This is a product that works as claimed.  I don't know how to explain the one reviewers safflower seed that sprouted, but we use it in the bottom of our upside-down Goldfinch feeder containing thistle and it keeps the seed from molding.  To be fair, we also put Feeder Fresh on top of the seed, too, and use a dome baffle over the feeder.  We used to have problems with mold, but no more!

Confession time:  I’m a bandaholic. I admit it.  I love band music.  Wind Band, Symphonic Band, Brass Band.  Add nothing or add bagpipes, organ, or even full orchestra.  It doesn’t matter.  I still love it.  With that being said, I am happy to report that this album is a band lover’s dream.  The works recorded for this Klavier album are exceptional compositions that receive exquisite performances with resplendent sound.  The pieces include Richard Danielpour’s Icarus, Eric Ewazen’s Shadowcatcher, Kathryn Salfelder’s Stylus Phantasticus, and Anthony Plog’s Concerto 2010.  They were recorded in 2012 and 2013.  Performing the program are the Western Michigan University Symphonic Band, Western Winds, and Western Brass Quintet.The album begins with Danielpour’s Icarus for Brass Ensemble, Percussion, and Two Pianos, an 11-minute work inspired by the Greek mythology story of Daedalus and his son Icarus and their tragic flight (literally and figuratively) from imprisonment.  The fear, drama, angst are all superbly depicted by Danielpour’s unique cast of instruments.  The music reflects a series of moods from agitation to worrisome, despair, and lament.  Enjoyable rhythms and pulse as well as instrumental sonorities throughout!Ewazen’s moving Shadowcatcher, a work commissioned by the Butler University Wind Ensemble, was inspired by four photographs from a photo journey through the North American Indian nations made by Edward Curtis over the first three decades of the 20th century.  The 1st movement Offering to the Sun captures both the optimism of light and celebratory gratitude with attractive melodic elements.  The 2nd movement Among the Aspens begins with the sounds of Native ceremony.  The writing is entirely moving with wonderful arpeggio work by the trumpets.  The melodic elements that infuse the movement are simply beautiful.  Note the marvelous effect of the off-stage trumpets at 5:00.  Drums add to the decidedly Native feel of the piece.  The final few minutes are so emotionally driven that you can’t help but feel guilt about our regrettable treatment of these spiritual giants.  The 3rd movement The Vanishing Race only continues the emotional tone begun in the 2nd movement, but now the mood becomes more mournful and sad.  You sense the aimless wandering of a people who have lost their home.  I find Ewazen’s ability to compose such superb depictions of intense moods astonishing.  With the 4th movement’s Dancing to Restore an Eclipsed Moon depicts the Kwakiuntl Indians’ belief that a lunar eclipse resulted from the moon being swallowed by a creature.  Their dance around a fire was aimed at making the creature sneeze and free the moon.  The music is agitated appropriately as though the intensity was required for the dance to work its magic.  Serenity if restored in the final few minutes and the music says all is right with the world again.  Ewazen’s creative genius has never been so well displayed!Salfelder’s Stylus Phantasticus is all the more impressive when one realizes that she is still a doctoral student at the New England Conservatory, with an already-enviable list of compositions and commissioned works!  She has been awarded the 2012 ASCAP Morton Gould Young Composer Award and 2008 ASCAP/CBDNA Frederick Fennell Prize and her music clearly explains why.  Stylus Phantasticus is a Baroque style.  During the piece, Salfelder has musical flashbacks (including fugal passages) to the Baroque period as the work unfolds in a mostly-modern manner.  Stylus Phantasticus is a fascinating bridge between two widely divergent periods in music history.  The writing itself is ingenious and the orchestration absolutely grand and large-scaled.  This is one I will listen to repeatedly!Plog’s Concerto 2010 is a four movement work in which movements share motifs or attaccas.  Analysis aside, the Concerto is a very original and fascinating work of various instrumental combinations.  The 1st movement begins calmly but soon progresses to the 2nd movement and near-perpetual motion.  The 3rd movement Adagio sounds rather sparse of instruments and ideas.  The 4th movements returns us to the agitation of the 2nd movement.  Quite interesting.This is an extraordinary album from compositional, performance and sound perspectives.  Aside from Plog’s not very special 1st and 3rd movements, all are uniformly impressive musical works.  The performances are exquisite as is the sound.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

Everything about Toru Takemitsu’s and his list of accomplishments is unique.  Among his accomplishments, he organized an experimental workshop for painters and composers in Tokyo and designed a Space Theater for the Osaka Exposition in 1970.  Oh and I almost forgot, he is also a noted Japanese composer who has been influenced by Debussy, Messiaen, Cage, and Boulez on the Western end of music.  Of course, Takemitsu has been most influenced by his traditional Japanese music.  The results are very original compositions that blend the two spheres of influence.  Given what you have read, it should come as no surprise that Takemitsu’s music is like none I have ever heard.  As a Westerner, it sounds more Japanese than anything else to me.  In other words, compared to Takemitsu, the most modern atonal music sounds absolutely conventional to me.So, this Philips album is going to be fun to review!  It features Seiji Ozawa conducting the Saito Kinen Orchestra in Takemitsu’s November Steps for orchestra with shakubachi and biwa, Eclipse for shakubachi and biwa, and Viola Concerto “A String around Autumn”.  The album was recorded in 1989 and 1990.  Expect some unusual (for Western listeners) sounds and instruments you are not accustomed to hearing.  To the average listener, some of the instruments sound like stretched rubber band plucked and other unusual instrumental sonorities.November Steps is, like most of Takemitsu’s works, a single movement.  It features the shakubachi and biwa.  The Shakubachi is a wind instrument resembling a recorder.  The Biwa is a fretted string instrument resembling a lute.  This is an orchestral piece, but as the piece unfolds there is increasing emphasis on the Japanese instruments with minor elaboration by strings.  It sounds like you would anticipate traditional Japanese music sounding.  If you like the twanging effect of the Biwa in an advent-guard piece, they you will like November Steps.  Eclipse is much the same but with even less conventional orchestra.It isn’t until we hear A String Around Autumn that we hear the more familiar Avant-guard “conventiality”. The work is tonal and the most accessible on the disc.  For modern music, I was surprised how listenable the work was.  The influence of Debussy is obvious, and melody is present (of course, it is the modern notion of melody).  The viola is played superbly and according to the composer, “the viola plays the part of a human being observing nature in this Autumn scene.”  There is much beauty to behold in this work.Sound is exemplary with no issues whatsoever.  This is difficult music, so adequate time must be allowed to appreciate the music within.  RECOMMENDED!

English composer Sir Michael Tippett didn't really discover music until his teens and in his adult life was composer, conductor, and politically incorrect pacifist radical  (he was actually imprisoned for three months during WW II for his pacifist actions). He wrote his first Symphony at 37 years of age and was most prolific during his later years. His work was especially popular in the United States, and Symphony No. 4 was commissioned by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.  In the present album we hear Byzantium and Symphony No. 4 by Sir Michael Tippett performed by Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on a London disc recorded in or before 1991.Byzantium originated as a song cycle of three movements but was abandoned in favor of the present set of five songs with mezzo Faye Robinson.  The singer does a first rate job and the performance is commendable.  I must confess not being especially of modern song cycles, and despite the superb orchestral role, I will be unlikely to revisit Byzantium in the future.  If you enjoy such works, I am certain that you will  not be disappointed in this performance.  The orchestra sounds fantastic!Symphony 4 is organized as a single 30-minute movement, but sections roughly correspond to movements.  Tippett called the symphony a "birth to death piece," harking back to a visit to a museum experience during which he saw preserved fetuses.  The symphony even employs breathing sound machine.  The 1st section opens darkly (almost bleakly) and introduces several tempi that will characterize the remaining sections.  I find that absorbing the music produces the greatest pleasure when you first listen to this symphony, because trying to make sense of symphony initially is a rather challenging.  There are a multitude of musical ideas and they seem to be thrown about at random.  If you like difficult modern music, then you will love this symphony, his crowning symphonic work.  If the Symphony 4 is at first frustrating as it was for me, repeated listening will increase your satisfaction to the point of enjoyment.  It certainly did for me.  I actually enjoy its amazing complexity, intensity, and fascinating orchestral sonorities, now.This is a superb sounding album with performances that are bettered only by Tippett’s own performances.  Michael Tippett conducted both Symphony 2 and 4 with the BBC Symphony Orchestra exactly as he intended them to sound on a BBC disc that I reviewed a couple of months ago.  The Second Symphony is far more accessible than the initially confusing Fourth. The recorded sound on the present disc is surprisingly good.  Soundstage, orchestral balance, and center fill is great. Solti’s performances are certainly recommended, but if you are interested only in Symphony 4, then buy the BBC disc that contains Symphony 2 as well.

Nothing special but perfect for the job at hand.  I use these applicators for my neuro exam in physicals for patients in my clinical drug research trials.  Pull off a bit of cotton for testing corneal reflexes, then break it in half and use for dull and sharp sensation on the skin.  Then throw away.  Perfect and economical.  I suppose it could also be used as a defensive weapon with particularly hostile and aggressive inmates if you are an attending in a jail or prison (grin).

I was disappointed in this Queen Square reflex hammer in most every way.  I ordered this as a spare for my more substantial hammer I bought for my bag in the sophomore year of medical school in 1983.  That hammer had a larger diameter handle that fit the hand better than the toothpick feel of the hammer under review.  The rubber disc of my old hammer is also more substantial.  This one feels like a toy by comparison.  I will keep you posted on what I can find that serves my needs (hopefully) as well as my present Queen Square.

Randall Thompson was an important figure in 20th century American music who taught at UC Berkeley, was the Director of Curtis Institute, and faculty member at Princeton and Harvard.  Besides his three symphonies, he also composed much choral music including Choose Something Like a Star from Americana.  If you haven't heard this wonderfully moving piece, I strongly encourage you to do so.  The present Koch album presents Thompson's Symphony 2 and 3 performed by Andrew Schenck conducting the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra.Special mention is appropriate for the conductor who died tragically of cancer at 52 in 1992. Schenck studied conducting with Leonard Bernstein, Pierre Monteux, and Izler Solomon (late conductor of the Indianapolis SO).  He graduated from Harvard and obtained his Masters from Indiana University. Andrew Schenck was a superb conductor who with this orchestra resurrected the music of Samuel Barber from the doldrums.  The music world lost one of its finest conductors by his early death, and he will be missed by many of us grateful listeners. Symphony 2 begins energetically with vivacious rhythms.  The 2nd movement is as lovely a slow movement as you are likely to hear from the 20th century and would be a fitting tribute to Andrew Schenck.  The pensive theme can only be described as sublime.  The 3rd movement begins with plucked bass and has a hint of jazz majesty to it.  I heard more than a few Gershwin-like bars of music. This music may not be moving but certainly makes you want to move.  A middle section is at times dreamy.  Thompson demonstrates a bit of musical chameleon to his character, able to change his color at a moment's notice.  Impressive.  The 4th movement Andante had another lovely theme that walked along with a hint of melancholy before transforming to an upbeat tempo.  More chameleon.  You gotta love it!  Finally, Thompson gives us a full orchestra version of the original melody that is just awe-inspiring.  If I had to pick one phrase to describe Thompson, it would be "one colorful surprise after another."  This is some of the easiest to hear and most beautiful 20th century music ever written - right up there with Copland's Appalachian Spring.Symphony 3 begins with sorrowful strings playing one of the most melancholic themes in music.  If anyone doubts Thompson's creative genius, this 1st movement alone should dismiss any question about his ability to construct sublime music.  If sorrowful isn't enough, prepare for intensely anguished at the 3 minute mark, when the music takes a decided turn to serious emotional impact.  It immediately drew tears as I listened.  I have always maintained that the true merit of a composer is not how well he conveys his emotions but how well he draws yours.  Randall Thompson does.  The 2nd movement may be the most brilliantly written and thrilling movements in the 20th century symphonic repertoire.  The orchestration, especially in the tutti climaxes, is astonishing.  The brass players must have been delighted beyond belief.  At the conclusion, however, Thompson quiets to a pastoral close. The 3rd movement represents another moving piece of composition, tender and pastoral with a hint of longing.  I know of no 20th century composer who could write more beautiful slow movements.  The 4th and final movement reminds you of youthful play, innocent and the like, yet on occasion the music upscales to mature, sometimes serious climaxes.  The brass and timpani play a particularly important roles in this movement, with the former glorious and the latter profound.  The conclusion of the symphony is stupendous.This album is likely to be my absolute favorite disc of 20th century music, immensely enjoyable from start to finish.  The music is more wonderful than words can describe.  The performance is exquisite, and the sound is resplendent.  This is a Must Have album for every music lover with even the slightest interest in 20th century American music.  There are NO shortcomings whatsoever, and the disc earns MY ABSOLUTELY HIGHEST RECOMMENDATION!!!!!

Virgil Thomson, like many smart musicians, hedged his musical bets with “real” jobs, music critic and film composer.  Born in Kansas City, Missouri, the young musician attended Harvard University thanks to a loan from Mormon Joseph Smith’s grandson.  After graduation, he moved to Europe and studied with famed French composition teacher Nadia Boulanger whose other noted American students included Aaron Copland, Roy Harris, Elliott Carter, and Walter Piston (pretty much a Who’s Who of 20th century American music).  While in Europe, Thomson enjoyed friendships with James Joyce, Gertrude Stein, Ernest Hemingway, Aaron Copland, Ezra Pound, Igor Stravinsky, Pablo Picasso,  and Orson Welles.  When Thomson returned home to America in 1940, he landed the position of music critic with the NY Herald Tribune alongside Aaron Copland.While Thomson composed a number of classical works including three symphonies and three operas, he is perhaps much better known as a film composer.  The present disc of film music includes scores for The River and The Plough that Broke the Plains performed by Richard Kapp conducting the Philharmonia Virtuosi.  Thomson’s music for these films is strikingly Americana, with abundant references to common hymns and folk tunes such as When Johnny Comes Marching Home.  The music is thoroughly enjoyable for what it is, and the writing is similar to Copland in Appalachian Spring.  The orchestra plays the works splendidly and the sound is first rate.  RECOMMENDED.

Witold Lutoslawski was the most prolific of 20th century Polish composers (and pianist and conductor) who was little known in America until 1956 when he visited the U.S. to give lectures and seminars.  Lutoslawski was trained for the Polish Army Signal Corp during WW II but was captured and imprisoned by the Germans.  He escaped and played piano in musical cafes  of Poland for the duration of the war.  He was also a composer in search of a compositional style with which he could confidently express his musical ideas, and his musical journey meandered through several influences and styles before arriving at his own.  Initially, the expression of his musical ideas was limited to folk-dominated music by the post-war Polish state until finally in the 1950’s, when he devised his own methods that involved using groups of musical intervals to build his harmonic structure. He also employed aleatory in which rhythmic elements of the music are subjected to chance.  This element of chance culminates in Indeterminacy in which increasing degrees of freedom are granted to the performer.I’ve covered only a sampling of Lutoslawski’s life to give you some idea of its breadth.  That life was an active one experientially as well as musically, and this album presents works beginning with the Symphonic Variations, his orchestral debut written at the age of 25, his Piano Concerto (1988), Variations on a Theme by Paganini for Solo Piano and Orchestra (1978), and his final Symphony 4 composed in 1992, just two years before his death.  The works are performed by Edward Gardner and the BBC Symphony Orchestra on Chandos and were recorded in 2011.The album begins with Lutoslawski’s Symphonic Variations, composed while the composer was studying composition at the Warsaw Conservatory.  His teacher pronounced it musically incomprehensible and ugly.  Nice.  It depicts the influence of Stravinsky and involves a ten measure theme first presented by flute, then violins.  Seven variations follow with a final coda.  The music immediately captures and holds your attention, and it demonstrates how fine an orchestrator Lutoslawski had already become.  The music is exciting, sometimes lovely, and sometimes powerful, sometimes stark, sometimes lush – but ALWAYS endlessly fascinating.  Okay, I’ll admit it:  I enjoy Lutoslawski!  The rhythms, melodic elements, dynamic contrasts, orchestral sonorities, and drama make this music easy to enjoy.The Piano Concerto was composed specifically for Krystain Zimmerman but is played here by Louis Lortie.  Each movement has the tempo specified with metronome markings.  The 1st movement is a driving affair with impressive climaxes.  Lortie’s piano tone is beautifully rounded.  The 2nd movement is marked Presto but is inconsistently so.  I did not find it nearly as interesting as the 1st.  The 3rd movement is slower and even less interesting.  The 4th movement opens with low strings playing a quiet but agitated melodic element (really, a brief series of strongly rhythmic motifs).  After 30 seconds of that introduction, the piano enters.  As the movement continues and more instruments join in, those motifs dominate the musicscape. A final coda ensues that is quite exciting.  Lortie demonstrates superb technique in one of the more difficult sounding piano concertos I have heard.  The music is uniformly interesting and more than listenable, but I find it somewhat difficult to give it stars for beauty.The Variations on a Theme by Paganini have an interesting history.  German occupation of Poland stripped the land of its classical music opportunities, and musical cafes popped up as a new venue.  Lutoslawski partnered with composer/pianist Panufnik to arrange and perform light music.  They composed or arranged a considerable number of works, all but these Variations lost in the 1944 Polish Uprising.  Much later, Lutoslawski arranged the Variations for piano and orchestra.  These are interesting and superbly played, but I will always defer to Rachmaninov for such an arrangement.Symphony 4 begins darkly.  A clarinet sings a long, slow, rather pensive melody is soon repeated that is taken up by other instruments and instrument ensembles as the single movement symphony unfolds.  Before the first tempo closes, the intensity increases, and the “movement” becomes a bit furious.  The second tempo section is agitated and at times angry-sounding.  Four more tempo section follow.  This is difficult music to love, yet Lutoslawski felt that his later music better expressed his musical ideas.  Personally, although I find great pleasure in modern music, I find Lutoslawski’s earlier works that are more easily accessible are far more enjoyable.This album is an excellent sampling of Lutoslawski across time.  Orchestral execution is superb, and Gardner is certainly in the mind of the music even if it has varying degrees of heart.  Sonically, the disc is without flaw, and the music makes a big splash on an adequately amped audio system.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for the Symphonic Variations, but others may enjoy his more obtuse works as well.  The latter, for me, are more enjoyable if absorbed rather than analyzed.

Roy Harris, Randall Thompson, and David Diamond – three noted 20th century American composers on one disc, Bernstein:  American Masters.  The Sony album presents Harris Symphony 3, Thompson Symphony 2, and Diamond Symphony 4 performed by Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic Orchestra in recordings made in 1962, 1969, and 1959, respectively.I recently reviewed Roy Harris’s Third Symphony performed by Bernstein/NYPO on a DG disc.  Quoting from that review, I said:  “Harris, who didn’t chose composition as a career until 26, studied with Sir Arthur Bliss and Nadia Boulanger. He is quoted as saying that his Third Symphony came along when it was needed. To be sure, it is a modern single-movement symphony of 1939 that was easily accessible, and it garnered wide acclaim upon its introduction. The music is assertive, direct, and relatively uncomplicated when compared to some other early 20th century music. It begins with melancholic cellos on a meandering modern theme. Additional strings take up the theme as tension build. Horns and other instruments complete the ensemble as the harmony increases in complexity. The music is interesting and easy to listen to. The pace quickens in a second-like movement, and the music adopts a new, more lively theme that jumps from one instrument to another before an exquisite fugue-like passage that brings in the timpani’s first appearance. Increasing complexity, tension, and dynamic contrasts ensue. We don’t hear even an intermediate full orchestra climax until the 14 minute mark in this 18  minute work. The music then slows with a repeated timpani pulse as the mood returns to mournful. A final set of chords played by strings and brass adds a timpani roll that brings the symphony to a close. Fine 20th century music. Not great, but Bernstein and crew perform it with precise distinction.”  The present Sony recording has more immediacy that DG’s as well as more excitement.  AND the timpani are very well defined. (Those familiar with my review know that in my next life I will play the timpani as well as the piano!)  The sound on this recording is far more vivid that DG’s, with the brass especially glorious.  The Sony disc unquestionably offers the better performance and sound.  It’s surprising how different two recordings of the same symphony, conductor, and orchestra can be.  Having heard this performance, I would NOT have called the music “fine but not great.”  It’s great!Randall Thompson was another important figure in 20th century American music who made his rounds of elite American music schools including UC Berkeley, Director of Curtis Institute, and faculty member of Princeton and Harvard.  Not a bad C.V.  Besides his three symphonies, he also composed much choral music including Choose Something Like a Star from Americana.  If you haven’t heard this wonderfully moving piece, find it, buy it, and prepare to be moved.  Thompson’s Symphony 2 begins energetically with vivacious rhythms.  The 2nd movement is as lovely a slow movement as you are likely to hear from the 20th century.  The 3rd movement begins with plucked bass and has a hint of jazz majesty to it.  I heard more than a few Gershwin-like bars of music. This music may not be moving but certainly makes you want to move.  A middle section is at times dreamy.  Thompson demonstrates a bit of musical chameleon to his character, able to change his color at a moment’s notice.  Impressive.  The 4th movement Andante had another lovely theme that walked along with a hint of melancholy before transforming to an upbeat tempo.  More chameleon.  You gotta love it!  Finally, Thompson gives us a full orchestra version of the original melody that is just awe-inspiring.  If I had to pick one phrase to describe Thompson, it would be “one colorful surprise after another.”  This is some of the easiest to hear 20th century music ever written – right up there with Copland’s Appalachian Spring.David Diamond may have been the least academically oriented of the three composers on this disc, but he was the most prolific and the biggest award-winner.  He wrote 11 symphonies, of which the Fourth is performed on this disc.  The 1st movement is a serious-sounding work but never ponderous or overworked.  It is very attractive modern music but not beautifully melodic like that of Thompson.  Diamond writes with power and substance with more tutti than ensemble.  The 2nd movement begins with a stark brass passage sounding very modern that adds strings in a melancholic, almost anguished, hymn.  The music, though modern, is of considerable interest, and it is a fine demonstration of Diamonds superb orchestration skills.  Just listen to the powerful climaxes.  This deserves repeated listening.  The 3rd and final movement is energized with a plethora of different orchestral sonorities.  The music is exciting throughout and easily holds the listener’s attention.  It is easy to see why Bernstein included Diamond on this disc.This is one of the most enjoyable albums of 20th century American music I have yet heard, and I can’t think of a finer introduction to our symphonic music of the last century.  Equally enjoyable is the sound which absolutely defies its age.  Everything sonically is as it should be.  Sony should be commended for its remastering which is astonishing.  The album easily deserves my VERY HIGHEST RECOMMENDATION!!!  Not to be missed!

Roger Sessions is found only a few pages after “serialism” in music dictionaries and encyclopedias.  How appropriate given his use of this compositional system.  He is regarded as an important figure in 20th century American music.  Born just before his century began, Sessions studied at Harvard and Yale, took private lessons from Ernest Bloch, and later became Bloch’s assistant at Curtis Institute.  Most impressive, as always, is not the education one receives but rather the education one gives.  In this regard, Sessions’ students affirm his place in American music:  Milton Babbitt, Peter Maxwell Davies, and Ellen Zwilich – each an American composer of considerable note.  And so was Sessions.Although I attended music school at Indiana University (but left after a three semesters for medicine), I am not about to claim any profound knowledge of serialism.  I approach modern music from my right hemisphere much more than from my left one.  In so doing, modern music such as that of Roger Sessions is either approachable or it isn’t.  I listen and absorb when I can’t listen and analyze.  The music of Sessions is: a) very approachable and enjoyable, and b) I listen and absorb much more than I even try to analyze it.  So, given those honest admissions, what do I think of his music and this recording?  First answers to that question: interesting musical ideas and instrumentation; stretches my musical mind which prevents me from becoming stagnant; enjoyable.  No, it didn’t evoke tears.  Sessions’ music isn’t amelodic, but don’t lose sleep if you can’t spot them.  Look for motifs both melodic and rhythmic.With a little patience, I found beauty within this pleasant music, enough that I want to listen to more works of Sessions.  I find multiple sequences of intervals and somewhat novel sonorities.  Symphony 5 is more energetic than Symphony 4.  I found the Fifth more interesting and energized but less soothing.  Both require active attention to reap rewards.  The sound is excellent.  The Columbus Symphony is a fine regional orchestra that plays well for Badea.  Soundstage is excellent with superb center fill.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

Stanislaw Skrowaczewski had quite a celebrated tenure at Minneapolis and here performs Prokofiev Romeo and Juliet Suites.  Also on the disc is A Night on Bald Mountain with Antal Dorati and the London Symphony.  These are both original Mercury recordings, Romeo and Juliet from 1962 and Bald Mountain from 1960.The two Romeo and Juliet Suites are given excellent albeit refined performances with exquisite sonic.  Skrowaczewski is a terrific interpreter of the music but never pulls out all the stops or plays over the top.  These are distinguished performances with wonderful energy and excitement.  I could be happy with them being my only recordings.  I suspect, however, that most listeners will prefer more dynamic and emotional accounts of competing conductors.  The Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra plays with precision.  The sound is extraordinary, with excellent soundstage, center fill, and orchestral sonorities.For excitement and energy, listen to Dorati’s LSO performance of Night on Bald Mountain.  This is a conductor known for pulling out the stops, and he gives one of the finest accounts I’ve heard.  Sound, however, is not up to that of the Suites.  Center fill is less than desirable, and the ambience is typical of a studio recording.  Even so, this is a reading that I would position on the top shelf ahead of the majority of competitors.  Talk about dynamics.Sound is excellent to superb.  Night on Bald Mountain is the tastiest treat here, but the Romeo and Juliet Suites are almost their equal.  All things considered, I must give this a rating of VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

This is a case when a pair of Threes wins the hand.  Here we have classic accounts of Roy Harris Symphony 3 and William Schuman Symphony 3 by perhaps the greatest champion of American music that ever lived – Leonard Bernstein – with his NYPO on the DG label.  Both works and performances are of definitive status with great sound.Harris, who didn’t chose composition as a career until 26, studied with Sir Arthur Bliss and Nadia Boulanger.  He is quoted as saying that his Third Symphony came along when it was needed.  To be sure, it is a modern single-movement symphony of 1939 that was easily accessible, and it garnered wide acclaim upon its introduction.  The music is assertive, direct, and relatively uncomplicated when compared to some other early 20th century music.  It begins with melancholic cellos on a meandering modern theme.  Additional strings take up the theme as tension build.  Horns and other instruments complete the ensemble as the harmony increases in complexity.  The music is interesting and easy to listen to.  The pace quickens in a second-like movement, and the music adopts a new, more lively theme that jumps from one instrument to another before an exquisite fugue-like passage that brings in the timpani’s first appearance.  Increasing complexity, tension, and dynamic contrasts ensue.  We don’t hear even an intermediate full orchestra climax until the 14 minute mark in this 18 ½ minute work.  The music then slows with a repeated timpani pulse as the mood returns to mournful.  A final set of chords played by strings and brass adds a timpani roll that brings the symphony to a close.  Fine 20th century music.  Not great, but Bernstein and crew perform it with precise distinction.William Schuman studies at Juilliard with Roy Harris.  His composition career was set when drew the attention of Koussevitzky.  Schuman also had an administrative career, as well, serving a publications director for G. Schirmer and as presidents of Juilliard and Lincoln Center.  Best of all, his music is more interesting than his mentor’s!  The present work is two parts of two movements each.  Schuman’s Third Symphony begins with similarity to Harris’ but the 1st movement Passacaglia quickly picks up the pace, additional instruments, and harmonic and textural interest.  The 2nd movement Fugue is an incredible piece of music, although not readily identifiable as a fugue.  This is your Mamma’s Bach in name only, but it is completely extraordinary and fun to follow.  You’ll love it.  There is such harmonic and textural beauty, I almost forgot that it was modern music.  The sonorities are terrific.  The 3rd movement is a mournful Chorale the opens with strings.  A single trumpet joins to take up the theme, then turns it over to a single flute, all the while the strings provide a moving base. Strings resume the theme and underlying harmonic foundation with sublime beauty.  The melancholic mood never subsides.  The 4th movement Toccata is studded with snare while woodwind instruments present the lively theme.  Frequent runs enhance the interest.  The music often becomes anguished or agitated but never dull.  Increasing appearances of timpani and cymbals announce increasing tension as the symphony draws to an exciting close.  This is superb 20th century music with much greater interest and beauty than its companion on the disc.This is an all-together successful album of American music.  The sound is as distinguished as the performances, although the Schuman is far more enjoyable.  Soundstage, center fill, and orchestral sonorities are superb.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!

I have been on a recent quest for greatest recordings of Brahms Symphony No. 4 and have come upon one that other reviewers and now I have found outstanding - Carlos Kleiber and the Vienna PO on DG, which I recently reviewed and is vivid in interpretation and sound.  The present account by Fritz Reiner and the Royal PO is a remastering by Chesky Records.  It is phenomenal, a perfect example of the capability of astute technicians to both eliminate the hiss of older recordings while actually enhancing the sound rather than degrading the highs.  Chesky considers itself an audiophile label, and they'll get no argument from me.  The sound is absolutely stupendous.  You would never guess that this is a 1962 recording.  Chesky could teach RCA a thing or two about rehabilitating old recordings the right way, certainly better than those RCA SACD's of the classic accounts.Reiner's interpretation is a bit more relaxed in comparison to the fire typically infused into his performances.  The tempos aren't slow but they sure aren't rushed, either.  In the 1st movement (and the other, for that matter), Reiner seems to aim more for exploring the depth of the music rather than settle for a mere blockbuster performance. This is a stately performance of considerable emotional depth.  The Andante is very capable of evoking listener emotion.  The warmth of the reading is astonishing for Reiner.  In the 3rd movement, I noticed that the slightly-dulled leading edge of instrumental attacks may be a casualty of Chesky's process of restoration.  It could also be a consequence of the reverberation.  Once noticed, it seemed to be ubiquitous.  Same with the 4th movement.  Still, this is a wonderful interpretation and not one to be missed.After rehearing the album, I am convinced that Reiner's recording of Symphony 4 won't displace Kleiber's account despite the generally phenomenal sound for a 1962 recording.  However, I would rank Reiner ahead of Nagano.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!

It is difficult from me to put my finger on, but there is something about this recording of Brahms Symphony 4 with Kent Nagano and the German Symphony Orchestra on Harmonia Mundi that strikes me as not quite right; and it is the recorded sound rather than the interpretation that is the more problematic.  According to Wikipedia, the orchestra was founded in 1946 by the American occupation forces in Berlin.  Although the Deutsches SO has had an incredibly notable number of conductors - Ferenc Fricsay (1948-1954, 1959-1963), Lorin Maazel (1964-1975), Riccardo Chailly (1982-1989), Vladimir Ashkenazy (1989-1999), and Kent Nagano (2000-2006) – it competes with the Berlin PO for players.  Now, who do you think is going to win the best players?  I could not find any information regarding the size of the Deutsches SO, but by the sound of the recording I would guess that the orchestra is smaller than the norm.  This is not to say that it isn’t an excellent orchestra, for it is.  They play with distinction for their conductor of half a dozen years.  The sound issue may be a slight lack of brilliance and less than optimally defined timpani.  My “like-new” disc lacked the booklet, but this sounds like a recording made in an overly damped studio.  Perhaps others can hear the issue more clearly.Kent Nagano’s interpretation played by the Berlin PO would probably have sounded better.  The interpretation lacks the electricity of one of my favorites – Kleiber, but he has been accused by some of being too white-hot with his reading on DG.  Still this is a superb interpretation, perhaps more lyrical than Kleiber’s.  I would certainly place it as a 4.5 Stars - 5 for interpretation and 4.25 for sound - and recommend it highly.

Eric Ewazen teaches at Julliard, and his music has the simple beauty and accessibility of Karl Jenkins.  In this album the International Sejong Soloists play Ewazen’s Concerto for Violin and Strings, Down a River of Time (Concerto for Oboe & Strings), and Sinfonia for Strings.  Each are three-movement works.  Each is a refined, well-played work of considerable interest.  Most of all, each work is a pure delight.  Is Ewazen really a modern-day composer?  The question is at once appropriate for his music is heaven sent in a day usually filled with dissonance and atonality.  Not so with Ewazen.  While not quite music that you hum after listening, this (like Jenkins) is almost too accessible to be 21st century products.I very much enjoy listening to and reviewing modern music with its often times difficult-to-describe sonorities.  I was surprised by the sheer beauty of this music.  It is truly a breath of fresh air.  I compose piano music without major dissonance and sometimes feel like I am in the wrong century.  Ewazen quells my self-doubt. It IS possible to write serious music that doesn’t attack the listener after all.  I don’t typically enjoy concertos other than piano, but both the violin and oboe concertos are splendid creations.  His Sinfonia is a sublime work of music.Ewazen’s music has considerable poignancy infused throughout each work.  I don’t know if Ewazen’s music will stand the test of time, but I can assure you that his music will fall favorably and easily on the ears of our time.  I strongly encourage you to take the opportunity to hear this wonderful music.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

Gustav Allan Pettersson was a Stockholm-born symphonist who composed in the vicinity of the middle of the 20th century.  He is considered one of Sweden’s most important 20th century composers.  He is unique in that his symphonic music fails to adhere to any particular school of composition unless you consider “dark” a school.  His music is, indeed, quite dark – but also quite compelling.  His life is a fascinating one and of immediate interest to a psychiatrist.  We know that his father was apparently a roaring alcoholic blacksmith, while his mother was kind and playful.  He began studying at the Stockholm Royal Conservatory (violin and viola) at 19.  A later diagnosis of polyarthritis was to ultimately confine him to his apartment for the last years of his life.  Pettersson was better known as a performer until 1968 when Antal Dorati premiered his fame-producing Symphony No. 7.  He continued to write until his death in 1080.On this SACD disc, Christian Lindberg leads the Norrkoping Symphony Orchestra in Pettersson’s Ninth Symphony.  Symphony 9, like most of his 16 symphonies, is organized as one long movement, in this case of almost 70 minutes duration.  His music is tonal, but don’t expect melodies as such.  There are abundant melodic motifs, however.  Rather, Pettersson produces a variety of orchestral sonorities, moods, and rhythms, many of the latter repetitive.  Fortunately, his music is variable enough to easily sustain the listener’s interest.  I certainly found his Ninth to do so.  Yes, it is dark, but I don’t find it oppressively so.  Like many 20th century composers, Pettersson enjoys combinations of instruments as much as orchestral tutti’s.  When a tutti appears, there is a repetitive relentlessness about it, usually connoting a struggle.  Tutti’s are usually accompanied by plenty of timpani, always dear to my heart.  You will hear traces of dances and minimalism.  Despite the lack of flowing melodic lines, there is a poignancy to Pettersson’s music that is very alluring and engaging.  And I found the symphony very enjoyable – not smile-provoking, but enjoyable nonetheless.  After 70 minutes of gloom, the music ends simply with a touching Picardy third.The orchestra plays beautifully, but sounds like a regional orchestra with forces I wish were greater.  Sonics are excellent, however.  I really liked this modern symphony and will order more Pettersson as a result.  I rate the recording Highly Recommended.

This is the big brother to the Dorcy 41-2510.  Both are superb flashlights with intense light.  The company should rename it a mini-searchlight.  It is relatively light and fairly difficult to lose with its vibrant yellow and black color scheme.  Now you might ask why you should buy a $13 flashlight. First, you don't change the batteries very often.  LEDs don't consume much energy.  This flashlight uses 4-AA batteries and will last 5 hours of continuous use.  When was the last time you used any flashlight that long?  Probably never.  Second, this thing is VERY bright.  Third, it looks rugged. I bought two of these and five of its little brother.  Frankly, most users would do as well to just buy the little brother which is cheaper, lighter, uses only two batteries, and still shines one heck of a beam.  If you want the light that ate Tokyo, then buy this one.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!

This may be the best flashlight out there!  Its inexpensive, throws a bright beam more than adequate for almost any use, uses 2 AA batteries, and comes in six colors (why, I'll never understand). And it floats.  I have a total of five (one for each car and boat and one for home.  The photo makes it look larger than its brighter big brother which is overkill for most needs.  It is smaller.  You will age before you need to change the batteries.  What more can you ask for.  Heck, it even comes in pink.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

The most important thing to know about this Thermo Hygrometer is to experiment with the location for your sensor.  We are only interested in the temperature reading and have discovered that placement of the sensor does indeed affect your temperature reading.  The location of ours is in the crevice of the window.  This shields it a tiny bit so that it reads warmer by a few degrees in the winter, and colder in the summer because that location is in the shade.  We adjust our expectations knowing the limitations of placement.  Still, it's nice to know the "general" temperature without the burden of wires running through the bottom of your windows.  For our purposes, the Thermo Hygrometer is perfect, and we would buy it again in a heartbeat!  Definitely RECOMMENDED!!

I jokingly refer to this little book as my peripheral brain - actually not really jokingly as I near retirement.  I use it every week at least once to check on how small a dose a drug comes in that I don't usually prescribe.  The content is accurate and the format makes the book a joy to use.  With so many new drugs on the market, I wish it was published every year.  The PDR print is too small for me and the book has become to large to easily use.  The Handbook couldn't be handier.  Highly Recommended!

My wife uses this to make whole wheat pancakes and to cook frozen vegan sausage patties every Sunday morning.  With the griddle's 22 inch length, she can now make all the pancakes and sausage paddies at one time.  She said that her only complaint was the pebbled cooking surface, because it is harder to clean (pancake batter sticks in the grooves.  It heats us within a couple of minutes.  The handles allow you to move the griddle when the surface is still hot.  Because we use no oil, we have no need for the grease catcher, but it seems like a good plan.

We have been very happy with this coffeemaker and use it every morning.  Filling it with water requires adequate space above and around the unit, so expect to move it our from under the cabinets on the countertop.  It is fairly tall, so someone of short stature might find it a bit of a challenge to fill the water reservoir and coffee hopper.  We have a separate water filter (Premia), so we don't use the coffeemaker's internal replaceable filter.  It produces a great cup of coffee (12).  We fill our Zorjurishi thermos and leave the rest in the pot.  The heating element stays on for long enough for me to drink what is left in the pot before the element turns off.  When it does, a few beeps alerts you to that.  We have cracked on decanter pot but the replacement was easy to obtain.  I would buy it again!

This is a great, relatively inexpensive, easy to clean pot that is perfect for cooking pasta or preparing enough bean soup to last a couple of days.  We use it several times a week.  It is sturdy without being too heavy.  The handles do not get hot (don't touch the metal stems, though).  We couldn't be happier with it and would recommend it to anyone.  We have the cookware set as well.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!

This Oral-B product is superbly designed and is appropriate for a maximum of four users (if each uses only one toothbrush).  My wife and I use this product.  I like the separate holding areas for the brushes and the ability to put the cover down.  The product has plenty of power, enough so that each of use can brush our teeth on the charge without the unit running out of steam.  I also like the two-minute timer that alerts you when an acceptable time of brushing has occurred.  I always go beyond the two minute mark, but I am confident that I haven't undercleaned.  The unit fits nicely on a fairly small surface.  VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

I am not a huge coffee drinker. I'm sensitive to caffeine and especially now while pregnant it's just not something my body reacts well to. BUT with being in my 3rd trimester comes exhaustion... and now that it's cooling off outside I really just have those mornings where I want to sit on my front porch and drink a hot cup of coffee under my blanket. There had to be a middle ground right? I had previously tried the Latitude brand flavored coffee and really enjoyed it, so when I saw they offered a half caff I thought it could be perfect for me. I like that it's got a nice rich flavor without sending my heart into a racing beat. It gives me enough perk without over stimulating me. It's a nice treat for cool mornings (which are few and far between in Louisiana).I received a discount for this item in exchange for my review. This is my real experience.

Getting my kids to take their vitamins and probiotics has never been a problem... except with my 4yo. That kid absolutely refuses even gummy vitamins. This became available to me as part of a review promotion and I thought maybe... Sure enough, I put it in his morning milk/juice/etc and he drinks it up none the wiser. I feel better because he is my preemie and I worry more about his health than my other 4, and he has never noticed or mentioned that his drink was different.I received this at a discount in exchange for my honest review. This is my own experience.

This set of DVDs is pretty adorable. My 19mo son really loves it as much as my 3yo does. It's "hosted" by Abigail the robot and features 4 DVDs: Letters, Numbers, Shapes, and Colors. It seems to work similarly to using flash cards by going through each lesson and presenting examples that match the lesson. For example: "A" "a" (Photo of apple) "A" "a" "Apple". It's set to friendly instrumental music. I don't think it's incredibly advanced, but if your baby is just learning these things, it is a nice introduction to them. It's marketed to ages 9mo through 36mo and I would say that's appropriate. I like that I could put on a DVD and for 30min or so my littles are occupied and learning.I received this free in exchange for my honest evaluation. My opinion is my own and hasn't been biased.

Summary - My husband has been using this kit for a week now. He is satisfied with the level of results, but feels that it's not the most comfortable process. Overall he still felt confident in giving it 4 stars vs 3 because the results have been that good (more than 3 shades whiter so far).Pros - The kit came with more than enough supplies to get a great result, and my husband is experiencing continued success. He's an avid coffee drinker and a smoker and his teeth had taken on a yellow tinge despite using whitening toothpaste on a regular basis. This has taken some of those deeply set stains out.Cons - He's advised me that the trays are uncomfortable to wear and holding the light in his mouth in place for 15 minutes feels like a long time.We received this at a discount in exchange for our honest review.

Clips hold well and have a nice design that allows them to open and close with ease and without pinching. I like that they're compatible with our soothie paci which is notoriously NOT clip friendly. I appreciate having more than one to choose from (or keep in different places, like clipped to my purse). The have held up to being washed in the washing machine without fraying or breaking (no rust b/c they're plastic at the closure part). My 18mo can open and close them himself after watching us do it so much and he often is found wearing more than one at a time. I think they're adorable & I don't know how I waited until my 4th kid to try them.I received these free in exchange for my honest evaluation.

This set worked well for me. It fit my pans nicely - provided a non stick surface that cleaned easily with soap and water. I used it for both biscuits and baked chicken (separately) and my food cooked evenly and without extra browning on the bottom in both cases. I like that the edges were squared off b/c it made the mat fit better in my pans. I would have liked to have a set that had one this size and one a size smaller for my smaller baking sheets, but I wouldn't say that's worth giving it 4 stars over. I don't know what the circles are marking except a nice pattern b/c they appear too close together to be marking anything like placement for cookies or biscuits. Overall it worked as expected and met the basic qualities of a great silicone baking set.I received this at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

Fantastic set - would make a gerat gift. Has lots of positive features like being non porous, the handles and edges with rubber coating so they are nonslip when you're using them, the deep groove edge which contains any fruit or meat juices while you're using it. I appreciate the varied sizes and really just having more than one cutting board. I don't have to necessarily wash my board between cutting different items b/c there's more than one board and I can use one for items that you should be careful with (for reasons of cross contamination like raw meat), and another for my veggies and sides. They've held up over the last week to nightly use (my husband is a sucker for a new kitchen gadget). They wash easily with soap and water. They met all of my expectations for a nice cutting board set.I received these at a discount in exchange for my honest review

A really nice iPhone 6 case that adds a cool color without adding bulk. This case is a great way to protect your phone from scratches and light bumps, but I don't think it would hold up to a big drop. It's lightweight and low profile - doesn't add any bulk at all. Fit snugly and was easy to put on. It came with a screen protector (YAY) and accessories to apply it easily. I liked that it was packaged so the screen protector and accessories didn't come already scratched like I have experience with other brands. I don't know how well this will stand up to long term use and scratches, but it's a great case if you like to change often and want a new look for your phone without a lot of bulk or weight.I received this at a discount in exchange for my honest review

When I'm reviewing a product I like to do the pros and cons in my head of what I expect from a product. For this product I expect a level of grit that will be comfortable but will get the job done. This met my expectations of what a good foot file would have. It gets the dead skin off my feet effectively without being uncomfortable. I like that it came with two files - I have one in the bathtub and I use it there. The other I keep next to my vanity and I use it if I feel like my feet are rough before I put lotion on in the morning. They're both double sided though I cannot tell a difference in the texture from top to bottom. The handle fit my hand well and the hole in the handle allows me to hang it from my shower caddy so it doesn't get gross from sitting on a shelf. All in all it completely met my expectations and I am totally satisfied.I received this at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I received this at a discount in exchange for my honest evaluation.I am currently 8.5 mo pregnant so I couldn't try it on myself - though I fully intend to use it postpartum as my core support and I will update my review if anything changes. For the purposes of this review I asked a friend who is 8 weeks postpartum and similarly sized and shaped to me to wear it for a week over her tank top and tell me how it fit. First of all when I think latex I imagine like fake rubber - that's not the case here, it's soft and stretchy. It has three adjustment levels so you can tighten or loosen it depending on if you're experiencing a bloated day or you're losing weight. It didn't irritate the skin, or cause excessive sweating. It fit comfortably and being an underbust style didn't affect nursing in a negative way. It gave a shapely silhouette under her clothes and I didn't even realize she had it on one day when I visited a few days later. She said she was impressed it didn't dig into her hips when she sat down as she has a much shorter torso than I do (she's 5'4" to my 5'8"). I look forward to trying this myself in about 6 weeks.

This is not a good match for survival or for any outdoor use for that matter.The case is not waterproof, contrary to their statement. It is plastic and weather-proof, but the cap is only on by friction. It is nether a snap nor has threads, so the cap can come off unexpectedly.The match does light hotly, but it burns too quickly and goes out in seconds. The quality varies quite a bit, with varying length of sticks and wax coating. Some are so short that it can burn your finger when lit.There are much better products, especially when considering survival use where it has to work.

This is a very useful tape. I use it on bathroom grab bars and on hand-held shower head and it really prevents slippage even with wet soapy hands. It is great on stairs edge, I also use it on laptop PC so it can be grabbed securely.Another use is to apply under tool box so that it does not slide inside car trunk. Male Velcro strip works for this, too, but it tends to grab too hard and also picks up unwanted items.Adhesion is excellent. Just make sure to clean the surface and make sure it is dry.

Annoying green lines speckled the screen on the first unit I received. It was defective and the seller replaced it quickly. The second did not have the green line  problem, but it did not work with an Android TV box K-R42 Quad Core Google Android 4.2.2 RK3188 28nm Cortex-A9 1.6Ghz Mini TV BOX HDMI HDD Player 2G/8G External Wifi Antenna Ethernet Port with IR Remote Controller - Black which kept blanking the screen every few seconds. It works with some, but apparently not all HDMI outputs sufficient power for this device to work. I wound up using Ugreen Active HDMI to VGA with Audio and Mirco USB Converter Support 1920x1080@60Hz for Apple TV/ PC / Laptop / Ultrabook / Rasberry Pi / Chomebook, Black with a mini HDMI to regular HDMI adapter which worked well.

This works really well to keep partially used chalk from drying out. I usually have several tubes of different colors and they used to get wasted because they harden without a good cap. Some tubes come with a cap, but they do not work as well as these tips. It is not just a cover, but also has an inner tube that go into the chalk tube for a better seal.

The 3 pieces can be used individually or connected to stack together.I use them individually next to various equipment like furnace and central vacuum system, and keep instruction manual in them. Wall mounting saves space and I always know where the manuals, sales receipts, and warranty information are.They are good for keeping bills and other paper work organized, too.The packaging is flimsy, but I have never received a broken one despite ordering quite a few.

This is for the 12-inch length by 1.25-inch diameter bar.I was disappointed by a number of points, probably because of "premium" in its title was not up to my expectations.The knurled grip is nice, but it would have been better if it covered more handle area closer to the bend for a greater grip area. It is ironic that the ends do not have a fine polished look, and they look institutional. They probably meant "polished bar with knurled grip", not "polished knurled".The mount has a flange with an ugly dimple that holds it in place, and that does not look good. I had expected a less-noticeable way for a "concealed" mount. The flange diameter is about 3 inches and also quite thick, perhaps to make the screws concealed.

OK for short and light hose. Plastic is too flimsy to hold the rated 225 feet length.Smart Trak is a great feature to wind the hose neatly, but that is the weakest part and it fails.Looks good, though.

The round tablets are bigger and a bit more difficult to swallow than Lactaid's caplet size.Compared to Lactaid's same 3000 FCC units, this one seems to be less effective and I wound up having to take 2 tablets for the equivalent relief.It may be that this one takes longer to start working, however, and I may have to just take it earlier before milk product.What I did not like was unnecessary large bottle mostly full of cotton. Removing the cotton wad caused many pills to fall out with it. Smaller bottle would be easier to carry or store, and perhaps less pills would get caught in smaller amount of cotton.
I am using this with SEEK thermal imager and HTC 510 Desire to orient the camera to the correct direction. This was the only extension cable that worked with this camera.

It did not fit my my Kohler K-10217 faucet, so the very nice customer service agent sent me a free adapter.The coupler looks OK by itself, but the adapter extends it too long and makes it unsightly.I like the simplicity of plugging it in for use without needing electricity or a bulky device.On the other hand, there is no good way to store it except on a towel to soak up residual water.The water pressure is quite strong coming out of the irrigator, and it takes a bit of adjustment of faucet handle.One disappointment is the lack of on/off switch on the irrigation handle. Having to reach the faucet handle while trying to aim the water jet is problematic for me, and the water can spray everywhere.
Good quality gaffers tape.It is the one to carry if you can only take one tape, instead of masking tape and duct tape.

Holds tools well with strong magnet.As they state, color varies depending on what plastic tape they put on. Logo may, or may not, be there.The rack length also varies. It seems to depend on the production batch.I have purchased a few, and they varied from about 23 to 23.75 inches in length. It would have been nicer if the screw holes were made wider to accommodate for this variation to hit the studs.The actual magnet portion is about 19.5 inches.
Fast for a submarine plot.
Pretty good action movie. Can do with less shooting, though.
Entertaining if physics and biology can be ignored

Borescope makes any work behind wall or ceiling easier and saves lots of time.This is a good low-cost unit for casual work. Not only does it save money by using your existing smartphone, the display is better because of it (smartphone almost always has a better display).The picture from the camera is not bad. Color washes out in the dark, despite the LEDs next to the camera, and the dynamic range is lacking. Overall, however, the image is usable and actually better than the rest in this price range.The main issue I had was that smartphone could not be clamped on securely. It only holds by pressure and there is no U-channel to hold it in. So the phone would often drop with a bump. Phone with square edges should be OK, but all the ones I used had rounded edges.A minor issue was with a 1W built-in flashlight. It is very handy, but its trigger switch was too easy to accidentally turn on.

Since there are various models listed under this item, this review is for Ti2 V2 NW.Mine was defective and did not light up at all. It was drawing power as the battery was getting warm, but it was not drawing enough current as to be shorted. It drained 2 batteries while I tested this.
