If you just want a dim light to see around you, pull it up about half inch, and it will stay. If you want more light or full light, you simply pull the lantern up further. To shut it off, you simply slide it closed, and fold the handles down out of the way..My nephew was extremely excited about this lantern and I did not own it very long before he decided he needed it for his camp out. He is 8 years old and having his very own lantern just made his day. Great product, would recommend.

The color of the storage wardrobe is pretty true to what they have displayed. I was a little concerned about this and happy that it was as close as it was. The actual frame of the unit is made up of a gazillion plastic pieces. While this partly annoys me, as I have had many of these different types of organizing closets that don't require half as many parts, I also like that there are so many because it makes it so much easier to personalize for our needs.I received this at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest opinion and started out taking photos of the process, but after a while it became to much of a hassle to keep up with pictures with so many pieces involved. There are a ton of connector pieces to help make sections as tall, short, wise or slim as you want. However the main frame stays the same. You just adjust the middles sections as you wish.The cover is thicker than I thought it would be and I like that it is a clothe type material. Makes it easy to spot wash, or even take off the frame completely and throw in the washing machine. The cover has a double zipper that allows you to open one section and reach in grab, or you can open both zippers and have a wide access opening. This unit stands off the ground, keeping your stuff off the floor or even allowing a little extra storage area underneath.Since I purchased this with intentions of my daughter taking it off to college with her and putting it in her dorm, we then had to disassemble the unit and hope we could get it back in the box. While it ended up being a lot easier to take apart than it was to put together, be prepared for it to start falling apart as you take pieces out of connection. It seems to lose a lot of the stability any time you try to adjust it. However, once we realized that, we became more cautious of how we were doing it and it became a lot easier.I am personally happy with my purchase and would recommend to anyone needing alittle extra storage or temporary storage.

This rechargeable camping light is awesome! I absolutely love it. I like how portable it is. How quick and easy it works. Has dim, med and full setting as well as a red light setting. Takes two of the big 18650 rechargeable batteries. but also has a plug section for a cord if needed.My absolute favorite feature of this light is the emergency back up power source it offers. There is a standard USB connection and a microUSB port. You can charge your batteries with the microUSB port and charge your phone via the standard USB. Great for emergency situations or even if you have a kid that needs music or lights while sleeping. Received at a discounted rate for review. I love it, worth every penny. Will most likely purchase more of the same.

This stool is very portable and easy to store when folded up. To set up, you unfold the sides out until they click and lock into place. Once all sides have clicked and locked in place the stool is ready to be used. Took maybe 20 seconds. My husband is over 200lbs and stood on this stool and bounced up and down a little. There was very little if any give while bouncing and none by just standing on it. Folding it back in to make it flat was a little bit confusing, but it did fold back up easily and fast as well, maybe 40 seconds instead of 20 if that. Great product. Will use it a lot in my kitchen. Received at a discounted rate for review. I honestly like it. I am barely 5'4", so having a nice sturdy stool to reach the tops of my cupboards is great so I am not constantly having to ask someone else for help, climbing on  my counters or pulling chairs everywhere. I pull this out use it. fold it up and put i t back away. Very happy with my purchase and would recommend.

These bike lights are easy to assemble and stay secure on the bikes. The two valve cover lights have a cap to go over the threads when not in use. I like that feature. They simply screw on to the air valve and as the bike wheels turn the lights activate and light up creating a neat effect.The front and rear lights have a rubber strap to help secure the lights on the frame of the bike in the front or back. The strap has holes and one end has a T shaped section that pops into the hole and catches to secure the light. Received at a discounted rate for review.

This pill holder water bottle is extremely convenient. My mom has had some recent health related issues and has been put on a couple daily medications. While she is used to drinking and carrying around a bottle of water, remembering to take her pills hasn't become quite a habit yet. Having the pill holder connected to the bottle is great. It's a quick visual reminder and if your someone who is always carrying a water bottle, your meds are always with you. Received discount for review. I like it a lot. The only thing I personally don't like is that it is like a wide mouth, there is no mouth piece of any kind. The screw on lid is the only lid. I could see this being leaky after a while. As of now, there has been no leaking..

This camping lantern is lightweight. Battery operated. Needs 3 AAA batteries OR one 18650 Battery.  The battery compartment can hold the one 18650 Battery or you can use the included AAA battery holder. This camping light can be hung inside the tent, on a rope or really anywhere you can connect the dual sided carabiner clip they included in the packaging.There is a little red on/off button on the top side of the tent light. Simply press to turn on or off. There are 4 circles of lights inside the cover. When you first press the on button the very center circle of lights come on. This is the dim setting. The second time you press the button the next circle of lights light up and this is the medium setting. The third time you press the button the last two circles of light, come on and that is the full light system. The forth press of the button will turn the unit off.The light is bright and offers a good amount of illumination. Received discount for my honest opinion. I honestly like this camping light and will be using it a lot this summer. Would recommend to any camping enthusiast!

o,audio and data in a single cable . This cable supports 4kx2k max resolution up to 4 times the resolution of 1080p, it has more color spaces idealfor advanced HDTVs it widens the number of colors for 1.8 times more colors than standard RBG . This high speed cable with Ethernet is ideal for set-top boxes, blu-ray disc players, video game consoles, AV receivers, PS3, Xbox360 and other devices with HDMI plugs and with its 12 ft length it is handy when devices are a distance apart. The plugs fit nice and secure. They are not loose in anyway. Received a discount for review. The connection is clear and we had no issues with this cord. Great length.

This is by far one of the nicest Bluetooth speakers I have used thus far. Aside from the eye appealing bright colors, I purchased the green one for my daughter. I liked that it included a carabiner clip to make it easy for walks, hikes and activities..The silicone cover makes a great security feature as well as making it look nice. The silicone cover is probably close to 1/16th inch thickness and seems like a good shock absorption if the wireless speaker gets dropped or falls. This is definitely a nice added feature.The package included:1. Bluetooth / NFC Wireless Speaker Unit w/ Silicone cover and Carabiner clip2. USB Cable3. 1/8 inch Audio Cable4. Detailed instruction manual.This particular Bluetooth speaker can be used with NFC technology or via Bluetooth. I had never even heard of NFC technology. And if any of my other speakers had it, it wasn't obvious. The manual gives you step by step instructions on how to connect with the NFC as well as how to connect via Bluetooth.Charging time is roughly 3 hours to full charge. When we charged ours, it was only about 2 hours. I am not sure if it was because it already had a partial charge or if it was from using a fast port charging station.The sound quality is amazing! With or without the silicone cover. I honestly thought the cover would distort the sound at least a little. It did not at all so far. Actually it barely even distorts the volume let alone the clarity. I received this for review and I honestly love it. I like it better than my $400 wireless speaker. The size and convenience paired with excellent sound quality  and clarity in a little device is perfect to me.

I actually paid for this, unlike most of the other reviewers.  I've been mountain biking for 25 years, so I'm well versed in these pumps.There are basically two types of these things: ones without a little hose that pops out and ones with the hose.  The hose makes pumping these WAY easier, because it separates the pump (which you move around as you pump it) from the valve, but the hose adds weight and saves a lot of wear on the valve and the better the hose, the heavier it is.  The hose in any pump also is likely to be the first thing to fail.I had a plastic pump with no hose and the thing weighed only 3 ounces, this one weighs 5.5 without the bracket, and 5.4 if you remove the two adapters for filling balls and other inflatables that you probably will never use.  Most of the extra weight comes from what appears to be a very high quality (and therefor heavy) hose.I was really prepared not to like this one because of the extra weight, but the two extra ounces are probably worth it, especially if you are going to make this your only pump.  The reason is it's a lot of extra weight to carry around if you are only going to use it in an emergency.  With tire liners, I only seem to get a flat every two or three years, and about half of those are slow leaks that can be fixed at home using the floor pump.  So carrying around the extra two ounces for something I'll only use once every five years is probably overkill.  It's also twice the price of the plastic pumps and the plastic one I had lasted 15 years.  The likelihood any company will be around in 15 years to honor a warranty is low, and you could just buy a second half priced one and that gets you 30 years.I deflated a presta valve tire and it reinflated it relatively quickly, though the amount of air per pump is lower than others that are engineered to maximize that issue.  Note that it takes a couple of pumps to put enough pressure in the thing to push against the presta valve to open it, so you have to pump a few times at a fairly rapid clip or it won't add any air at all.  The design will also limit the amount of air you can pump into a presta valve tube.  70-80psi is probably about the best you are going to do, though I didn't test it.So this was a tough call on how to rate it.  Where it excels is a situation where you are going to beat the heck out of the pump, like keeping it in a backpack because the all plastic ones don't hold up too well in that situation.  So for a commuter like me, it works and I'm keeping it.  It's also a good choice if you aren't going to have a floor pump because of the hose.  However, if you want something to take on the trail that you'll mount to your bike and then remove, and you have a regular pump like a floor pump, you can save a few ounces and get a plastic one that maximizes the amount of air per pump.So I started with 5 stars for being well built.  I took off one star for the small amount of air per pump and extra weight.  I took off one star for the price being twice as high as others, and rate this one 3 stars.  Based on the price, I think I wished I had spent more time and bought something else that was lighter and cheaper, even if I had to replace it in 15 years on my own.

I have several of these, all operating trouble free.  However:1.  Cisco stopped selling these in May of 2012.  Search "spa2102 discontinued".  Although some companies bought tons and never used them, most of what you can get by now are used.  I've bought used ones without any problems.  I typically pay, with shipping, around $35.2.  The user interface is extremely technical.  These are designed for someone who knows what they are doing.  The average non technical person is going to be flummoxed.  Definitely not plug and play.  Those having intermittent problems and the like probably didn't configure them properly.3.  The one I bought in 2010 is still working just fine.  I have two others bought two years ago, used, also working fine.  But these are now 5-8 years old, and you shouldn't expect an infinite life out of them.4.  These have been replaced with a newer model SPA122 that's around the same price of these.  As far as I know, they are basically identical: same complex user interface.  Will probably last much longer than these.  See that "was this review helpful button" at the bottom?  Answer that Yes and then go buy the newer one if you are technically inclined.  Think of all the heartache I just saved you.

This is just way more than you need to spend on tire levers and it solves a problem no one has.  The things are freaking enormous.  They are the size of a butter knife, which means you won't be taking them anywhere.  They certainly reduce the effort required in using them, but my standard 3" tools never gave me any problem there, so they solve a problem no one has.They also have a sort of sandpaper type finish.  So they are, in my opinion, the wrong tool for the job because you can't slide them without damaging the rim.  So, great they solve a problem that doesn't exist and they prevent you from using them properly or taking them with you.  And for this, you get to spend three times as much money.So what should you get?  The Pedros levers come highly rated.  Same for the Park Tools levers.  The problem is that they are plastic and my experience is that old plastic levers break.  If you use tire liners, you rarely get a flat, so you want something you can keep in a drawer and use every 5 years.  After about 15 years, plastic levers get old and brittle and break.What would I recommend.  Get the Ice Toolz steel levers.  First of all, there are three of them and I always need all three.  Second, they are metal and will never break, though all metal levers run the risk of damaging rims.  However, those are smooth, not scratchy like these, so you can at least use them for their intended purpose.These would be great if you are elderly or female or don't have much hand strength and need the extra leverage an enormous tire lever like this provides.  They can also be used to demounting much thicker tires, like a small trailer tire or a hand truck pneumatic tire.  Otherwise, buy a set of three plastic ones from a reputable source to take with you on the trail and a set of three metal ones to keep at home to use as a backup when the plastic ones get old and break.  And you'll still have money left over to replace the plastic ones when they finally break (note the pedros have a lifetime warranty).  These are just way more money for too little benefit.

Those of you reading the lousy reviews should note that this product page is for MULTIPLE BLADES, and you have to select the right one.  All these reviewes selected the wrong blade and pouted about it.What you probably came here looking for is the 10178600 Eversharp 110/66 punch down blade, and Surprise, if you select it, that's what you'll get and not the blade everyone here is complaining about because they didn't select the right one from the drop down list next to the photo.Also known as the 10056500 on other web sites.Your Welcome.  Now press the YES button that says whether this review is helpful, so this one floats to the top.

It's the same length but much lighter and narrower.  In my case, one end slid into some slots, while the other end was held in place by a nut and a screw.  I unscrewed the one screw and this one, being the same length, slid right into place.HOWEVER, the wires are not long enough to reach the tombstone sockets.  So the next step is to cut the color coded wires and reinstall color for color.  There are two of each color: it doesn't matter which one of the same color is which, connect one yellow to a yellow wire and then connect the other yellow to the other yellow wire.  Only one to one, don't connect both yellow wires coming out of this thing together.  Now repeat for red and then for blue.  Code would require these connections to be made using wire nuts.  You'll need 8 18 ga. wire nuts.Why 8 when there are only three pairs of output wires and you can reuse the wire nuts for the input wires?  Because the input wires are ridiculously short, so you may need to extend them.  Where are you going to get extension wire?  Cut the black and white wires from the old one and use it as extension wire.  One could also twist the wires together and use electrical tape, but that wouldn't be to code.

Our local bike station, where people drop off bikes for the day and take the train, has this bike pump for people to use for free.  It's probably used at least 20 times per day, 200 days per year or 4000 uses a year.  The pump seems to last them 2-3 years, or about 10,000 pumps before they have to replace it.Assuming I use this twice a month, that's 24 pumps per year.  It should therefore last me 400 years.Good enough for me.

This is a comparison of the Amazon Basics Large Portable Speaker with the SHARKK® Boombox Wireless Bluetooth Speaker with 18+ Hour Battery Life and Award Winning Top Rated High-Def Sound Quality 10W Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker for iPhone iPad Samsung Computers both about the same price.Weight: The sameSize: Sharkk is about 70% of the size of the Amazon Basics product, which is much larger.User Interface: Amazon retains your last setting, Shark doesn't.  Kind of a minor annoyance.Power: Amazon uses it's own wall wart and cable.  Shark uses a Micro USB which is more widely available in various lengths.Sound: The Sharkk uses smaller speaker but has a well-designed passive radiator system that gives it a bit more bass.  It also has a 6 watt amplifier instead of the 5 watt amplifier of the Amazon product.  The larger speakers of the Amazon product provide clearer sound, but it struggles with the low notes that the Sharkk hits easily.  As a result, you can't really turn up the volume to make the amazon product louder, because it is limited by the bass response: it starts distorting before you can really blast it.  As a result, the Amazon product is no louder than the Sharkk.  The bass response difference is slight, but definitely noticeable.  I'd give the nod to the Sharkk because of the better bass response.  If the Amazon product had a passive radiator like the Sharkk, it would win hands down, but it doesn't.Quality: The Sharkk is a disaster.  I've owned three of them and they have all failed for the same reason: the auxiliary input jack has nothing holding it but the solder to the circuit board.  When you use it as you expect, portably, plugging the music source in and unplugging it, the jack will separate from the circuit board, making the product unuseable.  The most recent one failed in two weeks of owning it, and I'm extra careful with them because I know of the problem.  You can use bluetooth and skip the wiring problem as long as your devices have bluetooth, but the sound isn't that great.  I haven't owned the Amazon product long enough to determine if this is an issue, but if it is, I'll update my review if it is.Conclusion: The Sharkk is a better product because of it's superior sound and size, but quality problems of the Sharkk make the Amazon product the better choice.  The sound quality of the Amazon product is good, not great like the Sharkk.  If you want a small speaker that sits in a dorm room and never moves, you'll be happier with the Sharkk.  If you want something you can take with you, the Amazon product is possibly the better choice.  In either case, unplug the audio cable before transporting them.I paid for both products.  I did not receive anything for the review.

No problems at all with the set up.  Insert the disk and go, it's that simple.  Takes about 20 minutes to install, but will then run through about 2 hours of updates. For anyone wondering what this stuff is, it's just Alberger Process salt with a little bit of artificial butter flavoring and some dye mixed in.  Alberger Process results in salt that is flaky like snowflakes rather than grainy like grains of sand, so it sticks to the popcorn better than other types of salt and distributes more readily in oil.  Salt doesn't dissolve in oil, but flaky salt will suspend while grainy salt will sink to the bottom.The butter flavor adds taste without the hit in calories of real butter.  Butter flavor is *usually* just butter and maltodextrin (an artificial sugar used to extend the butter: i.e. to give it more volume by coating a lower calorie product, maltodextrin, with butter flavor, to provide nearly the same taste with lower calories overall).  Maltodextrin has some health effects like weight gain, but there wouldn't be that much of it in this product to cause much of a concern.  Note that I don't know for certain that this product contains maltodextrin, it may be flavored with nothing other than butter, with the salt itself used as the extender.If you want an alternative that doesn't have the artificial flavor and dye, search Amazon for "Fine Salt" and a bunch of them will pop  up, including Diamond Crystal Popcorn and Nut Salt.  That product has some Tricalcium Phosphate as an anti caking agent, but your teeth and bones are made if it, and there is some in cow's milk, so it doesn't seem harmful.  It's a bit more expensive than this stuff.
These labels have a good appearance, stick well and don't Jam the printer.  Just what yu want in a label.

This popcorn is cheap for a reason.  It's about the worst popcorn you can buy right now.  This stuff was the first branded popcorn, so people just keep buying it because it's all they know.  They buy it because their parents did.However, since then, others have come along with better popcorn.  Oville Reddinbacher started it when he developed a hybrid corn that produced better popcorn.  Since then, Snappy and Pop Secret have all developed a superior product.However, since there is only a limited amount of those other products, and a far higher demand, they are 3 times as expensive.Jolly time is just generic popcorn with someone's name on it.  It doesn't pop very forcefully, which means you'll get smaller popped kernels that don't explode with as much force, and therefore stick to the bottom of the pan and are more likely to burn.  When I pop this stuff, I end up with 1/3 smaller popped corn even though I started with the same amount of unpopped corn.If you're wondering why your popcorn tastes slightly burnt and isn't as big as movie theater popcorn, try any other brand.  You'll never go back.

I have gotten 3 of these, and 3 out of 3 have failed.  I bought the first version when there were literally 2 product reviews, a few years ago.  Loved the product.  You really need to use a jack to get the most out of it, and that's how I've been using it.However, the first one failed.  There is a HUGE design flaw for a portable speaker that you'll keep connecting and disconnecting every time you use it: the jack is not mounted to anything, the solder is the only thing holding it on so ultimately, the solder joint fails and the whole thing won't work.  I kept resoldering it and kept it going.  I really like it a lot so I keep repairing it.I came on here and provided a review stating all of this, and the company was nice enough to send me another one, a newer version.  The newer version is more powerful and even better than the original version.  Just the perfect speaker when I thought you really couldn't get any better.  But that one also failed, almost immediately, for the very same reason.  So I had two, one was kept in reserve for when the other one failed, and then the failed one would get repaired, and back and forth.  Again I resoldered the newer one and the older one and kept it going, but the jack finally ripped the leads off the circuit board so it cannot be resoldered.Down to one, continuously repairing it until an accident left it inoperable.  Not the product's fault.So I ordered a *third* one, and within two weeks: same problem.  The jack is coming off.This is just the most fantastic speaker ever, I just can't say enough good things about the sound quality, but not if it breaks every few weeks.  The design flaw is something that I finally just gave up on, and I'm looking at a different model.So now I have three of these, and all of them have failed repeatedly due to the same problem.  I really like the sound quality, but I can't live with the build quality any longer.

I think a lot of supplements are voodoo.  Most people don't really need them.  However, I was having trouble in terms of mental clarity and some mild depression after the loss of my 21 year old cat.  I saw this product (though not from this seller) being promoted in a book on aging and decided to try it.  I started with just one dose per day and when I didn't get any side effects, increased it to two doses per day.It took two days before I felt any difference at all, and the difference is small, but definitely noticeable.  Mental clarity went up for sure and my mood lightened a little.  Now I'm only spending 5 cents or so per dose, so it's not like I expected miracles, but it did way better than I expected.  I normally have fairly stressful dreams and woke up on my 4th day after starting this stuff and instantly realized I had my first really *good* dream in years.  I mean years.  And it was so vivid that I had to question whether it had been a dream.  That just doesn't happen to me.Was it a placebo?  Possibly, but if so, it was worth every penny.  I'm a bit more alert and find it a bit easier to think clearly.  I have not found it helpful in helping me sleep better or longer.  It's not going to make you 20 again, but it seems to be able to erase about a decade in terms of mental alertness, so I can highly recommend it.

I bought one pair and used them to replace the most worn pads, the front pads.  They initially seemed mch better, but not so much better that I would buy another pair until the back pads wore out.Who knew that they get a lot better after they've been broken in?  Three weeks after I installed them, a car came charging out of a driveway, right into my path.  Both brakes were applied to maximum force.  The rear brakes stopped about as well as you would expect: stopping distance would have been about 10 feet.  The Kool Stops locked the front wheels instantly: I was lucky I didn't fly over the top, because the rear wheels came off the ground.  The front wheel simply stopped instantly.I came back here to buy another pair for the back brakes!  Best brakes I've ever experienced.  Surprised the heck out of me

This is not a light you can see by, it's purpose is to be seen.  The corner LEDs give nearly 180 degree visibility and it is VERY bright for this purpose.  A big benefit is its light weight.  I have it hooked to my helmet, so weight is important.  The strap wraps around just about anything, so you can use it wherever you want.The downside is that none of the USB rechargeable lights made by any manufacturer is actually waterproof.  To protect mine, I slip a sandwich baggie over it and bunch it up where the light meets the strap.  Then I double up a rubber band to hold the baggie in place.  It keeps it dry enough to keep working, but it's of course a bit of a pain to have to remember to do it and to actually do it every time it rains.  But I do, and it's about the best thing I could find.Use it if you want a light weight light.  Otherwise, there are better options.

I've tried others with little success.  This is the only one that works.  It will hold for about 8 months and then fail, but by then it will be scratched up enough that you'll want to replace it anyway. You get three, so you'll have a two year supply.

There is a thick side and a thin side.  Keep the thick side DOWN and it won't leak.  The reviews from people saying it leaks didn't notice it (neither did I, at first).  It doesn't leak at all, even if the pan isn't very hot.However, don't touch the end of the handle with your bare hands.  It is surrounded by metal and the metal gets very hot. This is a very sturdy hanging rack.  It does require assembly, but assembly takes about ten seconds, you just twist the main bar until it snaps into place, there's no tools and anyone can do it.  You can't see it but the hangar in the back is square, it just hangs over any standard door.  There's no screws to hold it in place.Some people have mentioned you can use both the front bar and the sides, but that's only the case if you are using men's pants hangars.  A standard hangar will let you use the front bar OR the sides, but not both.  If you use the sides, the hangars hang halfway out from each side and if you use the front bar, they hang halfway out from that.I've had 6 pair of wet jeans on the thing and it just laughs at the weight.  My doors are hollow, but it's not a problem.12 shirts hang from the front OR the sides.  I tend to use the sides because using the front bar means everything sticks way out from the door.  The wavy sides keep everything spaced apart, which is ideal for use as a drying rack.  I have it centered on the door and the hangars come just about an inch past each side of the door, not really visible.Now for the downsides.1.  The thing is metal and it's going to scratch the door when you put it on or take it off.  Do what I did, take some sticky back felt and put it on the front and back of the square hangar.  Don't put it on the underside of the top because of #2, below.2.  The metal hangar is thick.  It's about 3/16" thick.  That makes it sturdy, but I didn't have a single door that closed on it.  That means it won't work for most bathroom doors, which need to close.  I put it on a closet door that I never close.This thing is really excellent quality, but just don't expect to close the door its on.

I tried the best Sony and it was terrible.  Sony has sacrificed sound quality as much as possible in order to squeeze every drop out of the battery, and the results are terrible.This radio, on the other hand is a joy to listen to.  Sound quality is as good as you can get from FM.Just a helpful hint for those people complaining about the included earbuds, a serious listener throws included earbuds in the trash, without even trying them.  Apple does the same thing: they just include cheap terrible ones so you can listen to it right away if you don't have anything else lying around but no one expects them to sound anything but terrible or last more than a week.  Throw them away and get something decent.The sound quality of a radio is really a function of how much power it uses.  These use two AA batteries, a rarity.  That means it has the power to pack a punch.  Stay away from single battery units (i.e. Sony) - they have no punch and listening to music on them is boring (if you are looking for talk radio or ball games, any radio will do).  This radio is the real deal if you like music sound quality.  FM radio cannot deliver high quality, but this is as good as it gets.  I'm so happy that at least one company still makes something that's actually nice to listen to.

This was one of the three items I've bought on Amazon that I ended up returning in over 12 years.  The reviews make it sound better than it is.Like many of you, I had an old style Sony FM radio that I purchased many years ago that needed to be replaced.  In my case, the volume control knob had fallen off, but at a level that worked for at least one setting, so I thought it might be time to replace it.  I was hoping that in ten years, the reception might have improved.I looked at some of the reviews and  What Sony appears to have done is to have decided that battery life matters more than sound quality, and so many of their newer radios will last forever on one AAA battery, but to do that they engineered the sound to make the battery last as long as possible.  The way they did it was to reduce the dynamic range, so that the loudest sounds are not much different from the least loud sounds.  The result is music that sounds dull and lifeless.  The notes are all there, but the punch is completely, and I mean completely, gone.In my case, I still had the old radio, so I was able to compare them.  The reception on this unit is improved, but slightly and is nothing to write home about.  You'll barely notice the difference.  But the music is really, really bland.So I think the best advice is to steer clear of the "45 hours on one AAA" battery models and go for the double AAA or AA models.  My old one only lasts about 8 hours on two AAAs, but the sound quality makes it totally worth the battery life reduction.  I use rechargeables, so it doesn't really cost em any more.I haven't yet found one I'm willing to buy, but when I do, I'll be back to let you know how it worked out.Edit: Found the ideal radio.  The Sangean DT-200X FM-Stereo AM/FM Digital Tuning Personal Receiver.  Gets fantastic reception, better than this Sony and better than anything I've ever had, long battery life from 2 AA batteries and sounds terrific, better than the old school radios I thought I'd never be able to replace.

Your USB device that you want to plug into this has a male plug.  That plug draws power to allow your USB device to work.This adapter will not supply any power because the round jack that this device plugs into doesn't supply any power either.  The USB connection will be made, but your USB device will not be powered on, and so it will not work.What device could this adapter work for?  Something completely passive.  That means a plain microphone (no noise cancelling mics or electret) and plain headphones (again, no noise canceling).  Those don't use any power - they just need the signal this device, in theory, provides.  There will be no power supplied at the USB plug, so any USB device that does anything that requires power (which is basically everything else I can think of) will never power on.It would be like buying an adapter that has an electric plug on one end and a hose adapter on the other end: plug your vacuum cleaner into your faucet!  Your vacuum cleaner will never power on so it will never work.

This arrived to me in perfect shape.  It had no bent pins or anything, because it was packaged with the pins in foam.It's possible to connect it so that the labels are backwards.  To connect it so that the labels read correctly, orient the label on this device so that the pins marked 5V of this device are sitting in the same side as the corner of the Pi nearest the GPIO pins.  That is, if the corner of the Pi nearest the GPIO are on the right side of the GPIO, the label of this device that says 5V should also be on the right side.  This device should be nearest you, the Pi should be farther away from you, and if you orient right to right or left to left as the sentence above, plug in the ribbon cable to the GPIO and to this device, which is now properly oriented.  It will be correctly installed.  See the crude drawing below.---------------------------.....................................|.....................................|..............Pi....................|..................GPIO............|---------------------------...............|..Ribbon..|...............|..Cable ...|...............|.............|...............--------------..............|..................|..............|..................|..............|.........5V.5V.|...............--------------Amazon, it's fine.  The only complaint I have about it is that it's wider than necessary, so it takes up more room on the breadboard than it really needs.

These products consist of two clamps, one for the phone and one for the bike, and an adjustable knuckle connecting the two clamps that you adjust and tighten in place.  There is a limited range of tubes you can clamp around, this one is really optimized for bike handlebars.  You can't really clamp it to many other parts of the bike.  That wouldn't be a problem, but the knuckle is not all that adjustable, so you can sometimes get stuck if you want to use this as a mount for a bike cam.  It's passable, but you may find yourself making compromises.  The clamp for the phone is surprisingly strong, but I wouldn't trust it under all circumstances.  That problem is easily solved with a rubber band around the camera and the back plate of this device.All in all, I'm happy with what I got for the price.  Better, but for three times the price, is the GreatShield Clip-Grip Handlebar Bike Mount Holder for iPhones, samsung galaxy, htc smartphones, GPS Devices and More.  I have them both and I'm happier with that one.  But for this price, I thought it was a very good deal.

I have a bike mount for my Galaxy S3.  The things I don't like about that other one (not this one) is it's not very adjustable, doesn't clamp onto a large range of tubes, and the clamp for the phone is good but not great.  I bought this to use as a rear camera mount for an older smart phone and it's superior to my other one in every way.It can clamp around a tube between 1/2" and 1.5".  The clamp for the camera is like a strong chip clip and I'm not remotely worried about the phone falling out.  It has rubber grips where the clamp meets the phone so it won't scratch it, though you'll have to avoid the side buttons.  The two clamps are coupled by an adjustable knuckle that you move around and then tighten in place, which is much more flexible than my other one, providing a much greater range of mounting options.This is certainly more expensive than the others, my Galaxy one was $3, but it's really worth it. And I can use it with any phone.

It lasts for about 3 hours.  Then, doing nothing but sitting there, you start to smell.Notice my name, how it says "See all my reviews?"  Now look at all the 5 star reviews gushing about this product.  Notice that's their only review, as if the only product they ever wanted to review was deodorant?Ignore the fake reviews, this stuff is terrible.  It doesn't work.  Every other deodorant I've ever tried has worked.  The reason is the active ingredient is too weak.  At 14%, it won't do much.  Arm and Hammer has 19% of the same stuff. These put out what appears to be about 15 watts equivalent of light and use 2 watts of electricity according to my Kil-O-Watt.  That may be rounded from 1.5, but assuming it's really 2, that means you can get 500 hours out of each one for a killowatt of electricity, which generally costs about 10-13 cents.  At an average of 12 hours per day, it means each one will cost you about eight to ten cents per month to operate.  Being solid state, you can expect them to last 5-10 years.  So they cost about $2 per year in lamp costs plus electricity, so I thought it was a worthy purchase.I use these in the hallways of a small office building and if I can shut my main lights off an hour earlier than I would otherwise, but still allow the tenants to leave safely, I save about 9 kilowatts per month, about $11 per year, so net, I save about $7 per year with two of these lights.

My S3 is a great phone, but I chew through the battery in about 8 hours, requiring a mid day recharge.  Enter this bad boy, I can run for over three days without charging.  Have an all day conference call?  This battery will laugh at your conference call.  Want to video your all day city tour without a charger?  Not a problem.It's basically a replacement S3 battery attached to another battery that takes up the lower 2/3 of your phone.  To hold the behemoth in place, they supply a cover that you use instead of your S3 cover, which is surprisingly easy to remove.  The cover fits over the phone and holds the battery in place, but allows full use of the camera without interference. Ingenious!Of course it makes your phone 3+ times as thick, and 3 times as heavy but it still fits comfortably in your pocket and is comfortable to hold so who cares.  It charges fully overnight.  When you don't need it, pull it out after you finished charging it and use your regular battery.  When I put it back in after a month of non use, this guy is still 99% charged.It also makes a great spare, for times you forget to charge your battery, so I keep this one charged before I put it away.This is quite possibly the best product I've ever got.  It does what it was designed to do as elegantly as possible.  Buy it, you won't regret it.
We've used this thing every day for the last 7 years.  Never jammed, goes through stacks of paper like butter.

Search for Swingline Heavy-duty Stapler - Heavy Duty Stapler - 160 Sheets Capacity - 1/4", 3/8", 1/2", 3/4" Staple Size - Platinum, that's the one you want: and probably the one you are looking to replace.  That one lasts forever.  This is the newer model and is terrible.

I assume the dosage is being kept secret because no one wants you to know these are 200mg tablets.  There are 120 of them, but the dosage listed is 400mg, so you take two tablets to get 400mg.Yes, the people stating that the tablets are 400mg are wrong: they don't know how to read a label because the label plainly states that there are two tablets required to get 400mg.In any event, I posted a photo of the back of the label so that the secret mystery dosage per tablet could be exposed.  It's 200mg.  And after I did this, they finally posted all the photos of the product (before I posted my review, there was one photo of the front only, with the number of tablets blacked out).The ingredients used in this brand are of a higher quality than other brands, for example, no polyethylene glycol, so I think in the end it is worth the higher price.

DON'T PLUG IT IN!1.  First download the software from the web site on the package, install the software.  It takes a while to install.  Do not plug the device in when you install.2.  Reboot your system, even if it doesn't ask you to.  Do not plug in the device.  Wait for your system to come up fully.3.  NOW plug in the device.  More software will install.It works fine and I've had no software issues or reboots on windows 7.I previously installed the Anker Uspeed Superspeed USB 3.0 PCI-E Express Card with 4 USB 3.0 Ports and 5V 4-Pin Power Connector for Desktops [one step to upgrade your PC to USB3.0], and have plugged this device into one of the USB 3.0 ports from that card.  Note that it comes with all power connectors, you don't need a separate connector.  It was just as effortless, but you do need to open your computer. Best approach is to order that card first, after that's installed, order this one.  That will give you the maximum time to make sure this one is working without the USB card install eating it's way to your return period for this product.The only downside is that the software to adjust the color and such is nonexistent.  Your monitor is the only way to adjust.  Probably not recommended for high end graphics work unless there is some other program that will work with this card to adjust it.

This product is the printer only.  To print stamps on it, you have to use the Dymo Stamps program.  To use that program, they require you to use labels that they sell for about 9 cents per stamp each.  Generic labels won't work because you need an activation code on the labels.  The generic labels themselves retail for a penny, so you are basically paying them 8 cents per stamp.We use about 12 stamps per week, so the fee is going to be about $4 per month.  If that's worth it, this is the product for you.  If you send more than 25 pieces of mail, you can buy an account for $9.95 per month that lets you use the generic stamps.You can buy stamps online at usps.gov and they will deliver them to your door for free.

I've gotten these from the dentist for $300 each.  This product is every bit as good as those.Just follow the directions and it fits as well as the ones from my dentist.  Do you see all the comments from people saying it isn't as good?  Those are dentists.  Ignore them.Here's what I did.First, practice putting it in your mouth on your upper teeth, push your tongue on it to push it up on your teeth and suck, hard, to get the air out of it and mold it to your teeth.  Got it?  Now take it out and set it aside.I have a small mouth, so I trimmed the back on the line they provide for that purpose.  It made it exactly the same size as the one I got from the dentist.  When you trim it, round the corners.  That means start parallel to the long sides and turn the scissors to make a little quarter circle and then cut the rest of the way.  When you reach the other side, round that too.  Do both ends.Then I put about 2/3 of a cup of water in a coffee mug.  I microwaved it for about 1:45 until it was at a full boil.  Note, I did NOT put the product in the cup while I was microwaving it.  Do you see all the people who said the thing turned into a melted clump?  That's what they did, they microwaved the product with the water.  Don't do that.  Leave the product OUT and just microwave the water.Next, using the handy little tab attached to the front, dunk the product into the water and count to ten.Shake the water off -  the product won't even be remotely hot, so don't worry, put it into your mouth on the upper teeth and push it with your tongue and suck, just like you did for practice.  Count to twenty.Pull it out, run it under cold water for five seconds and you're done.  You just saved yourself a trip to the dentist and $300.Buy denture cleaner to clean it.  The cheap fizzy tabs, generic quality, are fine.They give you a cool little holder.  If you don't need the holder, buy a denture cleaner holder and then buy the version that comes as an add on product from amazon (you have to buy something else for them to ship it to you).  That is about $8 cheaper but doesn't have the holder.  This holder has air slots to dry it.  I just left the denture cleaner holder open and it dries just as fast.  This holder is good for travel, so it doesn't hurt to have one.

This is not a super high security lock.  It's better than a cable (anything is better than a cable) and better than most chains.  It's fairly light weight so it's a decent trade off.  But it's bigger than necessary and that makes it easy to defeat.  U locks take some effort to defeat, and if you aren't leaving your bike outside overnight, this is probably a decent choice.

Did your vet prescribe Famotidine?  He's probably selling it to you in a solution that you have to fight to give your pet.  And he's charging you about ten times the price of these tablets.Each tablet is 20Mg, figure out the strength from the bottle, which will be in mg/Ml, and then measure the amount you've been giving your pet (ue a table spoon or teaspoon measure and then convert in your friendly search engine.  Get a pill grinder and grind away.And I avoid the fight with my cat by just mixing it directly into the can of cat food and adding a little water.  The extra strength is more concentrated so you need less for the same amount of medicine, making it less likely to be detected by your pet.

I have virtually every new model of bike light on the market today, and this is the one I use.Pros:-Very well built.  The battery slot is far superior to the battery slots of other lights - better constructed.  The lens has a gasket to keep water out.  Solidly built and will last for years.-Very bright.  Among the brightest lights on the market, good side to side visibility too.  A lot of lights give you brightness in a narrowly focused beam, -- not this one. It's bright and dispersed.-Good battery life.  I only use rechargeables and it's giving more than 30 hours per charge on 2-AAA Eneloops.-Best design on the market. As mentioned, the light pattern is disbursed exceptionally well, yet brightness is preserved.Cons:-The switch can turn the light on accidentally.  This is not a light you throw in a backpack and expect it to be fully powered.-Flash pattern.  This is the only real complaint I have with the light: the flash pattern is steady and unvaried.  This can invite drunk/high drivers to get fixated by the pattern and run into the bike.  The solution I use is to use two of them.  Each one has a slightly different flash speed than the other, so the pattern of both of them randomizes and prevents the "moth effect".  They are so cheap, buying two is still very inexpensive and provides a simply massive amount of light.  If you can't buy two, I would advise to leave it on steady, though that will impact the battery life.I ride in traffic in San Francisco, the city with one of the highest bike fatalities in the US.  These lights are a dream come true for me.  The ultimate test is how far away the cars pass you.  They are giving me a wide berth.  Buy two of these, you'll never regret it.  These lights are **the best on the market today**: the fact that they are also one of the most inexpensive is simply fantastic.

This is 5 of the red forms 1096 and ZERO 1099s.  I can't imagine who would need this.  I got them and realized I ordered the wrong item and these went in the trash, as the 1099 forms always come with 1096s.Buy these and you'll throw them in the trash like I did.

Turn it over when you get it and check the expiration date.  I wish I had.I went back and checked the order date: December 2011.  Expiration date: January 2011.  It had been expired for nearly a year when shipped.  That's why you see all these people complaining about the strength.  They were shipping product that had long since expired.I won't be ordering from them again.
